column2: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Bill Virdon, a rookie infielder, drove in Ken Boyer with the deciding run after two were out in the tenth to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 verdict over the Cincinnati Redlegs today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 14 -- Pakistan's ninth year of independence begins tomorrow under a Prime Minister who never wanted the post.
It may not be too late this season to institute a water safety program along the ocean front.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Air Force Association started a campaign today for the posthumous award of the rank of General of the Air Force to William (Billy) Mitchell, advocate of air power.
The Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., of New York said yesterday a poll it conducted showed that if Governor Harriman were running for re-election today he would receive 59 per cent of the vote.
The past week in the charter market was described as "routine,'' with average volume and no sharp rate changes.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- Thirty-two school-boys and five police escorts were killed when Communist rebels dynamited a passenger bus in the Tavoy tin-mining region near the Burmese-Thailand border, according to a report received here today.

The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday a basic reorganization of its marketing program, with the promotion of two executives and the addition of three new specialists in the textile merchandising program.

Before the public power advocates get a lot of political steam engendered in their claim that the public interest is being "sabotaged" by the Federal Power Commission's decision to authorize the Idaho Power Company to build three dams in the Hells Canyon area between Idaho and Oregon, the people should become aware of these facts:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The United States will use trade fairs in the next several months to tell Asians how its science and industry can help them raise their standards of living.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Postal pay and highway bills prompted the greatest flow of mail to members during the first session of the eighty-fourth Congress.

Government, and especially local government, is often likened to housekeeping. New York begins in August each year the serious contemplation of what it needs to build and buy, in the way of permanent improvements, in the approaching calendar year. The preliminaries actually begin much earlier, but in mid-August the City Planning Commission hears departments present their arguments and explanations.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Thirteen new poliomyelitis cases were reported today in Boston, bringing the city's case load so far this year to 435.
PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 14 -- Dr. Morgan, who was 78 years old, had been living at 47 Howthorne Avenue, Princeton, since his retirement in 1950.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Betty Mullen won the 100meter butterfly championship at the women's national American Athletic Union swimming and diving meet today in world record time. The race was so close that the second and third place finishers also bettered the recognized world mark.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The grain markets had a lot of bearish news developments last week. The coarse grains especially face the prospect of huge crops. August crop forecasts, both of Government and private surveys, were extremely optimistic. This and the return to more normal weather throughout the country deprived the commodity markets of much support.
Cuban politics has a unique quality; it is sui generis. Things seem to happen in Cuba that cannot happen anywhere else. The experts, always prepared for the unpredictable, are rarely disappointed.
MOSCOW, Aug. 14 -- What does the Soviet man in the street think about the new look in East-West relations?
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The United States won the British-American cup contests for yachts of the six-meter international class today, four victories to none.

Walnut Manor, a twenty-acre estate with an interesting history in Tenafly, N. J., has been sold by Mrs. Ernest J. Heppenheimer for more than $11,000 an acre. This is said to be the highest price ever paid for residentially zoned realty in Bergen County.

The term of office of Justice Hubert T. Delany of the Domestic Relations Court of the City of New York will expire on Aug. 31, and the term of Justice Justine Wise Polier, on the same bench, will end on Sept. 13. Both these justices have served with distinction and richly deserve reappointment by Mayor Wagner.

THERE'S nothing like living with plain painted walls for a while to make a decorative wall covering seem the height of luxury. But coordinating the design and colors of fabrics with wallpaper is a thorny problem.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, hailed today the "remarkable growth" of the Federal -state unemployment insurance program. But he said it still was not good enough.

In the course of his admirable presidential address before the international conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy the distinguished Indian physicist Homi J. Bhabha predicted that within two decades a way would be found of taming the energy of fusion, that is the energy that makes the hydrogen bomb the most terrible of weapons.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Communist Albania today protested that Greece had adopted an "openly opposite attitude" toward her bid for patching up diplomatic relations between the two countries.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies said today Australia would withhold most-favored-nation treatment from Japan, newest member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox put together a single, two sacrifices and an infield out in the eighth inning today to edge the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 4. Billy Pierce gained his first victory over a Detroit team in two years.

Plans for altering a Lenox Hill house for occupancy by the buyer were announced as the building at 255 East Seventy-eighth Street was sold by the Lenox Hill Corporation to Elizabeth B. Allard. Alexander Schiffer and Gilbert Lewis were the brokers.
The Du Mont television network, which has curtailed its program schedule drastically in recent months, will soon be down to one program a week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Eisenhower signed today legislation to take control of this city's strike-bound transit system from Louis E. Wolfson, the Florida financier.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 UP) -- Julius Boros, aided by a "gift" par on the seventieth hole when his tee shot caromed from a mass of spectators to the green, today won the "world" title and golf's biggest pay-off with a seventy-two-hole total Of 281 -- seven under par.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 14 -- The California State Theatrical Federation posed today the possibility of a "nation-wide battle by organized labor against runaway production in foreign countries of filmed television commercials."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Twelve Republican Senators labeled today the Democratic-controlled Congress the "let's-put-it-off session" and "the Congress of procrastination."

CAIRO, Aug. 14 -- Egypt is in the middle of a revolution under way since King Farouk was deposed by an officers' coup d'etat three years ago. But no one can yet define its ideology or predict an ultimate course. Like the river Nile it flows through a great political desert.
After selected gains in the early dealings, stock prices yesterday developed a sagging tendency. They closed irregularly lower in the slowest trading since mid-January, 1954.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Columbia Records has founded a "record-of-the-month" club. The company announced yesterday it had notified 6,200 dealers to this effect.
ATLANTA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Georgia State Board of Education rescinded today its resolutions aimed at teachers who favor racial integration of classes in public schools.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 15 -- Union leaders at the Kennecott Copper Corporation division in Ray, Ariz., today blocked the return of workers to company mines and mills in Utah, Nevada and New Mexico. Successful contract negotiations had been carried out in last-named three states.

A unanimous decision to uphold the denial of a Production Code Administration seal of approval to the film "I Am a Camera" was made yesterday by the board of directors of the Motion Picture Association of America.
The following booklet, published recently, may be of interest to parents:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The contract bridge team of Samuel M. Stayman, Lee Hazen, Richard Kahn and Myron Field, all of New York with Charles J. Solomon of Philadelphia, this afternoon won its third straight match. It now leads a field of eight finalist teams in the round-robin contest for the 1955 masters team of four championship.
NEW CASTLE, Ind., Aug 15 (AP) -- About 100 to 150 men rushed inside the gates at Perfect Circle's foundry here this morning and turned over four automobiles.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- What was it someone once said about all work and no play? That goes, too, for the fellows who follow the fortunes of the major league baseball clubs in the daily press. A baseball writer has to have some fun too, but what happened here today was ridiculous.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I O., said last night it had no knowledge of "job action" by Brooklyn bus drivers, but ordered the men to stop it anyway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare enunciated today the principle that social legislation cannot be static.

Rubber prices declined about 1 1/2 cents a pound yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in the second heaviest trading since World War II. The 5,840 tons traded compared with 7,270 on July 29. Final quotations were off 140 to 155 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

A Brooklyn girl who tied for the top mark in the state's first scholarship awards for nursing education was congratulated yesterday at the Board of Education. She is Miss Miriam R. Gellert of 871 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, a graduate of Midwood High School in that borough.
Motion-picture rights to two properties for theatrical release have been acquired by Demby Productions, Inc., producers of live and filmed television programs.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Paced by Louise Brough, the Wimbledon champion, the United States won the Wightman Cup for the nineteenth straight time as the series with Great Britain ended today on the grass courts of the Westchester Country Club.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The auto production pace has eased, but still is relatively high.

The Quinby Plan for accumulating common stock added American Telephone and Telegraph Company and General Electric Company yesterday to the roster of leading companies figuring in the services of the Rochester investment company.
Neal Rivers, 156, of Niagara Falls, N. Y., gained an unanimous decision over Jimmy King, 154 1/2, of Birmingham, Ala., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
News that the United States is about to embark on a Buck Rogers era of man-made satellites has been coupled with a flint-lock policy of sharing information gained from the venture with Russia.

SOME ten years before the end of the fourteenth century public affairs in western Christendom were jogging along much as usual. In England the young Richard II, who not long before had suppressed a peasant revolution, did not yet suspect that a usurper would rob him of his throne and his life. In France Charles VI had not yet succumbed to his first, comparatively short spell of insanity.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Five players were tied for the lead today in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation. Each had a score of 6 -- 1 after seven rounds of play.

Alvin Dark, the Giants' captain and shortstop, is going to be on the sidelines for four weeks. Officials of the New York club made the announcement yesterday when it was discovered the star infielder was suffering from a fractured rib.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today the Administration's new cotton export policy does not "come to grips with our serious surplus problem."

Relaxation in the rationing of British newspapers after fifteen years of control has at last been announced for next year. After so many years on so thin a diet, the newspapers and the British public will be faced with many problems, although the result is bound to be good.

A stitch in time may save the appearance of your luggage. Directions recently issued by the Pfaff Sewing Institute suggest a heavy, durable, pre-shrunk cotton or linen fabric as a cover for worn suitcases or hatboxes.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- A 27-year-old Egyptian won an international cross-Channel swimming race today. In a driving finish he spurted ahead of an American entry who had kept pace with him much of the way.

A former convict escaped yesterday from the West Twentieth Street police station. He had been taken there for questioning in a vice case involving two teen-age girls. He fled through a second-floor washroom window while high police officials were interrogating civilians and several patrolmen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department announced today that it had agreed with the Republic of Korea to set the exchange rate of Korean hwan at 500 to $1.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 15 -- Premier Moshe Sharett tendered the resignation of his Government today to President Izhak Ben-Zvi as the newly elected third Knesset (Parliament) convened here.

THE Washington Square chamber music concerts continue to draw. Last night the third in this summer's series attracted 3,800 to the square. Besides engulfing the 500 folding chairs in the center the audience overflowed onto the lawns.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Australia qualified today to play the United States for the Davis Cup in the challenge round at Forest Hills Aug. 26 to 28.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- England, all out for 151, today dismissed South Africa for 112 to gain a first-innings lead of 39 at the close of the second day's play in the fifth and final test cricket match at The Oval. The teams are tied in the series with two victories each.

In its first change of ownership in thirty-five years, the four-story residential building at 51 West Ninth Street was sold by Lelia Dame for cash to Arthur E. Buchwald. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., and the Grenvil Realty Company were the brokers.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, the United States Davis Cup team star who has been sidelined for two weeks with a shoulder injury, displayed his old-time power today. He teamed with Vic Seixas to gain an easy first-round victory in the seventy-fifth national doubles tennis tournament at Longwood.
Lucien Hugh Cullen has been elected president of the newly formed Cullen Minerals Corporation, San Antonio, Tex. Mr. Cullen had been president of the Atomic Power Uranium Corporation.

Wall Street long has had its own special definition of "good news." Yesterday, for instance, the directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared a dividend of $1.50 a common share as the interim payment for the third quarter. Dividends of $1.25 were paid in each of the first and second quarters of this year.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 -Great Lakes vessels hauled 3,152.672 tons of ore in the week ended today, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.. This was the largest amount moved in any seven-day period this season.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities today opposed a pending agreement between the New York, New Haven and Hartford, the Boston and Maine and the Delaware and Hudson Railroads relating to joint handling of freight.

GRAND PRE, N. S., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Thousands of Acadians, descendants of French settlers expelled from their homes and dispersed across North America 200 years ago, returned to the land of their ancestors today.

WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Top-seeded Althea Gibson of New York today opened the final phase of the American Tennis Association national tournament here with an easy victory over Cleveland's Lovelene House.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Aug. 14--When this correspondent's family crossed over from the Arab-held Old City of Jerusalem into the Israeli sector one of the boys threw a doll belonging to one of his sisters from the car window in No Man's Land at the Mandelbaum Gate. Neither the Jordanians nor the Israelis could retrieve it.

The veil of secrecy that surrounds cases arising out of the Government's personnel security program is the major reason why its occasional inadequacies, injustices and even downright absurdities are not better known to the general public.
Organized labor broke even here last week in its drive for the guaranteed annual wage.
TOKYO, Aug. 15 -- North Korea has proposed that two conferences be called as soon as possible to discuss unification of the divided Korean peninsula.
ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 15--The boom in the economy can get out of hand and bring on a bust, Dean W. I. Myers of the College of Agriculture at Cornell University, warned today.
LARCHMONT. N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Fred Hibberd Jr. of the American Yacht Club, Rye, became the Long Island Sound junior sailing champion after a five-race marathon session off Larchmont Y. C. today.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 15 -- Members of the Disabled American Veterans opened their thirty-fourth annual national convention here today.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- New varieties of high yielding hardy crop plants can be created by subjecting seeds to atomic radiation. Cereals have proved particularly responsive to this treatment.

YONKERS, Aug. 15 -- A ten-horse field of 3-year-olds, headed by Quick Chief, was named today for the $71,000 William H. Cane Futurity Pace at Yonkers Raceway on Thursday night. The winner's share will be $35,164 if all ten start.
Half-year sales and earnings of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation set company post-war highs for any six-month period, according to the semi-annual figures released today.

COLUMBIA FALLS, Mont., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A $65,000,000 primary aluminum plant was formally opened here today by the Anaconda Aluminum Company, first new concern to enter the field in this country since 1946.

Manufacturers booked sizable orders yesterday at the fiftieth annual convention and trade show of the American National Retail Jewelers Association. The five-day show opened Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- "Our Miss Brooks," the Columbia Broadcasting System television series, will undergo considerable revision in story content and performers starting on Oct. 14.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15--Another armed plot against President Juan D. Peron and his Government has been foiled, the Federal police announced today.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Nuclear scientists of the world are going to discuss the setting up of an international agency to study the effects of atomic radiation on man, a Danish geneticist announced today.
New York, Chicago and Washington were the big three in air traffic last year, both for number of aircraft departures and number of passengers handled.

Marc Daniels, who earned unstinted praise last season from the New York theatre critics for his direction of "Phoenix '55," has been engaged by Alexander H. Cohen to stage the forthcoming untitled comedy by Max Wilk.

Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, announced last night an impending investigation of Communist infiltration in high government circles.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The British Cabinet met today for the first time since Parliament adjourned at the end of July.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in the first six months of 1955 achieved the highest sales and earnings for any half-year in its history, P. W. Litchfield, board chairman, reported yesterday to stockholders.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 115 -- It became increasingly evident here today that the withdrawal of the reigning Sultan of Morocco was now more than ever merely a matter of time.

WALLA WALLA, Wash., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Rebellious convicts at Washington State Penitentiary grudgingly gave up their hostages and a cache of knives and razors today. A six-hour uprising was broken up by tear gas and telephone persuasion.

It is apparent that President Eisenhower will and should be reelected in 1956. Yet if Adlai Stevenson is nominated on the Democratic ticket only to be defeated, it would crush forever the possibility that our country might have the benefit of his leadership at a later date.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The question of antitrust law violations was cted today by Homer H. Kirby, Insterstate Commerce Commission examiner, as a possible objection to the proposed pooling of freight by the Boston and Maine, New York, New Haven and Hartford and Delaware and Hudson Railroads.

DENVER, Aug. 15 -- The Presidency blossomed today into the sport-shirted elegance of yore. Adorned in a gaudy blue and watermelon-red sports shirt reminiscent of former President Truman's summer styles, President Eisenhower checked into his summer White House office this morning to get the feel of his vacation headquarters. colors had run badly at the laundry.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- Moscow reiterated today that "the shortest way to German unity in present conditions" is through the creation of an all-European system of collective security with both parts of Germany as members.

Philip H. Bagby's letter in The Times of Aug. 13 describes the damage done to our American Foreign Service by the attack of McCarthyism, from which our country is now convalescing, and by the lowering of standards for admission. It is not too early to address ourselves to certain practical problems which follow.

Surrogate George Frankenthaler ordered the Bankers Trust Company yesterday to return $150,000 in commissions to the estate of Leon Schinasi, tobacco executive. The bank was one of three executors and trustees of the estate.

Connie was a weak sister of the hurricane family, the men who run New York City's ferryboats said yesterday. But they said it while keeping their fingers crossed and with a weather eye cocked for any new big winds that might be miffed by the slur to their kin.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The development of a wood-fiber to be used in shelters for the protection of civilians and troops from atomic dusts and poison of germ warfare was announced here today.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ted Williams' 450-foot grand-slam home run coupled with superb relief pitching by Leo Kiely, a southpaw, lifted the Boston Red Sox to their third straight victory over the Washington Senators tonight, 8 -- 4.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- A proposal by State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits to set up a single state agency for juvenile delniquency was challenged today by several authorities. They contended that creation of a State Youth Authority, as suggested by Mr. Javits last month, was unnecessary and might prove damaging to existing programs.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 15--The Russian farm delegation spent today examining examples of the modern farm machinery that has revolutionized United States agricultural production in recent years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A new Administration appeal to Congress to make careful tax concessions to stimulate American capital investment abroad was disclosed today.

It will be known to many of your readers that Kent School, Connecticut, offered to Stephen Ramasodi, a pupil at St. Peter's School Rosettenville, Johannesburg, the opportunity to complete his education at Kent School.
ALBANY, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A court-appointed lawyer for John F. Roche, condemned rape slayer, said today the man had committed the crime because he wanted to be executed by the state.
Cedric H. Belfrage, British-born author and editor, was deported yesterday aboard the Holland-American liner Nieuw Amsterdam.

Two Words That Mean Trouble This is a season when the apartment dweller knows not how well off he is. For the cliff hanger may have many, many problems, but at least he has no lawn. And because he has no lawn he has one problem fewer than the suburbanite who has a lawn -- or, until about now, had a lawn.
ALMA ATA, U. S. S. R., Aug. 15 -- Dry weather has hit the Soviet Government's "new lands" project in Kazakhstan this summer.
The Philco Corporation, which has presented the "Philco Television Playhouse" for seven years, will discontinue its sponsorship after Oct. 2.

Great airliners whirred an accompaniment yesterday to a concert at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The singers were twenty-two young men and an equal number of young women of the Oklahoma City University Choir.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr.. who began winning sailing titles twenty years ago, captured the Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy at the Indian Harbor Y. C. today. The 33-year-old Beach Point Y. C. commodore won with the biggest margin in the four-year history of the competition.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- The Westinghouse Electric Company was reported today to have bids from foreign countries for "several" small nuclear power reactors.

A political history of the United States Supreme Court from its inception in 1790 to the present will be issued Aug. 29 by Random House, entitled "Nine Men." The author is Fred Rodell, Professor of Law at Yale University.

Blood will be collected today or the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at 460 West Thirty-fourth Street from employes of the Hammarlund Manufacturing Company, Inc., and the W. L. Maxson Corporation.

Whatever curative benefits the waters of New York's celebrated spa at Saratoga Springs may hold for some, they have given state officials one of their worst governmental headaches. The "season" is at its height at Saratoga, and so is the state's quandary over what to do about its financially sick investment in health.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 15 -- President Eisenhower said today that teachers should be paid salaries commensurate with their services to the family, community and nation.
The letter from Ernest Nash published in The Times of Aug. 2 is written in Alice in Wonderland double talk.
Worse, perhaps, than a bull in a china shop is a pigeon in a carpet store. The bird, however, enjoyed its week-end there so much that it refused to leave yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Donald A. Quarles was sworn in as Secretary of the Air Force today in a ceremony particularly enjoyed by Mrs. Quarles.

ANY fish may be "escabeched," Bob Brown tells us in his "The Fish and Seafood Cook Book" (Grosset Dunlap, 1954). This interesting New Yorker, who lived for many years in South America, says escabeche stands for a method of treating fish with an acid sauce, a kind of mild pickle, that is popular throughout Latin America.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- Tumultuous scenes accompanied the opening last Saturday of the Saar Government's campaign in favor of placing the territory under the Western European Union.
TRENTON, Aug. 15 -- The Republican - controlled Legislature gave final approval today to a bill providing for a referendum on use of voting machines in eleven counties that still use paper ballots.
Six actors and an actress balked the House Un-American Activities Committee yesterday as it opened a week's hearings on Communist penetration into show business.
Sgt. James C. Gallagher swore yesterday that he had never caused the death of an American soldier or collaborated with the Chinese Communists while a war prisoner in Korea.
The advisability of renting space in commercial structures for public library branches instead of constructing new buildings is being studied by city officials.
SEOUL, Aug. 15 -- President Syngman Rhee said today the United States and Korea had a common cause.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UP) -- Attorneys for the Federal Communications Commission urged the body today not to renew Edward O. Lamb's license for a television station in Erie, Pa.
Hurricane Diane bowled ominously last night toward the Georgia and South Carolina coasts.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa is in danger of turning the fiscal watchdog tradition of his office into a penuriousness which could damage New York City's future. He recently led the opposition to making two city-owned hospital sites into parks, on the ground that the city could not afford more parks.

THIS may require a bit of practice. Let's see. Etaoin shrdlu. Oops! Sorry. The typewriter must be a little rusty. That dratted hurricane, it would seem, did more damage than originally suspected. But a guy who returns to the store after being off on a holiday should first take a look around. He should examine the shelves and storerooms to see what goods moved where.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Armed with new Congressional authority, city officials began fresh efforts today to restore public transportation in the Capital.

United States District Court Judge J. Edward Lumbard yesterday issued an injunction restraining an independent stockholders' committee of Libby, McNeill Libby from circulating "misleading" statements in its proxy fight to gain control of the company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Security restrictions were removed from a new air navigation system used by the armed services and scheduled for use by commercial aviation.
Storm warnings are up in the New York City automobile retail market.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Wilson Co., meat packers, plans to stop slaughtering hogs and cattle in Chicago. The company will transfer these operations elsewhere, and will sell a substantial part of its 40 acre plant, James D. Cooney said today in a letter to stockholders.
The Calvert Distillers Company made this liquor and advertising news yesterday:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- National Theatres Corporation, one of the country's leading theatre chains, is about to step into the field of film production on a limited scale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration said today that a new law gave some veterans of the Korean War another chance to reinstate expired G. I. term insurance policies from World Wars I and II.

LAKEHURST, N. J., Aug. 15 -- A blimp with three crew members still aboard escaped from the Naval Air Station here this afternoon. It drifted aloft for ninety-three minutes at the mercy of a mild wind before landing safely in a potato field twenty-five miles away.

The money market continued tight here yesterday, with a rate of 2 per cent quoted by money brokers for the loan of Federal funds, that is, free member bank balances on deposit with the Reserve District Bank. This is the same charge as the newly raised rediscount rate of the New York Reserve institution.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 13 -- Rare writings and inscriptions bearing on the influence of Indian thought in Central Asia have been acquired by an Indian philologist.
TOKYO, Aug. 15--A brother of the Dalai Lama is getting asylum in the United States.

In response to the renewed invitation to Moscow for potentially fateful bilateral talks on Germany, Chancellor Adenauer has informed the Soviet Government that he is ready to go around Sept. 9. But he has also made it plain that he does not propose to limit himself in such talks to the three questions on the Soviet agenda -- namely, establishment of diplomatic, commercial and cultural relations -- but will insist on raising "politically related" problems.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Wheat declined sharply today, long liquidation finding a thin demand, while corn and oats were strong. Corn was helped a little by reports indicating that corn borer damage will be greater than usual. Some reports from good corn sections indicated the ears were not filling well.
Seven persons, six of whom were small children, were injured yesterday in Brooklyn by an automobile that jumped a curb and crashed into a three-story brick house.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 15 -- Mayor Harry J. Thourot of Union City today told why he keeps large sums in his office safe and at the same time borrows money in substantial amounts from a bank.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- More than 3,500 members of the Air Force Association closed their annual convention over the week-end with election of Gill Robb Wilson of New York as president.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- Vandalism in public schools here has been markedly reduced in the last year, according to a report just released by the Board of Education.
A cascade of warm water pouring down two elevator shafts in the R. C. A. Building on Rockefeller Plaza put twelve of the sixteen elevators serving its top floors out of action yesterday afternoon.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 -- The Yankees stormed into first place today as they swept an outlandish double-header that started at 3 in the afternoon and wound up under lights six hours later.

There was something a little ridiculous about the elections in the "Most Serene Republic of San Marino" on Sunday. Naturally one hoped that the Communists would lose in the quadrennial voting for the Grand and General Council, but they stacked the cards in their own favor and made it a pretty hopeless fight for the democratic forces.
HONG KONG, Aug. 15 -- Premier Chou En-lai renewed tonight Communist China's call for a Far Eastern conference to seek a "peaceful settlement" of the "Korean question."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that output from the nation's factories and mines hung up another new record in July and was 14 per cent higher than a year earlier.

Atomic Development Mutual Fund, Inc.'s total net assets soared twenty times during the past fiscal year. This was disclosed in the annual report for the year ended June 30, the first complete year of the fund's operations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- State Department officials said today none of the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had proposed reductions in the commitments to collective defense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee asked the Coast Guard today for a complete report on its investigation of the sinking of a pleasure cruise schooner in Chesapeake Bay last Friday.

CAIRO, Aug. 14 -- In Jerusalem about a week ago, Israelis were telling this correspondent that Egyptian border questions were of pressing importance. In talks with Egyptians during the last few days in Cairo, the demarcation line between Egypt and Israel has never been mentioned.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UP) -- The White House, which was virtually rebuilt three years ago, was closed to public inspection today for another repair job.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Industrial shares closed with widespread small declines today, reflecting fears that stronger doses of anti-inflationary medicine might soon be prescribed by the Government.

Atomic Development Mutual Fund, Inc.'s total net assets soared twenty times during the past fiscal year. This was disclosed in the annual report for the year ended June 30, the first complete year of the fund's operations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- State Department officials said today none of the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had proposed reductions in the commitments to collective defense.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Health officials saw in latest Massachusetts poliomyelitis figures today an indication that the outbreak may be leveling off.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 15 -- S. Klein On-the-Square brought its own special kind of merchandising to the suburbs today, causing a serious traffic jam on Long Island.

Those who contend that the answer to the problem of our heavy farm surpluses is not to be found in acreage curtailment alone found that conviction strengthened by an official Government estimate of this year's cotton crop, which placed the latter at 12,728,000 bales.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 13 -- The Waterman Steamship Corporation has undergone many changes since it was purchased for $41,367,040 in May by the C. Lee Company, Inc.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- New techniques for extracting uranium and thorium from ordinary granites have vastly extended the practical reserves of these atomic energy fuels. Whereas earlier figures indicated that the supply would last 500 to 5,000 years, the world was assured here today that it could count on these atomic energy reserves to last for millions of years.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 15 -- The Army and the newly installed Indonesian Cabinet joined today in an expanding war against corruption.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 15 (UP) -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, United States commander in the Far East, returned unexpectedly to Seoul from Tokyo today in the wake of a new demand by President Syngman Rhee that Communist truce inspectors be ousted from South Korea.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs had declined slightly from the highest levels in two years.

The Goldman Band last night closed the thirty-eighth season of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in the city's parks. The final concert was on the Mall in Central Park and it was the 2,146th in the series.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 15 (AP) -- K. M. Jedhe, president of the Goa Liberation Committee, said scores of marchers were missing in the jungles. He added an undetermined number were detained by the Portuguese at their three centers -- Goa, Damao and Diu.
MENEMSHA, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The fishing seems to have made a rapid recovery here following the rough water that was the aftermath of Hurricane Connie.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Five armed Irish raiders were foiled today in an attempt to seize arms and ammunition from a British Army camp in North Wales. The camp is situated in Kinmel, near Rhyl.
YOU may reshape your nose, raise a drooping eyebrow or smooth a sagging chin by merely changing the part in your hair, according to Henry of the Roosevelt.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association today launched a campaign to clean up big-time boxing, unanimously adopting a resolution calling for a Congressional investigation of the sport.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Paul Bailey whipped fourteen to the dozen in the Saratoga stretch today and thus extracted sufficient run from C. V. Whitney's Head Man to win the $14,125 Sanford Stakes. Head Man, a 13-to-10 proposition, made it with half a length to spare.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A House investigating subcommittee will move West next month to see whether investors in uranium and other speculative securities need greater protection.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 15 -- The entire diplomatic and official community here, led by Premier Field Marshal Pibul Songgram, paid last respects today to the late John E. Peurifoy, United States Ambassador.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 15 -- The Westchester County Golf Association moved its pro-amateur championship into Connecticut for the first time today. Fifty-eight teams participated in the event at the Wee Burn Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Democratic National Committee attacked President Eisenhower today for what it called "antiunion" labor policies. It also criticized former President Hoover for "stacking" Government reorganization study groups.
A few years ago a classified advertisement was placed in The Brooklyn Eagle: Wanted -- Bat boy. Apply Brooklyn Dodgers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13 -- An authoritative Yugoslav source has confirmed that the Soviet Union has indicated its readiness to give Yugoslavia the designs and license for construction of MIG jet aircraft.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady 6 points higher to 18 points lower than on last Friday. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.
GOA, Aug. 15 -- The dark, heavy jungles along Goa's frontiers were turned today into a political battleground.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 15 (AP) -- More than 200 office workers went on strike against the Knights of Columbus today and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Connecticut backed them in their principal demand, arbitration of issues not settled through negotiation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 16 -- The withdrawal of Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall and a practice match in which Tony Trabert and Victor Seixas worked against Donald Budge and Jack Kramer caused the most comment at the national doubles tennis championships today.
A Harvard senior returned here yesterday after having stowed away on the Cunarder Queen Elizabeth. He said he had suffered the ultimate indignity, betrayal by a Yale man.

THE other day the Yankees met an old pal in a new uniform. For the first time since he was sent to Baltimore, Eddie Lopat faced his former team-mates. Considering their fondness for him, the Bombers treated their friend with considerable rudeness. They knocked him from the box in the fifth inning.
TOKYO, Aug. 16. (AP) -- Japan's top cotton goods exporters agreed yesterday to back the government's drive to halt "indiscriminate sales" of Japanese cotton goods to the United States and Canada.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 (UP) -Soviet physicists attending the atoms-for-peace conference here are telling the world just how much help they got from the West in their race for nuclear know-how, where they got it and, in many instances, at what price.

G. Ilivitsky, Soviet grand master, took the lead with a score of 2-0 in the interzone chess tournament at Goteborg, according to a report received last night through Swedish news sources. He beat P. Sliwa of Poland in fifty-one moves.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Billy Hoeft retired twenty-one successive batters in one stretch and allowed only two singles while pitching the Detroit Tigers to a 7-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians in Briggs Stadium tonight.

When the United States embarked upon its rearmament program in 1950 it found itself faced immediately with the task of vastly expanding its productive capacity for steel, aluminum, petroleum and similar basic materials. Both experience and public opinion supported the view that this could be achieved most efficiently through the industries concerned.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -The State Department hopes to make public a record of the important documents and texts of the Big Four Geneva conference. Secretary of State Dulles said today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 16 -Ever since Khrushchev decided to smile the Western defense position has shown startling signs of weakness. The momentum that had reached its peak when the German Federal Republic was admitted into NATO has slowed to a stumble.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 16 -- Parents who use their influence as members of parent-teacher organizations to undermine the authority of teachers were critized here today.

DENIS JOHNSTON, a sardonic Irishman with a weird imagination and a disastrous inability to cut short his own verbosity, is the author of a book of war reminiscences which has received an unusually favorable critical reception in England. It is called "Nine Rivers From Jordan"* and it contains some clever and even brilliant writ ing.

The Regional Red Cross will have four mobile units in operation today to receive blood donations -- all in Manhattan. Members of the Biscuit and Cracker Workers Union, Local 405. A. F. L., employed by the National Biscuit Company, 415 West Fifteenth Street, an other employes of the company are expected to donate 200 pints.

REGIN, Sask., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press) -- The Saskatchewan Wheat Pool said today that harvesting will be general in the province by this week-end "but the final outcome of the 1955 crop as a whole still is by no means certain."
GUATEMALA, Aug. 12 -- The Organization of Central American States convenes Wednesday at near-by Antigua. The foreign ministers of the five member countries will meet for five days.

Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N. J., and J. Gilbert Shea of Los Angeles last night were picked by the United States Davis Cup Selection Committee to defend the trophy in the challenge round.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 16 -- Scores of Indian rioters fell before police gunfire in Bombay today as demonstrators surged through Indian cities. They were protesting the bloody repulse of yesterday's "passive resistance" invasion of Portuguese territory.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 16 (AP) Admiral Arleigh A. (31-knot) Burke, whose ceremonies as the new Chief of Naval Operations were blown here by Hurricane Diane, can still set a precedent in his change of command tomorrow.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 16 -- After an hour and a half wait in light air, a fleet of 147 was able to launch the seventh annual Manhasset Bay junior regatta today. All sailed a triangular course within the harbor.

United States Attorney Lloyd F. MacMahon moved yesterday to quash subpoenas served recently on Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.; J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Elizabeth Bentley, confessed former Communist espionage agent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The contract bridge team of Howard Schenken, B. Jay Becker and George Rapee, all of New York, and John R. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, moved into a tie for first place today, in the eight-team round robin for the masters team-offour championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16--Following is the State Department transcript of the record of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dulles.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club captured the Women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association championship today for the third time in seven years.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 16 -- Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney was elected president of Brown University today. The 40-year-old educator has been Dean of the College here.
GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- President Eisenhower went on record today as favoring a second United Nations-sponsored conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
Designs for 1959 automobiles are now in the making, James C. Zeder, vice president of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday. He added that designs for 1957 models already were completed.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Federal conciliators stepped into the strike of office workers today at the national headquarters of the Knights of Columbus.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 16 -- The South Korean Government condemned today a proposal by Kim Il Sung, North Korean Premier, that two conferences be held to discuss the unification of Korea.

The Court of Domestic Relations, dealing as its name suggests with intimate questions affecting parents, children and family life, requires judges of broad understanding, tolerance and humanity. Two judges who over the years have built up a reputation for just such qualities are Justine Wise Polier and Hubert T. Delany.
The publishing house of Simon Schuster, Inc., will join with the National Broadcasting Company in producing a television program for children.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The General Motors Corporation notified this village and the Westchester County Park Commission today that it had no intention of closing its local plants, regardless of whether extra land was acquired.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Britain moved today to ease the developing quarrel with Egypt over the future of the now nearly sovereign state of the Sudan.

Directors of Adams Express Company and its affiliate, American International Corporation, have declared 100 per cent stock dividends on their respective shares. Adams Express owns 69 per cent of the outstanding stock of American International.

The Baldwin Transportation Company has purchased the twostory garage-type building at 132 St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, from the Carolyn Laundry Corporation and will use it in connection with its trucking business. The property occupies a plot 80 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of 134th Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Australia completed a 5-0 sweep of Italy in its interzone final Davis Cup tennis matches today. Ken Rosewall defeated Orlando Sirola, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, and Lew Hoad downed Nicola Pietrangeli, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 16 -- Patricia Martin Pool received a divorce yesterday from Dr. John. L. Pool of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- World trade in manufactured goods has been increasing rapidly, but Britain's share has been declining for the last five years. In the same period West Germany's share has more than doubled and that of the United States has remained relatively stable.
STOCKTON, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) -A telegram from President Eisenhower and a huge cake highlighted the celebration of the ninety-third birthday anniversary of Amos Alonzo Stagg today.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 16 -Jack Patroni of Apawamis carded a two-under-par 70 for the first-round lead in the Westchester open golf championship today. Considering the conditions, with the course still heavy from recent rain, the score was one of the best competitive rounds at the Wee Burn Country Club in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Government denied today a request by Joseph Accardi, New Jersey racketeer, to reopen deportation proceedings against him. An order of deportation was issued by the Board of Immigration Appeals on April 3, 1953.
GOA, Aug. 16 -- Indian leaders were reported today to have called off for the time being the "political invasion" of Portuguese Goa.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Visiting Russian farm experts inspected the International Harvester Company's tractor plant today.

Two baby humming birds, less than two weeks old, have found a home at the Bronx Zoo. The birds -- they are of the ruby-throated species -- were orphaned in Woodbury, Conn., last Saturday by Hurricane Connie.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- A recent recapitulation of geographical distribution of Secretariat posts among the member nations does not indicate any inequity with respect to Asian countries, United Nations sources said today.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 16 -- Talks that may determine whether Singapore is to have a governmental crisis began here today between David Marshall, Chief Minister, and Alan T. Lennox-Boyd, British Secretary of State for the Colonies.
KOCHI, Japan, Aug. 16 (AP) -American college stars outswam Japan's best for the first time tonight in the third of a series of meets between the two leading swimming nations.

GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, U. Alexis Johnson, held his seventh "talk" with Wang Ping-nan, Communist Chinese Ambassador to Poland, here today. All that Mr. Johnson said afterward was "I am still sitting there trying to get some prisoners released."
ON the seventh anniversary of his death, an impressive radio tribute to Babe Ruth was offered last night over WRCA and the National Broadcasting Company network.
DETROIT, Aug. 16 (UP) -Senator Charles E. Potter, Michigan Republican, said today he would recommend a Senate investigation of charges underworld characters have invaded boxing.

United States and Canada Naval Week, which will bring a visit by thirty-nine vessels of the two navies, was marked yesterday in Battery Park. The noon ceremony was part of the regular Tuesday concert of the New York Summer Festival.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 -The Supreme Council of the Peronist party announced today it was going to reassume the fighting role it had in 1946. It was in that year that President Juan D. Peron was elected to the presidency the first time.

Admiral Robert B. Carney, who is being relieved today as Chief of Naval Operations, has warned that the naval superiority of the United States and its Allies is being slowly reduced by the growth of Communist sea power.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The United Nations will cost less to run in 1956, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today.
GENEVA, Aug. 16 -- New information about the workings of the brain was given by delegates at today's sessions of the International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy.
A Chinese exchange student who voluntarily returned to Communist China has escaped to Hong Kong after having spent most of his time back home in jail or begging.
Plans to launch the first man-made satellite were hailed here yesterday as marking what may possibly be one of the greatest achievements of mankind.
MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Aug. 16 -- No one has ever charged the bluefish with being as selective as brown trout, but there are occasions when they can be annoyingly perverse.
PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Two well-known members of the French nobility, the Marquis and Marquise Melchior de Vogue, have decided to enter separate religious orders after thirty-five years of marriage.

A joint funeral service was held here yesterday for Louis H. Sobel of 211 Central Park West, executive director of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York, and his wife, Minna. Both were among the victims of the foundering of the schooner Levin J. Marvel in Chesapeake Bay last Friday.

Detroit and Canada Tunnel The proposed two-for-one split of the common stock of the Detroit and Canada Tunnel Corporation has been approved by shareholders. The split is subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
They came, they saw, they stood pat.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Industrial and Government securities remained dull today as the volume of business fell to the lowest level in months.
Thirty-four men were overcome by carbon monoxide poisoning yesterday while removing flood waters from the Fourteenth Street-Canarsie Line tracks of the B. M. T....
LINCOLN, Neb., Wednesday, Aug. 17 (UP) -- More than 200 prisoners rooted and burned nearly half the buildings inside the Nebraska penitentiary late yesterday.
Robert Moses called yesterday on Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn to support the Parks Department's plan for a promenade to link Brighton and Manhattan Beaches.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley told the City Planning Commission yesterday that he planned to add 10,000 parking meters in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A Federal judge refused today to order the State Department to issue a passport to Paul Robeson.

W. R. Grace Co., international chemical and trading concern, announced yesterday that its Davison Chemical division and Rare Earths, Inc., of Pompton Plains, N. J., a wholly owned subsidiary, would conduct a joint program aimed at expanded production, sales and research of rare earths and thorium.
FATHERS with overworked checkbooks and recent grads on beginning salaries alike will applaud Saks-34th's collegecareer collection. It was shown yesterday at the store.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -The City Department of Recreation canceled today an open-air performance of Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" that was scheduled for tomorrow night on Reyburn Plaza, opposite City Hall.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Montgomery Ward Co. announced issuance of the largest fall sale book in its history. The mail order and retail chain described the catalogue as "a strong bid for seasonal business with reductions averaging 10 per cent, and cuts on many items ranging as high as 40 per cent or more."
Jewelry will enjoy a boom if jewelry retailers fight for a greater share of the consumer dollar, according to Irving N. Chayken, chairman of the Jewelry Industry Council.

Construction contract awards in thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains last month set a new record for any previous July, the F. W. Dodge Corporation, construction news and market specialists, reported. The awards totaled $2,271,537,000, which represents a jump of 24 per cent over the corresponding month last year.
Billy Gardner made a triumphant return to the Giants last night.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday shook up the force in the Coney Island area, He transferred seven officers and sixteen plainclothes men.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox gained a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in the eleventh inning tonight and moved into second place in the American League, a game and a half behind the league-leading New York Yankees.

MAPLE syrup -- produced in only one place in the world, northeast United States and southeast Canada -- is turned out to delicate perfection at a farm in Milton, Vt. There a young couple, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Bruce, make a limited amount of syrup each spring of remarkably high quality.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- The Yankees brought no end of grief to a sweltering crowd of 34,152 Hub fans tonight.
A stevedore may not pay a "rebate" to a steamship agent unless the principal involved is aware of such an arrangement, State Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz ruled yesterday.
The Transit Authority conceded yesterday that "Exasperated," whose letter to the editor apperead in Monday's New York Times, had a point.
The first of four tracks on the Manhattan approach to the new Harlem River bridge of the New York Central Railroad will be put into use today without interruption to train schedules.

Mayor Wagner will serve as honorary chairman of the City of New York Committee for the 1956 Olympic Games. The announcement of the Mayor's acceptance was made yesterday by Jay-Ehret Mahoney, president of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union.
An excursion boat with 2,000 persons aboard struck a sandbar in fog-bound waters near Coney Island last night, but backed off under her own power and went on to dock at Bayonne, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Disappointment was expressed by Secretary of State Dulles today at lack of progress in the Geneva talks with Communist China.
Nikita S. Khrushchev seems to be losing the two major gambles he made in Soviet agriculture this year.

SELMER, Tenn., Aug. 16 (UP) -- A highly respected building contractor who recently was defeated as a candidate for sheriff was arrested today. He was charged with being the masked gunman who had robbed his home-town bank of Ackerman, Miss., of $46,000 last Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Elisha Gray, president of the Whirlpool Corporation of St. Joseph, Mich., said today he expected the proposed Whirlpool-Seeger Corporation to be a reality on Sept. 16. Its first appliances will be on the market in January, he said.

HONG KONG, Aug. 16 -- The Peiping regime renewed its bid for "normal relations" with Japan today. It issued a statement denying Japan's assertion that 40,000 of her nationals were still unaccounted for in China.

All seven actors who refused on Monday to answer questions before the House Un-American Activities Committee relating to membership in the Communist party are members of both Actors Equity Association and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
The Coast Guard hearing on the sinking of the schooner Levin J. Marvel last Friday in Chesapeake Bay during Hurricane Connie has been postponed because of the approach of Hurricane Diane.

A rainy day in summer is a remarkably good thing, provided it is just a rain and not something called Connie or Diane. Quite aside from the fact it will improve the tomato crop, with effects, through canning, felt into the winter, it has an immediate, short-range value.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Scotland Yard detectives recovered today most of the arms and ammunition seized at the British Army's Arborfield camp Saturday by Irish Nationalist raiders. Officials believe that, with this find, the entire loot of arms and ammunition has been recovered.

Rubber prices soared yesterday on the Commodity Exchange after two days of sharp declines. Short covering, commission house buying and trade purchasing raised prices 225 to 270 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 3,800 tons.
Bernard M. Baruch, "the father" of Saratoga Spa, has a parental rebuke and some advice for the state on its moneylosing health resort.

If the seventy-two nations that are participating in the Geneva conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy needed any proof of President Eisenhower's sincerity in determining to divert attention from bombs and guns to the constructive work that can be done with atoms it has been furnished by the discussions on the production of power.

Today's new film is "Ulysses," an Italian-made, English-language color adaptation of Homer's "Odyssey," with Kirk Douglas, Silvana Mangano, Anthony Quinn and Rossana Podesta, at the Globe. The Lux Film-Ponti de Laurentiis production was directed by Mario Camerini, from a screen play by Franco Brusati, Ennio de Concini, Hugh Gray, Ben Hecht, Ivo Perilli, Irwin Shaw and Signor Camerini.

TRENTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today New Jersey was a "billion-dollar corporation" and its financial position was excellent. Mr. Meyner told a news conference "we have dedicated pension and trust funds amounting to $1,023,604,000."

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago yesterday offered its smallest stockholders an opportunity to round out their holdidngs to ten shares or dispose of them, free of brokerage costs or transfer taxes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16--Red Cross National Headquarters announced today the opening of new emergency hurricane centers in Georgia and South Carolina.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The governors of Connecticut and New York will meet here Friday to discuss disputed water supplies in Fairfield and Westchester counties.

The eleven United States fliers have hen released. Who are the parties that have really contributed to their release? President Eisenhower expressed gratitude to United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold for his efforts in bringing about this release.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The Westchester Park Commission reported to the County Board of Supervisors today that it was speeding preparation of a detailed proposal for the exclusion of nonresidents from the county parks.

The six-story apartment house containing fifty-five suites at 400 Riverside Drive, corner of 112th Street, has figured in a quick resale. The property was purchased by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, from the 400 Riverside Drive Corporation through the Amal Realty Company and John Hennessey as co-brokers.
MELBOURNE, Aug. 16 -- A record offering of more than four million bales is expected to be sold at the new season's wool auctions beginning in Sydney on Aug. 29.
Good olives, like bad pennies, apparently have a way of turning up again.
The Sylvan Lawrence Company, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the ninestory office building at 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn, from the Chase Manhattan Bank.
John Blair Co, radio and television representative, through Cross Brown Co, agent, floor in office building under construction at 415 Madison Ave -John J. Reynolds Inc, broker.

Once again the news from Argentina is hitting the front pages. This time it is the foiling of still another plot, accompanied by further demonstrations of Roman Catholics and students and agitation in the ranks of the political opposition.
Twenty-one bathers at Rockaway Beach in Queens were stung yesterday by a school of Portuguese men-of-war, a type of jellyfish.

The sagging tendency evident in the stock market for several sessions continued yesterday. From time to time various groups and issues pushed forward, but the general movement was downward most of the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Mr. Robeson later called it "rather absurd" that Soviet farmers could visit here and American Baptist preachers go to Moscow, yet he was "not allowed to travel because of my friendship -- open, spoken friendship -for the Soviet people and the peoples of all the world."

FIFTY or more workers for the Gahagan Construction Corporation will leave Pier 1 at the Battery at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning on a plushy Moran tug for a party aboard Gahagan Dredge No. 5, which is working in the Bay, back of the Statue of Liberty.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- The Knights of Columbus was told here tonight that efforts again were being made to impede Roman Catholic education in the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. has purchased a "substantial" stock interest in Walton's, Ltd., Australian department store and chain store organization with headquarters in Sydney, Theodore V. Houser, Sears' board chairman, said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- High borrowing rates in a heavily extended bond market prompted the Cook County Board today to vote unanimously to reject bids for the immediate sale of $40,000,000 of bonds as the first part of a $245,000,000 issue authorized for construction of Chicago's superhighway system.

A Federal Maritime Board examiner recommended yesterday that American President Lines' round-the-world service be permitted to add steamship calls at North Atlantic ports other than New York and Boston.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A deal involving $1,017,000 for the purchase of 500 new Chevrolet passenger cars by Bulgaria has fallen through.

A one-story building at 27-03 Fortieth Avenue in Long Island City. Queens, has been leased by the Bechik Products, Inc., of St. Paul, Minn. The lessee, manufacturer and distributor of hardware and accessories for bedding manufacturers, will occupy the property as its eastern branch office and warehouse.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 -- Prime Minister Nehru declared today in the House of the People (lower chamber of Parliament) that Portuguese in Goa had "deliberately" opened fire and killed Indian volunteers to provoke India into some kind of "wrong action."
Bernard M. Baruch created a stir yesterday in an unexpected appearance at the House UnAmerican Activities Committee hearings into Communist penetration of the theatre.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Grain futures were erratic today. Sharp declines followed a generally firm opening, but wheat met good support on the setbacks, leading a recovery.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Aug. 16 -- The Sudanese Parliament unanimously approved today a resolution calling for the evacuation of British and Egyptian troops within ninety days. The aim of the resolution is to clear the way for Sudan's freedom after fifty-six years of foreign rule.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 16 -President Eisenhower motored through a mountain rainstorm and into a rousing cowtown welcome this afternoon.
TOKYO, Aug. 16 -- Japan is making a determined propaganda effort to support her case for the return of the Kuriles, southern Sakhalin and other islands from the Soviet Union.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Reardon of the State Division of Communicable Diseases today advised parents whose homes are in areas of low polio incidence to avoid taking their children to places where the incidence is high.
A dim picture of Brazilian finance is painted in the latest of a series of analyses of that nation's problems by the New York Trust Company.

"The New Dimensions of Peace" has been chosen as the title for the new book by Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India and Nepal. To be published on Oct. 31 by Harper, it presents Mr. Bowles' impressions and observations gained from a three months' visit with the leaders and "ordinary citizens" of India and Africa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- The Army disclosed today that troops now heading toward the Arctic frontier would build more than fifty radar stations as part of the North American air raid warning network.

Secretary Dulles' comment yesterday on Russia's announced plan to reduce her armed forces by 640,000 men between now and Dec. 15 is plain common sense. We desire peace, we would like to see a general reduction of armaments, but we do want proof that Russia is willing to go along with us in deeds as well as in words.

Five well-known trade names will join next month in a drive to promote Du Mont television receivers. The theme of the advertising will be "Recognized as the Height of Quality Throughout the World." The participants, in addition to the television receiver division of the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., will be the Cadillac division of General Motors, Ceil Chapman, dress designer; Trifari jewels and Schumacher wall papers.
The pennant-bound Brooklyn Dodgers announced yesterday that they planned to play seven 1956 home games at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City.

One more glaring example of the need for advancing the city's master plan for a complete network of one-way avenues has been furnished by the trials of motorists trying to cope with the dual light system prevailing on West End-Eleventh Avenues.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- Three special showings of "Oklahoma!" in the new ToddA. O. big-screen process were held today on a converted sound stage of the Metro-GoldwynMayer studio. Newspaper, magazine, radio and television representatives and movie industry personalities attended.
The New York Coliseum will become a "showcase for better living" when the first exhibition! to use the entire four-floor structure opens there on May 12, 1956.
MORE and more housewives are "roughing it" with their husbands on hunting and fishing trips rather than staying at home.

Four more witnesses stubbornly resisted yesterday all efforts of the House Un-American Activities Committee to get them to tell how their lives and work may have been affected or exploited by communism.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 16 -- French security forces have been strengthened in anticipation of possible nationalist disturbances next Saturday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -Willie Shoemaker rode six winners at Washington Park today, including Colleoni in the featured $4,500 Niles Purse.

Thanks to "Salute to France," a hands-across-the-sea project nurtured by the American National Theatre and Academy, New Yorkers will assemble tonight to see Helen Hayes, Mary Martin, George Abbott and Florence Reed in the first local revival of "The Skin of Our Teeth."

James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, said yesterday he would welcome Federal control of boxing. The I. B. C. promoter also said he did not deal with racketeers and would get out of the sport if he had to.

The nation's life insurance companies paid out $1,112,665,000 in death claims under 834,255 policies in the first half of this year, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday. This compared with $1,047,326,000 under 811,147 policies in the like period last year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A new issue of $200,000,000 of twenty-year debentures of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation wlil be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 75 underwriting houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -- Members of the Screen Actors Guild, by a vote of 735 to 307, approved at a stormy mass meeting here tonight terms of a new contract with television entertainment film producers. The new contract grants residual payments starting with the second run.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- In the main event at the Saratoga track today were five nominees for next week's Alabama Stakes, the nation's oldest race for three-year-old fillies. The one other entrant was a filly that wasn't named for the seventy-fifth Alabama.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The new $300,000 home of the National Museum of Racing was dedicated today by Governor Harriman, who later went to the races.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday. The market moved 6 points up to 5 points off.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 16 -- Donald Byrne of the University of Michigan gained the undisputed lead last night in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation. The 1953 open titleholder was paired with Paul Brandts of New York, who had the black pieces.

Traffic Commissioner Wiley, as reported in The Times, believes that there are no panaceas for New York's traffic problems; that no "big, bold stroke" can solve the situation; that, on the contrary, one must approach each of tens of little problems individually.
CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 16 -- The state plans to open its first forestry camp for young offenders this fall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover today accused officials of the Democratic Digest, organ of the Democratic National Committee, or an "infamous smear" attack on the Commission for Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government. Mr. Hoover headed the commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin forbade the Government today to suspend a postal clerk because of a letter-to-the-editor opposing the renomination of Gov. Allan Shivers of Texas last year.

Sgt. James C. Gallagher admitted yesterday that he had signed an appeal to United Nations troops to quit the "useless war" in Korea. But he denied under cross-examination that he ever had caused the death of a fellow prisoner of war.

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 16 -President Eisenhower named tonight a three-man emergency board to investigate a rules dispute between the eastern section of the New York Central Railway system and its conductors and brakemen.

An agreement for construction of Mexico's first newsprint mill was announced yesterday by the Parsons Whittemore, Inc., New York, supplier of pulp, paper and machinery with affiliates here and abroad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -Secretary of State Dulles welcomed today the Soviet Union's announcement that it would reduce its military manpower by 640,000 men by Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today a prerequisite for new talks on Korea would be Communist acceptance of the principle of United Nations supervision of all-Korean elections.
MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Russian tourists may yet rub elbows with the Americans on the Rue de Rivoli in Paris.

We greatly appreciate the efforts your paper has made to present a fair and impartial view of the current happenings in Morocco. However, in your editorial of Aug. 12 on "The Moroccan Danger" we were extremely grieved to see the words "utterly unworthy" applied to our exiled Sultan, Mohammed ben Youssef; this is a leftover from years of French colonial propaganda.
Ninety-mile winds, forerunners of Hurricane Diane, struck the North Carolina coast early today. The full force of the second hurricane within a week was expected to hit that area later this morning.
The Kimberly-Clark Corporation realized an increase of 16 per cent in earnings for the quarter ended July 31 on a sales gain of about 9 per cent over the corresponding three onths last year.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 16 (Reuters) -- The Portuguese Foreign Ministry, in a communique issued after demonstrations in Bombay today, said Portugal held India responsible for the rioting.
The Liberal party withdrew yesterday all of its Manhattan candidates for the Sept. 13 primary and substituted the Democratic designees.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation will have its new central office quarters in Manhattan instead of in Westchester County. Plans to move outside the city have been abandoned by the company, which will erect a $40.000,000 skyscraper office structure on the site of the former Marguery Hotel at 270 Park Avenue.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday the signing of a contract to buy Canadian natural gas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission challenged yesterday the adequacy of two registration statements and sought to halt stock offerings. Hearings will be held in each case.

Union agreements with General Electric and the two big can companies -- Continental and American -- have thrown the misnamed "guaranteed annual wage" into the front-page headlines again. Measured on the surface by the G. A. W. yardstick, the G. E. settlement, which omits supplementary unemployment benefits, seems to have been a setback and the can companies' contract, which includes them, a gain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The Republican National Chairman denied today that a confidential report by party agents had warned of a dangerous split in Republican ranks in Connecticut.

ROME, Aug. 17 -- One Senator and five Representatives on the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy were received in private audience by Pope Pius XII this morning. The Congressmen discussed atomic energy with the Pontiff at considerable length.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 -- Members of the right-wing Herut party, second largest in the newly elected Knesset, refused today to pay the traditional call on President Izhak Ben-zvi.

KABUL, Afghanistan, July 30 -- The drive across Iran from Teheran gave the expedition a new awareness of the history and culture of this part of the Moslem world. Still primitive and backward, it has a spirit all its own.
DETROIT, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Babe Birrer, a relief pitcher, turned in a five-inning scoreless performance today to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 9-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

Plans for a fifteen-story apartment building at 518 to 522 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street, have announced as a result of the purchase of a plot 75 by 877 feet there by the Third-Thirty-fifth Corporation, represented by Paul Shaw.

Married life, as summed up at least by one sociological survey, is nowhere near so sad as the soap operas paint it. A study of 440 married men and women conducted by social scientists at the University of Pennsylvania rated 71.4 per cent as happy, 15 per cent as medium-happy and only an unlucky 13.6 per cent as miserable.
A former diplomat reported today that Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam had deflated Communist propaganda in his country.
The Anaconda Company raised the price of refined copper 4 cents a pound yesterday, to 40 cents. This is believed to be the highest price set by a major producer since 1872.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Chicago and the other Great Lakes port cities will be served by at least fifteen more steamship lines after the full opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1959.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Aram Khatchaturian, Soviet composer, added his voice today to those suggesting musical exchanges between the United States and Russia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of the report sent to the Secretary of Defense today by his Advisory Committee on Prisoners of War;

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., plans "very soon" to build a new generating plant on Staten Island. Harland C. Forbes, executive vice president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Russians "certainly have full freedom of worship," a United States Baptist minister said today after a tour of the Soviet Union. "Of course, they do not have religious freedom the way we know it," he added.

UNION CITY, N. J., Aug. 17 -- A 27-year-old head teller at a branch office of the Commonwealth Trust Company here was arrested today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after a shortage of $28,500 was discovered.

BECAUSE too much celery and too little chicken have been included in the chicken salad inevitably served at overcrowded wedding breakfasts, many fine cooks have ruled out this dish from their repertoires.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing," a romantic drama placed in Hong Kong with William Holden and Jennifer Jones, arrives at the Roxy. John Patrick wrote the screen play, based on a novel by Han Suyin. The Twentieth Century-Fox film, in CinemaScope and color, was directed by Henry King and produced by Buddy Adler.
Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will offer its two 1956 room air conditioners to the public next month at prices $100 below those they will bring next year. The uints are not yet in stores.
Four amendments to the Constitution have been cited by witnesses who have testified so far in the hearing by the House Committee on Un-American Activities into Communist penetration of the theatre.
