INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Judge Walter Pritchard upheld a union shop clause in the new General Motors wage contract today. He said he had no right to write a so-called "right to work" law which had been defeated by three Indiana legislatures.

The pennant-bound Dodgers dropped their second straight decision to the Giants last night at the Polo Grounds. This one, a 5-1 defeat by Ramon Monzant, who never had pitched a complete game in the majors, provoked one disgruntled Flatbush fan to remark:
The Association of Polish Merchant Marine Officers in the United States broke yesterday with its best known member over a question of "ethics."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Coast Guard held back today a Reserve commission for a high-ranking student of its officers training school at New London, Conn.

"New Skyscraper for Park Avenue" is a headline as familiar as the refrain of a popular song. New office-building construction in the area north of the Grand Central Terminal has been and is tremendous.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Harry S. Truman today prepared a give-'em-hell speechmaking campaign aimed at helping return the Democratic party to the White House.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 17 -- Voters here approved a city charter amendment to shorten the terms of city officials by one year and to hold a new city election Nov. 19, official returns showed today.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 17 -- Delegations of five countries gathered here today preparatory to inaugurating tomorrow in nearby Antigua the first formal conference of the Organization of the Central American States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A ten-member Pentagon committee drew up the new code of conduct for war prisoners after consulting with scores of experts on mental and military behavior, including former captives.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- The Saratoga racing show had an extra attraction today. The Belair stud's Nashua, with Eddie Arcaro in the role of exercise rider, had a seven-furlong workout over the muddy track half an hour before the first race.
FRASER, Col., Aug. 17 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Archie A. Alexander as Governor of the Virgin Islands.

By his revelation that the Dodgers plan to play seven home games in Jersey City's Roosevelt Stadium next year, Walter F. O'Malley seems to have gained ground toward his goal of building a new ball park for the Dodgers in Brooklyn.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower today appointed John M. Cashen, County Judge of Ulster County, N. Y., as Federal District Judge for the Southern District of New York.
The twelfth witness in the House Un-American Activities Committee's inquiry into communism in the theatre was the first to cooperate with the committee.

The Sudan has now announced that she feels herself ready to decide on her political future. Her past, since 1899, has been as a condominium of Britain and Egypt, although in reality the British have done the ruling.
Mayor Wagner presented the $2,500 cash award of the John C. Sable Memorial Heart Fund last night to Dr. Edward F. Cannon of Highland Hospital in Rochester, N. Y.

A plain, slightly battered wooden door lying in the middle of the sidewalk on a busy thoroughfare adds an Alice-in-Wonderland touch to the everyday scene with its silent invitation to be opened, perhaps to reveal a set of stairs descending to adventure.

Commodity fUtures closed ir- I regular yesterday. Cocoa, wool,[ hides and copper were higher;I cottonseed oil and zinc eased,] and coffee, sugar, rubber, pota-I toes and soybean oil price[ changes were mixed. I
ALBANY, Aug. 17 (UP) -- New York City's request that the Public Service Commission reject a stop-gap telephone rate increase of $34,000,000 will be reviewed by the full board on Aug. 30.

Jon William Hurst of Inglewood, Calif., 23-year-old Harvard student who stowed away on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth last June 15, slept in a public bathtub of the ship and subsisted on a diet of bouillon and crackers (served on deck in the morning) and tea and cake (served in the afternoon).

BELGAUM, India, Aug. 17 -- Bitterness rising in India following the bloodshed in Portuguese Goa Monday will pose for Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his Congress party a major test of political leadership.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Prices in the stock market continued to drift lower today, mainly from a lack of incentive.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, was reported today to be planning to ask Governments to lend him the continuing assistance of some of the leading atomic scientists in the world.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 17 -- Ed Draper and Mike Homa finished in a tie for the Westchester open golf title today. At the end of the regular fifty-four holes of play at the Wee Burn Country Club, each had scores of 214. As a result, an eighteen - hole play-off will be held here Friday.

Stockholders of the Globe-Wernicke Company, Cincinnati, have approved sale of the concern to the City Auto Stamping Company of Toledo. The transaction, to be completed by Aug. 31, involves $6,000,000. Globe-Wernicke's real estate holdings in Norwood, Ohio, are not included in the purchase but will be leased by City Auto Stamping with the privilege of purchased.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 10:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- European countries will need atomic energy more and more in the next few decades, a United States Government study disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Government contracts to buy and sell cheese under price-supporting arrangements last year have been declared "unauthorizd and improper" by...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The Democratic Digest struck back today at former President Herbert Hoover. It charged anew that he had "stacked" the subcommittees of his Government reform commission.
PORT WASHINGTON. L. I., Aug. 17 -- There was only one major repeater -- Kraus in the Penguins, as the second day of competition in the seventh annual junior regatta was held in Manhasset Bay today.

Essex County, N. J., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $8,753,000 on Sept. 8 to finance public improvements. Bids will be taken on an issue of bonds totaling this amount. The obligations will be dated Sept. 1, 1955 and will come due on Sept. 1 from 1956 to 1976.

A drop last week of 1,493,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 154,983,000 barrels, compared with 156,476,000 a week earlier and 156,328,000 a year ago.

"A Cure for Serpents: A Doctor in Africa," by Alberto Denti di Pirajno, an Italian duke, will be published by William Sloane Associates on Sept. 15. It is an account of the author's twenty years in North Africa as a doctor and medical administrator of Italy's former colonies.
Following is the list of citizens, former prisoners of war and Government representatives who consulted with the Defense Advisory Committee on Prisoners of War on the Code of Conduct:
After sagging since Monday, stocks rallied in the final hour of trading yesterday, with the rail issues in the forefront. However, closing prices were irregularly lower for the day.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 -- Premier Chou En-lai told Japanese correspondents today that Communist China wanted to "normalize relations" with Japan and had "taken a series of steps toward this end." The interview with a visiting press group was reported by the Hsinhua (New China) news agency.

National Department Stores yesterday announced the sale of its subsidiary in Baton Rouge, La., the Rosenfield Dry Goods Company, Ltd., to the House of Fashion, another Baton Rouge store. The price was not disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The history of prisoners of war is a history of death, deprivation, suffering and torture.
THE lamps that light New York homes may be as dated as kerosene lanterns within a few years if two recent lighting developments are any indication.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Horses trained by Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons have won close to $1,000,000 this year. But, strange to relate, his horses hadn't been able to win a race at the Saratoga meet till today's sixth event. For fifteen days they had been trying, and for fifteen days they had been failing.
The threat posed by Hurricane Diane to the New York metropolitan area was dissipated yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Long liquidation was again pretty heavy in September wheat, corn, oats and soybeans today.
The first electronic brain to control the creation and moving of millions of kilowatts of electricity through an entire power system will go into action next year.
This country's volume of advertising is at its highest level in history and is still climbing, Printers' Ink reports in its latest issue, out today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Officials of the Knights of Columbus and the Office Employes Union, A. F. L., announced today that they had reached a "basis for the resolution" of a three-day strike by 200 office employes at the Roman Catholic organization's home office in New Haven, Conn.

Julius Kayser Co., manufacturer of women's lingerie, gloves and hosiery, announced yesterday acquisition of Holeproof hosiery Company, Milwaukee, producer of men's and women's hosiery and underwear, for a sum estimated at $13,000,000.

The Department of Hospitals has discontinued the operation of the Neponsit Beach Hospital, and Parks Commissioner Robert Moses has proposed that the present site of the hospital be returned to the Parks Department for development as an addition to the adjoining Jacob Riis Park.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A new opera, "Irish Legend," by Werner Egk, German composer, was received tonight with enthusiastic applause in the Salzburg Festival House. It was the highlight of the 1955 Music Festival.

Yesterday for the first time in two years a major bank called brokers' loans based on security collateral. But Wall Street foresaw no dire effects. The general opinion seemed to be that the call, which was for only $20,000,000, resulted from the tight cash position and that it had nothing to do with the basic value of stocks at current prices.
"If Jersey wants a baseball team, let them get their own team. The Dodgers belong in Brooklyn."
Employes of downtown companies will give blood today at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. The hours will be 10 A. M. to 4:30 P. M.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -- The Indonesian Republic celebrated today the tenth anniversary of its proclamation of independence. President Sukarno marked the occasion with a bitter denunciation of the Dutch, the country's former colonial masters.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 18 (UP) -- South Koreans reported today that an unarmed United States trainer plane was shot down yesterday by North Korean ground fire near the truce village of Panmunjom. The village is within Red territory.

Ernest W. Mandeville, in a letter in your Aug. 8 issue, points out the lamentable failure of Congress to pass a law for Federal aid for school construction, despite the obvious and serious need for such financial help to hard-pressed localities where the increase in the birth rate has necessitated a big increase in school construction.
GENEVA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Scientists continued to explore today a wide variety of problems connected with materials, designs and safety measures to help speed up the fast-moving atomic industry.
Robert Moses wrote another of his bitter notes yesterday.
The public hearings into communism in the entertainment world were denounced here last night at two rallies under the sponsorship of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday in favor of William McMahon and against the Moore-McCormack Lines and the International Longshoremen's Association in an unfair labor practice case dating back to 1954.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A broad program of child welfare for the twenty-one American Republics was outlined here today by the new president of the American International Institute for the Protection of Childhood.

TRACY, Calif., Aug. 17 -- The nation's No. 1 farm state, with annual cash crop and livestock income exceeding $2,500,000,000, spread some of its agricultural glories today before the visiting Soviet farm delegation.

The three days of hearings on communism in the theatrical profession have thus far turned up one admitted former Communist and a number of actors who refuse to answer questions about their political memberships and associations.

Rather than let men -- and English men at that -- have the last word on the title preferred by that portion of the American population that keeps the homes intact, for the other portion to come back to in the evening, we have conducted a small local census.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 17 -- Former President Shukri al-Kuwatly was generally thought to be assured of victory in the Presidential balloting in Parliament tomorrow morning.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced terms of its pending offering up to $650,000,000 of new convertible debentures, the largest private financing ever undertaken.
Final testimony in the court-martial of Sgt. James C. Gallagher yesterday produced new accusations of brutality and collaboration.

GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- Surveys of the air, the earth and the water around the Hanford plutonium works in Washington indicate that radioactive chemicals are escaping from it. But there is no evidence that they have caused material damage to a large variety of plants and animals, including man, that have absorbed them.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The 1955 masters team-of-four championship was won this afternoon by the contract bridge team of Samuel M. Stayman, Lee Hazen, Myron Field and Richard Kahn, all of New York, with Charles J. Solomon of Philadelphia.
Arrangements for visiting ten United States and six Canadian naval ships were announced yesterday.

A proposal that the motion picture industry's production code "should be examined in the light of present-day thinking" was made yesterday by Fred J. Schwartz, president of the Distributors Corporation of America, which is releasing the motion picture "I Am a Camera."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Herb Shriner, the comedian, and Barbara Hale have been signed to star in "Governor's Wife," the initial TV film production of the "Screen Directors Playhouse" series.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- Eight miles of the Albany Post Road with a long record of automobile crashes, fatalities and congestion will be redeveloped by the state at a cost of $7,500,000.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 -- The business and government districts of this capital were the scenes of noisy disorders today. Policemen and firemen prevented the staging of another anti-Government demonstration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States, for the first time in its history, proclaimed today a definitive Code of Conduct for American service men while prisoners of war.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Bob Satterfield, 183 pounds, floored Nino Valdes, 215, in a savage last round tonight in gaining a unanimous ten-round decision.
Sales of frozen foods during the first half of this year were well ahead of the similar period of 1954, according to a study released yesterday by the National Frozen Food Distributors Association.

"There is plenty of room for self-expression in a home where discipline and authority are found," according to Miss Phyllis Page Bradshaw. But parents are often confused about where their authority should end and their children's freedom begin, she adds in a recent report from Rutgers University. She is a specialist in human relations there.

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The failure of Gov. George M. Leader in Pennsylvania to honor Georgia's request for extradition of a convicted murderer was termed today by Georgia's Governor and Attorney General "an open invitation" for every escaped convict to seek refuge in Pennsylvania.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- It is vacation time in the Soviet Union and the two top men of the Soviet Communist party and state seem to be taking advantage of it.

INCHON, Korea, Aug. 16 -- Eight United States Army vehicles were stoned by Korean terrorists here today and one American officer was seriously injured. Second Lieut. Wayne Hansen of Augusta, Ga., was struck in the head by a stone and was taken to a hospital.

We have heard much of "fallout" and of its immediate and remote effects if there are many more test explosions of hydrogen bombs. The peaceful uses of atomic energy also have their radiation hazards, and these have been disturbing the biologists and physicians at Geneva.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -The Government traded two old tankers and six dry-cargo Liberty ships today for two high-speed supertankers and $4,059,500.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- A drenching rain flooded the courts of the Longwood Cricket Club today.

An experiment in labor-management relations began yesterday in the long-haul trucking industry. It was the setting up of a union-employer panel empowered to rule on grievances arising under union contracts.
FRASER, Col., Aug. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower chose Robert H. Thayer, a specialist on national security affairs, today to be minister to Communist Rumania.
GENEVA, Aug. 17 -- Leading atomic scientists from the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union today shared fundamental secrets essential to the production of atomic power.

The five-story apartment house for fifty-six families on plot 150 by 100 feet at 147-49 West Tremont Avenue, corner of University Avenue, in the Bronx, has been resold after a brief ownership by Goodman-Herman, operators, in a deal negotiated by Langsam Siegel, brokers.

Manufacturers should work with retail jewelers to develop realistic mark-ups, according to Donald W. Leach, vice president of the R. Wallace Sons Manufacturing Company, Wallingford, Conn. Retailers' profits might be increased on some items but other mark-ups could be reduced to meet competition, he said yesterday at the fiftieth annual convention and trade show of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Nehru expressed today his deep regret apology to foreign missions and consulates that were attacked by Indian demonstrators yesterday and offered to pay full compensation for any damages.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Eugene O'Neill's "Anna Christie" will be re-done by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a music drama with Ava Gardner and Howard Keel co-starred.
SIDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Two of the biggest companies in Australia have announced record high profits.

Ken Rosewall, Lewis Hoad and Rex Hartwig, Australia's top tennis players, and Neale Fraser, a newcomer, were chosen yesterday to meet the United States team in the Davis Cup challenge round. The American squad will defend the international trophy at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, Aug. 26 to 28.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 17 -- The American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., charged here today that the National Education Association could no longer be considered a representative of teachers. It accused the association of a diversity of interests and an anti-union attitude.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 17 (UP) -- The Anaconda Company's local subsidiary announced today that it had increased its price for Chilean copper from 36 to 40 cents a pound.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Governor Harriman's committee assigned to study the finances of the state-owned Saratoga Spa has approved informally a plan to expand facilities at the Gideon Putnam Hotel with funds from a $400,000 bond issue.

TOKYO, Aug. 17 -- Friendly relations between Japan and Communist China seemed to be far off today. The principal foreign-policy spokesmen of both countries have issued extraordinarily inimical statements almost simultaneously.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A committee here of the Society of Friends (Quakers) invited Soviet tourists today to visit the "birthplace of American freedom."
CAIRO, Aug. 17 -- The Nile River attained the crest of its annual flood today but it was in manageable proportions. Egyptian cotton prospects are rosy.

FRASER, Col., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Mr. Alexander, 67 years old, is a contractor from Des Moines, Iowa. He was appointed by President Eisenhower last year as the first Republican Governor since civil government was established in the Virgin Islands in 1931.
BERGDORF GOODMAN, the blueblood store with a sophisticated following, opens its doors today to a younger crowd with slimmer pocketbooks.

The depths of political barbarism are apparently being pierced these days in Hungary by the puppet Communist regime there. Infuriated by it heir inability to stop the effective work of Radio Free Europe and the Free Europe Press in communicating truth to the Hungarian people through broadcasts and balloons, the Budapest regime is taking revenge upon helpless people, relatives of escaped Hungarians in the West working for these agencies.

"IF you wish," said Walter O'Malley, eyes twinkling mischievously, "you may call it Hurricane Dodger. And the core of the hurricane is now passing over Brooklyn." But the bland president of the Brooks didn't look the slightest bit wind-blown. He even seemed pleased at the storm he had created.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Of the 1,600,000 American fighting men engaged in the Korea War, 7,190 became prisoners of the enemy.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 17 -- The threat of a Government crisis in Singapore dwindled today. David Marshal, the Chief Minister, announced that he had received satisfactory assurances regarding eventual full self-government and the interpretation of the colony's present Constitution from Alan T. Lennox-Boyd, British Secretary of State for the Colonies.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (UP) -- A 5-year-old boy told the police today that he had shut the door of an old, unused refrigerator in which two young brothers were found suffocated last night.
WHAT'S good enough for the French is good enough for us. "The Skin of Our Teeth," which was acted at the Paris Festival last month, opened at the ANTA Theatre last evening.

For the first time in ninety-three years the Knights Templar of the United States, high ranking order of Masonry, will hold its triennial meeting in this city. The sessions will begin at dinner Saturday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Gov. Raymond Gary of Oklahoma headed a group that arrived here yesterday to attend the New York Summer Festival's "Oklahoma Song Fest" on the Central Park Mall on Sunday afternoon.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 17 -- The angler fortunate enough to take the largest bass in the forthcoming Vineyard Striper and Bluefish Derby will never again face accommodation problems on this island. He will have his own private fishing lodge.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 3 points up to 8 off, with the distant months weakest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington today approved a credit of $11,000,000 for railroad equipment to be bought here by Iran.

The Cunard Line announced yesterday that Princess Margaret would perform the naming ceremony of the company's new Carinthia when the vessel is launched at John Brown's Yard, Clydebank, Scotland, on Dec. 14.

As a Filipino reader of your distinguished newspaper I wish to concur in the sentiments expressed in your editorial the other day commenting on the clash in the Philippines between President Magsaysay and Senator Claro M. Recto.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- Massachusetts reported ninety-three new polio cases today.

The articles of Col. James C. Murray in The Marine Corps Gazette, as quoted and discussed by Hanson Baldwin on Aug. 12, deserve reply. On the second day of this month the United States deposited its instrument of ratification of the Geneva Conventions of 1949 for the Protection of War Victims.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- The Yankees' sizzling attack, which for the past few days has been piling up a staggering total of hits and runs, faded to a whisper tonight.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17 -- Four out of five mental patients being treated in veterans' hospitals eventually will be able to return to their romes. This forecast was made today by Harvey V. Higley, National Administrator of Veterans Affairs.

BACK in the days when Miss Fannie Merritt Farmer was conducting her famous cooking school in Boston, before the advent of the mechanical refrigerator or home freezer, desserts were frozen in a crank-turned apparatus. This method, though an arm-breaking chore, resulted in fluffy, smooth ices and sherbers as well as perfect ice creams.
The National Association of Blouse Manufacturers is planning a major effort to increase the style emphasis of its members' product.

THE world of television, the real, producing-acting world as distinct from the make-believe that invades so many living rooms still awaits fictional treatment in depth. Two years ago, Alfred Bester offered us a macabre glimpse in "Who He?" -- a novel that read, at times, like a psychiatrist's report from the violent ward.
ONEONTA, N. Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Governor Harriman said today that Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, had no proposals for solving problems of agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- A staff report to the Senate Interior Committee said today that Government red tape and timidity had retarded efforts to broaden use of the lightweight metal titanium in United States warplanes.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Six of the leading players drew their games in the ninth round of the national open chess championship tournament last night.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- A letter from the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, caused uncertainty today as to the Government's next step in the crisis in the French Protectorate.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 17 -- Southampton Day will be held on Tuesday at the Old Water Mill Shop for the Blind in Water Mill. The shop will be open from 10 A. M. until 6 P. M., and its Tea Room from noon until 6 P. M.

Sales and earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries for the three and six months ended June 30 were the highest for any quarter or half-year in its history. As a major world copper producer, the company's earnings have benefitted from the higher prices that prevailed for copper.
Cardinal Spellman returned to New York yesterday after a thirty-nine-day visit to Latin America.
The City Planning Commission yesterday approved four city housing projects planned as part of the $225,000,000 Federal-city public housing program.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 17 -- Gilbert Grandval, the Resident General, indicated today he was convinced a lasting settlement of the Moroccan crisis was impossible without the participation in the Sultan's government of the nationalist parties.
The nation's largest commercial producer of bituminous coal, the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, is entering the chemical processing field.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 17 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority said today its purchases during the 1955 fiscal year, which ened June 30, had totaled $84,411,261.

Charges and counter-charges of assault in the serving of a subpoena last month were made yesterday by a witness and a Government investigating attorney at the hearing here on communism in the theatre.
TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Charlie Sifford, a Philadelphia pro, carded a nine-under-par 63 for a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Canadian open golf championship today.
Police Inspector Thomas F. Patton applied for retirement yesterday, one day after he had been assigned to take over the Coney Island area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, denounced Democratic criticism of President Eisenhower's golf and vacations today. He said the President "can run his office as well from Gettysburg or Denver as from the White House."
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today a treaty of mutual understanding with Panama.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- For the first time in several years, theatrical entertainment in Yiddish is now being given in Moscow.
Mack Trucks, Inc., arranged yesterday to borrow $80,000,000 under a three-year revolving credit agreement with forty-eight banks headed by Bankers Trust Company.

CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 17 -- An expert on law drafting proposed today a complete revision of the State Penal Code. He urged a "modern" code to guide judges and others handling offenders. Frank Grad, a lawyer, sociologist and associate director of the Legislative Drafting Research Fund of Columbia University, called for a long-term study by the Legislature of the state's "haphazard" crime statutes in the light of new penological thinking.
New issues of corporate securities priced at more than $42,500,000 are being offered to investors today in underwritten transactions, as follows:

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower paused this morning between his palette and the trout stream to sign the new Executive Order governing the conduct of American fighting men in combat and captivity.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Florida Attorney General's office is studying a proposal under which a subsidiary of Standard Oil Company of California would conduct a $10,000,000 oil hunt under Florida off-shore any inland waters.
An underground garage, which would be the city's first, was proposed yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley and John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn.
Trans World Airlines is working out a plan to fly theatreminded persons to New York from various parts of the country.

Strategic Materials Corporation, Montreal, Que., announced yesterday development of a process for the economic treatment of low-grade manganiferous ores. John C. Udd, president, said the new process had "great promise" of freeing the North American Continent from reliance on foreign sources for manganese.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) -- England won a thrilling, closely-fought test series by three victories to two today, beating South Africa by 92 runs in the fifth match at the oval.

A building at 23-29 Sussex Avenue in Newark, N. J., containing 11,000 square feet of space, has been leased by the Aristocrat Plastics of New York. The structure, owned by John Talbot, will be used by the lessee for the manufacture of sheet plastics and allied items for use by the aircraft and electronics industries as well as for novelty items.

After a long series of negotiations, the Mutual Broadcasting System has submitted a contract to Walter Winchell for his signature. If the commentator signs it, he will begin a weekly radio broadcast over the network on Sunday, Sept. 11, from 6 to 6:15 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -The executive secretary of the Educational Policies Commission of the National Education Association, said today his commission had no intention whatever of criticizing private schools.
Under "Tyranny in Colombia" your editorial of Aug. 8 says there can be no democracy in Colombia until newspapers are allowed to publish freely all the news.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Government outlined today a plan for a major study of hurricane devastation and possible ways to minimize damage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UP) -- Turkish soldiers, "a pretty rugged race of people," probably stood up best to Communist prison treatment in the Korean conflict.

Will you please bring to the attention of the public, which has been most generous in the past, the plight of the Rockland Hospital Guild, a membership organization chartered and incorporated under the laws of the State of New York?
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- Communist party philosophers and propagandists are laying ideological foundations for the Soviet Union's new "internationalism."
First Deputy Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy by-passed the Brooklyn morals squad yesterday morning when he led a raid on a floating dice game in South Brooklyn.

For the first time in twenty-three years Jack Benny will not be on radio when the 1955-56 season begins next month. The comedian, who had been a fixture on Sundays from 7 to 7:30 P. M. since May, 1932, will devote himself in the future to television.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Despite cloudy weather and rain, thirty-eight clubs took part in the twelfth annual Hoffhine Memorial golf tourney today.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Teachers, A.F.L., moved today to underwrite the defense of three Newark school teachers who had been dismissed for invoking the Fifth Amendment.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Oscar M. Taylor of Albany, a Republican, has resigned from the State Civil Service Commission, paving the way for Democrats to take control of the three-member group.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced plans yesterday to expand substantially its synthetic rubber producing facilities at Houston, Tex.

Commodity futures were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, rubber, wool, hides and soybean oil eased; sugar, cocoa, zinc, lead and copper gained, and coffee and potatoes closed mixed.

John J. Bennett is to retire as chairman of the City Planning Commission and, consequently, Mayor Wagner has before him one of the most difficult and one of the most important appointments that he is called upon to make.

The face of Nassau County has changed drastically within the last ten years. Suffolk, the other suburban county on Long Island, is also beginning to change rapidly. Statistics about either county are obsolete almost as soon as they are published. However, they show plainly that the two counties' metamorphosis will have far-reaching influence on the future of the City of New York.
American Gas and Electric Company's net income for the year ended on July 31 topped $36,000,000 for the first time in any twelve months period in the Midwest company's history.
CANTON, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The most serious forms of male delinquency have been traced more often to the mother than to the father, a New Jersey psychiatrist reported today.
The Queens Chamber of Commerce mailed yesterday a stern rebuttal to a letter received Wednesday from Robert Moses.

The recent dramatic change of attitude by Soviet leaders toward the United States requires careful evaluations in three main categories: the basic reason for this change, prospects for the future and what our response should be.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Aug. 18 -- A polyglot world in miniature was abuilding here today as the majority of 10,000 Boy Scouts from sixty-four lands began to assemble for the Eighth World Jamboree, opening Saturday.

The industrial building at 251 Lee Avenue in Brooklyn has been leased by Sirac, Inc., from the Johnson Estates. The structure, in the Williamsburg section, contains 32,000 square feet of space. It will be used as general offices and for the manufacture and distribution of insulated plastic and textile bays, hats and plastic novelties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 George Killion, president of the American President Lines, and T. E. Cuffe, president of the Pacific Far East Line, announced today the creation of a jointly owned corporation. The new corporation will be American Bulk Cargoes, Inc.

The City of Elizabeth, N. J., sold yesterday $1,996,000 of sewer bonds due serially on Sept. 1 from 1956 to 1975 to R. W. Pressprich Co. and associates at a bid of 100.206 for obligations bearing interest of 2.65 per cent.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The management of Libby, McNeil Libby, giant food-packing company, claimed today to have won a proxy battle with an independent stockholders' committee.

MANILA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Agriculture Secretary Salvador Araneta today advocated increased trade with sterling-bloc countries, particularly Europe. He also suggested a four-year dollar "decontrol policy" to combat the Philippines' business recession and dwindling foreign exchange reserves.

The letter on the Hell's Canyon issue in The New York Times of Aug. 15 by Frank K. Van Arsdel completely ignores the findings of the Federal Power Commission's hearing examiner that the proposed high Federal dam would develop nearly twice as much prime power as the three Idaho Power Company low dams.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Argument over Negro participation in Little League baseball threatens a schism of some Southern groups from the parent organization.
Emerson-Garden Electric Co. space for New York executive headquarters, in new twenty-six story National Distillers Building at 99 Park Ave -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The United Nations Command, through General Parks, accused the Communists by letter of "wanton barbarism" in shooting down the unarmed trainer.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- Oceanographic institutions in the United States have been asked by the Atomic Energy Commission to consider the advisability of using the sea as a dumping ground for large amounts of radioactive waste products.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 18 -- Morocco was in a state of nerves today as the political crisis moved quickly but not quickly enough toward a denouement.
Erich Kleiber of Austria and Andre Cluytens of Belgium will conduct the Vienna Philharmonic when it makes a five-week tour of the United States, starting in November, 1956.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Argentine Senate approved tonight a bill giving Presdent Juan D. Peron power to put off until mid-1956 the loaded question of separation of the state and the church.

The decision of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission to inspect motorists' tires before allowing their cars on the toll highway is a sound safety technique -- and a strongly implied rebuke to New York State.

SUMMING up local food supplies and prices, the City Department of Markets says that "broiler-fryers merit special attention." They average 45 cents a pound. (The distinction between young chickens used for broiling and those for frying has disappeared; any tender bird of less than three and a half pounds, ready-to-cook weight, is a "broiler-fryer.")
RUSSELL, Mass., Aug. 18 (UP) -- Three cars and the locomotive of a Chicago-to-Boston passenger train were derailed today. The section of track had been undermined by the rain-swollen Westfield River.
The stock market yesterday was an indecisive affair. After some gains in the early trading, prices began to ease a bit, and final quotations were thoroughly mixed.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Gov. Christian A. Herter, a Republican, had asked permission to speak to the Massachusetts Legislature to seek revival of a once-rejected $150,000,000 highway bond issue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Walter A. Gordon, chairman of the California Adult Authority, the state pardon board, was reported today to be the choice of the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay, to be Governor of the Virgin Islands.

The reaction of Premier Bulganin to the President's proposal for armament inspection suggests that the time may be ripe for considering a basic solution for this vital problem. As Mr. Bulganin says, it would be possible for Russia or any large country to hide enough nuclear weapons to prevent any other country from safely disarming.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 18 -- Shukri al-Kuwatly will become President of Syria for the third time Sept. 6, succeeding the aging Hashem al-Atassi.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today made public a preliminary award to the Georgia-Pacific Alaska Corporation of 7,500,000,000 board feet of timber in the Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Harry Hopman, captain of the Australian Davis Cup team, today accused American tennis officials of "impertinence."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Riding winners of Saratoga's Beverwyck Steeplechase is getting to be a habit with Pat Smithwick. Today, astride Mrs. Michael G. Walsh's Rythminhim, he cut in for the winning jockey's share of a Beverwyck purse for the fourth year in succession.

A Code of Conduct for American servicemen and the report on which it was based, both released on Wednesday, call attention to one of the most difficult problems that free societies in the modern world have to face. We may make a beginning by the observation that there is a very simple way of understanding the problem of the prisoner of war who is mistreated.
Briggs, Schaedle Co., Discount Corporation of New York and First Boston Corporation raised the rate on bankers' acceptances by 1/8 of one percentage point yesterday.

Jim Hearn, the winningest pitcher the Giants have this season, intimated that he did not have that loose feeling before he took the mound against the Dodgers yesterday at the Polo Grounds. He didn't. Because two outs, five hits and three runs later, the big right-hander was on his way to a first-inning shower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The United States indicated today that it would report to the United Nations General Assembly next month the progress of its efforts to establish a permanent international agency on the peaceful use of atomic energy.

Motorists traveling in the metropolitan area this weekend may expect detours or delays, because of repairs, new construction or congestion, on the following routes (the numbers correspond to those on the map):
" CLIMAX!" provided an absorbing hour of television on Channel 2 last night in its dramatization of a true story of an athlete's winning fight against mental illness.

Manning M. Exton, budget director of Seabrook Farms Company, Bridgeton, N .J., was elected a vice president of that company yesterday at a meeting of its board of directors. Also elected by the board of the large integrated farming and food freezing concern were Elmer N. Sprenkel, who becomes treasurer, and John R. Kiessling, who was named controller.

CAIRO, Aug. 18 -- The Egyptian negotiator in the Gaza border talks with Israel indicated today that the talks were deadlocked. He said the deadlock occurred because Egypt wanted the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization to be more of an active third party in the proposed arrangement than did Israel.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the nine months ended July 31 achieved the highest sales and earnings for any similar period in its history, according to figures announced yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 18 -- The United Nations Command protested today against the shooting down of an unarmed United States training plane in the Korean demilitarized zone yesterday by Communist anti-aircraft fire.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A Government loyalty board has decided to reopen hearings in the case of William Henry Taylor, assistant director of the Middle Eastern Department of the International Monetary Fund.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 3 per cent above those in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The Strategic Air Command's new eight-engine jet bomber, the B-52, will be saluted by Warner Brothers in a motion picture tentatively titled "Flight Line Chief."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Two chief justices disagreed today on whether judicial opinions should be short or long.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- The development of a new technology for transferring heat at high temperatures will result in "significant reductions in the cost of nuclear power" derived from atomic energy, according to reports presented here today.
New Jersey has thrown up a fifty-mile defense line along its northern frontier to prevent an aerial invasion from New York. The enemy is the gypsy moth, an annihilator of tree foliage.

Twenty thousand commuters were late to work yesterday morning when twenty - seven trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad were delayed getting into Grand Central Terminal in the rush hours.

Customers of the grocery store at 245 Howard Avenue, Brooklyn, not only brought home the bacon but sometimes brought along a typewriter, an adding machine or even a full suit of clothes -- all brand new.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- A force of police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents ended one of Chicago's largest manhunts tonight. They captured Richard Carpenter, 26 years old, who was wanted for the murder of one policeman and the wounding of another.

The post of chairman of the City Planning Commission becomes vacant at the end of this month with the regretted retirement of John J. Bennett. It will not be an easy job for Mayor Wagner to fill well. The planning function has never received the attention or the respect it deserves in New York.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Aug. 18 -- Reconstruction of the unity of Central America is the most fundamental and urgent problem facing it, President Carlos Castillo Armas declared today. The President of Guatemala spoke at the first formal meeting of the Organization of Central American States.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The General Electric Company will open next week a $5,000,000 laboratory to develop new materials for satellites and stoves, jet turbines and television tubes. It is said to be the world's most complete workshop for creating metals and ceramics tough enough for tomorrow's machinery of war and peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- John G. Adams, former Army counsel, revealed today that he had joined a firm of criminal lawyers here. He was a central figure in the 1954 hearings involving the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Eleese Thornton of Los Angeles today won the senior women's singles crown at the American Tennis Association National Championships.

Bernard J. O'Connell, City Commissioner of Licenses, renewed yesterday the motion-picture theatre license of the Times Theatre, Eighth Avenue and West Forty-second Street. Mr. O'Connell's decision, in effect, put the theatre on probation, as he announced that, if its management did not keep its promise not to use indecent outdoor displays of photographs and advertisements, he would revoke the license without hesitation.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Homer H. Kirby, Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, today concluded hearings on a petition by the New York, New Haven and Hartford, Boston and Maine and Delaware and Hudson Railroads to pool freight traffic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Swings in grain futures prices were irregular today. New low seasonal prices were set for some deliveries, but there were occasional rallies as short profit-taking broadened and selling pressure waned.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Warren Spahn tonight scored his second victory in four nights and the fortieth of his career over the St. Louis Cardinals. The Milwaukee Braves won, 5 -- 3, with Bill Bruton driving in two runs and Chuck Tanner one on homers.

William B. Herlands, a Federal, state and city prosecutor in charge of racket investigations for many years, was sworn in yesterday as a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York. The oath was administered by Chief District Court Judge William Bondy in the United States Court House at Foley Square.

C. A. Olsen Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of gas and oil-fired warm air home heating units, has called a special meeting of stockholders on Sept. 7 to vote on sale of its assets. Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation on Wednesday approved the purchase of the assets of the Olsen organization.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's wheat exports declined slightly in the first eleven months of the last crop year while shipments from all her competitors increased.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- Communist China deferred for the eighth time today a reply to United States demands for the release of the forty United States citizens imprisoned in or otherwise prevented from leaving mainland China.

For some reason, everything has been hush hush regarding Maxwell Anderson's theme in his forthcoming play. Although it could not be verified from official sources yesterday, it was learned that the central character is Richard III. Instead of depicting him as the bloody king of popular conception, he emerges in the untitled script as a maligned hero.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- South Korea has asked the United Nations to disband the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission, established to control observance of the armistice of 1953.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 18 (AP) -- An airman from Hunter Air Force Base near Savannah was killed early today when an automobile struck a bridge on the Savannah Beach Highway and overturned.
The Waterfront Commission reserved decision yesterday on a plea to rehear charges against 138 dockworkers who participated in a port-wide pier strike in the spring of 1954.
DAVISVILLE, R. I., Aug. 18 (UP) -- Two hundred Seabees bound for the South Pole received a message of congratulations today from Admiral Richard E. Byrd.

GENEVA, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- A United States atomic expert forecast today that doctors of the future would hand out radioactive pills instead of medicine bottles when their patients come to them with aches and pains.
Production and consumption of newsprint in July maintained record levels for the seventh straight month this year, according to reports by trade groups yesterday.

Eight ships of a Royal Canadian Navy task group moved smartly into port here yesterday morning. They will be here until Monday. By noon blue-clad seamen and khaki-uniformed officers from the vessels could be seen making their way to the Polo Grounds, the theatres, and other attractions of the city.

Bernard M. Baruch, son of a Confederate surgeon, distinguished citizen of this Republic and of this city for more years than most of us can remember, reaches today the age of 85. We delight to do him honor. He is one of those men gifted in the art of making money who did not choose to devote the major part of his attention to doing so.

Catastrophe looms in Brooklyn. The cloud no larger than a hand against the sky when President O'Malley announced that the Dodgers would play seven home games in Jersey City next season quickly darkened the whole enclave of Flatbush.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Aneurin Bevan suggested today that the story told by Col. John Knox Arnold Jr. about his torture at the hands of the Chinese Communists was faked.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 Gov. William G. Stratton of Illinois today called for the "draft by acclamation" of President Eisenhower as a candidate for reelection.
Meetings of all seven locals of the Furriers Joint Council of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., were scheduled yesterday for next week.

CLOTHES that light up when an automobile headlight shines on them are now available at B. Altman Co. Except under the direct beam of a headlight, the garments look just like any others. They may be washed or cleaned, and pressed.
A military court of eight officers sitting in judgment on Sgt. James C. Gallagher adjourned last night after deliberating for three hours.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- The Salt Lake City Mormon Tabernacle Choir arrived today at Greenock aboard the Cunard liner Saxonia to begin a tour of Britain and major cities of Europe.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- The Plymouth division of Chrysler Corporation, getting an early start on 1956 model production, is manufacturing 600 new V-8 engines a day at a new $50,000,000 plant here.
Chadbourn Hosiery Mills and Burlington Hosiery Company have formed a new concern -- Patentex, Inc. -- to grant licenses for the manufacture of women's sheer stretch hosiery.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 18 -- Violence by the pro-German parties led to action today by the international commission named to supervise the referendum to decide the Saar's future.

This is written after reading the first of your articles on Saratoga Springs. I would like to offer my own impressions and suggestions, uncolored by others', resulting from a four-day visit to the springs.

Governor Harriman has decided to appoint Roger Tubby, former press secretary of President Harry S. Truman and more recently press adviser to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., to the State Department of Commerce.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- One of Britain's new, semi - secret Charioteer tanks broke loose from its moorings on a hill on Salisbury Plain before dawn today. It crashed into the rear of two other tanks, starting them on a course of death through a camp full of sleeping soldiers.

In the past only five to ten hurricanes a century used to range as far as the middle and northeastern states. Now, in less than one year, five have plowed their way through this section of the country -- two within the last eight days -- and the season has only just begun.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The Soviet agricultural delegates picked their first grapes today after a full month in the United States.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The defending singles champions had little trouble today advancing to the semi-finals in the twenty-ninth annual public parks tennis tournament.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 18 -- The United States unveiled a secret weapon in the "cold war" with devastating effect today. It was a model electric train and the wail of its whistle seemed an irresistible call to all who heard it.

THE more liberal waterfowl season granted by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service came as a pleasant surprise to wildfowlers, who now will have the pleasure of debating the opening and closing dates of this season in their individual states.

G. Ilivitsky, Russian grandmaster, was overtaken yesterday in the interzone chess tournament at Goteborg. He drew in the third round with Laszio Szabo of Hungary, according to Swedish news sources. Szabo resorted to the King's Indian defense and halved the point in thirty-five moves.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Canada accused the Soviet Union today of deliberately giving a distorted and untrue picture of Canada in the latest edition of the "Great Soviet Encyclopaedia."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A team of special investigators and attorneys of the Securities and Exchange Commission was dispatched to the agency's Denver office today to aid the staff there in "an intensive inspection'' of stock brokers and dealers in the Colorado-Utah area.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18 -- The eighth annual American Dance Festival under the auspices of Connecticut College opened in Palmer Auditorium here tonight with the first performances in modern dance idiom.
Joseph P. Ryan, life president emeritus of the International Longshoremen's Association, was indicted yesterday on income tax evasion charges.

Plans for replacing nine tenement houses at 315-21 East Seventy-second Street through to 310-18 East Seventy-third Street with two modern apartment buildings were announced yesterday by Joseph Sager Sons, builders, who have bought the site.
Downtown retail stores' difficulty in competing with suburban shopping centers was attributed yesterday to the outmoded physical facilities of many big-city stores.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- The Knights of Columbus went on record today opposing the admission of Communist China into the United Nations.
Mayor Wagner started a campaign last night to have products manufactured here bear the label, "Made in New York -- Fashion Center of the World."
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Joseph M. Swing, the Immigration Commissioner, announced today that all foreign students entering the United States would be required to sign an oath swearing that they understood their responsibilities under the law.
Future ship construction subsidies will be based on the most comprehensive foreign cost studies ever made by Government maritime authorities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Coast Guard disclosed today that it was running security checks on fourteen men in addition to N. Pierre Gaston.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Marine Corps today ordered production of a radical new anti-tank destroyer known as Ontos, in Greek roughly "The Thing."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party will offer an apology for permitting violently anti-American Soviet propaganda to be printed in its official journal.
On Friday, Aug. 5, at 4:25 P. M., a woman was hit by a city bus, and badly injured, near the corner of Duane Street and Park Row.
People are already returning home from faraway places, visited on vacations, exclaiming how beautiful was this place, how lovely that (with pictures to prove it).

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Dr. David E. Price, Assistant Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, predicted today "a future in which the threat of paralytic polio will diminsh to the vanishing point."

The National Better Business Bureau is taking action to protect the public's confidence in advertising by curbing what it calls "fictitious and unbelievable comparative price advertising." This is the type of copy that offers an item at a certain price and says it formerly was sold at a higher price or is worth much more.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18 -- A four-day strike of some 300 office employes of the Supreme Council of the Knights of Columbus ended today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, noted an "extraordinary coincidence" today. He said the Idaho Power Company's plans to build dams in Hell's Canyon coincided strangely with the Federal Power Commission's ruling permitting the company to go ahead with the projects.
A MAXIMUM of invention and a minimum of investments combined to create this comfortable and unusual summer home just outside Aspen, Colo., for cartoonist Garth Williams and his wife.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that Government agencies might use "quickie" procedures to dismiss workers on charges of inefficiency.

Today's new film is "Female On the Beach," a Universal-International suspense drama starring Joan Crawford, Jeff Chandler and Jan Sterling, at the Palace. Robert Hill and Richard Alan Simmons wrote the scenario, based on a play by Robert Hill. The film was directed by Joseph Pevney and produced by Albert Zugsmith.

THE 30,000 Knights Templar who come to town tomorrow for their week-long Forty-sixth Triennial Conclave are the elder statesmen of Masonry. It is ninety-three years (1862) since they turned out in jeweled splendor for their last previous New York City conclave.

Members of the Navy, Air Force, Coast Guard and National Guard will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. The donations will be made at the Naval Air Station, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.
The House Un-American Activities Committee ended yesterday four days of hearings on Communist infiltration into the entertainment world.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18 -- Political tension here rose sharply today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox enjoyed a few hours of leading the American League today after defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 6 to 2, in the opener of a twin bill. But they dropped the second game, 5 -- 3, and fell back into second place.

Roy Campanella has played baseball for at least eight months a year almost every year since 1937. He actively manages a thriving retail liquor business. He is raising a family of six children. He takes a keen interest in community affairs.
TORONTO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer, 1954 United States amateur titleholder, took the lead in the Canadian open golf championship today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- Fifteen hundred West German citizens, 120 news correspondents and a few soccer players have begun to arrive in Moscow.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Friday, Aug. 19 -- Heavy rains that inundated highways in the extreme western part of Orange County caused the evacuation of some vacationists and residents in low-lying areas early today.
YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- A heavy rainstorm that made the track sloppy and unsafe forced postponement tonight of the first William H. Cane Futurity at Yonkers Raceway.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Art Fowler pitched a six-hitter today to help the Cincinnati Redlegs gain a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

After starting the Geneva talks on the release of the American civilians with the hopeful gesture of liberating the American fliers the Chinese Communist regime is now revealing its real purpose, which has thus far deadlocked the talks themselves.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Three fielding lapses -- two by Al Kaline in right field -- opened the gates for Cleveland in the eighth inning today and the Indians poured across four runs to beat the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 3.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Donald Byrne of the University of Michigan captured first place last night in the open tournament of the United States Chess Federation.
Eight amendments and one paragraph of the United States Constitution have been cited by uncooperative witnesses at the hearings into Communist penetration of the theatre.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States hopes to extend to the whole world the principle of President Eisenhower's plan for an exchange of military blueprints and for mutual arms inspection by air.
FRASER, Col., Aug. 18 -- The peace was as deep as the blue of the Rockies today at President Eisenhower's mountain vacation retreat.

With a warning that future witnesses defying the new Compulsory Testimony Act would be jailed for at least two and a half years, Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh yesterday sentenced Edward J. Fitzgerald to a six-month term for contempt.

Moore-McCormack Lines and Local 895, International Longshoremen's Association, will share the cost of about a month's back pay for William McMahon, a former fork-lift driver for the steamship company on Pier 32, North River.
GENEVA, Aug. 18 -- Members of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy of the United States Congress commended the Geneva atoms for peace conference today as "very worthwhile" and "a real success."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 18 -- At least 2,000,000 handicapped persons in the United States are capable of being employed and now need jobs, Maj. Gen. Melvin J. Maas, chairman of the President's Committee on Employment of the Physically Handicapped, said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The United States hopes to extend to the whole world the principle of President Eisenhower's plan for an exchange of military blueprints and for mutual arms inspection by air.
FRASER, Col., Aug. 18 -- The peace was as deep as the blue of the Rockies today at President Eisenhower's mountain vacation retreat.

With a warning that future witnesses defying the new Compulsory Testimony Act would be jailed for at least two and a half years, Federal Judge Lawrence E. Walsh yesterday sentenced Edward J. Fitzgerald to a six-month term for contempt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 775,397 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,945 cars or 1.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 90,125 cars or 13.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 32,225 cars or 4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Two of the major United States airlines yesterday began through service between New York and the principal cities of South America.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- Massachusetts reported eighty new polio cases today but health officials still believed that the outbreak would start to recede soon.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- A serious impasse was reached in the national doubles tennis championships today, and for the first time within memory play in the men's tournament will be conducted indoors tomorrow.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 18 -- Led by Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the left-wing People's Action party, almost half of the members walked out of today's session of Singapore's Legislative Assembly.

The short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on Monday amounted to 2,823,446 shares, the exchange reported yesterday. This compares with 2,739,976 shares on July 15.
Control of Tiffany Co., a New York landmark and international synonym for quality for more than a century, has passed from its founding families.
TOKYO, Aug. 18 -- Relations between Japan and South Korea appeared near a complete breakdown today.
Refusal to sign statements of non-membership in organizations on the Attorney General's subversive list may result in five families being evicted from public housing projects here.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The United States State Department warned the 900 German employes of the United States mission here today to be on their constant guard against Communist attempts to recruit them as spies.

A major expansion and reorganization of the air defense of the United States now is in progress. When completed, it will strengthen greatly the defensive capability of the nation. The program involves an increase next month of the number of air divisions -- each of varying size -- in the Air Defense Command from twelve to sixteen.

News in the electronics field came from widely separated points yesterday. Here in New York at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel, Raytheon Manufacturing Company showed for the first time a "fully transistorized" portable radio.

THE new home of the Dodgers -- when, as and if it is constructed -- will be the fifth ball park to house Brooklyn's entry in the National League. It is to be hoped that Walter O'Malley won't make the mistake that was made by his ancient predecessor as president of the Dodgers, Charlie Ebbets.

Ann Bridge, whose novels have settings in many countries of the world, is the wife of a British diplomat whose duties took him to those parts of the globe. With her husband's retirement from his last post, Ambassador to Portugal, she now has written the book she wanted to write for twenty years.
PARIS, Aug. 18 -- The Cabinet rejected today an attempt by the Moroccan Sultan, Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, to form a Government of only his own followers in the French Protectorate.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Sam Boulmetis scored his third consecutive victory and fourth of the afternoon aboard G. M. Cohen's Chuck Thompson in the feature on grass today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The production of entertainment films for television is underway again after the termination yesterday of the strike by the Screen Actors Guild.

COMSTOCK, N. Y., Aug. 18 (UP) -- Armed state police officers and guards charged into a mob of convicts at the Great Meadows State Prison today and broke up a ten-hour sitdown strike in a thirty-minute battle that left eighteen persons injured.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending Aug. 17 decreased $67,000,000 to $18,757,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Moore - McCormack Lines has opened a $12,000,000 damage suit against the estates of the chief mate and the chief engineer of its freighter Mormackite. The vesssl foundered in a storm last Oct. 7 and thirty-seven men were lost, including the two named officers.

A retail outlet is planned by Bond Stores, Inc., at the Mid-Island Shopping Plaza under construction in Hicksville, L. I. The clothing store chain has leased 25,200 square feet of space on the first floor and in the basement. Plans call for the space to be ready for occupancy in September.
It isn't the heat and it isn't the humidity, either. It's worse than that. A combination of at least four factors determines whether a person is or is not comfortable outside in the summer.
Loans to business by New York City banks climbed $123,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Never liking to let Brooklyn get too far ahead, the owners of the New York Giants called yesterday for city aid in finding a new home for the Polo Grounders -- as well as the Dodgers.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The British telegraph ship Monarch completed today the laying of 1,300 miles of the deep-water section of the first trans-Atlantic telephone cable.

A final wish was granted yesterday to an 80-year-old Brooklyn mother before her eyesight fails completely. Her Army sergeant son stationed in Heidelberg, Germany, arrived by air so she could have a last glimpse of him.

MONTREAL Aug. 18 (UP) -- Representatives of the Walter Reed Swim Club of Washington broke three Dominion records tonight in the opening-day events of the Canadian swimming and diving championships. Eight Canadian records were shattered.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees and the Red Sox had to settle for a draw today when rain washed out the third and final game of the series.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Richard Ward of Washington broke two national records and Jon Tarantino of San Francisco bettered a third today in the second day of the annual national fly casting tournament.
THE creative cook must reckon in noodles when she looks around for dishes that not only are quick but also extend an invitation to the appetite.

LISBON, Portugal, Saturday, Aug. 20 (Reuters) -- The Portuguese Foreign Ministry, in a communiqu issued early today, denounced India's decision to close her consulates in Goa and to ask Portugal to close her consulates in Bombay, Calcutta and Madras.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- New violence, in which a demonstrator was killed, broke out tonight at Nantes, French shipbuilding center. The disorder was a sequel to labor riots and a bombing that left scores of injured yesterday.
Sgt. James C. Gallagher was found guilty yesterday of the murder of two fellow prisoners of war and flagrant collaboration with the enemy in the Korean prison camps.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 19 -- India broke her last diplomatic ties with the Government of Portugal today.
WICK, Scotland, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Twenty-nine crewmen of a fire-wrecked freighter leaped one by one into the North Atlantic today and were plucked to safety by lifeboats of the liner Kungsholm.
The aircraft carrier Ticonderoga played host to nearly 5,000 visitors yesterday at Pier 88, Hudson River, at Forty-eighth Street.

The operation of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor cost the longshore industry $2,117,959 during the fiscal year ended June 30. This figures to approximately $64 a year for every registered longshoreman.
The city has worked out a tentative agreement that would assure continued operation of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway.

During the post-Korean recession the nation's output of goods and services (or gross national product) declined from an annual rate of $369.9 billions in the second quarter of 1953 to a rate of $357.6 billions in the second quarter of 1954, or by $12.3 billions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- More than 400,000 room air conditioners were sold in July, making that month the biggest in the history of the air-conditioning industry, Bernard A. Mitchell, president of the Mitchell Manufacturing Company, Chicago, said today.
A helicopter pilot with a war-proved knack for unorthodox rescues displayed his talent again in yesterday's flood crisis.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- A record rainstorm pounded Massachusetts today, causing at least eleven deaths and damage running into the millions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower increased duties on all imported bicycles by 50 per cent today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 19 (AP) -- West Germany's Lufthansa Airline will start trans-polar service to the west coast of the United States within two years, Dr. Hans Christian Seebohm, Minister of Transport, said today.

Sotir Falli and his sons, Dhori and Peter, manufacturing furriers, bought the three-story business building at 281 East Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, from Frank Newman in a deal negotiated by Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker.

The Catholic War Veterans of the U. S. A. adopted a resolution yesterday opposing recognition of Red China or her admission to the United Nations. The organization commended the anti- Communist work of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON Aug. 19 -- United States Customs and Post Office authorities have set up new ground rules to eliminate delay and interference in the delivery of materials printed behind the Iron Curtain to scholars, students and newsmen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The impending Public Health Service report on polio cases that followed inoculation by Cutter vaccine is expected to criticize inadequate Federal safety standards, rather than the Cutter Laboratories in Berkeley, Calif.

MARKED TREE, Ark., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Four cars of the Frisco Railroad's Kansas City to Florida special jumped the track here today. Five persons were killed, including a mother and her 18-month-old son when a car was demolished.

Delegates of the New York State Department of the American Legion, at the thirty-seventh annual convention held in Buffalo, "approved a resolution calling for $100 a month pensions for World War I veterans." Apparently this would be paid to all such veterans, regardless of need.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Storms sweeping northward from the Atlantic swamped Connecticut today, creating the worst floods in the state's history.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- The biggest question mark of Soviet agriculture today is written in dust over Kazakhstan and western Siberia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- George Bernard Shaw's great comedy, "The Devil's Disciple," will be made into a motion picture by Hecht-Lancaster Productions if negotiations now under way are concluded.
"Much Ado About Nothing" was presented at Stratford, Conn., yesterday as the American Shakespeare Festival's third production of its inaugural season.
YONKERS, Aug. 19 -- Billy Haughton drove John Froelich's colt Quick Chief to a neck victory in the $71,040 William H. Cane Futurity Pace at the Yonkers Raceway tonight.
NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Aug. 19 -- Ten thousand Boy Scouts from sixty-four countries looked each other over today, shook hands and were soon busy in one of the biggest trade deals ever.
Bernard M. Baruch financier, "elder statesman," and genial park bench philosopher, celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday quietly yesterday.

The five-story residence with limestone facade at 18 East Seventy-fourth Street has been sold by Miss Ann MacCarthy to Col. Jackson Matthews of the Air Force Reserve. Colonel Matthews resides here and in Peru, Vt.

The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A. F. L., announced yesterday that its fight for control of New York's dock workers would not be slowed by "so - called mutual-aid pacts" signed by rival organizations.
WOONSOCKET, R. I., Aug. 19 (AP) -- A massive section of Horseshoe Dam burst under pressure tonight, spilling tons of water over a four-square-mile area of congested tenements and small stores.
GENEVA, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Atomic energy advisers to the world's four largest banks met today to discuss some of the financial problems related to peaceful atomic developments.
American parents will have to pay about 10 per cent more for an imported bicycle this Christmas than last.

Seven hundred and forty-six pints of blood were collected by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Thursday, the most contributed on any one day this month. Two-hundred and eleven pints were donated at the New York Telephone Company, 435 West Fiftieth Street, 209 at the International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue, and 207 at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, where employee of financial and other companies were donors.

The Commerce Department, following the advice of the State Department, is now planning to spend approximately 65 per cent of its available exhibition funds to participate in seven important Asian trade fairs. The United States has a display at the current Jakarta fair in Indonesia, and will also exhibit at coming fairs in Karachi, Pakistan; New Delhi, India; Phom-penh, Cambodia; Bangkok, Thailand; Colombo, Ceylon, and Tokyo.

Hans Schwieger resigned yesterday as general music director and conductor of the Aspen Music Festival in Colorado. In a statement to the press he charged that Aspen officials had provided "unworkable orchestral conditions."

RIFLE, Colo., Aug. 19 -- Just a few miles from some of the nation's busiest uranium mines engineers are preparing for an oil shale production test that may prove as important to the consuming public as the more widely publicized prospects for nuclear power.

In the current negotiations in Geneva between U. Alexis Johnson, United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, and Wang Ping-nan, Peiping's Ambassador to Poland, one of the major snags is Red China's demand that a neutral power be allowed to question each of the 4,020- odd Chinese presently in the United States about his desire to return to mainland China.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Fifteen nations that sent men to the Korean war moved today to make the Allied Military Cemetery near Pusan a permanent United Nations memorial.

Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, House Minority Leader, said yesterday that despite his close relations with President Eisenhower, "I do not think anybody has the inside information on his running again for President unless it is Mamie Mrs. Eisenhower]."
A 1956 capital budget allocation of $127,500,000 for new school projects was asked yesterday by the Board of Education at a hearing before the City Planning Commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The second-place Chicago White Sox rode to a 3-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers on Billy Pierce's six-hit southpaw pitching and Walt Dropo's two-run homer tonight. The victory kept the Chicagoans one game behind the league-leading Yankees in the torrid American League pennant race.
After all the dock and trucking turmoil in and around New York two evidences this week of orderly and peaceful labor relations in these fields deserve special public recognition.
TRENTON, Aug. 19 -- While flood waters lapped at the back of the State House today, a legislative hearing inside grappled with another problem: the water shortage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Mr. Gordon was nominated by the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay. He has built a national reputation as a penologist during eleven years on the State Adult Authority, eight of them as chairman. The agency is concerned with pardons and paroles.

New Yorkers who desire to be properly outfitted for the weather are advised to take off their rubbers and get out their fans. A new heat wave of at least two days' duration is to start today, according to the 11 o'clock weather forecast last night.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Aug. 19 -- A mutiny broke out Wednesday among soldiers of the Equatoria Corps of the Sudan Defense Force at Torit in southern Sudan. The events, news of which came to light today, have become a serious threat to the security of the whole of Equatoria province.

TORONTO, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Denbeigh Taylor of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, skippered his six-meter yacht Bibis to victory today in the opening race of the three-day George Cup competition.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Heavy rains and floods created disaster in areas in three sections of Litchfield County today and isolated many small towns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Civil Air Patrol asked its organizations in four states -- Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and New York -- today to get ready to help rescue or bring relief to flood victims.
