Keeping up the initiative which has made the United States the leading champion of peace and disarmament, President Eisenhower has in preparation a new armament reduction and control program which will be submitted to the United Nations Disarmament subcommittee later this month.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The Walter Reed Hospital Swim Club team of Washington set a world record tonight in the women's senior 400-yard medley relay at the Canadian championships. The time of 4:30.5 was almost two seconds better than the club's own previous world mark of 4:32.4.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The International Typographical Union has voted to continue the operation of newspapers in cities and towns where there are newspaper strikes.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 -- Msgr. Albino Mensa of Buenos Aires protested tonight the resurgence of a Government campaign of "columny" against the Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and northern producers have negotiated the first wage increase for soft coal miners in three years, an informed source said today.

New York department and specialty stores, their stocks of summer fashions depleted and their fall merchandise not yet in demand by the public, were hard put this week to maintain a satisfactory selling pace.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 13 points off to 3 points up yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 19 -- The Turkish revolution is one of this century's remarkable phenomena. When the First World War ended the Ottoman Empire, long considered Europe's Sick Man, came apart. Yet within less than two generations a national renaissance begun by the remarkable Kemal Ataturk has made this country a dynamic force.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Clement R. Attlee, former Prime Minister, suffered a cerebral thrombosis about ten days ago but is now completely recovered, his wife said today.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 19 -Information - hungry Soviet agriculturists ate citrus fruit, drank its juice and studied it today.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 19 -- After long and bitter debate the convention of the American Federation of Teachers, A. F. L., voted today to suspend the charter of any of its local unions that practice segregation.

TORONTO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer shot an eight-under-par 64 today for a three-round total of 195 to lead the field in the Canadian open golf championship. The Latrobe (Pa.) pro is making his first bid this season on the tournament circuit.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Roger Tubby, who was press secretary to former President Harry S. Truman, will be appointed chief of information and promotion in the State Commerce Department, it was announced today.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 19 -- The Soviet Union beat the United States on the volleyball court this afternoon in a setting redolent of the spirit of coexistence, cooperation and goodwill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Bondholders and the State of New Jersey would profit under the terms of an amended reorganization plan of the New Jersey and New York Railroad proposed today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Activity in the new capital market is expected to be stepped up next week, with local governments claiming much of the spotlight.
Coffee and rubber were sharply higher and cocoa prices tumbled yesterday on the New York exchanges. All three commodities registered heavy volume.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100) during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Higher average prices for processed foods were chiefly responsible for the rise.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 19 -- It was suggested today that if the violence in the Saar referendum campaign continued, the European commission overseeing it might appeal to the Council of Ministers of the Western European Union for new instructions.

The last time the northeastern states felt anything like yesterday's floods was in March, 1936. For two weeks rampaging rivers from Virginia to Maine wrought more than $500,000,000 damage in thirteen states, caused the deaths of 168 persons and left 429,000 others homeless.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Navy reported today it had fired rockets seventeen miles into the upper air above a jet plane from which they were launched at 30,000 feet.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) -Saved again by the sensational relief pitching of Don Rossi and Ray Narleski, the Cleveland Indians beat the Kansas City Athletics, 2 -- 1, tonight on eleventh inning singles by Hal Naragon, Ralph Kiner and Dale Mitchell.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Share prices continued weak and business shrank again on the stock markets here today. Business this week was the smallest since the end of April.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Northampton was one of a series of municipal islands in rain-swept western Massachusetts today.

RED BLUFF, Calif., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Airman Daniel C. Schmidt fried a divorce complaint in the Tehama County courthouse here today. He charged his twice-married wife Una with "extreme cruelty" and unfitness as a mother.

The Soviet press is giving its readers a somewhat more optimistic picture of this year's agricultural accomplishments in Kazakhstan than has been reported by the American agricultural delegation that visited there.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug 19 -- Larry Evans of New York, the defending champion, went into a triple tie for first place in the open tournament of the United States Chess Federation last night by defeating Donald Byrne, the 1953 winner.

TORONTO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The next world convention of the Churches of Christ (Disciples) will be held the summer of 1960 in Edinburgh, Scotland, it was announced today by Dr. Jesse M. Bader of New York. Dr. Bader is general secretary of the fifth world convention, meeting here.
BISMARCK, N. D., Aug. 19 (AP) -- A shortage of storage space and boxcars combined with a bumper wheat harvest was causing dumping of grain on the ground in North Dakota.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to Senator Richard F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, and Representative Jere Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, chairmen of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees, explaining his action today in increasing the import duties on bicycles:

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The newspaper Asahi said today Japan would drop her demand for territorial rights on Southern Sakhalin and the Kuriles in the present peace talks with the Soviet Union in London.
Severe floods struck large areas of the northeastern United States yesterday.

Directors of the Patican Company, Ltd., and Patino Enterprises of Canada, Ltd., two Canadian mining investment companies, have agreed to a merger plan. Under the proposal Patican would acquire the business and assets of Patino Enterprises through an exchange of two shares of Patican for every three shares of Patino Enterprises.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Aug. 19 -- Units of the French Foreign Legion stationed at Meknes were rushed to Khenifra in Central Morocco today to relieve a police station besieged by 800 nationalists demonstrators.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The Connecticut legislation that forbids the Greenwich Water Company to supply water in times of shortages to its New York State neighbors, Port Chester and Rye, will be signed into law by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19. (AP) --- Roland Williams of Baytown, Tex., today won the skish accuracy fly event and Warren Rector of Oklahoma City finished in front in the five-eighths-ounce skish accuracy bait event at the annual national fly casting tournament.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Sir Alexander Knox Helm, Governor General of the Sudan, proclaimed a state of emergency in the three southern Sudan provinces early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19(AP) -- A former Democratic Cabinet officer denounced today what he called a "ridiculous outcry" against business men who work in Government without compensation while drawing salaries from private corporations.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 -- Oddities do not bob up exclusively in Brooklyn. Sometimes the unusual happens elsewhere -Forbes Field, for instance, where the Pirates beat the Giants tonight, 8-3. Among other things proved in this encounter before 9,695 fans, was that even the "smart" ones miss 'em on occasion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Aug. 19 -Walt Disney's latest television show, the hour-long "Mickey Mouse Club," will have its premiere over the A. B. C.-TV network on Oct. 3. The Monday through Friday filmed variety program will be seen at 5 P. M. in all time zones.

GENEVA, Aug. 19 -- Although it had no ostensible political objective, the first United Nations-sponsored Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy has already had a tremendous political impact.
Sixty-five families in two Williamsburg apartment houses in Brooklyn were evacuated yesterday when a sixty-six-inch water main on South Fifth Street burst at midnight.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Thirty-five Rowayton families left their homes today when the Five Mile River overflowed its banks. Seven Darien families living along the Noroton River were evacuated.

PARIS, Aug. 19 -- The Government will start direct talks with all representative elements in Morocco Monday at Aix-les-Bains in an effort to get a final solution to the political crisis in the French protectorate.
CAIRO, Aug. 19 -- Moslem Egypt rejoiced today that a crescent moon had denoted the dawn of the year 1375.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- G. I. Pokrovsky, Russian physicist, asserted today that in the "not far off" future Russia will be sending space ships to other planets on regular schedules.
AFTER the rain come the insects. A local outbreak of household pests that thrive in warm, wet weather was predicted today by Dr. Ralph E. Heal, executive secretary of the National Pest Association.

Work was resumed at Pier 64, North River, yesterday morning by the 200 longshoremen who had walked out in protest Thursday afternoon. The men resented "tactics" used by Waterfront Commission investigators, it was said. The stoppage forced the Panama Line's Cristobal to depart without some of her cargo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Secretary of Defense ordered the armed forces today to start training their men to resist Communist brainwashing and otherwise live up to the military's new Code of Conduct for prisoners of war.

The Times' editorial "Conflict of Interest" invites clarification. The person proposed for appointment by the President must be approved by the Senate -- that is the law. That body, therefore, has the right and duty to exercise its investigatorial powers in order to determine the candidate's fitness for office.

The entire blockfront on the north side of Thirtieth Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway, has been purchased by a syndicate of investors represented by Netter Netter, attorneys. The buyers gave the sellers a purchase money first mortgage of $250,000 at 4 1/2 per cent as part of the deal.

Your reader's complaint about tennis courts in Central Park in your Aug. 12 issue is but a minor grievance compared to the situation in Brooklyn. After all, slippery courts are a commonplace in tennis and the better players are surefooted athletes who include falls among the calculated risks of the game.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 19 -- A state of emergency was declared here today as swollen waters of the Still River rampaged through residential, factory and business districts. Early estimates put the loss at more than $3,000,000.

Peter Lawrence, a witness before the House Un-American Activities Committee here Wednesday, was turned down for membership yesterday by the membership committee of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers.
A Sunday school lesson one wintry morning in New Rochelle, N. Y., started a chain reaction that is bringing two French students to the United States on Monday for a year's study.

An English scholar's explanation to the British side of the Atlantic how the American side is different is the subject of "The Great Experiment," by Frank Thistlethwaite. To be issued Wednesday by Cambridge University Press, the volume describes what facts of geography and race, religion, politics and war have made the American people what it is.

The first biennial convention of the Council of Liberal Churches will be held in Detroit Aug. 23 to 29. Universalist and Unitarian churches will be represented. Nearly 1,000 delegates from the United States and Canada are expected. The convention theme will be "Man's Confidence in Himself."
THE big tuna are again feeding off Rhode Island. A report yesterday stated that some had been hooked and a 752-pounder boated by anglers fishing near Nebraska Shoals.

Two vacant plots in Maspeth, Queens, have been assembled for the Chase Brass and Copper Company of Waterbury, Conn., for improvement with a warehouse. One parcel on Fifty-eighth Street, between Fifty-fifth Drive and Fifty-sixth Avenue, contains 150,000 square feet of space.
FRASER, Col., Aug. 19 -- Philip Ray Rodgers, a member of the National Labor Relations Board, was designated today as acting board chairman.

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 19 -- Flash floods following a steady, twenty-four hour rainfall took four lives, caused damage estimated at millions of dollars and left thousands of persons homeless today in Scranton and northeastern Pennsylvania.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (AP) -The Milwaukee Braves' drive to stake down second place in the National League sputtered anew today with the news that Gene Conley will be out for the remainder of the season with a serious shoulder injury.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (UP) -- The Department of Internal Revenue has quit racing horses since one of its string finished last in a seven-horse race.

The rain - swollen Delaware River and countless other streams sent thousands of New Jersey residents and campers fleeing yesterday. Helicopters, scows, boats and amphibious vehicles were used to rescue men, women and children from flooded or threatened low-lying areas.
GENEVA, Aug. 19 -- The concept of automatic weather stations powered by products of nuclear fission was envisaged in reports read here today.
After fluctuating narrowly for the greater part of the session, the stock market developed a firmer tone in the late dealings yesterday. Final quotations generally were slightly higher for the day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Soybean and corn futures took the lead in an advancing grain market today. The forecast of another five days of torrid temperatures with little precipitation gave the market more buying momentum than has been seen for some time.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Bill Kurross and Ben Soberaij of the United States Navy upset Ken Boyum and Norman McDonald of Minneapolis, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, in the doubles quarter-finals of the national public parks tennis championship today.
DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Shutdowns for additional model changeovers cut into motor vehicle output this week.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19. -- Without a quibble, the Soviet Government agreed today to discuss the German reunification question with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer when he comes here next month.

The real estate industry will applaud Controller Gerosa for his timely warning to the public and to his colleagues on the Board of Estimate in relation to the city's indebtedness and the capital construction program.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Calumet Hecla, Inc., a mining concern, yesterday acquired the Goodman Lumber Company of Goodman, Wis., through an exchange of stock.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 19 -- According to West Berlin reports today, the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin has assured the Government of East Germany that the prisoners-of-war problem will be settled before Chancellor Konrad Adenauer reaches Moscow Sept. 9.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, Aug. 20 -- Eastern Pennsylvania counted at least thirty-seven dead and millions of dollars in damage this morning as the result of this area's most violent and destructive flood in generations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Army announced today that it would accept immediately enlistments for the new six-year Reserve training program.

The General Tire and Rubber Company plans further diversification. It has announced the proposed acquisition of Respro, Inc., of Cranston, R. I. Respro and its subsidiaries, which include United Lace and Braid Company, Lion Products Company and United Chemicals, Inc., manufacture shoe materials, tapes for electrical and other installations, shoelaces, insulation, dress and millinery braid as well as impregnated and coated, woven and unwoven, rubberized and unrubberized fabrics.

PARIS, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- A minority of 2,000 delegates attending the world congress of the Young Men's Christian Association here called today for sweeping reforms and more youthful representation on the world council of the organization.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The sensational Swaps, who this year has beaten every sophomore of note, including Nashua, aims for an $89,600 jackpot in the American Derby tomorrow and his eighth straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed in this country during the marketing year ended on July 31 totaled 8,835,149 running bales, compared with 8,576,191 bales in the preceding marketing year.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- President Eisenhower's authorization of a 50 per cent increase in tariffs on imported bicycles was criticized today by British bicycle manufacturers.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The winner of today's best Saratoga race was Christopher T. Chenery's Manotick, a 3-year-old filly in a line-up with four 3-year-old colts.
The National Dairy Council says the best way to preserve milk in hot weather is to keep it cold, clean and in the dark, reports The United Press from Chicago.
ATHENS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- This quiet village on the west bank of the Hudson opened today a three-day observance of the 150th anniversary of the granting of its first charter.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy appointed yesterday a squad of fifty men and women to investigate police involvement in recent morals cases.
DALLAS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Ted Wegert dashed 83 yards for one touchdown and scored another on a 7-yard end run to carry the Philadelphia Eagles to a 14-8 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

Commissioner Swing deserves praise for two changes in the way deportation cases are to be handled by the Immigration Service beginning this fall. Approval is especially in order because the service has been frequently criticized for its treatment of aliens who have run afoul of the McCarran-Walter Act.

COLOMBO, Aug. 18 -- Ceylon, the third largest producer of rubber in the world, is experiencing such a boom in its rubber industry that the Ceylonese Government is finding it difficult to meet its commitment of rubber delivery to Communist China. Under its contract to barter rubber for rice, Ceylon must send China 50,000 tons of rubber this year.
Vincent J. Powers has been elected president and general manager of the Accurate Bushing Company, Garwood, N. J.

FRASER, Colo., Aug. 19 -- This is a story about a President and a 7-year-old scene stealer. Its moral, if you insist on one, is that Dwight D. Eisenhower can be pushed out of the limelight if the competition is a bright-eyed youngster wearing a cowboy hat and named Eisenhower.

MILFORD, Pa., Aug. 19 -- This borough of 1,135 persons was an isolated island from 9 o'clock last night until 7 A. M. today. The Delaware River and its tributaries, not yet recovered from the saturation of Hurricane Connie last week, spilled over without restraint as Diane poured nearly thirteen hours of new rains upon this area. The downpour lasted from 4 P. M. yesterday until 4:45 o'clock this morning.
From the air yesterday, the flooded areas presented a nightmare in full daylight.

The right of State Investigation Commissioner J. Irwin Shapiro to compel answers to financial questionnaires in his investigation of the State Liquor Authority was attacked in Supreme Court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The indoor golf practice range has gone scientific. A Connecticut manufacturer of electronic instruments got a patent this week for a system that computes where a captive ball would go and projects a picture of the ball and its flight on a screen.
UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Syracuse Broadcasting Corporation today lost a $1,088,112 antitrust suit against the Syracuse newspaper, radio and television interests of S. I. Newhouse.
The Sanitation Department will employ a special task force tomorrow to remove tons of debris left over from recent storms.
When a front-runner meets a hapless tail-ender, one is reasonably certain to see what 14,602 fans witnessed at the Stadium last night.
The junior fishermen of the five boroughs had their award day yesterday at Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Frank Sullivan became the first American League pitcher to win fifteen games when he blanked the Washington Senators on six hits and led the Boston Red Sox to an 8-0 victory tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today an exchange of official visits with the Soviet Union was not in sight.
Despite a decrease of 137 ships in the active merchant marine last year, book services for American seamen were accelerated.

The Republic of Korea is certainly in the right in appealing to the United Nations for the dissolution of the so-called "truce commission." The charges of espionage against the Polish and Czech members of this body may or may not be valid.

Someone in search of a doctorate thesis might do worse than consider the relationship of a lawn mower to personal philosophy. Does a certain type of mower make for a certain type of philosopher, or does the chicken precede the egg and the philosophy so determine the mower?

If United States companies trading abroad suffer from foreign discrimination or handicaps from American laws, they will have a chance to tell their stories this autumn. Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on anti-trust and monopoly matters, is going to hold hearings in London, Paris and Rome, according to an Associated Press dispatch from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- An end to Washington's fifty-day streetcar and bus strike appeared in sight tonight. The striking A. F. L. union accepted settlement terms proposed by the District of Columbia Commissioners.

Today's new film is "The Teckman Mystery," a suspense drama starring Margaret Leighton and John Justin, at the Symphony. Francis Durbridge and James Matthews wrote the screen play from a story by Mr. Durbridge.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 19 (AP) -- About 14,100 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists from New York will move into Camp Drum this week-end for a two-week training period.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- An amphibious Amy duck got stuck in the mud trying to rescue stranded campers along a rain-swollen creek near here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Government confessed error and consented to a new trial today for a Chicago lawyer serving a six-year prison sentence for concealing four stolen paintings.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Aug. 19 -- The Foreign Ministers of five Central American countries were apparently still deadlocked today over the selection of a secretary general of the Organization of Central American States.
Maxwell Lehman, editor of the Civil Service Leader, has been appointed a Deputy City Administrator at an annual salary of $20,000.

"I Can Get It for You Wholesale," Jerome Weidman's savagely satirical novel about a young man's rise to success in Manhattan's garment district, is headed for the musical stage. The novel was a best-seller of the 1937 season and was made into a movie in 1951.
The American Meteorological Society has embarked on a program of doing something about the weather, as far as radio and television are concerned at any rate.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -Robin Roberts of the Phillies became the season's first twenty-game winner in the majors tonight as he beat the Dodgers' Don Newcombe, 3 -- 2, in a pitchers' duel at Connie Mack Stadium.

After review of the movies, the stewards decided that Earl Phelps, on Another Hyacinth, had run interference for his entry-mate, Rythminhim, in yesterday's Beverwyck Steeplechase. The stewards called it "herding" and susupended Phelps for fifteen days.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (UP) -- Two teen-agers dominated today's opening of the fifty-seventh Grand American trapshoot.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 19 -- Alan T. Lennox-Boyd, Secretary of State for the Colonies, said today that Britain would look with favor on a federation of the territories in Southeast Asia now under British colonial control.
The possibility was raised yesterday that two of New York's baseball teams -- the Dodgers and the Giants -- might have to leave the city.

MUNSAN, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Demands that the Communists turn over a United States Army captain and an Air Force lieutenant they shot down Wednesday in an unarmed training plane will be made by the United Nations Command at a full dress Joint Military Armistice Commission meeting at 10 A. M. tomorrow [9 P.M. Saturday, eastern daylight time].

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 19 -- This was Jose Limon's night in the American Dance Festival in Palmer Auditorium under the sponsorship of Connecticut College. The second performance in the series was given over entirely to compositions by him and danced by him and his company.

FORT CARSON, Colo., Aug. 19 (UP) -- Dr. Sammy Lee, Army Major, twice Olympic diving champion and winner of America's highest award for sportsmanship, disclosed today that he had twice been rebuffed in attempts to buy a home in Southern California because of his Korean ancestry.

Paul Keres, one of six Russian grandmasters in the inter-zone chess championship at Goteborg, was the sole victor in the fourth round, according to a report received yesterday through Swedish news channels.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Four junior British Army officers have confessed that they had staged a raid on a camp in North Wales Monday as a "practical joke."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 19 -Maj. Gen. Melvin J. Maas, chairman of President Eisenhower's Committee on Employment of the Physical Handicapped, was elected national commander of the Disabled American Veterans today.
Tropical hurricanes continued yesterday to dominate the weather in the East as the watery remains of Hurricane Diane brought heavy rains to this area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) -Bulgaria has apologized to the United States and offered to pay compensation for the death of twelve killed aboard an Israeli plane shot down by Bulgarian fighters last month.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- In a withdrawal without parallel in the seventy-five years of the tournament, the Davis Cup players of the United States and Australia pulled out of the national doubles tennis championships today. The defenders, Tony Trabert and Victor Seixas, were among them.
WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Favored players scored semi-final victories today in the American Tennis Association national championships at Central State College.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Massachusetts added sixty-two cases to its polio total today, making 1,606 for the year. At this time in 1954, the Commonwealth had 193 cases.
Ben Jeby lives very simply in a hotel room on East Twenty-eighth Street. It is a neatly kept room with a bed, a chest of drawers, a desk and an easy chair.
The "Gold Award" of the New York Board of Trade will go this year to a foreigner and to the son of a former President of the United States.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Union Chemical and Materials Corporation, Pittsburgh, and the Easy Washing Machine Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y., today approved a proposed merger.
GENEVA, Aug. 19 -- A team of six atomic scientists from the Soviet Union revealed today the details of one of their important nuclear reactors.

Railroad service linking New York with Boston, the Berkshire Hill towns of Connecticut and Massachusetts and the Pocono resorts of Pennsylvania was halted yesterday by washouts and earthslides on the tracks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UP) Two Senate subcommittees today announced coordinated hearings next month on public and private power programs.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is about to shake off the last of the inflexible debt structure that has held the road in a financial straitjacket since 1933.

EVERY, summer since 1947 a beguiling paradox has renewed itself in Aix-enProvence. Eight times now, the ancient, changeless beauties of this sun-drenched little French city have rung with the sounds of enthusiastic young musicians in festival assembled.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 20-- Two Noroton Yacht Club skippers, Bob Bavier Jr. and Bill Cox, were tied for the Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship, at 33 1/4 points after two races were sailed off the Riverside Y. C. today. A final race will be held tomorrow.
LONDON--The average Briton is inclined to look slightly resentful at any suggestion that he has been influenced by the American way of life.

WITH the painstaking precision of an honor student building a ship model inside a bottle in an occupationaltherapy clinic, Alan Harrington has carpentered an intricate and bitter little farce having to do with the ravages of "Centralism," or the desire to be Like Everyone Else, on a sensitive psyche.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20-- Senator Strom Thurmond, the States' Rights party candidate for President In 1948, indicated strongly today that his state and others in the South might again bolt to a third party in the 1956 election.

TORONTO, Aug. 20--Arnold Palmer, 25-year-old first-year pro, won the $15,000 Canadian open golf championship today by shooting a two-under-par 70 for a seventy-two-hole total of 265. His score was two strokes above the tournament record.

TELEVISION'S situation comedies, which want to nip in the bud that tired, run - down feeling, are moving to different locales, inserting fresh story lines and bringing on new faces. Operation perk-up will become noticeable to viewers with the start of the fall season.
The privately owned merchant fleet flying the American flag increased last month for the first time in nearly two years.

AFTER a short pause to have a baby, Mary Stuart will return soon to the troubled haunts of "Search for Tomorrow," the granddaddy of television soap operas on which she has already set a longevity record for the young medium with more than 1,000 performances.
TORONTO, Aug. 20--Wes Santee of the United States raced a mile in 4 minutes 11.1 seconds today. He failed, in 95-degree heat, to come close to his stated ambition of cracking the 4-minute barrier.
Just when it appeared that the hapless Orioles might finally win a game from the Yankees, a strategem dear to the heart of Paul Richards backfired on the Baltimore manager.

SIR ANTHONY EDEN is at once the best known and least known of British statesmen. His political and diplomatic careers, his speeches, the impressions he made on diarists, newspaper men and foreign statesmen are all available.

ONE among several lessons learned in the wake of "Connie": tree work isn't as easy as it looks. Any American male with suburban or country background has splendid memories of scrambling up ladderlike evergreens, exploring the ramifications of a noble apple, shinnying up a frail birch. And in later years he has watched the commercial or municipal tree men working their easy ways around the lofty branches.

PITTSFIELD. THERE is something late Victorian about the Berkshires, something faintly resentful of modern times in the lofty, languorous trees that line the spa-like village streets on which visitors in shorts look so strangely out of place.

YOUNG Ed Harris, up-andcoming, cynical, and on the lecherous side, is given the assignment of writing and emceeing a program honoring the late Herb Fuller, a radio and television personality whose words shake household purchasing habits, revivify the sick, and inspire the discouraged.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20-- The known death toll from the disastrous floods in eastern Pennsylvania rose to seventyfour today.
HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 20 (Canadian Press)--Raw gypsum is being carted out of the new development on the shores of Bedford Basin at the rate of 5,600 tons a day.

AURORA, N.Y., Aug. 20-- Some remains of one of New York State's earliest inhabitants lay uncovered near here today. A farm bulldozer had uprooted the jawbone and one tusk of a mastodon at least 5,000 years old.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would be impossible to take exception to most of the points covered in Mr. Hook's letter. But in my opinion the spirit of his letter and, specifically, some of the principles enumerated in it are at variance with some of the Hoover Commission recommendations.

NAPLES--Delicatessens have ousted many of the old-fashioned salami shops in Naples. Blaring jukeboxes drown the soft notes of the guitar. Hurry and urgency have affected the sleepy Neapolitans. All these examples of the influence of the United States and Americans on this most stubbornly traditional Italian city.

The fight to oust President Juan D. Peron in Argentina is developing into one of the most dramatic struggles of contemporary Latin-American history. More than two months have passed since naval air force units staged an abortive revolt, yet Argentina refuses to settle down.

MADRID--The United States' gesture in breaking the isolation in which Spain had been placed by the Western powers following her Civil War has done much to strengthen the American impact on modern Spain.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP)--The hottest competitive battles in auto history will push the car makers to still more production and sales records in the model year immediately ahead.

EDINBURGH. THE ninth Edinburgh Festival begins today, a fact that must be a source of astonishment to anyone who visits the town out of season --or out of curiosity. How can culture blossom in this stony soil? The Scots are a flinty critical race, suspicious at all times of imaginative excesses.

Moscow and Bonn Moscow's note to Bonn last week was the fifth in a Russian-German exchange that began on June 7. In the first, the Russians invited Dr. Adenauer to Moscow. In the fifth, they accepted his proposal for Sept. 9 as a date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) --The National Grange voiced fears today that the "propaganda potential" of the armed forces might be used some day to end civilian control and set up a "military dictatorship."

IN his constant effort to conceal the true nature of his hand and his plans from the defenders the declarer must give particular thought to the cards he discards from dummy. Such discards are likely to be more important than the discards from his own hand, because the dummy is exposed to view.

HERE is another book in a vein that remains inexhaustible, a novel that attempts to present the story of Christ and his followers from a special vantage point. In this particular book we view certain important events of the times, historical and imaginary, through the eyes of one Lavinia, fictitious niece of Pontius Pilate's wife, Claudia.

TO THE EDITOR: I have just had the opportunity of reading Arnold Toynbee's "The Question: Can Russia Really Change?" (July 24), [in which he sets forth the thesis that it is unlikely that the fundamental tenets of Marxism will be repudiated by the Soviet Union but that at the same time "a sincere and durable change in Russian policy might be on the way."

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 20 (AP)--Marine air reservists from squadrons in the western two thirds of the nation were put through all the rigors of a full-fledged interrogation as a cilmax of their summer training.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP)-- Joe Nuxhall, who was Wasted from last night's game in the first inning, came back tonight in a first-inning relief role to pitch the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals, trying to steady a riddled bullpen, today bought Allen Gettel from the Oakland Oaks of the Pacific Coast League, and optioned Brooks Lawrence to the Oaks for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20-- William V. Holohan, a New York lawyer who successfully tried the Securities and Exchange Commission's first stock manipulation case, was a graduate of Manhattan College and Harvard Law School.
HOLLYWOOD. PLANS for a two-program television scanning of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus under General Foods sponsorship are nearing completion, a circus spokesman said last week.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20-- There might be a bit of a premonition that all is not well will with the Dodgers after what has happened to them here in the last two nights.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP)-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today he was helping Dr. Sammy Lee, Army major and former Olympic diving champion, obtain a home in California.

NEXT Wednesday a ceremony will be held on Philadelphia's new Independence Mall commemorating the 200th anniversary of the birth of John Marshall. The event is one of a number this year in which patriotic Americans of various political faiths are honoring the great jurist.

Governor Harriman criticized the Eisenhower Administration last night for not insisting at the Geneva Conference that "the Kremlin live up to its war-time agreements" to permit free elections in the Iron Curtain countries.
GENEVA, Aug. 20.--Switzerland became the first nation today to receive a nuclear reactor under the United States AtomsFor-Peace Program.

LONDON. ON Sunday, July 3, of this year about sixty art critics from fourteen nations converged on Oxford. During the early afternoon they had been hurriedly getting their bearings in a city unfamiliar to most of them--dodging in and out of college quadrangles between flurries of English rain, sorting out what was medieval from what was modern in Oxford's amiable medley of old and new.

THE match race between Swaps and Nashua at Chicago's Washington Park Aug. 31 has the turf world in a tizzy. Match races usually do precisely that. It was only yesterday that an old-timer got to talking about one of the most famous matches of them all, the historic battle of 1878 between Ten Broeck and Mollie McCarthy, a great horse against a great mare.

The Maritime Administration is again seeking buyers for nine ships it would like to get off its books. The vessels are located at varying distances from the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts. They also are eight to ninety fathoms below the surface.

THE author of this book has spent the greater part of a long and productive career preserving Jewish culture for the English-speaking world. It always seemed to me that Maurice Samuel's work--as in "The World of Sholom Aleichem" and "Prince of the Ghetto"-- fell short of its objective; these were vivid miniatures of the recent past, and yet they were remote and in spite of themselves left the impression that the Jewish past was irrecoverable.

The stereotype of the advertising man runs heavily to the martini (very dry), the threehour luncheon, the pink shirt, the charcoal suit and such esoteric language as "Wheels?" for "Is your wife meeting you at the station?"

WITH penetrating clarity Arthur E. Morgan, famous engineer and first chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, has written a prophetic analysis of the spiritual and scientific dilemma of modern man.
The Grand Encampment of Knights Templar of the United States, organized in this city 139 years ago, opened its forty-sixth triennial conclave, here yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20--The Soviet Union's grain harvest this year will fall considerably short of the reduced goal of 114,000,000 metric tons set by the Government.
More home buyers as well as builders are being helped by the Voluntary Home Mortgage Credit Program since it started operations about last February.

THE economy is poised on a high plateau and industry is trying to gauge the temper of the consumer. It hopes to learn whether the upward swing that began eighteen months ago will continue in boom proportions or slide downward.

THE increasing popularity of the ranch-type house in recent years has resulted in more and more homes being built with their exterior trim and siding made of unpainted, "natural finish" cedar, redwood or knotty pine.
THE young mother was in tears. She hadn't slept well the night before. With one interruption after another she had spent all morning doing the baby's washing and tidying the house.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 --To tens of millions of Asians the most important place in world this week was Portuguese Goa, a lush sliver of land bounded by the Arabian Sea and Asian nationalism.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 20-- The tempo of retail trade slowed a little from its recent pace in the Kansas City area last week but the seasonable upturn is well under way. Since mid-July each week has shown a gain in volume over the previous week.
Within six months the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company will take delivery of eight new freighters.
MACAO, Aug. 12--Communist China has the freedom of this tiny Portuguese colony in the muddy estuary of the Pearl River.

GENEVA, Aug. 19--The leading industrial countries of Europe are faced with a new, and largely unknown, kind of competition in the international market. It is a competition in delaying cost increases in industry arising from nation-wide, or at least broad, increases in wages.

PANMUNJOM, Sunday, Aug. 21 (AP)--General Jung of North Korea charged in his statement to General Parks of the United Nations Command here today that the United States T-6 plane was not on a "routine training mission" when Communist guns shot it down.

A model house is being opened today in Montauk, L.I., by the Montauk Beach Company. The two-bedroom building, priced at $10,000, is on display at the Plaza and the Montauk Highway, opposite the sevenstory office building of the company.
BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)--Waterlogged western Massachusetts braced itself today against the twin menace of hunger and disease as it strained to mop up the debris left by the worst flood in its history.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20 --More than 14,000 members of the state's National Guard and Army Reserve Forces began arriving at Camp Drum today for two weeks of training.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) --The Government set in motion today newly created machinery to assure that papers of United States Presidents will be preserved in a manner easily accessible to scholors and historians.

THERE were records that featured the speaking voice rather than music in the days before the invention of LP disks. But it was not until after the new process was introduced that such records had much of a following.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20-- Fear that business might falter before the year is over seems to have vanished, says the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. If anything, there is fear of posible inflation, the bank adds. In banks of leading cities throughout this district, business loans, ignoring the usual seasonal fluctuations, have pushed upward.

The excavation was completed last week on a fifteen-acre hole which will provide the subterranean facilities of the Green Acres Shopping Center on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, L.I. The underground space will be used for basement sales, a truck tunnel and auxiliary service tunnels in the first eight major store buildings in the development.

A quick profit of about $3,000,000 is reported to be involved in the sale of the option on the Marguery property at 270 Park Avenue. This is the difference between what the New York Central Railroad had agreed to pay for the building and leasehold and the amount it will receive from the Union Carbide and Carbon Company in the latest of a series of deals involving the property.

I WAS pleased to read the article on duet playing which appeared on July 31. I am in complete agreement with Mr. Downes that duet playing as a social function is sadly neglected today, and the suggestion of using arrangements of orchestral works in the duet version for study purposes is certainly a valid one.
Jersey City threw the Brooklyn Dodgers a curve ball last night and is wondering today how the baseball club will handle the new offer.

TRENTON, Aug. 20--President Eisenhower today declared New Jersey a disaster area. This promise of Federal aid followed a plea for assistance by Gov. Robert B. Meyner and Representative Frank Thompson Jr.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20--The Soviet agricultural delegation ended its United States farm tour today with a visit to a dairy "ranch" and a fifty-mile-an-hour ride through Hollywood.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 --This week in India the Babus almost revolted--almost but not quite.

GENEVA, Aug. 20--The first International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy came to a close here this afternoon after a fortnight of historic sessions. During them the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and other nations shared hitherto closely guarded secrets of how to harness the vast energy of the atom for the benefit of mankind.

BASEBALL The Yankees defeated the Orioles, 3 to 2, yesterday on Elston Howard's two-run double in the fourth inning. The victory was the league-leading Bombers' second straight over Baltimore at the Stadium.

The motor cargo ship Sagami Maru, first of six 11,200 deadweight -ton vessels to be built by the Japanese-flag Nippon Yusen Kaisha Line for New York Orient service, is due here next month on her maiden voyage.

The old glass blowers' magic has been surpassed by the wizardry of the fledgling fiber glass industry. Millions of Americans daily come into contact with these new materials in some form or another and they are being used in more than 4,000 household and industrial products.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 20--More than 80 per cent of the total trade of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua in recent years has been done with the United States and Western Europe.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 13 --United States, French and Indonesian pilots are being trained in the fine points of flying helicopters in mountainous terrain in an area around Penticton, B.C. Penticton is a few miles north of the United States border.

A question which has intrigued scientists for ages is, How old is the universe? New light is thrown on this question by a report in Nature, British scientific periodical, on chemical tests of meteorites. These tests suggest that stone meteorites which have arrived on earth from outer space are some five billion years old and that iron meteorites are about one-tenth that old, or roughly 500,000,000 years old.
AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 16-- Gov. Edmund S. Muskie appears to be living up to the promise that prompted so many Republicans to help elect him as the first Democratic Governor of Maine in twenty years.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 20-- Chet Sanok and Phil Dameo of The Knoll, co-medalist team, led the field into the semi-final round of the New Jersey Golf Association annual best-ball championship today at the Braidburn Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) --The order by Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson that racial segregation in schools on military posts be ended by this fall has been carried out at all except two posts.

Much like the recent weather, the stock market moved uncertainly again last week. Traders trimmed their commitments, allowing stocks to drift lower early in the period. Then the market rallied, with mixed tendencies toward the close.

In Wake of Diane In the Northeast, the summer of 1955 will not soon be forgotten. It has been a season of extremes.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 20--The waters of the Connecticut River and its tributaries gradually subsided in western Massachusetts today. Under a a blazing sun weary workers toiled to remove the traces of $25,000,000 damage caused by two days of relentless rain.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20--The sensational Swaps, leading all the way, spurted to a one-length victory over the fast-closing Traffic Judge to win the $146,425 American Derby at Washington Park today.

THE opportunities for scenic excursions to various corners of the world that the movies have been extending copiously of late have been further expanded in the last few weeks. Travel-minded filmgoers are urged to lend an eye.

FOR all that two continents bear his name, and that much ink has been spilled in discussing the authenticity of his narratives of four voyages, until now little effort has been spent in describing the shore life of Amerigo Vespucci.

HONG KONG, Aug. 20--Red China said tonight a returned Chinese physicist, educated at Stanford University, had charged in Peiping that United States representatives had tried to dissuade him from returning to the China mainland.

INDIVIDUALS and communities interested in the issuance of special stamps are perhaps not fully aware of the obstacles they face in getting consideration of their wishes. The procedure in such cases has been fairly strictly canalized of late.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20-- Banners and placards used by women picketing the White House during their drive for suffrage are being brought out this week-end in a thirty fifth anniversary celebration.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 4-- Purchase of the French-owned D.H. and P. Railroad by the Syrian Government, concluded here recently, is a major step toward the revival of railroading in the Middle East.

WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Aug. 20 (UP)--Robert Ryland of Nashville won the men's title and Althea Gibson of New York captured the women's singles championship today in the American Tennis Association tournament at Central State College.
FRASER, Colo., Aug. 20--Every moviegoer who has ever seen Randolph Scott clean up a tough street knows Fraser, Colo.
AN ISSUE that has been a source of increasing if sporadic aggravation to the flying public will be taken up at The Hague on Sept. 6. The issue has to do with the Warsaw Convention of 1929.
NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Aug. 20--The cannons bomed, the flags of sixty-four nations were unfurled and the eighth World Boy Scout Jamboree was officially under way today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 20 --A 3,200-acre wilderness park is being created from the valley of the Little Blue River about ten miles east of here in the direct line of growth of this city. Less than a mile to the north, suburban home districts already are springing up.
A six-state area in the northeastern United States counted 143 deaths yesterday, with the full measure of damage from Friday's floods still to be assessed.
A tract of 500 acres has been opened for residential development near the approaches to the proposed Fire. Island bridge in Shirley, L.I.

The roads of America, particularly the roads of the West, are the paths of history. West of the Mississippi the traveler is, more often than not, going the way of the great migrations, following the ox teams and the mule trains that hauled the Conestoga wagons into a new land.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Sharp criticism of the new code of behavior for American prisoners of war came from within Congress today. A possible widespread controversy was indicated.

YARMOUTH, N.S. -- This has been a year of special events for Nova Scotia. LONDON, Aug. 20--Princess Margaret will celebrate her twenty-fifth birthday quietly tomorrow with members of the Royal Family at Balmoral, the royal Scottish residence.

The display of two model houses marks the formal opening today of a development of thirty split-level dwellings on Cedar Lane, west of Knickerbocker Road, in Closter, N.J. Priced at $21,750 and up, the houses have three bedrooms and attached garages for one or two cars.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (UP) --Northern California blanked Middle Atlantic, 7--0, and Southern California defeated Florida, 3--1, today in the semi-final round of the United States girls grass court team tennis championships.

HARTFORD, Aug. 20--Waters receded and the sun shone today to bare Connecticut's deep gashes from yesterday's record floods. Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker arrived by plane and flew over the stricken areas by helicopter. He declared the disaster was so great he was making immediate assignments of engineers and funds to restore transportation and public health.

WEBSTER, N. H.--A certain Captain Shakespeare and his family are perhaps the most popular people along the entire Blackwater Road, a few miles out of the center of this community, and their home is possibly the most frequented of any in the neighborhood.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 19-- This community was emerging today from the havoc caused by the overflowed Still River, which surged through the business and residential area yesterday.
