SAARBRUEKEN, The Saar, Aug. 20--The head of the Saar Government called on the West German Chancellor and the Roman Catholic Church today to clarify the political struggle in this disputed territory.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 20--The Navy will test the British system of "mirror and lights" in directing aircraft carrier landings for the first time afloat when the carrier Bennington goes to sea Monday from the Brooklyn navy shipyard.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--The possibility that United States public opinion may be "softening" toward the Soviet Union is causing concern among foreign diplomatic observers here.

THE movie industry's apathy toward institutional public relations has been pointed up anew by the collapse of efforts to establish the proposed Motion Picture Exposition and Hall of Fame in Hollywood More than a year of planning had gone into the project.
Monorail, championed as a more economical means of mass transportation than existing rail travel, shortly will have its first "field" test in this country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--A new wage contract giving northern soft coal miners a wage increase of $2 a day was signed here tonight.

THE author's impressive background of experience on Washington, D.C., newspapers undoubtedly contributes much to the rich documentation apparent in this, his first fulllength venture into fiction. By its own easygoing standards, "Good as Gold" is a readable and, in its rowdier episodes, a screamingly funny harlequinade, perhaps even an important social document.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: In order to have bloom this winter indoors, prune poinsettia plants by reducing each stem one-third. Pot up oxalis and calla bulbs for bloom in the house. Keep in the coldframe until October. Cut stems of ivy and keep in a pail of water outdoors for a few days before bringing them in and arranging them in bowls of water.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Aug. 15 -- A move is steadily gaining to continue the Chief of State, Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz, in power.

PUTNAM, Conn., Aug. 20 (AP) --Ten thousand residents of this city in northern Connecticut spent a night of terror as hundreds of barrels of exploding magnesium floated on flood waters through the business district.
Reorders for women's coats continued to run well ahead in the New York market last week, resident offices report. Early promotions were credited.
RIO DE JANEIRO--Brazilians are a proud people, and they are sensitive about suggestions that they are indebted to any other lands for their way of life.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug 20--Peter Fenner, a teen-age skipper from the Westhampton (L. I.) Yacht Squadron, qualified for the men's North American sailing championship today. Fenner won the Area-2 semi-final round-robin at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
LONDON, Aug. 20--Relations between Britain and her small vocal neighbor, the Republic of Ireland, have been likened to those between a busy mere de famille and a rebellious younger son.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) --Government and industry experts are not surprised at the sharp decline in housing starts in July. They contend it does not indicate a break in the market.

Western diplomats spent much of last week analyzing the reasons for and probable consequences of Moscow's announcement that it would cut its armed forces by 640,000 men Dec. 15. High among the factors unearthed in these analyses was the pressure of the Soviet domestic labor crisis, a crisis that is expected to become worse in the years immediately ahead.

EVERY day is flower day in this city. To reach this conclusion it isn't necessary for a visitor to penetrate the residential areas but only to walk along the shopping and business streets. And perhaps there is no city in the country where cut flowers are so much a part of daily living.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20--The key to the exact dates of what are believed to be the two oldest villages in which man settled for permanent agricultural life may have been found by the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20--The big cash-collecting horse-owners at the Saratoga track today were Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, two gentlemen who didn't really need the money.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 20-- West German steel mills have begun to import large quantities of pig iron from the Soviet Union. One hundred thousand tons are en route, according to Handelsblatt, West Germany's leading economic newspaper.

IT WAS the end of the Berkshire Music Center's sixweek season, and Roger Sessions was looking back in an effort to evaluate it. This had been Mr. Sessions' first experience on the Tanglewood faculty. Since he is both an accomplished composer and a seasoned teacher, his views would have weight.

WESTERN RESERVE--Business The growing trend of corporate giving to private colleges and universities is a welcome and significant trend for higher education in this country, President John S. Millis of Western Reserve University reported recently.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20--A racial integration controversy as bitter as any in the South is heading for a showdown here.

A complete rupture of the diplomatic relations between India and Portugal was almost inevitable when the dispute had been allowed to reach the violent stage. If the break makes it clear that some new approach must be made and some new formula for settlement devised it will have served a good purpose.

CHICAGO--Two new papers for making color prints from color negatives and transparencies were introduced by Eastman Kodak Company at the diamond jubilee convention of the Photographers Association of America held here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UP) --The Civil Service Commission said today it would "re-examine" the guilt-by-kinship case of a Cleveland scientist who was discharged from a Government research job because his parents once had bought insurance policies from an alleged Communist front.

There's little doubt that Edward Schinman's favorite reading matter is classified newspaper advertising. That preference may seem a bit unusual, but it follows naturally in the light of some recent industrial history.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Aug. 20-- The Seneca Indians, long neglected "first settlers" of New York State's Finger Lakes region, will be honored Labor Day week-end in ceremonies at Keuka Lake here and near-by Canandaigua Lake.
HONG KONG, Aug. 20--Although little progress has been registered thus far at the Geneva ambassadorial talks, the Peiping regime is still preserving a "peaceful coexistence" posture.

CHICAGO--Two new series of electronic flash units designed for portability and maximum light volume were introduced at the trade show that supplemented the diamond jubilee convention of the Photographers' Association of America held here last week.

IN spite of stormy weather in the Carolinas, the North Carolina Garden Club was able to dedicate the Elizabethan Garden at Roanoke Island last Thursday. It is located near Manteo and the entire area is steeped with lore of the famous "lost colony."

THESE five stories by K.M. Wallenius, a retired Finnish major general, in a strange, formless, and somberly flashing style that at times sings as purely as the wind, describe man's almost inhuman struggle for existence within the Arctic Circle at the northern tip of Scandinavia.
Governor Harrimant saw for himself yesterday some of the staggering damage the heavy rains and rampaging rivers have inflicted in this state's southeastern resort and industrial communities.
CHICAGO--The era of miracle film speeds has only just begun and will progress in the next seventyfive years to the point where photography may be possible even by the light of a single firefly.

THE story of a young girl raised in a strict religious home, who subsequently discovers broader patterns of life, is certainly not a new one. It is, in fact, impossible not to wonder what sort of a story "The World and Julie" would have been if it had been written in another era.

TORRINGTON, Conn., Aug. 21 -- All major factories here have been knocked out of commission by this week-end's floods of the Naugatuck River. The business district in Center Square has been placed off limits to the general public.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- An appeal for "more love for freedom than hatred for communism" was sounded tonight before the United States National Student Association at its annual congress.

The Schinitzelbank song is usually shouted (it is rarely "sung") to the accompaniment of beer, wurst and cheese. The Gardner Advertising Company of St. Louis, well aware of this fact, took the song as a basis for an advertising campaign for the Mayrose frankfurter produced by the Independent packing Company, its client.
An office and showroom for the sale of Citroen automobiles will be established in 300 Park Avenue, a building at Forty-ninth Street being erected by Uris Bros.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., was a slight favorite today to make it two titles in a row as a field of 104 prepared to open play tomorrow in the United States Golf Association's women's national amateur championship.
A personal appeal to the five borough presidents to reconsider their stand in favor of selling the abandoned Neponsit Beach Hospital site to private developers was made yesterday.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Althea Knickerbocker exhibited a pair of hunters in sparkling style today in the eighth annual Brookville horse show at the Brookville Stables.

Stepfathers of children who have problems should no longer be considered ogres, a Smith College study indicates. The groundwork for most of the situation, it reveals, was laid in the early mother-child relationship when the stepfather was nowhere around.
KURE, Japan, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Four Japanese swimmers chopped nearly one second off the world 400-meter medley relay record tonight in a meet with a United States team.
A blast against noise was delivered by a Nova Scotia preacher yesterday in a not altogether quiet New York church.

When members of the International Civil Aviation Organization meet at Manila this fall to discuss navigational problems in the Pacific area, the operation of turbine-powered airliners will be among the principal subjects considered.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Flood reconstruction became the primary target of Connecticut today.

The mind reels before the accounting of the death and destruction brought to this and neighboring states by last week's rain and floods. Hundreds killed or missing, thousands homeless, whole communities without a source of safe, drinkable water, billions in property damage -- these are but part of the staggering toll.

Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest producer, has purchased a thirty-one acre site at Willimantic, Conn. C. L. Austin, president, said the land will be used initially for construction of a plant to produce cold finished steel bars. The site was bought from the American Screw Company of Willimantic.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Aided again by their brilliant bullpen, the Cleveland Indians came from behind to win their third straight from the Kansas City Athletics today, 9 to 4.

ALTHOUGH laundries and restaurants may consider the figure conservative, 97 per cent of all American women use lipstick. But these bold-mouthed creatures are shy about their eyes, for only 23 per cent use eye make-up.
Automation has come to the Transit Authority.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 -- Representatives of twenty-seven universities walked in a colorful procession through the cobbled streets of this Scottish capital today to attend a religious service inaugurating the ninth Edinburgh International Festival of Music and Drama.
Carmine G. DeSapio, Democratic National Committeeman from New York, reiterated his backing of Governor Harriman as a 1956 Presidential candidate yesterday.

I note with increasing astonishment the continued complaints of the Air Force that their trained electronic specialists refuse to re-enlist because they are offered better paying jobs in the civilian field.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 21 -- The Indian Parliament is considering comprehensive legislation seeking to enforce tighter control over the management of private industries.
BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Bob Tarr of Babylon more than covered the 2-hour 40-minute handicap allotted his Spendthrift today to capture the forty-mile night race from Babylon to Bellport and return.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today it stepped up investigation of alleged violations of the trade laws last year by nearly 50 per cent.
Two natives of New York whose songs about Oklahoma have endeared them to music lovers were honored yesterday at a song festival in the Mall of Central Park.

Formation of the Development and Resources Corporation by Lazard Freres Co., investment banking firm, and David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority and first chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, was announced over the weekend.

HONOLULU, Aug. 21 -- Crew members of a Military Air Transport Service plane reported a new volcanic island 375 miles northwest of Honolulu. It was the first reported eruption in that area. Volcanologists had believed that part of the Midway-Hawaii volcanic chain extinct.
A caravan of twenty automobiles yesterday brought home to New York eighty children the Fire Department at Bantam, Conn., had fished out of their flooded camp at 4 A. M. Friday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, with Andy Pafko and Bobby Thomson providing most of the thunder in a thirteen-hit attack, defeated the Chicago Cubs, 8 -- 1, today for their fifth consecutive victory before 33,198 persons in near 100-degree heat.

VIENNA, Aug. 21 -- The Austrian Government has discovered that the Soviet military bank has 10 per cent of the total volume of money in circulation in Austria and is wondering what the Russians propose to do with it.

"LET'S TAKE A TRIP" brought its viewers to Niagara - on - the - Lake, Ont., yesterday for the eighth World Boy Scout Jamboree. The program, seen over Channel 2 from 4:30 to 5:30 P.M., was fine television entertainment and ideal publicity for the Boy Scout movement.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 -- A platoon of autograph hunters waylaid Vladimir V. Matskevitch, Soviet Acting Minister of Agriculture, at the Los Angeles International Airport today. He genially signed his name as old envelopes, notebooks and torn pieces of paper were thrust at him.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Lyman Frasier of the Baltimore Olympic Club outscored ten other athletes in the national all-around track and field championship today. Yale's Stu Thomson, competing in only seven events, smashed three meet records.

TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner has decided not to make a bid next year for a place on the Democratic national ticket. He prefers to stand for re-election as Governor in 1957 and to defer further national aspirations until 1960.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Aug. 22 -- The United Nations Command has warned the Communists that their inclination to shoot at every Allied plane that wanders by mistake over the Korean neutral zone may cause the United Nations forces to take the same action against erring Red aircraft.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's picked national team today defeated West Germany's world football (soccer) champions, 3 -- 2. More than 80,000 spectators, including 1,500 West German fans, watched the game in Dynamo Stadium.
PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The unofficial death toll rose to nearly 800 tonight after two days of nationalist violence in Algeria and Morocco.

The Hudson Tubes, operated by the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, had an operating income of $52,952 for the first six months of this year, compared with an operating deficit of $185,751 in the like period of 1954.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Edward Chandler and Gerald Stratford of San Francisco won the senior men's championship of the seventy-fifth national doubles tennis tournament today by defeating Edward Jacobs of Baltimore and C. Alphonse Smith of Washington in an indoor match.
The United States Navy's aircraft carrier Ticonderoga yesterday stole visitors away from the other twenty-one warships open to the public on a Sunday afternoon in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, a probable candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year, is likely to find one of his strongest opponents right in his own backyard.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Arthur Cook of Washington, the 1948 National and Olympic champion, today took a 2-point lead at the quarter mark in the national small-bore rifle championships.

GENEVA, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Six nations, including the United States and the Soviet Union, announced tonight they would continue the atoms-for-peace talks on the "technical aspects" of making nuclear power safe.

PUTNAM, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The Quinebaug River is down to four feet deep and twenty-five wide, but it takes a seventy-mile drive to go from the east to the west side of town. The roaring flood waters smashed three bridges and cut Putnam in two, and it will take time to repair the damage.
Federal offices will be opened early this week to consider disaster loans for factories, businesses, summer camps and private homes in flood-struck areas of New York State.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Just before today's game between the Dodgers and the Phillies, some Brooklyn fan perched a large sign atop the Brooklyn dugout that read:

Mr. and Mrs. A., stars in their eyes, bought a wedding ring, a honeymoon and a house and straightway (the stars having dimmed) began figuring out what they had spent. The house, Mr. A. explained, rather less tenderly than he had talked of other subjects, was not "consumed," but represented a transfer of assets from cash to house, with no effect on net worth.
TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today called a special Cabinet meeting for tomorrow to mobilize New Jersey's resources to handle the "catastrophic" problems caused by the flood.

"Alarming" flouting of civil liberties in the United States was noted yesterday in the first report of the Fund for the Republic. The fund's president, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, declared: "Although in some particulars the atmosphere is better than it was five years ago, the misunderstanding of civil liberties, the indifference to them, and the violations of them, to which we too easily grow accustomed, are still such as to give cause for alarm."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Marion Garber, 25, of Toledo, today won the all-around casting championship at the national fly and bait casting tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Department of Agriculture hopes to sell more United States surplus foods and fibers this year than ever. Officials of the International Cooperation Administration, however, doubt that it can fulfill its share of the disposal program.

"The more it changes the more it is the same" is a proverb, inapplicable to New York's suburbs. The series of articles on Our Changing City has been exploring near-by counties, and this morning crosses the Hudson. Someone has said that the whole area from Baltimore to Boston would some day be one great metropolis.
William L. Harris has been named manager of the New York office of the mercantile claims division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ROBERT PENN WARREN'S new novel, "Band of Angels," his first in five years, is a readable and dramatic combination of flamboyant melodrama and thoughtful reflection about moral issues and psychological factors. The melodrama is expert and thoroughly entertaining, which accounts for this book being the September selection of the Literary Guild.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- Steel output was up slightly last week but not enough to make a dent in the big volume of new business or in the extension of deliveries. The end of a local strike in the Southeast and subsiding hot weather combined to expand the steel production rate to slightly more than 90 per cent of capacity.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Robin Evan Roberts doesn't talk much. He prefers to let his right arm do his talking for him.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Peabody Coal Company reported today that its earnings before Federal income taxes in the quarter ended July 31 were $178,017. The earnings include those of the Sinclair group of coal companies since the date of merger, July 12.
A group of religious and civic leaders yesterday issued an open letter praising Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. for activating the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights.
The chaplain of the University of Edinburgh, Scotland, urged Christians yesterday to do more than "coexist" with God.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Senate Majority Leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, said today that the Eighty-fourth was a "working" or "can-do" Congress.

Thunderstorms accompanied by spasmodic wind gusts up to sixty miles an hour swept through the metropolitan area of New York last night. They felled trees and power lines and caused some of the year's worst traffic jams on highways leading into the city.

The charter market is continuing in a late summer lull with volume down. Rates are off only slightly. The principal sufferers, according to all indications, are vessel owners who are seeking immediate contracts.

OUED ZEM, French Morocco, Aug. 21 -- The Berber tribesmen who yesterday sacked the European section of this town threatened to attack again today but were thrown back by French Security forces. Instead, they vented their ire on near-by Khouribga, an important phosphate-mining center.
Grief or pain, spiritually channeled, can be a "tremendous power for good," the Rev. Robert M. O'Connell declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

"How to Make Your Living in Four Hours a Day Without Feeling Guilty About It" is the intriguing title of a new book by William J. Reilly. The author is certainly swimming with the tide if not actually anticipating it, for all about us are signs of a lessening need for work.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- An uneasy and pronounced quietude has descended on stock markets in the last week.
A $2,000,000 regional shopping center will rise on a thirty-acre site at the junction of West Middle Turnpike and Broad St. in Manchester, Conn., about nine miles east of Hartford.

If the crucial events in our lives are shaped by destiny, why struggle? This question was posed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George W. Barrett in a sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eighty-fourth Street.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Shotgun experts by the hundreds flocked into this Miami Valley village today for the opening tomorrow of the fifty-sixth Grand American Trap-shoot.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 21 (AP) -- John Roosevelt, youngest son of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, will assume command in October of a new independent movement for re-election of President Eisenhower, the Chattanooga Times reported in an article for tomorrow's editions.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey urged young lawyers today to "protect our most precious heritage -- the Bill of Rights."

The last remaining space in the recently modernized office structure at 125 West Forty-first Street, through to Forty-second Street between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, has been rented on a long-term lesse to Logantex, Inc., textile coverter company.

Prices of domestic cotton futures moved irregularly last week. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the trading session on Friday 29 points higher to 33 points below the close of the previous week, when prices were unchanged to 80 points below the week before.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- A magnesium explosion caused by flood waters rocked the Rochdale area along Wappinger's Creek early yesterday morning, the Poughkeepsie Town police reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The proposed House investigation into alleged Communist infiltration into Senate committee staffs will be a new grappling with an old problem.

Sunday travelers interfered with emergency vehicles in some of the flood areas yesterday. Highway conditions in general improved during the day, although last night's squalls changed the picture in some sections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- Sammy White hit a homer in the fourth inning and doubled home a run in the eighth today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Washington Senators in the rubber game of their three-game series.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The first Sunday rainout at Forbes Field since April 23, 1944, kept the Giants and the Pirates idle today. The scheduled doubleheader was postponed until tomorrow, originally an off-day for both clubs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Officials of the Eisenhower Administration were accused today of deliberately concealing facts from the public and Congress in the Dixon-Yates power controversy.

Erich Fromm has a new book scheduled for publication next Monday by Rinehart, entitled "The Sane Society." It is described as a continuation of the psychiatric concepts he formulated in "Escape From Freedom." In his new work, the author examines man's escape into overconformity and the danger of robotism in contemporary industrial society.
Plans for a two-story store and office building in the Greenwich Village section of Manhattan have been announced by Jack Brause, realty operator and builder.

Seven thousand Knights Templar, in colorful uniforms and plumed hats, attended religious services yesterday afternoon at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today it has granted $291,500,000 in tax write-off certificates covering part of the cost of forty new or expanded industrial production programs.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 21 -- Dutch monetary authorities are apparently marking time on allowing the issuance of new foreign loans in the Amsterdam market. Before acting, they want to study the effects of the new European Payments Union regulations, British measures for support of sterling, and the way the Dutch balance of payments develops.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 21 -- The new coalition Government of Indonesia has won the approval of the Western diplomatic community in this capital.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- Not only the American people but the Soviet people have been told what United States farm experts think is wrong with Soviet agriculture.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Don Gross of the Cincinnati Redlegs shut out the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-0, today on four hits. Wally Post's thirty-first home run of the year and a single accounted for three of the Redleg runs.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Housewives and politicians are awaiting the outcome of a Western Massachusetts milk dealer's challenge of the Commonwealth's right to fix milk prices.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The eyes of Britain were upon Princess Margaret, today as she quietly celebrated her twenty-fifth birthday with members of the Royal Family at Balmoral Castle in Scotland.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Attention in flood-battered Pennsylvania turned today toward Pike County, across the Delaware River from Port Jervis, N. Y. Large sections of the county remained cut off from communications.

The report of the Fund for the Republic, released today, shows a diversity of important projects undertaken in advancing an understanding of civil liberties and promoting the cause of personal freedom in accordance with our basic constitutional principles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Hugh M. Milton 2d, Assistant Secretary of the Army, said today the new military code for prisoners of war placed responsibility for misconduct "solely on the individual."
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Amateur radio operators, since Friday night, have provided almost the only communications link with several of the state's disaster areas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Or-organizations called today for a new Federal agency to develop public and private programs for relieving unemployment in "chronically depressed areas."

MADISON, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Chet Sanok and Phil Dameo of The Knoll won the twenty-third annual New Jersey amateur best-ball championship today. They scored a 2 and 1 victory over Billy Dear and Gordon Brown of Morris County in the final at the Braidburn Country Club.

The duties of Julius S. Wikler, First Deputy Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York, have been expanded to include general supervisory authority over all affairs of the department both in New York City and Albany, it was announced over the week-end. He will also supervise directly the legal, rating and welfare bureaus.
KFAR SABA, Israel, Aug. 6 -- Forays by Jordanian infiltrators have declined appreciably in the last two years, according to Israeli settlers, officers and truce officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Budget Bureau has reported that Congress did well during the recent session to improve the gathering of facts on the country's economic health. But the bureau indicated that the legislators could have done much better.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The second phase of the Senate investigation of the adequacy of the antitrust laws will start Tuesday.

PAUL BROWN had dinner with Mr. and Mrs. Otto Graham one day last week. It was not a social occasion. At least Brown hopes it wasn't strictly social. He hopes it also was a business meeting. Brown (Paul) is the boss man of the Browns (Cleveland), the champions of the National Football League, and he was very unhappy.
Westward expansion of the New York metropolitan area is showing its most pronounced effects in Bergen, Rockland and Passaic Counties.
The metropolitan papers recently carried the news that seven New York State officials were sworn in by Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio. All of these posts were filled by men.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Aug. 20 -- Three of the men chosen to survey the Canadian economy and forecast its future course made this the first stop on a fact-finding mission to the last frontier in North America -- the forbidding North.
The Fund for the Republic, Inc., has allotted $200,000 for the production of a television series featuring Herbert L. Block, editorial cartoonist of The Washington Post and Times-Herald.
PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The New York Athletic Club took eight of the ten events of the second annual mid-summer regatta of the New York Rowing Association today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Bill Cox of the Noroton Y. C., sailing Zig Zagger, captured the third annual Long Island Sound Lightning Class championship at the Riverside Y. C. today to give the donor club a third straight leg on the Noroton Challenge Trophy.

G. R. (Bill) Corwin scored his sixteenth triumph of the season yesterday with his 210 Class craft Harpoon in the Bayside Yacht Club's regatta. A fleet of eighty sailed in the twenty-ninth program of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported tonight that $2,469,000,000 worth of new securities were offered for sale in the United States during the second quarter.

ZURICH, Aug. 21 -- As on most European stock exchanges, the volume of business here last week was considerably less than the week before. Despite the fact that numer ous Swiss companies issued reports showing satisfactory yields for the preceding year, investors showed uneasiness about the future, fearing that the boom might end abruptly.
The most comprehensive port rehabilitation project ever drawn here has been proposed to the city by Marine and Aviation Commissioner Vincent A. G. O'Connor.
An American housewife visiting one of West Germany's growing number of self-service food stores might well imagine she had taken a magic-carpet ride home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- City buses and street cars will roll in Washington tomorrow for the first time since July 1.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 21 -- Kemal Ataturk, the great Turkish revolutionary, said in 1937: "We can never know that an event taking place even at a very remote part of the world will not touch us; for mankind is a body of which each nation is a part. A pain even at the tip of a finger or a toe affects the whole body."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Clyde Hippenstiel of San Bernardino, Calif., won the national public parks men's singles title for the third straight time today. He defeated Ben Sobieraj, United States Navy star from St. Louis, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6, 10 -- 8, in a three-hour final that was brilliantly played.
The events leading to the signing of Bob Rippy for the featured role opposite Carol Channing in the new musical, "Delilah," unfold as do those in a Cinderella-like story.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A broadened Federal loan program for college housing presages more campus building during the coming school year.

A WOMAN from Britain only a little while resident in New York, the other day asked Andrew Weiss, teller in the Central Savings Bank at Seventy-third Street and Broadway, off Verdi Square, to close out her entire account, something above $3,000, and to pay her in cash.

NIAGARA - ON - THE - LAKE, Ont., Aug. 21 (AP) -- This village of 2,500 residents opened its hearts and homes today to the more than 10,000 Boy Scouts assembled in a tent city here for the eighth World Jamboree.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A rise of nearly $3,000,000,000 in private United States investment abroad was registered last year.
HONG KONG, Aug. 21 -- Political observers here were stunned today by the report from Taipei, Formosa, that Gen. Sun Li-jen had "resigned" as Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's personal Chief of Staff.

The second round of decasualization proceedings by the Waterfront Commission against this port's longshoremen will get unler way this month and it is indicated that "thousands" of dockers will be dropped from the agency's register.
The Lackawanna Railroad announced last night it would restore some main-line passenger service this morning.

The change in Soviet attitudes and manners toward greater amiability without a change in fundamentals continues to puzzle the outside world, which views the new Kremlin look with mingled hope and uneasiness. On the one hand, the Russian Bolsheviks now act as if they have decided to join the human race.

Last week's article here dealing with the post-war economic recovery in Western Europe stressed the importance of the role of monetary policy in that episode. At one point it referred to "the restitution of monetary policy" and then added, by way of particularization, "or, more specifically, a policy of flexible interest rates."
The Orioles made their last appearance of the season at the Stadium yesterday. The Yankees were more than a little sorry to see them go.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- River-wrecked areas of Massachusetts and Rhode Island fought doggedly today against post-flood health hazards and scarcities of food and drinking water as the death toll climbed to fourteen persons.
BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- Russian farmers were pictured today as having only the "bare necessities" of life but content because they were living better than ever before.

After an entirely inexcusable delay the Communists in Korea have finally admitted that they shot down two American fliers, killing one of them and seriously injuring another. They promise to return the still living flier shortly, apparently after having attempted to obtain some statement from a man with a fractured skull.
The latest police drive against undesirables and individuals with criminal records resulted in the checking Saturday of 5,655 licensed premises. This was learned last night at Police Headquarters.
STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 21 -- Salvage and repair operations in this city and its neighbor, East Stroudsburg across Brodhead Creek, began moving briskly today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The United States Government will probably confine its reaction to the clashes in North Africa to expressing hopes that both sides will resolve differences by conciliation, United States officials said today.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 21 -- The pro-German parties in the Saar have mobilized a good deal of political talent.

MANILA, Aug. 21 -- President Ramon Magsaysay got just about everything he asked for from his Nationalist party senatorial nominating convention today. The convention had been advertised as another test of strength of his political leadership.
Months of recovery tasks loomed today for the six Northeastern states struck by treacherous week-end floods.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- One of the West's most colorful "ghost towns," Virginia City, will be re-created by Columbia Broadcasting System television for a musical drama titled "Virginia City." Michael Fessier has been signed by Harry Ackerman, C. B. S. director of special projects, to write the program as an hour or an hour-and-a-half color telecast.
"I DID send for a cup of tee," Samuel Pepys noted in 1660, "a China drink of which I had never drunk before."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Red Cross issued today a list of more than thirty camps in the flooded Pocono Mountain region of eastern Pennsylvania about which it had received unofficial word that all were safe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Elsie Janis, the "sweetheart of the American Expeditionary Forces" in World War I, has consented finally to have the story of her life told in a motion picture. Sol Siegel, who has an independent producer arrangement with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and is a personal friend of Miss Janis, bought the rights to her autobiography "So Far So Good."

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a fellowship program for special advanced training related to international and foreign affairs. The purpose is to help persons who are teaching or doing research in international relations to broaden their competence in related fields and to encourage a larger contribution from the social sciences to the understanding of international and foreign affairs.
The nation's principal state courts have cut trial delays. But in many populous counties it still takes more than two years to bring a civil jury case to trial.

Alfred P. Slaner has been elected executive vice president and vice chairman of the board and Joseph J. Bird has been elected executive vice president of Chester H. Roth Company Inc., hosiery manufacturer.
Prof. William Persen's dissertation in your issue of Aug. 10 on the iniquities of Israel compared with the virtues of the Arabs, notably the Egyptians, contains many misstatements of fact.

Godfrey P. Schmidt, president of AWARE, Inc., suggested in two television programs last night that there was a parallel between the technique of his organization and that of a labor union legally on strike.
The full dimensions of the Soviet food problem appear to have emerged as a result of the United States farm delegation's visit to the Soviet Union.

While terror stalks through French North Africa as a result of nationalist uprisings amounting to incipient insurrection and civil war, the French Government begins talks with nationalist leaders today in an effort to master the crisis in at least one part of the stricken area -- Morocco.
PARIS, Aug. 21 -- French currency reserves have reached a record high of $1,800,000,000. This figure is the one officially acknowledged by the Bank of France and may be higher.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- All grain and soybean futures were under pressure of liquidating sales last week. But the change to less favorable weather and the revival of serious damage claims affecting corn and soybeans encouraged a broadening of the demand on the setbacks and started short covering.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Commandant of the Coast Guard today expressed hope that the guilt-by-kinship case of a Coast Guard Academy graduate whose commission was held up would be settled quickly "in his favor."
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The American Dance Festival sponsored by Connecticut College closed this afternoon with the third performance of a busy week-end in Palmer Auditorium.
Lewis Hoad, Australia's on-again-off-again tennis flash, is "on" again -- and that's jolting news for America's Davis Cup team, The Associated Press reports.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 2 -- 0 and 8 -- 2, today to move within a half game of the league-leading New York Yankees.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Indications that the Chicago Transit Authority might forestall a fare increase until early next summer were contained in financial reports for June and July made public today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 22 -- A national Negro leader today urged members of his race to spend less money on "the fineries of life" and to give more financial aid to the fight for civil rights.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Airman 3/c Stephen Branzovich of near-by Farrell, Pa., said today he would fight the Air Force's plan to give him an undesirable discharge from the Reserve. He is accused of being a security risk because his father reportedly was a Communist.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Unseeded Bill Quillian of Seattle and Jerry Moss of St. Petersburg, Fla. -- brilliant at the net -- upset Cliff Mayne and Eddie Moylan today in the feature third-round men's match in the national doubles tennis tournament.

Form in lawn tennis is less variable than in most games, and its prophets usually are not without honor at home or abroad. Rare is the occasion when a Bill Tilden, a Don Budge or a Jack Kramer, in the plenitude of his powers, fails to make the expert look good.

NOW that the subject has been brought up, I realize that I never noticed before how few current novels are concerned with the psychological and emotional problems of stepmothers. Perhaps in these days of easy divorce and frequent remarriage -- of your children, my children and our children -- such problems are so commonplace they are taken for granted.

The French gambled with the lives of their own people and of the native people in Morocco last weekend and they lost -- heavily and terribly. Counting the obviously synchronized attacks in Algeria, at least 1,000 and perhaps as many as 1,300 people were killed, some of them horribly.
Only parts of five main highways in the flood-ravaged Northeast were still closed yesterday. However, several local roads were washed out, with detours in effect.

Having completed five weeks of location filming on Paramount's "The Proud and Profane" in the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, four of the cast principals, Deborah Kerr, William Holden, Thelma Ritter and William Ritter, will arrive here today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was unchanged to 11 points, 55 cents a bale, off yesterday. July showed the greatest weakness.
Latin-American countries reduced their purchases from the United States in July below the amounts they bought in June, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
GENEVA., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The United Nations secretariat proposed today an international charter for the treatment of prisoners.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The British Government is expected to resist Egypt's proposal that both countries offer troops to help quell a revolt in the southern Sudan. The two countries are still joint administrators of the Sudan until its full independence.
DENVER, Aug. 22 -- Lewis L. Strauss, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the United States is "clearly ahead" of the Soviet Union in development in atomic power.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Three photographers snapped pictures today while members of the American Bar Association participated in a mock courtroom trial.
The first American freighter fleet to meet the new cleanliness standards of the United States Public Health Service was honored yesterday at a Brooklyn pier.
DENVER, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement to newsmen today on his plans for a conference at Hartford, Conn., tomorrow on flood relief in the Northeast: ...
Dr. Buell Gallagher, president of City College, returned from Europe yesterday after attending the annual International Assembly of the World University Service in Helsinki, Finland.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug 22 -- Delegates from nineteen Latin-American Republics met here today to discuss means of fighting Soviet penetration of this hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- A high Defense Department official said tonight that jaundice -- not fall-out effects -- killed the Japanese fisherman who died after being exposed to fall-out from the big United States hydrogen bomb test at Eniwetok in March, 1954.
Governor Harriman promised yesterday a nonpolitical approach toward curbing juvenile delinquency.
Charles Greenberg and Associates, merchandising consultants, in 1140 Broadway -- Williams Co, brokers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Stimulated by a surge of unaccustomed hitting power and bolstered by the return of Dick Donovan, the Chicago White Sox looked forward today to getting off to a good start in the American League pennant stretch drive.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22 -- With the entire major-league field to themselves, the Giants and the Pirates were unable to get in one game of the two they had scheduled for today at Forbes Field. A rainstorm deluged the park after four and one-third innings of the opener and washed out everything that had happened.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Federal, state and local governments moved into swifter channels today to alleviate Connecticut's hardship from Friday's record flood.

Automation, whatever its general merits, has lost a round on points at Macy's. For at least one aspect of modern business, the old-fashioned way has turned out to be vastly superior to all the latest electronic gadgets.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- The Chicago Tribune made it official in its Sunday edition that after three-quarters of a century of unusual spelling, it has returned to the conventional.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio. Aug. 22 (AP) -- Arthur Cook of Washington held his 2-point lead intact tonight at the half-way point of the four-day national small-bore rifle championships. His score was 3,196 of a possible 3,200.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A 71-year-old retired professional and an Ohio farm wife, who admits being over 50, today won the national veterans championships as the fifty-sixth Grand American trapshoot opened.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mississippi will vote tomorrow for a governor in the Democratic run-off election.

David Bronstein of Russia took the lead in the interzonal chess tournament at Goteborg in Sweden yesterday, when he defeated J. H. Donner of the Netherlands in twenty-five moves, according to a report from Swedish news sources.

The State of Delaware announced yesterday plans for borrowing $7,000,000 on serial bonds on Sept. 8 to finance public improvements. The obligations will be dated Sept. 15, 1955 and will come due on Sept. 15 from 1956 to 1975.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- A "compelling case" for encouraging development of the pulp and paper industry in Latin America is made out in a report issued today by a committee of experts which deliberated the situation last fall in Buenos Aires.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- Indian parliamentary support was given today to plans for Government control over most commercial aspects of the newspaper business.
" TO an adult, play is entertainment, relaxation. To a child, play is work and a necessary preparation for adult life."
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress expressed "grave disquiet" today about the effects of the Government's economic policy.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Dave Gundy, the defending champion, won both races as the qualifying series for the twenty-eighth Long Island Sound midget sailing championship began at the American Yacht Club today.

There were some unexpected developments yesterday in the formal contract signing between Rocky Marciano, heavyweight champion, and Archie Moore, light heavyweight ruler, for theirs fifteen-round fight on Sept. 20 at Yankee Stadium.
ERIE, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The 6,000-mile wedding trip cruise of 77-year-old Harvey H. Hecker and his 70-year-old bride of three months ended today when he was drowned in a storm on Lake Erie.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- There was a thumping surprise today in the $50,950 Spinaway, the nation's oldest stake for 2-year-old fillies. The winner was Greentree Stable's $29.20-for-$2 Register, the fourth choice in a five - betting - unit line-up.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Soviet farm delegation put the Russian "new look" on display in the nation's capital today. In the whirlwind fashion that has become almost commonplace in their thirty-five days in the United States the Russians proceeded to break precedents right and left.
WASHINGTON, Aug 22 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins called today for Congressional consideration of possible extension and revision of the refugee admission act.
ROME, Aug. 22 -- The Communist party's chances of obtaining a foothold in the Italian Government through its allies, the Left-Wing Socialists, have receded.
A contribution of $30,000 to the Barter Theatre of Abingdon, Va., founded and managed by Robert Porterfield, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration announced tonight it had acted to take control of six more Government - insured projects in its drive to recover allegedly illegal windfall profits.
The New York Yankees yesterday announced that they would tour Japan this fall to play a series of exhibition games. Native professional and United States service teams will furnish the opposition.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- More than 45,000 officers, employes and unpaid advisers of the Commerce Department were warned today that conflict-of-interest activities could cost them their jobs.
Mayor Wagner was advised yesterday that a stronger City Planning Department and a modernized zoning code were needed if a balanced housing program was to be developed in the next fifteen years.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- The American Bar Association heard addresses today that reflected the deep concern of the law with the preservation of individual, national and international freedoms.

The New York regional Red Cross blood program received 472 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 225 taken at the United States Naval Air Station, Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, and 133 at the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., Kingsland Avenue and the East River, Brooklyn.
STROUDSBURG, Pa., Aug. 22 -- Fifty bodies have been recovered in this area from Thursday day night's flood, according to Dr. Charles H. Rushmore, Monroe County coroner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Former President Truman believes the "best cure" for juvenile delinquency "is for the mommas and poppas to stay at home and raise their families."

" The Big Surprise," a television show on which a participant could win $100,000 or more in cash, will make its debut over the National Broadcasting Company network on Saturday, Oct. 8, from 7:30 to 8 P. M.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 22 -- A group of Foreign Office officials departed today for Moscow to arrange the technical details of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to the Soviet capital next month.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- While French tanks, planes and infantry struck back at North African rebels, French and Moroccan leaders met today in Aixles-Bains to talk peace.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Vocational Advisory Service will be the beneficiary of the first public performance of the motion picture "Oklahoma!" on Oct. 11 at the Rivoli Theatre. The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical was filmed in the Todd-AO wide-screen process.
SHENANDOAH, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Twisted steel and splintered wood hurtled from a 100-foot coal breaker today, killing three men and injuring eleven others seriously in this anthracite community.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, Aug. 10 -- This ancient oasis, which stood on the southern marches of Israel in the days of the patriarchs, has become a boom town in the last three years. It is the regional capital and manufacturing center for the rapidly developing resources of the Negev.
GENEVA, Aug. 20 -- Boons to the home cook of the Nineteen Sixties were foreshadowed at the International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy that closed here today.

The one-story industrial building at 10-32 Forty-seventh Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Custom Crown Mat Company, Inc., of Los Angeles, Calif. The lessee, manufacturer of custom floor mats for automobiles, will occupy the structure as its eastern distribution center. The structure, containing about 4,700 square feet of space, was leased through Queens Industrials as brokers.

Twelve thousand giftware buyers from retail stores in all parts of the country will be in the New York market this week to refill their depleted inventories for the fall and Christmas selling seasons.
Naval Reserve air crew today had stretched the cruise time of Lockheed P2V patrol bomber more than four hours beyond the plane's rated time in the air with combat load.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Southern Association of Attorneys General condemned today any rebirth of the Ku Klux Klan in the south.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing protested today to President Eisenhower what it called a "do-nothing" pattern on racial segregation in the Administration's housing program.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 22 -- Barbara Romack, the defending champion, won easily in the opening round of the women's amateur championship of the United States Golf Association today.
Boston, Aug. 22 -- Thousands of homeless and jobless in Massachusetts and Rhode Island received today assuring messages of temporal and spiritual hope.
Parking and the flow of city traffic are two of the most serious problems facing New York City today.
ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Aug. 22 -- Dr. Jose Guillermo Trabanino, Foreign Minister of El Salvador, was elected today the first permanent Secretary General of the Organization of Central American States.

Plans for the construction of a new commercial heliport in Manhattan were outlined yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. The bi-state agency called upon the city's Department of Marine and Aviation for permission to develop a helicopter base along the Hudson River at Thirtieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Agriculture Department announced today it had reinstated six of eight top officials who were improperly dismissed last year. They received a total of $41,893 in back pay.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Another New Haven train was derailed at the Railroad Avenue curve here only five weeks after the Federal Express had jumped the tracks. Then one person died and more than a score were injured.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, Aug. 21 -- The Royal Commission studying Canada's economic outlook spent the past two days inspecting one of the Yukon's richest mines. The members of the commission flew from here to Mayo, 300 miles to the north, to visit the United Keno Hill Mines, the territory's richest producer of base metals. They returned here this evening by car.
BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 22 -- A series of last-minute frustrations figured in the sinking of the vacation cruise schooner Levin J. Marvel Aug 12, the captain, John Meckling, testified today.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- Gen. Raymond-Francis Duval, Commander in Chief of French forces in Morocco, was killed today in a plane crash near Kasba-Tadla in the Atlas Mountains of central Morocco.

An informal biography of Sir James Barrie by Lady Cynthia Asquith, his former secretary, friend and confidante, is planned for Sept. 9 publication by Dutton. In "Portrait of Barrie" Lady Cynthia presents the literary life of London from 1917 to 1937, and includes informal and "hitherto unpublished" reports of visits from Thomas Hardy, of Barrie's contacts with A. E. Housman and of his friendship with the Austrian actress, Elizabeth Bergner.

Boys' Towns of Italy will benefit from the Sept. 21 premiere of the Twentieth Century-Fox film, "The Left Hand of God," at the Roxy Theatre. Mrs. George P. Skouras is serving as chairman of the benefit committee.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu will leave tonight for "heart-to-heart" talks in Washington -- his first trip to the United States since he signed Japan's surrender ten years ago.

The stock market registered mixed changes yesterday, again in slow trading. Railroad issues were a bit firmer than last week; but the industrial group generally lost ground. Gains and losses were mostly in fractions. In only a relatively few issues were the price changes as much as a point.

After a spectacular quiescence of three years, and with equally spectacular lack of sound and fury, John L. Lewis has announced a wage increase of $2 a day, plus fringe benefits, for the 120,000 miners in the Northern bituminous coal fields. While the Southern operators are reported-reluctant to follow suit, they usually do -- which would affect 80,000 more.

With travel and living expenses covered by scholarships, twenty-eight professors and graduate students from colleges and universities in twenty states will be exploring Wall Street the next three weeks, seeing firsthand what makes the marketplace tick.
ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- The huge tent of the Empire State Music Festival here rode out last week's storm while floods were devastating more permanent structures all around it.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 22 -- An Israeli Army patrol stormed and captured an Egyptian outpost in the Gaza Strip today.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 -- Yugoslavia has asked the Western powers to help her settle some pressing foreign debts amounting to $100,000,000. These are the most critical among foreign obligations officially estimated at $400,000,000.

ITALY TODAY is the name of a housewares shop that has just moved from Ninth Avenue to 59 West Fifty-sixth Street. in so doing it has acquired a counter, some tables, chairs and an espresso machine, and thus it is now a coffee house as well as a store.

A supermarket is planned for the site of St. Philomena's Roman Catholic Church at 29 Northfield Avenue and 17 Collins Terrace in Livingston, N. J. The five-acre plot has been purchased from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark by the C. R. Realty Company, a holding company for the Food Fair supermarket chain. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today that foreign countries were accepting the United States plan for selling some of its surplus cotton on the world market. He commented that it showed some of the fears about United States disposal of agricultural stocks have been relieved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Buses and street cars operated here today for the first time in fifty-two days with little back-to-work confusion. Officials estimated the passenger load at about 50 per cent below that normally carried before the strike began July 1.

The removal of Dr. Frank S. Home from his position as guiding head of the Racial Relations Service of the Housing and Home Finance Agency and of his assistant, Corienne R. Morrow, has implications greater than the "budgetary reasons" to which it has been ascribed.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Two lightweight, low-slung stream-lined trains were exhibited in this area today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The executive committee of the Southern Coal Producers Association discussed today the new labor contract negotiated by Northern mine owners. The president of the association said they had not reached a decision on whether to agree to similar terms.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 22 -- The North Korean Communists said today they would return tomorrow the United States Air Force pilot shot down in the demilitarized zone. The pilot is Second Lieut. Guy H. Bumpass Jr., who is being held in a North Korean hospital with a fractured skull.
One of the largest animal shipments for a single zoo is scheduled to be unloaded tomorrow morning from the Dutch freighter Roebiah in Brooklyn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Changes of personnel to strengthen its television operations were made known today by Twentieth Century-Fox. Otto Lang, who was transferred from the studio's theatrical producers staff last week, will be an executive in charge of video production under Sid Rogell, Fox vice president and general manager of the TV project.
HAYWARD, Calif., Aug. 22 (UP) -- Nine cars of the Western Pacific Railroad's westbound California Zephyr were derailed here late today, but none of the 250 passengers aboard was injured.
One of the tragedies in New York State is that many of our 16,000,000 people, crowded into great cities, have no opportunity to enjoy the magnificent beauties of the Adirondacks and the Catskills.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Effects of new model change-overs are beginning to show in the auto industry's output volume.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 22 -- A reactionary fight is being waged against labor and is being intensified, A. F. Hartung, president of the International Woodworkers of America, C. I. O., said today.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Some 40,000 United Auto Workers, C. I. O., at eighteen International Harvester plants in six states were called out on strike at 1:01 A. M. Eastern Daylight Time today. Company and union negotiators had failed to reach a new contract agreement.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- "Queuemania" is an ailment that afflicts people with a compulsive urge to line up behind someone or something, even a lamp-post.
A children's camp near Poughkeepsie is still run by a former officer of the defunct International Workers Order identified as a Communist, it was charged at a state legislative inquiry yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 22 -- Although the Brooklyn Dodgers would like to play seven regular baseball games here next year, Walter O'Malley, president of the club, reiterated today that he hoped to build a stadium on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn before 1958.
A detective shot and seriously wounded one man and arrested three others yesterday morning in a tavern at 232 West Forty-eigthth Street.
WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Frank Lemoine of May Pearl, Tex., captured second division honors in the national toque tournament today, posting a 3-0 mark in the round-robin finals.

Reminders from Government officials and others in recent weeks have been increasingly frequent and increasingly pointed that recovery, like recession, brings its own problems and its own dangers. Moral suasion is being generously employed to reinforce the monetary brakes on an economy that has been getting too exuberant for its own good.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 22 -- Gov. George M. Leader completed today plans for the evacuation of up to 10,O00 children from summer camps in the Pocono Mountains as the Commonwealth pressed all of its agencies into the effort to cope with damage and problems in the wake of eastern Pennsylvania's death-dealing flood.

The New York and Brooklyn chapters of the American Red Cross have answered nearly 20,000 inquiries since Friday about the location and condition of relatives and young campers in flood-stricken areas.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that contracts had been awarded on the final phase of its experimental conversion and engine improvement program for Liberty ships.
New York Maritime Festival Week will get under way at noon today.
The development of a new drug, equanil, said to bring quick and safe relief to those who suffer from tenseness and anxiety, was announced today by Wyeth Laboratories.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, said tonight the Big Four conference in Geneva "justified the hopes and aspirations of peace-minded people," the Moscow radio reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The United States is prodding France to move more swiftly in search of political solutions to her North African problems. In accordance with its policy of nonintervention, the State Department declined to comment today on the North African riots.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The twenty-second World Conference of Young Men's Christian Associations ended here tonight with a "re-dedication rally" at the Palais des Sports attended by about 8,000.
Mayor Wagner officially welcomed yesterday the Grand Encampment of Knights Templar of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported tonight that earnings of private United States investments abroad reached a new high of $2,535,000,000 in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to let it fly the New York-Washington and New York-Boston routes.

Last week's floods will aggravate, at least temporarily, the growing steel shortage. Many steel products are even now on the scarce list. Loss of production, due to the watery aftermath of Hurricane Diane, promises to intensify the squeeze.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has uncovered sixty violations of agreements by business concerns to cease allegedly illegal practices, it was announced today.

The five-story remodeled building containing twenty apartments at 1553 York Avenue, near Eighty-second Street, has been sold by the Polrose Realty Corporation to clients of Albert C. Drucker. George Schaffer of the Maxwell Brody Company and Cornel Rowe of Brener Lewis Inc., were co-brokers in the transaction.

The temperature failed yesterday by eighth tenths of a degree to establish a new record for heat. At 3:55 P.M. the mercury rose to 89.2 degrees, high point for the day, and then began to recede. Thus the 1944 and 1955 records of nineteen days each of above-90 degree temperatures remained equal.

Ownership of the Trust Company of North America, 115 Broadway, has changed hands. A group of private investors has purchased substantially all the outstanding stock of the bank, Charles D. Runyan, president, announced yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 22 -- The first conference of Southeast Asia defense alliance members to be held in Australia began in Melbourne today.
Net profit of the Parker Appliance Company for the fiscal year ended June 30 amounted to $1,120,342, sharply above the $686,443 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced today that Chrysler Corporation workers had voted overwhelmingly to strike, if necessary, to obtain contract demands.
Smarting from their three setbacks at the hands of the Phillies last week-end, the Dodgers returned to Brooklyn yesterday and sought to sharpen their bat-ring eyes.

The City Planning Commission heard yesterday a request by the Parks Department for a 1956 capital budget allocation of $45,485,647. John Mulcahy, assistant executive officer of the department, told the commission that the funds would be used to advance its program of school and neighborhood centers, recreation centers and park projects.

A jury in Federal Court returned a verdict of guilty yesterday against Hyman Harvey Klein of Los Angeles, former Baltimore liquor dealer who allegedly made $30,000,000 in wartime Canadian whisky deals.

A HIGHLY improbable bit of Graustarkian fluff, with no message and no moral, provided ninety minutes of relaxing and enjoyable television last night. The presentation was the musical "The King and Mrs. Candle," seen on "Producers Showcase" over Channel 4 from 8 to 9:30 P. M.

City Hall's promises to do something substantial about improving the New York waterfront, antedate the second World War. Mayor O'Dwyer expressed early in his administration his concern over pier deterioration. One Marine and Aviation Commissioner after another offered a program.

Thousands of New Jerseyans bailed dirty water out of their basements and shoveled mud off living room carpets yesterday while state officials laid plans for rehabilitation of $100,000,000 of damaged property.
TRENTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Mayor Leo P. Carlin of Newark said today that a proposal to build a reservoir at Chimney Rock faced possible defeat if it went to a referendum in November.

The near-by September coffee position soared the 2-cents-a-pound dally limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The rise was influenced by reports that the expected revision in Brazil's exchange rate may be announced too late to affect September deliveries. The strength in the spot month was reflected across the board.

Olin Downes had a passionate love for music and the people who made it. His enthusiasm for both never diminished in fifty years of activity as a critic, more than thirty of which he spent on The New York Times. No matter how many times he heard a work, no matter how many times he heard a performance, he had the precious capacity of reacting as though it were a wholly fresh experience.
