Pier 57, Hudson River, was hit yesterday by another wildcat strike. It was the latest in the long series of unauthorized work stoppages that have plagued the Port of New York's newest pier, at West Fifteenth Street, since the Grace Line moved into the facility last December.

The advertising specialty and premium field, which gives signs at times of being a free-for-all among a dozen contenders for leadership, is to have still another major contestant for business. The Chase Bag Company, a major organization specializing in many types of packaging, is entering the field with wares made of textiles, plastic film and paper.

CAIRO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An aging desert fighter who once challenged the armies of France and Spain in the Moroccan mountains predicted today that the French would leave North Africa "only when North Africans drive them out."

The fourth and final concert in the series presented in Washington Square Park by the Washington Square Association last night drew an audience of 3,800. The concert was financed by a grant from the Music Performance Trust Funds recommended by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

MALVERNE, L. I., Aug. 22 -- A husband and wife team of amateur radio operators continued today into their fourth day of handling vital messages of aid and comfort to and from flood-stricken areas for the American Red Cross here.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- Prices are going down in Moscow and the number of services offered to consumers is going up -- on a very limited scale.
Led by President Eisenhower, Government and private agencies were intensifying relief measures yesterday in the Northeastern flood disaster.
I am intrigued by the comment in your editorial "Europe and the Saar" that the Saar is rich in coal and steel and France needs that production to escape a dangerous inferiority to the Germans.
Thirty persons, including nine policemen, were named yesterday in a criminal information stemming from a morals case in the Coney Island area of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Washington rooming-house proprietor was indicted today on the charge of having falsely accused a White House clerk of being a subversive.
GENEVA, Aug. 22 -- Scientists of six countries met here today to discuss urgent problems of international control of certain aspects of nuclear energy.
A big question yesterday, as flood damage estimates in six Northeastern states ran near three billion dollars, was "Who's going to foot the bill?"

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation has acquired an interest in the Hycon Manufacturing Company. The two firms have established an inter - company working relationship, Victor Emanuel, Avco chairman and president, and Harry Oedekerk, Hycon chairman, announced yesterday.

The Erie Railroad foresees an additional $10,000,000 in new freight revenue from plants that have become situated along its lines in 1955. Paul W. Johnston, Erie's president, made the prediction yesterday in announcing that the National Biscuit Company had acquired forty-acres at Fair Lawn, N. J., and would build a factory there.
I have just returned from a trip which included travel through New York State.
DESPITE the "zephyrs" that have been creating a chop on the Sound and off-shore waters, the fishing on eastern Long Island has been productive.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (UP) -- Alcohol and soft music make it easier for a patient to undergo surgery, three doctors reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Treasury reported today that its short-term borrowing costs had decreased.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A move to assure full disclosure and identification of all participants in the solicitation of proxies was announced today by J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 22 (UP) -- An organization of prominent North Carolinians was chartered today to "maintain the purity and culture of the white race."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Darryl F. Zanuck, studio chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, will take personal charge of two big budget pictures to be made during the next twelve months.
SPRING CITY, Tenn., Aug. 22 -- A 100-car freight train demolished a school bus loaded with about forty children here today. At least ten children were killed and all the others were injured.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Ted Williams drove in four runs tonight as the fourth-place Boston Red Sox blasted the Cleveland Indians, 8--3. The Tribe, thwarted in their try for five straight, outhit Boston 10--6.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Aug. 23--Premier Moshe Sharett called tonight for a "determined and sustained effort to accelerate the pace of immigration" of Jews from North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23, -- The United States Government apologized today to the Indian Government and to the Indian Ambassador for an incident at a Texas airport. The Ambassador was asked to leave a public dining room when he was mistaken for a Negro.
New York retailers soon will close their books on a summer selling season that fell short of fulfilling the high hopes that had been held out for apparel business during the hot-weather months.
Paul LaPalme's slick relief hurling and the lusty bats of his team-mates combined to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-1 victory over the Giants at the Polo Grounds last night.
Business during the rest of this year will be as good as, if not better than it was in the record first half.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) --George Genereux of Saskatoon, Sask., today won the Class AA championship of North America at the Grand American trapshoot.
ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Aug. 23--Delegates of the five Central American republics were putting the finishing touches today on the first formal conference of the Organization of Central American States.

LONDON, Aug. 23--A Canberra twin-jet bomber flew from London to New York and back today in less than fourteen and a half hours. The time included a refueling stop of thirty-five minutes in New York. It was a record dual crossing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--A grim official search for funds to alleviate distress in northeastern flood disaster areas was under way here tonight.
A new big block of long-term debenture obligations of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company has been priced for marketing by underwriters to yield 3.5 per cent to maturity in 1991.

Many debutantes of the current season will be introduced to society at the tenth annual Yuletide Assembly Ball, to be held Dec. 27 in the ballroom of The Ambassador. Miss Bonnie May Murray is directing the ball.
Nine suspended policemen were among thirty persons who pleaded not guilty yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, to charges arising from a morals case in the Coney Island area.

The Cerro da Pasco Corporation, said to be the largest single commercial enterprise in Peru, which produces copper, lead, zinc, silver and gold, achieved this year the highest sales and the second largest earnings for the first half in its fifty-year history.

Trans-Canada Air Lines will start tourist service between Canada and Florida, Bermuda and the Caribbean area beginning Nov. 1. Fare reductions up to 34 per cent from the established first-class fares will be offered.

Concerned over the leagueleading Dodgers' recent lack of punch, Manager Walt Alston shuffled his line-up last night. The Brooks responded with an eleven-hit barrage that added up to a 6-4 victory over the Cubs at Ebbets Field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (A.P.)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 11,000 head: butchers 50 to 75c lower, full decline on U.S. No. 1 and 2 grades under 230 pounds: sows 25 to 50c, mostly around 25c lower, trade moderately
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 --Columbia Pictures has invested about $400,000 in the purchase of screen rights to two new novels.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP)--Following is the text of the remarks today by President Eisenhower after his conference with Governors on flood relief: I have met here with Governors and Federal officials that you have heard mentioned in this broadcast.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (UP) --Vic Powers' fifteenth homer and clutch single and Art Ditmar's outstanding relief work gave the Kansas City Athletics a 4-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
Knights Templar trooped in eleventh - century splendor down Fifth Avenue last night.

PARIS, Aug. 23--The French Government decided today to call up military reservists to reinforce the garrisons in Algeria and Morocco. About ten divisions or their equivalent are already stationed in the two countries.

The stock market recovered sharply yesterday in more active dealings. The railroads, which had been showing some strength in recent sessions, led the way and the chemicals, motors and steels joined in the upturn as trading progressed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 --A series of thirty-four onehour telefilms, called "President of the United States," is being planned by World Films, headed by William Rowland and Monte Brice. The series would draw on the dramatic episodes and achievements in the lives of past Presidents.
Emergency and long - range plans to protect flood-damaged New York areas from future catastrophes will be discussed today at a conference in Albany.
FIFTY-seventh Street, which is beginning to sag a bit about the jowls, may be due for a facelifting soon.

Commodity markets were generally dull yesterday. Rubber and wool rose about 1 cent a pound on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, hides, zinc, copper and onions also advanced; coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar, potatoes and lead closed mixed, and burlap eased.

Florida Rejects Bids The Florida State Board of Education yesterday rejected all bids submitted by investment banking syndicates for an issue of $10,585,000 of serial bonds intended to make available school building funds to six Florida counties.
The subway kiosk will be gone from the Manhattan scene by the end of 1957 if Borough President Hulan E. Jack has his way.
Admiral of the Winds One can't help wondering what the reaction of Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort would be, were he alive, to the current practice of attaching feminine names to hurricanes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--After flying nearly 2,000 miles to view the destruction in flood-ravaged Northeastern states, President Eisenhower was temporarily back in the White House tonight. He had seen a great many clouds, but not much flood damage. A low, sullen overcast blanketed most of the six states he had planned to survey from the air early this morning.

VIENNA, Aug. 19--Experts from the Austrian state archives have confirmed the authenticity of a document found recently in Berlin as the secret report written by Baron Krauss, the Vienna Chief of Police in 1889, on the Mayerling tragedy.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 23 --Long Islanders were warned today that they are required by law to report salvagable materials washing up on the shoreline from disaster areas in Connecticut and Rhode Island.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 (UP)-- Frank Thomas drove in Eddie O'Brien, a pinch runner, with a sacrifice fly in the eighth inning tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 23--Dave Gundy of the American Yacht Club and Vincent J. (Bizzy) Monte-Sano 3d of Larchmont Were tied with 8 points each after two Scovill Cup races were sailed today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--Foreign long-term investments in this country reached the record total of $11,000,000,000 at the end of 1954, the Government disclosed today.
It is not easy to reconcile the President's reiterated endorsement of "ever-expanding levels of international trade" with his decision to increase the bicycle tariff by 50 per cent.

THE New York Public Library announced yesterday that it had just acquired for its Science and Technology Division a complete set of Sears, Roebuck catalogues on microfilm. The catalogue's date back to 1892.

INEVITABLY during a summer in France, Americans drive from Paris southwest to the chateau country around Tours, to the Smile of France and the Garden of France, as the area has been called. This delightful region around the Loire River is full of history.

Sales and earnings of Food Pair Stores, Inc., in the quarter ended July 23, first three months of its current fiscal year, surpassed all previous records. Sales for the period exceeded $100,000,000 for the first time in the company's history, Samuel Friedland, chairman, and Louis Stein, president, reported to stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox stumbled into first place in the American League tonight by splitting a twilight-night program with the Baltimore Orioles. The Sox won the opener, 6--2, and dropped the finale, 10--3, before a crowd of 33,525.

"Year of Decisions," the first volume of two of "The Memoirs of Harry S. Truman," has been scheduled for Nov. 2 publication by Doubleday. It will cover President Truman's first year in office, with flashbacks to his earlier career in Missouri and in the Senate.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Lord Douglas, chairman of the British European Airways, said today that preliminary investigation had been made into the possibility of running an air service to and from the Iron Countries.

IN THE back-to-school department of a Fifth Avenue store yesterday a girl of about 12 was telling her troubles to a sales clerk. The child's mother was busily examining a selection of dresses and skirts while child and clerk stood idly by.

TENNIS matches from a television studio were seen last night over WABD (Channel 5). The presentation was part of a plan by the station to stage many sports events on its premises, with readily available lighting and electronic devices, rather than from remote stadiums and arenas.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23--Senator Alleen J. Ellender told Soviet leaders tonight that he proposed to organize a delegation of United States Senators and Representatives to visit the Soviet Union, next year.
FORT SMITH, Northwest Territories, Aug. 22--Members of the Royal Commission studying the economic prospects in Canada "north of sixty" discussed their impressions of the Yukon today.
Five games in the sixth round of the interzone chess tournament in Goteborg were decided last night. All were drawn, according to a report received through Swedish news sources. Five were adjourned.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 23 --The contract system of shipping wool from Australia to Europe and Britain broke down today.

NARA, Japan, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Three Americans teamed with Japan's world champion in the breast-stroke tonight in an assault on the world 400-meter medley relay record and missed by eight-tenths of a second.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is trying to arrange for a color television presentation of "Porgy and Bess," the American folk operetta now touring South America.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 23--Offensive operations were in progress today against rebel tribesmen in Morocco's central plain.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Early weather news was more favorable and caused selling of corn futures by recent buyers. The midday forecasts, however, indicated a return of high temperatures in the northwest section, with little rain in sight, and there was some commission absorption on the setbacks with a partial recovery.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 23-- The growing menace of dog packs to livestock and poultry on Suffolk County farms is the target of a campaign started today by the county Farm Bureau.
Last week's withdrawal of the Davis Cup players from the national doubles tournament at Brookline, Mass., points up the difference in tennis as played on various surfaces.

LONDON, Aug. 23--Thornton Wilder's new play, "A Life in the Sun," was met without enthusiasm today by most of the representative British theatre critics. The play, whose theme comes mainly from "Alcestis" of Euripides, is the major dramatic presentation of the Edinburgh Festival.
WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Aug. 23--A Federal program for flood reconstruction in the Northeastern states was drafted here today by President Eisenhower and the Governors of six states.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A tentative plan for administering direct controls over prices, wages, salaries and rents and for rationing measures has been completed by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- Lawyers in the atomic age face novel legal problems "almost as appalling as the force itself," delegates to the annual meeting of the American Bar Association were told today.

Courageous describes Peter Cookson's action in tying up the stage rights to Don M. Mankiewicz' best seller, "Trial." The dramatization will mark the author's first attempt in the theatre. Acting in it will be Mr. Cookson and his wife, Beatrice Straight.
Hamilton Richardson moved into the Davis Cup picture yesterday as a possible singles player on the defending United States team.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) --Stan Lopata's bases loade single capped a three-run come from-behind rally in the ninth inning as the Philadelphia Phillies nipped the Milwauke Braves, 4--3, tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23--Seven Asian, Arab and African delegates called on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today for help in halting the bloodshed in French North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The Consumer Price Index rose in July for the second month in a row to reach its highest point in 1955. The rise was 0.3 per cent.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, Aug. 23--Lieut. Guy H. Bumpass, who was shot down last Wednesday over the demilitarized zone near here, walked back to freedom today. He was returned by the North Koreans, who had held him a prisoner for six days.
On ever-widening fronts, the nation's leaders labored yesterday to increase safeguards against floods, as well as to help victims of last week-end's disaster in the Northeast.

HARTFORD, Aug. 23--Fifteen miles northwest of Hartford, in a deep and sudden valley along the Farmington River, a village of 3,000 persons is demonstrating again how resilient the human spirit can be.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 23-- State law enforcement authorities made surprise raids today on fourteen suspected gambling establishments in Bayonne. Twenty-eight persons were seized, but three were released later.
The Copper and Brass Warehouse Association reported yesterday that last week's floods would cost brass mills in Connecticut a large part of their normal September production.
HARTFORD, Aug. 23--The dispute between Connecticut and New York State over use of Mianus River water seemed headed today for the Federal courts.
New liability insurance rates, effective today, impose higher costs on motorists in most fastgrowing suburbs.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 --The cruise schooner, Levin J. Marvel, which sank in Chesapeake Bay during Hurricane Connie with the loss of 14 passengers, was in doubtful condition before she sailed, two witnesses told a Coast Guard board of inquiry today.
The writer of the following letter is a justice in the Supreme Court of the State of New York.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23 (UP) --J. P. Coleman, State Attorney General pledged to perpetual racial segregation, swept to victory tonight in Mississippi's Democratic run-off primary for Governor.

A full water tank fell through the roof of the Fortyeighth Street Theatre yesterday morning and turned half the orchestra into rubble and ruins. No one was hurt. The theatre, which is situated on the north side between, the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, was unoccupied at the time except for Harold Blakey, the house porter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Four new nuclear-powered submarines dominate the Navy's shipbuilding and conversion program for the 1956 fiscal year. Thirty-three ships are include in the program.

NO one knows whether a largemouth bass strikes a lure through anger, belligerence or hunger, which undoubtedly is one reason why tackle companies find it profitable to produce a wide assortment of plugs, spoons and spinners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) --The Justice Department disclosed today that it had paid forty-seven undercover informants a total of $43,000 in fees and expenses in a recent twentyone-and-one-half-month period.

The industrial plant of the Reilly Tar and Chemical Corporation in Newark, N. J., has been purchased by the Pitt-Consol Chemical Company, a New Jersey subsidiary of the Pittsburgh, Consolidation Coal Company. Comprising forty-eight acres with a frontage of 612 feet on the Passaic River, the property was acquired in a transaction negotiated by Joseph T. Mirtl and Henry H. Martin of William A. White Sons, brokers.

HOUSTON, Aug. 23--Mayor Roy Hofheinz apologized to Ambassador Mehta today. John Stephen, the Mayor's executive assistant, said that the dining room at the International Airport in the future "should conform" to the terms of the contract with the Federal Government outlawing segregation at the airport facility.
Battery Park was host yesterday to 2,000 visitors at the opening day of New York Maritime Festival Week.

Diane's devastation by torrential rains and flood has now been grimly revealed in all its tragic magnitude. It staggers the imagination: some 200 dead, with the injured as yet unreported, and property damage of about $3 billions, not to mention the intangible damage to the health and nerves of those who have suffered and the wider ranging effects of life's routine disrupted.

The Gaza strip is in the news again, which means that Israelis and Egyptians have clashed in one more sanguinary incident. The Gaza zone is a ribbon of land along the Mediterranean Sea, 125 square miles in size, between Israel and Egypt. Egypt administers it and the Egyptian Army has the task of defending it.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 23-- Gen. Sun Li-jen refused tonight to discuss the events that precipitated his resignation as personal Chief of Staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in a case involving an alleged Communist spy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--A new treaty regulating relations between the United States and Panama went into effect today. The exchange of instruments of ratification took place at the State Department.
Flood damage to the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was assessed yesterday at $10,000,000.

Gross revenues of the Erie Railroad for the first seven months of this year rose 2.7 per cent to $90,858,952 from $88,487,010 in the corresponding period in 1954, but the net declined. On the other hand, share earnings went up nearly 24 per cent.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 23 --Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore eliminated the defending champion, Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., in the second round of the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

ATHENS, Aug. 23--The threecornered argument over Cyprus is distasteful and wholly unnecessary. It is to be hoped the coming London conference among Britain, Greece and Turkey will help to calm the atmosphere. At present hysteria is being permitted to poison Allied relationships and disturb the strategic balance of the eastern Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- President Eisenhower's Cabinet officer in charge of health is "taking a new look at the whole business of health reinsurance."

The Glidden Company, producer of paints, foods, chemicals, metals and naval stores, reported yesterday a 31.2 per cent increase in earnings in the nine months ended on July 31, as compared with the nine-month period ending July 31, 1954.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UP) --The Weather Bureau has begun an official investigation to find out if it gave the public all possible warning of the floods that swept the northeastern states last week.

IN 1916, when he was only 22 years of age, Aldous Huxley's first book was published, a collection of poems called "The Burning Wheel." Today, when he is 61 and the world-famous author of more than forty books, his new book is published, a short novel called "The Genius and the Goddess."* Judged as a work of fiction, almost nothing good can be said for this pompous, pretentious and quite preposterous story.

Thousands of commuters were late for work yesterday morning when fifteen trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad were delayed from several minutes to more than two hours in arriving at Grand Central Terminal.
A group of parents "sang" the blues yesterday--a tuneless lament on their daily difficulties-- at a meeting of the Play Schools Association at Public School 125, 425 West 123d Street.
Eight more witnesses invoked the Fifth Amendment yesterday before the Joint Legislative committee to Study Charitable and Philanthropic Agencies and Organizations.

The Ripley Manufacturing Corporation, manufacturer and retailer of men's and boys' clothing, has leased 12,000 square feet of store space in the twostory building at the southwest corner of Courtlandt Avenue and 149th Street in the Bronx.
Apartment properties on Washington Heights were conveyed in realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Members of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy said today that the United States was "fumbling" its program to harness the power of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful purposes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- A group of new Foreign Service officers taking a Foreign Service Institute training course received congratulations today from the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles.

An assertion that aggressive and alert newspapers can grow despite television and at the expense of television" was put yesterday before a meeting of the Mid-American Periodical Distributors in Chicago by Chesser M. Campbell, president of The Tribune Company and publisher of The Chicago Tribune.

DETROIT, Aug. 23--A rise of half an index point between April 15 and July 15 in the Consumer Price Index will mean wage increases of one cent an hour in September for 392,000 hourly employes of General Motors and 144,000 hourly employes at Ford.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved somewhat irregularly yesterday. The close was 14 points lower to 6 points higher than on Monday, with the near months the weakest.

KHARTUM, The Sudan, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--The Government announced today that mutinous soldiers holding Torit had offered to surrender if British or Egyptian troops replaced Sudanese forces in nearby, Juba.

BASIL--once called the herb of kings--is becoming more common in American cookery. The sweet, fragrant plant is well known to European epicureans, who use it for flavoring soups, meats and sauces. Italians, Portuguese and Spaniards value it especially with tomatoes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I express my sincere appreciation of the benevolent interest in the cause of Cyprus displayed by C. L. Sulzberger in his recent correspondence from Istanbul, entitled "The Kremlin's New Tactics Weaken Allied Defense."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23-- Two California Mayors, seated one mile apart, chatted on a telephone today while looking at each other.
PARIS, Aug. 23 -- France came closer to a political crisis tonight. The situation was aggravated by a right-wing attempt to block a compromise with the Moroccan nationalists.

SITE 215, Negev Archaeological Survey, Israel, Aug. 11--This prehistoric graveyard on a barren desert peak, fifty miles south of Beersheba, was marked on a map today for the first time. The site was recorded in an archaeological survey of a long-ago civilization that, incidentally, has given the Israeli Government a key to open the arid Negev fastnesses for settlement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Vladimir M. Matskevich, Acting Soviet Minister of Agriculture and spokesman for Russia's "new look," received an ovation from an audience here today.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A huge Air Force transport, crippled by engine trouble, crashed in flames into three small houses near the Air Force base here before dawn today. At least nine fliers and civilians were killed.
PARIS, Aug. 23--French, newspapers expressed shock and anger today over the insurrections and massacres by nationalists in this country's North African territories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Jesse Markham, a Government economist, told a Congressional inquiry today the Federal antiprice-discrimination law kept prices to the consumer higher than they needed to be.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23--Dobey Doc is a 3-yearold race horse. He hasn't done much to distinguish himself. And it seems unlikely that he'll ever be a top-notcher. But he was good enough to win Saratoga's main event today.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Stocks failed to follow up early gains today. The rises were whittled down or replaced by small falls.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 22--In a hall in Neunkirchen, not far from a steel mill that threw a column of fire into the night sky, Johannes Hoffmann, Premier of the Saar, urged a large audience to vote in the October referendum for the plan to give the territory a "European" political status.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 23--The Federation of Malaya's Chief Minister announced tonight that the Government would offer an amnesty to Communists in September.
The "short interest" in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange at mid-month in August amounted to 2,823,446 shares, according to figures released by the Exchange.

Industry sharply challenged the professors of engineering yesterday. Robert Paxton, executive vice president of General Electric Company, described at Schenectady the "almost insatiable" need of his and other companies for engineering graduates.

The Mayor's Committee for Better Housing appointed in October, 1954, is now driving toward completion of its work, done under the chairmanship of Henry Bruere. The reports of more than half of its subcommittees have been made public. The full committee of 117 members when appointed by Mr. Wagner is now working on the final report, which will surely illuminate and we hope help to solve New York City's housing problem.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) --Business has been stronger than usual this summer, the Department of Commerce said today.
DETROIT, Aug. 23--The thermometer took quite a drop here tonight and so did the Yankees.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The survey of commutation facilities recently published by The Times was most interesting. No mention was made, however, of the fact that these commutation railroads lessen traffic congestion in the cities involved.
The Port of New York Authority has been, denied permission, temporarily at least, to develop a heliport along the Hudson River at Thirtieth Street.
A wildcat strike involving one man on one pier spread like an epidemic yesterday and threatened port-wide paralysis today.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The stock markets rallied smartly at the opening of a new bookkeeping account today. The lead was taken by Government stocks and the improvement spread to industrial shares.
A trusted employe of a brokerage house was charged yesterday with forgery in attempting to conceal the theft of $180,000 from his firm over the last twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A Hoover Commission task force criticized today the Air Force's program of helping Britain build jet fighters and bombers.

Ray Drake of Far Rockaway, Queens, gave Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn a boxing lesson in Madison Square Garden last night. The Long Island fighter gained a unanimous decision over the ten-round route in the middleweight bout.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Ambassador Mehta politely turned down an invitation today from the Mayor of Houston to visit his home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Aug. 24 -- The first formal meeting of Organization of Central American States ended today amid harmony.
A NEW outdoor method of cooking chicken, corn and potatoes requires one piece of equipment only -- a kitchen scrub pail.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Aug. 24 -- Reports seeping through to Khartum from the southern provinces indicate that the trouble there, which began as a mutiny of southern soldiers in the Sudan Defense Force, has assumed the character of a popular rising.
Employes of offices at 247 Park Avenue gave 180 pints of blood on Tuesday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. The day's total was 462 pints.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A General Motors worker who failed to win a court injunction against a new union shop contract paid initiation fees and dues today to the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.
Stockholders of the Lukens Steel Company yesterday amended the company charter to broaden its field of operations.

Directors of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company voted yesterday to raise about $65,000,000 in the public market by the sale of new pipeline bonds and common stock and to distribute to company shareholders one new share for each three held.
Uta Hagen, who gave a sensitive performance in last year's "The Magic and the Loss," will undertake another role characterized by strong and tragic overtones.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The United States will begin talks with other Western powers next week to work out an approach to the next round of negotiations with the Soviet Union.
Don Liddle, Giants' left-hander, won his sixth game since July 17 when he checked the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 to 1, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Today's new film is "You're Never Too Young," a Paramount comedy in Vista Vision and color with Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, at the Criterion. Paul Jones produced and Norman Taurog directed. The screen play by Sidney Sheldon is based on a story by Fannie Kilbourne. Heading the supporting cast are Diana Lynn, Nina Foch and Raymond Burr.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- Experts today looked forward only ten years to a $20,000,000,000-a-year electronics industry.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A United States airman shot twelve persons, three fatally, within a few minutes today at the United States Air Force base at Manston, Kent, about seventy miles from here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The State Department will sponsor lectures in European and Near Eastern countries by the members of the United States delegation to the recent atomic energy conference in Geneva.

IN the market from January through December, fresh corn is most gratifying to New York City appetites in late summer and early fall when it comes from near-by gardens. For the shorter the trip from stalk to table, the less chance is there for sugar in the kernels to change to starch.
The port's waterfront strike collapsed yesterday.

Interval Concerts continue to live up to their name. For the sixth successive year they are filling the interval between the close of the summer season and the opening of the fall one. And last night, Norman Seaman, the originator of the series, presented the first of the ten concerts he is managing at Carnegie Recital Hall before music's 1955-56 season really gets under way.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 24 -- Second Lieut. Guy H. Bumpass Jr. will be flown to Japan tomorrow for further medical examination. His stated determination not to reveal information to the Communists after his plane was shot down in Korea won high praise from his commanding officers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UP) -Union officials charged today that rs. Esther Quigley's onewoman "war" against their strike was a plot "instigated" .by the company in an effort to halt the walkout;

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A group of southern coal mine owners employing 10,000 to 12,000 miners ratified today a wage agreement for a $2-a-day pay rise.
LIKE sparks from a faulty generator, brain waves will be flashing at Forest Hills over the coming week-end. The non-playing captains of the Davis Cup teams will be thinking.
Rabbi Emanuel Rackman's letter in The Times of Aug. 16 urging both parties to nominate President Eisenhower in 1956 is a startling, radical but rather unrealistic suggestion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner has ordered the Kordol Corporation of America, 618 Lexington Avenue, New York City, to stop "exaggerating the effectiveness" of Kordolin tablets in treating arthritis and rheumatism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Foreign Minister, will press the United States for release of Japanese war criminals and for a definite, United States commitment eventually to return the Ryukyu and Bonin Islands to Japan.

A contraseasonal increase of 580,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 155,563,000 barrels, compared with 154,983,000 a week earlier and 155,017,000 a year ago.
Now that the staggering first impact of Diane's floods has passed we are beginning to take the measure of the problems they have posed and how these problems may best be met.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles knocked the Chicago White Sox out of first place in the American League today by winning the second game of a double-header, 2 -- 1, after losing the opener, 14 -- 1.

Alarmed at the declining trend in attendance, the Yankees and Giants are considering blacking out their home night games on television in 1956. They also will seek to have the Dodgers join them in a concerted plan of local television control.

Commodity futures were dull and irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, soybean oil, wool, rubber, zinc and copper closed mixed; onions, potatoes and cottonseed oil eased, and sugar, hides and burlap rose.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- Americans should not wait to be solicited for donations to flood relief, but should "force upon" the Red Cross more money than it can use, President Eisenhower said today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Ned Lilly of Stanton, Mich., and Helen Thomas, a 15-year-old mute from Los Angeles, today won the North American clay target championships at the fifty-sixth Grand American trapshoot.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- The United States spent $2,800,000 to increase coal production in an Italian mine where Communist influence made sabotage more likely than work in the event of an emergency, according to a Hoover Commission study made public today.

The principles of a sound and liberal foreign policy in the "spirit of Geneva" were defined by President Eisenhower in his eloquent address to the American Bar association in Philadelphia yesterday. No one who heard or read his words could doubt the sincerity of his quest for peace.

The flood disaster in Northeastern states has given radio and television the opportunity for its biggest public service job in years. Now that the reconstruction period is beginning in devastated areas, stations and networks are making appeals for aid to flood victims.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A member of the Senate Republican Policy Committee said today that four more years of President Eisenhower in the White House could transform the G. O. P. into the nation's majority party.

A chapter of history was ended on Tuesday when the United States and Panama exchanged instruments ratifying a new treaty. We are not giving up the Canal, to be sure, nor does Panama want us to. What we have done is to increase greatly the annuity that the United States pays for the use of Panamanian territory, which was unfairly low.

Electric power production in the week ended on last Saturday rose to 10,812,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 10,729,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Aug. 21, 1954, was 9,207,000,000.
The public assistance caseload of the Welfare Department showed last month a decline in every category of relief, Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- Japan's Foreign Minister said today it was time to review the security treaty between his country and the United States.
Following are the texts of addresses by President Eisenhower and Chief Justice Earl Warren yesterday at the American Bar Association convention in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The newspaper El Tiempo, closed by the Colombian Government Aug. 4, will make no effort to reappear unless it can do so free of restrictions, Eduardo Santos, the publisher, told his staff yesterday.

The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday that its separtely-operated but wholly-controlled affiliated transportation companies had net earnings amounting to $38,246,859, or $4.23 a share, in the first seven months of this year.

MANCHESTER, Mass, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Janet Hopps of Seattle defeated Patricia Ward of England in the second round of the Essex County Club's invitation tennis tournament today. Miss Ward defaulted because of illness after dropping the first set, 6 -- 0.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- Some persons who were born in this country are returning to see their relatives here.
Immediate improvement of the city's waterfront facilities is imperative if New York is to retain its supremacy as a port, Vincent A. G. O'Connor declared yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- "Star Stage," a new weekly series of half-hour dramatic shows, will start over the National Broadcasting Company television network on Friday, Sept. 9.

Edward Fields, Inc., manufacturer of hand-hooked wool rugs and carpets, is expanding its facilities in Flushing, Queens, where it has leased a new building at 32-15 Downing Street from the Porter Operating Company. Charles M. Richardson was the broker in the transaction.

The appointment of Mario Pittoni, Professor of Law at Brooklyn Law School, as First Deputy Commissioner of the New York State Department of Commerce was announced yesterday in Albany by Edward T. Dickinson, the Commissioner of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Prof. Walter Adams accused high government officials today of helping business monopolies they were supposed to fight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Imparato Stevedoring Corporation and the International Longshoremen's Association (independent) had violated the Taft-Hartley Act by refusing to give dock jobs to eleven longshoremen affiliated with a rival labor union.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Mike Garcia's pitching and home runs by Al Smith and Bob Avila enabled the Cleveland Indians to score a 2-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.
F. William DeBree has been named general sales manager of the American Plastic Corporation.

A syndicate headed by Henry, Jerome and Myron Minskoff, builders, has purchased the group of nine brownstone apartment houses at the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Fifty-first Street, a plot 100 by 150 feet, for future improvement.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 -- Frank Lloyd, director-producer, has initiated negotiations to obtain screen rights to the life story of Lord Baden-Powell, who founded the Boy Scout movement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Most of the time, Soviet jamming stations drown out the Voice of America. But tonight the Voice broadcast a program that officials hoped would pierce the Iron Curtain. Vladimir M. Matskevich, acting Soviet Agriculture Minister, accepted an invitation from the Voice to broadcast to the Soviet people a report on his tour of the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug 24 -- Argentina's General Confederation of Labor was strongly attacked today by fifty-three former labor leaders. It was described as an organization that had ceased fulfilling its specific mission and had become a mere political appendix of the peronista party.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- The dean of the Harvard Law School and a West Coast attorney debated the Fifth Amendment today. They agreed upon only one thing.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- The stirring music of drum and bugle and the easy informality of a picnic were contrasting features of Philadelphia's welcome to President Eisenhower today.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24 (UP) -- Capt. Alfred W. Kabernagel, a member of the Coast Guard board of inquiry investigating the sinking of the schooner Levin J. Marvel, accused the ship's captain today of having violated at least three maritime laws.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The Long Island Golf Association's eighteen-player squad yesterday regained possession of the Stoddard Bowl, symbolic of the Metropolitan District's amateur team championship. It turned back New Jersey and Westchester County in the annual triangular team matches at the Metropolis Country Club.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- One of the most popular and unusual art exhibitions ever held in any country comes to an end here tomorrow.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway borrowed $19,500,000 in the public market yesterday to finance improvements in its system. The borrowing was done at an interest cost of 4.11 per cent on first mortgage bonds maturing in twenty-five years.
Any move to restrict freedom of the press anywhere in the world is of direct concern to everyone who believes in freedom of the press.

THE appeal of the past as well the pride of accomplishment can be enjoyed by the home craftsman. Early American antique reproductions for home assembly are being offered in kits with pre-cut wooded pieces and directions for assembling and finishing.

A proposal that the city purchase eight buildings and their 211-acre site in Bedford Hills, Westchester County, as an adjunct to the Children's Center in Manhattan was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Food-pinched Communist China tonight ordered grain rationed to the 100,000,000 urban population.

I was greatly interested in a recent article by Russell Porter about the changes on the West Side of Manhattan, particularly in the caption under the photograph of the Manhattanville housing site. "The West Side," it says, "* * * has roused itself to provide better housing for its residents."

James P. McAllister, president of McAllister Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday the promotion of his assistant, John F. Drews, to vice president. Mr. Drews will have charge of the East Coast towing and transportation company's operations in the Hampton Roads, Va., area.

Chicago borrowed $12,500,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance public-school construction. It accepted a bid of a syndicate of ninety-four investment houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., setting an interest cost of 2.69 per cent.
Magnesium has been called the Jekyll and Hyde of metals. Last week's floods in the Northeast underscored the Hyde or destructive nature of the material.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Voice of America, which has had trouble with appropriations, investigations and Soviet jammings, is now being bothered by low-frequency interference from air-conditioning machinery.

Having completed an eleven-year tour of European duty, the second contingent of the Second Armored Cavalry Regiment arrived with dependents aboard the General Simon B. Buckner yesterday. The ship berthed at the Brooklyn Army Base, Fifty-eighth Street and First Avenue.

The question of reversal of American policy toward German and Japanese private assets in the United States is currently being debated. The Congress in 1948 decided Almost unanimously that these assets would not be returned, that they would be used instead for payments to American prisoners of war, and that compensation for the German owners ought to come from the German Government.
Ten American Protestants sailed yesterday afternoon to "serve, but not evangelize" in Turkey. They are being sent by the Congregational Christian Churches.

Officials of Southern states said yesterday they were not taking advantage of the floods in the Northeast to try to lure industries southward. They denounced as "untrue" and "indecent" a published report that they were making a "grab for flooded industries."
Mayor Wagner became yesterday the temporary chairman of a special committee whose goal will be the elimination of unnecessary blowing of automobile horns.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24 -- Eight representatives of the council of the Southeast Asian alliance met here today to discuss economic and military questions, including "subversion in the treaty area."
" Spring?" asked the lady of the house. And as she moved away, fanning herself languidly in August's humidity, it was clear that the lady of the house was not especially interested in spring.
The cost of borrowing in one sector of the money market increased yesterday for the seventh time this year, reflecting a continued tightening in the supply of lendable funds.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits warned Connecticut yesterday that it could not limit or cut off New York's share of water from the nearly completed Mianus River dam project.

HAY RIVER, Northwest Territories, Aug. 23 -- This little community of 800 persons is the only one in the vast Northwest Territories that is connected by highway with the provinces of Canada, 675 miles away.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 24 -- Burhanuddin Harahap, the new Premier of Indonesia said today he thought a closer relationship between the United States and his country should be developed.

A registered nurse from Canada yesterday invoked the First and Fifth Amendments rather than tell an investigating committee who had recommended two summer resorts to her. She has just been promoted in a job here and is awaiting citizenship.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- President Eisenhower expressed today his abiding faith that an enduring world peace based on justice could be achieved.

The clothing industry is pressing vigorously its plan for an industry-wide educational and promotional campaign for men's and boys' wear. At a dinner in the Commodore Hotel last evening several hundred manufacturers and suppliers heard details of the advertising campaign projected by Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc. Additional pledges of support were given.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- The Minister of the Interior asked today for six more battalions to garrison Algeria. The nationalist outbreaks there have brought death to more than 1,000 persons since last Saturday.

VIENNA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Austrian Catholic news service, Kathpress, said today the Premier of Czechoslovakia's wartime Government-in-Exile, Msgr. Jan Sramek, had died in a "concentration monastery." He was 84 years old.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Nearly 40,000 Government workers launched a new wave of strikes today in inflation - plagued Chile. Twelve thousand of them agreed to resume work a few hours after President Carlos Ibanez del Campo had promised to increase their pay 53 per cent.
The American Red Cross raised its national target for flood relief contributions yesterday from $5,000,000 to more than $8,000,000.
Celery, coming now from near-by areas, is at a seasonal levy in price 19 cents a bunch). Both the green and white varieties are abundant.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday elected Gwilym A. Price chairman in addition to his office of president. He continues as chief executive officer. The board chairmanship has not been occupied since 1951.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Possibly in defense of a nomination that failed, President Eisenhower gave one political tinge to his address today before the American Bar Association.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 24 -- The position of Gilbert Grandval, Resident General in French Morocco, has become increasingly untenable in the last few days and his recall is now thought to be imminent. The expectation here is that he will be replaced by Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour, Resident General in Tunisia.

Foremost Dairies, Inc., which has become the nation's third largest dairy company through its program of expansion and acquisitions, is carrying on merger discussions with the Western Condensing Company of Petaluma, Calif.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- By 1960 the United States plans to have a new fast liner ready for the North Atlantic service. She would be a sister ship of the 55,000-ton United States.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Securities of Canadian concerns were widely sought in the United States in the first half of 1955. Net sales to foreign investors more than doubled, rising to a record $109,400,000.

A dwelling on Griswold Road in Harrison, N. Y., has been sold by Dr. Anton B. Meister to J. Wes Gallagher, foreign correspondent of The Associated Press. The property occupies a plot 100 by 125 feet adjoining the Westchester Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- President Eisenhower led all the forces of his Administration today in a flood-relief program. It may amount to $100,000,000 in grants to the states, and many millions more in Federal loans.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Dave Gundy kept the Edward Ely Scovill Cup at the American Yacht Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP) -- President Eisenhower is expected to ask Congress next year to kill a provision in the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act that requires fingerprinting of all nonofficial visitors to this country.

HAVING received a half-dozen reports on a reputed scarcity of woodchucks, we cruised the rural lanes of two milkshed areas within a l00-mile radius of the city. In four hours we spotted nineteen chucks, which hardly constitutes "scarcity."

The stock market climbed again yesterday, but gains in the early tradings were reduced late in the session. The steel and chemical issues were the best group performers. Movements in other categories were narrow and pretty well mixed.
UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Edward A. Hanna called upon Governor Harriman today to move for the ouster of Robert Moses as chairman of the State Parks Council.
The quest of the Brooklyn Dodgers for a new home led yesterday to virtual approval of a $100,000 survey of 500 Brooklyn acres.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The nation's oldest stake for 3-year-old fillies, the Alabama, had its seventy-fifth running at the Saratoga track today, and favorite-players didn't enjoy it a bit.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The Soviet press has stepped up criticism of research scientists and university degree-seekers who pass their time on questions of little practical interest.
BLED, Yugoslavia, Aug. 24 -- Some quarters here say the Soviet Union will withdraw at least the majority of its troops from Rumania and Hungary.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock market follows:
DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- Casey Stengel rejoined his Yankees today. But if it was peace and quiet the doctor prescribed, Casey got little of it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy denied today as "false" a report that Vladimir Matskevich, head of the visiting Russian farm delegation, once had been a Soviet secret police official.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 24 -- Hurricane Edith, fifth of the season, whirled far out in the Atlantic tonight.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 24 -- Pat Lesser of Seattle scored an important fourth-round victory to gain the quarter-finals of the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

Federated Department Stores, one of the nation's largest retail chains, holding the Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus stores here, realized a 38.4 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 8.9 per cent for the quarter ended July 30.
The Flatbush homs of Edward S. Silver, Kings County District Attorney, was robbed yesterday of jewels valued at $10,400.

The whole Far Eastern situation, in which Japan plays a key role, will be subjected to a new review following the arrival of Japanese Foreign Minister Shigemitsu, who is due in Washington tonight for consultations beginning Monday with the American Government.

Every time the railroads come up with a money maker, someone kicks. There was Patrick B. McGinnis' parking meters for commuters on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. Now come some roads, particularly in the Midwest, with 200-car freight trains drawn by five or six Diesels hooked together.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 -- Premier Moshe Sharett said tonight that the fight between Egyptian and Israeli forces on the Gaza truce line Monday was apparently a "politically motivated attempt by Egypt to torpedo" the Egyptian-Israeli talks.
Forty children were brought here yesterday from three summer camps in the flood-ravaged Pocono Mountain area near Stroudsburg, Pa.
Travel blocks that were rolled in by the floods were slowly being removed yesterday, but the task remained prodigious.

Nopco Chemical Company, Harrison, N. J., announced yesterday a new expansion program to capitalize on the growing market for polyurethane foam. Polyurethane is a plastic which can be used in either rigid or foam forms.
The shout "Squad goes!" has become a familiar cry in the firehouse at 180 West 137th Street, the home of New York's first flying squad of firefighters.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- You walk around the Saratoga race track asking experts in the business who'll win the Swaps-Nashua match. After you have talked with twenty persons, you find that the score is 13 -- 7 in favor of Swaps.

A good time seems to have been had by all at the National Press Club luncheon for the visiting Russian farm delegation on Tuesday. Thus the reciprocal visits of American farmers to the Soviet Union and of Soviet farm officials to this country neared their respective ends.
As a citizen and taxpayer I take exception to Murray Kagel's protest over the low jurors' fees in his letter published in The Times of Aug. 16.

Col. Bernard Thielen, who supervised the drawing up of the Japanese surrender articles in 1945, will retire at Fort Wadsworth, S. I., today after twenty-four years of Army service. There will be a retreat parade, open to the public, in his honor at 4:30 P. M.
VIENNA, Aug. 24 -- The Czechoslovak Government has decided to decrease its armed forces by 34,000 men. This followed Moscow's proclaimed reduction of the Soviet Army by 640,000 men.
MADRID, Aug. 24 -- Arab leaders in Spanish Morocco were reported today to have pledged support to the nationalists in French Morocco. The Spanish authorities in Tetuan were said to have approved.
DENVER, Aug. 24 -- President Eisenhower landed in Denver at 7:48 o'clock tonight. He was accompanied by Mrs. Eisenhower.
The Army threw scores of military and civilian engineers into six Northeastern states yesterday to appraise and guide the job of recovery and reconstruction from last week-end's floods.
CAIRO, Aug. 24 -- Egypt withdrew today from talks with Israel concerning means to lessen tension on the Gaza border.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 24 -- Prof. Carl Friedrich Ophuels of the Foreign Office announced today that West Germany's first experimental reactors would be purchased in the United States.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Earl Sande, rider of three Kentucky Derby winners, and eleven other jockeys were named to racing's Hall of Fame today by the organization's executive committee.
A Federal injunction provided the impetus and an ancient Oriental practice supplied the method. As a result, the City of New York is today a successful manufacturer of synthetic topsoil.
Competition among the airlines operating transcontinental flights has moved into a new phase.
The Dodgers doused the faint glimmers of hope that had started to flicker in their distant National League pursuers by erupting with one of their old-time home-run barrages yesterday.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 8 points lower to 18 points higher than on Tuesday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Irregular price changes were the feature of grain and soybean markets today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- An Air Force airplane was reported today to have set the world's first speed record for straightaway flight faster than sound, just over 800 miles an hour.
General Telephone Corporation, the nation's largest telephone network outside of the Bell System, took close aim yesterday at the billion-dollar company class.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Two of East Hampton's oldest houses will be used this year for a benefit flower show whose theme is "A Date With the Past." The show is being sponsored by the East Hampton Garden Club with the assistance of the Eastern Gate Garden Club next Wednesday.
HONOLULU, Aug. 24 -- The high command of the Far East Air Force opened a two-day conference at Hickam Field today to do some "progressive thinking" about new air strategy in the Pacific and Asia.
Any doubt that Victor Seixas will be named with Tony Trabert for the Davis Cup challenge round singles with Australia was dissolved yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 -- Governor Harriman and Leut. Gen. Samuel D. Sturgis Jr., the chief of the Army Engineers, agreed today that long-range flood control plans for New York must be revised.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 24 -- The Peiping announcement indicates that the Chinese Communists have reorganized and tightened up the rationing system already in effect. The new announcement accentuates a "Save Grain" campaign that has been going on for months now in urban centers.

THE BIBLE (and this is a fact that can hardly be overstressed in an age starving for a lack of faith) is a treasure-trove from God, bequeathed to His children with a rhetorical assist from Man. The bitter fact remains that this same Bible (particularly the Old Testament) is largely unread today -- or, at least, largely misunderstood by those most in need of its deep-toned poetry, its down - to - earth wisdom.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Governor Harriman granted a stay of execution tonight to John Roche. He was scheduled to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing tomorrow night for the slaying of Dorothy Westwater, a 14-year-old New York City schoolgirl.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 24 -- The Navy has designated Rear Admiral Stuart H. Ingersoll, U. S. N., Chief of Staff for the Atlantic Fleet, as the new commander of the Seventh Fleet in the Western Pacific.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 24 -- The budget for the fiscal year that began July 1 was introduced in the House of Representatives tonight by the Treasurer, Sir Arthur Fadden. It effects no reductions in direct or indirect taxation.

TOKYO, Aug. 24 -- The residents of Sunakawa, reinforced by Leftist sympathizers from Tokyo, prevented today a Government surveys of scheduled extensions of a big United States trait Force base near by. The villagers protested that the proposed expansion would deprive them of farmland and would cut their town in to.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The forty-eight state governments collected a record $11,584,000,000 in state taxes during the fiscal year of 1955, the Census Bureau reported today. This is equivalent to $72.25 from each man, woman and child.
The General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers. C. I. O., signed a five-year contract yesterday.

Scientific American, Inc., publisher of the Scientific American magazine, has leased the entire twelfth floor in the office building under construction at 415 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-fifth Street. The building, which is being erected by Samuel Rudin, is scheduled to be ready for occupancy early next year.

Consumers Power Company achieved a new twelve-months high of $180,027,646 in operating revenues for the period ended July 31, the company reported yesterday. This was a gain of $14,358,561, or 9 per cent, over the like 1954 period. July revenues of $13,064,831 increased by $1,524,527, or 13 per cent, over July, 1954.

"A Wayfarer in Central America," by Tord Wallstrom, will be issued Sept. 19 by Roy Publishers. The author, a Swedish journalist, tells of a hike through Nicaragua, Honduras and Guatemala. The book was translated by M. A. Michael.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- British Air Ministry officials disputed today American criticisms of their military aircraft.

When an Ambassador of the Indian Government is "segregated" in an airport restaurant in Texas under the supposition that he is a Negro an international incident arises. Mr. Gaganvihari Lallubhai Mehta and his secretary were thus segregated on Monday at Houston.
NORMAN WELLS, Northwest Territories, Aug. 24 -- The white citizens of Fort Simpson gave the Royal Commission on Canada's economic future its first brief today.

Even though it has been called off -- at least for the time being -- the walkout of the longshoremen on the Manhattan docks this week is a somber warning of incalculable dangers that may lie ahead. All concerned should meet the situation with understanding and resolute courage.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 25 (UP) -- Airman Daniel C. Schmidt dropped his divorce plans today and went on a belated wedding trip with his 20-year-old wife. She had married a lumberjack after Airman Schmidt was shot down and captured in Korea.
NAGOYA, Japan, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Four United States star swimmers were stricken with slight cases of food poisoning today and Japan won all eight races in its final meet with the visiting Americans.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Jackie Jensen today became the first American League player to drive in 100 runs this season. He accounted for four tallies to give the Boston Red Sox a 6-4 victory over Detroit after the Tigers had won the first game of a double-header, 6 -- 1.

Rubber prices tumbled 90 to 165 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Volume was 1,690 tons. Trading was influenced by reports that Indonesia would release supplies that had been held off the market and that production and stocks in Malaya had increased.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits called tonight for a state-wide system of public defenders for persons under 21 years of age accused of crimes and unable to retain lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A proposal that the Commodity Credit Corporation dispose of its wool surplus through a series of regional auctions was made at a meeting of the Department of Agriculture Wool Merchandising Advisory Committee here today.
The state inquiry into Communist subversion of summer resorts for children and adults was suspended yesterday after a fourth session at the Supreme Court Building in Foley Square.

The Giants yielded ground to the Braves yesterday in the first skirmish of their battle for second place. Warren Spahn's six-hit pitching and a three-run rally in the seventh inning gave the Milwaukeans a 3-2 verdict over the New Yorkers at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Representative Wright Patman charged today that the Small Business Administration had been secretly subjecting small business men seeking Government loans to security-risk investigations.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The seventh-place Washington Senators beat the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 1, today. The Senators had lost fifteen of their previous seventeen games to the Sox.

The delay in justice that is a denial of justice continues to be a distinguishing feature of the state courts in New York City. The Institute of Judicial Administration, Inc., a nonprofit research group operating with a Rockefeller Foundation grant, has surveyed ninety-eight courts in the forty-eight states in the first half of 1955.

SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Aug. 23 -- It is hardly surprising that Saar industrialists, coal miners and steel workers are confused when asked to vote for "Europe." They are asked to do so by approving in a referendum a plan to make the Saar a kind of political ward of seven European nations.
Three hundred fifty-four deeply tanned, tired but happy young seafarers returned yesterday aboard their 6,000-ton training ship from ten weeks of sea duty and port calling through Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States Government has decided on an extremely cautious approach to next week's conversations at the United Nations on disarmament. After months of re-examination of the problem here in preparation for the United Nations Disarmament Subcommittee meetings starting in New York Monday, officials here are in general agreement on these assumptions:
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- French diplomatic representations are expected to be made in Washington to line up United States support for France's North African policy.
The Dodgers played ball with the Redlegs from 6 o'clock until almost midnight at Ebbets Field last night and put two more games into their loss column.

It is hard to get enthusiastic about the first formal meeting of the Organization of Central American States (ODECA), which ended in Antigua, Guatemala, on Wednesday. However, it is a case where one can be thankful that the conference took place at all and ended in something resembling harmony.

There seems to be no end to steel demand. The hungry maw of the metal working industries is going to be even wider than it is now. They will spend $2,000,000,000 for new fabricating equipment in the next eighteen months, according to American Machinist, a trade paper, on the basis of a survey of 1,574 companies, about a tenth of the total.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 25 -- New York's Mayor Wagner, borough presidents, police commissioner and members of the New York City Youth Board have been invited to a special open house at Anthony Drexel Duke's Boys Harbor here on Saturday.
The Government gave the green light yesterday to plans of three companies to build five roll on-roll off ships at a total cost of $23,500,000.

Early in 1900 a Harvard University undergraduate, Dwight F. Davis, ordered a silversmith to fashion 217 troy ounces of silver into a thirteen-inch bowl. He called it the International Lawn Tennis Challenge Trophy. Today it is called the Davis Cup and it is one of the most famous trophies in sports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- The National Broadcasting Company has set up a development group to help its artists appear before the television public in fresh and entertaining ways. This group, it was learned today, is composed of three N. B C. executives, Elliott Lewis, Milton Josephsberg and Merritt W. Barnum.
Motorists traveling in the metropolitan area this weekend may expect detours or delays, owing to new construction, repairs or congestion, on these routes (the numbers correspond to those on the map):

Forty-eight years of handling money for the United States Lines is long enough, in the opinion of John L. McCaffrey, freight cashier for the company. He has decided to exchange the "green stuff" for the greener waves off his Rockaway Beach home and the ease of retirement.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- F. B. Rees, 40-year-old tire salesman from Heyworth, Ill., won the Preliminary Handicap at the Grand American trapshoot today -- but there's still a question whether he'll get the title and some $7,000 prize money.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower's Philadelphia speech was welcomed today by the Government as a timely intervention.

The International Longshoremen's Association won a strategic victory yesterday in its two-year-old struggle against the policing authority of the bi-state Waterfront Commission. This was the interpretation placed on the announcement in Albany that Governor Harriman might set up a "buffer committee" to function between the commission and longshoremen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The weekly average of member bank reserve balances for the week ending Aug. 24 decreased $84,000,000 to $18,673,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa dealt a heavy blow yesterday to the proposal to substitute a passenger belt conveyor system for the thirty-seven-year-old I. R. T. subway train shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central Terminal.
OUED ZEM, French Morocco, Aug. 25 -- Peace has returned to Oued Zem.
Few ballpayers have strong feelings of attachment to the cities they represent. To a professional, playing baseball is just a job. It doesn't make a great deal of difference where or for whom.

THE vanguard of the early striped bass migration, it is reported, has arrived in Martha's Vineyard waters, with several big fish, scaling from thirty-eight to fifty pounds, taken during the past few days.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- Twin passenger ships being built for the Oceanic Steamship Company are to have underwater "fins" designed to reduce roll by as much as 90 per cent.

TIMES were hard in 1786. In Massachusetts the debt-ridden farmers complained of intolerable taxes levied, they thought mistakenly, to support state officials in extravagant luxury. When the Court of Common Pleas met, honest, hard-working, God-fearing men, patriots who had fought in the late war with England, were sent to prison for debts and unpaid taxes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States has expressed concern to France about the use of American military equipment against North Africans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A balanced Federal budget this fiscal year was envisioned today by the Secretary of the Treasury.

DENVER, Aug. 25 -- Politics, reclamation and the refugee program, in addition to flood relief measures, occupied President Eisenhower's attention this morning at his Lowry Air Force base vacation headquarters.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Shipboard, well trained and well ridden, gave a top-notch performance to win the $11,075 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today.

Margin requirements for trading in rubber futures on the New York Commodity Exchange should be increased, according to W. S. Richardson, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company. If the "current wild speculation in the purchase of this vital material" is not stopped, Mr. Richardson said yesterday, the complete changeover to manmade rubber in the United States will be greatly accelerated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Mamoru Shigemitsu, Foreign Minister of Japan, said upon his arrival here tonight for an official visit that he hoped to "reaffirm in unmistakable terms the enduring friendship that now happily exists between Japan and the United States."
Thursday, Sept. 15, has been set for the world premiere of Walt Disney's newest True-Life Adventure feature, "The African Lion," at the Trans-Lux Normandie Theatre.
Two Brooklyn policemen used their patrol car as an emergency ambulance yesterday to help save the sight of a workman whose eyes had been seared in an oil-burner backfire.
From the oil-soaked timbers of Weehawken's wharves, west to the muddy Musconetcong and south to the varicolored sand dunes and scrub pine that dot the Manasquan lies a vast segment of suburbia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today on the military and economic strength the free world had built up with the help of United States foreign-aid programs.
What such stalwarts as Paul Gregory and subsequently Hume Cronyn were eager to put on but didn't, the adventuresome Proscenium Productions will tackle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Bank at Atlanta will raise its discount rate to 2 1/4 per cent. effective tomorrow, as part of the Government's new crackdown on inflationary tendencies.

The Broderick and Bascom Rope Company of St. Louis, Mo., has leased a new building at the southwest corner of North Street and North Industrial Avenue in Teterboro, N. J. The property, containing 10,000 square feet of space, will be used as a sales office and distribution center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25-- Physical damage in last week's floods was estimated by the Army Corps of Engineers today at $1,677,000,000. Lieut. Gen. S. D. Sturgis Jr., Chief of Engineers, emphasized that this figure took no account of current loss of income or production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The United States labor force probably will exceed 80,000,000 persons by 1965, Federal Reserve Board economists said today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, Va., came in late today with a five-under-par 65 to share the lead with Mike Souchak of Grossinger. N. Y., in the first round of the $26,800 Montreal open.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, urged a Federal court today to reject the argument that the armed services could not court-martial servicemen accused of collaboration in Korea.

NORTH BELLMORE, L. I., Aug. 25 -- An automobile that "must have been traveling at a terrific rate of speed," according to the police, killed a newspaper delivery boy on a bicycle and injured three other children in a parked car here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Plans for a motion picture based on the life of Homer Lea, who forecast Japan's invasion of the Philippines before his death in 1912, were disclosed today by William Schorr.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Adequate defense rather than economy is the principle behind the current Defense Department budget, a spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Public Health Service's report today on polio vaccine produced by the Cutter Laboratories of Berkeley, Calif.:

Because an alert detective saw a huge arm shaking a spinach can and a group of children watching the arm, Martin Lopez, 27 years old, of 235 East 103d Street, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of impairing the morals of a minor.

Kenneth Rosewall and Victor Seixas, each the champion of his country, will play the opening match today in the Davis Cup challenge round between Australia and the United States at Forest Hills. Lewis Hoad and Tony Trabert, the siege guns of amateur tennis, will follow them on the court.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benzon, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today the Administration was "not content" with the current level of farm prices and farmer income.
THE olive means just one taste to most of us. To the gourmet there can be many.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Many influential Britons share the Eisenhower Administration's belief that a brake must be put on the optimism created by the Geneva conference last month.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to let Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore have $100,000 for a public improvement survey of the area in which the Brooklyn Dodgers want to build a modern baseball park.
PARIS, Aug. 25 -- France has notified the European command of the North Atlantic alliance that another French division will be withdrawn for service in North Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Homicide squad detectives began an investigation today into the sudden death of Mrs. Doris Jean Silver Ostreicher, daughter of Herman R. Silver, vice president of Food Fair Stores, Inc.
Prices of cotton were unchanged to 21 points off yesterday. The far months showed the most weakness, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange continued rather slow.
CAIRO, Aug. 25 -- A renewal of the nationalist drive in Tunisia will be discussed here in the next few days by several leaders of the Neo-Destour party.
David Bronstein of Russia, leading the interzone chess tournament at Goteborg, defeated Paul Keres in the seventh round last night, according to a report received through Swedish news sources.
