This country, which has for years been bestowing aid on many parts of the world, became the recipient yesterday of gifts from abroad to help flood victims in the Northeastern states.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP) The Department of Agriculture said today the nation's cotton supply may dip slightly in 1956 for the first time in five years. The forecast, based on estimated supplies and probable consumption, was made in the Department's publication, "The Cotton Situation."

A SUNDAY night in August is not the most propitious time to hold a testimonial dinner. But any date must be propitious when the affair is held in honor of Eddie Brannick. So the boys will toss a shindig for the secretary of the Giants at the Waldorf-Astoria this Sunday to help him celebrate his golden anniversary as a Polo Grounds landmark.

Earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad in the first seven months of this year were the highest for any comparable period in the company's history. Net income amounted to $42,388,048, equal to $9.01 a common share.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The United States Public Health Service today blamed a failure of its safety tests for the fact that live virus had been found in six lots of Cutter polio vaccine.

The Board of Estimate, we are glad to see, has promptly responded to the appeal of the Brooklyn Dodgers for help in finding a site for a new stadium to replace Ebbets Field. A grant of $100,000 conditioned on approval by the city's Budget Director has been voted to survey a large area in northwesterly Brooklyn.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 -- President Juan D. Peron continued the reorganization of his Cabinet today by accepting the resignation of the Foreign Minister, Dr. Jeronimo Remorino. General Peron also announced changes in the security organization and named Maj. Gen. Felix Maria Robles to be its chief.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Foreign teams dominated the men's play but two American teams reached the women's final today in the national doubles tennis tournament at Longwood.
A vast new generation of mosquitos, bred in stagnant pools and puddles left by last week's rain, flood and high tides, is on the warpath in New Jersey and Connecticut.

The stock market rose again yesterday. Strength in the coppers and steels and a few issues affected by special developments featured trading. Other major groups, including the rails, were only moderately improved or mixed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- Hydrogen war can be averted only if the United States proposes and other nations accept a disarmament plan to be enforced by the United Nations. Thomas K. Finletter asserted here today.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday plans of the Board of Health to overhaul and modernize the city's Sanitary Code. The code constitutes the city's health laws.

Because a native boy of 16 was refused a passport to come to America he condemns a policy which is applicable to the multi-racial population of South Africa. That is sheer nonsense.

This is all to the good, of course, and for a reason quite aside from the fact that the courteous guest always eats whatever is set before him, whenever offered.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 25 -- Polly Riley of Fort Worth, moved a rung closer to the women's United States amateur golf title today. In a keen quarter-final match on the Myers Park Country Club course. Miss Riley defeated Margaret (Wiffi) Smith of St. Clair, Mich., by 1 up.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold helped today to split a gold bar at a ceremony that stirred memories of the flourishing days of the League of Nations.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- A probate court today took charge of a $125,000 estate to keep the money from going to two heirs in Communist Poland.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Aug. 25 (UP) -- Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate Democratic leader, came home from Washington today to recuperate from a heart attack. He landed in a private plane at Fredericksburg, thirty-one miles from his ranch near here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Directors of the Capital Transit Company today voted against paying any dividend for the third quarter of this year and advised stockholders they anticipated a liquidation over the next twelve months.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 25 -- The elections in Indonesia may be delayed for a month or more in some areas. Preparations for the country's first nation-wide poll remain incomplete.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 25 -- Singapore took a big step today toward relaxing the emergency regulations under which it has suppressed Communist revolutionary activities.

Consolidated net profit of A. C. F. Industries, Inc., for the quarter ended July 31 increased 32 per cent to $2,062,132 from $1,557,541 earned in the similar first three months of the preceding fiscal year.

Three more ninety-minute television shows in the realm of "spectaculars" were announced yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System. They will be presented during the 1955-56 season, but the actual dates have not been set.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 25 -- The long-outlawed Costa Rican Communist party has emerged to intervene in the United Fruit Company labor dispute.

THERE were four co-stars in last night's drama called "Deal a Blow" on "Climax!" over Channel 2. One of them was James MacArthur, 17-year-old son of Helen Hayes and Charles MacArthur. He was making his television debut and he performed splendidly. But that is only part of the good news this morning.
Twenty-nine crew members of the disabled British freighter Argobeam, plucked from gale-swept Atlantic waters last Friday, arrived here yesterday aboard the Swedish-American liner Kungsholm.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 -- The Brazilian Government has named of one of the country's outstanding coffee experts chief of Brazil's delegation to the United Nations economic conference on Latin America opening next Monday in Bogota, Colombia.
A Federal fund of nearly $1,000,000,000 was made available by President Eisenhower yesterday to help rebuild the flood-battered Northeast.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- The Soviet Union is expected to declare soon its willingness to join an international atomic energy agency associated with the United Nations. United States sources in a position to know consider it almost certain that the Russians will do so.
MAZAGAN, French Morocco, Aug. 25 (Reuters) -- The Jewish community of this city has made an urgent appeal for an immediate transfer to Israel.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 -- A joint commission of the Unitarian and Universalist churches met here today to consider recommendations relating to their fuller merger.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, 86 years old, former State Education Commissioner, was reported in fair condition at St. Peter's Hospital today with a broken hip. The hospital said he was resting comfortably. Dr. Graves' right hip was fractured in a fall at his home Sunday and he underwent an operation Tuesday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Governor Harriman watched a "tremendously impressive" performance by the Air Force's B-57 jet bomber today and said a "reckless decision" by the Republican national Administration was to blame for the fact that "we've got so few of them."

GHENT, Belgium, Aug. 25 (AP) -- John B. Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia won his preliminary heat in the single sculls of the European rowing championships today, while Russian rowers qualified in five of the seven events.

VIENNA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The nation-wide strike is in protest against a proposed law that would extend national health benefits to all Austrians regardless of their income. The doctors say this would limit their private practices by giving cheap services to high income groups.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25 -- The United Nations General Assembly meeting next month here has the greatest opportunity presented to date to contribute to a solution of the disarmament problem and control of the atom, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Government threatened tonight to invoke the death penalty against hospital attendants whose patients die for lack of care during the strike in public health services.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Trade interest centered largely in the corn pit today, although soybean trade also was enlivened by various bullish crop reports that filtered into the market.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $69,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Financing of a proposed 223- mile expressway linking the Texas cities of Dallas and Houston is back on the marketing calendar for early fall.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies swept a double-header from the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 11 -- 9 and 8 -- 3. The Phils extended their winning streak to six games.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 25 (UP) -- The Russians followed their usual jamming practices against the Voice of America today during broadcasts of a friendly report by the head of the Soviet agricultural delegation visiting the United States.

The New York Regional Red Cross Program received 479 pints of blood on Wednesday. National newspaper advertising is breaking more records.
The price of copper continues to climb. Anaconda Sales Company, subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, raised the price 3 cents yesterday to 43 cents a pound. The increase is effective immediately.
Hurricane Edith, as yet "in a very early stage of development," was 250 miles northeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, more than 1,000 miles from Miami, early this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the executive committee of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway, disclosed today that he heads a group that has obtained an option to buy 90,000 shares of the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company.
DECLINES of 5 cents a dozen on large Grade A eggs and 4 cents a dozen on mediums indirectly resulted from recent floods. Unfortunately for shoppers, the downward price trend is unlikely to continue.

South Carolina assured flood-stricken Connecticut yesterday that she would never seek industrial development "based upon the misfortune of others." She promised to do her part through contributions to the Red Cross "to help other states in distress."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- A prediction that guided missiles would be carrying freight in ten or twelve years was made today at the Western Electronic Show and Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today that the Eisenhower Administration had pursued a "weak, cowardly and immoral" foreign policy in Asia. The result, he said, was "appeasement, retreat and surrender" to communism.

Although great strides have been taken in making it possible to insure one's self against the expenses of illness -- hospitalization, doctors' fees, and cost of operations -- there are still serious imperfections in this type of insurance.
The 1956 line of Lincoln cars, featuring increased length and engine power, was announced yesterday by the Lincoln division of the Ford Motor Company.

NEWARK, Aug. 25 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport received permission today from the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners to increase its bus fares from 10 to 12 cents for rides in one zone. The present additional 5-cent fare for each additional zone remains unchanged.
A proposed merger of a bank in Westchester and one across the river in Rockland County was made known yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- Gilbert Grandval, Resident General in Morocco, was understood today to have resigned. His resignation was not immediately accepted but probably will be at the end of this week as part of a solution to the Moroccan crisis.

The six-story building containing thirty-nine apartments and a self-service elevator at 539 West 112th Street, near Broadway, has been sold by Joseph Aspis to an investing client of Aaron Sofer, attorney. The property is 100 by 100 feet and is assessed at $175,000, of which $65,000 is land value.
VIENNA, Aug. 25 -- Doctors and dentists struck and demonstrated throughout Austria today against the medical provisions of the new Austrian social security law.

Congratulations are in order for the individual who conceived and executed the effective new sign recently installed at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, one of the busiest intersections in the world, and for the Borough of Manhattan Department of Public Works for approving it, and determining to make its use general.

THE WATERFALL on the Pepsi-Cola sign in Times Square has been turned off to give painters a chance to do a new horizon blue background for it. Soon as the paint dries the cascade will go back into action.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 -- For the eleventh time, United States and Communist Chinese representatives met today without making any progress toward getting forty United States citizens released from the Chinese mainland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A Senate subcommittee said today that the television industry was taking "a calculated risk" with crime and violence on programs during children's viewing hours.
Directors of the Reynolds Metals Company yesterday declared a dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, payable Oct. 1 to holders of record Sept. 7.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 25 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson today urged President Eisenhower to undertake a "crash" program to tame the hydrogen bomb for industrial energy.

The six-story building at 22 East Forty-second Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, until recently occupied by Alex Taylor Co., sporting goods, has been sold by Beatrice Berle and members of her family to the Ann-Nassau Realty Corporation for investment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. appointed today Milo V. Olson, Los Angeles attorney, to handle the Government's $100,000,000 oil claims.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 26 -- One week after the great flood, workmen began to see some progress today in their herculean labors of digging the muck out of wrecked industrial plants on the banks of the Naugatuck River.

CAIRO, Aug. 26 -- An Egyptian communique tonight announced that Egyptian forces had killed twelve Israelis in a battle this morning.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his party, the Christian Democratic Union, disavowed today the campaign of the pro-German parties in the Saar against the new territorial statute. The statute is to be submitted to a referendum in October.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Morrisville, Pa., won the Little League world series today when Rich Cominski smashed an extra-inning homer in the seventh to defeat Delaware Township, N. J., 4 -- 3, in an encounter involving towns only 35 miles apart.

General Sessions Judge Louis J. Capozzoli ruled yesterday that a grand jury does not have the right to compel a witness to fill out a questionnaire.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The stock markets recovered from a dull start today. Industrial issues fully recovered early losses but some Government stocks were slightly lower on balance, net losses ranging up to five shillings (70 cents) in the long and medium-dated loans.

The Board of Estimate, in granting a two-year franchise to a privately owned bus line carrying students to nine Brooklyn high schools and to Brooklyn College, is in effect legalizing competition with the transportation furnished by the New York City Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Government awarded today an order for more than $6,000,000 worth of electric generators and transformers to United States companies despite lower bids by British producers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Army assigned its highest priority today to research and development with the appointment of William H. Martin as Director of Research and Development.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (UP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, the middleweight champion, finished strong tonight to score a unanimous ten-round decision over Joey Giambra in a non-title bout at the Cow Palace.
ROME, Aug. 26 -- A new political group came into existence today when the Neo-Fascists and all but a small part of the Monarchists decided to act as a single unit in Parliament and in labor unions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A picket line disturbance led to the arrest today of a housewife and the president of her husband's union whose strike she was opposing vigorously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- One invention patented this week offers a moving solution to the flood problem. It is a house that rises with high water and falls back into place afterward -- a sort of tethered Noah's ark.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Ed Sullivan will devote half of his Sept. 4 Columbia Broadcasting System television show to the motion picture "Night of the Hunter." Three members of the cast, Lillian Gish, Shelley Winters and Peter Graves, have been scheduled to perform on the program.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Air Research and Development Command announced today it had developed an electronic aircraft detector to help spotters detect low-flying enemy planes.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The internal revenue commissioner, T. Coleman Andrews, has asserted in an interview that Federal judges are breaking down law enforcement by being too soft in sentencing tax evaders.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Kosei Kamo and Atsushi Miyagi today became the first Japanese team in the seventy-five-year-history of the national tennis doubles championship to reach the finals. They downed the British tandem of Roger Becker and Robert Wilson, 4 -- 6, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6.

THE chunky, bull-nosed, sweet green pepper now in excellent supply needs no introduction to American cooks. But this also is the season when other, less familiar, members of the family Capsicum frutescens are readily available.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Aug. 26 (Reuters) -- The sporadic fighting in Morocco between Arab nationalists and French authorities has kept United States airmen confined to the limits of the big American airbases in the area.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 26 (UP) -- Air Force Secretary Donald A. Quarles said today that Russia now was turning out scientists and engineers at a "considerably higher rate" than the United States.

PARIS, Aug. 26 -- Reserves to be called up for active duty will more than replace French troops now being transferred to North Africa, the French Foreign Ministry said today. Consequently, "there will be no hole in the ranks committed by France to the North Atlantic alliance," the statement continued:

Oil and oil products imported to the United States via the Suez Canal increased 39 per cent in the first six months of this year, as compared with the like period of 1954, the Suez Canal Company reported yesterday.

The apartment property at 814-820 Prince Street and 815-821 Red Road in Teaneck, N. J., has been purchased by the Bergen Investment Company from the Wyndham Construction Company. The property comprises eight buildings with a total of forty-eight apartments.

Cooler weather in the last few days has restored the smiles to the faces of local merchants. Department and specialty stores reported yesterday that the welcome break in the weather has produced the first good demand for fall apparel.

Trading in rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York serves a necessary economic function by providing hedging facilities for those wishing to obtain protection on committments or inventories, according to Theodore A. Lauer, president of the exchange.

We suppose there are people outside New York City, and maybe in it, who don't know whether a kiosk is something to eat or to wear. Then again perhaps we underestimate the prevalence of exotic information. Webster says the kiosk is a Turkish open summerhouse or pavilion, often supported by pillars.
FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 26 (UP) -- A military court today rejected arguments that Korean war prisoners accused of collaborating with the enemy should be tried in civilian courts.

Thirty-two member concerns of the Textile Refinishers Association, Inc., and two American Federation of Labor unions were enjoined yesterday from continuing a monopoly of examining and sponging of woolen cloth.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 1 to 11 points yesterday in rather quiet trading.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 -- The Indians tonight performed with the ferocity of men who had been subsisting on a diet of raw meat.
Robert Moses replied sharply yesterday to criticism from State Senator Robert C. McEwen on the land acquisition program for construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 26 -- A school teacher and a college senior became the finalists in the women's United States amateur golf championship today.

Enlightened penologists, sociologists and those generally interested in more constructive penal methods will take encouragement from the recent announcement that New York will open its first forestry camp for young prison inmates at North Pharsalia in late fall.
For the first time in its 170-year history, the Protestant Episcopal Church will hold next month a triennial general convention outside the continental United States.
Week-end motorists will be kept away from the worst-hit flood communities, officials of four states announced yesterday.
The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, formerly known as the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, is entering the underwear business.
TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The management of the Thermoid Company claimed victory today in a battle for control of the company.
TORONTO, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Two stages of Toronto harbor's five-stage plan of preparation to handle St. Lawrence Seaway shipping will be completed this year.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 26 -- Leaders of the Turkish minority of Cyprus expressed satisfaction today over Turkey's stand for the status quo in this island. Premier Adnan Menderes said yesterday this would be the least of Turkey's demands in the London talks next week on problems of the Eastern Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 26 -- The United States embassies in Israel and the Arab states de livered to each Government a copy of Secretary of State Dulles' address, coincident with its delivery.

Your article "Ladies' Day Comes to Rochester" is good news from my native city. Susan B. Anthony would turn over in her grave to know that finally, after fifty-five years, mostly of "coordinate" education for women in the University of Rochester, the university is to become truly coeducational by abolishing the separate campus for the girls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The world's fastest earthbound human received aviation's Cheney Award for 1954 today for having achieved a speed of 632 miles an hour on the ground last December.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The number of workers striking against the Chilean Government rose to nearly 55,000 today when two new groups joined public employes demanding wage increases ranging up to 60 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold praised today the "generous and constructive spirit" of Secretary of State Dulles' new offer of United States assistance to settle Arab-Israeli quarrels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Top-ranking members of the Senate Finance Committee gave cautious endorsement today to tax reductions next year provided the budget could be balanced and Federal spending reduced.

CAIRO, Aug. 26 -- Egypt associates the United States with France in the responsibility for developments in North Africa. This was disclosed tonight by a Government statement on a talk between Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser and the United States Ambassador, Henry A. Byroade.

Directors of Aetna Casualty and Surety Company and the Automobile Insurance Company of Hartford, both members of the Aetna Life Affiliated Companies, announced yesterday a plan for merging the two as of Dec. 31.
Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, has announced that Rabbi Aaron B. Ilson is to become spiritual leader of Temple Sinai, Squirrel Hill, Pittsburg.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sheep growers apparently favor a promotional and advertising campaign to boost wool and lamb sales, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson said today.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregularly higher yesterday. Trading was dull in most markets, limited to evening of holdings for the week-end. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and copper rose; coffee and sugar closed mixed, and wool, hides and burlap eased.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Government hopes to have its plan for paying subsidies to potato growers in full operation by Sept. 26, the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today.

Last night at Ebbets Field a majority of the 12,840 fans cheered Duke Snider and the Duke made three hits, all singles. Gil Hodges belted his twenty-third homer into the upper left-field stands in the seventh inning.
You are to be commended on your editorial criticizing the Marine and Aviation Department and the city administration for failure to improve the condition of the Port of New York.

UNDOUBTEDLY mankind's fondness for preferring unflattering stereotypes of foreigners to lifelike portraits has been an impediment to unsullied international comity. The "typical" American may exist nowhere in the forty-eight states, but he is well known abroad. You may look in vain for the Frenchman of cartoon and stereotype all the way from Le Havre to Biarritz, but he has a very real existence in the United States.

Ringsby Truck Lines, Inc., Denver, Col. has contracted to purchase Inland Freight Line. According to the joint announcement yesterday by J. W. Ringsby, president of the Ringsby system and Ray V. Lilenquist, president of Inland, application will be made to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of the purchase.

MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., shot a one-under-par 69 today for a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $26,800 Montreal open golf tournament. Snead had a 134.

The Geneva Big Four Conference raised hopes because it gave promise of a new diplomacy adequate to the task of negotiating collective security in the atomic age. There is anxiety about United States negotiations with the Chinese Communists because it has not been made clear whether the new diplomacy is to be applied to Asian as well as European problems.

I am writing to protest about the misstatements and inaccuracies in The Times' recent obituary on the eminent French painter, Fernand Leger. The Times is usually so painstaking and accurate in its obituaries on figures from other fields -- politics, sports, for example -- that it seems to me shocking that its columns on deceased artists are done so casually.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 -- The Joint Interim Commission on Federal Union of the Unitarian and Universalist churches was reported today to be favorable to a fuller merger of the two groups.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 -- India has warned that South Vietnam's refusal to discuss national elections with the Communist Government of North Vietnam endangers the position of the International Supervisory Commission in the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An American agricultural group just back from Russia today proposed a broader program of trade and technical interchange with the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Delegates of four Western powers held informal meetings today, planning strategy for their sessions here with Soviet representatives on disarmament and control of atomic weapons.

Fourteen new American-built airliners have been bought for use on European and South American routes, Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, president of the Convair Division of the General Dynamics Corporation, announced last night that eleven Convair 440's had been purchased by the Scandinavian Airlines System for domestic service within Scandinavia, two by a South American airline and one by a Finnish carrier.

This is a horse tale of two cities. It involves Impkin, a 3-year-old filly pacer, who led policemen on a jolly three-and-one quarter-mile chase early yesterday morning. Impkin had a glorious hour of liberty until she was caught.

ROME, Aug. 26 -- Twice this year the monthly index of Italian industrial production has reached a point 200 per cent above the average for the last year before World War II. In March the index figure reached 201 and in May 203.

The pre-Labor Day week in the new capital market is shaping up, as usual, to only moderate activity. Buyers and sellers of prime new investments will be kept on their toes, however, by the imminence of the $280,000,000 refunding of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

PINE, Colo., Aug. 26 (UP) -- President Eisenhower and his three fishing friends interrupted their outing near here today long enough for the President to cook a picnic lunch of pan-fried trout. This was followed by chilled watermelon slices.

In a nine-page report complete with fifty-five footnotes, a chemist issued a challenge yesterday to scientists who report that man can communicate in some mysterious brain-to-brain way. Either submit one really controlled experiment, he told them in effect, or stop cluttering up scientific journals withyour claims.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.2 per cent, to 110.5, to the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for all commodities other than farm products and foods accounted for the increase.
Under an order issued yesterday by Mayor Wagner, many city officials will lose their official limousines and chauffeurs by Sept. 15.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 26 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State under President Truman, predicted today that President Eisenhower would run again in 1956 and would be a hard man to beat.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today this week's car output will total 129,222 units compared with last week's 138,209. The agency put this week's truck assemblies at 21,177 against last week's 21,319.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Japanese Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu said today the Japanese must be less dependent upon the United States. They must move ahead to "a complete posture of independence," he added.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Logan Bennett, a 39-year-old salesman from Hodgenville, Ky., who never had won a trapshooting title, today captured the sports' biggest championship, the Grand American handicap.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 182 pints of blood Thursday at Fort Tilden, Rockaway Point, Queens. The day's total was 488 pints.
Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, announced yesterday a program designed to revitalize the Democratic party in upstate New York.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 26 -- Army headquarters reported today that one Israeli civilian had been killed and a soldier wounded in Egyptian ambushes in the Negev. A well was also said to have been blown up.
A barrage of criticism appeared yesterday to have doomed a proposed buffer committee to function between longshoremen and the bi-state Waterfront Commission.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The Orienta Yacht Club's third annual Mary Adams Maudice commemorative regatta, the last of nine events on the Junior Yacht Racing Association calendar, drew eighty-six starters off Scotch Caps today.
Russian farming and communism in children's camps will be two of the contemporary topics to be aired on television tomorrow.
The St. Regis Paper Company, after a long series of negotiations, has acquired the General Container Corporation of Cleveland, Ohio.

Last night was a rough one for the gunman who tried to stage a hold-up in the delicatessen at 1750 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. His victims refused to be scared. The cash register balked, and his pistol would not go off.

TRENTON, Aug. 26 -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. moved today to crack down on high-speed drivers. He ordered the state police and state vehicle inspectors to charge violators henceforth with reckless driving rather than speeding. The reckless-driving charge carries a heavier penalty.
SCHROON LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- The state's first forestry camp for young offenders will open in Chenango County in late October.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Fatin Rustu Zorlu, Turkish Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister who reiterated here today the Turkish Government's refusal to accept any change in the status quo with regard to Cyprus. However, he said he did not expect the coming talks on Cyprus to break up.

Phelps Dodge Corporation, largest domestic producer of copper, announced yesterday that it will increase the price of the metal from 40 cents to 43 cents a pound, effective Monday. The Anaconda Company took similar action Thursday and Inspiration Copper Company followed suit yesterday morning.
New England floods and sanguinary events in North Africa have played two odd tricks with French trade.

It is nothing short of amazing, when one stops to think of it -- which hardly anyone ever does -- that our magnificent network of roads is crowded in summertime with millions of motorists who know next to nothing about motors.
Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, conferred yesterday with Bernard M. Baruch on the disposition of property formerly belonging to Germany and Japan and their nationals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Reports that the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer motion picture "Blackboard Jungle" had been withdrawn from exhibition at the Venice Film Festival at the urging of United States Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce were confirmed today by Arthur Loew, president of Loew's International Corporation.
Edith -- the hurricane, that is -- seems to be a backward child, slow in development and rather uncertain of intentions.
Salvation Army trucks continued to roll out of the city yesterday with necessities for victims of the northeastern states' floods. And money continued to roll in to the American Red Cross.

DE KALB, Ill., Aug. 26 -- The ten millionth appliance motor to be produced at the General Electric Company's De Kalb plant since it began production in 1946 came off the production lines this morning.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 26 -- The Argentine Government has rejected three Uruguayan requests for a safe conduct permit for Raul Lamuraglia, refugee Argentine industrialist, who took asylum in the Uruguayan Embassy in Buenos Aires at the time of the June 16 revolt.

David Bronstein of Russia, the leader with a 5 1/2 -- 1 1/2 score in the interzone chess tournament in Goteborg, drew his eighth-round game yesterday. His countryman, G. Ilivitsky, moved back into second place with 5 -- 3, according to a report received through Swedish news sources.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama defended today the controversial expansion of United States air bases here as "essential" to Japan's future security. The extension of the runway of the Tachikawa air base near Tokio is violently opposed by local residents whose land would be requisitioned for the project.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- There was a rush to buy corn and soybeen futures at the opening today following the five-day weather forecast. It predicted temperatures over the Corn Belt 10 degrees above normal with extremely light rain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board refused today to intervene in the Miami hotel dispute over union bargaining elections.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- The American Bar Association moved today to meet the legal problems that would arise from an atomic attack on the United States.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 -- The Indians suffered a jolt to their pennant hopes today when it was revealed that Vic Wertz, their slugging first baseman-outfielder, was a polio victim. He likely will be lost to the Tribe for the rest of the season.

There has been no region of the world these last ten years in greater ferment than the Middle East. The term is a misnomer, for the vast nationalistic upheaval that we are witnessing stretches all the way from Morocco on the Atlantic to Pakistan on the Indian Ocean.

Mrs. Kenneth Vines of New Orleans yesterday won her adjourned third-round game to tie Mrs. Gisela K. Gresser of New York for first place with three straight victories in the women's national championship at the Manhattan Chess Club.

The world premiere of "The Left Hand of God" at the Roxy Theatre on Sept. 21 will be a benefit showing. Proceeds will go to Boys Towns of Italy, Inc. Mrs. George P. Skouras is chairman of the benefit committee. The event is being sponsored by a number of local, state and national leaders.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Army has been ordered to appear in Federal Court on Wednesday to answer a defense move to get Otho Bell. Korean war turncoat-out of military jail at near-by Fort Baker.

The uptrend in the stock market continued yesterday. Steel and copper issues and a few selected stocks again were the best performers. Some hesitancy developed in the afternoon, but a strong recovery got under way in the late trading. Final prices were generally near their best for the day.
The Hunter College Subscription Series will open this season on Oct. 22 with a recital by Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, the German soprano. It will be her only New York recital of the 1955-56 season.
Secretary of State Dulles proposed yesterday a program to end hostilities between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
OUED ZEM, French Morocco, Aug. 26 -- Moroccan tribesmen gathered near here to surrender heard a French general tell them they had behaved like "stinking jackals" in the recent massacres.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A Senate subcommittee investigating the Government's security-risk program will hold a series of re-examinations into individual case histories next week.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Pedro Ramos, a 20-year-old Washington right-hander, blanked the Chicago White Sox on two hits tonight while his team-mates collected fourteen for a 10-0 victory.

A shipment of 1,000,000 pounds of borax will be offered at public auction at 2 P. M. Sept. 13 on Staten Island. It was part of an $83,000 cargo seized by the Government in May on grounds that it was intended for Iron Curtain countries.
An Australian jockey whose ambition is to ride on every steeplechase course in the world has traveled halfway around the globe on a mission that may prove fruitless.
This country's projected fleet of roll on-roll off trailer-carrying ships increased three-fold overnight.
Milwaukee's battery of Bob Buhl and Del Crandall paced the streaking Braves to a second straight victory over the enfeebled Giants last night at the Polo Grounds.
PINE, Colo., Aug. 26 -- President Eisenhower went fishing today, in private.

WEATHER, good and bad, seems to crop up fairly often in this hardware - and - paintbrush corner, but there always seems to be a reason for it. Nature's didoes have a lot to do with what a man can or should work on around the place.

MADRAS, India, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- V. K. Krishna Menon, India's top foreign affairs adviser, said today he thought that "within a week or so we should see the questions resolved" at the current United States-Communist China negotiations in Geneva.
PARIS, Aug. 27 -- The violent outbreaks in French North Africa have shaken this country as few things have since the war.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 27 -Border-jumping by Mexican farm workers, the "wetback" traffic, has been reduced to a "trickle," Texas labor leaders reported this week, but many of its evils go on.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Kansas City Athletics came within a whisker of losing their young, prize third baseman to immigration authorities, it was disclosed today.

SALZBURG, Austria -- Along the narrow Getreidegasse here, tourists exclaim over medieval facades and elaborate black iron and gilt hanging signs. Then, in happy surprise, they notice that behind the antique exteriors, shops are bursting with goods of Madison Avenue quality at Fourteenth Street prices.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 27 -- Labor Minister Otto Fallas said today he thought moderate councils would prevail to prevent a threatened strike of United Fruit Company banana workers.

Danny O'Connell, not noted as a slugger, connected for two home runs at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The second came in the eleventh inning and gave the streaking Braves a 5-4 victory over the Giants before a ladies day gathering of 7,145 spectators.

Tradition sits lightly on the shoulders of James Talcott, chairman of the board of James Talcott, Inc., the nation's largest independent factoring concern. Tradition was established by his New England forebears, especially his grandfather, the first James Talcott, and "father" of modern factoring.

The high incidence of Shakespeare in North America was augmented recently by the opening of a Shakespeare Institute at Yale University. The purpose of the three-week annual course, first of its kind in the country, is to promote better teaching of the Bard in high schools.

LAST year the National Broadcasting Company introduced "spectaculars" and now comes a television producer who plans to do what he calls "actuals." David Susskind, who is not at all hesitant to take credit for the new tag, said his "actuals" would be "dramatizations based on truth."

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 27 -- The Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank's "barometer of business" was holding steady over the Ninth Federal Reserve District during July. Its report showed country department store sales to be even with the 1947-49 average, while inventories were running about the same as those of a year ago.

AFTER almost fifty years of making the opera and concert rounds, a man could be bored and lackadaisical about another performance, but Olin Downes never learned to be indifferent. There were times in the last few seasons when he was tired and went to a concert out of a sense of duty.

The Greater New York Safety Council will conduct a free driver-testing clinic for five days beginning tomorrow. The clinic will run from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M. in a trailer van parked on the Broadway side of City Hall Park at Murray Street.
Atomic radiation may be used to save the aged timbers in Westminster Abbey, St. Paul's Cathedral and hundreds of other ancient churches, and wooden relics threatened by gnawing and devouring insects.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 -- The chief of the Los Angeles Fire Department was buffeted on three sides this week in his fight to delay integration of the department's eighty-one Negroes.
LELYSTAD, the Netherlands, Aug. 20 -- Out of sand and stone and willow branches, the Dutch are fashioning here a capital for a province still mostly under water.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. SEEDSMEN to the world would be an apt slogan for the Ferry-Morse Seed Co. According to a recent count at their office here seed has been sold to eighty-seven countries this year.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The "blitz" sales technique is spreading in the auto retailing business.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 27 -- Former President Harry S. Truman tonight attacked the policies and performances of President Eisenhower and the Republican Administration.

THE automotive past will assault the present with fanfares of puffing and wheezing when 250 antique automobiles depart from Niagara Falls, N. Y., tomorrow on the start of the annual Glidden Tour revival.

THE summer will soon be behind us and it will be time to correct the damage to floors incurred during the past few months, when the doors of the house have been open and the floors subject to heavy traffic. Mud, sand and general disregard of the doormat, even with the best of care, have caused wear and tear; heavily used floor areas may have lost their finish, dirt has been ground into the flooring.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- In a sensational finish to the Silver Cup regatta as dusk gathered over the Detroit River tonight, Dan Foster piloted Tempo VII to victory over Bill Cantrell in Gale V, the winner of the Gold Cup at Seattle early this month.

A little over a week has passed since the tumultuous floods in the wake of Hurricane Diane devastated large sectors of the northeast. Since then, as private, state and Federal aid was rushed to the area, the enormity of the flood's damage has been revealed in human, economic and civic terms.
THE defenders may sometimes be persuaded to discard valuable cards in a suit that declarer or dummy has discarded, for declarer's discards make it appear that the suit is not valuable to him.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Federal judge adhered today to a ruling that the Government cannot collect on health insurance policies held by veterans treated at Veterans Administration hospitals.
AMONG the many individuals who worked unselfishly to aid victims of the recent floods in the Northeastern states were hundreds of amateur radio operators.

CABINET and dresser drawers often swell during moist, humid weather. A cure for this is to remove the drawers (during a dry spell) and give two coats of shellac to all inside surfaces. Cover the back, insides and outsides of drawers and any raw wood that is exposed.
CORNWALL, Ont., Aug. 27 -- Work on the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project is progressing according to schedule.

CALAIS, France, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Bill Pickering, 34-year-old English swimming pool manager, heaved himself up on the beach here today after swimming the twenty-one miles from England in 14 hours 6 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) Officers of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., warned newly acquired fur and leather worker locals again today to purge their official ranks of all subversive influences.

Back at the turn of the century a handsome blond young man named Bobby Walthour eloped from Atlanta with his sweetheart Daisy. They rode a tandem bicycle. After their marriage, they rode to New York for their honeymoon. It is said that this romance inspired the song "A Bicycle Built for Two."

WOONSOCKET, R. I., Aug. 27 (AP) -- You are flooded out. You are thankful your family is alive. But your home is gone. So is your job, at least temporarily, because of water damage to the place where you worked.
The New York Age Defender, one of the oldest Negro weekly newspapers in the country, observed its seventy-fifth anniversary yesterday.

THE justices now sitting on the Supreme Court would unanimously endorse the general theme of this book. No one can insist more earnestly than they that judges are human, variable and fallible men. To illustrate the theme in a proper scholarly narrative would call for a work of three or four substantial volumes.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 27 -- Walter J. Mahoney, Republican majority leader in the State Senate, said tonight that Governor Harriman and John W. Johnson, Public Works Superintendent, had deliberately delayed vitally needed construction work, presumably until an election year.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Mayor Wagner, members of the New York City Youth Board and Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy got a first-hand look today at Boys Harbor, one of the country's most unusual summer camps.

ROME, Aug. 27 -- A privately financed international organization to support free political parties throughout the world in their fight against communism was proposed here today by Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat oil Brooklyn.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 27 -- A team of legal and sociological experts, headed by Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, retired, will study Wisconsin's criminal justice system, from crime to punishment. General Donovan was head of the Office of Strategic Services in World War II.

Candidates for Fulbright fellowships for study in Australia and New Zealand in 1956-57 may make applications through Oct. 31. Fellowship holders will study zoology, agriculture, Southeast Asian affairs and other subjects under the educational exchange program.

GHENT, Belgium, Aug. 27 -- John Kelly Jr. of Philadelphia finished second to Poland's Teodor Kocerka today in the second heat of the single sculls semi-finals at the European rowing championships. Kelly remained in contention for the title.
Only eight months after it lost the Davis Cup to the United States at Sydney, Australia regained the world team tennis championship yesterday at Forest Hills.

When the Israeli freighter Tamar arrives today at Bridgeport, Conn., she will establish two firsts. It will mark the first time an Israeli-flag ship has called at a port in that state and the first delivery of Israeli cement in this country.

In his first news conference in Washington the visiting Japanese Foreign Minister, Mamoru Shigemitsu, stated that Japan must be less dependent upon the United States and move ahead to "a complete posture of independence." This is in entire accord with American plans and wishes for Japan. It is certainly to our advantage to have Japan progressively less dependent upon the United States.
The country's scheduled air carriers, it appears, are not prepared to yield to the gentleman from Massachusetts on the issue of serving alcoholic beverages aloft.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Last April a group of truck farmers in El Salvador could hardly credit their prosperity when they banked the equivalent of $5,000 from vegetable crops on their cooperatively farmed land. Their gross a year earlier from the same products on the same twenty-eight acres had been only $1,000.
The annual Eastern Conference of the National Fencing Coaches Association of America will meet at New York University this week to inspect new electrical equipment and discuss rules changes.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Cavcote Farm's bay mare Night Lilly scored 19 points to win the working hunter championship during the Smithtown horse show today.

THE cool look of ferns in shady areas of the garden is especially prized during the dogdays of midsummer. Wise indeed is the gardener who views such shady spots not as "problem patches" but as potential oases of refreshing green.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The mutineers of the Sudan Defense Force in the southern Sudan have agreed to surrender. The Foreign Office announced tonight that the mutineers, holding out in the town of Torit in the province of Equatoria, had unconditionally accepted the terms of Governor General Sir Knox Helms' ultimatum to surrender or face the consequences.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- California Democrats were laying plans this week to ease Thomas H. Kuchel, Republican, out of the Senate next year.
ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Five Liberian lawyers have come to Cornell to go over a new code of their country's laws that was prepared at the university.

YOUNG people -- and adults too -- will find "Atoms Today and Tomorrow" informative, accurate and unexpectedly pleasant reading. Unlike so many books on atomic energy, this one does not foster fear and frustration. There are no pictures of menacing mushroom clouds, blasted buildings and pathetically maimed humans.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Richard Webber of Sussex, Wis., broke ninety-eight of 100 clay targets at 21 yards today to win the Vandalia handicap, the final event on the nine days of the Grand American trapshooting tournament.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Joe W. Brown's Hi Pardner came up fast in the stretch to defeat eleven other 3-year-olds and capture the eleventh running of the $25,000-added Del Mar Derby today.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 27 -- Political unrest in South Africa is growing.
Threatening skies and the prospect of many roadblocks and detours in nearby flood areas produced a sharp reduction in week-end automobile traffic out of the city yesterday.
Labor-management relations in the traditionally turbulent Port of New York reached a new low of uncertainty and confusion last week.
TOKYO -- One of the more pleasant places to eat dinner on a hot summer night in Tokyo is down Tokyo Bay on a fishing boat. If the fishing is good, the catch becames part of the meal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- The Chicago White Sox ended a hitting drought and a three-game losing streak today by routing the Washington Senators, 11 -- 1. The 8,442 fans present sent the Comiskey Park attendance for the season over the 1,000,000 mark.

SLOPES and shade are two stumbling blocks for lawn builders. And loss of moisture is the greatest problem that affects these areas. On slopes water runs off without penetrating the soil (depending, of course, on the amount of slope), while under trees hungry roots grab most of the free supply.
" Whole hog or nothing" is the credo of the modern meat packer. Through an ingenious "dis-assembly" production line he processes everything from the hog except the squeal.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 27 -- The Export-Import Bank has agreed "in principle" to lend Costa Rica $9,000,000, official sources disclosed today.

PREDETERMINING the course of business is difficult because production, sales, and prices often fail to follow each other. The current, situation is a case in point. Sales have leveled off, but production appears still to be making some gains.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 27 -- The Department of Agriculture's plan to subsidize the diversion of inferior potatoes to the production of starch, animal feeds and flour was hailed here today.
GENEVA, Aug. 26 -- The United States is participating in an international project for resettling Okinawans in Bolivia.

THE jacket blurb for this book notes that "Goggle is a little boy. 'This Is Goggle' is the loving, laughing story of his growing up, as told by his infatuated (if somewhat battered) father." There are other references to "heart-warming and hilarious.

Strong demands for speeding long - range flood - prevention measures were being pressed last week as the Northeast counted its losses -- in lives property and employment opportunities -- from its worst natural disaster of recent years.

As Congress adjourned early this month, its members could look back with merited satisfaction on two appropriation increases they had made voluntarily. They had added $500,000 to the appropriation of the National Institute of Neurological Diseases and Blindness and $250,000 to that of the National Institute of Mental Health for research in mental retardation.

If some formula is not found soon to prevent work stoppages on the New York waterfront, many banana importers either will have to use other ports to bring in the fruit or quit the business, according to a spokesman for a major importing company.
OTTAWA, Aug. 18 -- Canada wants and needs immigrants to provide the skills and labor required to develop its vast areas.

The delivery situation in ready-to-wear is expected to tighten further as a result of delays in shipment of fabrics to apparel manufacturers following the New England floods, resident buying offices report.

Producers of watches will have an excellent year, according to Arthur B. Sinkler, president of the American Watch Manufacturers Association and of the Hamilton Watch Company. Domestic watch producers, he said, are in a better competitive position because of recent increases in tariffs.
A colorful baseball figure who has scored many a hit without swinging a bat in a half-century of major league service will get his innings tonight.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP) -- An Army veteran, denied an honorable discharge because of his associations before induction, will appear as a witness Monday before a Senate subcommittee investigating the Administration's loyalty program.
The "battle of the bikes" has taken an ironic turn.

KARACHI, Aug. 27 -- Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali appealed today to the French Government to "take early steps to allow the people of Morocco and Algeria to achieve their national aspiration" of freedom.
TEANECK, N. J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A New York City man was killed and six others were injured in a five-car crash on Route 4 near Belle Avenue late today. Five of the injured are from Brooklyn.

Paris Receives a Queen The summer of 1855 was a great one in Paris, with a climax in late August. The Universal Exposition of Industry there, which had opened May 15, was attracting world attention, also the visits of numerous European potentates.

FOR many reasons the flow of first-rate old master paintings into this country has noticeably slowed down in recent years. For one thing, there is a growing shortage of these; for another, foreign governments have been putting up an increasingly stiff opposition to the disposal of their artistic patrimony abroad.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Aug. 28 -- D. M. Ferguson, president of the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia, said today that Australia had scored a "magnificent victory" in the Davis Cup championships.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 26 -- The rapidly increasing importance of Japanese industrial power in the Asian economy is underlined by a sheet of purchase statistics issued today by the Indian Government.

OLIN DOWNES wrote his first review for this paper on Jan. 2, 1924. He covered the New York premiere of Wilhelm Krienzl's "Der Evangelimann" at the Manhattan Opera House. "There is not a stroke of originality in the opera," he snorted.

BERRYVILLE, Va., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, proposed today a policy of "limited friendship" toward the Russians while the United States put the Soviet Union's peaceful overtures to the test.

THE first processing system designed for home development of miniature and roll color film has been announced by Brown-Forman Industries of Louisville, Ky. Although introduced as a convenient means of developing black-and-white rollfilm by a new seven-minute process, hence its name, 7-Minute Processer, the device actually is more logically adaptable to simplified processing of color film by amateurs.

WHO wants to live in Bernard Shaw's old home, Shaw's Corner, Ayot Street. Lawrence, Hertfordshire? American househunters who plan a sojourn abroad are advised to contact The National Trust of London, England.

North Africa has been called a "continent within a continent." Two deserts (the Libyan and Sahara) isolate it from the rest of Africa. Two seas (the Mediterranean and Atlantic) separate it from the Western world.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Elimination of all foreign bids on Federal contracts for domestic construction is under consideration by the Administration.

THE plot of Elizabeth Cadell's latest novel is woven around the devotion of a family of impoverished orphans to their beautiful old house in the English New Forest. When lovely but "uppish" Lucille, the eldest of the six Waynes, became engaged to a mother-ridden, amiably dull bachelor, she put up Wood Mount for sale.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- A new coal region is being developed in the western Soviet Union.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 27 -- Fifty-seven Syracuse University football candidates will report to Coach Ben Schwartzwalder Thursday when the Orange starts drills for its sixty-seventh campaign.

WITH ships and planes bringing home this year's group of American students who spent their vacation traveling in Europe, the Council on Student Travel, a non-profit educational organization, has released a study showing that today's student traveler to Europe is spending more money, seeing more countries and learning more languages than the postwar student traveler seven or eight years ago.

SUMMER excursions away from Manhattan invariably reveal that contemporary art is a house of many more mansions than one might suspect. THE humor of James Helvick suggests rather sober combination of Bemelmans, Shulman and Thorne Smith -- which, as a comedy-formula of sorts, need not necessarily prove outlandish, unless, say, the author happened to use the worst of each.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 27 -- The recent explosions in North Africa have cast a lurid light on the local brand of Arab nationalism.

FOLK music recordings are apt to fall into two main categories: those by named performers, who often have individual styles, and those by anonymous groups and individuals who carry on old traditions. Recent disks by known musicians will be discussed here.

More than half the pleasure of going is in the return, as any traveler knows. To go, to see the far place, the place beyond the familiar horizon, is exciting; but to return is satisfying as few other things can ever be. To know after absence the familiar street and road and village and house is to know again the satisfaction of home.

EDWARD R. MURROW, the Columbia Broadcasting System's indefatigable newsman, will lay down his plowshare to take up his typewriter again when he returns this week, from a summer's work on his 280-acre farm.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 -- Should it come to pass that the Yankees fail to win the American League pennant this year, it is a good bet that Casey Stengel will point to this date as the day on which the Bombers blew it.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Britain pledge her full support today for the United States' proposal to guarantee agreements between Israel and the Arab states.
Scoring her fourth straight victory, Mrs. Kenneth Vines of New Orleans took the undisputed lead yesterday in the United States women's chess championship at the Manhattan Chess Club.

CHICAGO -- For transcontinental rail travelers this city will soon lose one of its most familiar landmarks, figurative if not literal. The Parmelee Company, its "Parmelee Man" a symbolic figure almost as well known to tourists as "The Man From Cook's," is bowing out of the transfer business here.

Traders took a more active interest in the stock market last week. Favorable business forecasts for the remainder of the year brought about an abrupt change in sentiment -- and a strong rally in prices. Selected issues advanced sharply in the most active trading in three weeks.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 -- A piece of man-bites-dog news from the nation's second largest city-school system: No teacher shortage.

Once he has done this, and written a best-seller about the trip and, on the strength of his achievement, been engaged to endorse soap and so on, he will be content to dwell in a conventional civilized rut.

PEACE has broken out among some of the principal United States-flag airlines and as a result passengers making flights along the lengthy north-south air routes of the Western Hemisphere are being provided with new through-plane services.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 -- With all but four of 260 freighters now in commission, Great Lakes vessel operators are having a busy and profitable season. Jones of the Wilson Transit Company collided in the St. Mary's River and sustained heavy damage.

WHO among us of a certain age -- over 25, say -- does not remember with nostalgia the ugly old crank-up Victrola, the stacks of Carusos, McCormacks and Galli-Curcis that invariably accompanied it, and the wondrous tinny sounds that emerged from it?

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray chrysanthemums and skrubs with nicotine sulfate for aphids, and dust broccoli with rotenone for the same insect. Continue to spray roses, particularly for black spot, with special three-purpose spray. Dust with sulfur zinnias, phlox or any plants infected with mildew. Apply a miticide to shrubs for red spider.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Negotiators for the Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C.I.O., met today in a round of bargaining sessions aimed at averting a strike of 139,000 workers. The strike is set for midnight Wednesday.

NO matter how hard the reader looks for it on maps, he won't find the never-never island of Cibola. Most fourth-dimensional islands have a kind of Celtic-inspired proclivity to appear, when they do appear, in the eastern part of the Atlantic, and Cibola is no exception.
The 70-year-old owner of a downtown jewelry concern was shot dead yesterday in his seventh-floor office.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 19 -- The farthest north helicopter operation ever attempted is being carried out this summer over islands of the Canadian Arctic 500 miles north of Resolute Bay.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- This famous springtime vacation resort is enjoying the biggest summer tourist season in its history. Bermuda, like Florida, is apparently being discovered by the traditional summer travel crowds that normally have neither the time nor the money to visit such a glamorous spot in season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles' proposal of a program to restore peace in the Middle East was described today as a major effort to break the deadlock in the Israeli-Arab situation. WHITING, Ind., Sunday, Aug. 28 -- A roaring fire, touched off by devastating explosions, swept the huge refinery of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana here yesterday. The blaze, which still was out of control early today, for a while threatened a large section of this city of 10,000.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 27 -- India took two small steps this week along a winding road that is supposed to lead toward her own variety of socialism.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 27 -- While the rest of French North Africa was settling down from anti-French violence. Tunisia rejoiced today.
ANSBACH, Germany. AMONG the many new festivals that have appeared on the European musical scene in the past ten years, the Bachwoche (Bach Week) in Ansbach, Franconia, is unique.

Hurricane Edith yesterday appeared destined to blow herself out at a point far from the storm-weary Atlantic coast, but weather men nevertheless maintained a round-the-clock watch on the still-developing storm.

POSTAL administrations of all the free world nations are being invited by the United States Government to take part in F. I. P. E. X. (Fifth International Philatelic Exhibition). Informally, England, France, the Netherlands and Switzerland have already accepted bids to send exhibits here for display at New York's first international stamp show since 1947.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 27 -- The formal surrender of the two Smala tribes near Oued Zem in central Morocco yesterday does not seem to mean that peace has been entirely restored in the area.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Chicago's apparel shows will occupy the attention of Midwest retailers during the first three weeks of September. Starting off the series of exhibits will be the Children's Wear Association at the Merchandise Mart and the Bandwagon of Infant's, Children's and Girls' Wear at the Palmer House from Sept. 4 to 9.
GENEVA, Aug. 27 -- Discussion by scientists of six countries of the technical problems of international control of atomic energy ended here today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y. -- This year's New York State Fair -- which is the 109th and thus just about the oldest in the nation -- runs from Saturday to Sept. 10, and will be streamlined more than it has ever been.
TRENTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Dwight R. G. Palmer, New Jersey flood disaster coordinator, says over-all damage caused by last week-end's floods is approaching $30,000,000.

CARL CARMER in his review of Samuel Hopkins Adams' "Grandfather Stories," writes that "the sound we describe as a Bronx cheer was known as a gardaloo." The derivation of this is interesting. It comes from France via Scotland.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Mrs. Jennifer Hoad and Wilma McIver were two of the thousands of Australians who got up at 5 A. M. to listen to radio broadcasts of yesterday's Davis Cup matches at Forest Hills.
The General Electric Company, world's largest electrical manufacturer, also is, in a sense, one of the world's largest educational institutions.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer returned to his capital tonight for the final weekend of his summer holiday, before discussions on the last outstanding details of his visit to Moscow next month.

TEN years ago, on a pitch-black night, a Japanese Navy bomber skidded on the sea a few yards from the beach near the town of Hamamatsu, south of Toyko. At the instant of impact the pilot, considered the most skillful in Japan, gunned his engines with the last ounces of gasoline in the tanks.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Leila Buckland, a 30-year-old British housewife from Biggin Hill, Kent, set an unofficial women's world record for the two-mile run today. She won in 11 minutes 1.8 seconds during a track meet at Charlton Park.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 27 -- Pakistan and India ratified today a liberal trade agreement that virtually eliminates customs and exchange restrictions on a wide variety of basic commodities for millions of persons living in the border areas of East Pakistan and four states in India.
DENVER, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower discussed today plans for reducing job discrimination in defense industries without punitive legal action.

DUBLIN, Aug. 22 -- The Republic of Ireland has issued invitations to several countries, including the United States, to help its industrial development by providing both capital and technical skills for establishing new projects.

TO facilitate cabinet and furniture work, or the laying of a plank floor, the Screw-Mate combination sets may be of interest. The Screw-Mate is basically a drill that bores a pilot hole for the threads of a wood screw, a large hole for the non-threaded shoulder of the screw and a countersunk hole for the head.

IN straightforward fashion John Perry, a consultant on visual presentation and human relations, presents an astounding amount of information about the human eye -- why it sees, how it works, its importance and its care. With considerable ingenuity he clinches the facts stressed by suggesting simple experiments to prove their validity.

In view of the preparatory talks being started by the United States this week with its Western allies to work out a common approach to the Big Four foreign ministers conference in October, both President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles have now issued a restatement of American foreign policy which events since the Geneva "summit" meeting have made necessary.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Directors of the Bank of Northern Brookhaven, L. I., and the First Suffolk National Bank of Huntington, L. I. have agreed on a merger of the two institutions. It would be the seventh bank in Suffolk County to merge with First Suffolk in two years.

Sandy Koufax, the Brooklyn club's bonus baby, wrote a new chapter in the annals of baseball at Ebbets' Field yesterday when he hurled a two-hit shutout against the Cincinnati Redlegs and struck out fourteen. The score was 7 -- 0.

THE author of "Search for a Hero" and two earlier novels of quiet realism lit by irony has now turned his hand to a strangely potent suspense novel. A prologue, in itself a tour de force of satire, introduces both the protagonist and his narrative.
Insurance companies and banks have no answer to the problem of flood losses. The waters wash away homes, factories and stores, but debts and mortgages remain with the debris.

GENEVA, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- A Boston juvenile court judge told delegates to the first United Nations Congress on Crime Prevention today that in eighteen years of court experience she had seen many cases of parental delinquency but none of juvenile delinquency.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 --Responding to an appeal from the American Red Cross, Cyrus S. Jullien, president of the Aqueduct race track, announced today that all proceeds of next Wednesday's program at Aqueduct would go to the Red Cross flood relief fund.
New York University's varsity basketball team will participate in the Orange Bowl Festival in Miami Beach, Fla., in addition to playing a regular sixteen-game schedule for the 1955-56 season.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 27 -- Patricia Ann Lesser of Seattle, the new women's amateur golf champion, was born in Brooklyn, while her father, an artillery officer in the United States Army, was stationed at Fort Totten. She has traveled a good deal since.

THIS short novel, once more, shows Aldous Huxley, in all lucidity, treating human beings as a mixture of moral and scientific phenomena. The form is conventional; two men sit up sucking pipes, sipping whisky and talking about the private life of a scientist of genius and his wife.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Duke's Lea, a 4-year-old dark bay colt, today won the $56,150 Meadowland Handicap at Washington Park. In a driving finish under Willie Shoemaker, the Calumet Farm racer beat Blue Choir by a head.
The boys' wear business is booming. Manufacturers of dress and sport shirts, slacks, ties and similar items expect 1955 to be the best year in the history of the industry.

THE relaxed attitude of the British toward the sedition expressed every day in Hyde Park would reduce an American superpatriot to apoplexy. While the United States has tied itself into a legal and constitutional tangle over the problem of free speech, Britain long ago took a common-sense approach that protects the rights of both the soapbox orator and the public.

The consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for July, just released, shows an advance of three-tenths of a point over the June figure, or from 114.4 (1947-1949=100) to 114.7. Modest though this advance is, it is the widest since May, 1954. In June consumer prices had moved up from 114.2 to 114.4. Not since May-June, 1954, has this index, familiarly known as the C. P. I., advanced in two successive months.

TRENTON, Aug. 27 -- The Republican-controlled New Jersey Legislature, reconvening here Monday, is slated to adopt bills appropriating $3,000,000 to $5,000,000 for flood relief, and $200,000 to repair Delaware River bridges damaged by the recent deluge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- It is more than a month since President Eisenhower ordered cancellation of the controversial Dixon-Yates contract -- something sooner said than done.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The pilot of Britain's newest top-secret jet fighter told today how he fought his plane back to base after it "blew its top" while diving at 600 miles an hour.

ANYONE who has followed the checkered course of American aid to Asia in the last decade knows that something has gone awry. Why is it that those hundreds of millions of dollars generously contributed by taxpayers of the United States and all the shining new equipment and the high-priced technicians that accompany it have not achieved more success in helping Asians help themselves?

SEATTLE, Aug. 27 (AP) -- O. A. Knight, one of the architects of the planned merger of the Congress of Industrial Organization and American Federation of Labor, predicted today the merger would be completed on schedule.

WEATHER and climate are major factors in lawn greenness, but they are not always to blame for a shabby lawn. A visit to the local golf course will prove this. The greenskeeper will testify that the most important thing in the establishment and permanence of a lawn is the nature and depth of the topsoil.
NAHAL OZ, Israel, Aug. 24 -- From the coastal hills of the Egyptian-held Gaza Strip, one can look across the troubled truce line at this settlement.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Communist China and East Germany will not attend the forty-fourth congress of the Inter-Parliamentary Union under way here, it was learned tonight.

THE Canadian Government has decided the time has come to take another look at its broadcasting policies for radio and television. Rising costs, especially for television, and mounting criticism of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation have led the Government to announce that a Royal Commission or a board of inquiry soon will be appointed to conduct an investigation into the subject.

A division chief of the Army Engineers, back from a survey of flood rehabilitation work, declared yesterday that "the country isn't rich enough to build everything that would be needed to stop floods."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Souvenir sheets of three stamps commemorating the tenth anniversary of the United Nations will be issued Oct. 24 by the United Nations Postal Administration, an announcement yesterday said.

PARIS, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The French Foreign Legion is back in action in North Africa, trying as ever to keep the empire from falling apart.

He does not say who his colleagues are, or what their number, nor does his letter explain the curious fact that it emanates from Paris and not from Saigon.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Fourteen-year-old Bill Kober is doing a man-size job in flood-stricken Carpentersville, three miles south of here. The town, on the Delaware River, was hit hard by the flood. Of the eighty-nine homes in the river colony, thirty-one were washed away and fifty were damaged. Communications were shattered.
KIMBERLY, South Africa, Aug. 18 -- Behind the facade of apartheid (racial segregation), the stage is being set to integrate the Negro reservations into South Africa's economy.
LINDENHURST, L. I., Aug. 27 -- Three members of a family were killed at 6:46 o'clock this morning when a train hit their car at the Wellwood Avenue grade crossing of the Long Island Rail Road.

PORT RADIUM, Northwest Territories, Aug. 26 -- Everywhere the Royal Commission on Economic Prospects has gone in the Mackenzie District of the Northwest Territories great efforts have been made to impress upon its members the importance of better transportation.

THE "ocean postal service," one of the oldest forms of communication, may be making deliveries soon on one of the larger mailings recently committed to its care. The crew of the Atka returning from the Antarctic
CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The condition of polio-stricken Vic Wertz of the Cleveland Indians took a hopeful turn today as his fever subsided during the second day of his illness.
OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Cornelius Shields Jr., a lanky 21 - year - old yachtsman from Larchmont, N. Y., today won the 1955 international Class 110 championship regatta.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 27 -- Chief Minister David Marshall said today that Singapore would achieve self-government by the end of next year. He added that he would go to London in November to arrange the agenda for a conference next April on self-rule between the British Government and a delegation from Singapore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn, who lost one tax cut fight this year, vowed today that "the little fella" will not be left out of any cut that Congress might vote in the 1956 election year.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Prime Minister Eden stressed today that the British Government still believed "there cannot be security in Europe while Germany is divided."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Any notions that this country's tariffs can remain static for even so much as a year were pretty effectively dispelled a week ago Friday. On that day President Eisenhower approved a tariff increase of 50 per cent on bicycles.
THE 1956 Photography Annual (New York: Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. $1), published last week, is distinguished from earlier issues principally by the new method of grouping the pictures.

The recent six months' interim report of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation gave further support to the validity of the policies of its chairman and president, Roy T. Hurley. He discussed in an interview how development of these policies had doubled the company's consolidated net profit after taxes over the first half of 1954.
SAYREVILLE, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Anthony S. Gadek, a Middlesex County Freeholder since 1936, was killed by an automobile early today on the approach to the Victory Bridge over the Raritan River.

The Small Business Administration yesterday listed the places where business and home owners in flooded areas may apply for disaster loans. The emergency offices are empowered to make loans up to $20,000 without referral to the regional office in New York.
