IN "Bell's Landing." Gerald Warner Brace, a somewhat under-rated American novelist, has written another warmhearted, shrewd and penetrating novel. It is easy to read; it flatters the reader's intelligence; it entertains.

TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- The conservative Government of Premier Ichiro Hatoyama is making a major bid for United States cooperation -- a move that it hopes will strengthen it on the domestic political front as well as in the larger game of international relations.
WITH the water barely dry on its stage and the mud still ankle-deep in its parking lot, the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., is gamely set to ring up its damp curtain tomorrow night.

READING, Pa., Aug. 27 -- The $30,000,000 state program to dredge culm out of the Schuylkill and other rivers over the last five years appears now to be a failure as a flood-control measure. Culm is a carboniferous deposit found under good coal and is discarded as a waste product of mining.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Sammy Boulmetis rode five winners today at the Atlantic City race track, including Talora in the $23,250 Philadelphia Turf Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson, departs tomorrow for a seventeen-day tour of Western Europe to try and sell some of America's huge food surpluses.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 27 -- One of the oldest annual benefits on the North Shore of Long Island is scheduled for Oct. 23 in the auditorium of the Gen Cove High School. The local unit of the New York Speedwell Society will sponsor Burl Ives, star of the Broadway production "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" in an evening's program.

THE Davis Cup rested in silvery splendor in front of the marquee at Forest Hills yesterday. By late afternoon the setting sun had speckled it with a golden glow. It made a pretty sight. But if any Americans still want to get a glimpse of Dwight F. Davis' gift to international tennis, they'd better hurry.

ALTHOUGH lawns seeded in September are generally more successful than those started in the spring, a disturbingly high percentage of these cannot be termed a complete success. Failures can usually be traced to the use of inferior seed or the haphazard preparation of the seed bed.

Chairman Lewis L. Strauss of the Atomic Energy Commission called attention last week to the growing shortage of scientists and engineers in this country. On his return from the Geneva International Conference on Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, Mr. Strauss warned that we are losing our supremacy in the science fields. The Soviet Union, he said, is making a greater effort than the United States to encourage students to train as scientists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest at Folly Beach, S. C., tonight of Elmer Francis (Trigger) Burke, 37 years old, described as a "self-professed New York killer."

The report spread the blame between the pharmaceutical manufacturer and the Public Health Service. Deep mystery obscured large areas of the study.

TETERBORO, N. J., Sunday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A strike was called at the New Jersey plants of Bendix early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The heads of six cities in the United States will leave New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, tomorrow for a four-week tour of fiftten West German cities. The group, led by Patrick Healy Jr., executive director of the American Municipal Association, will study general municipal operations in Germany and exchange ideas and information on city services and techniques with German federal officials at round-table discussions.

RICHMOND, Aug. 27 -- Voluntary wage increases became general in Fifth Reserve District textile mills at the start of last week. The pattern set earlier by a few companies swept the whole industry. The increase averaged 5 cents an hour and did not reflect union demands.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 27 -There has been a retrogression in the moral standards of motion pictures shown in this country in the last year, Msgr. Thomas F. Little of Brooklyn declared here today.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 27 -- The East Hampton Settlement House on the Three Mile Harbor Road will benefit by the annual tea, bridge and canasta party to be held at the Maidstone Club on Wednesday afternoon, Sept. 7.

PHYSICAL expansion of television facilities in Hollywood is sprouting like Jack's beanstalk. New building operations by two motion-picture companies and two networks demonstrate that growth for TV film production is the order of the day.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Argentine Federal police seized a cache of arms and bomb parts early today and arrested at least four persons in a series of raids.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 28 -- Exchange reform in Brazil is near, according to Minister of Finance Jose Maria Whitaker, but not as near as it was expected.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Herve Alphand of France arrived this morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by an Air France plane, to take over the dual posts of French permanent representative at the United Nations and on the Security Council.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- The ninety-three sloops appearing for the New York Athletic Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today drifted across the finish line after a spell of excellent sailing.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- Now the second greatest coal-producing country in the world, the Soviet Union, will mine more than 390,000,000 tons of coal this year. That is the figure reached twenty years ago by the United States, which leads the world in coal production.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that Parks Commissioner Robert Moses already had at his disposal more tax-free land than he knew how to improve.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Aug. 28 -Plans have been discussed between United States and Chinese Nationalist officials in Formosa for establishing a reserve training program. It would give the Nationalists a backlog force amounting to nine reserve divisions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Elizabeth Taylor will be starred by Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer in its film version of "Raintree County," the novel by the late Ross Lockridge Jr. The studio has owned screen rights to the book since its publication in 1947.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Government allocated $32,600,000 in vocational rehabilitation funds to states this fiscal year, an increase of $5,800,000 over last year. Mary E. JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 28 There was something new under the tropical Indonesian sun yesterday -- ice skating.

Demonstrating again that he and his Government are determined to keep in good faith all agreements they make, Chancellor Adenauer has bluntly repudiated the campaign of the pro-German parties in the Saar against the new "European" statute for the territory and has not only condemned their riotous behavior but has in effect urged them to vote for the statute in the referendum on Oct. 23.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 28 -- Two Israeli soldiers were killed and three wounded and a wounded Egyptian terrorist was captured in sporadic fighting today around the northern perimeter of the Gaza strip.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- A new attempt by the major nations of the world to settle questions of disarmament and control of the atomic bomb begins here tomorrow.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28 -- The atomic age will be symbolized tomorrow when Rich's $8,000,000 department store is opened here. Ribbons at the store's entrances will be cut by radioactive controlled energy.
It takes more than printed timetables to turn New York subway riders into smooth commuters.
New York is having its own flood.

Cotton prices in the domestic market were narrowly irregular last week. Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended trading on Friday with net declines 5 to26 points. At the close of the previous week futures were up 29 to down 33 points.

In compliance with a directive from Cardinal Spellman, the clergy in all parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York urged worshipers yesterday to give generously to the Red Cross Flood Relief Fund.

Thomas B. Costain's eighth novel, "The Tontine," is the story of four generations of three families in nineteenth-century England and America. Published in two volumes, the story covers from the day of the Battle of Waterloo to 1880, giving a picture of what was going on in that period.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 28 -Fifty-four foreign business concerns here are closing their doors tomorrow in protest against what they describe as unfair taxation. Forty of these have headquarters in the United States.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates cut down the second - place Milwaukee Braves twice today. Vernon Law blanked the Braves, 2 -- 0, in the second game after the Pirates put together a four-run eighth-inning rally to win the opener, 5 -- 3.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (UP) -- A Federal labor mediator met today with representatives of the Bendix Corporation and the United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., in an effort to end the strike of 20,000 Bendix workers at eight plants across the country.

THOMAS EDWARD LAWRENCE died in a motorcycle crash twenty years ago, but his legend goes marching on. No hero of World War I has retained such a hold on popular imagination as Lawrence of Arabia; no amateur soldier has ever inspired more hero worship, more controversy or more books. Within the last year Law rence's own memoir of his life as an air-force recruit, "The Mint," was published.
NEWARK, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The oft - criticized Plainfield - Union Water Company now can give its customers "safe, adequate and proper service," the Public Utility Commission says.

Flare-ups of mass violence in the nation's prisons this year have deepened official concern over penal problems. Eighteen uprisings have been reported since Jan. 19 in ten state prisons, one state hospital for the criminally insane and two county jails. One man was killed and about fifty injured. Inmates seized thirty-five guards as hostages.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- The Times of London criticized today the Palestine peace plan of Secretary of State Dulles as "likely to satisfy nobody in the Middle East."

Virgil M. Rogers, dean of the School of Education of Syracuse University, deplored yesterday the shortage of school teachers throughout the country. He said the need for more teachers was so urgent that it was "becoming a scandal to a great many people all over the country."

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Federal police rounding up suspects in the wake of the discovery of an illegal cache of arms were reported today to have arrested at least twenty-eight persons, many of them youths.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board split today in deciding not to punish a union accused of unfair practices against its own employes.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The crisis in Morocco that the French Government is attempting to resolve is largely of its own making. Lack of authority, indecision, weakness under pressure, and delay, have characterized French handling of the situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The United States expedition to the Antarctic, beginning in October, plans to transport thirty tons of supplies for each man. This figure compares with the seven tons shipped abroad for each United States soldier in World War II.

It was triple-or-no-count at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Chicago Cubs got all the triples and all the runs and the Giants were of no account as Bob Rush blanked the fading champions, 3 -- 0. The Windy City right-hander now owns three shutouts over the New Yorkers this season.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 28 -- A feud between two neighbors over a fence culminated last night in the wounding of one of them by a policeman three days before he was to have moved.

Former President Herbert Hoover, Dr. Ralph Bunche and Bing Crosby are among 100 prominent citizens named yesterday to the National Citizens Committee of the 1955 United Community Campaigns of America.
Four new vice presidents in the Pepsi-Cola Company were announced over the week-end by Herbert L. Barnet, president. They will have charge of the company's recently created divisional authorities.
Increase in expenditures for private nonresidential and residential construction are predicted for 1956.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Republican National Chairman denounced former President Harry S. Truman today as a "bitter, frustrated man." Leonard W. Hall said Mr. Truman was jealous of President Eisenhower's accomplishments and popularity.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- Law enforcement authorities have are making a strong bid to extradite Burke for trial.

Christians the world over belong to "one church," the Rev. Dr. Toru Matsumoto declared yesterday, and no national differences can separate them in their universal adoration of Christ. "Though we speak different tongues, we come together to speak one language -- a language of love," he said.
TIMES SQUARE'S well of light will glow brighter in a few weeks. A new sign -- a spectacular, the trade calls it -- is to go on Toffenetti's roof at the Square's southeast corner.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 28 (AP) -- India's uncounted millions of numbers game players and operators were amused and concerned today over what's going on in Washington and New York.

Conventional programs to convince industry to continue older workers on the job or to employ older applicants have made virtually no impact. Only by a straight-forward economic inducement to reward industry for its employment of older workers by a reduction in payroll taxes, pension and unemployment insurance costs can it be persuaded to begin a reversal of its prejudices against them.

ATHENS, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece headed a first-night audience last night at Gluck's "Orpheus in the Underworld," the first opera to be performed at the Athens Music Festival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Administration's chief financial officers, with President Eisenhower's backing, have opened a Government-wide campaign to cut back the upward spending trend revealed in last week's midyear budget review.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- The Government newspaper Izvestia said today the Soviet would give "serious consideration" to Western proposals at the United Nations disarmament subcommittee talks tomorrow in New York.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Arthur M. Deacon of Larchmont, sailing Armade, took the last race of the three-race series at the American Yacht Club today to capture the Western Long Island Sound district Lightning Class championship. He had a perfect score of seventy-two points.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- In the chilly dusk, 6,000 persons gathered tonight at the Boston University Alumni Field for a memorial service opening the fifty-sixth national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 -- The Soviet Union commands a formidable corps of research scientists capable of infusing new productivity into agriculture.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Sir John Braithwaite, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, challenged assertions today by Labor party spokesmen and the Trades on Congress that dividends and company profits had risen faster than wages.

A former California State speed skating champion, who did not own a bicycle until three and a half years ago, won the national senior men's amateur cycling championship for the second straight year yesterday.
Following is a chronological review of prison uprisings in the nation this year:

A SET of seventeenth century paintings has started Guy Roop, the decorator, off on a distinctive style of interior design. The Flemish paintings, which were cartoons (designs) for tapestries, demanded the proper setting. The result was a room resembling the backgrounds in old Dutch pictures.

" ONE TOUCH OF VENUS" was a whopping financial success on the stage a dozen years ago. The musical about a statue of Venus that comes to life and upsets the tranquil life of a young barber had a Broadway run of 567 performances.
HINTERZARTEN, Germany, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Olympic officials from East and West Germany announced today that Germany's new "unified" team would use two national hymns.

West Germany's market for capital is experiencing a marked recovery, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York notes in and article to appear in its forthcoming Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions for September.

The post-war trend toward higher expenses and lower percentage profits among limited-price variety stores continued through 1954, according to a survey by the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Britain officially expressed "grave concern" tonight over the rejection by the United States of a British manufacturer's bid to provide equipment for an American hydroelectric project.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Corn and soybean futures took the speculative spotlight last week as news regarding these products became almost unanimously bullish. Sharp advances from early week low spots were registered in both corn and soybeans, and these upturns imparted a small measure of strength to wheat, rye and oats.
PARIS, Monday, August 29 -- The French Cabinet failed this morning after almost nine hours of debate to agree on a solution to the crisis in Morocco.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The Delaware River Port Author proposed today construction of a new high-level, seven-lane bridge linking Northeast Philadelphia and New Jersey.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug. 28 -- Mr. Truman charged tonight that President Eisenhower's Administration was "100 per cent" under the domination of big business.

The Bucks County Playhouse at New Hope, Pa., will not reopen tonight with "The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker" as planned. Because of the severe damage caused by the flood waters of the Delaware River, the house has been closed since Aug. 19.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -Herbert Hoover today prescribed more clubs for the nation's "3,000,000 pavement boys" as the surest cure for juvenile delinquency.

Members of the American and Australian Davis Cup teams went through the motions of finishing the challenge round at Forest Hills yesterday. The results emphasized that the squad from Down Under richly deserved its place at the top of the tennis world.
CORNWALL, Pa., Aug. 28 -The sign over the snack bar reads: "We want bread -- and roses, too."
GHENT, Belgium, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Theodor Kocerka of Poland easily won the single sculls title today in the 1955 European rowing championships as John B. Kelly Jr., of Philadelphia finished fourth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George rebuffed today a suggestion that he retire from office.

The American Cyanamid Company has leased the second floor in the new United States Rubber Company Building Addition at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Forty-ninth Street. The lease completes renting of the new $11,000,000 annex on the site of the old Center Theatre. The structure will be completed about Dec. 1.
Three changes of executive personnel at three networks became known over the week-end.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday the start of a study of Government news policies to spotlight areas in which the press and other mass media assertedly have been denied free access to information.
Recent personnel changes among provincial Communist party leaders in the Soviet Union appear to suggest continuing ferment beneath the outward calm of "collective leadership."
Mayor Wagner was told yesterday that the city and state must subsidize private building to provide sufficient housing at rentals middle income families could afford.
Rabbi Louis D. Newman questioned yesterday the "get-rich-quick, get-well-quick" promises held forth by many religionists, evangelists and best-selling authors.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- In the Far East, 100,000,000 to 150,000,00 families are living in slum conditions in rural and urban communities. For them, a report just issued by the United Nations indicates, 1956 is to mark accelerated activity toward solution of their problems.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 28 -- During the last five years investments in Dutch industry have increased by 50 per cent. Investments for this year were estimated by industrial leaders at 1,753,000,000 guilders against a total of realized investments last year of 1,480,000,000.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- City health officials maintained optimism today despite reports of eleven new cases of poliomyelitis. This was four more than yesterday and seven more than Friday.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 28 - Outwardly, business on the Zurich stock exchange last week was comparatively quiet but friendly in tone.

In the next few weeks, with the weather turning brisker and the bare-leg style drawing to its seasonal close, the hosiery manufacturers will be turning on a full-scale drive to sell more women more hosiery.

NEW SUFFOLK, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Doug Sceth, a New York harbor pilot who guides multi-ton ocean liners, switched to a 350-pound sailboat for the weekend and won the Comet Class fleet's Long Island Bowl today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines says "it can be expected that petroleum reserves and productive capacity will be able to meet demands for many years to come."
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has come under attack from a new quarter.
Plans for an apartment house to replace four old buildings in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan's East Side have been announced by builders.

Representatives of Britain, Greece and Turkey are meeting in London this morning to discuss the question of Cyprus. Their agreement to come together is a good thing. The ultimate political disposition of the island should be settled through the most thoughtful discussions and negotiations and not through irresponsible riots and terror.
REGINA, Sask., Aug. 28 (UP) -- Some 2,000 persons turned out to greet nine Soviet farm experts when they arrived by air late today from eastern Canada to begin a tour of the prairies.

As we have had melancholy occasion to remark before, we can hardly be expected to shout "Hurrah" when the Davis Cup goes back to Australia. We hoped that we could keep it here this year. But if we have to lose it, it is certainly no disgrace to do so to such a mag nificent team as Rosewall, Hoad and Hartwig.
Tramp-ship charter rates rose last week, but shipowners still appeared reluctant to do business.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Government today told 50,000 strikers paralyzing public services they must return to work unconditionally before grievances could be discussed.
DENVER, Colo., Aug. 28--The President and Mrs. Eisenhower went to church this morning and then visited the grave of Mrs. Eisenhower's father.
CAIRO, Aug. 28 -- Renewed shooting on the Gaza border that killed four Egyptians today seemed to observers here to threaten the peace prospects raised by United States Secretary of State Dulles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The Yankees had to settle for a draw today. Yet, so startling were the rapid-fire developments in the American League's seething flag race that by the end of the day the Bombers found themselves in undisputed possession of first place.
The Miami Copper Company estimates its consolidated net income for the first six months this year at $2,591,800, compared with $1,619,500 in the similar period of 1954.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 28 (AP) -- All Australia was bleary-eyed but happy today. For the last two mornings most alarm clocks have been pealing at 5 A. M. so the nation's 9,000,000 inhabitants could listen to direct broadcasts of the Davis Cup matches.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- The pressure was building up last week for one of the tightest steel markets since World War II. While there were some reports that mills might be in a better delivery situation by the end of September, indications are that they represented more or less wishful thinking.

Even while the terrible toll that Hurricane Diane exacted of lives and property is still fresh in the public's mind, Washington is being warned that one tiny country, Haiti, is still suffering appalling misery from Hurricane Hazel of last October.
Construction of the final two miles of the Sunrise Highway within the city has been started by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

DOVER, England, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- Bill Pickering, who swam the English Channel Saturday to give grumbling hometown supporters a "run for their money," today learned he had set a new record for the England-to-France course.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Casey Stengel, manager of the Yankees, received a lift today when advised of a report from San Francisco that Billy Martin was about to be released from his Army duties.
ROME -- Early each morning at the Villa Taverna, spacious residence here of Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce, the telephone rings -- not for the Ambassador but for her Italian chef, Rocco Colletta.
Hurricane Edith is expected to pick up extra forward speed this morning on its course in the direction of Bermuda, but most of its fury may be spent against the sea.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The stock markets remain in a highly sensitive and unsettled condition. They opened last week badly and the Financial Times industrial share index dropped to its lowest since the general election last May. Government securities index touched its lowest since compilation of these indexes started in 1926.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Kosei Kamo and Atsushi Miyagi of Japan took the national doubles tennis championship today with a five-set victory over Jerry Moss and Bill Quillian at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The latest flare-up on the Egyptian-Israeli border points up once again the urgency and importance of the Middle East initiative taken by Secretary Dulles last Friday. Great Britain has already announced its support for Mr. Dulles' proposals on aid to Arab refugees and Great Power guarantees for mutually agreed borders between Israel and its Arab neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Lewis L. Strauss denied today that the United States was dragging its feet on the development of controlled energy from the fusion of hydrogen atoms. He said the money and manpower in that field had been increased tenfold in the last two years.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The seventh-place Washington Senators scored eight runs in the seventh inning of the second game today in sweeping a doubleheader from the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 2 and 13 -- 4.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 28 -- Morocco was quiet today but there was electricity in the air.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The armed services have decided that service men's under-shorts are about as comfortable as a hair shirt. Last week, they started to do something about them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The head of the American farmers' delegation that went to the Soviet Union said today he did not believe the Soviet Union had the food reserves to wage war now.

Nothing lasts forever, and that is the trouble with a vacation. Too soon it ends and the long grind of earning a living, making a home or attending school begins anew.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Aug. 28 -- In a corner of the little postoffice here there is a mound of packages wrapped in white paper. Each of them is worth about $28,000. They are gold bricks -- real ones -- awaiting shipment by air to Edmonton for the Canadian mint at Ottawa.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Dr. Persia Campbell, consumer counsel to Governor Harriman, will start a survey of milk consumption in the New York metropolitan area Sept. 12 in conjunction with several state and municipal agencies.
TWO gentlemen from Elgin, Ill., came to town a few weeks back. And with the aid of the 540 watches they brought with them, they have managed to keep up with New York's hectic pace.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Elmer Francis (Trigger) Burke was held today on bonds totaling $200,000 for a New York City murder and a Boston jail break.
Things are on the upswing at Ebbets Field. Yesterday, for the third straight day, Manager Smokey Alston started a young southpaw pitcher and was rewarded with a third straight victory.

The Lone Star Cement Corporation announced yesterday a $35,000,000 expansion program including plans for a $14,000,000 plant near Lake Charles, La. The company said it also would enlarge its plants at Hudson, N. Y., and Dallas and Houston.

ISLAND PARK, L. I., Aug. 29 -- William C. DeKoning Jr., son of a jailed labor leader, came back into the limelight here today when a jurisdictional dispute between two unions slowed construction work on the Long Island Lighting Company's $150,000,000 power station.
Two acrobatic firemen, inching their way along a shaky fishbone shaped ladder nine floors up, rescued a terrified woman from her smoke-filled room in the Madison Hotel,...
A resurvey of flood areas shows the number of families with a serious loss of belongings to be 38 per cent larger than earlier estimates, the Red Cross reported yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor made a whirlwind inspection tour of Camp Drum today. He is believed to be the highest ranking officer to observe summer field training of National Guardsmen and Reservists at Camp Drum.
When Joe Zichella won his first horseshoe-pitching tournament-the New York City Department of Parks championship in 1943 -- his wife, Onaida, gave him a watch. The gift was prophetic.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 29 -- The United Nations Command proposed officially today for the first time that the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission be disbanded.

Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president in charge of production for Twentieth Century-Fox, left New York yesterday for London, where he will confer with Sir Alexander Korda about a threepicture arrangement involving starring vehicles for Vivien Leigh, Sir Laurence Olivier and Alec Guinness.

Shelley Winters, star of the touring summer attraction "Wedding Breakfast," was flown to New York rate Saturday evening to undergo an "emergency operation" at Mount Sinai Hospital. The actress was said to be "resting comfortably" at the hospital yesterday.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Hundreds of grain handlers and railway employes are being laid off at this Lake Superior port because grain elevators are filled and shipping is at a near standstill.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's July earnings statement issued yesterday, reflected unusually heavy non-recurring expenses.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The shape of things to come in Soviet agriculture seems clear. Official statements that followed the recent visits by Russian farm delegations to the United States and Great Britain provide the clues.

PARIS, Tuesday, Aug. 30 -The state of emergency powers exercised by the French Administration in the Algerian Department of Constantine were extended today to the two other departments, Algiers and Oran. The official journal published a decree of Minister of the Interior Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, who had desired such an extension to combat more effectively terrorist activity.

Chris Christensen of Denmark scored a technical knockout over Gene Poirier, Niagara Falls, N. Y., welterweight, in the main bout listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -Two educational leaders denied today that public-school groups were trying to destroy the private and parochial school systems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -Chief Justice Earl Warren today asked, a nation-wide observance of September as "John Marshall Bicentennial Month."
TRENTON, Aug. 29 -- The State Legislature confined its session today primarily to flood relief.

The four-story store and apartment building at 558 Third Avenue and 164 East Thirty-seventh Street has been sold by Edward Schwartz, real estate operator, to Margaret Kennedy. The property, on a plot 23 by 80 feet, is situated on the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 29 -- The Malay community here sought today to block a measure to admit 200,000 Chinese aliens to full citizenship. Chinese leaders have been clamoring for this plan for several weeks.

United States Commissioner Earle N. Bishopp signed a warrant here yesterday for the removal of Elmer F. (Trigger) Burke from Charleston, S. C., near where the desperado was seized by Federal agents Saturday night.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 29 (UP) -- Four baby musk oxen captured in the remote Arctic took off from Churchill, Man., Canada, in a Flying Boxcar today.

YONKERS, Aug. 29 (AP) -Eight 3-year-old trotters were entered today for Thursday's mile and one-sixteenth Yonkers Futurity Trot at Yonkers Raceway, making it the richest event of night harness racing.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The Australian auctions opened yesterday in Sydney and prices for most grades were about 10 per cent below those of the last sales in June. The trade had anticipated a decline, but not so sharp a one.

Dorothy Courtney has sold the eight-family building at 703 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, to Vincent Puccio. L. L. Yearsaley, broker in this transaction, also reported the sale of the fourstory apartment house, with a store, at 306 Fifth Avenue.
LONG ISLAND again has been allotted a waterfowl season separate from the rest fo the state, according to information just released by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)--Nashua drew the No. 1 post position today for his $100,000 winner-take-all match race with Swaps, but trainers of each colt saw little, if any, advantage in the spot.
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced yesterday an increase of 1/4 of 1 point in the interest rate it pays to buyers of the corporation's short-term commercial paper.
WHITING, Ind., Aug. 29 -- Two-thirds of the residents of this city of 10,000 who were evacuated after an explosion and fire early Saturday were permitted to return to their homes today.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation cleared $9,089,000 in the first half of this year after providing $9,444,000 for taxes.
ROME, Aug. 29 -- Ten thousand persons crowded into the Baths of Caracalla last night to hear "Aida."
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 29 -- John J. McNamara today took a big step toward retaining the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup as he won the first race of the series off the Corinthian Yacht Club.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug. 29 -- Harry S. Truman accused the Republican Administration today of subverting the nation's laws in an effort to aid special interests.

PARIS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O., today suggested a mediator role for the United States in the French North African crisis and said military aid should be given neither side.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Furniture manufacturers in the next ten years can double their markets over present levels, Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research for the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency, said today.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- William Lombardy of New York City, the defending champion, scored again today in the second round of the New York State Chess Association's championship tournament.

Despite flood damage to some plants, steel production increased slightly last week. The industry operated at 90.6 per cent of rated capacity, turning out 2,186,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the discontinuance of its six-year program of distributing cyclotron - produced radioisotopes for scientific research. A cyclotron is the socalled "atom-smashing" device.

But now we are told that there is unanimous agreement to form a new and representative Moroccan government through negotiations with nationalist leaders.

Although separated by thousands of miles, a United States Army private in Germany and his wife in New York had a memorable first wedding anniversary yesterday. By means of an amateur radio station, Pvt. and Mrs. William E. Whiting, both 21 years old, were able to understand each other clearly as they exchanged anniversary greetings.

Philadelphia's Democratic candidate for Mayor reported yesterday that Pennsylvania was leaning toward Adlai E. Stevenson as the next Democratic candidate for President.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Most of the industrial leaders lost a few pence today in a quiet trading session. Investors' restraint stemmed from a hint by Prime Minister Eden that further antiinflationary measures might be necessary for Britain's economic health.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Negotiators for the Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., today discussed at least a dozen unresolved side issues that threatened to send 139,000 employes on strike at midnight Wednesday.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Billy Martin's chances of playing in the world series appear slim, even if the Yankees make the grade.
