RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of Hupp Corporation and Perfection Industries, Inc., both Cleveland concerns, voted here today to merge the two companies.

The New York Central Railroad is extending Centronic, an electronically-controlled central reservation system, to its lines west of Buffalo, including the Michigan Central division. The road announced last month that it was installing the system east of Buffalo.

GENEVA, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- The first United Nations congress on the prevention of crime and the treatment of offenders called today for prisons without locks or bars for as many prisoners as possible.
DENVER, Aug. 29 -- President Eisenhower predicted success today for the United Nations disarmament talks if the big powers' delegates negotiated in the spirit of Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Houston Texas Gas and Oil Corporation of Houston, Tex., has asked the Federal Power Commission for authority to build and operate a natural gas pipeline from Louisiana to Florida.
A sleek white cargo ship that usually puts into port laden with ores, sugar, hemp and bounty of the Orient, sailed into Brooklyn this week with the fruits of other artistic labors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Government's employe security-risk system went under attack today in a Senate subcommittee investigation. Investigators applied the word "dilatory" to the handling of risk cases. They commented that Government agency representatives at times had been "so damn diligent."
DENVER, Aug. 29 -- The White House is taking up a political position on Mount Olympus to look down upon former President Harry S. Truman's attacks on the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today route extensions for four airlines to improve service between northeastern and southwestern states. The four are American, Capital, Eastern and Trans World.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., Aug. 29 -- In the swamps and mountains of North Carolina the United States Army has developed a corps of liberation fighters to strike behind the lines of any future enemy.
ROME, Aug. 29 -- The contribution United States investments might make toward solving unemployment in Italy was discussed in a two-hour meeting today.
Four home runs, three in the fourth inning, carried the Chicago Cubs to a 6-3 victory over the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
MONTE CARLO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- France has offered to help Monaco's biggest bank reopen its doors by taking over its $8,500,000 deficit, informed sources said today.
BARTOW, Fla., Aug. 29 (UP) -- A dynamite blast ripped through a section of a struck phosphate plant today and bullets whizzed over the head of a guard at another struck plant.
The Waterfront Commission appeared yesterday to have weathered the worst storm of its turbulent two-year career without having had to change its aims, methods or personnel.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 29, (AP) -- Three cheerful, nattily dressed Russian Army officers came to Fort Benning today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 28 -As violence mounts along the Egyptian-Israeli armistice line and the tranquility of the last three months goes up in gun smoke, Israel is looking to her arms and men. Both are in excellent condition.

A New York City policeman and an alleged accomplice were arrested early today and charged with having attempted to extort $600 from a couple under threat of arresting the woman for prostitution. On a previous occasion the two men were said to have obtained $400 after displaying a police shield.

On the theory that this country has won the battle of production and now must turn its attention to distribution, and specifically selling, a new magazine three years in the planning will make its appearance next week to concentrate on selling and salesmen.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- A $5,500,000 loan has been made to develop electric power facilities in Uruguay, it was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The First National City Bank of New York will put up $200,000 of the loan.

Down in the Cornwall Mountains of Pennsylvania the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., has opened a vacation resort and education center for 18,000 shirt workers in the area. The union's theme for the magnificent estate, which was built seventy-five years ago to meet the requirements of a millionaire, is "Bread and Roses."

Speed is the Number One killer on the nation's highways, and the best way to discourage speeding is to crack down on speeders. Evidently the State of New Jersey intends to do just this. Its Attorney General has ordered state police to charge speed-law violators with reckless driving, which carries heavier penalties than does a speeding charge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -Aldo L. Icardi, thus far outside the jurisdiction of any court in the World War II murder of Maj. William V. Holohan in Italy, was indicted today for perjury.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 -- The United Jewish Appeal is starting at once an emergency campaign to finance the migration of Moroccan Jews to Israel, the executive vice chairman of the Zionist fund-raising organization said here today.
Three youths were arrested yesterday in Queens after the police had received reports that pistol shots had been heard in the yard of one of them.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Following are excerpts from statements made today in the Disarmament Subcommittee by representatives of France, the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and Canada:
WEYBURN, Sask., Aug. 29--The nine-man Russian agricultural delegation today studied the latest farming techniques in this rich wheat-growing area.

Mayor Wagner presented the United Jewish Appeal's Freedom Award yesterday to Lucius D. Clay for his "distinguished humanitarian service to victims of Nazi tyranny" from 1947 to 1949 as commanding general of United States occupation forces in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Bank at St. Louis will raise its discount rate to 2 1/4 per cent tomorrow, the highest level since 1934, it was announced today. The rate has been 2 per cent.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- A starstudded field of twenty-nine net stars from nine countries began competition today in the Westchester Country Club's invitation singles tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had liberalized its rules on advertising new security issues.
Thoroughbred racing returned to Long Island yesterday, and a crowd of 20,718 fans saw the Apheim Stable interests become $19,600 richer.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 29 -- If it's a shot in the arm the Yankees need to give them that extra lift down the home stretch of this sizzling American League pennant race, it seems they are about to get it.

CAIRO, Aug. 29 -- Major Salah Salem, one of Egypt's top leaders, was reported today to have gone on vacation -- an action interpreted by political observers as meaning there was a division of opinion in the Government.
Forest Hills had that afterthe-battle look yesterday following the 5-0 defeat of the United States by the Australian Davis Cup team.
The widening range of foreign trade has just been well illustrated in two air-freight shipments at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, won the promise of the Greek and Turkish Foreign Ministers today to help maintain secrecy about negotiations over Cyprus and other political-defense questions in the eastern Mediterranean.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29 -President Juan D. Peron's fiveman supercabinet underwent another change today when the resignation of Dr. Raul Mende, Secretary for Technical Affairs, was accepted.

After some strength in the early dealings, the stock market yesterday developed easiness and final prices were pretty well mixed. The steels, chemicals and some selected issues ended with some small gains, but other groups were generally on the downside.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa was accused yesterday by Parks Commissioner Robert Moses of "adding to his park program a general policy to sell off city parks to balance the budget."

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (AP) -Representative Patrick J. Hillings declared today the United States Embassy in Moscow "is like a pig pen" and demanded that Congress provide diplomats here with facilities worthy of "the world's greatest power."

The ground-floor store at Lexington Avenue and Fortyfirst Street, in the fifty-sixstory Chanin Building, has been leased by Steiner, Rouse Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, for a branch brokerage office.
Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was on both the giving and receiving end of bad news yesterday. The union made known that it was ready to ask nine private...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Pierce J. Gerety said today that the United States was admitting "a rather steady flow" of immigrants under the refugee relief program.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Adios, sire of harness race champions, was sold today for $500,000. The event was hailed as being of "tremendous significance" to the standardbred horse industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) -- The State Department said today Israel and the Arab nations had indicated they were giving serious consideration to Secretary Dulles' Middle East peace proposal.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -The recent flood caused more than $1,000,000 damage to the Delaware River's twenty-fivefoot-deep channel between Allegheny Avenue in Northeast Philadelphia and Trenton.
Joseph Klein Co. denied yesterday a Department of Agriculture charge that it had rigged futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 29 -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla opened today an international meeting on Latin-American economic problems with a plea for unity and collaboration as the alternative to disaster.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 29 (Reuters) -- American Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, warned today that in the coming months the West should view "with skepticism" Soviet proposals on disarmament.
THE tourist in Italy who must eat all his meals in restaurants is likely to get indigestion and the mistaken idea that Italians gorge themselves at every meal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The United States called on the United Nations today to support President Eisenhower's proposals to control international disarmament and atomic weapons through exchange of military "blueprints" and through aerial inspection.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Authorities said tonight Elmer (Trigger) Burke had given them "some answers to a five-year scourge of crime in Boston starting with Brinks."
LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation does not intend to allow the new Independent Television Authority to outbid it for attractions.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 -- Egyptian and Israeli jet fighters met over the Gaza frontier area this morning. This was believed to be the first such encounter since the signing of the armistice in 1948.

When Harry S. Truman was President of the United States he was responsible for some bold and brave decisions, for which this newspaper -- in company with a large proportion of the rest of the American press -- gave him full credit. Even then, when Mr. Truman was big, he could be very big; but, alas, when he was small, he could be very small.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- The French Government took a belated step today to free imports from quota restrictions.

Newsprint control established by the Colombian Government has resulted in the closing of another Bogota newspaper and threatens the rest of the Opposition press with economic strangulation, the Inter American Press Association reported yesterday.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 29 -- The 60,000-ton supercarrier Forrestal moved into the James River today and headed for sea on her maiden voyage. Aided by a half-dozen tugs and with 2,300 persons aboard, the Forrestal began a five-day trial run.
District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens contended yesterday that he had been offered a judgeship to step aside as a candidate for renomination.

The New York regional Red Cross blood program received 411 pints of blood Friday. Included were 201 pints donated by members of Local 812 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., at the Pepsi-Cola Company, 46-02 Fifth Street, Long Island City, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -A preliminary arrangement under which the Government would sell power from its Clark Hill Dam to rural electric cooperatives in Georgia was disclosed today by the Interior Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu of Japan assured Secretary of State Dulles today that Japan was determined to stay in the defensive system of the Western world. This was the central theme of the Foreign Minister's talk with Mr. Dulles this afternoon and was the burden of his message to the American people.
MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- Soviet pupils returning to school this fall will get far more practical training than they have ever had before.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 29 -Clergymen representing state and municipal organizations of Protestant churches today appeared at a hearing of the New Jersey State Racing Commission in the Hudson County Court House here to protest the issuance of a license for a trotting track in Secaucus, applied for by the Metropolitan Racing Association.

New York thoroughbred racing officials placed an embargo on horses from New England yesterday because of an outbreak of equine sleeping sickness in that sector. Soon after the action was taken, George P. Monaghan, New York State harness racing commissioner, took the same steps with standardbred horses.

MELBOURNE, Aug. 29 -Prices at the opening sales of the new wool season in Sydney today ranged from 5 per cent below rates at the closing series of last June for fine quality wools, to 7 1/2 per cent less for crossbreds and 10 per cent less for broad quality fleeces.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs hit four home runs, two by Wally Post, and one each by Smoky Burgess and Hobie Landrith, to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 3, tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- The life story of Mickey Walker, who formerly held the middleweight and light heavyweight world championships, will be produced independently as a motion picture by Harriet Parsons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The 119th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron of the New Jersey National Guard has again won the Spaatz Trophy as the outstanding tactical flying squadron of the Air Guard, the Air Force announced today.
ALBANY, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Governor Harriman, in proclaiming next Monday Labor Day, called on business, labor and Government today to join in creative planning for an expanded economy.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that Communist China must alter its ways before the United States would consider approval of its admission to the United Nations.

Since the city's fiscal year has been under way only two months Mayor Wagner may be premature in expressing a belief that the 1956-57 fiscal year, starting next July 1, can be managed without tax increases. The statement is a novel one for this season.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 29 -- The resignation of Gilbert Grandval, Resident General in French Morocco, is not. being announced here until his .successor is officially appointed. The French authorities are eager to avoid a hiatus that might be prejudicial to maintenance of public order.
ATHENS, Aug. 29 (UP) -- Police and troops arrived at the Cretan village of Vorizia today to end a family vendetta in which seven persons have been killed and ten others seriously wounded.
Pontiac has purchased sponsorship of six "See It Now" television broadcasts during the 1955-56 season.

Willard F. Place, long a top executive of the New York Central Railroad, has taken a leave of absence to become executive vice president of the Excelsior Savings Bank. Mr. Place, vice president in charge of finance for the railroad, has been a trustee of the bank since 1934.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Rita Hayworth said today she had separated from Dick Haymes, who later retorted, "I don't believe it."
Safie Brothers, Inc., New York textile concern, yesterday acquired control of the Reliance Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of men's and boys' wear.

These are days of numerous tensions among nations. But on the issue of Goa, Indo-Portuguese tension has reached the point of a serious international crisis. It is a pity that while discussing the Goa issue many American editorials have been violently anti-Indian, which has meant adding fuel to existing IndoAmerican suspicion, leading to illwill.
A refinancing intended to place all the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's callable mortgage debt under a single-system mortgage is now in effect.

Man's relentless war against the insects has taken a new turn during this closing vacation period, when the insects follow the rains. The latest move in this neverending conflict has been the development of a new yellow-coated electric bulb called "Bug Lites," used for porch and other outdoor lighting.

THE ancient city of Phrax lay on the shore between the beaches and the hills. When the ships from the mother city brought the first colonists there was nothing there save yellow sand and rich earth and the smoke rising from the villages of the hill-men in the interior. Hipponax, the Founder, was a brave man and a devout one, skilled in the ways of gods and the proper rites and sacrifices.

A 6-year-old boy was saved from drowning in Buttermilk Channel of the Red Hook section of Brooklyn yesterday. The two men who rescued him were rewarded by their employer with the rest of the day off and a $25 bonus each.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 -- Red Skelton will combine forces with Jackie Gleason and Art Carney Oct. 4 on the second telecast of "The New Red Skelton Show."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- About ten proposals a week for cultural and technical exchanges with the Soviet Union are reaching the State Department, officials report.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, said here today that a lack of adequate roads was casting a blight on the national economic structure.
Wholesale buyers of fancy foods and confections are saving considerable shoe leather this week.
Musicians employed in Broadway musical and dramatic presentations have won a 4 per cent wage increase.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A gunman stood off a siege by 200 policemen for four hours last night. Then he was shot to death in flight from a burning home that was filled with tear gas. The siege started when two neighbors reported that Charles Luther Rollins, 44 years old, an unemployed sweeper, had threatened them.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Governor Harriman asserted tonight that the Eisenhower Administration appeared to be blind to farm problems. He said it was dominated by "big corporations and special interests."

If there is anything better than a cool day following a certain number of hot ones -- well, name it. Winning an election for the Presidency is said to set up a pretty fair mood, as does receiving the cashier's check for the first million.

The stock market staged an almost complete stand-off yesterday as volume continued to ebb. While a few pivotal issues helped lift the average a fraction, just about as many issues fell back as moved ahead.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., will seek a guaranteed annual wage from the basic steel industry next year, the union's president, David J. McDonald, said today.

Repeal of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act was advocated by Mayor Wagner last night. Addressing the Columbus Citizens Committee in the Commodore Hotel, he said he had been upset while on his recent foreign visit at the numbers of persons desiring to migrate to this country but barred by the present law. The act, he said, should be repealed "to let those people come over here."
REGINA, Sask., Aug. 30 -- Their patience, although not their energy, beginning to show signs of strain, nine Russian farm officials continued today to study Canadian wheat farming.

SEABRIGHT, N. J., Aug. 30 -- The Australian Davis Cup team did a repeat performance, defeating the American squad, 7 -- 1, in the annual international match at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Joseph L. Mankiewicz, writer, director and producer of the motion picture "The Barefoot Contessa," was named defendant in a $50,000 plagiarism suit filed today in Superior Court in Santa Monica.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., Aug. 30 -- When the troopers of the Army's Special Forces, Airborne, go anywhere, they usually parachute in and walk out.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Governor Harriman's Democratic Administration moved today to develop new job opportunities for men and women over 45. It announced that it would add eighteen trained interviewers to state employment offices in New York and five other cities.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- It was announced here that the British and Egyptian Governments had agreed on a revision of the sterling releases agreement of 1951. British-Egyptian relations were seriously strained that year by Egypt's abrogation of the 1936 treaty giving British base rights in the Suez.
Pan American World Airways, the world's largest international airline, was threatened yesterday by a strike of 6,000 maintenance workers.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Toni Monetti, the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association representative from Manhasset Bay, and Mrs. William Saltonstall of the Beverly Y. C., Buzzards Bay, Marion, Mass., representing the Southern Massachusetts Y. R. A., tied at 18 1/4 points after the first three races for the twenty-seventh women's national sailing championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The usually solemn Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, was in a mood of relaxed good humor at his news conference today.
JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Aug. 31 -- The United Nations truce commission announced early today that Egypt had agreed to a cease-fire on the Israeli-Egyptian front near Gaza.
Reflecting an 11.4 per cent sales gain of the Marathon Corporation, net earnings in the nine months ended July 31 increased to $6,672,460 from $5,327,795 earned in the similar period a year earlier.

Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball, yesterday called a meeting for next Tuesday in his offices here to make plans for the 1955 world series. All clubs in both major leagues that retain reasonable pennant hopes will be asked to send representatives.
GENEVA, Aug. 30 -- The United States has decided to slow down the rhythm of its talks with Communist China about returning Americans held on the Chinese mainland.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- The Soviet Government will permit "tens of thousands" of Soviet citizens to visit the United States if satisfactory financial arrangements can be made.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- J. Sinclair Armstrong, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today proposed a new S. E. C. regulation to tighten supervision of stock brokers and dealers.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Shirley Fry of St. Petersburg, Fla., who quit tennis a year ago, upset Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, today to win the singles final of the twenty-eighth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tournament.

REHOVOT, Israel, Wednesday, Aug. 31 -- A wave of terror has broken over central Israel since Monday evening. Assassins, hunting their victims from the thicket-like cover of orange groves, began a series of murders that had reached seven by yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles commented today on three aspects of the Far Eastern situation -- United States negotiations with the Chinese Communists at Geneva, the question of Vietnamese elections and the status of the Korean Armistice Commission.

THE grand ballroom of the Sheraton-Astor Hotel looked like a giant grocery store earlier this week. Good things to eat -- some already in the shops, others to be available in a few weeks -- were being shown to the trade at the first Fancy Food and Confection Show.
A set of moral rights that all men possess in common was placed before a group of scholars yesterday as they grappled with fundamentals in quest of a definition of human equality.

Johnny Antonelli and Don Liddle, southpaws, returned the Giants to the winning column last night at the Polo Grounds. The New Yorkers whipped the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -- 0 and 9 -- 7, in a twilight-night program.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Continuing fears of a further credit squeeze depressed the stock market today. Prices again fell, especially Government stocks. Selling of gilt-edged issues increased slightly, but undated and long-term issues fell as much as 17s 6d ($2.45).

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Federal attorneys came here today from Buffalo and immediately conferred with two key witnesses in the investigation of the Holohan slaying. The former Italian partisans had been flown to the United States for the inquiry.
WHITING, Ind., Aug. 30 -- This city was returning to normal today in the wake of its huge explosion and fire.

REALIZATION of the important part parents play in helping a hospitalized child get well is sparking a nation-wide trend toward the liberalization of hospital visiting privileges for mothers and fathers. The "visiting manners" of those who have frequent opportunities to be with their ailing young will play an important part in shaping the decisions of other hospitals on this score.

Today's new film is "The Man From Laramie," a Columbia Western drama in CinemaScope and color, starring James Stewart, at the Capitol. William Goetz produced and Anthony Mann directed, from a screen play by Philip Yordan and Frank Burt and a story by Thomas T. Flynn. Arthur Kennedy, Donald Crisp, Cathy O'Donnell, Alex Nicol and Aline MacMahon head the supporting cast.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 30 -- Indonesia will take a new and amicable approach when she presses her claim to Netherlands New Guinea at the fall session of the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the United Nations disarmament talks would provide the first test of the genuineness of the "Geneva spirit" of better East-West relations.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- Leonid I. Lubennikov has replaced Alexander N. Yegorov as First Secretary of the Communist party of the Karelo-Finnish Republic.

Your editorial "City vs. Itself on Buses" calls for comment. Because city-owned transportation is finding rough going financially you criticize the Board of Estimate for granting a franchise to a privately owned bus line, in this case carrying students to and from school.
Interest rates in the short-term money market stiffened again yesterday. Dealers marked up yields on both bankers' acceptances and short-dated commercial paper by 1/8 of 1 percentage point.

New York University has notified tenants in the Washington Square Southeast Redevelopment Project area that it intends to demolish buildings there and use their sites "for educational purposes." The area is bounded by Washington Square South and West Fourth Street, Mercer Street, West Third Street and Broadway.

CONCORD, N. H., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee chairman reported today that newly received papers of the late Harry Dexter White threw "light on the conduct" of an unnamed individual to be investigated. He said they would aid in a broad inquiry into influences exerted on United States policies in China and Europe.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- More than 20,000 persons marched through the Back Bay section for four hours this afternoon in the major parade of the Veterans of Foreign Wars' fifty-sixth national encampment.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., Aug. 30 -- Real farmers, gentleman farmers and their city cousins from the north Jersey area turned out today for the first day of the Flemington Agricultural Fair.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The contingent of French conscripts who would have finished their military service Nov. 1 will be kept on active duty, the French Government announced today. One hundred thousand men will be affected, of whom 77,000 are in the Army.

Net income of the Carrier Corporation, air conditioning manufacturer, for the nine months ended July 31 amounted to $6,955,229, or $3.97 a share on the 1,692,209 common shares outstanding, the company reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company today increased its prices 25 to 40 cents a ton, effective Thurday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- The first overseas sales of television films by Screen Gems has been made, according to John H. Mitchell, vice president in charge of sales for the Columbia Pictures telefilm producing subsidiary.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Royal Air Force is equipping its fighter pilots with tiny, portable radar transmitters. These would signal the fliers' position to rescue craft when they have crash-landed in the sea or bailed out over water.

The Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday recalled sixteen players optioned to various minor league affiliates. Only two, Charley Templeton, a right-handed pitcher, and Walt Moryn, an outfielder, will report this season. Now with St. Paul, they will join the Brooks after the close of the American Association season.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 -- One seven-year legal battle growing out of Hollywood's "unfriendly ten" episode was disclosed tonight to have been settled. A second headed for another round.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 30 -- Members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea said tonight that about forty of their colleagues were being "held as individual hostages for their corporations" because of a taxation dispute.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products declined 2 per cent between mid-July and mid-August.

The Women's Sportswear Show has leased space in the New York Trade Show Building, 500 Eighth Avenue, for its semi-annual display. The building was formerly occupied by Ludwig-Baumann. It is situated on the east side of the avenue, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets.

The International Teamsters Union and several of its constituent organizations in Oregon -- including one that owns and operates a commercial office building -- were charged last winter by the Portland local of the Office Employes Union with obstructing its efforts to organize the Teamsters' clerical help.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 -- Yugoslavia has officially advised the United States that there is "no truth" to the report that she is contemplating a Soviet offer to license the manufacture here of Soviet MIG aircraft parts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- At times today Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' news conference sounded more like a script for "Dragnet" than a solemn discussion of foreign affairs.

cision to increase the bicycle tariff 50 per cent." Of course it is not easy -- nor is it easy to reconcile his campaign assurances of full development of T. V. A. with his stigmatizing of T. V. A., a few months later, as "creeping socialism."

LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Japan cold shouldered today a renewed Soviet demand for a peace treaty that would close the Sea of Japan to United States and other Western warships, Japanese sources said tonight.

IN the absence of an encyclopedic knowledge of furniture and values, the neophyte antique shopper might do well to begin her hobby in the antique department of such well-known stores as Macy's, W. and J. Sloane, B. Altman and Lord Taylor. There is no unpleasant haggling about prices. Payments need not be immediate or in cash, and young homemakers may take advantage of time payments.

Guilt by kinship is the kind of thing Americans learned to expect out of Communist Russia and Nazi Germany. Nothing could seem more remote from the American tradition that every man is judged by what he is himself, not what his ancestors, relatives or descendants may be.
Three mobile units of the Red Cross regional blood program will operate tomorrow. One will be at the Biltmore Hotel for employes of concerns at 380 Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- "I arrived late," said Eddie Arcaro after flying here from New York. Then a thought suddenly hit him. He grinned. "I trust I won't have to repeat that statement while I'm in Chicago," he added hastily. Willie Shoemaker smiled shyly but said nothing. He rarely talks. But the sparkle in his eyes almost indicated that his mind was forming the words, "Me, too."
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Operators of the Newburgh-Beacon ferry indicated today they might be willing to delay its Sept. 30 abandonment to give the state a chance to take it over.
CAIRO, Aug. 30 -- The Egyptian Ministry of War announced today that one of its soldiers had been killed and four wounded during two clashes with Israelis along the Gaza strip demarcation line.

Four major tenants have signed leases for space in the proposed Latham Corners Shopping Center, a $6,000,000 retail project which will rise on Route 9 about midway between Albany, Schenectady and Troy, N. Y.
The flow of material and monetary gifts for flood victims continued unabated yesterday.

Mayor Wagner received yesterday a small landscape painting by a 12-year-old French boy and an eight-by-eight foot hooked rug made by children in Belgium. They were presented in ceremonies in City Hall as gifts of gratitude from the needy children of Europe to New Yorkers for funds contributed to the Foster Parents' Plan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Charles Chaplin, the film star now living in Switzerland, is resisting a United States tax bill of $516,167.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 30 -- Brooklyn Dodger baseball fans who want to watch their team play in Jersey City's Roosevelt Stadium next season learned today it will be a case of "all or nothing."
TRENTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The management of the Thermoid Company today won a proxy battle by a 6-1 margin.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Valerian A. Zorin, acting Soviet Foreign Minister, told a United States member of Congress today that the Soviet Union might release "some information" on the strength of its armed forces.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox made four errors tonight to set up five unearned runs as the Chicago White Sox gained a 7-5 triumph before 41,166 fans.
The first public report of the Siegler Corporation yesterday showed net income for the fiscal year ended June 30 at $774,571, equal to $1.53 a common share. Sales totaled $10,471,144.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 30 -- A campaign to put Senator Estes Kefauver in the White House was started today by a group of California Democrats, with the Senator's tacit consent.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- A $10,000,000 "Powerama" with 253 exhibits capable of producing $15,000,000 worth of power will open here tomorrow.

Stockholders of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company, New York, at a special meeting yesterday approved a proposed four-for-one split and an increase in the authorized common stock from 500,000 shares of no par to 2,000,000 shares of $1 par. Effective date of the split is next Tuesday.

One detail in the statements that opened the otherwise closed sessions of the United Nations Subcommittee on Disarmament on Tuesday may have been overlooked by many persons. This detail was, as our own representative, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., remarked, that this was the fifty-first session of the subcommittee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- One of the year's most provocative sports questions will be answered late tomorrow afternoon at Washington Park, a race track located about twenty-five miles from the center of Chicago. The question: Can Swaps beat Nashua again ?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Senate Finance Committee intends to act early next year on a bill for taxing the 1955 income of life insurance companies.
ROME, Aug. 30 -- The statue of a nude young woman in Rome's Capitol Museum represents not Venus but Cleopatra, who posed for it more than 2,000 years ago, a scholar suggested today.

The mere thought of reaching the age of ninety-seven seems appalling to most of us. Very few people ever attain such an age. Even fewer retain their full mental vigor or do more than glory in their memories of the past. Today we honor Charles C. Burlingham, who is affectionately known to countless friends of many generations as C. C. B.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The first full-scale hydrogen bomb explosion in the Pacific in late, 1952 produced two new chemical elements, atomic scientists disclosed today.

The naming of Gustave L. Levy as head of the 1955-56 maintenance campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York has been announced. The drive, the goal of which has not been announced, will open on Sept. 29 and continue through January.
Many of the New England textile mills hit by floods a week ago last Friday are resuming shipments this week. Others will require from three to four weeks to repair damage and begin deliveries.

FORT SMITH, Northwest Territories, Aug. 28 -- The men who are planning Canada's future and the men who govern the country's last frontier in the Northwest Territories have met here to discuss common problems.

One industry seems to have only two kinds of business -- very good and very bad. That's railroad equipment. Nowadays, with freight traffic roaring on the "high iron" (main lines), the railroads are deluging their own shops and the contract builders with orders for the cars and engines to keep it rolling.
Directors of Safeway Stores, Inc., have recommended the election of Robert A. Magowan to the board to be designated as chairman and of Milton L. Selby as president.
The International Longshoremen's Association has asked employers to renegotiate part of their existing contract dealing with hiring procedures.
Members of the Australian and United States Davis Cup teams and representatives of fourteen other nations were drawn yesterday for play in the combined national tennis championships.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 30 -- Billy Martin, fresh out of the Army, rejoined the Yankees today. But he had to watch tonight's encounter with the Athletics from the sidelines and what he saw scarcely gave him any great pleasure.
Both the state and city health authorities reported yesterday that the Salk vaccine had proved itself of value in preventing paralytic poliomyelitis in children.
To your fairly appraising editorial of Aug. 25 on the visit of Soviet farmers to Iowa and other centers of farm-lore may I add a brief note?

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The seeded contingent, reduced by three on opening day, was cut to three survivors as the Westchester Country Club invitation singles tennis tournament moved through the second round today. There were two casualties this afternoon.
The New York Investors Group, Robert J. Morman, president, disposed of two Third Avenue corners to an investor yesterday.

Don Newcombe finally notched his nineteenth victory last night. Brooklyn's big right-hander retired at the end of six innings so as not to aggravate a slightly strained back. But Don was in action long enough to get credit for an 8-6 Dodger triumph over the Braves in a slugging match at Ebbets Field.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 30 -- Excellent conditions existed today for the second race of the thirty-first annual competition for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 30 (UP) -- Elmer (Trigger) Burke probably will face a murder charge in New York State before he is tried for breaking out of a Massachusetts jail last year, authorities said today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Gen. Rafael Calderon Reyes, head of the new National Publications Corporation, has promised there will be no discrimination in the allotment of preferential licenses for newsprint imports, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The total strength of the armed forces increased by almost 5,000 last month, reversing a trend downward in the last two years.

Private investment abroad by Americans in 1954, according to a study just published in the Survey of Current Business of the Department of Commerce, totaled $2.8 billions, bringing the sum of all such investments at the end of that year to $26.5 billions.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- Tim Holland of Rockville led the metropolitan district qualifiers for the United States amateur golf championship today.
A new process for welding stainless steel and high-alloy tubing was announced yesterday by the Trent Tube Company, East Troy, Wis., subsidiary of the Crucible Steel Company of America.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 30 -- Completion dates for thousands of new homes on Long Island were set back indefinitely today when a union controlled by William C. DeKoning Jr. withdrew its men from installing gas mains at seventeen housing developments in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation, one of the nation's largest hotel chains, achieved in the first six months this year the highest gross revenues and earnings in its history for such a period.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Traffic deaths in the nation last month were the highest for any July since 1937, the National Safety Council reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, led with his diplomatic ace in negotiations with Greece and Turkey today. He said Britain's commitments to defend those two countries, as well as others in the Middle East, demanded continuing British sovereignty over Cyprus.

Directors of B. S. F. Company have voted to merge the present Pennsylvania corporation with a newly-formed Delaware corporation of the same name with an authorized capital of 500,000 common shares of $1 par value, Maurice Goodman, president of both corporations, announced yesterday.

The Maritime Administration gave its final approval yesterday to an application by the United Oceanic Company of New York for Federal ship mortgage insurance to cover the construction of eight tankers for charter to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.
The city's Willard Parker Hospital at Fifteenth Street and the East River will be closed about Dec. 1.
CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- John T. Westbrock of Brooklyn defeated William Lombardy of Manhattan, titleholder, in the third round of the New York State Chess Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the State Department would ask Congress for more funds to improve the accommodations for United States diplomats abroad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- William Simon, counsel for the Empire State Petroleum Association, told Senate investigators today that the Robinson-Patman Act tended "to keep all prices high."
Victor Clemente, sewer contractor, was sentenced yesterday to serve eight and a half to seventeen years in prison for building a Queens sewer so faulty the city had to tear it up.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Following is a State Department transcript of two sections of the record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:

Wool prices continued to decline yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was influenced by reports of slightly easier prices at the Australian auctions. Liquidation and hedge selling offset scale-down trade and speculator buying.

When engineers differ the public has a dilemma on its hands. This has now happened with the long-discussed proposal to install a conveyor-belt system of passenger transportation to replace that monstrous imposition on the riding public, that infamous Grand Central-Times Square subway shuttle. Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, acting on the advice of his bureau's engineers, says the conveyor belt plan won't do.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Aldo L. Icardi appeared voluntarily this morning in Federal District Court here. The slight, 34-year-old former Army lieutenant pleaded not guilty to charges of perjury in connection with the 1944 murder of Maj. William V. Holohan.

The Department of Hospitals acquired yesterday a new deputy commissioner in charge of medical activities. He is Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, senior general medical superintendent of the department. Dr. Jacobs will be on leave of absence from his Civil Service post.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating the Government's employe security-risk program was accused by a witness today of "shadow-boxing."

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Mr. Hillings' talk with the acting Soviet Foreign Minister also touched on the shooting down of United States planes near Soviet borders. The Congressman was told "it is doubtful if you need worry about such incidents in the future."

Tom Courtney, one of America's top middle-distance runners, met Franz Stampfl,a a Hungarian track coach, for the first time this summer. Courtney was competing in an English meet during an etxended European tour.

The Lamson Sessions Company, Cleveland manufacturer of bolts and nuts, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of 62,500 shares of $50 par value convertible preferred stock, of which 60,000 shares would be marketed publicly through McDonald Co. The remaining shares would be offered in exchange for outstanding preferred stock of the company.
Two armed men kidnapped the driver of an armored collection car for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority yesterday but were foiled in their attempt to make off with the proceeds.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $11,000,000 will be offered to investors today, as follows:

I wonder if the language of your editorial entitled "A Code of Behavior" is not calculated to do more harm than good in its attempt to apply the standards set for prisoners of war to our civilian citizens. Reference is made particularly to your discussion of the ethics and good morals of not "ratting," as you put it, on one's fellows.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Weather Bureau will install weather equipment on ships in the Gulf of Mexico to help track storms and hurricanes.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Preparations for the meeting in Geneva of the Big Four foreign ministers on Oct. 27 were discussed here today between French Foreign Ministry officials and Livingston T. Merchant, United States Assistant Secretary of State.

William F. Bishop has been named manager of national account sales and Robert C. Hughes has been appointed manager of sales training in the air-conditioning and refrigeration division of Worthington Corporation, Harrison, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A consultant on juvenile delinquency called today for wider knowledge and understanding of the social sciences, from the White House down.

MELBOURNE, Aug. 30 -- Prices at the second day's sales of the new wool selling season in Sydney today, at which 14,835 bales from western New South Wales were sold, were no higher than on the opening day.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Prime Minister Eden will swing by wire from a British cruiser to an aircraft carrier during Home Fleet maneuvers next month. Normally such transfers are made at full speed over "blue" water.

Four major roasters raised the wholesale price of coffee 3 cents a pound yesterday. The increases, effective this week, probably will be passed to the consumer, but the exact time of the rise will depend on the inventories of lower-price coffee in the hands of grocers.
A tentative plan has been agreed on for consolidating two large supermarket chains, the Winn Lovett Grocery Company and the Dixie-Home Stores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas recommended today the appointment of six Democratic Senators to special commissions and subcommittees created at the last session of Congress.

The concept of encouraging an employe's interest in his company by making him a stockholder, and thereby cutting down expensive turnover of personnel is steadily gaining ground in the advertising agency field.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 30 -- West Germany was reported today to have stated it would require at least five years to recruit, equip and train the first 500,000 men for its new armed forces. The original estimate was three years.

PARIS, Aug. 30 -- The discussions between French officials and Moroccan nationals are expected to continue here in an effort to form a representative Moroccan government by Sept. 12. This is the deadline the French Cabinet has set for resolving the Moroccan crisis.

Sometime Thing, a 3-year-old filly owned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, registered an expected victory in the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. The daughter of Discovery had little trouble taking the Nostrand Purse, a six-furlong sprint in which she opposed six other fillies her own age.
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 -- There was no information in Moscow tonight on the statement by Secretary Dulles that, according to reliable reports, Moscow had offered arms to some Middle East countries.

SOME of the harried executives from Steamship Row and the financial district of lower Manhattan have found a pleasant diversion from worries about cargoes and bond issues on Tuesday afternoons during the summer.
WORK ON REMOVAL of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad is coming along briskly, with gangs of huskies burning and lifting at both ends.

Joshua H. Justman, Director of Press Relations of the Delegation of Israel, has once again repeated the same old propaganda cry that it is Israel who seeks peace in the Middle East. In his attempt to put the blame on Egypt he presented quotations out of context, attributed to high Egyptian officials, failing, however, to substantiate his allegations.
Policemen can promote themselves by their actions, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday as he raised three patrolmen to the rank of detective for their "outstanding police work."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Labor Department estimated today that 79,640,000 workers were now enrolled in the Communist World Federation of Trade Unions. More than 90 per cent of the members, it said, are in Communist countries.

CAIRO, Aug. 30 -- Maj. Salah Salem has resigned as Minister of National Guidance and Minister of State for Sudanese affairs. His handling of Sudanese affairs is understood to have caused his departure.

THAT group of shooters whose sole object is to make one tiny hole in a target with ten consecutive shots will gather at Johnstown, N. Y., tomorrow for the opening of the three-day national bench rest championship matches.
Military brass in Central Park's Mall trumpeted a formal salute last night to leading generals and admirals, but the impromptu dancing of a little girl from Brooklyn stole some of the applause.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board voted today, 3 to 2, to prohibit an employer from insisting that a union win prior approval from both union and non-union employes before calling a strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu of Japan outlined to United States Government leaders today a plan to rearm his country and make the United States and Japan military partners.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Representative Alvin M. Bentley declared here today it would be tragic if the Democrats were returned to power in the 1956 election. Nevertheless, he criticized some phases of the Eisenhower Administration.
Station WABC-TV canceled its plan yesterday to resume "Entertainment," a daytime variety show featuring Tom Poston, Marion Colby, Bob Carroll and Ray McKinley and his orchestra.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Some form of Government-backed flood insurance, is essential, Norman P. Mason, Federal Housing Administration Commissioner, declared today.
Joyful and tearful family reunions marked the arrival yesterday of the Navy transport Gen. W. C. Langfitt with 1,210 refugees as passengers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Deferred deliveries of wheat were strong today, as some longs apparently shifted their lines to more distant positions.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The summer-autumn meeting of the New York State Society of Newspaper Editors ended today in the Queensbury Hotel with the election of officers, the adoption of resolutions and two panel discussions of operational matters.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FT. MEADE, Md., Aug. 30 (UP) -- An Army court rejected a plea today that collaboration charges against Maj. Ronald E. Alley were unrealistic because it was "common, usual and customary" for captured American officers to give Communists military information.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 30 -- The United States offered today to incorporate in President Eisenhower's disarmament plan the Soviet Union's proposal to post inspectors at key points within both countries.

Denver marketed yesterday $5,400,000 of water bonds due serially from 1963 to 1972 to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company at an interest cost of 2.187 per cent. The bankers paid a price of 100.058 for obligations bearing interest of 5 per cent and 2 per cent.

Door-to-door selling now, moves about $3,500,000,000 worth of merchandise into American homes each year. Its practitioners believe they have come a long way from the days of the itinerant peddler to the era of multi-million-dollar distributing companies which blanket the nation with doorbell ringers.
PARIS, Aug. 30 -- Military circles of the North Atlantic alliance are concerned over the prospect of a premature or one-sided relaxation of the Allied defense effort.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 30 -- Dr. Carlos Villaveces, Colombia's Finance Minister, said today effective economic development of Latin countries was impossible without stabilization of prices for their products.
The Quartermaster Inspection Service Command is being reorganized, it was announced yesterday in Philadelphia by Col. R. A. Howard Jr., Quartermaster Corps commanding officer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- A new Russian tour of the United States, with State Department approval, was in prospect today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles indicated today that the Soviet Union might be intervening in the Israeli-Arab conflict by supplying arms to Arab states.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Bob Lemon needed the help of Don Mossi to get the last out of the game tonight but scored his fifteenth victory of the season as the Cleveland Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7 -- 4.
DOVER PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A small private plane dived into a heavily wooded hill south of here and burst into flames today, killing all five occupants, including two children.

DEROIT, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Negotiators of the United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., appeared hopeful today that they could reach a settlement with the Chrysler Corporation, in time to avert a strike by 139,000 employes at midnight tomorrow.

NEWBY'S "The Picnic at Sakkara"* is the third novel I have read this year about the bewildering problems of Westerners confronted with the new nationalism of Near Eastern countries and the unpredictable ways of Moslem patriots. "Once in Aleppo," by Donald R. Barton, which was laid in an imaginary country much like Iran, and "A Show of Force,"

By drawing his tenth-round game in thirteen moves, David Bronstein of Russia kept the lead with a score of 7 -- 2 in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, according to a report received here yesterday through Swedish news sources.

The Minute Maid Corporation, one of the nation's leading producer - distributors of frozen foods and the largest factor in the frozen citrus juice business, earned $2,233,956 in the nine months ended July 31, in contrast to only $239,898 in the similar period a year ago.

A report that the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, severely damaged last week by the sudden collapse of a 10,000-gallon water tank, might become the site of a parking lot or garage was confirmed yesterday by Saul Lancourt, general manager of the house.

The New Jersey State Health Department was accused yesterday by Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen of seeking to clean up the Raritan River at the expense of Staten Island beaches and shellfish grounds.
The disaster growing out of unexpectedly heavy rainfall should teach us a lesson and give us an opportunity for something that has long needed doing.

Winter will soon be giving way to spring in South America. To meet the developing seasonal increase in travel between North and South America, Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) is stepping up its services.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 30 -- The Fifth Metropolitan Infantry Regiment, previously stationed in Germany, began to arrive in Morocco today to reinforce the French troops already here.
Paul Muni is out of the cast of "Inherit the Wind" because of an eye affliction.
In an emergency, individual egg pies can solve the problem of what to serve for lunch or supper. A package of pastry mix, a few eggs and a sauce are the only essentials for this novel entree.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The United States, British and French Foreign Ministers will meet in New York Sept. 27 to coordinate tactics for their conference in Geneva with their Soviet counterpart.

HERMAN WOUK, to most novel readers, is synonymous with "The Caine Mutiny," which is surely the most popular World War II novel in its class (United States Navy, Pacific Theatre Division). Mr. Wouk is also the author of two earlier novels, "Aurora Dawn," a study of the genus huckstar and "The City Boy," a memory-lane excursion down the pre-delinquent Manhattan sidewalks.
The Federal Maritime Board in Washington cleared the way yesterday for the United States Lines to acquire the name, vessel and good-will of the South Atlantic Steamship Line, Inc., of Savannah, Ga.
Several hundred homeward-bound subway riders were stranded for forty-two minutes last night when power failed in a BMT train bound from Manhattan to Jamaica, Queens.
Existence of Government corporations "makes it harder for Congress to adjust the nation's finances to changing conditions," the Tax Foundation declared yesterday.

In the seventy-one years since Willard Parker Hospital for contagious diseases was opened New York City has had reason to be thankful for its services. Now the city has equal reason to be pleased that the institution is closing and, more particularly, for the reasons it can close.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bob Keegan pitched his first complete game of the year and Jim Rivera slammed out a pair of two-run homers to pace the Chicago White Sox to a 4-to-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 22,638 today.

Sidney H. Bingham, who announced his retirement yesterday as executive director and general manager of the New York City Transit Authority, has been a faithful, hardworking public servant. For thirty-nine years he has been associated with the private and public business of passenger transportation in New York.
Two former longshoremen have started suit against the Waterfront Commission and the Federal Stevedoring Corporation, alleging harassment and intimidation has kept them from employment.
WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 31 -- An angry crowd of some 300 men and women rushed the delegation of Russian farm experts visiting Canada tonight as it arrived at the airfield.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Democrats picked two of their former Secretaries of Agriculture today to plan an attack on Eisenhower farm policies for the 1956 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Senate subcommittee investigating the Government's loyalty program heard a veteran with an honorable discharge say today that he had been dismissed from a civilian Navy post as a security risk. The only movement he ever had joined, he swore, was the Boy Scouts of America.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Sam Giammalva of Houston added another notable conquest to his string for the season today.

Electric power production in the week ended on last Saturday rose to 10,906,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 10,812,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Aug. 28, 1954, was 9,227,000,000.
The essential and immediate requirement in the critical situation on the Egyptian-Israeli border is to stop the fighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles can "pack a rod" anywhere in Washington if he wants to. But, it turns out, Mr. Dulles does not exercise his legalright. He keeps his gun at the back of a bureau drawer and seldom even looks at it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A group of leading farm organizations and several important commodity groups are exploring the possibility of a United States agricultural exhibition in Moscow.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday some readjustments in the price of Venezuelan crude oil. Effective today, the price changes represent an advance ranging from 10 to 20 cents a barrel in the lower grades of crude oil, used largely for fuel oil and asphalt.

Wool futures yesterday continued the decline that started on Monday when the Australian wool auctions opened with prices sharply, below those of the previous session that ended in June. Further declines for most grades in Australia yesterday closed tops on the New York Cotton Exchange 0.6 to 1.5 cents a pound lower and grease wool 1 to 1.5 cents down.

Governor Harriman had to "wait out" an objection at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, even as 16,143 other turf enthusiasts. After watching Helen W. Kellogg's Dark Charger finish ahead of Eugene Mori's Cosmah in the $17,625 Astarita Stakes, the Governor made his way to the winner's circle.

IT is distressing to report that Boris Karloff once again has fallen into evil ways. In recent months Mr. Karloff had been seen on television in a series of portrayals in which he had been an eminently correct gentleman on the side of the angels.
Sedgwick County Kan., announced yesterday that it planned to offer for sale on Sept. 28 issues of general obligation bonds totaling $5,760,000 to finance various public improvements.

When the national convention of the American Legion meets next month in Miami it will have before it a report on UNESCO, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. This report, prepared by a special committee of six prominent Legionnaires headed by Ray Murphy of New York, a past national commander, is the result of eighteen months' painstaking study of charges against UNESCO, including the charge that it is communistic.

LONDON, Aug. 31, -- The United States Secretary of Agriculture agreed with the British officials today that the problem of disposing of surplus United States commodities called for close cooperation with other Governments.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 31 -- A recessed Federal grand jury was reconvened here today with indications that it would consider whether Carl G. LoDolce had played any role in the 1944 slaying of Maj. William C. Holohan in Italy.

The establishment of sound foreign trade relations is now the best means of aiding the rehabilitation and development of friendly nations, in the opinion of the president of the National Industrial Conference Board.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 31 -- The Yankees brought their rough and tumble affairs in the West to a close tonight by subduing Manager Lou Boudreau's Athletics, 11 to 6, in the series finale.

May I take this opportunity to congratulate The Times for its recent editorial recommending and supporting the reappointment of Justine Wise Polier, and Hubert T. Delany as judges of the New York City. Domestic Relations Courts.
A $7,000,000 breach of contract suit in behalf of Walter Winchell has been initiated against the American Broadcasting Company. The commentator left the A. B. C. network last June.

The benefit committee of the Turtle Bay Music School has taken over the Oct. 25 evening performance of "The Desk Set," a comedy starring Shirley Booth, as its autumn theatre benefit. The play opens Oct. 13 at the Broadhurst Theatre.
A veteran pilot and airline operations expert has been chosen to head a technical assistance project to aid the development of commercial aviation in Turkey.

GREEN apples, the hard variety that has given many a youthful orchard raider a tummy ache, are now in good supply. These specimens may not have much to recommend them in appearance; however, with a bit of cooking and a dash of seasoning, they may be converted into something delicious.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in August was the smallest since September, 1954.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- French officials said today France was trying in Morocco to end "a source of worry that might impede American diplomacy."

The Veterans of Foreign Wars, now holding a National Encampment at Boston, was praised here yesterday by Francis T. Greene, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, for its unanimous approval of national maritime policy.
DUBLIN, Aug. 31 (UP) -- A United States astronomer said today the universe apparently was expanding only one-third as fast as science figured four or five years ago.
PARIS, Aug. 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour du Moulin, who became Resident General in Morocco today, has assumed one of the most difficult tasks assigned to a French official.

The three-story store and apartment building at 732-736 Chancellor Avenue, Irvington, N. J., has been sold by Thirty Rutgers Street, Inc., to the Heljam Realty Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
An 18-year-old heir to a $2,000,000 shipping fortune got his mother's approval for a new $2,700 automobile to use at Yale, but yesterday the Surrogate's Court here said no.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Administration authorized negotiations today for the sale or lease to private industry of the Government-owned and operated $13,200,000 tin smelter at Texas City, Tex.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -July sales of merchant wholesalers fell off 7 per cent compared with June but were still 8 per cent ahead of July a year ago, the Government said today.
The New York chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers announced yesterday the election of Elias Elvove of Yonkers as president.

The two-story taxpayer and apartment building at 1341-1351 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been resold by Herbert Felner to Louis Prager. The transaction was negotiated by Alexander and Stuart Herman, brokers. J. Fleishhaker was attorney for the buyer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Harold E. Stassen, special assistant to President Eisenhower, said today "constructive progress" had been made since the United Nations Subcommittee on Disarmament resumed meeting Monday.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A woman church leader today urged a joint legislative committee studying juvenile delinquency to bring out the "cold hard acts of our neglect" in not providing adequate funds to support childcare agencies.

Seeking to avert a strike by 6,000 maintenance workers, Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to make any contract settlement fully retroactive to today. The company's pact with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., expired last midnight.

Plans for altering the five-story building with basement at 66 East Eightieth Street into apartments for fifteen families were announced yesterday as the property was sold by Frederick Brown to the 66 East Eighty Realty Corporation, Mrs. Mollie Fischer, president.
BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The inadequacy of facilities at bases is seriously impairing the effectiveness of the Air Force, Gen. Nathan F. Twining said here today.
RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour du Moulin arrived here from Tunis today to take up his post as Resident General in French Morocco.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Dore Schary, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production chief, was smiling broadly today, having triumphed where other Hollywood producers have failed. He announced the signing of Alec Guinness to make his first motion picture in this country.

A gunman invaded the Belvedere Hotel yesterday afternoon, held up one of the proprietors in the lobby and escaped with a $2,800 payroll. Unaware of the hold-up were a number of policemen and other persons who were attending a patrolman's wedding reception at the other end of the hotel.

The rapid progress of the Dodgers toward the National League pennant was checked last night. The second-place Braves pounded six Brooklyn pitchers for sixteen hits to hand a 13-8 setblack to the league leaders before 17,604 spectators at Ebbets Field.
A flood relief donation of 300 prefabricated houses to Connecticut topped the list of contributions made yesterday to the devastated areas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- A representative of the automobile service industry today accused the "Big Three" car manufacturers -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- of false advertising and a monopolistic hold on the auto repair industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The tenet that unhappily married couples should stay together for the sake of their children was challenged today by Judson T. Landis, University of California sociologist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The State Department acknowledged receipt today of a protest from Arthur Loew over the United States' withdrawal of "Blackboard Jungle" from the Venice Film Festival in Italy.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- Two members of the Communist party's Presidium told Senator George W. Malone tonight he would get access to data on the Soviet Union's strategic mineral reserves.

LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- The Canadian Pacific Steamship Company announced today that its 19,000-ton liner Empress of Australia is up for sale. She was bought by the company for more than 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) in 1953 to replace the Empress of Canada, which was burned out at Birkenhead, England, in 1952.

CAIRO, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Mahmoud Fawzi, announced tonight that representatives of Arab states would meet in Cairo to discuss United States proposals for development of the Jordan River Valley water resources.

YONKERS, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Scott Frost, the California trotting sensation, goes after his fourteenth straight victory tomorrow night in the $73,840 Yonkers Futurity -- a race calculated to equal the Hambletonian in thrills.
Echoes of other ages and places are the popular note for shower curtains and coordinated curstains, hampers and baskets for fall.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
DENVER, Aug. 31 -- President Eisenhower, who prefers airplanes and golfmobiles, acquired a boat today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The United States and Japan agreed today to build up Japan's military strength so she could defend herself and contribute to "security in the Western Pacific."
Converted apartments will be considered exempt from rent control only after conversion work has been completed and the city has issued a certificate of occupancy.
A PRODUCTIVE fall weakfish season appears in prospect. Reports from Great South Bay and Peconic Bay show that quite a few fish have been taken during the past week.

Pretty soon she will be home again, and it will be high time. The woman who first discovered that she could slip away to a cool summer resort for a few weeks, leaving her husband at home, must have been extraordinarily clever; her example has been followed with entirely too much enthusiasm by armies of wives ever since.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Aug. 31 -Following the lead of Nassau County's older and bigger villages, Farmingdale will require a license-for a commuter to park in the village's field at railroad station tomorrow.
New bond financing crossed the billion-dollar mark in August for the third month this year, while stock flotations dropped to the smallest amount for any month since February, 1951.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A staff employe of the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee said tonight that Senator Malone was "offering the Russians something they already have."
RANGELEY, Me., Aug. 31 (UP) -- The man who guided President Eisenhower on a recent fishing trip will receive a portrait of himself, painted and initialed by the President.

THE annual all-Bach program has always been the Interval Concert that has drawn the best. Last night's, the sixth of its kind, drew so big an audience to Carnegie Recital Hall that when the hall was packed to its 300 capacity more than 100 would-be listeners had to be turned away.

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- All eyes now turn to the fashions Paris offers for fall. In creating these new clothes, the city's great designers have focused attention on the top of the figure. This is done by widening the shoulders, frequently emphasizing the size and shape of the sleeves, raising the bust line and resorting to such high strategy as placing pockets well up on the chest.

Arnold Bauman was reported yesterday to have been chosen as counsel for the legislative watchdog committee. He is now the chief of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- It was Nashua, all the way, in the big horse race at Washington Park today.

A New Yorker has been defined as one who looks both ways when crossing a one-way street. This wary citizen may not believe it, but three British experts came here yesterday hoping to find a solution to London's traffic problems.

THE Creole cookery of New Orleans provides inspiration for a menu that could fit into plans for the long holiday weekend ahead. A big bowl of hearty, savory gumbo is accompanied by fluffy white rice and a salad of thinly sliced cucumbers neat on a bed of crisp Boston lettuce.

The American Jewish Committee is gratified by the statement of Secretary of State Dulles on American policy in the Near East reported in The Times Aug. 27. It is a heartening declaration by which the United States is assuming the leadership in one of the most troubled areas of the world.
The wettest August in the city's records has ended with a total rainfall of 13.82 inches. This comes close to the rainiest month of all -- 14.51 inches in September, 1882.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The State Department said today it had denied a passport to Leonard B. Boudin, New York attorney, because his travel abroad would not be "in the national interest." Mr. Boudin's attorney, Harry Rand, said the passport had been denied because Mr. Boudin allegedly had Communist affiliations.

The do-it-yourself trend is steadily building up more and more linage in a field that produced very little only a few years ago. The Rockwell Manufacturing Company is scheduling what it calls the biggest campaign ever put behind power tools for its Delta line.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31 -- President Juan D. Peron tonight declared relentless war against his political opposition.
A railway union founder who lives in South Orange, N. J., but thinks "there isn't another town like New York," will become general manager of the city transit system on Oct. 1.

Sidney H. Bingham resigned yesterday as operating head of the city's subway, elevated and bus lines. After thirty-nine years with the system, he will go on leave Oct. 1, and his resignation will take effect Feb. 1.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Herb Score of the Indians and Hector (Skinny) Brown of the Orioles tied the two-team modern major league strikeout record of twenty-three today as Cleveland again defeated Baltimore, 5 -- 1.

JERUSALEM, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- Israel's Army struck at an Egyptian military camp in the Gaza strip last night, the Foreign Ministry announced early today. The military camp had served as a base of operations for Egyptian terrorist squads that have killed fifteen Israelis inside Israel since last Thursday, the statement asserted.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The Shinnecock reservation, largest on Long Island, will be the scene of a traditional Indian pow wow over the Labor Day week-end. The Shinnecocks, who govern their reservation, have invited tribesmen from neighboring reservations and from the West.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- The American folk opera, "Porgy and Bess," will be coming to Moscow in November, Vladimir Kemerov, a Soviet Deputy Minister of Culture, stated today.
Lower freight rates will become effective today over the world-wide routes of Air Express International Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 24:

A strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad by 35,000 non-operating personnel in twelve states and the District of Columbia was announced yesterday for midnight tomorrow -- the starts of the long Labor Day week-end.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The stock markets marked time today, uncertain whether tomorrow would bring an advance in the bank rate. Dated Government stock continued their downdrift but industrial recovered part of their early losses.
Deere Co., farm implement producers, realized a 53 per cent increase in earnings for the nine months ended July 31 on a sales gain of 18 per cent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -- The first American performance of Darius Milhaud's Symphony No. 5 is scheduled during the 1955-56 season of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra.

NOW that the time for renewing apartment leases is near, New York municipal departments offer reminders on the various laws and regulations governing the complex relationship between landlord and tenant. Rent control has been extended to June 30, 1957, according to the New York State Temporary Rent Commission.

A recent Moscow incident exemplifies how much the Soviet Government has lifted the Iron Curtain and how much it has not. The incident revolves about two of our Congressmen who have been visting Moscow, and the fact of their presence there testifies to the improvement in accessibility of the Soviet Union.

The Inter-American Press Association said yesterday it had learned that the Government of Colombia had banned two United States magazines, Time and Vision. The latter is printed in Spanish for distribution in Latin-American countries.
BRISTOL, England, Aug. 31 -Eminent British scientists disagreed strongly tonight about whether the atmosphere surrounding the earth could be set on fire by an uncontrollable nuclear reaction.

ELENVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- The Empire State Music Festival began the final week of its first season of concerts here tonight. It played to a full moon, an audience of nearly 2,000 and a landscape that looked as peaceful as the slumbering Catskills are supposed to look.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- The leaders of the Liberal International asking their followers throughout the world to take a strong stand against accepting "peaceful coexistence" with communism as a desirable state of affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- The Market Street-Frankford subway-elevated line here was tied up for two hours this afternoon by a "sitdown meeting" of maintenance employes on the tracks at the Sixty-ninth Street terminal.
A Presidential fact-finding board completed hearings yesterday in a dispute between the New York Central and the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen, independent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- A television film series called "The Ringmaster" is taking form. Built on circus stories, it will have George Sanders as the ringmaster, narrator and host.

A syndicate headed by Lawrence A. Wien has purchased the Warwick Hotel, Seventeenth and Locust Streets, Philadelphia, from Kirkeby Hotels, Inc., and has leased the premises for twenty-one years to the Warwick-Philadelphia Corporation, of which A. S. Kirkeby is president. The property will continue to be operated as a unit of the Kirkeby Hotels, Inc.
