IT is a fashion falacy to wear this season's clothes with last season's face.

Stock prices finished yesterday at their best levels of the month. Selected issues were strong and the list as a whole improved, although trading at 1,850,000 shares continued to lag well behind the daily average for the year to date.
Mayor Wagner gave a tacit endorsement yesterday to William J. Sheldrick, whose political life is at stake in a Tammany contest for leader in the Seventh Assembly District.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- When Eddie Arcaro strode down the steps of the jockey quarters after the Kentucky Derby, William Woodward was awaiting him. They were two heartsick men. Nashua, whom the one had ridden and the other owned, had been beaten roundly by Swaps. It was no fluke and there were no excuses possible.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 -- Unless nationalism is fostered in Malaya there is a possibility that the Communists will take over. This warning was the main theme of a speed by Tengku Abdul Rahman at the opening of the new Legislative Council of the Federation of Malaya today.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Two business groups have agreed to merge to restore one of Japan's huge pre-war combines, the Mitsui Bussan Trading Company, it was announced today.

Nathan M. Ohrbach, having turned 70, is receiving the many expressions of birthday congratulation and well-wishing that are inspired by affection and esteem. His name is widely known, of course, for his success as a merchant in New York, Newark and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission, moving to head off charges of "big business domination" of the drive for peacetime uses of atomic power, today announced rules limiting the scope of its industry advisory boards.

Nigeria, the British colony and protectorate in West Africa, is striving to expand its industrialization. A goodwill mission including A. M. A. Akinloye, Minister of Agriculture and Natural Resources of the Western Region of Nigeria, and fourteen representatives of farming communities in that area are making a ten-day goodwill and educational tour of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Consumer installment credit outstanding at the end of July was $562,000,000 higher than at the end of June, the Federal Reserve Bank Board reported today. The figure, however, was $312,000,000 less than the increase reported for June, according to the agency.
Foundation garments designers have more fashion responsibilities this year than they have had since the sixteen-inch waist was modish.
THE not-so-secret word for working fashion magic with accessories this fall is "blend."
The news that the Phillips Petroleum Company would retire its convertible debentures produced an immediate reaction in Wall Street on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- The Army's right to court-martial American war prisoners accused of collaboration with Communists in Korea was upheld today by Federal District Judge Joseph C. McGarraghy.

On Aug. 26 The Times printed a letter by the Rev. C. J. Lucas attacking Alan Paton and defending the apartheid policy in South Africa. Since the letter may confuse some uninformed readers it seems advisable to examine the arguments.
The Times of Aug. 24 carried a news story about homeless dogs menacing livestock and poultry in Suffolk County. It was correctly pointed out that the problem is caused by people who abandon the dogs.
BONN Germany, Aug. 31--Livingston T. Merchant, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, conferred today With Chancellor Konrad Aden-...
Shareholders of the Hoover Ball and Bearing Company yesterday approved acquisition of The Universal Die Casting and Manufacturing Company through in exchange of shares.
Foreign Minister Shigemitsu will arrive at La Guardia Airport this morning from Washington. His three-day visit will include one address and a press conference.
Free medical and hospital care will be made available to 54,000 union dressmakers here, starting about Nov. 1.
The Department of Justice started action in San Francisco yesterday against the Pacific Coast European Conference and its member steamship lines.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Elmer (Trigger) Burke left here tonight under heavy armed guard for New York City, where he faces a murder charge.

Ruben Gomez of the Giants blanked the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5--0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The right-hander notched his third shutout and posted his ninth victory of the season by checking the Redlegs on seven hits.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Plans for a merger of the D. L. Clark Company, Pittsburgh candy manufacturer, with the Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago were announced here today by William G. Karnes, president of Beatrice.

A decline last week of 865,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Last Friday total supplies were 154,698,000 barrels, compared with 155,563,000 a week earlier and 153,757,000 a year ago.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (UP) -- A trial committee of the United Lutheran Church's Northwest Synod tonight found the Rev. John Gerberding innocent of heresy charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The rehabilitation needs of the flooded Northeastern states now appear less costly than at first expected. Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, made this report today.
CAIRO, Aug. 31 -- Egyptian official opinion is hardening against proposals last week by Secretary of State Dulles for settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

Your editorial of Aug. 29 described graphically the continuing need for assistance to Haiti. The problems facing that country, as you point out, are a matter of concern to all Americans. While there is no contention over your appraisal of the need for more assistance, the readers of your editorial might like a summary of what the United States has done and is doing to aid her neighbor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The Chicago public got its first, long-awaited look at "Powerama" today.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Netherlands celebrated the seventy-fifth birthday of former Queen Wilhelmina today with a road safety campaign.
An air-conditioned subway car, believed to be the first on any rapid transit facility, was put into operation on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Following is a unofficial translation of President Juan D. Peron's speech to supporters in the Plaza de Mayo tonight:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (UP) -Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson's stronger finish tonight gave him another unanimous ten-round decision over the former heavyweight champion, Ezzard Charles, in their return fight at the Arena.

The latest annual report of the Controller of the Currency, released today, disclosed that the number of banks in this country has been reduced by almost half during the last twenty - nine years. There were 28,257 banks as of Dec. 31, 1925, compared with 14,388 as of Dec. 31, 1954.

NOW that the children are back from camp, many a house is strewn again with comic books. The parental wish that, once in a while at least, the children read something more substantial than the comics may be especially acute just now. Many youngsters, however, wise to adult wiles, continue conscientiously to resist trips to the public library or any thing else that smacks of attempted mental improvement.
The metropolitan area is surfeited with more than 212,000 unsold new automobiles.

DETROIT, Thursday, Sept. 1 -- A strike by 139,000 workers of the Chrysler Corporation began at midnight. At 3 A. M., Detroit time, (4 A. M., New York time) negotiators for the company and for the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., had failed to reach a settlement as they worked into the morning.

PRINCETON, Aug. 31 -- The Planned Parenthood Committee of Princeton has withdrawn from the Princeton Community Chest in a move to restore "cooperative effort" to the chest's campaign for funds. The drive begins in October.

A match race between two horses may not be the best way to decide their relative greatness. In a single race, in a single day, one horse may be "up to it," another may not. But a match race will have to serve until a better method is devised.
A twenty-one-pound narcotics cache, believed to be pure heroin worth $2,000,000 on the illicit market, was seized yesterday aboard a French freighter.
Scholars groping for a definition human equality agreed yesterday that they could not longer overlong in lofty philosophical realms.

The Burroughs Corporation, business machines manufacturer, plans to acquire R. Hadley Company, a Los Angeles printing concern, through an exchange of stocks. Burroughs stated yesterday it would exchange 79,400 shares of its common stock for

A group of seventeen girl scouts from seven countries discussed their experiences yesterday at International House, 500 Riverside Drive. They had just completed a ten-week exchange program in this country and Europe.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Greece asked today that Britain grant "self-determination" in a "logical, fixed period" to the inhabitants of Cyprus.

" My Aunt Lucienne," by Rose C. Feld, a series of incidents involving the author's French relatives, will be published Sept. 22 by Scribners. The stories begin in Paris in the Nineteen Twenties and present Uncle Paul, genial and easy-going expatriate American; his "very" Gallic wife, Aunt Lucienne, who loves a bargain and a bit of spice and romance, and their son Pierre, sophisticated and worldly wise at the age of 13.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Following is the joint statement on the United States-Japanese discussions issued today:

In the horse-and-buggy days transverse water breaks on a hilly road were known as "thank-you-ma'ams." They were designed to prevent ruts by carrying water to the side of the road. The young people of the Research Institute, looking ahead, forgot that.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Members of the United Nations were admonished today against setting exaggerated financial goals for projects voted in the General Assembly. The record on payment of members' pledges to date, the negotiating committee on extra-budgetary funds said, did not warrant the establishing of unduly ambitious totals.
The long-faced teen-ager who wants friends but has a hard time making or holding them constitutes a problem in many a household.

Yesterday's session of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg was devoted to playing off adjourned games. According to a report received through Swedish news sources, David Bronstein of Russia won his game with G. Stahlberg, Sweden, postponed from the first round, in eighty-three moves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The New York commission firm of Joseph Klein Co., its principal owner and a customer today failed to contest penalties arising from a Department of Agriculture complaint that they manipulated cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange in violation of law.

Gen. Oliver P. Smith, United States Marine Corps, retires today at Norfolk, Va., from his last command -- Fleet Marine Force, Atlantic -- after thirty-eight years of service. Ordinarily the retirement of a general officer attracts little atten- tion.
SWIFT CURRENT, Sask.,Aug. 31 -- The free-and-easy organization of a Saskatchewan cooperative farm baffled the visiting Russian agricultural officials today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- Twentieth Century-Fox said today it had agreed to the out-of-court settlement made yesterday with Ring Lardner Jr. to save further litigation expense.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 31 -- Polish and Czechoslovak observers pleaded here today for increased trade between Latin America and the Iron Curtain countries. They emphasized the possibilities of new outlets for Latin America's exports.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 31 -Prices of most types of wool declined again at the third day the new season's auctions in Sydney today.
CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Three players were in a tie for first place today at the close of the fourth round of the New York State Chess Association championship.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 31 (UP) -- The giant carrier Forrestal, which sailed from this port Monday in sunlight and splendor, came home today in a gray thundersquall with two of her four propellers out of action.
Storekeepers selling Westinghouse Electric Corporation electric mixers, toasters, blankets and other small household appliances henceforth will be able to charge customers whatever they wish.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission refused today to scrap the New York Telephone Company's petition for a stop-gap rate increase of $34,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon related today how he had tried playfully to cross up a Japanese translator.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -Eighteen-year-old Toni Monetti of Manhasset Bay Y. C., Port Washington, L. I., became the women's sailing champion of North America today. Even though one race remains in the series, Miss Monetti cannot be beaten.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength.

The myth of the bird-like appetite is being dispelled daily by two professional bird caterers in Brooklyn. They put in an eight-hour day wheeling the lunch wagon around for a thousand hungry rare birds on Abraham Straus' second floor.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 31 Bipartisanship was declared today to be the way to develop a relationship between the White House and Congress that would assure Senate approval of important treaties.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (UP) -- Huntington Hartford 2d, the Atlantic and Pacific Company food chain heir, was asked today in a paternity suit to acknowledge that he was the father of a 17-year-old son of a New York dancer. The dancer, Mary Barton, died in 1941.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- An inquiry into reported intimidation and rejection of Negro voters in the recent Mississippi primary elections was announced today by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.
After the man of thought has thought, what does he do?

TORONTO, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Odeon Theatres, Ltd., British parent of the companies included in the J. Arthur Rank Organization, had consolidate operating profit in the year ending June 25 of 8,727,000 before depreciation, taxes and interest.

FORT CARSON, Colo., Sept. 1 (UP) -- Maj. Sammy Lee, the Olympic diver who was kept from buying a home in Garden Grove, Calif., said today he had accepted an offer to set up his medical practice in Santa Ana, Calif., this November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Iron Curtain is going up for the American folk opera "Porgy and Bess."
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) - The Air Force announced today it planned to unload a billion dollars worth of obsolete property in the next ten months, most of it through disposal sales.

Oscar Panno, chess champion of Argentina, gained slightly on David Bronstein of Russia, leader in the interzone tournament at Gothenburg, when in the eleventh round he drew with Tigran Petrosian of Russia, according to a report received through Swedish news sources.
A hat was presented to Governor Harriman yesterday, but he declined to answer directly whether he would "toss it into the Presidential ring next year."
Business borrowings continue to soar. New York City banks now hold the greatest amount of such paper they have had in twenty months.
An anti-trust consent decree was entered in Federal Court here yesterday terminating civil anti-trust proceedings against the American News Company and its subsidiary, the Union News Company.

Michael Quill's threats of a strike on the Pennsylvania Railroad are an example of how not to make friends and influence people in favor of his Transport Workers Union. The day before yesterday he was brandishing the results of a vote of maintenance men in favor of a walkout tonight, stressing the inconvenience it would cause to hundreds of thousands of week-end travelers.
The motorist setting out for a drive this year has the lowest chance in history of meeting a fatal or serious injury-producing accident.

DETROIT, Friday, Sept. 2 -- The settlement of a short-lived strike against the Chrysler Corporation early yesterday appeared to assure an era of labor peace for the nation's three major auto producers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Three facets of continuing good business were reported by the Government today. Cash dividends by corporations were running about 10 per cent ahead of a year ago. Small firms were continuing to enjoy a marked pick-up in business that started late in 1954. And manufacturers maintained a high rate of shipments in July, although they fell below those of June.

Stocks made modest, irregular gains yesterday morning and lost most of them late in the session as volume shriveled, but managed to close higher for the eleventh successive day. Aircrafts, chemicals, motors and steels were the best performers.
The Dodgers yesterday reduced the so-called magic number to 10 by taking the rubber game from the runner-up Milwaukee Braves, 6 -- 3, at Ebbets Field. Brooklyn leads by thirteen games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Public Health Service announced today the allocation to the states of 3,348,000 cubic centimeters of poliomyelitis vaccine. It will be distributed under the voluntary control plan.
BONN, Sept. 1 -- The Federal Government today revealed the size of the massive investments without which Germany's remarkable post-war economic recovery and expansion would have been impossible.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- September and December wheat showed outstanding strength today on what appeared to be short covering and also on purchases against sales of corn in the form of backspreading.

THE big triangles that can break up marriages are usually built on a base of other triangles -- smaller but equally acute -- that have been irritating husband and wife with their sharp points for some time. So, at least, hold many marriage counselors.
GREENWOOD, Miss., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Governor of Mississippi called today for a complete investigation of the kidnap-killing of a Negro youth who allegedly had whistled at a white woman.
Summer, the season of casual, quick-cooked meals, is over. At least, shoppers are likely to get that impression from the meats offered by chain stores for the Labor Day week-end.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- Experts in psychology and psychiatry took pessimistic views today of progress toward curbing two of the nation's increasingly acute problems, alcoholism and juvenile delinquency.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- An injured foot today put Swaps out of competition for an indefinite period -- and clouded the hopes of fans of seeing him run against Nashua again this season.

Ohio Valley Electric Corporation reported here yesterday completion of the sixth of eleven proposed steam-electric generating units, bringing capability to 1,290,000 kilowatts. This is the halfway point in bringing into service facilities that will supply the full electric power requirements for the Atomic Energy Commission's gaseous diffusion plant near Portsmouth, Ohio.
The Propeller Club of the Port of Baltimore yesterday nominated Senator John Marshall Butler of Maryland for the maritime award of the Robert L. Hague Post of the American Legion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 791,977 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

A motion by an insurgent stockholders' group for a stay of the annual stockholders' meeting of Libby, McNeill Libby was denied yesterday by United States Court of Appeals Judge J. Edward Lumbard. The meeting, originally called for Aug. 17 in Portland, Me., is scheduled for next Wednesday.
Carmine G. DeSapio intervened last night in the Tammany leadership contest in the Seventh Assembly District.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman said today that he wanted a little rest between speaking engagements so he could "go stronger when the campaign gets hot" next year.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- The Indian Government conceded today it had been too optimistic in its first plans for guiding the country's economy in the next five years.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept, 1 -- On the eve of the opening of her biggest post-war international fair, Yugoslavia has initiated a drive f or trade with the Eastern Communist countries.

The French Foreign Ministry declares that in a few days Morocco will have the most representative government ever formed there and that this will end both the political and human difficulties in that area and the worries of "certain international circles," including American diplomacy.

The competent riding of Teddy Atkinson and George Glassner entertained the crowd of 15,751 at the Aqueduct race track yesterday. Master Teddy registered three flat victories in a row and Glassner scored two times, taking the first and sixth races.
BRISTOL, England, Sept. 1 -- British biochemists say they have advanced toward synthesizing life by tearing off and analyzing the jackets of bacteria.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The difference between winning the big race and losing it for Eddie Arcaro, the millionaire equestrian, was $9,965. That's from a strictly monetary standpoint since Arcaro's $10,000 pay-off represents 10 per cent of the $100,000 purse for the winning jockey and the one-race riding fee for the runner-up is $35.
ROME, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Gino Prato, the New York shoemaker who won $32,000 on a television show with his knowledge of opera, ducked today a musical question worth less than 2 cents.

A 22-year-old Queens mother, unnerved when her baby son cried in his bath, pushed him under the water yesterday and drowned him, according to the police. She made up a bizarre "kidnapping" tale, but the police found the body of the 2 1/2-month-old boy on a closet shelf in the family living room.

Wool prices were substantially higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The rise followed four days of sharp declines. Trading was influenced by reports of steadier prices in Australia and prospects of better quality grades at the auctions there next week.

CHICAGO, Friday, Sept. 2 (AP) -- About twenty-five persons were injured last night as an explosion and fire quickly destroyed half a square block in a factory district on the near Southwest side. Damage was estimated at $1,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- The Soviet Union called on the West today to accept "major points" in its disarmament plan. The United States and Britain

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Robert D. Murphy said tonight that the State Department was seeking to develop "a hopeful trend" with relation to the Soviet Union "so strong that it would be irreversible."
Philadelphia gave the lie yesterday to its reputation for somnolence.

The articles on Saratoga Springs by Richard Amper, published in your paper on Aug. 16 and 17, came belatedly to our attention. Mr. Amper did a commendable work presenting a realistic picture of the financial background of Saratoga Springs. Unfortunately, the same conditions prevail in other, still active American spas.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 1 -- Revision of the state's youthful offender and motor vehicle laws was advocated today at a hearing of the Temporary State Commission on Youth and Delinquency.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Witnesses for two organizations of grocery stores said today that a fair trade law aimed at big chain stores had missed its mark and hit independent dealers instead.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1 -- The test of strength between the Government and unions in Chile entered its second week today without a clear indication of how the situation was going to be settled.

Pity the poor postman today. At 8 o'clock this morning the world's largest public Utility will start to move out some 100 tons of mail through the Church Street and Thirty-third Street Post Offices. The mail will go to American Telephone and Telegraph Company's more than 1,380,000 stockholders.

AS a woman accents her costume with a jewel, so decorators often use a single piece of ornate furniture as a point of interest in an otherwise simple room setting. Typical of such "gems" are those shown on the right -- their harmony of line blending with that of contemporary pieces, their traditional appearance and rich ornament contrasting with them.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has leased space in the three-story building at 78-100 Columbus Avenue for its Labor and Migration Division, which will move from 21 West Sixtieth Street. The division will occupy, the second and hird floors and part of the ground floor of the structure, between West Sixty-third and West Sixty-fourth Streets. The lease was negotiated by Walter Scott Co., Inc., broker.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- Loans totaling $84,000,000 have been granted to Yugoslavia by the Soviet Union.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- Boston and twenty other Massachusetts communities have decided to postpone the opening of public schools because of the polio outbreak.
The change in the Soviet attitude toward the West is not quite as great as some believe, George F. Kennan said here yesterday.

In the Aug. 26 edition of The New York Times there appeared a graphic account of an injured workman's vision being saved as a result of alert action by two Brooklyn policemen. Here again is another example of the worthiness of New York's "finest" to bear that title. However, there is a lesson to be learned here that is too important to overlook.

Juan Domingo Peron of Argentina is a great showman. The theatrical performance he put on Wednesday with his rhetorical offer to resign, the massing of the descamisados, or shirtless workers, in the Plaza de Mayo in Buenos Aires, and finally his violent diatribe against his political enemies, was a typical Peronist gesture.
DENVER, Sept. 1 -- All forty-eight Republican state chairmen will fly to Denver from Washington Sept. 9 for a political conference with President Eisenhower.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- The life of Gen. John C. Fremont will be the subject of a television film series to be made by Robert Alexander Productions. Steve Cochran, the actor, who owns the production company with Harrison Reader, has decided to make the TV series first, rather than a theatrical motion picture as originally planned.
THE holiday week-end offers varied opportunities to coastal anglers, ranging from weakfish and fluke in the bays and inlets to bluefish and school tuna off-shore.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Rocky Marciano, tanned and boyish, celebrated his thirty-first birthday at his training camp today.

PARIS fashions for fall and winter, 4,963 pounds worth, arrived in New York Tuesday night on Air France Flight 47. Within three weeks, American women will be able to buy copies of them at modest -- or not so modest -- prices.
With representatives of sixteen nations in the lists, the combined men's, women's, senior and mixed doubles championships will start today at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
TWEEDS started life with a Scottish brogue, picked up a French accent and came on to New York.

Despite the negative effects of bad weather brought on by glancing blows of two hurricanes, New York department stores posted a 7.5 per cent increase in sales for August. Basement store sales increased 12 per cent.
PARIS, Sept. 1 -- The departure of a delegation of Moroccans for Madagascar to see the exiled Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, was again held up today.
The National Council of American Importers directed a protest yesterday to President Eisenhower against his action in making higher bicycle tariffs effective on the day they were announced.

CONSTANTINE, Algeria, Sept. 1 -- The French civil and military authorities are engaged here in a struggle against fear. It is a fear that has paralyzed the European and Moslem populations alike since the bloody week beginning Aug. 20.
BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- A nationwide re-examination of benefit payments to veterans that the Veterans Administration has been quietly conducting for some time came to light here today.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Herbie Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach, L. I., reached the final round of the Westchester Country Club invitation tennis tournament today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Gene Freese's hard-hit single in the last of the ninth today drove in the run that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

FINISHING flourishes for opulent evening fashions are the new, exotic dancing slippers. Like drawings from Oriental picture books, these imaginative shoes display intricate patterns, shocking colors and dramatic lines.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- A well-balanced program, featuring Leonard Rose as 'cello soloist, was presented this evening by the Empire State Music Festival, which is rounding out the final week of its first season. Izler Solomon was the conductor; he also will be in charge of the Sunday afternoon finale.

Now that the Soviet leaders smile instead of frown, display good instead of truculent manners, and employ sweetness and light instead of reckless arrogance, it is obvious that a new phase of world politics has been entered upon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The South was depicted today as having undergone "a quiet revolution" in the pattern of race relations on its college campuses.

THE block-deep roof on the seven-story building at 115 East Twenty-fourth Street is probably the only one in the city paved with hard brick. In its day it was the highest horse-exercising space in Greater New York.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 1 -- The United States flag is flying today over seven United States Air Force installations in French Morocco where it had been prohibited for years by diplomatic objections.
The possibility of a deluge of New Jersey bus tokens into the city's subway turnstiles has the Transit Authority worried.

Newspapers will be "the primary medium" for advertising planned by Seagram-Distillers Company for Seagram's V. O. and Seagram's Golden Gin for the remainder of 1955 and during 1956. This was disclosed yesterday by George E. Mosley, vice president in charge of advertising and sales promotion, in an address to 1,500 delegates attending Seagram's annual fall meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LONDON, Sept. -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation is studying the possibility of operating its planes to cities in the Far East by way of Moscow and Peiping.

An apartment house is planned at the northeast corner of Edwards Boulevard and East Broadway, Long Beach, L. I., where a vacant plot of 200 by 100 feet has been purchased by Morris Morgenstern Son, real estate investment company. Melvyn E. Kevin and Alexander MacMurray were the brokers in the transaction.
JAKARTA, Sept. 1 -- The new Indonesian Cabinet moved decisively today to cut away red tape on the import of foreign goods.
A minor structural change intended to permit the loading of laid-up Liberty ships with two-thirds more surplus grain than previously will be tested today.
The turbulent Port of New York and its restive waterfront industry will be put under the microscope by a research team from Cornell University.

The news columns bear ample evidence that a good many people are already thinking about Nov. 6, 1956, the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. They may be premature, but it is not a moment too early for New York City officials to be thinking about a reform they have the power to initiate that would be of immense service to the voters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The White House surveyed the work of the Eisenhower Administration today and found it good.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- A United States flier shot down by the North Koreans related today how his captors had persuaded him to sign a dictated "thank you letter" for his treatment.
The work of rehabilitating flood victims may still be going on in December, a vice president of the Red Cross said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The State Department said today it had instructed its diplomats to seize every opportunity to impress Egypt and Israel with the gravity of the situation resulting from the fighting in the Gaza strip.
OTTAWA, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- A one-time infantry private became Chief of the Canadian General Staff today.
After winning three straight games from the Redledgs, the Giants relapsed into all-around inefficiency and dropped a 7-4 decision to Cincinnati before a sparse Polo Grounds crowd of 2,262 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission barred book publishers today from compelling retailers to maintain a specified price on volumes while permitting book clubs to sell the same works without price restriction.
WHEREVER fur appears this year, it is top fashion news. From hats right on down to shoes, everyone has climbed on the fur band wagon.
A comparatively minor "incident" in Elmer F. (Trigger) Burke's life -- the slaying of a former friend in a Columbus Avenue barrom brawl three years ago -- brought him back to New York yesterday.
Mayor Wagner was warned yesterday that the cost of completing pending transit projects would soon reduce the city's borrowing power within its debt limit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP) -- Senator William Langer declared today that a "fumbling" Government policy had helped create juvenile and adult delinquency on Indian reservations.
President Eisenhower acted yesterday to avert a strike scheduled for midnight tonight against the Pennsylvania Railroad.
Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu ruled out yesterday any "neutralist course" for Japan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- North American Airlines today questioned the right of the Civil Aeronautics Board to appear in court against it in place of the Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles revealed today that he is a handy man with flapjacks and making maple syrup as well as with shooting irons.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- The Israeli Government proclaimed today new tax measures to finance stepped-up immigration of Jewish refugees from Morocco.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 -- To most leaders of the Liberal parties of the world, assembled here as the seventh congress of the Liberal International, the spirit of Geneva is anathema.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 -- Scott Frost, winner of the $86,863 Hambletonian at Goshen on Aug. 3, added night harness racing's richest event, the $73,840 Yonkers Futurity Trot for 3-year-olds, to his list of victories tonight.

The New York Rangers will begin their National Hockey League home schedule at Madison Square Garden against the Toronto Maple Leafs on Oct. 19 instead of against their traditional opening rival, the Boston Bruins.

Despite the fact that the ratio of serious traffic accidents to automobile registrations and miles traveled has been steadily declining, American motorists haven't been doing so well on the highways recently. The death toll in July over the nation was the highest for that month in eighteen years, and was 11 per cent above July, 1954.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Britain and her allies, Greece and Turkey, were widely split today on the problem of the future of Cyprus.

After its first two months in office the new Transit Authority reported yesterday an improved spirit among its 44,000 employes. Only the city, itself, with about 185,000 persons on its payroll, has more workers in New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Sightseers at the United Nations are to get a break. Major alterations in prospect for the General Assembly building have been forced, a staff member said today, by the influx of crowds for which no facilities were planned by the builders.

Record sales and earnings were attained by the Harris-Seybold Company in its fiscal year ended June 30, George S. Dively, president, reported in the annual statement to shareholders and employes to be released today.
The Thor Corporation manufacturer of washing machines and other home appliances, is going into the paper business through purchase of the Allied Paper Mills of Kalamazoo, Mich.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Capt. John W. Kolb of the United States Army, with a score of 198, took the lead in the service rifle championships of the United States today. He was followed by four Marines.

In withholding its approval of the contract between the Argentine Government and the Standard Oil Company of California the Argentine Congress seems to be in agreement with Prof. Robert J. Alexander, whose letter appeared in your columns on July 9.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 1 -- The Sultan of Morocco granted an audience today to Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour, whose job it is to get him off the throne.
VIENNA, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Austrian war prisoners arriving from the Soviet Union said today three Americans confined in a Soviet camp near Moscow would leave for the West Monday.
Philip Loeb, well-known actor, was found dead from an apparent overdose of sleeping pills in a room in the Taft Hotel last night.
A weekly series of radio broadcasts from Moscow will be initiated by the National Broadcasting Company on Wednesday from 10:20 to 10:30 P. M.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Sept. 1 -- Israel announced tonight there would be no further military action against Egypt "provided that all attacks by Egyptians, in whatever form, will cease."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The United States ordered Hungary today to halt all propaganda activities in this country. The action was in retaliation for Hungarian arrests and harassment of American personnel in Budapest.
Four eye specialists concurred yesterday in their findings that Paul Muni, star of "Inherit the Wind," is "most likely" suffering from a tumor of the left eye.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 1 -- The Argentine Congress swiftly passed legislation today to put Buenos Aires once again in a state of siege.
Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn and Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, will meet tonight in the ten-round featherweight main event at Madison Square Garden. They have met twice, each winning once.

The five-story building with frontage of twenty feet at 416 East Fiftieth Street, near Beekman Place, has been sold by A. G. Kehoe to Cedric J. Janien, president of the Bar Steel Construction Company.
Customs officers confirmed here yesterday that the cache of narcotics found Wednesday on the French freighter Saint Lo consisted of 94 to 96 per cent pure heroin.

Motorists traveling in the metropolitan area during the three-day holiday week-end may expect detours or delays -- owing to new construction, repairs or congestion -- on these routes (the numbers correspond to those on the map):

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Phenix City Story," an Allied Artists melodrama featuring John McIntire, Richard Kiley, Kathryn Grant, Edward Andrews and Lenka Peterson, is at Loew's State.
DUBLIN, Sept. 1 (UP) -- A United States astronomer told the International Astronomical Union's Assembly today that he had discovered two new stars.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines said today that in the last twelve months Mexico reached the highest economic activity in her history.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- The reconstruction of R. K. O. Radio Pictures as a major factor in the motion-picture business as well as its future development as an important force in television was forecast today.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- New York State got a new education commissioner today.
With fair weather in prospect for the Labor Day week-end traffic and transportation officials prepared yesterday for a possible travel record.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 1 -- The visiting Russian farm experts were whisked out of Winnipeg today after violent demonstrations by threatening, screaming anti-Communists had marred their reception in this city late last night.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Oliver Prince Smith of the Marine Corps, a hero of the Korean conflict, retired from active duty here this afternoon. He had more than thirty-eight years of service that spanned three major wars.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Ambassador to Britain, said today that peace was the most popular word in the Soviet Union because his countrymen had suffered so much from war.

Congratulation on your recent timely editorial entitled "The Steel Settlement" in which you briefly review the last three settlements in the basic steel negotiations and other factors affecting wage settlement since World War II.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 -- The outcome of the conferences between Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu and Secretary of State Dulles aroused sharp political differences in Japan today.
Six youths were accused yesterday of attempting to rob an ice peddler by holding flaming torches to his feet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- For the first time since the end of the Korean War the Office of Defense Mobilization will use Government funds to acquire machine tools and equipment for its defense mobilization base.

The State of New Mexico announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Sept. 23 on $8,879,000 of building bonds bearing interest of not more than 2 1/2 per cent. Dated July 1, 1955, the bonds will come due serially on July 1 from 1956 to 1965.

Frank Lane, general manager of the Chicago White Sox, was fined $500 yesterday by Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball. Lane also was ordered to make a public apology for "unbecoming conduct" in Chicago last Tuesday night.

A study of the childhood, youth and early manhood of Henry James will be published Sept. 15 by Bookman Associates. "Young Henry James" is written by Robert C. Le Clair, associate professor of English and American Literature at the Principia College, Elsah, Ill.

So far this year twenty-two companies have sought and received the dignity of New York Stock Exchange listing. Last year there were seventeen. Listing has cost them money and will continue to cost them money for fifteen years if the securities remain on the Big Board.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Despite the failure of the Cabinet to act on the bank rate, Government stocks continued to slide today. But industrial shares were encouraged to recover part of their early falls.

Just ten years after he signed the instrument of surrender on the battleship Missouri, Mamoru Shigemitsu is in this country, and in New York, as the Foreign Minister of his Government. He is undertaking to clarify the position of his country on matters of self-defense and to strengthen his conservative fellow-citizens in Japan through an assurance of further support from the United States.

There comes a time each year when, as all the world knows, a proprietor must bar his private road in order to maintain his legal rights to it, although he is perfectly willing, week after week and month after month, to let the public use it freely.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- A suit charging breach of contract and asking $470,116 in damages from Twentieth Century-Fox was filed in Federal District Court today on behalf of Frank Ross, the producer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A clash between the Legislative and Executive Branches of the Government over their Constitutional powers appears to be fore-shadowed in a request by a Senate committee to the Defense Department.
Eight flying lizards soared from Singapore to the Bronx Zoo yesterday -- by plane. The rare creatures were sent by Dr. William Beebe.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 2 -- The first suburban branch of Stern Brothers, Manhattan department store, was opened here today. It is in the Plaza shopping district between Middle Neck and Great Neck Roads, just opposite the Long Island Rail Road station.
New issues of securities will continue to come to market in moderate volume as the calendar heads into the last month of summer.
Wall Street has a stake in the shell business. A leading downtown banking house recently came to the aid of a young company dealing in oyster shells.
Volume ebbed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but quiet buying, notably in leading chemicals and motors, sent prices higher for the twelfth successive session.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits has called for the establishment of a state-wide system of public defenders for youths accused of crimes and unable to afford private lawyers. The public defender is a public official who is paid by the government to function as counsel to indigent individuals.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Today's grain trade was largely a matter of evening up for the long week-end, and prices were fairly steady in all pits. Commission buying was in evidence on the dips, but with still no disposition to follow bulges.

On July 24 you published a letter from James A. Michener dated July 8, Kabul, Afghanistan, criticizing our Government for lack of medical care for American civilians living there. He declared that an important American outpost has been erected there without adequate medical facilities.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 2 -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., announced agreement today on a three-year contract. It covers 17,770 production workers in six plants in five states. The company makes farm and electrical equipment.

HAVING passed through the most serious period of the Davy Crockett revival almost unscathed, this country appears to be about to enter the Dan'l Boone phase, for inquiries on bears and bear hunting are flowing across our desk.
NEW LONDON, Conn. Sept. 2 (AP) -- David F. du Pont was injured fatally early today in an automobile accident on near-by Fishers Island, New York. He was 21 years old.
TETERBORO, N. J., Sept. 2 -- The strike - bound Bendix Aviation Corporation plant was shut down completely early today until Tuesday morning to avert possible new violence.

An 18 - year - old thug, seized in the Bronx yesterday after a hold-up, confessed that he and four of his relatives had committed thirty robberies in the Bronx and Manhattan in the last four months, according to the police.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Governor Harriman warned today that the Russians, in being friendly, might be stalling.

Your complete coverage of the recent defeat of the highway legislation in Congress and your editorials -- particularly "Good Roads Lobbied to Death" -- were important contributions to the cause of good highways.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 2 -- A bid by the Communist bloc to restore its commercial and political relations with Yugoslavia was the dominant feature of the Zagreb fair, which opened today.
A passport has been refused Waldo Frank, American novelist and essayist, to attend an international literary conference in Peiping next month.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia has accepted a Soviet offer to deliver equipment and raw material for the production of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. This was announced tonight by Vice President Svetozar Vukmanovic-Tempo in an interview with the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- Misfortune continues to dog Alvin Dark. The Giant's hustling shortstop and captain, who only yesterday returned to the line-up after he had suffered a fractured rib at Cincinnati last Aug. 7, was injured in the sixth inning of the game between the Giants and Phillies at Connie Mack stadium tonight.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 2 -- A special committee will begin work soon in Mississippi to study methods of cutting down the number of Negro voters.

A situation which we have permitted to exist for approximately thirty years cannot be corrected in a year or two. I am referring to the situation on the waterfront of New York harbor, which is now being so strongly attacked by the people of both New York State and the State of New Jersey through the Waterfront Commission of New York harbor.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- A healthy swing at the post-Geneva policy of the United States Government was taken in the Soviet press today -- by an American commentator.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of Economics, announced today measures to force down prices to curb labor's growing demand for higher wages.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- British police announced today they were seeking a Chinese for conspiracy to cause the crash last April of a plane carrying Communist delegates to the Bandung conference. A warrant charging a murder conspiracy was issued here but police said the Chinese had fled to Formosa, the Nationalist China base.

Racing Fool of the Cain Hoy Stable made the figures "stand up" in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The crowd of 16,736 established the son of Jet Pilot the even-money favorite against four others in the mile and a sixteenth event and Racing Fool responded with a three-quarter-length triumph.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2. The Sears Roebuck Foundation announced today a $125,000 grant to assist newly practicing physicians.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 13 points off to 6 points up yesterday. The near months showed the most weakness.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 2 -- The leaders of the Western Liberal parties are uncertain and deeply troubled about the proper way to deal with Communist subversion in a democratic state.

Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet maker, suffered a net loss of $2,019,159 in the six months ended June 25 compared with one of $1,038,741 in the similar period a year ago. Net sales declined to $14,812,149 from $18,724,113.
Carmelo (Chubby) Costa of Brooklyn, rising a sharp left hook to advantage, gained a split decision over Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, in the ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Billy Graham, the evangelist, a major figure in the current religious revival, said here tonight that this revival was in some ways "hollow."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 2 -- Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali listed Kashmir today as "the great moral issue of our time." He said eight years of procrastination on Pakistan's demand for a plebiscite in Kashmir had created 'great tension" in Pakistan.

An appraisal of American foreign policy during World War I, entitled "Woodrow Wilson and the Balance of Power," will be published Oct. 24 by the Indiana University Press. The author is Edward Buehrig, a professor in the Department of Government at Indiana University.
With the help of American know-how, the port of Pusan, Korea, may become a self-supporting civilian, ocean terminal within a decade.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- After selling stock in himself to finance a vacation junket to Texas, a 16- year-old high school boy was back home today paying his debts. And he reported that the Lone Star State had won his heart so thoroughly that he intended to return to it some day to live.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Harold E. Stassen, Special Assistant to the President for Disarmament, predicted today that President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon would head the Republican ticket in 1956.
Stockholders of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation at a special meeting in San Francisco approved an increase in the authorized $50 par preferred stock to 1,500,000 from 700,000 shares.
TOKYO, Sept. 2 -- The tenth aniversary of Japan's formal surrender in World War II passed almost unnoticed here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The British Government has lodged a formal protest against the rejection by this country of bids by an English manufacturer to furnish equipment for the Chief Joseph Dam in the State of Washington.

I read with interest the letter of Marianne L. Black, secretary of the New York City Committee of the National Women's party, printed in your issue of Aug. 22, on the failure of Governor Harriman to designate even a single woman among the seven New York State Officials who were sworn in by Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio recently.
Federal officials and traffic police had a foretaste yesterday of peak-of-the season congestion along the trans-Atlantic piers.
Shovels, spades, ropes and even heavy cords are now in demand in the flood-damaged New England communities.

Atlas Corporation during July reduced its holdings of RKO Pictures Corporation common stock by 26,500 shares, according to the monthly New York Stock Exchange report of changes in ownership. As a result Atlas' holdings declined to 973,500 shares, the report noted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today excessive speed on a curve caused the derailment of a New York, New Haven and Hartford's passenger train at Bridgeport, Conn., July 14.

MAIZURU, Japan, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The son of the late pre-war Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, is serving a twenty-five-year sentence in a Soviet prison on a charge of supporting capitalism, a Japanese repatriate said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Both major political parties stepped up their campaigns for 1956 today, nearly a year before the national conventions.

"Tiger Girl," a Russian-made comedy in Sovcolor of circus life, will open today at the Stanley. Lena Kasatkina, Peter Kadochnikov and Lev Bykov are featured in the Lenfilm Production, which was directed by A. Ivanovsky. There are English titles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, reported today that she told the Venice Film Festival she did not care to participate in any program that included the United States movie "Blackboard Jungle."
DENVER, Sept. 2 -- President Eisenhower received from Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov today a color portrait of the marshal with his family.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Rochester phase of the Government's investigation into the slaying of Maj. William V. Holohan ended today as mysteriously as it began and a United States attorney here said no evidence would be taken "at this time."
Fifteen Greek seaman indicated yesterday that their tribulations did not end when they were pulled out of the stormy Atlantic two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Defense Mobilizer Arthur S. Flemming will hold a hearing on Sept. 12 on whether the Government should help finance a new petroleum pipeline from Texas to the East Coast.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station in Brooklyn was "occupied" by 160 youngsters from the Police Athletic League yesterday afternoon, and it was nearly overwhelmed in the process.

The very thought of forty-eight Republican state chairmen fluttering down out of the skies above Denver and coming to rest in a flock virtually on the summer White House lawn might make a lesser man shrink. But Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose tranquil vacation will next week thus be so rudely interrupted, is not the sort to run away from duty to his country, or to his party.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- The new Secretary of the Air Force said tonight that President Eisenhower's plan for "mutual surveillance against surprise attack" should be acceptable to any nation not planning aggression.

Oscar Panno, chess champion of Argentina, was set back by Paul Keres, former Soviet titleholder, in the twelfth round of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, according to a report received last night through Swedish news sources.
The report of the Cessna Aircraft Company yesterday disclosed increased sales and earnings for the nine months ended June 30.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 2 -- Hollywood studios will be humming with activity after Labor Day as the result of a combined filming spurt by producers of both theatrical and television motion pictures.

Communist broadcasts from Peiping are trumpeting that outside powers -- presumably the United States -- are trying to sabotage the plan for an election in Vietnam next July. The objection to the election as set forth in the Geneva agreement is coming, of course, from South Vietnam rather than from the United States.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- Moscow's National Hotel began to look like an annex to Capitol Hill today. Five members of the United States Congress, a Supreme Court justice and a Senate Committee counsel and their wives streamed in and out of the lobby.
Three hundred and thirty pints of blood were contributed yesterday at Fort Monmouth, N. J., to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
DUBLIN, Sept. 2 (AP) -- University of Michigan scientists told the International Astronomy Conference today they had made a long stride toward determining just how the sun was put together.
Fourteen men and three teen-agers, all of Brooklyn, were rounded up early yesterday on charges of possessing stolen pistols and of violating the Sullivan Law.

We have reached the rehabilitation stage in coping with Diane's devastation. The rescue work is done. Now the rebuilding of public works by Army engineers and local agencies, Government loans to help finance repairs and reconstruction and direct help by private agencies are the order of the day.
CONSTANTINE, Algeria, Sept. 2 -- French "minute men" are being armed here to combat the simmering terrorist rebellion.
CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Australia is applying for a large loan in a drive to avoid adopting new cuts of imports, Government sources here disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- "Medical Horizons," a new live A. B. C.-TV series covering the field of contemporary medicine, will begin on the network on Monday, Sept. 12. The program will be televised weekly by remote pick-up from institutions and research centers throughout the nation.
Two United States patrol escort ships were turned over to the Republic of Korea Navy yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

Eight high school boys from Los Angeles, just returned from the 100th anniversary international convention of the Young Men's Christian Association in Paris, told yesterday of a thirteen-country bus tour through Europe.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- Livingston T. Merchant, United States Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, conferred today with Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, on Western tactics for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference next month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- All-weather, any-time air support using new equipment for ground troops was announced today by the Marine Corps. The equipment is a radar guidance system that was combat-tested in Korea. It can direct aircraft flying blind to military targets and can control bomb releases with the accuracy of artillery.

Adaptations of works by well-known writers will set the pace for the new "Pontiac's Playwright Hour," which will be seen on the National Broadcasting Company television network every Tuesday beginning Oct. 4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A member of Congress returning from inspections of the radar defenses of the Western Hemisphere reported today that he had been informed that Canadians were manning some attack-warning stations only eight hours a day.
Last Sunday Karl Spooner held the Cardinals to one run in beating them. Last night at Ebbets Field the young southpaw cut it a little finer, allowing the Pittsburgh Pirates no runs at all.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Swaps, who lost his $100,000 match race to Nashua Wednesday at Washington Park, faces surgery on his injured right front foot that probably will keep him out of action until next year, his owner said today.
Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish bodies have issued Labor Day statements hailing the organized labor movement, but cautioning in some instances against the misuse of power.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Office of Education today predicted a 2,000,000 increase in school enrollment this year. The total would then be 32,000,000.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff announced today that the Federal Government is releasing large amounts of copper to Connecticut industrial plants.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area fell by $87,000,000 last month to a total of $2,457,000,000.
WAYNESBURG, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP) -- An archaeological crew has dug into the soil of Greene County and come up with apparent proof that an Indian village existed in the area as far back as 1100 or 1200.

The twelve-story office building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 15-17 East Fortieth Street has been sold by the Security Mutual Life Insurance Company to investing clients of Julian Bernstein, attorney. It is assessed at $650,000. The seller will continue to use its present space there.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Instead of letters, tape recorders will link Dr. and Mrs. Roger W. Richardson and their son, Hamilton, after the youth begins studies this month at Oxford University.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, romping through the offerings of five pitchers with fourteen hits, maintained their lead in the American League Pennant race tonight with an 8-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the opener of a four-game series.

A recent news item told of a new marvel in faraway Jakarta, a wonder that has stirred the breasts of Indonesians young and old. This great delight is an exhibit in the American pavilion at the Jakarta fair. It is a model train.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The stock market closed today with an extension of the losses in Government stocks and with industrial shares still drifting downward. Figures on the decline in gold and dollar reserves came too late to have much effect.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing cost had risen to the highest point in more than two years.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 -- The Indian Government entered today into a verbal battle with one of the founders of the republic. The struggle may affect the lives and health of millions in India.

BOCHUM, Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, in a final speech before his trip to Moscow next week, said tonight the struggle between Western and Communist ideologies "will continue for decades until we have achieved victory."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The United States Soldiers' Home, for more than 100 years a sanctuary for old or disabled veterans, received its first woman former soldier today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 (UP) -- A Federal Judge here ordered the Army today to release a soldier being held for court-martial on charges of disloyalty while a prisoner-of-war in North Korea.
BRISTOL, England, Sept. 2 -Workmen are digging into the south bank of the Thames Estuary in the hope of unearthing the remaining skull bones of the oldest known human being in Europe.

The Big Board has always been generous. An employe yesterday, observing that the Exchange community's gift of $151,048 for flood relief was the biggest single contribution, took a look at the record. It is meticulously complete back to 1836 in the quarto, half-calf minutes of the governing board.
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- British officials appeared pessimistic tonight with the end of the opening phase of the British-Greek-Turkish talks on the future of Cyprus.
Installment credit outstanding is in a healthier condition than at any time since World War II, the National Foundation for Consumer Credit said yesterday.

Your editorial "A Bad Immigration Law" is more timely and much more important than perhaps you realize. The Refugee Relief Act is becoming increasingly a moral and political menace to this country. I had stark evidence of this during the summer as I visited refugee camps in Europe and talked with many Government and religious workers attempting to deal with the refugee problem.
The Labor Day week-end, the last long one of summer, began yesterday with crowds swarming into and out of New York.
Behind each worker in the country is some $12,500 worth of equipment that makes the job possible. The figure is going steadily up.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox coupled four of their eight hits with an error in the eighth to score four times and beat the Baltimore Orioles, 8 -- 3, tonight.

Rubber futures climbed to the highest level since 1952 yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Speculator buying and light short covering were induced by strength in London and Singapore. Dealer and short selling limited the rise.
NEWARK, Sept. 2 -- The New Jersey Public Service-Coordinated Transport came up with a proposal today that may remove a threatened conflict between New Jersey and New York tokens.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Two population experts estimated today that the male college graduate would receive an average of $100,000 more in lifetime income than the average high school graduate.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Pakistan cotton year for 1955-56, which starts today, is expected to yield about 1,850,000 bales of cotton, compared with about 1,650,000 bales last year, according to the traders' estimate released here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- The United States is expected to reply early next week to the Soviet Union's call for acceptance of the "major" features of the Soviet disarmament plan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UP) -- Ernie Banks broke the major league record for home runs by a shortstop today. He walloped his fortieth homer of the year to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 12-2 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals. A ladies' day crowd of 14,693 saw the game.
In many homes the waffle iron has been covered and stored on a high shelf till the hot-bread-for-breakfast season returns in the fall.
Portchester Properties, Inc., has purchased two apartment houses in the Bronx through Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The French Government decided today to send nine more battalions to Algeria. At the same time reform measures were drawn up to reduce some of the basic causes of tension in the four Algerian departments.
Collectively and individually, the Yankees had a jubilant homecoming yesterday.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 2 (UP) -- The constitutionality of New York State's new uniform jury law was upheld today by Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 -- Under the new import rules, announced here today, all goods brought into the country will be broken down into four categories. They will be essential goods, subject to 50 per cent tax; semi-essential goods subject to 100 per cent tax; semi-luxury goods, and luxury goods whose import tax will be decided at auction.
The threatened strike of 35,000 nonoperating employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad, scheduled for last midnight, was postponed yesterday morning.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- The American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., reached agreement today on provisions of a new contract. The accord, covering 24,000 employes of the company, came after twenty-two-and-one-half hours of almost continuous bargaining and brought to an abrupt end a strike that began at midnight.

HALIFAX, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Chronicle-Herald says the Nova Scotia Government will announce within two weeks the signing of an agreement with the Hearst Corporation of New York for the construction of a $17,000,000 paper plant at Sheet Harbor, fifty miles east of here.
BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Some fifty eastern Massachusetts communities, including Boston, have postponed the start of school because of the outbreak of poliomyelitis.
GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- There has been a significant increase in Western Europe's imports from Eastern Europe, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- A Senate subcommittee said today it had asked Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, to intervene in the "shocking" discharge of an Army lieutenant involved in a guilt-by-kinship security case.
Elmer F. (Trigger) Burke, 38-year-old hoodlum linked to a series of slayings, was arraigned yesterday on a first-degree murder charge.
OUED ZEM, French Morocco, Sept. 2 -- The outlook for a political settlement in Morocco took a sudden turn for the worse today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 2 -- Residential garbage service was reduced to one pick-up a week today as William Gill Jr., City Manager, dismissed 287 city employes in a move to block a drive to unionize city workers.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 2 -- President Juan D. Peron assured visiting politicians from the Province of Cordoba today that they had nothing to worry about.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, gave new assignments to- [day to six generals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Two Bronx business men got a design patent this week for an invention with the intriguing title of "worm feeder." It turns out to be a floating dish in which an aquarium can serve worms to his pet fish.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Forty-nine craft started early tonight on the Stamford Yacht Club's annual race to Martha's Vineyard.
PARIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A United States Army corporal, jailed following an automobile accident, got a three-hour leave today -- to get married.

Hilda Chester was at Ebbets Field last night when the Dodgers met the Pittsburgh Pirates. Hilda hadn't been there since Sunday, however, and as a result things had been comparatively quiet at the home of the Brooks.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Sam Snead and Mike Souchak carved five-under-par 66's today to share the first-round lead in the $20,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.

Melvyn Douglas has agreed to take over the starring role of the defense attorney in "Inherit the Wind" starting Sept. 17. He will succeed Paul Muni, who was compelled to withdraw from the part on Tuesday because of a serious eye ailment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The United States has placed a "hold for October" label on virtually all major official proposals for further liberalizing relations with the Soviet Union.
HONG KONG, Sept. 2 -- The Communist - controlled Democratic Republic of Vietnam celebrated its tenth anniversary with a demonstration and military parade in Hanoi today.
Ten years to the day after Japan surrendered, Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu found out yesterday how he had come to be tried as a war criminal.
ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- A clever and effective performance of Shakespeare's "The Tempest" was given tonight by the Empire State Music Festival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UP) -- The Government's chief disease recorder predicted today the polio toll this year would fall far short of the 1952 epi- demic figure but would top the "mild" polio . years of 1950 and 1951.

Fat sputtering out of the frying pan and into the fire was responsible for property losses of more than $50,000,000 in the last decade, statisticians say. The fires were small at the start -- a little grease from frying pan, broiler or griddle -- but lives and money were lost in the end.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Navy today undertook without much hope of success, an effort to collect $133,000 paid by mistake to 1,400 sailors for "sea duty" during the Korean conflict.

The basement of an old barn on Long Ridge Road, Stamford, Conn., is the site of an interesting restaurant, the Country Kitchen. It gives a refreshing impression of old-fashioned rusticity. Whitewashed walls are hung with iron household utensils.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The index of primary market prices was unchanged at 110.5 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods were offset by higher prices for industrial commodities.

Radio Corporation of America is considering raising $100,000,000 in the public market to keep the company's capital on a level with its expanding business. The company's management is discussing with Lehman Brothers and Lazard Freres the possibility of putting out an issue of subordinated convertible debentures totaling $100,000,000 in anticipation of future capital needs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- New and improved air service between New York and Chicago was authorized today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 2 -- The neighborhood has disappeared, but 77-year-old George Grimsey and his Cairn terrier Scotty live on alone in a house spared by the wreckers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Greater progress against racial discrimination has been achieved since the start of the Eisenhower Administration than in any similar period since the Civil War, Herbert Brownell Jr. said tonight.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- The Soviet Union invited the United States Ambassador, Charles E. Bohlen, today to visit its top-secret atomic power station.
CHATHAM, Ont., Sept. 2 -- The Russian farm delegation moved through this lush farming area today in a cloak-and-dagger atmosphere.
NOW that American families have taken two-car prosperity in stride, small pleasure boats are being added to middle income luxuries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 2 -- Psychological research conducted at Harvard University suggests a great incongruity between the basic personality patterns of the Russian people and the behavior of the Soviet regime itself.

Tony Trabert began his quest for his third major tennis crown of the year with the start of the seventy-fifth championships of the United States at Forest Hills yesterday.
Improved selling of fashions at retail, owing largely to cooler weather, has brought store buyers back into the market for heavy reorders, resident buying offices report.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP) -- J. Rukin Jelks' Miss Todd, California's 2-year-old filly queen, led all the way to win the $29,970 Del Mar Debutante today.

Cornell University will expand its automotive crash research program under two grants of $200,000 each last week from the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 3 -- Officials at the French Residency here now expect to be unable to meet the Sept. 12 deadline set by the French Premier for the formation of a representative Moroccan government.

MONTAUK, N. Y. -- Camping trips and fun at the seashore do not have to be ruled out of an after-Labor Day vacation. Barring the occasional vagaries of the weather, summer will keep right on going, here on Long Island's easternmost extremity, for several weeks to come.

BASEL, Switzerland, Sept. 3 (UP) -- About 300 delegates from Europe, Latin America, South Africa and Israel opened a four-day congress of the European B'nai B'rith organization here today to found a grand lodge for continental Europe.

Dr. Harahap's new Government in Indonesia has acted with commendable promptness and wise foresight in changing the pattern of import trade controls. Some duties will go up, but the net effect is expected to be a far greater emphasis upon necessity rather than luxury imports.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- Larry Doby hit two home runs and Early Wynn hurled a six-hitter today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Chicago White Sox, 6 -- 1, to even their series.
