CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 -- Claims for unemployment compensation dropped to 7,566, lowest figure in twenty-three months, as business continued brisk in the Greater Cleveland area. A year ago at this time new and continued unemployment claims aggregated 21,000.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 -- Business activity in general is continuing to expand in the Southeast. Non-farm employment and department store sales have reached new high ground. At the same time, farm conditions are showing improvement, with prices of most important crops and livestock products, except corn and hogs, topping last year's levels.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Sept. 3 -- crowd of more than 15,000 persons heard Billy Graham tonight in Auditorium Park. Ocean Grove Auditorium was filled, the overflow crowded the Young People's Temple and loudspeakers carried the evangelist's words to thousands in the park.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A runaway research balloon drifted slowly across western Minnesota today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- United States information specialists are trying to devise a new strategy to meet a baffling Soviet propaganda twist that has turned the East-West battle of the air waves upside down.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is on the way to revamping the system's scattered mortgage debt on a scale outranking any comparable effort in the nation's railroad history.

PELHAM, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Another predicted-log triumph in power cruising navigation was registered this afternoon on Long Island Sound by Elias Kalil of Manhasset in his new Chris Craft yacht, Irene K. IV.
THE man-hours devoted to shopping around for just the right ingredients for a certain household project probably run up into figures that only an IBM machine could handle.

About a million dollars worth of musical instruments were stuffed into a trans-Atlantic plane last night. One hundred and four musicians boarded two other craft at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Two ministers who sat on a church trial board that returned a unanimous verdict of innocent in the heresy trial of a young Lutheran pastor repudiated their decisions last night and advocated a new trial.

RED BANK, N. J., Sept. 3 -- A woman Democrat who is enjoying her third term as Mayor of this predominantly Republican town was further honored this week. Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed her chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the $300,000,000 Garden State Parkway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- There is a lot of talk around here about the political ideas and future of Vice President Nixon, much of it based on the false assumption that he will play the same role in the campaign of 1956 as he did in 1954.

A STEPLADDER kit has a strongly braced back section, rubber feet to prevent skidding, and a recessed tray top for holding nuts and bolts or various tools. It can be put together in an hour with only a screwdriver and a wrench, according to the manufacturer.

Searching and Talora were the winners of the Vagrancy Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The seven-furlong race for fillies and mares was contested in two divisions, each worth a gross of $28,725, with each of the successful ones earning $19,675.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Critics of the Administration's personnel security program tossed more logs on the fire this week, thus keeping it burning for the 1956 political campaign.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers romped to a 9-1 victory at Cardiff today and led a burst of scoring in English League soccer.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 3 -- Dick Maioceo of New York won two races today as United States track and field stars captured five of six events during an international meet.

Henry Cabot Lodge said last night that Americans could be optimistic that World War III would never come. He tempered his hopeful statement, however with a warning that the nation's armed forces must be held ready indefinitely to fight "local wars."

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Undefeated in the New York State Chess Association championship, Edmar Mednis of Manhattan beat John T. Westbrock of Brooklyn in the seventh round today for a score of 6 1/2 -- 1/2.

IN appraising the work of the first session of the Eighty-fourth Congress in the field of conservation, it is necessary to say that its major achievement was a negative one; temporary defeat of the proposal to build Echo Park Dam inside the Dinosaur National Monument on the Utah-Colorado border.
A $109,500,000 construction program is getting under way to transform the Pan-American route into a broad highway from the Guatemalan-Mexican frontier to the Panama Canal.

IN many ways the 1955 season has been discouraging for gladiolus shows and showmen. The extreme heat and drought of July and early August forced many varieties into early and inferior bloom. In the Atlantic Coast and Northeast areas hurricane winds and rainstorms hit right at the height of the show season and made it difficult or impossible for many exhibitors to make entries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, will personally review the controversial discharge given to First Lieut. Walter K. Novak last month. Security charges, involving his parents and sister, had been made against the officer.
HONOLULU, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The problem of alcoholism was high on the agenda of the Protestant Episcopal Church convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Department store sales in the Twelfth District continued to show steady gains over similar reporting periods in 1954. Sales gains were general throughout the district although both Spokane and Salt Lake stores almost doubled the district's average Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans outstanding increased $16,000,000 for the week ended Aug. 24.

Five times within a stroke of defeat, Hamilton Richardson had an almost miraculous reprieve yesterday in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 -- Is the West Coast tired of bush league baseball -- or is it apathetic about baseball altogether?
FLORENCE, N. J., Sept. 3 -- A new, massive vehicular bridge over the now subdued but still muddy Delaware is rapidly taking shape here.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 3 -- Crowds reminiscent of the Christmas season crowded shopping centers in the Southwest last week to provide a record sales volume. The combination of cooler weather, back-to-school and seasonal apparel purchases was credited with the good results attained.

UNLESS present trends are violently altered, Ted Williams will finish out this season with the highest batting average in the majors, just as he did a year ago, and he still won't win a hitting championship. The rules insist on a minimum of 400 times at bat as a qualification for such a title. The Thunderer from Boston hasn't a chance of getting to the plate that often.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs, after failing to get a man on base for six and two-thirds innings, erupted for three runs in the eighth inning today to nip the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3.

The biggest boating season since the "Merrie Monarch," Charles II, introduced the sport of yachting to the English-speaking world in 1660 is now drawing to a close. And the center of all this salty congestion is in New York.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Inspired no doubt by a report that the Chancellor of the Exchequer almost certainly laid before a recent Cabinet meeting on developments in Britain's economic situation, Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden delivered a speech couched in terms so somber the whole country was aroused. This was reflected in a further stock market decline.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (UP) -- All the principal subjects in a year-old $18,000 hold-up in Philadelphia have been arrested here, in Brooklyn, New York, and Camden, N. J., the police announced today.
Robert Moses struck back yesterday at "certain bird watchers" who had complained about his plan for converting the Ramble in Central Park into a recreational center for older people.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 4 -- The French authorities here are alarmed by the present political crisis and are preparing for possible serious disturbances.

The packaging industry, riding the current boom in consummer goods and capitalizing on the rapid growth of self-service retailing, will have its biggest year in 1955. More than ten billion dollars will be spent by American manufacturers to package products of every description in paper boxes, tin cans, collapsible metal tubes, cellophane wrappings, plastic bottles and a variety of other containers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Defense Department officials will resume this week their studies of a dozen proposals for business reorganization within the department made by the Hoover Commission.
SALEM, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Don Da Vault, steering the 136-cubic- inch class speed boat Blue Blaze, captured two heats for a perfect score of 800 points today off Oakwood Beach on the Delaware River.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The number of persons holding jobs reached the record figure of 65,500,000 in August.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 4 -- H. H. Wemmers, chairman of the Dutch state coal mines, expressed fear last week that Western Europe faced a fuel shortage.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 4 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party, in a major political decision, called today for an end of "peaceful invasions" of the Portuguese colony of Goa.
Christianity and the working man was the theme of sermons in Protestant churches yesterday and will be emphasized in Roman Catholic churches today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians took over first place in the American League pennant race today by sweeping a doubleheader from the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 3 and 5 -- 3. Ralph Kiner's double in the first game and homers by Al Rosen and Al Smith in the second decided before a crowd of 52,487.

The store and office building at 570 Bergen Avenue, corner of Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of Bert H. Boxer, attorney, for cash over a mortgage of $41,000. It also contains Gleason's Gymnasium, a training place for prizefighters.

BRISTOL, England, Sept. 4 -- The Sussex constabulary was mobilized today to deal with the worst-kept ornithological secret in Britain: Two pairs of exotically colored bee eaters, exceedingly rare birds from south Europe, have nested in the hamlet of Streat on the south downs of Sussex.
CAIRO, Monday, Sept. 5 -- Four Israelis were killed when "gangs" last night breached the cease-fire line along the border of the Gaza strip, an Egyptian spokesman said early today.

IF the Chicago White Sox should win the American League pennant -- this is far from being a remote possibility -- considerable credit will have to go to a comparatively unknown pitcher named Dick Donovan. Remove him from the roster and the Pale Hose would not even be in contention, because he's scored more victories than any other pitcher on the staff.
The International Longshoremen's Association renewed its attack yesterday on the Waterfront Commission with warnings of possible wildcat strikes.
HONOLULU, Sept. 4 -- The top-ranking Protestant Episcopal clergyman of the United States called upon his church tonight to speak out boldly on great social issues confronting the modern world.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The gates of the centuries-old Leipzig Autumn Fair swung open today. Soviet exhibitors were conspicuous by their absence.
The pleasant weather brought out 7,000 to Forest Hills for the national championships yesterday and everyone must have had his fill of good tennis.

That the pages of The Times are a veritable treasury of bits of current information which neither the scholar nor the amateur observer of contemporary history can afford to miss is, by now, taken for granted. What gives added zest to the careful reading of the pages of The Times is that often its detailed reports are not in consonance with the generalizations and the unctuous propaganda speeches of big-name political figures.
Liberals in the Protestant Episcopal Church were characterized yesterday as "subversives" who seek to overthrow its traditional teachings.

ROCKLAND COUNTY now boasts three regional wihes of its own, products of the rocky mountainside of High Tor in New City. The best, which is labeled Rockland Red, makes no pretension to greatness. A young wine, it is a bit rough but pleasingly dry with a nice bouquet and color.

Storm warnings on the need for caution in drawing the city's capital budget of physical improvements to be progressed in 1956 have come from several officials recently, including Mayor Wagner, Chairman Bennett of the Planning Commission, Controller Gerosa and now from Budget Director Beame.

AS many viewers on the West Coast long have been aware, Dr. Frank C. Baxter has a winning way with Shakespeare. Dr. Baxter is an erudite and witty Professor of English Literature at the University of Southern California. His programs, called "Shakespeare on TV," had a great appeal when they were broadcast originally from Hollywood.
A brisk little man looked up from the plans for two new $30,000,000 passenger liners last week to accept birthday congratulations and to give a few expert opinions on the nation's merchant marine.

An analysis of life on the Pacific coast in the Eighteen Forties by Norman A. Graebner will be published Sept. 15 by Ronald Press. The title is "Empire on the Pacific: A Study in American Continental Expansion."

" A most generous gift" that will make possible the construction of a school of theology in Garden City, L. I., was announced today by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island. The gift was made by Mrs. Helen B. Mercer of New York in memory of her husband, George Mercer Jr., lawyer, business executive and yachtsman. The building will be named the George Mercer Jr. Memorial Building.
The Red Cross announced yesterday the completion of its two-week appeal for $10,000,000 to aid Eastern flood victims.

TO freshmen, their first college room probably will be a disappointment. It may not look like home at first, but a lot can be done to make it more liveable. It will be the college girl's first attempt at decoration, an art in which every woman should develop her own proficiency.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 4 -- Delegates representing more than 8,000,000 British trade unionists assembled here today for the eighty-seventh annual meeting of the Trades Union Congress, opening tomorrow.
CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Edmar Mednis of the Marshall Chess Club succeeds William Lombardy of the same club as champion of the New York State Chess Association.
OTTAWA, Sept. 4 -- The Russian farm experts decided today to by-pass Toronto. They returned to Ottawa tonight, three days ahead of schedule.

It has been five years since the Board of Estimate began proceedings for a new retail market in Harlem. Now the market is an accomplished fact -- it will open this week. For years pushcart peddlers have occupied the space on the east side of Eighth Avenue from 143d Street to 145th Street where it has been erected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that world production of wheat this year may be near a record level despite the existence of surpluses from previous big crops.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (UP) -- With Carroll Hardy, a rookie from Colorado, running for two early touchdowns, the San Francisco 49ers coasted to a 43-7 exhibition victory today over the Chicago Cardinals.

The United Community Campaigns of America will open a drive for $300,000,000 today. Nearly 3,000,000 men and women volunteers over the country will seek to raise funds for 1,900 Community Chests and United Funds.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Out-of-town Star Class skippers tuning up for the North American championship provided the keenest competition in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 -- The steel industry is in for one of the most active periods in its history. Order volume has been heavy and would have been much heavier if mills had accepted all orders.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 4 -- The United States Government's new program to patch up differences between Israel and her Arab neighbors has paradoxically helped mend difficulties between pro-Western and pro-Soviet labor groups inside Israel.
On an office wall at the Men's Shelter, 8 East Third Street -- a short stone's throw from the Bowery -- hangs a wooden plaque bearing one word: "Others."
The door is wide open for the Christian in Africa, the Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia declared here yesterday.

As we celebrate Labor Day this week-end, in far-off Israel tribute will be paid to one of the architects of the modern American trade-union movement, the late Philip Murray. Histadrut, the Israel Labor Federation, will dedicate at Elath, the pioneer village at the tip of the Negev, a Cultural Center bearing the name of the late president of the C. I. O.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., Sept. 4 -- A 20-year-old man, accused of the $253 hold-up of a supermarket here yesterday, was jailed today on robbery charges. He was arrested in Manhattan at the home of a brother.
Junior Gilliam, who hit the first Brooklyn home run of the season off Max Surkont on opening day, April 13, belted another one off the same pitcher yesterday at Ebbets Field.
The highway bond issue which will be voted on by the people of New York State this November seems to be developing into quite a battle.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 4 -- The technical staff of Chancellor Adenauer's mission to Moscow departed tonight aboard a special train.
YOUNG women rich in taste but less fortunate in pocketbook are getting a generous slice of Fifth Avenue store attention these days. One indication is Saks's new Safinia collection in junior sizes.
HOLLYSWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- Three suspense-type story purchases, two by Universal-International and the other by Bert E. Friedlob, an independent producer, were announced today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept 4 -- Public meetings of five or more persons and carrying of arms were banned in the capital today for a month.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Members of the Stamford Yacht Club's race committee were awaiting the first boat to finish the annual Vineyard race tonight. More than forty-nine hours had elapsed since the fleet of forty-nine craft had taken off for Buzzards Bay Lightship.
The following booklets lot young people may be of interest to parents (available for 15 cents each from The Queen's Printer, Department of Public Printing and Stationery, Ottawa, Canada):

Good-by to the singing beach and to the seashells which could be found there as the night tide receded. All during the summer that beach had a lyric voice, one raised to praise the sun, the sparkling water, the slowly tumbling waves.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Irregular price moves marked grain trading last week. The relief from drought and heat conditions started free selling of corn and soybean futures, with sympathetic declines in wheat, rye and oats.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Sam Snead shot a five-under-par 66 for a fifty-four-hole total of 200 to gain undisputed possession of the lead in the $20,000 Insurance City open golf tournament today.

ZURICH, Sept. 4 -- "The collective market -- the basic problem in European integration" was the theme of deliberation over the week-end at the eleventh annual rally of the European Forum at Alpbach, in the Austrian Tyrol.
It cannot be said that the Yankees polished off the Senators at the Stadium yesterday with any degree of elegance. Nor was Casey Stengel around to see it done.

When Labor Day was first becoming an American holiday some sixty-five or seventy years ago the average work week was close to sixty hours and the average industrial pay envelope contained less than $11 each week. The $11 bought several times as much as $11 could buy today, but the sixty hours were real and arduous.

BRISTOL, England, Sept. 4 -- An electromechanical apparatus that apparently "learns" by experience and also forgets has been shown to visitors at this year's meetings of the British Association for the Advancement of Science here.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves defeated Cincinnati, 5 -- 2, on a pair of home runs by Henry Aaron and one by Eddie Mathews today. The game was played under protest by the Redlegs from the first inning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Mr. Lewis said he was not criticizing the merging of the two big unions this December, but objected to the constitution for the federation.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- The outlook for a settlement in French Morocco brightened somewhat today with the departure of a delegation that will confer with the exiled Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, in Madagascar.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 4 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox pounded out thirteen hits, including four by Sammy White, to take their third straight game from the Baltimore Orioles today, 5 -- 4.

Your editorial of Aug. 11 entitled "The Hell's Canyon Dams" and one published on July 28 dealing with the same subject are both based upon your assumption of a premise that full development of the river resource would be attained with a single Federal dam but somehow would not be attained by three dams built with taxpaying private capital which would utilize the same head of falling water in the same river.

How the average American working man can clothe his family for a whole season with the money he earns in three weeks' work will be shown in a dramatic exhibit, at the Berlin Industries Fair this month.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- Harry S. Truman said today he thought the people were ready for another change of administration.

After two weeks of serious clashes on the Gaza front joined in by tanks and jet planes and costing some three scores of lives, both Israel and Egypt have now accepted the cease-fire urged by the United Nations truce commission, and hopes for the preservation of the armistice in the Holy Land are rising again.
Cotton prices in the domestic market last week again held within a narrow trading range and closed the period with irregular net changes.

One film is scheduled to open here this week. This is "The Warriors," an Allied Artists presentation filmed in Cinema-Scope and Technicolor, which arrives at the Palace on Friday. Errol Flynn, Joanne Dru and Peter Finnch head the cast.

TRENTON, Sept. 4 -- A Senate subcommittee will move into New Jersey this month in an effort to fix responsibility for recurring gasoline price wars. Such rate-cutting has become widespread and increasingly serious in this state, particularly since 1949.
THE increasing predilection among Presidents as well as other men for casual clothes is viewed tolerantly, though not with whole-hearted approval, by Joseph E. Gillow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- United States officials said today that the six students who have been traveling in the Soviet Union without valid passports probably would not face charges when they returned.
New York State faces the most serious teacher shortage in it's history.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 4 -- Three factors are emerging from expert studies as chief bottlenecks to the economic and industrial development of Latin-American countries -- low productivity of labor, shortage of electric power and price fluctuations.

A new seven-room stone and shingle dwelling on a plot 125 by 105 feet was sold on Lawn Terrace, Mamaroneck, N. Y. Angelo Spadaro, the builder, was the seller and Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Scanlon the buyers. Mr. Scanlon is a customer's broker with Fahnestock Co.
Haarlem House, the settlement that "opened a wide door to America" for dozens of prominent New Yorkers, will close its own doors at the end of this month.

The letter of Christopher Emmet, published in The Times of Aug. 23 regarding the Democratic party of Vietnam, gives us the opportunity to place before the international public the important and distressing problem of Vietnam and to find, with the aid of the United States and the free nations, an effective solution which will open the route to progress, independence and liberty for the people of Vietnam.
ROME, Sept. 4 -- The tenth International Congress of Historical Sciences opened here today in the vast white marble Palazzo dei Congressi built by Mussolini for a world's fair he never lived to see.
Increased margin requirements, combined with higher money costs, have effectively curtailed the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Henry Burbig, who appeared on radio when it was still in swaddling clothes, will return to the air this morning for his first regular program in sixteen years.

Thousands of golfers who quit playing because of heart conditions or other physical impairments are emerging from retirement these days. The magnet that is drawing them back to the fairways is the golf car, a device that has become increasingly popular in the last year.
Almost set as Ruth Gordon's vis-a-vis in Thornton Wilder's farce, "The Matchmaker," is Eddie Mayehoff. This much is definite: Contracts are ready for him to sign.
Her are a few suggestions to cope with what is wrong with traffic conditions in New York City. They are not the entire cure, but they could help.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- Four United States lawmakers and a Supreme Court Justice joined Moscow churchgoers today in prayers for continuing peace.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- One of the most widely held opinions in virtually all schools of psychology and common in the public mind received a jolt here today.
Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Foreign Minister, left here by plane yesterday for Los Angeles on his way home. He said he was "so happy" with his mission to the United States.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 41 -- School authorities are ready to use the state's new school placement law this week to sidestep integration in the Alabama public school system.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 4 -- Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, Chief of Staff of the Israeli Army, defended recent Israeli reprisal raids in a speech published today in the Army weekly magazine Bamahaneh.

Assemblyman Ludwig Teller was accused yesterday of misrepresenting his status as a Democratic district leader. The charge was made by Daniel Nelson, chairman of a group that is opposing Mr. Teller in next week's Democratic primary.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- An Air Force colonel flew his Super Sabre jet, the nation's first supersonic combat plane, across the country in 3 hours 48 minutes 4 seconds today to win the Bendix Air Race. However, uncooperative winds aloft balked him in his assault on records set in jets with slower top speeds. plane was scheduled for one refueling stop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The possibility of a balanced budget and a tax cut next year has brought general agreement on one thing among Administration supporters in Congress: the cuts had better go to individual taxpayers first.

MIAMI, Sept. 4 (UP) -- Gladys, the year's seventh tropical storm, whipped up tonight 140 miles east of Tampico, Mexico. At the same time Hurricane Flora churned the Atlantic waters with 80-mile-an-hour winds far out to sea.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- John L. Lewis said today that the proposed merger of the A. F. L. and C. I. O. would "part like the rope of sand it is" under pressures from rival union leaders.
The Empress of Britain, the newest luxury liner of the Canadian Pacific Steamship Company, will make her maiden voyage next April 20 from Liverpool, it was announced yesterday by the line.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- A four-run rally in the eighth inning gave the Giants a 7 -- 4 victory over the Phillies today at Connie Mack Stadium.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- For most practical purposes, the capital of West Germany will be moved this week to a railroad siding in Moscow.
GENEVA, Sept. 4 -- A new district lodge covering continental Europe was formally installed by B'nai B'rith at Basle today.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 4 -- "Ugetsu," a Japanese film drama based on a Samurai legend, was named here tonight as the motion picture that in the opinion of a United States jury contributed most to international goodwill in 1955.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- A wire fox terrier, Ch. Travella Superman of Harham, owned by Mrs. Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago, was named best in show in the ninth annual event of the Rockland County Kennel Club today.
There is renewed concern over the sporadic reappearances of public porters on the city's waterfront, particularly at the upper West Side luxury liner piers.

Soviet plans for major expansion of steel production over the next few years apparently depend primarily on two iron and steel plants now under construction. Information about these plants has only recently been made public in the Soviet press.

SALONIKA, Greece, Sept. 4 -- How Americans live through an ingenuity of their own was demonstrated today over 10,000 square feet leased at the annual International Fair here. Participating this year in international fairs for the first time with President Eisenhower's encouragement, the United States appears to have made a hit in Salonika.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Marion B. Folsom, new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today the teacher shortage in public schools was "primarily a problem for local communities."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Johnny Antonelli was not with the Giants today when they played the Phillies at Connie Mack Stadium. The ace left-hander was back in New York, suspended indefinitely without pay by Leo Durocher for insubordination.
The wood-hulled schooner Star of the Sea, one of America's last relics of the era of wind and sail, sank yesterday in Hempstead Harbor, L. I.

We have reason here in the United States to be happy over our diplomatic relations with Pakistan. They have been frank, cordial and mutually beneficial. One reason for that, of course, lies in the personalities of the men who have represented Pakistan here.

False thinking that ostracizes God from life is a root cause of today's world troubles, the Rev. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday. He spoke at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Spellman presided.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A week-old strike of 20,000 Bendix Aviation Corporation workers was settled today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- "Union-busting" was attributed today to the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay. Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, made the charge in a Labor Day statement.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers shelled four Kansas City pitchers for twenty hits, including three home runs, and a 17-1 victory today.
The presence of "a Christian bias" in social and political matters was affirmed yesterday by a Congregational leader.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector ), Sept. 4 -- The United Nations truce headquarters announced tonight that both Egypt and Israel had given "unconditional" agreement to an urgent ceasefire appeal.
Almost continuous processions of cars lined major highways yesterday, the second day of the Labor Day week-end.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers so far this year have built 5,561,720 passenger cars to top the total for all 1954. Last year's twelve-month total was 5,508,637.
BELGRADE, Sept. 5 -- With the arrival in Yugoslavia today of King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece, one phase of Yugoslav public relations is said to be ending and another beginning.

Two new productions will be given by the New York City Opera in its fall season at the City Center. One will be the already announced "Troilus and Cressida," by Sir William Walton, the other, a little-known comic opera by Tchaikovsky, to be given in an English version under the title "The Golden Slippers."
STATALE, Italy, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Gino Prato, the New York cobbler who won fame on "The 64,000 Dollar Question" television show, came home today.
A 6-month-old girl was killed and her mother critically injured yesterday in an accident in an elevator at 235 West 107th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

Home Properties, Inc., real estate operator and investor, has purchased the property at 1018 East 163d Street, the Bronx, known as the Hunts Point Professional Building. Occupying almost the entire block on 163d Street, between Southern Boulevard and Simpson Street, the building contains twenty-seven stores and 118 apartments.

The Naumburg Symphony Orchestra gave its traditional Labor Day concert last night on the Mall in Central Park. The program was the fourth and last of the summer series presented to the city by Walter W. and George W. Naumburg.

Second District member banks showed record operating earnings of $255,700,000 before taxes and non-recurring income during the first six months of 1955, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in the September issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Theodore C. Streibert, director of the United States Information Agency, told today how the agency had promoted this country's foreign policy in the half-year preceding the Geneva "summit" conference.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- Moscow finally spoke its mind today about the United States Government's policy of de-emphasizing the results of the Geneva Big Four conference. Vice President Richard M. Nixon and not President Eisenhower was the main target of the Soviet criticism.

When the Holland-America liner Maasdam arrives here this afternoon from Rotterdam, Le Havre and Southampton, she will be under the command of a new master, Capt. Coenraad Bouman. He replaces Capt. Johannes B. van Gaart, who has retired.

For the seventh time since World War II, shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are faced today with a challenging investment question. Should they maintain their present share of ownership in the company by subscribing to a new issue of debentures convertible into common stock ? Or should they sell their subscription rights ?
PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, Sept. 5 -- Rebel saboteurs cut off the water supply today of this city of 60,000 persons.

The coincidence that Labor Day this year came just after Harry S. Truman began a personal campaign to restore the Presidency to the Democrats in 1956 brings to mind the contrast between the situation in which Adlai E. Stevenson now finds himself and the one that contained him on Labor Day, 1952.

The subcommittee report on old-law tenements, made to Mayor Wagner's Committee for Better Housing, is a discouraging document. Old-law tenements, which are multiple dwellings built before the reform law of 1901, still number 52,348, according to the subcommittee, and house between 1,250,000 and 1,500,000 persons.

SALE, French Morocco, Sept. 5 -- Moroccan women -- the anonymous veiled mass and the modernists who are emerging from their veils -- are even more nationalistic than the men in this feverishly nationalist French protectorate.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 5 -- Harbor thieves boarded the water-logged Star of the Sea last night in Hempstead Harbor and made off with the ship's wheel and a lantern serving as a shipwreck beacon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -Republicans today demanded network radio and television time to answer former President Harry S. Truman's Labor Day speech in Detroit.
Men who smoke cigarettes regularly run a 40 per cent greater risk of dying of coronary heart disease than do non-smokers.

BRISTOL, England, Sept 5 -- Archaeologists are convinced that the most remarkable feat of prehistoric initiative in Europe was the transport of the massive blocks of Stonehenge from a quarry about 150 miles away.

DENVER, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A Labor Day message from President Eisenhower, filmed and recorded for television and radio, said today that "in honoring the nation's workers today, we reaffirm our devotion to the nation itself -which over the years and decades, American workmen have built."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 5 -- The cease-fire on the troubled Gaza strip truce line held firm through its second day today despite an incident last night in which at least two Israelis were killed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -The Office of Defense Mobilization today announced approval of tax benefits for thirty-four new or expanded production facilities, amounting to $20,635,471, as an inducement to build toward production levels needed for defense.
HONOLULU, Sept. 5 -- Two Episcopalian leaders took a look here at America's religious "revival" and came out on opposite sides of the fence.
TOKYO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A new phonetic version of the written Mongolian language will be used throughout the Inner Mongolian Autonomous Region of Northwest China, the Peiping radio said today.
AMERICAN women do not eat enough -- at least of the things they need.
To calypso and mambo music, the ninth annual Harlem Mardi Gras Parade danced along Seventh Avenue yesterday from 112th Street to 142d Street.

Shareholders of Natural Resources Fund, Inc., and Natural Resources of Canada Fund, Inc., have approved a series of proposals to combine assets of both funds totaling $5,147,000 under the name of International Resources Fund, Inc.

Vice President of the United States Richard M. Nixon will be the guest of honor and principal speaker at the annual dinner of the New York group of the Investment Bankers Association next month, according to an announcement by the association over the Week-end.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Federal civilian payroll rose $168,000,000 to $9,621,000,000 in the year that ended last June 30, a Senate-House committee reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UP) -Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today there were "good prospects" that the courts would nullify the Federal Power Commission's go-ahead for private development of power in Hell's Canyon.
WARSAW, Ind., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Senator William Langer said today he had been trying to "reform" President Eisenhower from the Senate floor, but that his efforts had failed.
OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 5 -- Canadian officials faced the unpalatable fact today that from the standpoint of Soviet-Canadian relations the Russian agriculture visit had been a failure.

Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday a reorganization of development and marketing in its textile division. John W. Brooks will head the new set-up as director of marketing. He will be responsible for all sales activities of acetate, Arnel, Fortisan, Fortisan-36, rayon and other products.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -The uncontrolled flight of a research balloon was still on tonight after it had failed to come low enough in the daylight for an Air Force jet to shoot it down.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -An Air Force test pilot has surpassed the world jet speed record. He went through the sound barrier at 822.135 miles an hour in straight and level flight.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5 -- The Yankees muffed a golden chance to improve their prospects in the American League pennant race today when they failed to do better than break even with the tail-end Orioles before a roaring crowd of 28,795.

For most of us, Labor Day ushers in the fall of the year. It marks the start of the downturn, after the burgeoning hopes of spring and the lush realization of summer. People in show business, though, whose inclination to turn night into day indicates that generally they do things a little differently from the majority, look upon this week as the start of the springtime of the year.
WESTBROOK, Conn., Sept. 5 -- What constitutes a successful fishing trip?
The Rev. Joseph P. O'Brien urged yesterday the recognition of religious principles in the settlement of labor and management disputes.

The promised study of waterfront labor relations in the Port of New York under the auspices of Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations is good news. But events are moving much faster than such a study possibly could.
RABAT, Fench Morocco, Sept. 4 -- The outline of a plan to settle the problem of Morocco's disputed throne emerged tonight after a meeting between the Sultan and the French Resident General.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Ten opposition members of Parliament rejected tonight Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru's call for ending "peaceful marches" into Portuguese India.
A freighter steward who plunged into the Upper Bay yesterday had to be made fast to a piling after fighting his rescuers for fifteen minutes.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Rip Repulski singled home the winning run in the tenth inning today as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 2, in the only single game in the majors' Labor Day program.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox checked a crippling four - game losing streak when Bob Keegan and Billy Pierce combined to shut out the Detroit Tigers, 3 -- 0, today in the second game of a double-header before 38,309 at Briggs Stadium.
U. S. Industries, Inc., has completed negotiations to acquire Garrett Oil Tools, Inc., of Longview, Tex., John I. Snyder Jr., board chairman and president of U. S. I. announced yesterday.

Interest in religion, as measured by church and temple membership, has reached new heights. This is indicated in statistics released yesterday by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- The United Nations Subcommittee on Disarmament will begin its second week of sessions here tomorrow. Important developments are probable.
Legislation providing for the defense of United States military personnel on trial in foreign courts has been prepared by the Defense Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- While Harold E. Stassen was presenting the United States "disarmament" plan to the United Nations last week, the new Secretary of the Air Force, Donald A. Quarles, made a speech in Philadelphia that illustrates the revolution that has taken place in American official thinking on the "disarmament" question.

EAGLE BRIDGE, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Here in the rolling hills she has shown the world, Grandma Moses will celebrate her ninety-fifth birthday Wednesday, surrounded by her children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and a few neighbors.

The Dodgers are impatient to clinch the pennant. Before 33,451, the largest Ebbets Field crowd of the season, they beat the Phillies twice yesterday, 11 -- 4 and 8 -- 2, even trouncing Robin Roberts in the process.

CARMEL, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Ch. Wilber White Swan, Bertha Smith's full-coated white toy poodle who has been creating a stir in bench show circles, scored again today. The 3-year-old dog turned back formidable opposition as he won best in show at the Putnam Kennel Club event.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 5 -- A United States exhibit again has stolen the show at an Asian trade fair -- even before the fair's start.

This reader of The New York Times would like to compliment its coverage of the limitation-of-arms question. The Times almost daily has searching and stimulating articles on this highly important but complicated subject.
BERLIN, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Two United States soldiers and a mystery man who tricked the Russians into thinking he was an American were released by the Soviet Union today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 5 -- American business men accused by the South Korean Government of failure to pay various business taxes said here tonight that an oral understanding had been reached deferring any action until the United States-Embassy-Republic of Korea Government talks had been completed.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Seven - year - old Bill Stockwell Jr. cleaned his piggy bank of its $2.29 and enclosed it in a letter to a Dutch artist.
Nicolo Pietrangeli, one of the most gifted young players coming up in tennis, made his exit from the national championship yesterday at Forest Hills.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 -Political pressures are building up in India for a faster march toward socialism.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 -- Harry S. Truman charged today that the Republican Administration was more concerned with dollars than with people.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 5 -- A South Korean intelligence report issued tonight indicated the presence of 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 Chinese Communist troops in North Korea.
Mayor Wagner has been urged to set up a city office to develop population statistics.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- Budd Boetticher, director; Lucien Ballard, cinematographer, and Clarence Eurist, production executive, are in the process of forming their own producing unit.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 5 -- The president of the Trades Union Congress warned today that the post-Geneva atmosphere of goodwill would make it easier for Communists to infiltrate unions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today that it might eliminate seven of its air safety activities and transfer or delegate twenty-one others to the aircraft industry. It would retain thirty-six safety functions.

The curtain will rise on a new drama in European affairs when Chancellor Adenauer arrives in Moscow Thursday for one of the most unusual and important conferences of the post-war era. He is going there at the invitation of the Soviets to discuss the establishment of diplomatic, commercial and cultural relations between West Germany and Soviet Russia.
The king is dead. "He" died yesterday at the Polo Grounds at 4:29 P. M.

It would be difficult to think, off-hand, of a more appropriate salute to Labor Day than the statistical one touched off in a Sunday television program by Secretary of Labor James A. Mitchell. In August, for the third consecutive month, Mr. Mitchell declared, the number of employed persons in the United States set a new all-time monthly record.

Net sales of the General Shoe Corporation reached $122,313,946 in the nine months ended on July 31. This compared with $106,017,087 in the like period a year earlier and was more than in any full year in the company's history, except fiscal 1954.

Although no records were reported, the combination of balmy weather and a large influx of out-of-town visitors helped to swell attendance at a majority of first-run film houses over the summer's last holiday week-end.
Death on the highways, striking across the nation at a faster rate than a year ago, was grasping last night toward a record for Labor Day week-ends.

Labor Day week-end is the traditional starting point each year for the great game of American politics. This year restless Republicans couldn't wait for the Labor Day week-end to be over. In fact, they could hardly wait for it to begin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- President Eisenhower's meeting next Saturday with the nation's top Republican leaders in Denver offers him an opportunity to clarify his status as a possible candidate for re-election.
ELATH, Israel, Sept. 5 -Walter P. Reuther voiced the support of "millions of organized workers" in the United States for Israel at a ceremony here today.

A three-story industrial building at 19-19 Twenty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, has been sold by the 19-19 Corporation to the Twenty-fourth Street Plaza Realty Corporation. The buyer is an affiliate of the Eagle Manufacturing Company, maker of fuses and other electrical wiring devices.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5 -- The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra blazed into the Edinburgh Festival in a triumphal entry tonight with its first concert at the Usher Hall. It was a great night.
Streamline Foods Corp, executive offices in 225 W 57th St; John Parlatore, store in 298 5th Ave -- Walter Scott Co, brokers.
The Downtown Manhattan Festival Band will give a concert at noon today in Battery Park. Herman Neuman will conduct and Floyd Worthington, baritone, will be the soloist.
PARIS, Sept. 5 -- The police raided Algerian communities throughout France today in a search for "agitators" helping the rebels in Algeria.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Thriving on a fifteen-mile breeze, Corny Shields made a runaway of the International Class race in the Lachmont Yacht Club's regatta on Long Island Sound today.

Bobby Courchesne, 131 pounds, Holyoke, Mass., made an impressive New York debut by scoring a technical knockout over Anthony (Sonny) Puleo, 135, Brooklyn, at 1:29 of the ninth round at St. Nicholas Arena last night. The bout was scheduled for ten rounds.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Harvey Conover's Revonoc captured the Vineyard Trophy in the twenty-first edition of the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race which ended today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Maine Chance Farm's Jet Action, responding to Willie Shoemaker's whip from the eighth pole to the finish, scored a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $152,950 Washington Park Handicap today.
TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Japan's two Socialist parties announced today that they would challenge the Government on the legality of Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu's defense commitments in Washington.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) -The Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 9 -- 2, in the nightcap of a double-header today to keep their grip on first place in the tight American League pennant race after losing the first game, 5 -- 4.

PORK liver has little but good food value to recommend it, Americans seem to think. A German sausage maker takes an opposite view. He contends this kind of liver -- richest in iron of all meats, incidentally -is delicious, versatile and interesting.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 5 -- After fifty years of trying, Michael Golon, 73-year-old professional gardener here, has raised a fifteen-foot female sunflower plant at his home, 238 Grant Avenue. Mr. Golon said that nine feet was his previous record for such a plant, although he has had male plants that reached eleven feet.
MILLVILLE, N. J., Sept. 5 -William Ott of Meadville, Pa., retained the national championship for the 44 - cubic - inch speed boat runabout class this afternoon on Laurel Lake.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Sept. 5 -A leak in a fire hydrant forced postponement today of the twenty-seventh annual Labor Day Fire Tournament. Only two of the scheduled seven contests were held.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 5 -- The National Broadcasting Company will use its facilities here to film in color at least two of the planned "N. B. C. Matinee Theatre" shows, a network official has stated. If film production proves successful, then about ten more will be done on film.

GENEVA, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Continuing floods in India and East Pakistan have wrecked more than 28,000 villages and damaged or destroyed the homes of 45,000,000 persons, according to a report received today by the League of Red Cross Societies.
Gordon Duff has resigned as producer of the "Television Playhouse" dramas presented by the National Broadcasting Company on Sundays from 9 to 10 P. M.

With Eddie Arcaro guiding him to the outside, Red Hannigan won the $28,750 Bay Shore Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old colt, in the silks of the Woodley Lane Farm, had three-quarters of a length over the favored Gold Box of the Greentree Stable at the finish.

TOKYO, Sept. 5 -- Japan's ship-building industry, prostrate after World War II, will probably reach a new post-war high this year in contracts for new vessels, the Transportation Ministry reported today.
Arnold Bauman, Assistant United States Attorney here, was appointed yesterday chief counsel to the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Government Operations.

American editions of two German novels that have received wide acclaim will be published this season by Criterion Books. The first to appear -- on Sept. 23 -- will be Hans Kades' "Without Sanction," in a translation by E. B. Ashton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A controversial plan to give "limited exemptions" from the anti-trust laws to United States business men operating abroad will come under Congressional scrutiny in public hearings starting next Monday.
An all-out campaign for the elimination or rehabilitation of the city's remaining 52,348 old-law tenements was recommended yesterday by the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 5 (AP) -- The tropical storm Gladys, unpredictable and dangerous, made a radical turn tonight. It headed in the general direction of Mexico City, where she already had caused the worst floods in that capital's recent history.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 5 -- The British aircraft industry unveiled more powerful engines and new transport planes today at the opening of the sixteenth annual display of the Society of British Aircraft Constructors.
Broadway receives its first revue of the season tonight at 8 o'clock, when "Catch a Star!" is unveiled at the Plymouth Theatre.
BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox kept within striking distance of the American League pennant today by sweeping a double-header from the Washington Senators, 10 -- 2 and 7 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture will hold a series of public hearings next week to consider new production control measures for burley tobacco. Burley is produced in quantities greater than it can be used.

The dominant dock union on the New York waterfront is continuing to issue memberships and jobs to new members despite its complaints that there are too many men on the piers, according to the longshore committee of the American Federation of Labor.

BUCYRUS, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's Manhattan Limited streaked through the early-morning Ohio haze at 70 miles an hour, today and smashed into derailed cars of a freight train near here.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Most leading industrial stocks were marked down today in the quietest trading session this year.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The ancient liturgy of the Byzantine rite was sung in English for the first time today by a Roman Catholic rite bishop who celebrated a solemn pontifical mass for the conversion of Russia.

Johnny Antonelli's indefinite suspension without pay lasted one day. The Giant's southpaw made his peace with Manager Leo Durocher before yesterday's first game at the Polo Grounds and was reinstated.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- There were strong indications today that the tripartite talks on the future of Cyprus might end later this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- American labor put its cards on the table today. It was Labor Day, just three months before the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations were scheduled to merge. The 15,000,000 members would form perhaps the greatest union force in United States history. Union leaders faced the country and told the Labor Day story.

MONTREAL, Sept. 5 (UP) -The Montreal Royals won the International League pennant today by sweeping two games from Rochester, 6 -- 0 and 4 -- 2, to finish the season a half-game ahead of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

A great many products come packed in a box. When the boxtop is removed and sent to the proper address with a coin (sometimes folding money is specified) back comes something useful. This operation is part of the premium industry, and it will be a topic for discussion when members of the Premium Advertising Association of America gather next week to show new ideas at the annual New York Premium Show.
CAIRO, Sept 5 -- The Egyptian Government received an explanation today that the breach of the newly agreed Gaza border cease-fire last night had resulted from an Israeli patrol's mistake.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs traded shutouts with the Milwaukee Braves today and moved into a tie for fifth place with Cincinnati.

EVERY baseball fan seems to take a fiendish delight whenever he sees managerial strategy backfire, especially the ostentatious kind. He'll sneer superciliously when a skipper guesses wrong on a pinch-hitter and when a missed signal on a hit-and-run leaves the runner hung up.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5 -- A warning against further industrialization of this predominantly residential community has started a lively controversy here. The warning was contained in a report to be presented on Thursday night to the Representative Town Meeting by a special housing committee.

WHEN old Doc Rossiter died, he left an embittered widow, a 17-year-old son, $30,000 in uncollected bills and a will with an unusual clause. He had paid in advance to have the clause published in the paper: "This is to notify my patients that I go to my Maker with clean hands, forgiving my debtors and thanking them for the privilege of permitting me to serve them."

Frank DuVinage has become president of Adler of America, Inc., East Coast importers and distributors of Adler and Adlermatic sewing machines. He has appointed Fred Salem as district manager for the East Coast offices.
Edward Corsi, chairman of the board of Haarlem House, denied yesterday that the settlement would be closed at the end of this month for lack of funds.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5 -- Housing is the most "vital unfinished business" in racial relations, the National Urban League was told today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- With foreign aid, South Korea's economy has been placed "firmly on the road to reconstruction," a United Nations agency reported today. However, it also warned that South Korea would need financial help from overseas for some time to come.
John F. Thurston has been named general manager of the Electro Dynamic division of General Dynamics Corporation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson declared today that the nation's entire economy was being endangered by the failure of the Eisenhower Administration to deal with the distress of farmers.

The six-story building at 41 St. Nicolas Terrace has been purchased by Herman Pesin. Assessed at $190,000, the building, which contains three stores and seventy-one apartments, occupies a plot 143 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of West 129th Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 -- A post-war dream of a "magic carpet" method of choosing job applicants was termed "a pipe dream" today.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Sept. 5 -Edmar Mednis of New York City, the new New York State chess champion, finished his schedule today with a victory over George Scriabin of Syracuse in forty-nine moves. His final score of 8 -- 1 was comprised of seven games won and two drawn.

In The Times of Aug. 28 Will Roberts wrote of the alarming shortage in our country of scientist and engineers and suggested the bold approach of having industry sponsor tremendous programs of university scholarships in science and engineering.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -More and more the world is going to school in the United States.
DENVER, Sept. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that persons close to President Eisenhower were more convinced than ever that he would seek re-election next year.
Gaynor Co., Inc. will be merged with Colman, Prentis Varley, Inc., as of Oct. 1, and the new agency will be known as Gaynor, Colman, Prentis Varley, Inc.
GENEVA, Sept. 5 -- Reaction against auto deaths is sweeping over Europe.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 3 -- The National Constituent Assembly has defeated attempts by groups favoring the Roman Catholic Church to obtain added concessions on religious provisions in the new Constitution.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 5 -- David Marshall, Chief Minister, will lead a Singapore trade and goodwill mission to Indonesia this week-end. An announcement here today said the visit was being made at the invitation of the new Indonesian Government.

In less than two weeks the Red Cross reached its goal of $10 millions for flood relief and has notified its chapters that no further contributions are needed at this time. A Red Cross official described the response as "one of the speediest and most generous" in Red Cross history.
The liability of international airlines for injury and death to passengers and damage to baggage and cargo may be increased as the result of a meeting beginning today at The Hague.
The toll roads have been advised to follow the telephone -in the matter of rates.

The New York Central Railroad earned $500,000 more in the first eight months of this year than it did in all 1953, which was one of the industry's most profitable post-war years. With operating revenues of $497,553,274 only $27,049,916 more than in the first eight months of 1954, the road managed to carry $34,531,222 through to net income.

The excellence of Kenneth Rosewall's ground strokes was too much for one of the soundest of backcourt players yesterday and the little Australian tennis champion defeated Edward Moylan at Forest Hills, Queens, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

After five weeks of discussion the Geneva conference on the liberation of American civilian captives in Communist China has produced a break in the deadlock with a Communist announcement that nine Americans, including four women and two girls, are now free to leave at any time.
Three networks reacted in three ways yesterday after having received a request for free air time from the Republican National Committee.
DENVER, Sept. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has been assigned to work the spare tire off the American midriff and step up the national muscle tone.

GENEVA, Sept. 6 -- Communist China announced unexpectedly today that it was ready to issue exit permits to twelve detained United States civilians. This was the first positive result of five weeks of closed conferences on freeing forty-one American civilians held by the Chinese Communists.
Trouble - shooting engineers from all over the country are working around the clock to repair thousands of electric motors, transformers and other equipment damaged by recent New England floods.
A PAIR or gang busters from the Old West arrived for the first time on television last night in two filmed programs that are scheduled to be seen in wekly installments.
Forty-two housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration have designated next Tuesday for the sale of temporary loan notes totaling $52,852,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Defense Department aimed today at an expenditure of $33,000,000,000 for the fiscal year of 1956. This is an even billion dollars less than its estimate two weeks ago. Major national security items consume 64 cents of every dollar in the Federal budget. If the armed services reach their own goal on expenditures,that would go far toward balancing the whole budget for the fiscal year that began July 1.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 6 -- Brahms, No. 1 in C minor! The mere announcement is enough to set the listener's nerves to tingling in anticipation. And never, surely, did any listener's nerves tingle so intensely as tonight, when Guido Cantelli conducted the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in this work at the Edinburgh Festival.

About $1,000,000 worth of cocoa beans that arrived here two weeks ago has been denied entry into this country and probably will be shipped abroad this week. The shipment came from Cape Palmas, British West Africa. It was declared by the Food and Drug Division of the Department of Agriculture to be unfit for consumption.
Mutual funds may be described as a modern application of the old adage against "putting all your eggs in one basket."

ATLANTA, Sept. 6 (UP) -- More than 100 Negroes started school with white pupils at Federally controlled Oak Ridge, Tenn. But elsewhere in the deep South public schools re-opened on a segregated basis.
James O'Farrell, the gymnasium teacher who was stabbed by a juvenile delinquent last June 8, has instituted suit for $250,000 against the city.

Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, yesterday set Wednesday, Sept, 28, as the opening date for the 1955 world series. The scene of action will be the park of the American League pennant-winner.

In your editorial of Aug. 18 "The Sudan Comes of Age" there are serious statements which are apt to create a totally erroneous impression of Egypt's sincere intentions toward her southern neighbor. You say: "The Egyptians have already been violating the spirit, if not the word, of their 1953 agreement to leave the Sudanese free to make their own decision."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A House investigating subcommittee demanded today that the Department of Defense give to service men overseas better protection against the practices of several insurance companies.
Eleven double-headers and two tournaments make up the 195556 college basketball program at Madison Square Garden.

LIFE begins after intermission for "Catch A Star!," which opened a new season at the Plymouth last evening. This is the part of the program in which Pat Carroll and Jack Wakefield do a funny parody of a wonderful movie called "Marty."
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 6 -- An international armada of thirtyfive warships will rendezvous off the Virginia Capes tomorrow morning to begin a seven-day exercise in ship convoy tactics.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A huge backfire was started today in an already flaming California forest to protect a city of about 5,000 persons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -California's four principal seaports suffered a decline in foreign -commerce tonnage handled last year despite increases in military shipments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -The Smithsonian Institution announced today the discovery of tiny "planarian" worms in Alaska. This was viewed as new evidence that the land masses of Asia and North America had been joined centuries ago.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 -- A bill postponing the election of a constituent assembly to disestablish the Roman Catholic Church has been signed by President Juan D. Peron.
GENEVA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States Chinese announcement on the release of Americans in Communist China:...

A contract for the purchase of the six-story store and loft building at 434 Avenue of the Americas has been signed by M. Robert Steel, realty manager, in association with the Slim-UEtte Fashions Company, dress manufacturer.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- A contemplative cucumber cultivator of these parts has perfected a platform for picking prospective pickles in the prone position. It's not only pleasing to the pickers, but kind to the cucumbers.

BONN, West Germany, Sept. 6 -- The Bank Deutscher Laender, the central bank of West Germany, recommended today in its monthly report that measures be taken to consolidate West Germany's great economic gains instead of permitting the current boom to continue uncontrolled.
ANGLERS who spent the long week-end coastal fishing from Montauk to Cape Cod found plenty of activity. The fall run of striped bass is in progress.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 6 (AP) -Hungary's Laszlo Tabori, one of the world's five four-minute milers, bettered the listed world record by a second tonight as he nosed out Denmark's Gunnar Nielsen in a spectacular finish to a thrilling 1,500-meter race.
The Tampa Gas Company at noon yesterday became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Peoples Water and Gas Company, with general offices at Miami.

A new cassis, differing from others on the market in that it is higher in alcohol is appearing for the first time in wine shops here. Lejay-Lagoute, a Dijon concern, has been making this black currant liqueur since 1841, but, has not shipped it to this country before.
Mediation efforts in the dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, independent, have failed, the union announced yesterday.
SOPHIE of Saks Fifth Avenue is off on the Orient Express.

Britain's stockpile of gold and dollar reserves, rebuilt so painstakingly under the stern policies of the Conservative Government over the past three years, suffered its second consecutive monthly depletion in August, with a decline of $87 millions.
MID-MANHATTAN men deny themselves one of the qualities they admire most in women -- wavy hair.
William F. Lydon, who went absent without leave from the United States Army twentyseven years ago, squared matters with the Army yesterday and was a free man.
VANCOUVER, B. C. (Canadian Press) -- Mrs. Edmund Morrison, speaking for the British Columbia Parent-Teacher Council, has praised a Government order increasing homework roy school children.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Hurricane-hunter planes studied a wide squall line off the coast of Texas today and weather men eyed a potential new storm in the Gulf of Mexico.
SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 6 -Four English sailors took a big step toward capturing one of the oldest and least publicized international sports trophies in a canoe race in Hempstead Harbor today.
LE HAVRE, France, Aug. 10 -Le Havre has been called the most reconstructed city in the world. Today, after ten years of rebuilding, it is probably the most modern town in Europe.
SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 6 (AP) -A grand jury indicted two white men today or charges of kidnapping and murdering Emmett Louis Till, 14-year-old Negro boy who allegedly had whistled at a white woman.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 6 -The Indian Parliament gave its backing today to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's renunciation of "peaceful invasion" as a weaponto force the Portuguese out of their colony of Goa.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 6 -- The Trades Union Congress took steps today to bring about greater industrial stability in Britain.
ONE day last week George Kell, the literate philosopher from Arkansas, was reflecting on the American League pennant race.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 6 -- Anti - Greek rioting exploded in Istanbul tonight.

Those devotees of the "royal and ancient" game who betook themselves to the Aqueduct race track yesterday instead of to the links, could not miss getting club dues. Sometimes one must approach horse racing purely from the standpoint of the hunch play, and yesterday was undoubtedly the golfers' hunch day.
The spirit of religion and freedom is strong in the peoples behind the Iron Curtain, but they need and deserve the support of the Western world, Archbishop Joseph Felix Gawlina-declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -The Department of Justice has started what it described today as a "routine investigation" of two "leaks" from the National Security Council that appeared in The Washington Post and Times Herald.
HONOLULU, Sept. 6 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church has been asked to authorize changes in the Book of Common Prayer that would make it more acceptable in foreign lands.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Officials expressed hope today that Communist China would release all Americans held there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Paul Gregory Productions has added two new properties, "Fahrenheit 451," a science-fiction tale by Ray Bradbury, and "The Day Lincoln Was Shot," by Jim Bishop to its motion-picture production schedule.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 6 -- King Paul of Greece and Queen Frederika received the Communist version of a royal welcome upon their arrival here this afternoon on a state visit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The United States called today for a new study of the whole question of inspection and control of nuclear and conventional weapons.
PARIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The United States Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, plans to rebuke foreign critics of United States farm policies in a speech here tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6 (UP) -Southern California's heat wave sent temperatures past 100 degrees today for the seventh straight day. The heat death toll soared to sixty, and a layer of smog added to the discomfort.

LOVABLE, excellent and colorful horses race at tracks around New York. But a bay mare scheduled to run at Aqueduct this afternoon, Glorious Emma, is in an entirely different class. She is unlovable, mean, cantankerous and unreliable.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 7 to 29 points yesterday. The far months showed the most weakness.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- The Soviet criminal code was reported today to be undergoing revision to safeguard the rights of accused persons during pre-trial investigations.

The International Harvester Company, said to be the nation's largest producer of farm implements and farm tractors, increased its earnings by $12,869,000 in the nine months ended July 31 over the corresponding period last year.

MADRID, Sept. 3 -- Maximo Bendres is the talk of the town today. For him the dream of treasure-hunting art collectors has come true. About four years ago Senor Bendres saw in a Pamplona antique shop an old painting.

Federal Judge David N. Edelstein signed yesterday an order staying deportation proceedings against a Chinese seaman, Bun Jik (Sammy) Lee, who has been in this country since 1952 and contends it would cost him his life to return to Communist China.
THE best anchovies, like the best shrimp and sardines, are the smallest. Several experts, polled recently for tips on how to buy anchovies, agreed on this point.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- A stronger tone developed in wheat and corn futures today. Early selling was absorbed by commission houses, with free short covering by local professionals.

Underwriters headed by Allen Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler are offering a new issue of $7,830,000 of Foremost Dairies, Inc., 4 1/2 per cent subordinated debentures due July 1, 1980, at 105. The offering represents debentures not placed in an exchange offer that ended Aug. 13.
MOUNT VERNON, Ohio, Sept. 6 (UP) -- A mysterious explosion shook the top-secret experimental laboratory of the Cooper-Bessemer Company today, killing two men and injuring three others.
The largest college scholarship program in the history of American education has been established.

BOSTON, Sept. 6 -- The police broke up a disturbance today on Boston Common between a religious group and bystanders who objected to a placard message charging desecration at Brandeis University. The university, situated in near-by Waltham, Mass., is Jewish sponsored. There were no arrests.

BERLIN, Sept. 6 (AP) -- United States officials announced tonight that an alleged American released by the Russians now claimed to be a German named Klaus Frederick Glaubitz. But the officials said they were dissatisfied with his story.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America (known as ECLA for short) has been unable thus far during its meeting in Bogota, Colombia, to come up with any dramatic ideas or solutions. Nevertheless, this sixth conference of ECLA is an important one, just as the meetings of the sister organizations for Europe and for Asia always are.
NOORDWIJK AAN ZEE, the Netherlands, Sept. 6 -- Another modest step toward Western European economic unity was taken today at this Dutch seaside resort.

Directors of the First National City Bank of New York yesterday increased the dividend rate on its stock to $2.60 a year from the $2.40 previously paid with the declaration of 65 cents for the quarter. The dividend is payable Nov. 1.
Many stores waste fully a third of their advertising expenditures, the Carolina Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers was told at its convention yesterday at Greenville, S. C.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- Miss Frieda Miller has been commissioned by the International Labor Organization to survey conditions of work for women in eight countries of Asia.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 6 -- The preliminaries for the Cavalcade of Golf began today at the Shackamaxon Country Club. The sport's newest tournament is a 72-hole affair, with $50,000 in cash prizes at stake.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A special Government committee will begin a study of "Buy American" policies this month.

PARAMUS, N. J., Sept. 6 -Vincent Fitzgerald of the Garden City Golf Club won the qualifying medal today in the metropolitan sectional qualifying round for the first United States Golf Association senior championship.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Sept. 6 -- The impact of mechanization on cotton labor, production and markets will be studied at a three-day conference that opens here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- A group of Virginia operators attacked Government's proposed minimum wage in soft-coal mining today on social as well as legal grounds.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Sept. 7 -- Reports from Izmir (Smyrna), Turkey, said crowds had set afire the Greek pavilion at the international fair there. The reports were confirmed early today by Deputy Premier Panayotis Canellopoulos.

The A. S. Beck shoe chain and the Walgreen drug stores have leased space in the Lake Success Shopping Center, now under construction on a twenty-acre tract fronting on Union Turnpike, North Hempstead, L. I. Milton Peck and Arthur Shactman are the owner-builders.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- The Western Big Three were reported ready tonight to call for a Security Council meeting to bolster the truce along the Egyptian-Israeli border.

The end of the love feast between the United States Government and the Soviet dictatorship, or the "phony peace," as James Restol has termed it, should be a reminder that the expressions of sweetness and light emanating from the Kremlin come from individuals who may be blotted out of the picture over night, not from public opinion in Russia but by a few gunshots of forcible removal from power.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Two factors helped most stock prices rise today. Operators were glad to see the last day of a dismal bookkeeping account and they were encouraged by the tone of speeches at the Trades Union Congress in favor of wage restraint.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Reports that Jacob M. Arvey and Adlai E. Stevenson were on the verge of ending a long political friendship over the Presidential aspirations of Governor Harriman of New York were denied by Mr. Arvey today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 -This capital has lived under a state of siege since Friday night, but a stranger in town would hardly be aware of it if not told of it.
Frank M. Stanton, who holds the unofficial record for putting together major investment banking syndicates, has retired as a top executive of the First Boston Corporation.
The Port of New York Authority began yesterday to probe the subsoil of a two-mile area of the Brooklyn waterfront, which it plans to develop at a cost of $70,000,000.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Prime Minister Eden flew as co-pilot in one of Britain's huge bombers today to dramatize this country's bid for jet-plane leadership.
DENVER, Sept. 6 -- President Eisenhower was urged today to capitalize on the "Geneva spirit" by expanding this country's information program for the Communist world.
In connection with the discussion under way regarding bus service, the following thoughts may be pertinent:

Hide prices fell to new lows for the life of contracts yesterday in all traded positions on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Speculator liquidation was absorbed by scale-down dealer buying. Heavy supplies of actuals depressed the market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UP) -- Frank J. Meistrell general counsel of the Federal Housing Administration, was appointed today as Deputy Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency. This is the parent agency of most of the Government's housing operations.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 6 -- The Communists in Singapore will be offered an amnesty along with the insurgent Reds in the Federation of Malaya. An announcement to this effect was made here today by David Marshall, Singapore's Chief Minister.
Strong and sustained consumer demand is expected for fall apparel and activity in coats and suits and other ready-to-wear promises to be greater than for several seasons.
Large requirements of the flood-ravaged Northeast for structural steels, combined with booming industrial demand, continue to hold steel output at a high rate.
Post-Labor Day stock purchases lifted prices yesterday close to record highs.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- William Gentzlinger, a Long Island ace who sails in the Huntington Bay fleet, had the distinction of winning today among the biggest number of Star boats ever assembled for a major regatta.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 -George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that President Eisenhower had failed thus far in his civil rights program.
