PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, Sept. 6 -- The supreme governmental authority in Philippeville, center of Moslem dissidence in Algeria, was transferred today from civilian to military hands.

A picture of the new era of advertising, when "the creative man" Will he dominant, was drawn last night by Milton M. Rockmore, president of The Rockmore Company, in an address before the Association of Advertising Men and Women at the Biltmore Hotel.

E. W. Bliss Company, manufacturer of metal-working presses, has arranged to borrow privately $8,000,000 from Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States on 4 per cent sinking fund notes maturing from 1957 to 1970.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- For the first time an American inspected the Soviet Union's atomic energy power plant today.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 6 -- The great phosphate mines near Khouribga that were devastated by Moroccan rioters on Aug. 21 are being brought rapidly back into production.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 -A program to "immunize" children against possible bad effects from comic books, television and movies was suggested late today at the annual convention of the American Psychological Association.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that India could not function as chairman of the Indochina truce control commission unless all parties accepted the terms of the Geneva armistice agreement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- President Eisenhower was asked today to call a special session of Congress if necessary to bring relief to the copper and brass industry now confronted with "the worst crisis in the industry's history."
A system-wide ban on overtime work on the Pan American World Airways was announced yesterday by the air transport division of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 6 -Harry S. Truman charged today that Republicans were guilty of demagoguery for implying that there would be tax cuts next year.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 -- Another United States Senator warned here today against the belief that the Soviet regime was imperiled by popular discontent.
PARIS, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -William E. Boone, a United States contractor, left tonight for New York after spending four days confined to the transit lounge at Orly airport because he lost his passport.
LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, offered a substantial measure of self-government today to the Greek and Turkish inhabitants of Cyprus.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -The United States and the Philippines today signed a revised trade agreement to become effective Jan. 1. Their annual trade now amounts to about $600,000,000 a year.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Oscar Panno, the runner-up, gained ground in the interzonal chess tournament at Gothenburg yesterday when he defeated Boris Spassky of Russia in the thirteenth round, according to a report from Swedish sources.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Sept. 6 -- The Columbia Broadcasting Company's television network will increase its schedule of color shows this season by almost 400 per cent over last year.
Longshoremen throughout the Port of New York will meet today to decide whether the long threatened strike against the bi-state Waterfront Commission is on or off.

OTTAWA, Sept. 6 -- An official attempt will be made tomorrow to smoothe the ruffled feelings of the Russian agricultural delegation. Its visit to Canada has been marred by demonstrations and poor planning.

As motorists continued their return to the city in large numbers yesterday morning, late reports showed that 438 persons had been killed in traffic accidents throughout the nation over the Labor Day week-end.

Mississippi has a larger Negro population, according to the latest census, than any other state in the Union. The fact makes the state a particularly important testing ground in race relations. If there can be progress in those relations toward greater justice and greater democracy in Mississippi, then we can feel grateful.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The polio vaccination program will resume in a new situation of tight supply with fall and school's opening.

DENVER, Sept. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby today to the Committee for the White House Conference on Education. She is the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Republican state chairmen arrived in Washington for a special "campaign school" today with but a single thought: Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Employes of the Lockheed Aircraft Service International, Inc., will begin today a two-day blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Two Army tents at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, will serve as a center.

The Stacor Equipment Company has leased the one-story industrial building at 172 Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, from the Malbone Garage, Inc. The structure, containing 1,200 square feet of space, will be used in conjunction with the lessee's present factory of more than 18,000 square feet at 768 East New York Avenue, Brooklyn.

Despite all warnings to be careful, despite the many reminders of the toll of past holidays, the nation's dead in highway accidents on the Labor Day week-end outran the estimates and numbered nearly 450. Once again the automobile, blessing that it is, proves itself a deadly machine which we have not yet mastered.

Edmund Hillary, who with Tenzing, the Sherpa climber, reached the top of Mount Everest, has written his autobiography, "High Adventure," which Dutton will issue next Monday. His story begins with his first view of a mountain peak in his native New Zealand and continues to that day in 1953 when he and Tenzing stood atop Everest.
The account against the twinsister scofflaws, who between them ran up a record 100 traffic violations, was closed yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 (AP) -Warren C. Giles, president of the National League, today turned down the protest of Manager Birdie Tebbetts of the Redlegs on a ball game played with Milwaukee Sept. 4. The Braves won the game, 5 to 2.
East Side House Settlement, which has served the Upper East Side since 1891, will benefit from a dinner dance on Sept. 21. The dance will open the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the season.

An apparent conspiracy of the elements kept many potential visitors away from New York this summer. However, neither threat of hurricane nor record heat could entirely dim the city's lure as a vacation center.

At 7:45 o'clock tonight, "Othello" will be revived at the City Center. Inasmuch as the running time will be ten minutes longer, Jean Dalrymple, supervisor of the drama activities there, is urging the first night brigade to cooperate by being prompt. Subsequent evening performances will start at the customary hour -- 8:30.

Today, up in Eagle Bridge, N. Y., surrounded by her children, grand-children and great-grandchildren, Anna Mary Robertson Moses is celebrating her ninety-fifth birthday. Grandma Moses took up painting at the age of 76 because her fingers were too stiff for needlework and she found painting "a lot easier than embroidering."

A six-month effort to recruit investment banking houses into an inter-American investment company with initial capital of about $10,000,000 has been given up. Instead, the initial capital will be held to less than $1,500,000 and the money will be raised from sources other than the securities underwriting community.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Official circles expressed optimism tonight over the Moroccan situation. A message was received from Gen. Georges Catroux, who is in Madagascar seeking a settlement with the exiled Moroccan Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would offer "distress" loans on 1955 crop grain sorghums stored in temporary structures or on the ground if there is a shortage of regular facilities.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 6 -- A United Nations truce committee has condemned Israel and Egypt for having violated the armistice Aug. 22. Clashes that day touched off nearly two weeks of violence in which seventy or more persons lost their lives.
A. E. C. SALTON SEA BASE, Calif., Sept. 1 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is lifting the veil of mystery that for five years has shrouded one of its most secret installations.
The New Jersey State Senate is considering the appointments of two new members to the state's board of pilot commissioners to bring it up to full strength.

At 7:45 o'clock tonight, "Othello" will be revived at the City Center. Inasmuch as the running time will be ten minutes longer, Jean Dalrymple, supervisor of the drama activities there, is urging the first night brigade to cooperate by being prompt. Subsequent evening performances will start at the customary hour -- 8:30.

Today, up in Eagle Bridge, N. Y., surrounded by her children, grand-children and great-grandchildren, Anna Mary Robertson Moses is celebrating her ninety-fifth birthday. Grandma Moses took up painting at the age of 76 because her fingers were too stiff for needlework and she found painting "a lot easier than embroidering."
Your recent editorial "21 Years of Bank Insurance" called the Government insurance of bank deposits the most revolutionary provision of the bank legislation of 1933.

PARIS, Sept. 6 -- Official circles expressed optimism tonight over the Moroccan situation. A message was received from Gen. Georges Catroux, who is in Madagascar seeking a settlement with the exiled Moroccan Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would offer "distress" loans on 1955 crop grain sorghums stored in temporary structures or on the ground if there is a shortage of regular facilities.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 6 -- A United Nations truce committee has condemned Israel and Egypt for having violated the armistice Aug. 22. Clashes that day touched off nearly two weeks of violence in which seventy or more persons lost their lives.
A. E. C. SALTON SEA BASE, Calif., Sept. 1 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is lifting the veil of mystery that for five years has shrouded one of its most secret installations.
The New Jersey State Senate is considering the appointments of two new members to the state's board of pilot commissioners to bring it up to full strength.

THE weighty New York art season year by year extends later into the spring and renews its activities earlier each fall. Wasting no time, the Museum of Modern Art is opening today another in its long series of exhibitions dealing with important artists of the modern movement.
Miss Jo Guthrie was chosen yesterday to lead the grand march at the Debutantes New Year's Ball. Because New Year's Day falls on a Sunday, the ball this season will be held on Jan. 2.

The tie-up on the New York docks yesterday firmed coffee prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was heavy short covering. Buying, believed to be by speculators or Brazilian interests, was noted in the distant months.

The Transit Authority offered the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., an 11-cent-an-hour package increase in a three-year contract yesterday. But the union's negotiating committee rejected the offer as "totally unacceptable."
Three Democratic Governors declined to attend a radio and television executives' luncheon here next Wednesday at which Vice President Richard M. Nixon is to speak.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7 -- The Dodgers beat the Braves tonight at County Stadium, 3 -- 1, and clinched at least a tie for the National League pennant. The Brooks need only to win here tomorrow afternoon to wrap up the flag.

Directors of the Mead Corporation, paper manufacturer, have approved an agreement to purchase the assets of the Chillicothe Paper Company of Chillicothe, Ohio. The consideration would be about 25,000 shares of Mead common stock.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's advance party arrived in Moscow today.
Longshoremen shut down the Port of New York yesterday. The tie-up is expected to spread today to the ports of Philadelphia, Baltimore and Boston.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Sue Schectman of Scranton, Pa., was elected president of the National Jewish Youth Conference today at the eighth annual assembly sponsored by the National Jewish Welfare Board at Cejwin Camp here. She succeeds Ruth Breitman of the Bronx.
Trans-World Airlines will soon start a one-plane service from the West Coast through New York to Europe.
The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, announced plans yesterday to increase its steel-making capacity by 16 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 -- Johnny Antonelli, the Giants' left-handed pitching ace, who one night last week made headlines with his behavior, made them tonight with his arm and his bat.

How low is bottom? Hide prices on the Commodity Exchange of New York have been hitting new lows almost every week for the last four months. Every time the market sags, many brokers assert that the downtrend must have reached bottom and is now ready for a reversal.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer made final preparations today for his mission to Moscow. He met with his Cabinet and then with the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Meld set a money-winning record for a filly in English racing today when she came from behind to win the historic St. Leger Stakes at the Town Moor track.
MILFORD, Ind., Sept. 7 (AP) -- A retired college professor and a West Point classmate of President Eisenhower are the National Prohibition party's candidates in the 1956 Presidential election.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- "The Director," an original television play by Rod Serling, will be presented on "Jane Wyman's Fireside Theatre," on Sept. 13 at 9 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company TV network.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 7 -- Archie Moore lolled back in an overstuffed easy chair in the living room of his quarters at Camp Kenwood. His hands were clasped on the back of his head and a glint of perpetual amusement was in his eyes. Even in repose there is something strikingly regal about this king of the light-heavyweight division.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -The Opposition in the Argentine Congress asked President Juan D. Peron tonight to appear before the Chamber of Deputies to explain the "incitement to murder" speech he had made last Wednesday.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The temperature crossed the 100-degree mark in Los Angeles today for the eighth straight day. The heat wave has brought death to ninety-one persons since last Wednesday.

Directors of the American Viscose Corporation yesterday proposed a 25 per cent common stock dividend and voted a cash dividend of $1 to common stockholders. The cash dividend is payable Nov. 1. The company has been paying 50 cents quarterly.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 7 -- The Trades Union Congress rejected today a Communist-led attempt to put it on record as firmly opposed to any form of wage restraint.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Representative James P. S. Devereux, Republican of Maryland, told President Tito today that inspection of United States military aid to Yugoslavia was a necessity.
Plans for the production of a feature film about atomic energy in the Cinerama wide-screen process, were announced yesterday by Hazard E. Reeves, president and founder of Cinerama. Inc.

MANY a local youngster used to happy-go-lucky vacation ways will be torn from his bed next Monday morning for that first day back at school. Eager kindergarten students probably will be ready by 6:20 A. M., but reluctant upper graders are liable to try many a mother's patience as she struggles to supervise their preparations and get breakfast as well.

The four - story apartment house at 953-57 Sixty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Estate Securities Company, real estate operator, and then immediately resold to Morris Greenwald. The property occupies a plot 84 by 100 feet in the block between Ninth and Tenth Avenues. It contains suites of three and four rooms and has accommodations for thirty-one families.
The Department of Justice has appealed the dismissal of the contempt indictment against Corliss Lamont.
Thomas R. Curran, vice president in charge of South American operations for the United Press for the last twelve years, was named assistant general manager yesterday.
ATHENS, Sept. 7 -- Greece protested to Turkey today over mob violence against Greeks in Istanbul and Izmir.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 7 -- An official of the National Urban League charged today the New York State anti-segregation housing law was not adequately enforced.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- State Republican leaders agreed today that the drop in farm prices posed their biggest campaign problem for 1956.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The raising of more than $10,000,000 by the Red Cross in ten days for flood victims was acclaimed today as the "speediest disaster fund in history."
Cotton futures rose 5 to 12 points yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.

" We eat good and we live good and they are not going to push us out," said 78-year-old Peter Fusco, one of the few remaining farmers in the Bronx. Mr. Fusco, who is partly blind, is a native of Benevento, near Naples, Italy. He came to this country in 1898

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 7 -- The board of directors of Libby, McNeill Libby was re-elected unanimously today without a voice being sounded in anger. A proxy fight that began two months ago appeared to have collapsed yesterday when a committee of independent stockholders failed in a seventh legal attempt to block the annual meeting.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- The traditional "dry run" methods used by the Army to improve the marksmanship of its soldiers were termed meaningless today before the American Psychological Association.
THANKS to a group of actors from Cambridge, Mass., an excellent performance of "Othello" has come to the City Center, where it opened last evening.

THE occupational disease of biographers is a tendency to make their heroes look better on paper than they were in real life. A few gifted writers of biography strike miraculous balances. A few more go to the opposite extreme. In general, though, the rule holds: the occupational disease wins its benign triumph.

The millionaire advertisers -- those who spend at least $1,000,000 a year in major media -- are putting more than three-quarters of their expenditures into newspapers, magazines and television. This is to be reported by Printers' Ink in its issue that comes out today.

THE mention of the word "crepes" to an American usually brings one response: "suzette." It also brings to his mind a very special meal, probably in a fine French restaurant, which ended in a blaze of glory with the delicate pancakes in their zesty orange sauce flavored with liqueur.
The aging open-air market that flanked the east cliff of Eighth Avenue between West 142nd and 145th Streets for more than a half-century was replaced yesterday by a new municipal supermarket.
Massachuetts, there she stands!"
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The stock markets were more cheerful here today with the opening of new bookkeeping account and a moderation of the tone on wage policy at the Trades Union Congress.
The Columbia Broadcasting System urged the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to dismiss promptly the petitions of those who advocate pay-as-you-see television.
Terms of the proposed merger of Crown Zellerbach Corporation and Gaylord Container Corporation were formally agreed upon yesterday by directors of both paper companies.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Forest and brush fires roaring over a quarter-million acres blazed near the outskirts of two California cities today -- Santa Barbara and Yreka.

TRENTON, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Daniel Bergsma, State Commissioner of Health, denied today a charge that New Jersey was seeking to clean up the Raritan River at the expense of Raritan Bay and the Staten Island beaches.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Congressional inquiries were promised today into circumstances surrounding the 1953 dismissal of Edgar E. Hoppe from a high post in the Internal Revenue Service.

The recent Geneva conference on atomic energy was "a field day for scientists and engineers, but there were practically no business men there at all," according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas Corporation.
PARIS, Sept. 7 -- Rumblings of conservative dissatisfaction grew louder as time drew nearer for settlement of the political crisis in Morocco.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- Glenn Ford will be starred in "I Put My Right Foot In," Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer announced today. The story, taken from a novel by Harry Essex, concerns the efforts of a young playwright to get a play produced on Broadway.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Bob Friend, a right-hander, today came within one infield hit of pitching the first perfect game in the major leagues since 1922 as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Chicago Cubs, 2 -- 0.
Private spending in this country has been steadily replacing in the stream of commerce, and topping, the billions cut from the budget by the Eisenhower Administration.
Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader, said yesterday that France must establish a new relationship of a federal type with its North African territories.

PARIS, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agricultural, gave assurances again today that the United States would not dump its farm surpluses on the open market and disrupt world prices.

A five-story apartment house at 540 Fort Washington Avenue, near West 183d Street, has been sold by Mathilda Goetze to an investing client of Green Selzer, attorneys. The deal was negotiated by Nehring Brothers, brokers. The building occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet.
By the end of next week -- a month after the floods struck six Eastern states -- all rail service, with one major exception, will have been restored.
Yesterday's waterfront work stoppage caught the port's passenger steamship operators in the midst of one of the heaviest travel turnovers of the year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- The San Francisco Opera Association, about to open its thirty-third season, is appealing to the public for financial aid for the first time in its history.

The second group of candidates for "movie bests" to be voted on this fall by moviegoers has been announced by Elmer C. Rhoden, chairman of the Audience Award Poll Committee established by the Council of Motion Picture Organizations.

The New York Times is to be commended for its sober view of the Cyprus controversy as evinced by your editorial of Aug. 29. It is quite true that in the first place the decision for their future should be in the hands of the Cypriote people themselves.

In the fourteenth round of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg yesterday, David Bronstein of Russia was among the early winners. He defeated M. A. Medina of Venezuela by superior positional play in a Queen's Gambit declined and leads with a 10-3 score.
NEW YORK is surprisingly limited in schools that specialize in cooking instruction. The following is a list of institutions about to start fall courses:
A broad city program to increase parking facilities on waterfront land near congested areas was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Federal judge today struck down an order of the Federal Trade Commission designed to shield small tire retailers from undue competition from big dealers.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 7 -- The $50,000 Cavalcade of Golf open tournament is slated to get under way at the Shackamaxon Country Club tomorrow. Forty-six of the 168 professionals who will participate in this new 72-hole event took part in a preliminary pro-amateur competition today.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Sir Winston Churchill reopened today one of the sharpest political-military debates of the years immediately following World War II. He returned to his argument that the United States had frustrated Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's plan to take Berlin before the Russians.
THE latest survey from the Canadian "duck factory" bears out the forecast of peak production, so wildfowlers can be assured of plenty of waterfowl when the seasons open.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The old Custom House, keystone of this community's claim to being New York State's first Federal port of entry, has just been given to the Old Sagg-Harbour Committee, Inc., by Charles Edison.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted thirty-four patrolmen, sergeants and lieutenants yesterday in a brief ceremony at Police Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -The Civil Defense Administration today opened an ambitious program of drafting and testing "survival" plans for use by key "target" areas in the event of atomic attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- The National Association For the Advancement of Colored People called on the Justice Department today to act immediately to halt what it labeled a "state of jungle fury" in Mississippi.

DENVER, Sept. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has extended to Sept. 23 the deadline for an emergency board's report on a labor dispute between the New York Central Railroad and the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen.

May I commend your editorial on the importance of installing permanent personal registration in New York City now? When they had no power to do it the City Councilmen passed a resolution favoring it. Now it is in their power, will they do it?
A new low price has been set in the Maritime Administration's progrram to dispose of merchant ships sunk in United States coastal waters in World War II.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Spencer Chemical Company set a sales record in its fiscal year ended June 30, but earnings were slightly lower than previously because of a new plant.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Carmen Basilio, the world welterweight champion, gained a majority decision tonight over Gil Turner, a middleweight contender, in a thrilling ten-round nationally televised fight at the War Memorial Auditorium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Security Council will meet tomorrow morning in response to a call by the Western Big Three for new and stringent border reforms to prevent any recurrence of fighting along the Egyptian-Israeli frontier.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- Virtually all building in the Soviet Union will be standardized in the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 31:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- American Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to remove a restriction preventing it from offering non-stop service between the San Francisco-Oakland Bay area and Eastern cities.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 7 -- A fleet of 165 boats appeared for the opening of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-third annual race week this afternoon. Seventeen classes were represented and one-third were juniors.
Mary Martin may once more dazzle the small-fry and the adults with her aerial, vocal and dancing accomplishments in the musical version of Sir James M. Barrie's fantasy, "Peter Pan."

TWILLINGATE, Nfld., Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Two seamen probably saved this northeastern coast fishing town last night when they leaped aboard the blazing, oil-laden motor vessel Winnifred Lee and dropped her anchors in mid-harbor.
ROME, Sept. 7 -- Pope Pius XII warned today that tension between races and nations was growing. A strong religious and moral unification is the only way to avoid a catastrophe, he said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Because of objections by the Department of Justice the Minute Maid Corporation has agreed to dispose of frozen citrus juice facilities it obtained through acquisition of the Snop Crop division of Clinton Food, Inc.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Imagine a surprise party on the first day of school complete with ice cream, cake, paper hats and square dancing. Nearly 700 wide-eyed young sters enjoyed just that this morning at the opening of Stamford's new "candy stick" school -- so called because it has three brilliantly colored smokestacks resembling peppermint sticks.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7 -- Canada's top diplomat entertained the leader of the visiting Soviet agricultural delegation at luncheon today to try to allay the bitterness aroused by hostile demonstrations.

A contract was signed yesterday for a slum-clearance project that will provide accommodations for 2,000 families in two adjoining apartment house developments in Jersey City, N. J. Urban Developers, Inc., a group of investors headed by Sidney Fetner, New York builder, has agreed to purchase the two sites and improve them with apartments under the terms of Title I of the National Housing Act of 1949.

Whitey Ford pitched his second one-hit game in his last two starts yesterday. Even with this brilliant effort by their southpaw ace, the Yankees had to go down to the wire to squeeze out a 2-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics at the Stadium. A bases-loaded pass to Irv Noren with one out in the ninth settled matters.
YONKERS, Sept. 7 -- Gimbels Westchester, the first Gimbel store in the New York suburbs, held a house warming today for 4,000 guests. It will be opened to the public at noon tomorrow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7 -- King Paul of Greece told President Tito today that his country remained keenly interested in the military alliance with Turkey and Yugoslavia.

Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Precious Lady snapped a succession of victories by favorites by scoring in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Henry Moreno piloted the daughter of Requested to a length-and-a-half victory in the sprint of seven furlongs.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Britain's economic situation has reached something like a crisis but the Cabinet does not intend to slash defense expenditures or reduce the general level of the rearmament program.

ROSSANO BRAZZI, the Italian film star, made his American television debut last night in "Big Nick," a WRCA-TV drama with as many complications as a bowl of spaghetti and a melodramatic flavor reminiscent of Second Avenue.

HONOLULU, Sept. 7 -- The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island won a victory here late yesterday. The church's House of Bishops in effect endorsed plans for a new school of theology on the island.
A warm note of thanks is in the mail today from President Eisenhower's secretary to a 15-year-old Brooklyn youth who knows the devastation that flood waters can inflict.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Four Senators joined today in opposing the Administration's effort to cut defense spending to $33,000,000,000 in the 1956 fiscal year, which began July 1.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon predicted today that Republicans "will get support from labor in 1956 because -- if in 1948 they 'never had it so good' -- today they have it better."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Jim Busby's perfect peg to third took the heart out of a ninth-inning Washington rally tonight as the Chicago White Sox staggered to a 4-3 victory over the Senators.

IF the pre-World War I nostalgia continues to affect New York couturiers, women will be stepping out nights wearing headache bands low over their eyebrows and hobble skirts under puffy, knee-length tunics.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 7 -- Governor Harriman charged tonight that the Eisenhower Administration's agricultural policy had driven down farm incomes.
DENVER, Sept. 7 -- The White House today scotched speculation that President Eisenhower might declare his 1956 political plans at a meeting of Republican leaders here Saturday.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 7 -- A commuter said tonight at a public hearing here that the train he took to New York every morning had not arrived there on time so far this year.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -- The Argentine Central Bank has cleared up all its old debts to American exporters with the release of $850,000 for such purposes, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- One of the Defense Department's closely guarded secrets -- the importance of the pinched-waist design in supersonic fighter planes -- was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Three boom reports on the nation s economy came from Government economists today. Personal income touched high ground. August employment reached record levels. Spending for new construction continued at peak levels and reached a high for the first eight months of the year. The Commerce Department reported an annual personal-income rate of $304,500,000,000 in July.
BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Bedford Golf and Tennis Club was the setting here tonight for a dance for eight debutantes.
Martin Luther," the church-sponsored motion picture on the leader of the Protestant Reformation, has been banned in predominantly Roman Catholic Brazil, it was disclosed yesterday.
New York's 8,000,000 residents were entreated last night by Mayor Wagner to "fight on our side" to clean up littered streets.
It has surprised me that no one has protested against the proposal to change New York's street signs. The reasons given for the change are to me specious and ridiculous.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The country's railroads will have to spend $20,000,000,000 on new equipment and improved facilities in the next ten years to meet estimated needs for rail transportation in 1965, James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Sept. 7 -- The chief United Nations truce official here recommended today a one-kilometer wide demilitarized zone along the Gaza frontier. He also suggested the erection of an "effective physical barrier" as the "only" means to avoid renewed fighting.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 7 -- The American sailing team of Joe Farrugia, Frank Jordaens, Louis Whitman and Adolph Morse won the second round of the New York Canoe Club International Challenge Trophy competition in Hempstead Harbor today to tie the series at 1 -- 1.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- Following is a communique approved tonight by the foreign ministers of Britain, Greece and Turkey at the end of their conference on Cyprus:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Office of Education estimated today that 39,557,000 students had enrolled in public and private schools and colleges this fall. This is an increase of 1,657,000 over a year ago.

THE memory of the late F. Scott Fitzgerald was dishonored last night in an unfortunate television adaptation of his novel, "Tender Is the Night." The presentation was seen from 10 to 11 P. M. on the "Front Row Center" series over Channel 2.

On tour in Moscow, Senator George W. Malone of Nevada has had something to say about American information activities directed toward the Soviet Union. After nine days in Russia he has decided the Soviet people are not going to rise up against their rulers, and therefore "the propaganda disseminated by the Voice of America and other United States agencies designed to increase dissatisfaction and promote resistance to the Soviet rulers is pointless and wasteful."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Larry Doby slammed two home runs and Early Wynn hurled a masterly five-hitter as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 0, tonight to retain a half-game lead in the torrid American League pennant race.
Avez vous du chewing gum? Hast du Kaugummi? Any gum, chum? Former G. I.'s who served in France, Germany and England will readily recall one or all of these salutations.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7 -- By a single action, Kansas City ended eighty-eight years of school segregation today.
One man was killed and ten persons, including nine firemen, were felled by smoke poisoning yesterday in a two-alarm fire at 149 Church Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- The Soviet Union began today to answer questions from the West regarding its arms control plans. The plans provide for the inspection of armed forces on both sides of the Iron Curtain before the establishment of a disarmament program.

Rex Hartwig of Australia, a finalist a year ago with victories over Tony Trabert and Kenneth Rosewall, made his exit yesterday, almost laughingly, from the national tennis championship at Forest Hills, Queens.
PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, Sept. 7 -- The murder of a French woman and her two daughters near Philippeville last night has provoked a new wave of rage, fear and insecurity here.

SANDS POINT. L. I., Sept. 7 -- An appeal by a Jewish congregation to establish a synagogue in this exclusive estate community was turned down today in an action labeled "shocking" by Governor Harriman. He has a home here.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Originally scheduled for Aug. 17, the annual meeting of Libby, McNeill Libby was postponed when the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission won an injunction against the insurgents on grounds that literature circulated to win stockholder support contained "false and misleading statements."
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Greece planned today to take to the North Atlantic Council the matter of repercussions of the Cyprus dispute.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Vocational classes for high school graduates were proposed today to keep youths unable to get steady jobs out of trouble while awaiting the draft call.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 7 -- France has set up a home guard system designed to release regular troops held to garrison duty by the threat of terrorism.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Following is the text of a resolution to be introduced to the Security Council by Britain, France and the United States on the Palestine situation:
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7 -- Argentina's powerful General Confederation of Labor proposed tonight the formation of a "popular militia" to defend President Juan D. Peron against revolts.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- A Western Long Island Sound skipper and a Cuban shared the spotlight today in the second race of the Star Class North American sailing championship.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 7 -- Beethoven's Seventh Symphony, stupendous as it is in its vigor and large utterance, is for me the least lovable and most exasperating of his symphonies. Nowhere else, I feel, is he so didactic, so dictatorial and so repetitive. Nowhere else does he seem to bully his listeners so ferociously.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 -- More than 15,000 unarmed volunteers have organized a national "liberation army" to march on Indian Kashmir. The band is determined to cross the cease-fire line this month unless the Government convinces the people that India will agree to an early plebiscite in predominantly Moslem Kashmir.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- Frank Sullivan and Ellis Kinder combined to pitch a five-hitter today for Boston's sixth consecutive victory as the Red Sox downed the Detroit Tigers, 7 -- 4. The triumph was Sullivan's seventeenth of the season.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa rejected yesterday a $250,000 claim against the city by James O'Farrell. Mr. O'Farrell, a gymnasium teacher, was stabbed by a juvenile delinquent on June 8.

The "Walk-Don't Walk" signs erected by the Department of Traffic at many busy intersections are helping to improve a bad situation, but they do not yet appear to have the public's entire confidence. Pedestrians still seem to resort to jaywalking as much as ever.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Sept. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Northeastern Air Command said today that if conditions remained favorable the passengers and crew of the Norwegian trawler Jopeter would be evacuated from the trapped ship by late tonight.
The National Mediation Board in Washington indicated yesterday that it had no immediate intention of ending its peace-making efforts in the Long Island Rail Road dispute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A Senate subcommittee planned an unusual procedure today to open an inquiry into whether civil rights in the United States were threatened with erosion.

The stockholders of the Brooklyn Jockey Club agreed yesterday to dispose of the 31,800 shares that they own in the Queens County Jockey Club. This action removes another obstacle from the plan of the Greater New York Association to rehabilitate horse racing in this state, and to conduct it on a non-profit basis.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 -- A Ford Motor Company engineer foresaw the possibility today that automobile accident injuries might be reduced 35 to 40 per cent in the next few years as a result of new safety devices.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 7 -- Julius C. Holmes. United States Minister to Tangier, came to Rabat today to pay his first visit to the new French Resident General, Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Army announced today that volunteers for the new six-month, active duty Reserve program would receive their basic combat training at six established installations.

An inside look at the economy of Russia, along with something of an explanation as to why it does not produce goods and services as the Western economy does, was supplied yesterday by a man who went there to watch a chess game.

" The Prophet," Sholem Asch's new Biblical novel, has been scheduled for Nov. 14 publication by Putnam. It is built on the life of Isaiah who, five centuries before Christ, brought to the Judean exiles in Babylon a vision of the Messiah who would come to redeem mankind through His own suffering.

The quarrel over Cyprus, which has now led to grave rioting in the Turkish cities of Istanbul and Izmir, has frightening possibilities. It is dangerous, unnecessary, illogical and baffling. NATO's Council is to take the matter up this morning, as NATO headquarters for the Southeast Command in Izmir was attacked by rioters on Tuesday and Greek officers and their families were molested.

It is surprising that children think as well of adults as they do. For adults are constantly tossing thoughtless remarks to children who more often than not receive them more gracefully than would an adult in like circumstances.

Whatever the I. L. A. may choose to call it, the effective walkout of its longshoremen is not only a breach of contract but a violation of law -- grossly unfair to the shipping industry and an outrageous interference with the legitimate business of the Port of New York. It is also, for the union, the acme of stupidity. The essential facts on which these judgments rest are clear.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A Soviet Army officer detained two Americans, a Congressman and a diplomat, for more than an hour at the point of a cocked pistol last week.

After climbing doggedly for thirteen straight days, the stock market took a breather yesterday. Toward the end of a session of modest advances on good volume some of the industrial leaders softened, so that The New York Times combined averages closed at 320.41, down 0.39 point.
Record sales, improved earnings and prospects of a higher dividend were reported yesterday by S. W. Antoville, president of the United States Plywood Corporation.
Tennis balls, like suits and shirts and hose, have joined the synthetic parade. The newest ball has nylon and dacron in its cover and its manufacturers claim it is the best ever.

The new and richly endowed independent college scholarship program set in motion by initial grants of $20,000,000 from the Ford Foundation and $500,000 from the Carnegie Corporation is an inspiration to the youth of our country and, by its underlying terms, promises an accumulation of benefits to education.

Tax incentives to induce employers to give employment to more old people, such as are suggested by Leo M. Drachsler in his communication published on Aug. 29, are not a new idea, although this particular plan has some new features.

A New York Regional Red Cross bloodmobile collected 121 pints of blood at the United Nations Headquarters, First Avenue and Forty-third Street, on Tuesday. It was the first day of a two-day collection there. The day's total was 197 pints.
The Navy has cleared a scientist to retain his reserve officer's commission -- but has dismissed him from his Navy civilian post.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- An Air Force colonel commanding a combat training school near Reno, Nev., was summoned to the Pentagon today. He was told to explain school techniques after a weekly news magazine had described the school as unduly rough on airmen.

Mayor Wagner inspected the first unit of Bay View Houses in Brooklyn yesterday. This is the first no-cash-subsidy project to be constructed during his administration for tenants in the middle-income class.
WOMEN are being alerted that hats this fall are "more important." The reasons stem not only from their larger size but also from the bulkier fabrics often used to make them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -Wilbert M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, announced new assignments today for five generals and the retirements of two others.
HATTIE CARNEGIE is to fashion what the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is to the stock market.
WITH large, tough bluefish lingering along the south shore of Long Island from Freeport to Montauk, it is difficult to interest anglers in Great South Bay weakfishing, but the fish are there.

The Princeton Knitting Mills of Waterbury and Watertown, Conn., yesterday filed suit in Federal Court for $500,000 against three New York corporations for conspiracy to counterfeit and use Princeton labels.

Today's new film is "The Warriors," an Allied Artists adventure in CinemaScope and color, co-starring Errol Flynn and Joanne Dru, at the Palace. Walter Mirisch produced and Henry Levin directed from a story and screen play by Daniel B. Ullman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved new low-cost round-trip excursion fares proposed by three airlines for flights between the East Coast and California. The airlines involved are Trans World, United and American.
LONDON Sept. 8 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos said today that Greece would press her demands for a United Nations debate on self-determination for Cyprus.
A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was in critical condition from a knife wound last night because he wasslow in yielding $9 to a gang of teen-age thugs.
BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 8 (UP) -- Thirty persons escaped death today when their crippled airliner crashed into a parked plane and a hangar, killing two crew men and a bystander.

Controversy over this city's schools developed yesterday at a public hearing on delinquency and other problems of youth. The antagonists were Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court and Superintendent of Schools William Jansen.
Henry G. Norman, prominent Canadian business man and his country's Ambassador to Venezuela, was named yesterday to succeed Ray Lawson as Canadian consul general here.

It is Patrick Dennis, author of Auntie Mame," who is at work dramatizing the best seller to Rosalind Russell Note, too, at Patrick Dennis is the nom plume for Patrick Tanner, who will make his debut in the playwriting field.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 8 -- There has been much criticism of virtuoso conductors at the Edinburgh Festival. The critics usually coupled the names of Dimitri Mitropoulos and Guido Cantelli.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Active buying of wheat futures enlivened operations for a time on the Board of Trade today. The bread grain moved up to the highest levels in some time. While wheat and rye were both strong, there was not much demand for the feed grains, and soybeans also held in a modest range.

CHARLOTTE, N. C. Sept. 8 (UP) -- Four children who were found suffocated in a trunk last night apparently died because the trunk lid accidentally latched while they were playing inside, the police said today.
Adoption on the airways of the world of the TACAN system of aerial navigation, urged by the armed services, should not bankrupt aircraft operators, big or small.

Air-conditioning -- the dream of every neat-maddened subway sardine -- came to the transit system yesterday, just when nobody cared much. The Transit Authority. making good on a promise only a month old, operated an air-cooled subway car over the thirty-five-minute run on the I. R. T.

Japanese canners of tuna are being urged to advertise in this country as the American tuna industry does. The proposal was made by W. M. Chapman, director of research for the American Tuna Boat Association of San Diego, Calif., at a conference of tuna industry representatives of both countries, sponsored by this country's Department of Commerce.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 8 -- A drive in Congress for a twenty-year Federal tax "holiday" for Alaska was foreshadowed today.
With only unfinished games on the program yesterday, the positions of the three leaders remained unchanged in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 8 -- A fleet of 170 boats started today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual race week. There was a light northerly breeze blowing, which was of little assistance to the sailors.

The Federal Reserve System further tightened its grip on the lending ability of commercial banks. Yesterday six additional Reserve Banks announced they were increasing the rate they charge on loans to commercial banks from 2 per cent to 2 1/4 per cent, the highest level in 20 years.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 8 -- Istanbul is slowly recovering from the effects of Tuesday's riots. Tanks and troops are patrolling the main streets. No untoward incident occurred yesterday.

Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Kenneth Rosewall of Australia gained the upper semifinal bracket of the national tennis championship at Forest Hills yesterday. If Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Lewis Hoad of Australia win their quarterfinal matches today, tomorrow's men's singles program will duplicate the pairings for the opening day of the Davis Cup challenge round.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Drastic things happened to some of the talent in the third race of the Star Class North American sailing championship series today. While they were occurring a fresh-water sailor from Chicago rose to the top of the standing.

To some observers today is the day we should rightfully celebrate the exploits of Christopher Columbus. For it was on Sept. 9 that Columbus took his reluctant crews out of the sight of the westernmost landfall of the Canary Islands into the unknown waters of "the Ocean Sea."

HONOLULU, Sept. 8 -- A Roman Catholic prelate defended his church here today less than forty-eight hours after a Protestant Episcopal Bishop had described it as a religion of exploitation and superstition."

LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 8 -- Shick, Inc., pioneer manufacturer of electric shavers, put on display today a new plant and a new shaver. He plans to spend $2,500,000 over the next ninety days in promoting the new model.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP) --Burlington Industries, Inc., will purchase the Ely Walker Dry Goods Company of St. Louis for about $64,360,000, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's Government-controlled cotton crop at 12,873,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each -- an increase of 145,000 bales over its prediction of a month ago.

PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The split between Greece and Turkey over Cyprus brought the fifteen partners of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization together today to assess the damage. The North Atlantic Council heard regrets from the Turkish delegate over the anti-Greek rioting in Istanbul and Izmir, Turkey, and assurances that his Government had taken all measures to maintain order in an area that forms the easternmost wing of the North Atlantic alliance.
The International Longshoremen's Association now stands unmasked by its own hand. All pretense of "wildcat action" and "we can't hold the men back" is gone.
Walter Emmons (Smokey) Alston's major league playing career consisted of one time at bat with the Cardinals in 1936. He fanned.
YONKERS, Sept. 8 -- Crowds at Yonkers Raceway tonight saw an unarmed Teaneck, N. J., policeman shot by a New Jersey fugitive, who himself was wounded in the head as they scuffled.
A special referee recommended yesterday against adoption of a court rule limiting lawyers' contingent fees in negligence cases to 35 per cent.

When Adam Gimbel in 1842 established his little two-and-a-half-story frame store in Vincennes, Ind., no one could have foreseen the changes that a century or more would bring to merchandising. Yesterday Gimbel Brothers, Inc., opened to the public a fine new store in the Cross County Center in Yonkers, a center created by and for the automobile.

The appointment of Richard L. Maloney Jr. as a trustee of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund for a four-year term beginning July 1, 1955, was announced yesterday by George A. Mooney, New York State Superintendent of Banks.

The seasonal decline in the Nation's gasoline stocks continued in the week ended on last Friday. According to the American Petroleum Institute, there was a drop of 1,406,000 barrels. At the week-end, total supplies were 153,292,000 barrels, compared with 154,698,000 a week earlier and 153,497,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Massive self-propelled wheat harvesters, wheel-type tractors of all sizes and hay balers appear to be the three items that attracted major interest from Russian agriculturists in their recent tour of this country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States has offered to rush $1,000.000 worth of wheat to India for flood relief, John B. Hollister, director of the International Cooperation Administration, said today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Out of some of the most forbidding statistics in the world -- the weekly tables issued by the Federal Reserve Board -- emerges a graphic portrait of the heart of the economy: money.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Government today relaxed mandatory security controls over the export of technical data to friendly foreign countries.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 8 -- Governor Harriman heard himself described in song today as a "tremendous, stupendous, gigantic, titanic" President candidate. He just smiled.

Johannes de Jong was a Hollander from the Frisian Islands who entered the church, became a Professor of Church History, was in 1940 Archbishop of Utrecht and in 1946 received the Cardinal's red hat personally from the hands of the present Pope.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Government stocks faltered today but industrials extended their rally. After losing two shillings six pence (thirty-five cents) gilt edge issues steadied on the announcement that the bank rate would remain unchanged.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 8 -- The case of the agitated housewife who dunked a Health Department inspector in eighteen inches of muddy pond water is the talk of this town today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon gave the country's Republican state chairmen more hope today that President Eisenhower again would be their candidate in 1956.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 8 -- A bid was made today to end the even-and-a-half-year Communist rebellion in Malaya.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Labor Department ruled today that employer contributions toward privately negotiated lay-off pay plans were not wages within the meaning of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Brooklyn reaction to the Dodgers' clinching of the National League pennant yesterday was officially ecstatic, generally mixed and quite often indifferent.

The far-reaching importance of the American merchant marine and the foreign commerce it transports on the economic well-being of Texas was stressed in a report issued yesterday by the Committee of American Steamship Lines.

In launching its nation-wide drive for funds this week the United Community Campaigns of America offers every citizen the opportunity to bring new democratic vigor and meaning to the venerable concept of charity.

There have been few better recent examples of how to use the United Nations Security Council in the interests of world peace than yesterday's decision on the Gaza zone. The Council was summoned at the request of the United States, Britain and France.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- History reached another crossroads today when Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, arrived in Moscow. The Chancellor came here for negotiations that might well mark a turning point in Soviet-German relations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- United States officials in Ceylon had orders tonight to take steps to prevent a Greek-owned ship from carrying arms to Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The peak of the polio season apparently is past, the Public Health Service reported today.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- A Red Sox castoff, Charley Maxwell, hit a homer to open the ninth inning and started a Detroit four-run rally that gave the Tigers a 5-4 victory over fourth-place Boston today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The Security Council unanimously called on Egypt and Israel today to agree "forthwith" on tighter border controls to prevent renewal of clashes.

MILWAUKEE, Sept.8 -- The Brooklyn Dodgers today clinched their eleventh pennant in all and their eighth since the inception of modern baseball with the turn of the century. They did it with comparative ease before 18,335 fans at County Stadium.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- Engineers of the Ford Motor Company staged crash tests with four 1955 model cars today to demonstrate the effectiveness of new safety devices in reducing accident casualties.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -"It's a Great Life," N. B. C.-TV's situation comedy series, starring Michael O'Shea, William Bishop and James Dunn, will start its fall season on Sunday, Sept. 18, at a new time, 7 P.M. Eastern Time. Last year the comedy appeared on Tuesdays at 10:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Army apologized publicly today to Dr. Alfred H. Kelly of Wayne University at Detroit for having stated that the educator had been "a contributor and supporter of American Youth for Democracy."
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Thomas L. Robinson today became owner of The Charlotte News.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 8 -- The Trades Union Congress defeated today a resolution that had been denounced as a disguised Communist attempt to disrupt the work of free trade unions.

Carl Bridenbaugh has written a companion volume to his "Cities in the Wilderness: The First Century of Urban Life in America, 1625-1742." Called "Cities in Revolt: Urban Life in America, 1743-1776," which Knopf will publish Sept. 19, the volume presents the temper and spirit of the young American cities -- Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Newport and Charleston -- during the crucial years preceding the Revolution.
Volume increased on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and more stocks rose than fell -- but the advances were primarily in the issues that do not find their way into the stock averages.

ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- The people here seemed today to be not only hopeless about piecing together the shattered relations with Turkey but, moreover, opposed even to trying. They argue that the clay has proved too brittle.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Italian boxing authorities have ordered Antonio Crosia, heavyweight, not to fight 7-foot-2-inch Ewart Potgieter of South Africa because of the giant's "agonistic countenance," it was announced today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Patty Berg fired a seven-under-par 68 in the first round today to take the lead in the seventy-two-hole St. Louis open.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Army wrote another chapter today in the international controversy over contracts for the Chief Joseph Dam in Oregon. It announced that the contract for six generators had been awarded to Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The British Government intends to present at the Big Four foreign ministers conference at least three plans for relaxing tension in Germany and creating an atmosphere in which that country can be reunited.

CERTAINLY Capt. Richard S. McCutchen knows a tremendous amount about food. He demonstrated that last Tuesday on the television program, "The $64,000 Question," when he accurately described obscure desserts like flummery and olykoek.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The new crop of Republican state chairmen currently holding skull practice in the capital illustrates what is happening to the Republican party organization under President Eisenhower.

The National Broadcasting Company will televise twenty "Wide Wide World" shows during the 1955-56 season. They will be presented approximately every other Sunday from 4 to 5.30 P. M., according to N. B. C.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 -- Leo Durocher, who twelve days short of a year ago was receiving similar wires, sent a congratulatory telegram to Walter Alston tonight. Then he sent his ex-champions out to beat the Cardinals at Busch Stadium.
NEW YORK, the ever-changing city, is unchanged in one respect. It still is, as it was in the beginning, the haven for fugitives from oppression and despair.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 8 -- A top union official said today that the coming merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would help win wider civil rights and help end colonialism.

Hitler boasted that it was easy deal with democracies: all that necessary is to confuse them. This is now being demonstrated in the outcry against "colonialism." The slogan of anti-colonialism is being sounded by journalists and other as something sacred and not opt to question.

Bavaria of the Brookmeade Stable gave an exciting exhibition of jumping to win the Harbor Hill steeplechase handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With Flint Schulhofer riding, the 5-year-old gelding scored by three-quarters of a length over Mrs. Michael G. Walsh's Rythminhim in the test of about two miles.
Democratic insurgents in two district leadership battles won pre-primary legal victories yesterday.
General Motors' Aerotrain, "the train of tomorrow," is drawing gasps from the crowds at the corporation's Powerama in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- American Aviation Magazine said today that the Pentagon's policy of broadening the war mobilization base had left aircraft engine manufacturers in a state of unpreparedness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A Philadelphia electronics company announced plans today to test a new pay-as-you-see television system in several cities next year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- The Soviet Union appears ready for prompt discussion of international inspection of armaments and an "early warning" system. In discussions here it has re-emphasized the danger of surprise attack in the atomic world.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- The training of Chinese Nationalist officers at United States bases in Japan was attacked today as a violation of Japan's sovereignty. The attack was made by Asahi, the country's most widely circulated newspaper.
DENVER, Colo., Sept. 8 -- The White House declined today to be drawn into fresh debate with Sir Winston Churchill about President Eisenhower's conduct of the German campaign in World War II.

In another South Asian capital I recently had an experience much like James Michener's at Kabul. Though this may have caused me also to become unduly concerned about the issue he raised I cannot feel that Dean Carl Ackerman has fully answered his criticism of the medical service now provided civilian employes of the United States Government stationed in that area.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 8 -- The Roman Catholic Church in West Germany had refused to support the disputed Saar statute. It has recommended that each Saarlander vote in the referendum according to his conscience.

SOMETHING new in the way of an art exhibition awaits the visitor to the Artists Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue. To celebrate its twentieth anniversary the gallery has asked painters and sculptors who have exhibitied there during the last two decades to send in drawings on the theme "Man and Woman."
OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- Now that their tour is drawing to an end the thoughts of the Russian farm experts who have visited the United States and Canada are all of home and family.
Round-the-clock inspection of ships passing through the Panama Canal will begin Sept. 18.
The Democratic party in Queens vibrated with internal explosions yesterday as the primary battle for District Attorney entered its closing days.
It is doubtful whether any other group of students will find exactly the same conditions on their campuses as confronted the future doctors at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine yesterday.

YONKERS, Sept. 8 -- Torrid, the 15 -- 1 fifth choice in a field of nine, raced along the rail from third place in the stretch to finish in a dead heat for first place with the 9 -- 20 favorite. Adios Boy, in the $25.000 New York Championship Pace tonight.
ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- Greece badly needs some new banking institutions to make medium and long term loans to industry.
Carmine G. DeSapio is about to turn party-giver in his campaign to win delegates and influence Democrats in favor of Governor Harriman for President.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 8 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak said today there was a definite prospect that the governments of six European nations would ask their respective Parliaments next year to approve a treaty establishing a common market for all commodities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox and the Boston Red Sox fared the best today in coin-flipping ceremonies that decided the schedule of play-offs should the American League pennant race end in a tie.

The United States Foil Company, holding company that controls the Reynolds Metals Company, the No. 2 aluminum producer in the nation, plans to split both its class A and class B common stock six-for-one.
Sales and earnings of the Quaker Oats Company in the fiscal year ended June 30 were the highest in the company's history.
The New York Central Railroad borrowed $7,500,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the acquisition of sixty-one Diesel locomotives costing about $9,601,637.
Philadelphia announced yesterday that it was considering the sale on Oct. 8 of new issues of bonds totaling $39,920,000. The money raised would be used to finance various public improvements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- "Well go along as we have in the past doing our best to enforce the law," Mr. Gwynne said tonight.

Directors of Pacific-American Investors, Inc., approved yesterday a proposed merger of the closed-end investment company into American Mutual Fund, Inc., an open-end company. The latter would continue to operate as an open-end mutual fund with assets of about $50,000,000. The two funds have the same investment adviser, Capital Research and Management Company, and substantially similar portfolios.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UP) -- The Washington Senators, who are making a habit of upsetting the three top contenders for the American League pennant, did it again today when they rallied to beat the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 4, on Ernie Oravetz' seventh-inning sacrifice fly.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -The 125-year-old boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru took a sudden, dangerous turn today. It brought interAmerican security machinery quickly into action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Secretary of the Interior was accused by Senator Wayne Morse today of sponsoring private utility power that would condemn the Cabinet member's native Pacific Northwest to "perpetual economic malnutrition.''

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 8 -- The United States Navy hopes to land a large plane at the South Pole next January or February. It seeks to prove that flying in the fifteen-man station projected for that spot is feasible.

Commodity futures price moves were irregular in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Changes in coffee, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar, potatoes and copper were mixed; rubber, hides and zinc rose, and, cocoa eased.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 8 -- The man who some persons say may try to become Communist dictator of Nepal has returned to the Himalayan kingdom, from Communist China.

Employes of Lockheed Aircraft Service International, Inc., gave 173 pints of blood Wednesday. It was the first day of a two-day donation at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The blood went to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- Seventy-eight new cases of poliomyelitis were reported by the State Department of Public Health today. The new state total is 2,501.

Since early August, when the first installments of the memoirs of Yoshida were published in Tokyo, a very distinguished American has been enjoying an unexpected and most unusual tribute to his sagacity as a diplomatic observer. For the Japanese statesman's account of official meetings in Tokyo just before Pearl Harbor proves that Ambassador Joseph C. Grew was right in his report to this Government at the time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- A special contract, based on new wage formula for maritime workers, has been approve tentatively by the Masters, Mate and Pilots Union, A. F. L., an by American Bulk Cargo, Inc.
New York banks in the week ended Wednesday suffered their tightest squeeze of funds since early April, 1953, the Federal Reserve revealed yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -The Argentine Government tonight was seeking five high Army officers accused of having plotted another anti-Peron revolt.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- A protest was made today to the State Banking Department against the proposed merger of the County Trust Company of Westchester and the Ramapo Trust Company of Spring Valley.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8 -- Western diplomats here expect Yugoslavia to reduce her armed forces substantially within a few months.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 8 -A group of Mayors and First Selectmen of Connecticut cities and towns that suffered damage in the recent flood met here today to discuss ways of procuring state assistance for their communities.

Because he prefers steady hours on a West Side traffic beat, Patrolman Harry T. Zentgraf turned down a promotion to third-grade detective yesterday. It was to have been his reward for killing an ex-convict who was fleeing from a midtown hold-up Wednesday night.

The country's first installation of compatible color television for large-scale hospital use soon will be made by the Radio Corporation of America. Color sets will be installed at three Government medical units that are part of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Larry Doby slammed Ted Gray's first pitch in the tenth inning for a tie-breaking home run that helped the Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 3, today. Cleveland thus maintained its half-game lead over the runner-up New York Yankees.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 (UP) -- Dr. Kelly said today that he was "extremely gratified" by the Army's announcement.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 8 -- The Soviet Union offered today to make available a fragment of its Arctic territory for use as a Swiss scientific observation post.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution have laid plans for a nation-wide celebration in honor of the United States Constitution. The observance has been expanded from a day to one week -- Sept. 17 to 23.

The United States has always been the first to come to the assistance of countries in need and in dire distress. This time the east coast of this magnanimous country has suffered damage as a result of the hurricanes and torrential rains that have left thousands of families homeless and wanting the basic necessities of life.

Was there ever any doubt about the outcome in the National League after the Dodgers reeled off those lengthy winning streaks early in the season? When the diamond dust had settled Brooklyn was well out in front -- and to stay. The other seven clubs in the league were to spend the rest of the season in hopeful but futile pursuit.
Negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., once again reached the strike-threat stage yesterday.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy called on motorists yessterday to be extra careful in driving to safeguard the lives of school children. He said the police would do their part by strict traffic law enforcement.

TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- The Japan Teachers Union, often accused of Communist sympathies, is preparing to fight Government plans to bring school textbooks under control of the Education Ministry. Officials charge that many teachers, now free to select textbooks without official supervision, choose books containing pro-Communist material.

YONKERS, Sept. 8 -- Five thousand persons entered the new Gimbels Westchester in the Cross County Center here when it opened at noon today. The number grew rapidly. In the first forty minutes, 10,000 free shopping bags were given away and then the clerks lost count.
The Bronx farmer who has until Sept. 26 to rid his farm of four cows spent another busy day yesterday.

SHOPPERS this week-end will find many cuts of meat considerably higher in cost than they were last Friday. Calve's liver has advanced most sharply, from $1.49 to $1.59 a pound. Two pork cuts are 4 cents a pound more than a week ago and other increases have affected beef, veal land lamb.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Two big glass companies and a union announced today agreement on a three-year contract extension providing a lay-off pay plan with $30 weekly benefits up to a maximum of twenty weeks.
Continued heavy traffic on most highways in and around the metropolitan area is expected this week-end, even though Labor Day traditionally ends the summer vacation season.
A national program of disbility insurance and medical care for call may evolve in the next decade, a public welfare eader declared yesterday.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Sept. 8 -- Violence in this commercial capital of Morocco caused five deaths today and left twenty-one persons wounded.
SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 8 -- The lead in the first round of the Cavalcade of Golf open tournament was shared by Marty Furgol of Lemont, Ill., and Walker Inman Jr. of Augusta, Ga., today.

India's Prime Minister Nehru has been wise and right to throw his influence against the technique of "nonviolent" marches into the Portuguese colony of Goa in the attempt to force a decision. In the face of strong opposition he has been able to swing the Legislature behind his position.
There was some faltering in the ranks of the tightly packed American League first division yesterday -- but not by the Yankees.
The port's crippling waterfront strike spread along the coast to other cities yesterday as union leaders and dock workers defied court restraints on the walkout.

"ON THE WATERFRONT" was unquestionably a motion picture that thoroughly deserved all the honors it received -- first prize from the Venice Film Festival, first choice of the New York critics and the Academy Award. Marlon Brando's acting, Elia Kazan's direction and Budd Schulberg's script were all enormously effective.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Samuel Goldwyn Jr. will make "The Proud Rebel," a story of a 10-year-old boy and his father, as his next production. Present plans call for work to begin on the film in December.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Two veteran Air Force officers, both former prisoners of war, said today that their escape and evasion school in Nevada was a necessary part of present-day combat training.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- The exiled former Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Youssef, was reported today to have accepted a French plan to resolve the crisis that his exile provoked.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 8 -- The Dodger clubhouse here was a comparatively calm place after the players came in with the 1955 National League pennant wrapped up.

Most people do not think much about post office pens until they are confronted with the necessity of using one. Then the scratch is likely to induce a groan. But postmasters think about post office pens. A few months ago they thought of something to do about improving them.
What made the 1955 Dodgers click when the same team couldn't make it in 1954?

Moscow, long the "Third Rome" of Russian imperialism and now the capital and power center of imperialistic world communism, is at the moment the scene of one of those dramatic diplomatic interludes which stir the imagination and give spice to history.
Rails, steels, motors and metals pushed ahead in yesterday's stock market, but a slight sell-off in the last hour or so left the net gain for the day infinitesimal,

Futures price changes were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Most transactions were limited to evening up of holdings for the week-end. The dock strike steadied the near-by month on imported items. Coffee, sugar, soybean oil, silk and copper moves were mixed; rubber, onions and zinc rose, and cocoa, cottonseed oil, wool, hides and potatoes eased.

The one-story taxpayer at 105 Main Street, Hempstead, L. I., has been purchased for investment by Arthur Maxwell Co., Inc. The new owner plans to construct a building on the rear of the property, which fronts on the new municipal parking lot. The sale was for cash above mortgages of $115,000.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 9 -Western business leaders were told today by the chairman of the world's biggest bank that Eastern capital would be essential to Western industrialization for many years to come.

BERLIN, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York will present two concerts in Berlin Thursday and Friday as a preliminary attraction to the fifth Berlin Cultural Festival, which begins Sept. 17.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The "jet flap," a method of deflecting thrust from a gas turbine aviation engine to provide extra lift, has attracted attention at the current annual air display at Farnborough.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The Cleveland Indians retained the leader's spot in the keen American League pennant chase tonight by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 3 to 1, at Fenway Park.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Government stocks continued Weak today, but industrial share prices rose slightly. Government issues were said to be looking better at the close, but they lost as much as 5 shillings (70 cents) on the day.
EVEN professional interior decorators redecorate their homes ever so often.

Three adjoining apartment and store buildings at 5191 Broadway and 101-09 West 225th Street, bought about two months ago by the Estates Securities Company, Inc., have been resold to a client of M. S. Gaumont, Inc., broker.
A principal, two teachers and a teacher-clerk who had admitted past membership in the Communist party were ordered suspended yesterday for failure to name other persons in the party.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 9 (AP) -A special assistant attorney general was appointed tonight to help prosecute two men charged with murdering a Chicago Negro boy who allegedly wolf-whistled" at a white woman.

STARTED by suffragettes, the women's law course offered by New York University will enter its sixty-fifth year Sept. 27. Today, when the long-fought-for Nineteenth Amendment is celebrating its thirty-fifth anniversary, the "law for the laywoman" course is of much more importance in that the need for legal knowledge is greater.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The British Government intends to introduce constitutional home rule in Cyprus.

DENVER, Sept. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today a report saying that the United States was winning friends throughout the world with a $5,000,000 program to display wares and its cultural artists.
A fifteen-foot boat landed on Seventh Avenue near Twenty-third Street at 3:45 P. M. yesterday.
