David Bronstein of Russia defeated Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion, in the fifteenth round of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, Sweden, yesterday.

MARKET supplies suggest an old - fashioned Brunswick stew. The prime ingredient of that early American dish in its present up-dated version is chicken, now offered in abundance. Other essentials of the stew are seasonal; that is, fresh corn, tomatoes, lima beans and okra.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 9 -- The Trades Union Congress called on the Government today for an immediate reduction in the two-year period of national service.

A customer walked into an East Side delicatessen for a hot pastrami sandwich early this morning and instead rescued two men locked in a huge 45-degree icebox. The victims had been forced inside with the beer and cold cuts fifteen minutes earlier by two armed thugs.

South Africa's denial of a passport to Stephen Ramasodi, prospective Kent School scholar, needs further examination. Dr. T. S. van Rooyen defends his Government, as reported in The Times of July 23, saying, "experience has shown that to uproot a boy of that age completely from his surroundings would be dangerous to his whole future."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Democratic National Committee released today the text of a letter disclosing that ex-President Harry S. Truman's personal physician had ordered him to curtail his give-em-hell speaking campaign against the Republicans.

YONKERS, Sept. 9 -- Edward Dabdoub, 32-year-old ex-convict died early today after shooting himself last night at the crowded Yonkers Raceway to avoid recapture as a fugitive. He was wanted for several crimes in New Jersey.

Eighteen of the world's major sea disasters are retold in a new book by Hanson W. Baldwin, military analyst of The New York Times. It is entitled "Sea Fights and Shipwrecks," which Hanover House will issue Monday.

Courses in ocean terminal operation and in ocean traffic management will be offered this fall by the City College Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration and by New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey, and other high officials will meet in Paris Sept. 19 with United States economic officers from twenty Western European countries.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Top negotiators of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., met here tonight in an effort to head off a nation-wide strike at midnight Sunday.
If he had not been wearing a shinguard, Joe Collins probably would not have been in the game to hit the two home runs that helped the Yankees turn back the White Sox yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 9 -Somewhere in the mid-Atlantic yesterday seven United States and British submarines began "attacking" a North Atlantic Treaty Organization convoy of heavily guarded ships en route from Norfolk to Gibraltar.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Gun-firing guards and reinforcements broke up a shortlived riot that erupted from a morning-long sitdown strike at the Nebraska Men's Reformatory today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -- The Argentine Army rejected today a proposal by the General Confederation of Labor to establish itself as an armed reserve force.

Herve Alphand, who has just taken over his new duties as permanent delegate of France to the United Nations, deserves a warm welcome from Americans. His distinguished predecessors, Alexandre Parodi, Jean Chauvel and Henri Hoppenot, all worked for the advancement of the United Nations while defending the interests of France with equal zeal, and we are confident that he will do the same.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- The proposed Bergen Expressway will cost $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 more than was originally estimated. This was disclosed here today by Dwight R. G. Palmer, State Highway Commissioner.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- Fortified with a round of golf this morning, President Eisenhower prepared for the descent of the Republican faithful late tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Hurricanes in the East and dry, hot weather in the Midwest combined to reduce 1955 crop prospects by about 2 per cent last month. But production may still be the second largest on record.

ATHENS, Sept. 9 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos is expected back from London tomorrow to begin consultations with his Government colleagues and members of the opposition, and possibly the King, on British Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan's proposals for solution of the Cyprus question.

The sudden outbreak of a frontier dispute between Ecuador and Peru reads alarmingly, but in reality there is reason for satisfaction that it has at last come into the open and is being handled with customary efficiency and dispatch by the Council of the Organization of American States. The incident may now finally lead to the solution of a petty quarrel that has been an irritation for 125 years.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 9 -Overdevelopment of "postage stamp" home sites threatens to turn Nassau County into a suburban slum, Robert Moses asserted today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -France is known both for her scent and her sentiment. Appropriately enough, therefore, it was a Frenchman who received a patent this week for a postcard that carries perfume.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company stockholders invited to subscribe to the new issue of convertible debentures can not, of course, read the future.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Just before midnight tomorrow, some young woman will become Miss America 1956 -- and the new, glamorous subject of millions of dollars in commercial promotion.
Carmine G. DeSapio's feelings were ruffled by former President Harry S. Truman yesterday but were smoothed down quickly in a political double play.

September is the month of transition. There is no question about it, a feeling of change is in the air. The dwindling daylight is an infallible barometer signaling the change of the seasons no matter how summery the weather may be.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- The French Government prepared today to execute its plan for solving the Moroccan crisis. The first steps were expected early next week with the probable departure of the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.
WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 9 -Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston dedicated a Roman Catholic chapel today on the campus of Brandeis University. He named it Bethlehem.
Television's growing pains, so strong that the industry is bulging out of its studios into the street, were discussed by city officials and TV representatives yesterday.
Cotton textile manufacturers urged yesterday that a "cut-off" point be established for foreign textile shipments into this country.

I have read with interest your editorial of Aug. 24 "What Diane Taught Us." In the last paragraph you recommend that an "outstanding committee" be appointed by the President to review the work and efficiency of the Weather Bureau, particularly in relation to hurricane and other forecasts.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The fourth and next-to-last race of the Star Class North American sailing championship today produced some of the startling developments that almost have become routine.
We have good reason, right at this time, to be unusually sensitive to the need for flood relief in India and Pakistan. The Indians, the Pakistanis and ourselves are fellows in trouble.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Don Newcombe of the Dodgers was blasted for four home runs before he had pitched three innings today. The Cubs went on from there to beat Brooklyn, 11 to 4, in the opener of a twin bill at Wrigley Field.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Chancellor of Exchequer R. A. Butler declared today the British Government intended to fight inflation with the "utmost resolution."
WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 9 (UP) -- The United States captured the twelfth international tuna tournament today as deepsea fishermen went through the third and final day of the match without a strike.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -Average primary market prices registered a small advance of 0.1 per cent over the week ended Sept. 6 to 110.6 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The semi-finals of the men's national tennis championships at Forest Hills today will send the Davis Cup players of Australia and the United States against each other again.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The Soviet Union today began to question the United States on President Eisenhower's plan for the exchange of military blueprints between the two nations.
ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- The Court of Appeals today ruled six Democratic insurgent candidates off next Tuesday's primary ballot in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Admiral Radford's statement in Denver -- perhaps a slip of the tongue in a hasty interview -that defense spending would total $37,750,000,000 stirred wide confusion in the Pentagon this afternoon.

TWO half-hour National Broadcasting Company television shows checked in for the fall season last night. One of them was an old regular with a new look, the other a newcomer with a somewhat familiar look.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The United States is discussing with Britain and France the possibility of giving the Soviet Union a security guarantee in exchange for its consent to reunification of Germany, which would have freedom to join the North Atlantic alliance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- The wheat market, which was strong yesterday, reversed its trend today, while corn, which lagged yesterday, was unchanged to higher today. This suggested some back-spreading and also some evening up by corn shorts for over the Government crop report, due after the close.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 9 -- Yugoslavia proposed today using the machinery of the Balkan alliance to contribute to a solution of the Cyprus question.
Joe Collins, a fellow who has a way of doing big things at odd moments, had a couple of those moments at the Stadium yesterday.

Svengali," a Metro-GoldwynMayer presentation in color, with Hildegarde Neff and Donald Wolfit in the principal roles, has been scheduled to open late this month at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatre. It will follow the current engagement of "Court Martial."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A group of America's top salesmen propose to send a demonstration team behind the Iron Curtain to show Russia how American "consumerism" works.

Allied Stores Corporation, one of the world's largest department store groups, showed larger sales and earnings for three periods ended July 31 than in those of a year ago. Included in the seventy-seven-store operation are Stem's in Manhattan and Great Neck, L. I., and Gertz in Jamaica and Flushing, Queens.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- California's major forest fires spread over nearly 30,000 more acres of forest and brush lands today.
TRENTON, Sept. 9 -- Dwight R. G. Palmer, state flood recovery director, estimated today that it would cost $5,100,000 to repair and replace Delaware River bridges battered by last month's floods.
WINNIPEG, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Canadian Wheat Board announced today new restrictions on grain deliveries as a result of a severe storage situation.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 9 -- John Sherman Cooper, United States Ambassador to India, was questioned today on the United States offer of flood relief for India. Details are being discussed in New Delhi and Washington.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The "farm problem" is cutting into the Republicans' confidence about the 1956 elections.
Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Moscow emphasizes the increasing strategic importance of Germany as the balance of power in Europe.

The Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean has made public this week a bold and challenging program to activate every citizen in keeping the city's streets, buildings, vacant lots and public places free from litter and dirt. It has been prepared with the voluntary assistance of one of the country's most experienced agencies of advertising and promotion, Young Rubicam, which will also help in the plan's execution.

I have followed with interest the reaction to the plan put forth by Daniel Gutman, counsel to the Governor, for a buffer committee between the International Longshoremen's Association and the Waterfront Commission.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The United States Army's No. 1 pistol team won the service pistol championship today with a record-breaking score of 1,137 points of a possible 1,200.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9 (AP) -The Chief Justice of the United States said today he thought that lawyers and judges, working together, could ease congested court dockets and thus improve the administration of justice.

Until I read The New York Times of Aug. 24 I did not realize the tremendous difficulty which our city officials were having in thinking of any ways of disposing of the money which piles up in the city treasury. Borough President Jack's proposal to spend $880,000 to remove the subway kiosks will certainly be welcomed by these harried officials.

Cisco Andrade of Compton, Calif., made his Madison Square Garden boxing debut a success last night. The 25-year-old fighter scored a unanimous decision over Orlando Zulueta of Havana, Cuba, in their ten-round lightweight bout.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 9 -- H. Norman Schwarzkopf, bleeding profusely from a shoulder wound, walked into a drug store eight blocks from his home here at 8 o'clock last night and asked for medical aid.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Former President Harry S. Truman declared today that cuts in our military establishment made or contemplated by the Eisenhower Administration were "unjustified" and "dangerous."
Army Military Police, Naval Shore Patrol and Air Force Police now are patrolling the Times Square midtown area and other sections of the city under a provisional unified command.
OTTAWA, Sept. 9 -- The jeers, boos and insults directed at the Soviet agricultural delegation may have cost the Canadian farm machine industry a loss in sales.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 -- The major problem facing the National Urban League is to end housing segregation. This was the conclusion reached today at the end of the league's five-day convention here.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 9 -- Fred Haas Jr. took the lead in the second round of the Cavalcade of Golf tournament today. With a three-under-par 67 over the Shackamaxon Country Club course, he brought his thirty-sixhole aggregate to 137.

"IT'S a fine place to visit, but I wouldn't like to live there." That comment we sometimes forget, is by no means made only about New York. In fact, with a splendid sort of impartiality, it is made, sooner or later, about almost every part of this great sprawling Republic. In the last three summers I've heard it in the Rockies and in the Deep South, in Taos and Chicago, St. Louis and San Francisco.

Controller Gerosa's appeal to the Borough Presidents to sell to private developers that remaining portion of Jacob Riis Park which presently constitutes the site of the discontinued Neponsit Hospital violates a fundamental principle of park-land policy.
Striking dock workers in the Port of New York have been given until Monday afternoon to get back to their jobs or face possible legal penalties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Rea S. Van Fosson, a former A Force captain, pleaded innoce today to charges that he had e tracted a secret document fro Air Force files and had given to the House Committee on U American Activities.

Your correspondent in Moscow reported on Aug. 30 that Valerian A. Zorin, acting Foreign Minister, disclosed that Intourist, the Soviet travel agency, was planning to reopen bureaus in the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- There was an uncommon festive spirit here today as Secretary General Dag Hamharskjold joined his staff for an evening of dancing, entertainment and celebrating.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- Monsoon-born floods of terrifying proportions held 45,000,000 persons in their grip tonight in India and Pakistan. They have devastated some 10,000 square miles.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (AP) -Stuart Engstrand, the author, walked into the lake in MacArthur Park and drowned, the police reported today. Mr. Engstrand wrote "The Sling and the Arrow," a best selling novel in 1947.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission ruled today that it has control over natural gas produced within a state if any of the gas eventually is sold in interstate commerce.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 9 -- The United States will probably launch six to ten artificial earth satellites for scientific observation purposes by the end of 1958.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Silver and white decorations, enhanced with garlands of green and white blossoms, provided a sparkling background for forty-three Westchester debutantes who were introduced to society tonight at the seventeenth Westchester Cotillion.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 -President Juan D. Peron has exactly three weeks to avoid what would be perhaps his greatest political defeat since he assumed power ten years ago.

ST. JOHN'S, Nflld., Sept. 9 (UP) -- A doughty Danish master refused to give up his icebound ship, remaining aboard today with a skeleton crew after United States Air Force helicopters rescued twenty-eight other men from the vessel.

Serious efforts are being made to develop the petroleum possibilities of the so-called Paris basin. A French and an American group are sending seismograph crews to sound out some 20,000 square kilometers south of the French capital.
MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Following is a translation of the remarks by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, at the opening of his talks with Soviet leaders today:

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 596 pints of blood Thursday. Included were 170 taken at the Lockheed Aircraft Service International, Inc., New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on the second day of a two-day donation there.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The Westchester Red Cross refused today to permit any of its thirty-five branches to participate in united fund campaigns. The branch here had asked that the ban be removed for Rye.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- The Congressional investigation into "penny-ante" uranium stock issue ended its second and final day here Friday with repeated testimony that most abuses were being corrected.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UP) -- Pentagon officials are afraid that the new military Reserve program may keep thousands of young Americans from summer vacations.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- The Pakistan Government today announced that it had reached agreement in principle with Afghanistan in their dispute over attacks on the Pakistani Embassy in Kabul last March.
THE Amato Opera Theatre opened its fifth season of performances at 159 Bleecker Street last night with a sprightly performance of "Don Pasquale."

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- District Judge Levi M. Hall today denied a petition by Edward S. Reddig of Cleveland to inspect immediately the list of Minneapolis - Moline Company stockholders. Mr. Reddig is suing for, a special meeting to elect a new board of directors.

Searching, the 3-year-old War Admiral filly who has racked up a remarkable record since being purchased for Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, scored again yesterday. Opposing seven rivals in the $10,000 Joe Palmer Handicap at Aqueduct, Searching registered her third straight victory.
A total of 141,774,425 pounds of Government surplus food is expected to be distributed to needy persons overseas during 1955 by Church World Service.
Seventy-two New York Central and New Haven Railroad commuter trains, most of them New York-bound, were delayed seven to sixty minutes during the rush yesterday morning.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Elizabeth Few of Westport, Conn., won the junior championship with 14 points on the second day of the twenty-first annual North Shore horse show. Reserve was taken by Ronnie Catalano with 11 points.
Federal Old Age and Survivors' Insurance pays $5,000,000,000 to 7,500,000 persons annually and surpasses the combined expeditures of all public and voluntary relief programs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -Confidential Magazine has been barred from the mails. This was disclosed today when the publication asked United States District Court for an order requiring the Post Office Department to lift the ban.
Postmasters appealed yesterday to each householder to look at his house number.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board today approved a boost in the discount rate of the Minneapolis Reserve Bank from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent, effective on Monday.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- A foreign envoy can get no closer to the heart of the British masses than Blackpool, the sprawling Lancashire seaside resort. Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Ambassador, was there tonight to switch on the lights.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Sixty-three new cases of polio were reported in Massachusetts today, bringing the state's 1955 total to 2,563 as against only 428 up to Sept. 9 last year. The new cases brought the total for this week to 290, or twenty-eight under last week.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 9 -Ch. Blakeen van Aseltine, white miniature poodle owned by Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson of Washington was chosen best in breed for the second straight year at the fourteenth annual Interstate Poodle Club specialty show today.
Three teen-age Staten Island boys were rescued last night after clinging to their capsized fishing boat in Raritan Bay for almost three hours. But one of their companions was reported missing.
The Transit Authority directed a mild admonition yesterday at the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., for having threatened a half-day work stoppage by nonoperating personnel next Friday.

I note in The Times of Sept. 4 that certain prominent American and German historians in a joint conference have new decided to blame Woodrow Wilson for "ineptness as a political manipulator" because he failed to convince the Senate of the United States on his views on the Versailles Treaty.
It may be that a Spike Jones instead of a Richard Wagner will write the music for this sea saga. It concerns a thousand cases of onions that left here yesterday on the Greek Line's flagship Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -American Jews were urged today to accelerate their economic support of Israel in view of mounting tensions in the Middle East and Israel's decision to absorb thousands of North African Jews.

Twenty-five years ago Bob Jones of Atlanta completed his unequaled grand slam in golf. Almost everyone who is interested in the game has heard of Jones. But there are some youngsters who often surprise the older tournament players when they ask, "What's the 'grand slam?'"
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Western Hemisphere security machinery moved into high gear today to ease the crisis involving Ecuador and Peru.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission closed for the present today its bulging file on pay-tosee television after both sides in the dispute exchanged final written arguments.

With the construction by the Gulf Oil Company of an enclosed threestory parking garage on the East River at Twenty-third Street a new program is being launched for the conversion of patches of Manhattan waterfront property into parking facilities.

NOWSHERA, Pakistan, Aug. 23 -- The Defense Ministry relaxed security regulations this week and allowed nine Pakistani and two American reporters to witness the first demonstration of United States military equipment received since the Mutual Defense Security Agreement was signed last year.
HONOLULU, Sept. 9 -- A move to drop the word Protestant from the name of the Protestant Episcopal Church was defeated in the House of Deputies today.

One of three defendants in a $500,000 suit filed Thursday in Federal Court by the Princeton Knitting Mills of Waterbury and Watertown, Conn., denied the allegations yesterday. The suit charged conspiracy to counterfeit and use Princeton labels.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 -- Joe Nuxhall, the left-hander with more victories than any other southpaw in the National League this season, did a thorough job of blanking the Giants, 5 -- 0, for the Redlegs tonight at Crosley Field. He stopped the New Yorkers with four singles, permitting only one visitor to reach third base.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A threat of Federal controls spurred airline executives today toward consideration of a code for the serving of liquor aloft.

ROME, Sept. 9 -- Ezra Taft Benson, United States Secretary of Agriculture, said today that agricultural surpluses in the United States were no longer just a national problem. While he gave assurance that the United States did not intend to dump its surpluses on the world market, he said the present situation could not go on indefinitely.

MADRID, Sept. 9 -- Ahmed Balafrej, secretary of the Istiqlal party, said today that according to information he had received from France the outlook for a solution of the Moroccan crisis was "far from encouraging."
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., shot sub-par golf for the second day to take the lead today with a total 143 in the $5,000 St. Louis women's open tournament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, declared today that the condition of the farmers was "tough."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 9 -- Israel announced today she was ready to resume border pacification talks with Egypt and the United Nations truce organization in compliance with yesterday's Security Council resolution. The official reply was received this morning at the headquarters of the United Nations truce supervision organization in Jerusalem.
MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- At the opening of their negotiations here today the Soviet Union and West Germany took up radically opposed positions.

The wide gulf separating East and West is revealed again in the opening statements at the Moscow conference between the Soviet rulers and Chancellor Adenauer. Despite their more amiable attitude, which made Geneva and Moscow possible, the Soviet rulers have made it plain that their smiles do not herald concessions in substance.
ATHENS, Sept. 8 -- Greece is having a hard time getting foreign capital interested in projects that by usual standards should be enticing.
Plans are afoot to send an American production of "The Teahouse of the August Moon," featuring well-known players, on a tour of the Far East and Middle East this season.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Bill Corwin of the American Y. C. made it three straight with his 210 Class sloop Harpoon today in the Manhasset Bay Y. C. twenty-third annual fall series. There were seven 210's in the fleet of 168.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 9 -- The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, revealed its brilliant versatility in the most striking terms at the Edinburgh Festival tonight in a program of Wagner and Sibelius.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- All forty-eight Republican state chairmen told President Eisenhower formally today that they wanted him to run again in 1956. The chairmen, here for a special "campaign school" held by the Republican National Committee, have been saying this all week to everyone who would listen.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 9 -- Representatives of thirty key business and commercial concerns got a first-hand view today of the role the physically handicapped worker can play in industry. They were guests at a seminar at the plant here of Abilities, Inc., where 170 handicapped workers turn out components for fifteen defense and nondefense industries.
With closing weeks of summer there is becoming visible some increase of activity in the new capital market as well as a build-up in the backlog of unmarketed securities.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 9 -- A group of fifty European men and women rushed to the Imperial Palace in Rabat today to defend the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased, for an undisclosed sum, a group of six literary properties from Charles K. Feldman Group Productions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Navy's newest and largest aircraft carrier Forrestal will be commissioned at 2 P. M. on Saturday, Oct. 1, at the Norfolk Naval Shipyard in Portsmouth, Va.
Forty officers and men of the Fire Department won merit awards "in recognition of outstanding fire duty" yesterday.

PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, Sept. 9 -- An undisclosed number of Moslem workmen were killed and several others wounded in a panicky fusillade of shots fired by Europeans yesterday at a funeral for three victims of rebel terrorists.
DENVER, Sept. 9 -- Admiral Radford denied today that projected cuts in the defense budget would require a basic change in the nation's military program.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 9 -- The Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion was held tonight in the Wee Burn Country Club. Thirtythree young women from the two communities were presented to society at the event, proceeds of which will go to the Stamford, Norwalk and St. Joseph's Hospitals.
THE late migration of railbirds to Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey marshes has made for poor shooting in most areas, but the perigee tides of early October promise better results.

ATHENS, Sept. 10 -- The United States thinks Greece behaved in an "exemplary manner" following the anti-Greek riots in Turkey, Ray L. Thurston, United States Charge d'Affaires, told Panayotis Kanellopoulos, Deputy Premier and Minister of Defense, today.
An expanded program of seminars covering all phases of newspaper production has been announced by the American Press Institute at Columbia University.
A retail clothing operation that began in an out-of-the way loft in Waterbury, Conn., fifteen years ago will become the nation's largest family apparel chain this week.

AS every reader of "Sironia, Texas" knows, Madison Cooper is a stanchly loyal son of the Lone Star State. That being true, he almost certainly did not set out to prove in his new novel that civilization reached a singularly low point in West Texas about 1880, but that is the effect he has achieved.
TOWAOC, Colo., Sept. 10 -- Six hundred and sixty Mountain Utes are proving that it is not simple for a people who have never before used money to learn to spend $8,000,000 sensibly.

Assuming -- as they are -- that the President will run again, Republican leaders reduce 1956 to one big problem: How to transmute faith in Eisenhower into faith in the Republican party -- at least enough of it so that the party can control Congress.
VIENNA, Sept. 10 -- Sandor Iharos, the Hungarian Army lieutenant who already holds two world records, surpassed the world marks for three miles and 5,000 meters today, the Hungarian radio said.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- The Stamford Museum and Nature Center is going to bring the farm of grandpa's day back to the twentieth century suburbs.
PASSAIC, N. J., Sept. 10 -- A chemical company had been chalking its losses up to shrinkage and evaporation. It learned today that instead it had been systematically robbed for five years.

"Not Gobbledygook -- But Plain Words" (Aug. 21), by Jacques Barzun, was a reasoned and clear plea for less pompous and more straight and lucid prose. Though he directed his argument mainly at Government bureaus and bureaucrats, it might well be heeded by newspapers, too.

THE lament this week centers upon the amount of effort that goes into jobs that don't show up or are taken for granted. They usually involve finishing touches. The home artisan puts a fresh coat of paint on, say, a picket fence, and his family and friends compliment him on the improvement.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Business in many sections of New England is still handicapped as a result of the floods last month. While rehabilitation work is being rushed it will be many months before some of these areas can be restored to normal.
Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week were considerably higher than in the comparable week of last year.
Two New York rabbis differed sharply in their sermons yesterday on strife in the Holy Land.

WHEN it comes to detecting, Honey Ruffle, donkey hero in Mrs. Davis' latest book, almost makes Sherlock Holmes look like an amateur. He helps solve the mystery of an Indian whose strange disappearance over a hundred years ago has become a legend; he clears up the unexpected reappearance of the local music teacher who has supposedly gone to Italy; and he brings a swindler to justice.

Following is a hole-by-hole description of the James River course of the Country Club of Virginia, Richmond, Va., where the fifty-fifth amateur championship of the United States Golf Association will start tomorrow.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 10 -Construction activity continues to be the pace-setter for business in the Ninth Federal Reserve District, with dollar value of building permits 35 per cent ahead of last year for the first seven months.

IN preparing beef, home cooks do well to learn the tricks of the trade known to all fine chefs. They apply particularly to the stews, casseroles, pot roasts -- in other words, the less tender cuts that demand more finesse than does a filet mignon.
AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 10 -Historic Seward House will be opened to the public for the first time next month.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 -Should President Juan D. Peron fall from power it would not necessarily represent a return of democracy to Argentina, according to Opposition leaders. They think chaos would be more likely.

A SOMEWHAT smaller but equally beautiful and accommodating sister of New York's East Side Airlines Terminal is destined to open on Thursday on the other edge of midtown, at Tenth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Its complete purpose in life is to lick the city's crosstown traffic congestion and bring Newark Airport within twenty-one minutes, instead of forty minutes, travel time by airline bus.
American operators of freighters and tankers are not yet ready to try the fissionable atom in the engine rooms.

After careful appraisal of the economy, Louis F. Licht Jr., economist for Calvin Bullock, Ltd., estimated the gross national product (total output of goods and services) for this year at $384,700,000,000.

Three Brooklyn men, charged with a hold-up attempt at the East New York branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company April 11, were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday. Magistrate Milton Solomon ordered them held for a hearing Tuesday.
Prompt installation of a city owned and operated television station was urged yesterday.

The need for additional Federal judges in the Eastern District was stressed by United States Attorney Leonard P. Moore in his annual report submitted yesterday to Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 10 -- The third annual Pacific Coast Festival of Music began this afternoon in the Sunken Gardens of the picturesque Spanish courthouse when Leopold Stokowski conducted the first of four symphony concerts.

EVER since the end of World War II the U. S. public has been hearing about miraculous rocket missiles. They will fly across oceans, say their ecstatic fans. They will cruise in the vacuum of outer space. They will steer by the stars, read maps like touring motorists and snuffle their way to blacked-out cities like bird-dogs zeroing-in on coveys of hidden quail.
WILTON, Conn., Sept. 10 -- A campaign to rebuild and restock the library of a small Connecticut town that suffered severe damage in last month's floods has been started here as a community project.
Chauncey D. Steele, Jr., of Cambridge, Mass., received the William Johnston Trophy yesterday. The presentation was made in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 10 -The 45,000-ton aircraft carrier Coral Sea, currently serving with the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, is scheduled to go to the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn for conversion to the new angled-deck design within two months.

IN this published version of "The Bishop's Bonfire" the frontispiece is a reproduction of an oil portrait of Sean O'Casey by his son, Breon. Even in black-and-white it is an excellent picture. The face is thin and stern, like that of a bishop disapproving of his flock.

ALL great religions, in order to escape absurdity, have to admit a dilution of agnosticism. It is only the savage, whether of the African bush or the American gospel tent, who pretends to know the will and intent of God exactly and completely.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Planting of bulbs for spring bloom can begin anytime. Set out the small and early flowering bulbs such as crocus and, if possible, daffodils this month. Hyacinths go into the ground next month but tulips can wait until November. Order bulbs promptly and prepare soil now.

In his column, your critic gave no recognition to certain aspects of communism and to investigations thereof by Congressional committees. Communism is not simply another political belief or affiliation, like our two major parties, or reform movements within and without those parties.
BYRON HERBERT REECE, poet ("Ballad of the Bones," "Bow Down in Jericho") and novelist ("Better a Dinner of Herbs" and "The Season of Flesh"), has written a clean-cut, stark and sensitive novel.

HOUSEHOLD plastic cement is never quite satisfactory for gluing together sheets or pieces of ordinary plastic. The bond formed will take little stress or strain before breaking. A much better bond, the type used by commercial plastic firms, is made with methylene dichloride (a water white liquid available at model and hobby shops).

VIENNA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Hugon Hanke, chief of the Polish Pilsudski party exiles in Britain, turned up in Warsaw today. In a broadcast heard here he "plugged" for Communist Poland's "come home" campaign, calling upon all Poles in Western countries to return.
Casey Stengel's finest calculations went right out of a window at the Stadium yesterday as he strove to bring his Yankees home in front of the White Sox.

ASPECTS of life among contemporary Japanese children or those of Japanese descent are presented in these three stories. Each in its own way contributes something to our understanding of the Japanese way of life, although with varying degrees of success.
Defense authorities again are considering plans for increasing the pipeline capacity for petroleum products from Texas to the Eastern Seaboard.

BEFORE the first crisp tang of autumn nips the air, house plants that summered in the garden should be moved indoors. Those that look topheavy or have roots stuffed into a pot will need to be repotted.

Increases in sales of fashion apparel have caused a tightening of deliveries. With record early fall sales indicated, some substantial orders have been placed to guard against a shortage of goods for late fall and holiday business, resident buying offices report.

THE CALYPSO was a new clipper built for the passage around the Horn. Her captain was Varne Tucker, whose wife, Rachel, was as new as the ship, a bride of a few days when the clipper came to her berth in New York's East River.

The commissioning ceremonies for the world's largest warship -the 60,000 - ton aircraft carrier Forrestal -- were still scheduled yesterday for Oct. 1, despite recent failures on her builder's trials.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 -- The Soviet agricultural delegation completed its official tour of the United States and Canada today.

I wonder if as many other people are as disturbed as I over the cancellation of "Blackboard Jungle" at the Venice Film Festival. Ambassador Luce's objection that the film presents the United States in an unfavorable light, it seems to me, is pretty feeble.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -Confidential diplomatic reports for 1940, made public by the State Department today, forewarned of the Communist victory in China.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- The State Public Service Commission will hold a public hearing at Elmira Sept. 29 on a proposal by the Pennsylvania Railroad, that it be allowed to end passenger service on its ElmiraCanandaigua division.

FOR early bloom, novelty and bright accent in the spring garden, species tulips and their hybrids are ideal to plant this fall. Each year, long before regular tulip time is due, these quaint little charmers pop up to relieve any possible monotony of the yellow and white of daffodil time.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Communist China's decision to free United States civilian prisoners will not affect the United States' opposition to admission of the Peiping regime to the United Nations, it was said here today.
DENVER, Sept. 10 -- Leonard W. Hall, professor of practical politics, demonstrated last night his peerless technique at exuding confidence before the press.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- In the week ended on Sept. 3 construction recorded another multimillion-dollar week with building permits in Cleveland at $2,546,000. Non-residential permits accounted for more than $2,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Forty-eight skeptics came to Washington last Tuesday, convinced, so they told reporters privately, that they were to be nothing more than windowdressing for a publicity stunt.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 10 -The Kansas City Athletics tonight announced that Manager Lou Boudreau had been signed to head the club during the 1956 season. It was also disclosed that a pre-season series would be played with the St. Louis Cardinals of the National League.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 10 -- The supporters of the Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, were clinging to one last hope tonight. They felt that only a Cabinet crisis in France could give the Sultan an eleventh-hour reprieve.
ANGEL RECORDS, which last year issued an excellent LP version of Rossini's "L'Italiana in Algeri," now follows up with its sequel and companion-piece, Il Turco in Italia (The Turk in Italy).
The first trade show devoted exclusively to the display and sale of gifts American industry gives to its customers, employes and stockholders will open tomorrow.
The New York Public Library has announced a series of lectures on the general topic "Lifelong Education" to be given this week in the central library on Fifth Avenue and two branch libraries.

When the Zim Israel Navigation Company, Ltd., of Haifa takes delivery of two new freighters next month it will mark the completion of the dry cargo phase of a $26,000,000 fleet modernization and replacement program.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Former King Norodom Sihanouk charged tonight that his opponents were using "dirty, slanderous methods" in accusing him of having sold Cambodia to the United States in a military pact.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- The West German Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, and Soviet leaders attended a three-and-a-half-hour performance of Prokofieff's ballet "Romeo and Juliet" at the Bolshoi Theatre tonight.

The sixth annual Animal Kingdom Ball aiding the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will be held Jan. 26 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds will help maintain the society's animal adoption service clinic.
BONN Germany, Sept. 7 -West Germany is off to a fast start in its effort to become the world's leading producer of titanium, the "wonder metal."
The popcorn business is jumping. Sales are running at a record high, with hundreds of different brands vying for consumer acceptance in what has become a $375,000,000-a-year industry.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 -- A disputed single by Smokey Burgess in the eighth inning drove in the run that gave the Cincinnati Redlegs a 4-3 decision over the Giants before 4,867 fans at Crosley Field today.
Green should be -- and is -- Robert Gibson's favorite color.
Fifty years ago Charles C. Peterson, greatest of the world's trick-shot artists, created this slogan: "Show me a billiard shot I can't make."

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 10 -- The Portsmouth Naval Hospital is providing less than half the required medical care for dependents of servicemen on the base, according to the unit's commanding officer. The hospital is one of the principal military medical centers in the South.
A program of five-year grants for medical school faculty members planning careers in academic medicine will be continued next year by the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 511 Fifth Avenue.

"PERFECT Color Transparencies Every Time," a practical manual on photography with the new high-speed Anscochrome and Ektachrome color films, will be published at $1.50, postpaid, tomorrow by The Lofthouse Company, Box 832, Binghamton, N. Y. In addition to detailed instructions on how to get the best results with the new films through proper exposure outdoors and indoors, the fortyeight-page guide includes material on special processing methods.

In the Labor Day Message, Secretary of Labor James A. Mitchell announced that the number of job-holders in August had reached a record 65,500,000. This is good news, but it is particularly heartening that, included in those 65,500,000 employed persons, is also a record number of physically handicapped persons.
HARTFORD, Sept. 10 -- Both major political parties in Connecticut will have to revise their rules to conform with the state's first primary law, which goes into effect Jan. 1.

Cherished by theatregoers for his civilized mixtures of wit, fantasy and ideas in "The Madwoman of Chaillot" and "Ondine," the late French playwright Jean Giraudoux will soon be represented on Broadway by another play, "Tiger at the Gates." A "passionate comedy" set in ancient Troy, "Tiger" has been translated into English by Christopher Fry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Navy headquarters announced this week that the Military Sea Transportation Service was winning its battle with Arctic ice to land cargo for the Distant Early Warning Line. The line is a chain of radar stations being built across the roof of the continent.

LIMITED garden space need not mean limited plant selection. Home owners with small properties often hesitate to use flowering shrubs because of their height and spread, but this is unnecessary privation as there are a number of attractive dwarf flowering shrubs that seem "made" for today's small gardens and narrow borders.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 10 -- The Turkish State radio announced tonight the resignation of Interior Minister Namik Gedik. The broadcast said two of the nation's other top security officials had been transferred.

FRANK YERBY is an imaginative and resourceful writer. In a series of colorful novels he has blazed a scorching pathway, through a devious tangle of heroic to villainous adventures, against a variety of historical backgrounds.

NEXT week Thomas Mann's novel, titled "Confessions Felix Krull, Confidence Man," will hit the streets, and what has been ambiguous about it was whether Mr. Mann had done any serious work on its projected sequel. The last word on it is a positive negative.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of unilateral announcements today by U. Alexis Johnson of the United States and Wang Ping-nan of Communist China concerning Americans in China and Chinese in the United States:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -Department store sales in the twelfth district showed a tendency to level off for the week ending Sept. 3 compared with last year. Only San Jose, with a 19 per cent gain, and Los Angeles, with a 3 per cent gain, showed increases, along with smaller gains in the SeattleTacoma area.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 -- Integration of Negroes in Maryland's public schools, Inaugurated in Baltimore last September, was extended in the last week to ten of the state's twenty-three counties, with only a few instances of comparatively minor friction.
HONOLULU, Sept. 10 (AP) -The fifty-eighth Protestant Episcopal convention took up today the key item before it -- a budget for a stepped-up missionary program both at home and abroad.
ATHENS, Sept. 7 -- A plan to ring the Adriatic Sea with a modern highway is being quietly advanced. The road would enable tourists to go easily to centers of culture of the ancient Greco-Roman world.

THE Everest saga would now appear to be complete with this latest book -- the story of the 1953 climb written by the man probably most responsible for the final hours of supreme effort which made the British expedition victorious.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott's Mighty Mo made a courageous try for his second straight Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase today but lost by a head to Mrs. M. G. Walsh's Repose. The winner got a break on the next to last of nineteen jumps.
Wells College (Aurora, N. Y.) and Cornell University's School of Education will institute a cooperative program this term designed to encourage more college graduates to become teachers.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 1 -- This country's tourist trade appears to lack a comprehensive effort to promote and "sell" Guatemala's tourist attractions abroad.

WASHINGTON. "EVER hear of an enterprise closing shop because business was so good?" This was the query of a Washington critic when Arena Stage this summer decided on a temporary intermission after five successful years. And a pointed and pertinent query it was.

THE signs and portents pointing to a record year for travel abroad continue to accumulate. It will be some weeks yet before figures on the third quarter of the year (July-September) will be available, but the trend is unmistakable in the statistics on the second quarter.

The Yankees lost to the White Sox in ten innings yesterday, 9 -- 8, and dropped a game and one-half from first place as the league-leading Indians defeated the Red Sox, 10 -- 7. The Dodgers played a 3-3 tie with the Cubs in a game called after six innings because of rain, while the Giants dropped another to the Redlegs, 4 -- 3.

ROME, Sept. 10 -- The United States Federal Maritime Board, meeting in Rome today, decided that the Federal Government should contribute about $20,000,000 toward the cost of building two new passenger liners for the Moore-McCormack Lines of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept! 10 -- Health programs in seven Southeast Asian countries, maintained jointly by the governments and the Forld Health Organization, are making significant progress. Dr. Chandra Mani of India, regional director in the area for the organization, summarized the situation in a report prepared for the current meeting of the agency's regional committee in Bandung, Indonesia.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 -- On Jan. 15, 1950, Lawrence R. Buol, flight operations chief for the United States-operated Civil Air Transport company, landed at Mengtze, in southwest China, to examine local airfield facilities.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 10 -Steady progress was made by retailers in the tenth Federal Reserve District last week, chalking up modest to strong gains in sales over the like 1954 week. September got off to a good start with seasonal demand for fall goods reflecting the high level of employment and incomes in the area.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 (UP) -The Detroit Lions defeated the Cleveland Browns, 19 -- 3, before a crowd of 29,581 tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- All newspaper advertisements for alcoholic drinks are banned in Sweden for a sixmonth period starting this month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Peiping has agreed to set free all United States civilians remaining in Communist China.
DENVER, Sept. 10 -- President Eisenhower cautioned the Republican party today not to pin all its hopes on one man.

Stock traders returned last week from their long holiday in a buying spirit. The demand for equities lifted prices close to record levels in heavier trading, as sentiment was buoyed by many favorable corporate developments. It was the third successive week of advance.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Two hundred golfers are scheduled to start play on Monday in the tournament without a favorite -- the fifty-fifth United States amateur championship.

The formation of a city-wide planning and coordination unit has been announced by the New York City Youth Board as part of its expanded operations to prevent delinquency. The board's research department, as well as its program personnel, will work with the core group of the new unit.
Democratic conventions for the nomination of candidates for Supreme Court vacancies in the First, Second and Tenth Judicial Districts will be held Sept. 22.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The auto industry's huge output -more than 8,000,000 cars and trucks are indicated for this year -- promises to give permanence to a new concept in car merchandising. It is the conviction that profit can be made only with sustained high sales volume.

The Play Schools Association has taken over the Oct. 25 performance of Mac Hyman's new play based on his best-selling novel, "No Time for Sergeants," as its annual fall benefit. The comedy, produced by Maurice Evans and starring Andy Griffith and Roddy McDowall opens on Oct. 20 at the Alvin Theatre.
The New York Republican state chairman yesterday attacked critics of the $750,000,000 highway bond amendment to be submitted to voters in the November election.
CAIRO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Abd elKrim, one-time Moroccan rebel chieftain, denounced today a proposed regency council for French Morocco as a "plot against the country's future."

DENVER, Sept. 10 (UP) -Two Secret Service agents prevented today union men from handing President Eisenhower a copy of a petition protesting labor policies at the automobile agency of the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay in Salem, Ore.

With the National League pennant clinched, the combatant Dodgers could sit back and take it easy for a spell. For the front-office team behind the team, Brooklyn's victory was a signal to accelerate world series preparations that already were in high gear.

THE French have coined an apt word, roman-fleuve -literally, "a river-like novel" -to define certain works of fiction which are peculiarly rich in subject-matter and longstretched in time. To no other Italian novel of our age could the term be applied more fittingly than to Riccardo Bacchelli's "A Mill on the Po," which is centered around the shores of a powerful river, and traces through three generations the life of a flour-miller's family.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Cornell University is establishing a biological and conservation station at Shackelton Point on Lake Oneida, about ten miles northeast of Syracuse.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 10 -The national Congress of American Indians denounced here last week a recent change in Bureau of Indian Affairs policy concerning land titles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has discovered apparent variances between two series of employment figures. It is pressing the Government for an explanation. It contends that the more favorable figures have been emphasized in press releases to claim record employment.
LONDON -- Trans-Iron-Curtain vacations as an accompaniment of the current phase of East-West coexistence have begun in earnest.

IN the recent disastrous floods one of the great dangers was not the flood itself, but the fatal hazards created by use of electrical tools and appliances in water-filled cellars. Actually several deaths were attributed to electrical shock under those conditions.
Governor Luis Munoz-Martin of Puerto Rico predicted yesterday that Puerto Rican migration to New York eventually would decline as economic conditions improved there.

EVERY artist, needless to say, has his own distinguishing flavor. However, judging from the gilt-edge selection of later nineteenth and twentieth century French paintings now at Paul Rosenberg's, 20 East 79th Street, it would seem that the great men of those years carried individualism to a degree that would be hard to match nowadays.
A round trip that began over three centuries ago is, in a marner of speaking, about to be completed.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 -- The Opposition leader in the National Assembly charged Moslem League leaders today with election frauds.

JOHN FOSTER DULLES disclosed the other day that he owns a .38 revolver -- and that, like many others, he had to obtain police permission to keep it. In only a few states, like Arizona, are pistol permits not required.
BIG game hunting has reached the point where some practitioners expect a guarantee of good results before they take to the trail.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -The American Veterans of World War II paraded through central Philadelphia today as part of their eleventh annual convention. Units from thirtyfour states were in the parade, which drew the cheers of thousands.

ON the calendar of Moslem Morocco the last Monday of this August was the festival of Achoura, the tenth day after Mohammed's Meccan flight and a traditional time for almsgiving. The faithful who can afford it customarily donate up to 2.5 per cent of their cash assets, depending upon the fervor of their piety.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The auto industry, apparently headed for a production record of 8,000,000 cars this year, is looking forward to an equally prosperous 1956.
Ten young women made their debuts at parties given in the suburbs yesterday.

While David Bronstein of Russia, leader in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, adjourned his game in the sixteenth round yesterday, Paul Keres, Estonian, drew closer as runner-up by defeating A. Fuderer of Yugoslavia.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 10 -Westchester officials figure that flood control in the county would cost $20,000,000.

BEGINNING Nov. 1 air travelers setting out from Los Angeles for Europe will be able to make the journey without changing planes and with only one stop en route -- and that in New York for an hour and fifty minutes for crew change and refueling.

A BRITISH journalist and former Secret Service agent, E. H. Cookridge has undertaken the task of pulling together the major Soviet espionage cases since 1917 and, by focusing on their common techniques and organizational pattern, provides us with a methodology of Soviet underground operations in the West.

THE arid Southwest repels people when first they lay eyes on it. Those who know it only as they hurry by car from oasis to oasis never do find out what it's all about; those who give it a second look find, to their surprise, that it is fascinating.

Tragedy at Mayerling Many years have passed since the Mayerling tragedy fixed its misery-laden stare on Vienna. It came at a time when disaster was already shaking the roots of the dual monarchy of Austria - Hungary and threatening to bring the Habsburg dynasty to the ground.

AS a child Doris Hart was stricken with a leg ailment. There was concern for her life and only her father's strong stand prevented amputation. The best she could hope for, it appeared, was to go through life a cripple.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Thorium, Zinnwaldite, Glaucophane and Biotite, plus Amphibole, Pyroxene, Uranium, a dash of sphene -- and you're off to a running start on a batch of Scotch whisky.
TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- The Republican -controlled Legislature will convene here Monday and probably again on Thursday in an effort to dispose of the major legislation still pending.
JERUSALEM (Jordananian Sector), Sept. 10 (AP) -- Delegates from five Arab states rich in holy and historical sites met here today in the first conference to discuss methods of promoting tourism.

The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company have made grants of $200,000 each to Cornell University for the expansion of that institution's automotive crash research program. The $400,000 will be used in the Department of Public Health and Preventive Medicine at Cornell's Medical College here to study the causes of injury in automobile accidents.

WILMINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Delaware schools opened their fall terms this week with only fifteen of the sixty-two school districts integrated. All but one of these were in New Castle County, where integration has been in effect for a year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- There were unexpected developments at this seaside course today. The Maine Chance's Busher Fantasy, a juvenile colt who had won only once before, captured the big prize in the $30,925 World's Playground Stakes.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The failure of Britain, Greece and Turkey to agree here this week on the future of Cyprus now threatens to split the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Balkan Pact. Greek-Turkish hostility is rising and if unchecked may imperil the West's defense structure throughout the Middle East.
A hard-hitting drive to break up the nation-wide racket in used tube sales that is said to cost television and radio set owners $100,000,000 a year has begun.

TO this placid, beautiful little coastal village of 2,500 permanent residents, Labor Day means the gradual exodus of some 30,000 tourists. But the season's most interesting guests, from Hollywood, continue to linger. For "Carousel," courtesy of Twentieth Century-Fox, has put into port, in an authentic setting merely suggested by the notable Rodgers and Hammerstein stage musical.

DESPITE much uninformed comment on the corrupting influence of crime literature, there is, in truth, hardly any form of reading so conducive to serious moral and ethical reflections as the contemplation of the crimes (and punishments) of others -- a fact well known to writers as diverse as Aeschylus, Dostoevski and the chroniclers of the Bible.

Nurses in training at Roosevelt Hospital now have a new school and dormitory, completed in time for classes beginning tomorrow. The four-story brick structure adjoins the hospital at 428 West Fifty-ninth Street.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- The honeymoon is over for automobile carriers, which have been hauling cars from Detroit to other ports in record numbers since the Great Lakes shipping season got under way in April.

FOR sixty-five years the poems of Emily Dickinson have been parceled out by different editors in versions that were often inaccurate. Now the three-volume work edited by Thomas H. Johnson, author of several previous books in the field of American literary history, restores to us, unaltered, her full poetical achievement.

THE central situation of Monica Stirling's new novel offers great possibilities for hackneyed treatment -- or simple indifference. Her deftness and artistry have kept it from being either. At the center of this story (its action shuttling from Paris and vicinity to the Italian Riviera) is a love affair between a young man, 21, and a beautiful woman, 42.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Sir Tribal, owned by Charles Fritz of Chicago, today won the $33,700 Chicago Handicap at Hawthorne by a length over the Hasty House Farm's Summer Solstice.

BY now the musical world is familiar with the difficulties Prokofieff had in getting his "War and Peace" produced. The announcement that his "The Flaming Angel" is to be the contemporary opera of this year's Venice Festival brings to light the difficulties he had with this earlier opera more than thirty years ago.
Four nominations for public office and nine Tammany district leaderships are being contested in this year's primary elections. They will be held on Tuesday.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 -Agreement has been reached on a plan for the expansion of higher education in Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Senator Clifford P. Case called on the Navy today to grant hearings before denying applications for reserve officer commissions.
DENVER, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's remarks today at a breakfast with forty-eight Republican state chairmen:

ASSERTING that "philately of the future belongs to youth," Richard S. Bohn, president, and the other officers of the Association for Stamp Exhibitions, Inc., announced last week that 1,200 boys and girls are to be given opportunity to enter stamps, in competition with one another and not with adults, as one feature of the Fifth International Philatelic Exposition (FIPEX) that will be held in the New York Coliseum when it opens its doors next spring.
Many prominent persons are sponsors of the benefit performance of "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme" by the Comedie Francaise at the Broadway Theatre the night of Oct. 26.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Rocky Marciano pushed himself firmly away from the dinner table. He had the strength for it, too, because he'd just polished off a steak in most expert fashion.

APPROXIMATELY one-third of the Congress of the United States is now, as one of my favorite columnists put it, "gumshoeing around the globe." This is perilously close to the high mark for "junketing" -- 190 went abroad in 1947. The rest of us sometimes wish our colleagues would depart more quietly.
AS an inteersted professional observer at the Venice Film Festival, let me cast a vociferous vote on behalf of Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce's action relative to "Blackboard Jungle."

The rising cost of a college education has been an increasing source of concern to educators and parents since the end of World War II. Last week the Ford Foundation, together with the Carnegie Corporation and several business and industrial firms, decided to do something positive about this problem.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 10 -- A light vote is predicted for Tuesday's primary in Suffolk County. There are no contests for the four county offices for which designations have been made by the two major parties.

HOMEMAKERS refurbishing their living rooms for fall may find they need to replace their sofas and chairs because of the hard use they have been put to by today's increased at-home activities -- television, games, recorded music. To meet this demand, designers have been busy creating new styles which have in common an elegance of detail typical of today's trend in furniture.
ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Sept. 10 (UP) -- Frank Bott of Chicago survived a spin at the seventyeighth-mile post and went on to win the 100-mile sports car race on the new Road America course today.
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America will be developed as a "Center of Human Brotherhood." Dr. Louis Finkelstein, the chancellor, said yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Moscow is not generally considered a summer resort, but it is fast becoming this year's prime tourist attraction for Congressional visitors from the United States.

AN antiquated, awkward and even unsympathetic version of a tragedy can still communicate the essence of the poet's thought; such a version of comedy can communicate nothing but the plot and such of the jokes (naturally mainly physiological) as do not depend on contemporary allusions.

Jacques Barzun's essay contains much with which we both agree and disagree. However, he deserves to be set right on one point in his criticism of the General Services Administration's handbook, "Plain Letters."

"MARTY," the third Hecht-Lancaster production passed its initial six months on public exhibition today and a dip into company ledgers reveals the statistics of success. The $800,000 gathered in gross revenues to date means that the film's original production cost of $350,000 has more than been recouped.

The public market for new capital holds the promise of some interesting vicissitudes this fall. Unless the stock market falls out of bed, there should be a constant stream of new issues of common stock by alert corporations out to sell company equity at the relatively high prices now prevailing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Gus Zernial's three-run homer in the ninth, his second four-bagger of the game, enabled the Kansas City Athletics to score an 8-6 victory today over the Washington Senators.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Production in the Chicago area in the final weeks of August started its climb out of the midsummer vacation let-down, the purchasing agents' association of Chicago reported. Settlement of some strikes contributed to the upturn.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- There is a feeling among trade officials here that the condition of the Canadian textile industry is improving, but it might be difficult to find an industry spokesman who will agree.
QALYUB, Egypt, Aug. 29 -- A "well-being" state, which has a physician as its chief executive, is the form of government being tried here for a province with a population of 690,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A global foreign aid planning office has been suggested by the International Cooperation Administration.

THE summer holidays are over. Children are back from their camps and parents from their travels. It is good to be at home with a complete family again. Yet there are rubs. Family routine tightens up for busy days ahead. Easy-going vacation ways are put aside. Everyone has grown a bit, changed a bit and family life must readjust accordingly.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Following are translated excerpts of the text of Soviet Premier Bulganin's statement at today's session of the Moscow talks with West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer as broadcast from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of Interior, announced plans today for completing two National Park Service areas dedicated to the memory of Theodore Roosevelt.

THE Rhine River flows from the Alps to the sea through a valley which is stirring with vital forces of profound significance to Europe and the world. It is still the romantic Rhine -- the Rhine of history and legend, of castle and cathedral, of mellow wine and misty German sentiment. But now it is more than a river of nostalgia; its pulsing life reflects the dynamism of West Germany today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- A total of 263 boats competed today in the fourth program of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-third annual fall race week. Of these, 141 boats were in the smaller classes, from the Thistles down, which raced in the bay.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- A Cuban family dynasty in sailing gained a lot of extra luster today when Jorge de Cardenas won the North American championship of the worldwide Star Class.

ALMOST alone among the French novelists who had climbed to fame in the preWorld War II years, Jean Giono, recently elected to the Academic Goncourt, has staged a brilliant comeback in the decade following the liberation of his country.
CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 10 -Calcutta, India's largest and most hectic city, is this country's largest producer of jute and trouble.
Many wool market bulls have been slaughtered like lambs in recent months. Wool prices have shrunk more than 20 per cent during the past year.

Thanks to a colt named Westward Ho, who was supposed to be the party of the second part in an odds-on entry, the favoriteplayers did some ticket cashing after the running of the $28,350 Discovery Handicap at Aqueduct track yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the issue of Sept. 4 Benjamin Fine, in his review of current problems in American medical education, referred to the famous report of Abraham Flexner on American medical schools as having been commissioned by the Rockefeller Foundation in 1910.

The island of Cyprus seems to be no nearer independence and a subsequent union with Greece than it was before the conference held in London last week began. The Greek Foreign Minister, Stephan Stephanopoulos, is returning from London, having talked with the British and the Turks, with an offer of progressive self-rule for the island.

THE only Norwegian composer of international reputation was Edvard Grieg, a man overestimated in his day, underestimated in ours. A collection of music that will tell us something about subsequent Norwegian composers has been issued on four Mercury disks.

EARLY last month the Governor of New Jersey was urged to call a special session of the Legislature to deal with the unprecedented drought that had seared his state. Before the month was out, emergency state and Federal funds were being earmarked to repair the damage from floods and recordbreaking rainfall that had ravaged New Jersey and other northeastern states.

REGISTRATION for fall courses in photography starts this week at several schools. Sponsored by the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, workshops in photography conducted by Alexey Brodovitch, Berenice Abbott and Joseph Breitenbach will begin Sept. 27.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Chicago's terrific line play set up the only touchdown tonight as the Bears defeated the New York Giants, 7 -- 0, in an exhibition game between the two National Football League teams.
