UNLESS there is to be a radical change in dramatic values or public taste, the violence and venality of a seamy situation like the New York waterfront will always yield more reader magic than the idyllic placidity of a vinecovered cottage.
FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 10 -George H. Hartman's wire-haired foxterrier, Ch. Promoter of Wirehart, today took the bestin-show honors at the twentyfirst annual Somerset Hills Kennel Club event.

IN "1984" George Orwell showed how a new, special language, Newspeak, helped a dictator control the minds of his subjects. Orwell presumably had in mind the Soviet Union, where the dictatorship is termed "the moat democratic government in the world," and where preparation for war has often gone under the slogan "Work for Peace."

A national group of rural educators has asked for Federal funds for research in education to help low-income farm families. The suggestion was made in a resolution adopted at the end of a conference held at Teachers College, Columbia University.
PARIS, Sept. 10 -- The French Government has pledged as its goal in Morocco the creation of a "free, sovereign state" permanently tied to France by an act of "interdependence."
BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Boston University has named a painter and art educator as the first director of the University Division of Art within the School of Fine and Applied Art.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Edward J. Dennis of the New York Power Squadron triumphed with Madeline III today in the third annual Commodore's predicted-log race with a performance of 98.973 per cent correct in his prediction. His observer was Herbert Talbois.

SO many reviews indicate that books have been written to depict the seamy side of life, that I was rather heartened by David Dempsey's article, "Old Favorites That Are Still to Have and to Hold." We read to escape life, to enjoy a few moments leisure.

After fourteen meetings, which began on Aug. 1 in Geneva, the Chinese Communists have now agreed to release the Americans who are still detained in Red China. The first break in the wall of Red obstinacy came early last week when it was announced that twelve Americans would be allowed to leave.

WILDWOOD, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Blessed Sacrament Golden Knights of Newark won the New Jersey championship in the junior bugle and drum corps competition. It is sponsored by the Servicemen's Legion Post 302. The program was part of the thirty-sixth annual New Jersey American Legion convention here.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- A bank president whose hobby is auctioneering has found that auctions give him a good insight into human nature. Also, 72-year-old Robert Wilson said today, they "can keep a country banker up to date on the market."

MAMA, Pepito, Amelia -even Boca Grande, the parrot -- helped Papa make "the very tallest, the very widest and the very finest firework castle ever built by mortal man" to honor Santiago, the patron saint of their village.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- Mexico and most of Central America are attempting to snuff out the constant invasion of the Spanish language by foreign words and phrases.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 10 (AP) -Officials of Gulf of Mexico ports will meet here Sept. 19 to discuss mutual problems and promote trade. The ports handle about 250,000,000 tons of ship-borne commerce annually.

In a sense, identical twins are one person in two bodies. That is, they are hatched from a single egg; they are always of the same sex; and they are physically so much alike that their own mothers find it difficult to tell them apart. They constitute ideal subjects for the study of the effect of heredity and environment.
Emotionally disturbed adolescent girls cared for by the Girls Service League will benefit from the Nov. 10 performance of "The Chalk Garden." The comedy, starring Gladys Cooper, opens Oct. 26.

BEFORE the new season overwhelms us, as it will begin to do any minute now with Sadler's Wells' half a dozen scheduled novelties, there are one or two postscripts that are pressing to be added to the account of last month's modern dance festival at New London.

CAIRO, Sept. 10 -- The dawn always has come after the darkest hour, so it may be that Egyptian-Israeli peace will presently glimmer in the East. But observers here have not yet seen anything hopeful in their night glasses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Following are lists of ten Americans who the State Department said would be released soon by Communist China and of nineteen other Americans to be released "expeditiously":
McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., Sept. 10 -- This installation was dedicated today as the Air Force's largest and busiest air transport base in the country.

HONOLULU, Sept. 10 -- The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church proposed today that all delegates to the fifty-eighth Triennial General Convention contribute to build a new church in the Pearl Harbor area. The edifice would serve as a token of appreciation for the hospitality of the islanders.

What has sparked the rapid rise of the Reynolds Metals Company to a secure position as the nation's second largest aluminum producer? Many factors can be cited, but probably the most important is an intangible one -- "incurable optimism."

IN the issue of Sunday, Aug. 7, 1955, The New York Times (Page 76) and its Book Review Section (Page 8) published a news item and an editorial comment regarding the claim that Mrs. Frances Ford, a woman reputed to be 101 years old, is the author of the literary theme of "The Little Engine That Could."
A campaign for $1,675,000 has been started by Greer, a children's community for youngsters from broken homes. In December it will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Army plans to use its conventional eight-inch gun as an eventual replacement for the heavy and cumbersome 280-millimeter atomic cannon.

LIFE among the Mormons after Brigham Young's death was portrayed Ardyth Kennelly's first novel. Linnea Ecklund was the central character and in this, the author's fourth book, she once again takes up the story of Linnea, Olaf, her husband, and their children.
Demand for higher education in the United States continues to grow at an increasing rate while educational facilities lag.

The sixty student singers of the New York University Glee Club will move today into their pre-season training camp at Pocono Pines, Pa. The university trains its singers almost as hard as it does its football players.

DID you know that a man once wrote a book to prove that Byron was a centipede? Or that a codfish caught off the coast of England, when cut open, yielded three religious tracts dedicated to Lord Cromwell?

WHEN Vladimir M. Matskevitch, Acting Soviet Minister of Agriculture and spokesman for the Russian farm group visiting America, told a National Press Club audience that more than anything else he wanted to import into Russia some of America's Santa Gertrudis cattle, the State Department interpreter brought smiles from farm correspondents by translating the name "Santa Gertrude."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Public schools in the District of Columbia opened this week with the boast of the Superintendent that racial lines no longer existed in the educational system of the nation's capital.

WHEN Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony come to Greece this fall, they will play for a country with a multicolored musical life, a country that in music -as in literature and the arts -begins again to fill an importan role between East and West, the ancient and the new.

DURING the summer this Sunday space was once occupied by a characteristically entertaining article written by Guy Bolton. "Let's Be Friends" was the title. "Why can't a playwright be friends with a critic?" was the burden of Mr. Bolton's wistful argument.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10 (UP) -- A union order to return to work was booed today at a meeting of striking employes of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation.

A PROJECT is under way that would give New Yorkers something they've never had before -- an "allnight" television show. The proposed program, titled "Night Time New York," would be on the air from 1 to 7 A. M., giving insomniacs something to do until Dave Garroway gets up.

MARY MARTIN is living out of a trunk this summer in the best theatrical tradition, what with an itinerary that includes such widely scattered posts as Paris. Broadway, Flatbush and the British West Indies.
The American public, using twenty-five words or less, has endorsed the institution of the prize contest.
Monkey business is big business -- in the air.

A group of business men will hold a luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on Sept. 19 to honor the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau's accomplishments in the last ten years. More than 1,500 persons are expected to attend the gathering, at which Mayor Wagner will be the principal speaker.

WITH the 1956 models coming into production, no radical departures from the 1955 cars are as yet in sight. The difference between this year's and next year's cars will be in terms of improved mechanism, lower silhouettes, still more powerful engines, elongated and elevated rear fenders and interior refinements.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 10 -Top Republican leaders of Mount Vernon and New Castle are locked in battle for public-office nominations in Tuesday's primaries. New Rochelle and Pelham have lesser Republican contests.

THE next few years may turn out to be an era of good feeling at the Metropolitan Opera. It looks as though some problems have been solved for the time being, and others have a fine chance of being solved.

Too many gardeners struggle to put a formal planting in every nook and corner of the property. Actually, a few natural areas would be a great asset and lend a feeling of depth and quiet to the property.

Waterfront strike leaders left New York yesterday to drum up support in other ports, as the Waterfront Commission once more rejected demands for a buffer committee. The commission said it would discuss grievances only with the dock union. Union officials still hoped to obtain a review of commission action by an impartial body of citizens.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 10 -Only one fight for a major county office nomination will be decided by Nassau voters in Tuesday's primary elections. Their ballots, however, will determine the future Republican party leaders in Westbury and New Hyde Park, and the Democratic chief of Levittown. Committee rights have developed in all three communities.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 8 -- The planners of the United States expedition to Antarctica are working on a program of five tractor journeys designed to study the volume of the Antarctic ice sheet.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 10 -- Within the next few months the inventiveness and ingenuity of the Republican and Democratic parties will be up for a strenuous testing.

THE impudent, and one-time omnipotent, sage of Baltimore will be 75 tomorrow. In consonance with that solemn occasion, it may be fitting to refer to him by his full baptismal name, Henry Louis Mencken, even though he ranks among the few (R. L. S., T. R., G. B. S., F. P. A. and F. D. R.) who are as well known by their initials as by their given and family names.

LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- British and associated Dutch oil companies produced a record 111,430,000 metric tons of oil (including natural gasoline) last year. This was an increase of about 7.5 per cent over 1953, the previous record.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 -- The bitterness between United States business men and South Korean tax officials reached its peak this week-end. Each side issued a statement accusing the other of resorting to Communist practices.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Completion of additions to two schools here will be delayed one to two months because the necessary steel has been allotted to flood-stricken areas.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 -- Israeli political military leaders no longer expect the Arabs to make peace with them in the present generation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The Brooklyn Dodgers and the Chicago Cubs played to a 3-3 tie today as rain ended their final meeting of the season after six innings. Most of the 11,796 fans at Wrigley Field were more disappointed at the outcome than the National League champions or the Cubs were.
BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Combing five pitchers for eighteen hits, the American League-leading Cleveland Indiana defeated the Boston Red Sox, 10 -- 7, at Fenway Park today.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 10 -- The Government has decided to ban crossword puzzles and other forms of competition carrying high money prizes that are regularly run by a number of newspapers.

SHARP contrasts within a limited area may be very illuminating. Such is the case with the joint exhibition of paintings by Georgio de Chirico and the late Yves Tanguy which has just inaugurated the new season at the Museum of Modern Art.

THE impetus of the boom is carrying business upward on the charts after a leveling off during July and August. The continued expansion of inventories and demand for scarce materials has the Administration worried, and there is more caution being shown in the matter of credit expansion.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A new vista of people-to-people relations and competition of ideas may lie ahead for the United States and the Soviet Union.
The melting of sales resistance to frozen foods gained momentum during the hot summer.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- The Most Rev. Joseph E. Ritter, Archbishop of St. Louis, announced plans yesterday for completing and modernizing St. Louis Cathedral at an estimated cost of $1,780,000.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (UP) -The Baltimore Orioles capitalized on three Detroit errors in the sixth inning to score three unearned runs and defeat the Tigers, 5 -- 3, today.

IN an ivy covered garden in back of one of Baltimore's red brick, marble-trimmed row houses, an old man dozes. Opposite him is a massive brick wall studded with strange ornaments -- a plaque of the family coat of arms, a Beethoven death mask under which is carved the opening bars of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, a stone Cupid which serves as the figurehead of a fountain.
The United States has yet to convince Europeans of its readiness to end the "cold war," an American Jewish leader said yesterday after a summer tour of Europe.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The United States public is not disturbed about United States trade barriers and no change can be expected in that country's trade policies, a three-nation conference was told here today.
HAVANA. EVERY night at 10:30 o'clock most of the 5,000 United States residents here and a good number of natives tune in to the only English-speaking voice on Cuban television.

On Labor Day Col. Horace A. Hanes, an Air Force test pilot, beat the world's jet-speed record by going through the sound barrier in straight and level flight at 822.135 miles an hour. The speed of sound at sea level is 763 miles an hour at 59 degrees F.

PRINCESS MARGARET'S "coming of age" may have solved some emotional problems for her but it left unsolved one semantic problem that has plagued the palace correspondents: What to call the young men attentive to and attendant on the Princess.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- Miss Colorado, a 5-foot-6 redhead, was named Miss America 1956 just before midnight today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 10 -- The Korean Ambassador to Washington, Dr. You Chan Yang, said here today that voluntary withdrawal of the Swiss and Swedish members of the truce inspection body was the answer to dissolution of the controversial agency.
LeRoy Baxter has "learned a lot" about wheel chairs in the sixteen years in which paraplegia has confined him to one.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 10 -Quarterback Claude Benham demonstrated his passing wizardry today as Columbia University's football team played its first intrasquad game. The Lions' star, a. junior, completed ten of fifteen pass attempts as he sparked his Blue eleven to a 34-19 victory against the Red squad at Camp Columbia.

VISITORS from England, South Africa, as well as all parts of this country find their way, when in southern California, to a world famous collection of plants for arid areas. Here at the Huntington Botanical Garden flourish twelve acres of plants that are resistant to drought.

GIOVANNI VERGA is the most modern of the old Italian novelists and also the greatest, with the exception of Alessandro Manzoni. But while it is difficult to imagine Manzoni becoming popular today outside of Italy, this is conceivable in Verga's case: his art holds a strong appeal to the contemporary reader.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A co-author of the 1952 immigration act fired back at the critics today.
Two drivers and a passenger lost their lives, in three separate automobile accidents in Queens early yesterday.

IN January, 1932, Walter Lippmann wrote his famous description of Franklin Roosevelt as "a pleasant man who, without any important qualifications for the office, would very much like to be President." Roosevelt looked that way to a good many Americans in 1932, including millions who voted for him to get rid of Hoover.
The New York Vassar Club has taken over the entire Metropolitan Opera House for the performance of "Andrea Chenier" the evening of Jan. 14. Renata Tebaldi will sing the title role.

Since last Wednesday the International Longshoremen's Association has thoroughly and convincingly shut the great Port of New York. Not a single dock worker has moved cargo and there is no indication any will until the union gives the word.

RICHMOND, Sept. 10 -- Judged by bank debits the general business picture in the Fifth Reserve District in the first seven months of 1955 bettered the 1954 figure by 12 per cent. August debits were up 18 per cent. The total debits for seven months reached $50,320,000,000.

L. A. decided it was time to change presidents.

That means, at the outset, the problems of teacher shortage, of schoolroom shortage and, more often than not, shortage of funds.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 10 -There are no contests in Rockland County in the Tuesday primary election. Candidates will be nominated for two county offices, in each case without opposition.

THIS collection of one hundred folk tales, brought together and annotated by the chairman of the English Department at Long Island University, is entertaining and instructive. Reading these stories -- now witty, now humorous, again cruelly sardonic, or fantastical and dreamlike -- we are above all reminded, as James R. Foster no doubt intended us to be, that human nature changes only slowly, if at all.

As a singer, Kathleen Ferrier achieved greatness in a few short years. She found she had a voice when she was well past 20, and she did not become a celebrity until after World War II. She was hardly past 40, when in 1953 her voice was stilled forever.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Firefighters reinforced by battalions of Army troops and Marines battled two of California's major forest fires to a standstill today. At least five other blazes, however, still raged unchecked.

Early last Tuesday afternoon a special train from Bonn slowed to a halt at Brest on the RussianPolish frontier. Giant railway cranes were moved along side. One by one the thirteen coaches were lifted from their wheels and swung onto wheels fitted to Russia's widegauge tracks.

FOR the last twenty years of Sir James Barrie's life Cynthia Asquith was his "private, private secretary." As such, it was her job to deal with most of the routine mail that showered upon her unpredictable employer, to try to forecast his mood in regard to engagements and generally to take the buffet and cushion the shock.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- A brisk upturn in production of children's shoes by factories in this area during the summer has been followed by gains of 5 to 10 per cent in retail sales during the back-to-school buying of the last two weeks.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The State Department's recent refusal to grant me a passport to visit China has implications important for the American people to understand.

THIS year's Wagner festival at Baireuth offered no shocks or surprises such as have charged the atmosphere here since 1951, when the first post-war festival was produced. Wolfgang Wagner's new production of "The Flying Dutchman" displayed no noteworthy departures from tradition, aside from the sort of visual simplification that has become standard in recent years at Baireuth.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Once again the British economy is teetering on the edge of a crisis. Once again the situation has encouraged the party in opposition to assail Government policies. Once again the Government is casting about for measures to restore confidence and avert danger.

THE fourth factor that classical economists ignored when they attributed the creation of wealth to land, labor and capital has recently acquired increased importance, says economist George Soule. This factor is Time.

A COOKBOOK writer is no longer by definition a home economist or a food expert or even someone who spends long hours over a stove inventing new recipes for publication. The only prerequisites are an enthusiasm for food, an understanding of its preparation and the ability to communicate this to the reader.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse called on the Interstate Commerce Commission today to conduct a "searching investigation" into the reasons behind the current railroad freight car shortage.

More children will be adopted as a result of the first annual children's benefit to be held by the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.

For several years the Atomic Energy Commission has followed a policy of lending special nuclear material to nonprofit institutions without charge for research and for the development of reactor projects. CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Sept. 10 -- Jews have lived in Morocco since the time of the destruction of the Temple at Jerusalem in 70 A. D. and perhaps before that. Now they are leaving this troubled country.

Fast races marked the City Island Yacht Club's twenty-second annual set of overnight sailing contests. All but nine of the twenty-nine starters had been clocked at the finish line in Eastchester Bay by 9:30 last night.

THE approach of cooler weather is a reminder that the fall planting season is here. If any new plants are necessary, either to complete a planting group or to start a new one, now if the time to decide what to buy.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -Although 2 per cent higher than in July, 1954, employment in Pennsylvania was still 5 per cent below the level reached in July, 1953. The reason for this lag, in contrast to gains made elsewhere in the nation, is largely the fact that Pennsylvania is an industrial state and employment in industry has not come back to where it was in 1953, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported yesterday.

AT this time of year the amateur or hobbyist carefully selects his best flowers and enters them in competition at the local garden and harvest shows. THE hybrid rhododendrons commonly sold by the Eastern nurseries are great favorites with the gardening public. However, they come into flower in one great rush of color in late May or June and then they are finished.

NEWARK, Sept. 10 -- A group of Westinghouse Electric Corporation workers started action today to call a special meeting of the company's stockholders. The workers are also stockholders.

When the 410 Catholic elementary and secondary schools of the New York Archdiocese open tomorrow, 195,000 pupils will enroll. Of this number, 156,000 will be registered in the elementary grades. Msgr. John Paul Haverty, diocesan superintendent of schools, pointed out that the student enrollment exceeds the combined total public elementary and secondary school population of each of fourteen states.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10 -- Retail trade is continuing at an accelerated pace in the southeast. Heavy promotions of fall apparel, home furnishings and appliances were accompanied this week by brisk sales of a wide variety of items.

HOLLYWOOD. DESILU PRODUCTIONS INC., formed in 1919 by Desi Arnaz and Lucille Ball, has bloomed as an outstanding example of successful television film production. CARACAS, Venezuela, Septj ll--Alexander Calder, sculptor from Roxbury, Conn., opened an exhibition here today of his "mobiles," which seem to have taken Venezuelan art circles by storm.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 (AP) -Manager Lou Boudreau of the Kansas City Athletics gambled with two rookie pitchers against the Baltimore Orioles today and got an even break. The Athletics won the first game of a double-header, 4 -- 3, and dropped the second contest, 4 -- 2.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Wheat and rye futures were strong last week, while coarse grains and soybeans were a more mixed proposition. Buying demand for the latter was confined largely to periods of modest setbacks.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL, a man in a daze, wandered aimlessly around the Yankee dressing room before yesterday's key double-header with the Cleveland Indians. His mind was not on the present or even the immediate future. It was filled with nightmarish memories of the recent past, the untidy game that his heroes had inexcusably dropped to the White Sox the day before.

THE Helen Hayes-Mary Martin revival of "The Skin of Our Teeth" came to the end of its journeys last night. DENVER, Sept. 11 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that proper education for the atomic age requires a nation-wide system of free junior colleges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development said today that throughout most of the world production was drawing ahead of population. It added that living standards were on the rise.
An eight-story office and showroom building at 659-63 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty - second and Fifty-third Streets, has been purchased for investment by David W. Frankel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Government said today that a new pinch-waisted design in military aircraft had produced increases up to 25 per cent in supersonic speeds.
An over-all record time was set in the City Island Yacht Club's twenty - second annual overnight race program over the week-end, it was disclosed yesterday.
MONZA, Italy, Sept. 11 -- Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina drove his slick silver Mercedes to victory today in the twenty-sixth annual 500-kilometer (310 1/2 miles) Grand Prix of Italy.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The Government appealed tonight to the tense French and native populations of Morocco to await calmly decisions it implied were imminent.
The Brookhattan-Galicia soccer team defeated the New York Americans, 4 -- 2, in an exhibition game at Zerega Oval yesterday. The score was 2 -- 2 at the intermission.

The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, hardware producer, is issuing to its stockholders rights to subscribe for 106,931 new shares of stock at $56 a share, at the rate of one new share for each six held on Sept. 9.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 11 -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-third annual Race Week ended today as a fleet of 227 sloops took advantage of fine sailing weather. Close finishes were the order of the day.
Final preparations for tomorrow's primary occupied candidates, nonpartisan political groups and the police yesterday.
AT the Saturday evening Interval Concert in Carnegie Recital Hall the artist was Avram Lavin. He gave a 'cello recital, with the assistance of Edward Hausman at the piano.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Another overcrowded year of school is opening with no Federal aid for school construction in sight.

The automobile and other recent union-management agreements providing for company-financed unemployment benefits contain three important hurdles which must be taken before the plans are put into effect. These now seem to be in varying stages of elimination.
Thirty thousand persons pledged allegiance to the United States yesterday at the sixteenth annual Citizenship Day celebration on the Mall in Central Park.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- A pitcher may get away with other lapses, but when he walks his opposing moundsman he's definitely in trouble.
It costs more to go to college today than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore said today the Eisenhower Administration "has ducked every invitation" to tell Congress how it stood on proposed changes in the controversial McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- Miss America 1956 has red hair and a philosophy. She is both a fatalist and an optimist.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 -- Baffled and befuddled, the champion Brooklyn Dodgers couldn't even win an argument with the umpires today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Desilu Productions is planning to make a series of half-hour television films based on the adventures of two boys of foreign birth who are adopted by a young American.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -Detroit and Washington exchanged four-hit shutouts in splitting a double-header today.

That gigantic institution of learning, the New York City public school system, opens its doors today to an expected 923,505 school children, a number larger than the entire population of any city in the United States save the top six at the 1950 census.
Governor Harriman charged yesterday that President Eisenhower had failed to fulfill his 1952 campaign promises to the farmer.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 8 -Gov. George M. Leader is regarded here, after nine months in office, as a Democrat with a potential national future -- unless he stubs his toe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The aircraft industry reported today that it paid $4,759,320,000 to 50,000 subcontractors in the year ended June 30, 1954.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Sept. 11 -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff, the Memphis dentist who plays out of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., captured the first prize of $10,000 in the $50,000 Cavalcade of Golf open tournament at the Shackamaxon Country Club today. He shot a final-round 65 for a 72-hole total of 276.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 -Steel production rose a bit last week, but demand more than matched output. Most mills could fill their books for the first quarter of 1956 if they were to open them wide.

The Walworth Company has acquired the assets and business of the Alloy Steel Products Company, Inc., Linden, N. J., manufacturer of valves, it was announced over the week-end by Fred W. Belz, president of Walworth.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Composers, writers and other creative artists are due to acquire this week a measure of protection for their work beyond any extended to them in decades.

The American Legion's Distinguished Service Medal will be awarded to Representative Herbert C. Bonner, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, by the Robert L. Hague Merchant Marine Industries Post.

Manhattan has seen its share of intrepid mariners and unusual harbor craft since the days of Robert Fulton and, before him, the famed Cap'n Billop. But yesterday, for the first time, the Hudson, East and Harlem Rivers became a raceway for stock outboard craft, some downright tiny, fragile and almost paper thin.

Puget Sound Power and Light Company will hold a special meeting of stockholders on Oct. 20 at Boston, Frank McLaughlin, president, announced. Record date for meeting will be Sept. 20. This will be the first stockholders' meeting to be held by the company in more than two years, following lengthly litigation and attempts of a stockholders' committee to effect a merger with the Washington Water Power Company.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Peru proposed today an exchange of military inspection teams with Ecuador to clarify the situation in their disputed border zone.
Three clergymen in sermons this week-end voiced skepticism about the current revival of religious "faith."
A Second Avenue block near the United Nations headquarters has been selected as the site for a modern office building.
How does one spot a potentially great tennis player when what one sees is only an athletically inclined boy?
Nitroparaffins, a new family of chemicals with a growing range of uses, are now available in volume for the first time.
THE observation deck of the Empire State Building opens at 9:30 A. M. There never has been any demand for an earlier hour.

In the closing weeks of 1954 the Federal Reserve authorities, convinced that business recovery had reached the point where further stimulation would be likely to do more harm than good, abandoned their "actively easy money" policy in favor of a more negative version.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had his first look today at simple Soviet people.

So much has been written about the conquest of Mexico by Hernando Cortes and his little army of a few hundred Spaniards that one might think there was small room -- and no need -- for still another book about that epic adventure. In histories, biographies, poems and dozens of historical romances writers continue to demonstrate the hold Cortes maintains on their imaginations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Lumber production set a new record in the first six months of the year and is expected to remain at high levels for the remainder of 1955, the Department of Commerce said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Air Force, Donald A. Quarles, said today there would be "great difficulty" in balancing the Federal budget without injuring the military program. "And our present plan is not injuring the program," he added.
PARIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Five American athletes ran off with six of the seven events they entered in an international track and field meet today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 11 -- Bishops, Communists and terrorists, each moved by their own brand of nationalist idealism, have joined causes in this pastoral mountainous island in the blue Mediterranean.
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 11 -- A little concern has been raised in financial quarters by the considerable rise in prices and speculative activity in the stock market here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. announced today that the Senate Judiciary subcommittee, which he heads, will open public hearings next month on "guilt by association" security cases.

When Doris Hart was a teenage tennis player, beginning to play against more experienced competitors, she was, of course, often defeated. "Don't worry, Doris," friends would say. "You are still young. Your future is still ahead of you."
The Rev. Eugene V. Clark urged Roman Catholics yesterday to look at themselves as other religious groups regard them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- Lard prices were on the downgrade much of last week. Long liquidation was in evidence, especially in the September, which fell to a new seasonal low. Lack of strength in vegetable oil markets was a factor, while the export trade has not developed as rapidly as many had expected.
Montgomery Ward Co. plans to open about 100 new catalogue buying offices before the end of next year.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Sea Island, Ga., won the $5,000 St. Louis women's open golf tournament today by shooting a 72, her fourth successive sub-par round. She posted 289 for the victory.

Directors of Air-Way Industries, Inc., yesterday declared a 100 per cent common stock dividend. The dividend will be paid out of capital surplus to common shareholders and is in the nature of a split of two for one. The dividend is payable on Oct. 14.
Architects' recommendations for remodeling and enlarging the Queens Public Library in Jamaica have been approved by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Britain's export-import picture improved considerably last month, compared with the two previous months.

AURORA, Ill., Sept. 12 -- A demonstration of a "carveyor" system to replace New York City's antiquated shuttle subway between Grand Central and Times Square was held here today. Members of the New York City Transit Authority and representatives of the Controller's office were on hand.
The "bulls" were out in force at the opening yesterday of the three-day seventh annual mutual fund sales convention in the Statler Hotel here.
Executives of twenty - six American corporations have provided Hugh W. Long Co., investment company underwriters, with a glowing -- and at times a frightening -- forecast of this country in 1975.
The Federal Budget -- with all its recent political implications -- is rapidly becoming almost impossible to interpret as a factor in the national economy.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Sept. 12 -- A rigid curfew closed up Casablanca tonight before its citizens learned what decision the French Cabinet had reached on the future of Morocco.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, one of the big four domestic rubber producers, realized a 32 per cent increase in earnings for the nine months ended July 31. Sales gained 17 per cent over the similar period of the previous year.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- Infants may develop flat feet or become pigeon-toed if permitted to sleep too much on their stomach's, an orthopedic surgeon reported today.

I note with some surprise that the sound position you took in regard to Cyprus in your editorial of Aug. 29 has not been maintained in that of Sept. 8. In the former you wrote that among the fundamentals which cannot be ignored "is the moral right of the Cypriotes to live under a government of their own choosing.
DENVER, Sept. 12 -- President Eisenhower cited another reason today for getting out of the White House.
A Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that the State Commissioner of Investigation had no right to compel written answers to a controversial financial questionnaire.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 12 -- Archbishop Makarios said today he would soon begin a campaign against British colonial rule. He described the movement as "certain projects, something similar to India's struggle for freedom, which will perhaps be more successful than violence."
For a little while yesterday morning it looked as if the Pied Piper of Hamlin had come to town.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- The Screen Actors Guild membership has ratified the new collective bargaining contract with the Television Entertainment Film Producers by a vote of 4357 to 573, John L. Dales, national executive Secretary of the guild announced today.
Supersonics, high - frequency heat, resistors, air conditioned factories and tiny new batteries brought predictions yesterday in various places of fantastically different future living.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today the Soviet Union wanted to import United States machinery and agricultural products. The Communist party chief implied Moscow would offer manganese and other strategic materials in exchange for United States goods.

Colorful performances by relatively few stocks marked a session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that boasted the heaviest volume since July 21. At the same time The New York Times combined average advanced to within a point of its 1955 high.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov will head the Soviet delegation to the tenth United Nations General Assembly opening Sept. 20 in New York, the Moscow radio announced today.

The thirteen-story apartment house at 884 West End Avenue, northwest corner of 103d Street, has been purchased by a client of Sidney Leichter, attorney, from the 884 West End Avenue Corporation. The property occupies a plot about 101 by 98 feet and is assessed at $320,000. Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., Austin Hermann and J. Wattenberg were the brokers in the transaction.

The Sheraton Corporation of America has acquired the French Lick Springs Hotel in French Lick, Ind. The property was purchased from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company of New York for $1,600,000.
PARIS, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Following is a translation of the speech on the Government's Moroccan policy broadcast by Premier Edgar Faure tonight:
BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 12 -- The Tenth Amendment was described today as a weapon against Federal encroachment on states' rights.

The $202,450,000 appropriated by the Eighty-fourth Congress to maintain the merchant marine and the shipbuilding industry was described as inadequate yesterday by Joseph Curran, chairman of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee.

HONG KONG, Sept. 12 -- Communist China's official press declared today that the Peiping Government was ready to make all necessary effort for "further'' improvement of relations with the United States.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has placed all phases of its world-wide petrochemical operations under a central authority and named Robert M. Jackson yesterday as its first chemical products coordinator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The capital city smoothly entered its second year of desegregated schools today.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Virtually complete returns from Cambodia's general elections gave Prince Norodom Sihanouk a landslide victory today.

When the judges, lawyers and students of constitutional history gather at Harvard University on Sept. 24 to commemorate the two hundredth anniversary of the birth of John Marshall it will also be a celebration of the power with which the Chief Justice invested the Federal judiciary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- Shouted charges of "shenanigans" and "left wing propaganda" marked the opening here today of a three-day Congressional subcommittee hearing on Administration power policies.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- A rally in British Government securities led a general, but modest, advance in stock market prices today.
ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- The Democratic State Committee will hold a giant pro-election "pep rally" here on Oct. 7.

Your editorial of Sept. 7 "Hemispheric Economy" deserves commendation as an admirable synthesis of many of the factors which cause Latin America to be classed as an "underdeveloped area." Diversification, industrialization, better distribution of wealth, higher investment rates and higher productivity are certainly needed if Latin America is to realize her great economic potential.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 12 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced here tonight a plan intended to end -- or certainly lessen -- commuter complaints.

The Moroccan progress toward independence is proving to be an exceptionally painful travail for France. The world would have been more sympathetic about it if France had not handled the issue with such weakness and ineptitude since the war.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 12 (UP) -- Before he faces Archie Moore in their heavyweight title fight next Tuesday at Yankee Stadium, Rocky Marciano will spar five rounds in his dressing room to be sure of getting off to a fast start.

The heavyweight championship boxing bout between Rocky Marciano, the titleholder, and Archie Moore at Yankee Stadium on Sept. 20 will be described over the American Broadcasting Company radio network.
The twelve-man Fire Department Pension Board denied yesterday the application of Fire Chief Peter Loftus for retirement at three-quarters of his $15,000 annual salary.

David I. Ashe, former president of the United Parents Associations, will defend the public school principal suspended last week as a result of his refusal to answer questions pertaining to his admitted former membership in the Communist party.
BLOOMINGDALE'S, the East Side's comfy neighborhood store, suddenly has become conscious of both fashion and the increasing chic of the area it serves.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Tomorrow evening the mayor of Croydon, a London suburb, will press a button starting test transmissions by the Independent Television Authority's transmitter. Commercial television will present its first programs over the Croydon transmitter Sept. 22.

Premium buyers from all over the country gathered yesterday at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel to view the premiums they will be offering in their advertising or in that of their clients in the months ahead. Some of the objects they saw were old friends, and some were novel and new.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- The Cabinet gave its final agreement today to a French plan to solve the Moroccan crisis.
The International Longshoremen's Association ordered all Atlantic and Gulf ports shut down yesterday in its fight to smash the power of the Waterfront Commission.

The story of Degania, "Israel's first kibbutz" (a communal settlement) is told by Joseph Baratz in "A Village by the Jordan," which Roy Publishers will issue on Oct. 3. Mr. Baratz and his friends went to Palestine in 1906. By the work of their hands, they changed a desolate, malarial spot into a fertile valley of rich crops and healthy children.
HONOLULU, Sept. 12 -- A record budget was presented here today to the fifty-eighth triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- A twenty-four-hour general strike that tied up the city of Nantes today was seen as part of a movement that might precipitate another inflation in France.

Enrolled members of the three legally recognized political parties go to the polls in New York today to select candidates for elective offices to be filled in the fall and to choose party leaders in some areas.
The nation's steel mills poured more metal last month than in any other August in history.

BUCHANAN, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Steel feet for a tower to serve the nation's first privately built atomic electric power plant were set firmly in the soil in Indian Point, two miles south of Peeks-kill, this morning.

GENEVA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Britain and thirteen other members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will exclude Japanese trade from the provisions of the agreement despite Japan's admission to G. A. T. T., it was announced today.
Ninety thousand Long Island Rail Road riders were delayed yesterday morning from a half hour to an hour and fifty-seven minutes by a union slowdown.
The dock walkout here was marked yesterday by increasing eports of joblessness, financial loss and resentment against the disputants.
Mlle. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube gave a practical demonstration yesterday of the kind of quiet determination and courage that made her the heroine of the siege of Dienbienphu.

Commodity futures closed lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull and featureless. Cocoa, coffee, copper, cottonseed oil, rubber, soybean oil, hides, potatoes, wool and lead eased; onions rose, and sugar and zinc moved mixed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The editor of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists said today it was no longer technically possible to guarantee abolition of atomic and thermonuclear weapons. Dr. Eugene Rabinowitch said this was true because of large stock-plies of nuclear explosives in the United States, Russia and Great Britain.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 -- Manager Smokey Alston's pitching plans for the world series have not yet taken form, at least not to the extent that he can pick his starting moundsmen at this time.

The Frankfort Distillers Company is planning to offer its Four Roses Whisky for Christmas selling in a handsome decanter, a "first" for the company. And it will put behind it what Ralph Reese, vice president in charge of advertising and sales promotion, called yesterday, "perhaps the most impressive advertising and promotional campaign in Frankfort's long history."
ROBERT MONTGOMERY began another season of dramas last night on Channel 4 with an adaptation of "Woman in the Window." This morning he probably wishes he had pulled the shade.

Members of the Russian agricultural mission predicted last night that their two-month tour of the United States and Canada would be followed by increasingly numerous exchanges between this country and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Senate received a thank-you note today from the "very great statesman" it had praised in a resolution last July.
DENVER, Sept. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today named three Administration officials to three-year terms on the board of governors of the American Red Cross.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 12 -- Social scientists of the free world were warned today against the belief that security could be won by the sacrifice of freedom.

While I have no accurate knowledge on which to form judgment regarding the current controversy between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the Neponsit residents who oppose his efforts to expand park facilities in that area, it occurs to me that Mr. Moses, whose high motives no one can question, might well give some much-needed consideration to park acreage already, under his jurisdiction.
MIAMI, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Hurricane Hilda was building up in the Antilles today. As it churned within 750 miles of Miami an alert was spread through the Bahamas to the Florida coast.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Dr. Herold C. Hunt was sworn in today as Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare by Marion B. Folsom, the Secretary.
Events today: Band concert, Battery Park, 12 noon; Interval Concert, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P. M.

This is primary election day in this off-year, politically, and the polls will be open from 3 P. M. to 10 P. M. We urge every qualified resident to vote, where he has an opportunity to improve government or the character of party leadership.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 -- Work will begin by month's end on the project of preventing the Mississippi River from abandoning the port of New Orleans for a new route to the Gulf of Mexico.
BIG bluefish and an abundance of fluke dominate the New Jersey coastal fishing picture, with a scattering of albacore and school tuna taken by off-shore anglers.
RICHMOND, Sept. 12 -- Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie scored one of the important triumphs in the initial round of the United States amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Five Atlantic Coast railroads today opposed approval of a third air carrier between the Northeast and Florida. They said it might make competition so drastic as to jeopardize the rate structures of both forms of transportation.
The Yankees meet a rugged foe, the Detroit Tigers, in the opener of a two-game set at the Stadium today.
A strong possibility exists that the suspended trailership service on the Hudson River between here and Albany will be resumed next month.
A City Councilman introduced yesterday a bill to legalize a practice some Councilmen -- and other city officials -- have indulged in all along.
Fred J. Keller of Rowayton, Conn., was fatally injured yesterday when he was struck by a bus at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, according to the police. Mr. Keller was 51 years old.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 12 -- New Mexico is agog with a home-grown three-ring circus, chiefly political. It is literally giving competition to Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey's "Greatest Show on Earth."
VIENNA, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Fifty Bulgarian Army officers are reported to have been arrested in Bulgaria because they advocated a close military alliance with Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that price supports would be 62 cents a pound for shorn wool and 70 cents for mohair in the marketing year beginning April 1, 1956.
The United States Gypsum Company plans to split its common stock five for one.
MELBOURNE, Sept. 12 -- At the opening of the season's first wool sales in Melbourne today prices were steady with those in the first sales of the last two weeks in Sydney, Adelaide and Brisbane.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 12 -- One hundred tenants in a Glen Cove building called Nassau County's "weirdest slum" will not have to move out until Wednesday at least and possibly not for sixty days.

WHEN Isabella Holt's "Rampole Place" was published, three years ago this September, I read it with pleasure and admiration and did my best to persuade as many people as possible that my enthusiasm was well-founded. Mrs. Holt's new novel, "Midpoint,"* is now published, and once again I am convinced that here is a good novel, that rare kind that people keep asking for but that they often neglect when it appears.

Four furnished apartments have been placed on display in the north wing of the twelve-story and penthouse cooperative building at 1025 Fifth Avenue, opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Scheduled for occupancy this month, the twin structures contain a total of 167 apartments of three and one-half to seven rooms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Floyd S. Bryant of San Francisco, former vice president of the Standard Oil Company of California, has been named special assistant to Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 -- Living viruses have been broken apart for the first time by subtle chemical means and then put together again. The restored virus is capable of causing infection just as it was originally.

First Lap and Tick Tock waged a stirring duel in the Babylon Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, with the former gaining the victory by a nose. The outcome was popular with the 20,794 onlookers as the winner was the 2-to-1 favorite.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Mrs. Mamie Bradley will appear as a state's witness next Monday at Sumner, Miss., in the trial of two white men accused of slaying her Negro son, her lawyer said today.
The physician should not practice in a world of scientific fantasy, freshmen at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons were told yesterday.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 12 (UP) -A. Chinese who tried to save a dying United States newsman from a mob told a court today he feared his life was in danger.
The new Miss America, who bakes a tasty fudge cake, turned a queenly thumb down yesterday at camera men's requests for "cheesecake."
PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Some 43,000 workers struck twenty-seven plants of the Westinghouse Electric Company in nine states yesterday.
Life with the Alstons is nearly back to normal again this week after the excitement of last Thursday when the Dodgers clinches the National League pennant with a victory in Milwaukee.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 -- The New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, which last appeared in Vienna twenty-five years ago under Arturo Toscanini, was conducted in the first of two concerts here tonight by Dimitri Mitropoulos.
TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- The New Jersey Senate voted tonight to appropriate $6,500,000 for flood relief and $1,500,000 to expand the state's facilities for mentally retarded children.
Two thoroughbreds arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from France yesterday. They are Martin Fabini's Klairon and George Wildenstein's Jolly Friar.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Britain will stage the third of a series of atomic weapons tests next April in Australia, it was announced today. The tests will be held in the Monte Bello Islands, off the northwest coast, where the first British tests were conducted in 1952.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the purchase of 187,480 shares of Canadian Westinghouse Company, Ltd., at $54 each from the Westinghouse Air Brake Company.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- A leading United States authority on Soviet law said today that a "tremendous law reform movement" was under way in the Soviet Union.

Dr. Bela Fabian, a member of the executive committee of the Hungarian Government in Exile, won an award of $100,000 damages in Supreme Court yesterday in his libel suit against Egyleti Elet, a Hungarian-language newspaper published in this city.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. will place on the market today a block of 60,000 shares of capital stock of Massachusetts Indemnity Insurance Company at $46.50 a share. The sale marks the first public distribution of the company's stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Following is the text of Secretary General Dug Hammarskjold's report to the General Assembly, made public today, on his negotiations with the Communist Chinese Government concerning the release of American officers and airmen:

TOKYO, Sept. 12 -- Japan will station military observers in her principal embassies abroad for the first time since World War II, it was reported today. The move was described as intended to assist in the development of Japan's renascent armed forces.
Buckingham Palace came to the lower East Side yesterday fresh from a storybook world in the form of a Scots Guardsman, recently arrived for a goodwill tour of the country.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Sept. 12 -- A major was said today to have frustrated a large-scale military rebellion in Cordoba Province ten days ago.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Several hundred property owners in New Castle received reductions today in assessed valuations on their homes. The notices came on the eve of a heated primary contest. The timing led to charges of "dirty politics."

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Prices for all grains receded from initial quotations in extremely narrow trading. Later there was a quick recovery in wheat, with corn, oats and rye working back a little from the lows.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The Admiralty announced today that the 44,500-ton Vanguard, Britain's only battleship in commission, would go into the "ready" reserve in a few months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Business spending for plant and equipment is on the rise.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- The State Supreme Court rejected today a petition by Frank Hague for a rehearing on the right of Jersey City to sue two associates and himself for $15,000,000. No opinion accompanied the denial and the justices were not polled in court.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- The commanding officer of the Army Corps of Engineers in New England said today that by the next four months, his total expenditures for flood rehabilitation would total $25,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A jet propulsion scientist, Dr. Hsue-shen Tsien, 46 years old, will leave for Communist China Friday under a deportation order. The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service made the announcement today.

If any more evidence were needed of the bankruptcy of leadership in the International Longshoremen's Association it was dramatically supplied by the bizarre performance its chief officers have put on. Events have also shown how desperately these leaders want to settle the sorry mess of the longshoremen's strike against the Waterfront Commission -- if they can do it without losing too much face.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ambassador U. Alexis Johnson, now negotiating with the Chinese Communists at Geneva, was reported today to be under consideration as Ambassador to Thailand.

" The Night of the Hunter," the first film turned out by the producer-director team of Paul Gregory and Charles Laughton, has been booked as the next attraction at the Mayfair Theatre. The late James Agee wrote the screen play, based on the novel by Davis Grubb. Robert Mitchum, Lillian Gish and Shelley Winters head the cast.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- The Air Ministry said tonight that all the 400 Air Force Reservists who appeared to resist departure here yesterday were being flown to Morocco today and tomorrow.

There is no mystery about the outcome of the current strike in the Port of New York. It will be settled as the other recent strikes: in Capital Transit, by a wage increase to be paid out of higher fares; in the steel strike, by a wage increase to be paid out of higher steel prices.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 12 -- Last night in a house in Rabat a 9-year-old Moroccan girl recited a catechism in halting French.
CHELSEA, Mich., Sept. 12 -- Automotive improvements costing $175,000,000 were shown today by the Chrysler Corporation at a preview of 1956 passenger car lines.

It is safe to venture that a surprisingly large number of persons, when they think of whales -- if indeed they ever think of them at all -- link them with whaling ships under sail, Ahab, Moby Dick, hand-thrown harpoons and long-gone yesterdays.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- West Germany and the Soviet Union came to a deadlock today in their vigorous and argumentative negotiations in Moscow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- It was indicated today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was continuing his contacts with the Communist Chinese regime on behalf of United Nations military personnel listed as missing after the Korean war.

PACKAGED foods have eased home cooking; they also have standardized it. Meals in a Massachusetts household may taste much like those served in Minnesota. Individual twists, which make up regional cookery when added together, are disappearing.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, in first place in the American League pennant race by a game and a half, announced today they would begin taking mail orders tomorrow for world series tickets.

Whatever may or may not come out of the Moscow conference between the Soviet rulers and Chancellor Adenauer, that meeting has already served one good purpose. This is to focus increased attention on the inhuman treatment by the Communist regimes of both military prisoners of war and civilian captives.
Some 2,000,000 home owners in New York State were subjected yesterday to a 43 per cent rise in premium costs for storm insurance.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 -- Air Force plans to base a flying boxcar squadron at the Westchester County Airport in Purchase drew seventy-five protests today.

The State of California yesterday designated Nov. 2 as the sales date for bond issues totaling $60,000,000. The money raised will be used to help school districts in making capital outlays and in financing loans to war veterans in acquiring farms and homes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Samuel Goldwyn revealed today that he had received an offer of a $50,000 guarantee from a Las Vegas hotel that wants to book his film production of "Guys and Dolls" for a one-week run.
The following telegrams on the pier strike were exchanged yesterday by Governor Harriman and Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UP) -- Forty-eight cases of suspected collaboration among former Korean war prisoners have been dropped in the last two months, the Army said today.

A group of unidentified persons has made an offer to buy a controlling stock interest in the National Casket Company, Inc., Boston, maker of burial caskets and undertakers' equipment. The law firm of Hovell, Clarkson, Klupt Schrank of this city, which is representing the group, disclosed that the offer covers the purchase of 32,000 common shares at $48.50 a share.

Unworkable conditions and procedures imposed by the Federal Housing Administration are jeopardizing the city's slum-clearance housing program, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday. The charge was contained in a report by a subcommittee of the Mayor's Committee for Better Housing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Coast Guard cleared for ensign stripes today a graduate of its Officers Candidate School whose Reserve commission had been withheld because of his mother's former association with "subversive" groups. been decided on Mr. Gaston's "own merits." It praised his character and scholastic record.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Sol far this year the three production leaders are accounting for close to 95 per cent of the auto-mobile industry's output. General Motors Corporation has built 2,898, 763 cars against 2,096,206 last year at the same date; Ford Motor Company 1,506,168 Ford, Lincoln and Mercury units against 1,247,665, and Chrysler Corporation 961,691 against 459;039.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Directors of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad to day authorized a two-for-one split of common stock, subject to approval of stockholders and the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Two important problems were resolved yesterday for Edith Sommer's new comedy, "A Roomful of Roses." The Playhouse was booked as its New York showcase and Oct. 17 was decided on as its local unveiling date.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee asked the Justice Department today to determine whether the Southern Conference Educational Fund, Inc., was a Communist-front organization.
Supermarket operators were urged yesterday to create a "circus atmosphere" in their establishments if they wished to draw more business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- President Eisenhower has given the Republican party a goal for the 1956 election campaign which, if achieved, would produce the largest political landslide since Franklin D. Roosevelt's victory in 1936.
IT was at Vero Beach last March that Fresco Thompson, a vice president of the Dodgers, made a sage observation about the 1954 season.

An "epochal" step in court administration was announced yesterday -- creation of a Family Part in the Supreme Court for New York County. The new division will begin operation today with Justice Samuel M. Gold presiding.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, owner of one of the largest shipping fleets in the world, is entering the oil tanker field. It plans to have twenty-five tankers built in the next five years.

Only twelve air raid sirens here proved inoperative yesterday in the monthly test of the sirens by the New York City Office of Civil Defense. Yesterday 716 sirens were tested, or nineteen more than the city had in the last test on July 12, when fourteen were inoperative.

The thirty-four-mile toll expressway proposed to link Richmond and Petersburg, Va., will carry 18,052 vehicles and earn $4,471,000 in toll revenue in the first full year of operation in 1959, according to studies made by the engineering firm of Coverdale Colpitts.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 12 -- The tenth annual meeting of the boards of governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund opened here today. Both institutions presented optimistic reports about their operations and about the world economy in general.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A broad investigation of the nation's defenses with special emphasis on air power is under way.

Brooklyn yesterday listed eight new cases of poliomyelitis diagnosed since last Friday. Six more cases were found in Queens and five in the Bronx. They raise the city's total this year to 525, compared with 274 last year at the same time.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (UP) -- H. L. Mencken, "disturber of the peace" of American life and letters for more than a quarter-century, spent his seventy-fifth birthday today in mellow, sniffling seclusion.

An oil painting entitled "Mechanic Street, New Hope, Pa." has been adjudged the winner of the $100 grand prize in the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit. The painter is Stanley Sobossek of 309 Avenue of the Americas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- New protein foods are becoming increasingly available to benefit the malnourished children of the world, the Executive Board of the United Nations Children's Fund heard today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A crack in the Hollywood movie studios' stand against putting their feature films on television came today with the announcement of an anti-trust consent judgment against the Republic Pictures Corporation.

A national committee to encourage legislation providing American exporters with guarantees against political and related risks of non-payment of drafts was formed yesterday with offices at 291 Broadway.

We are glad to applaud the findings of a special committee of the American Legion which has been looking into the antecedents and activities of UNESCO. The committee includes, among others, Ray Murphy, a former national commander, and Mrs. Harold S. Burdett, a former head of the Legion auxiliary.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 541 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 148 pints given at the brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, 70 Pine Street, and 100 at the Bankers Trust Company, 9 Pine Street.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept 12 -- The lower house of Parliament passed today a comprehensive bill giving power to the Government to regulate the management of private industries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Democratic Digest asserted today that "deals and dealers" were flourishing in Washington under the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Government today sold an aluminum extrusion plant at Halethorpe, Md. to the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation for $3,841,000.

A youth was shot and seriously wounded by the police yesterday thirty-five minutes after he and a companion had held up a Bronx insurance company. He had led a patrolman on a four-block chase. The other youth surrendered after being chased one block by a second patrolman.
TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- The Pulaski Skyway is about to have its face lifted for the first time in a quarter of a century. The reason: A mounting toll of accidents that last year alone reached 430

Seymour J. Rubin, in his letter published Aug. 25, links in a rather puzzling way two important issues now facing national scrutiny. One is the question of United States assistance for the development of nuclear power stations in various parts of the free world.
SMART Parisian women buy their clothes from "good little dressmakers" and tell nobody -but nobody -- where they got them.

A suit seeking to force the Panama Canal Company to reduce tolls and to return $27,000,000 in alleged "excessive toll collections since 1951" was entered yesterday in Southern District Federal Court by twelve American steamship companies.
VIENNA, Sept. 13 -- The music critics of Vienna delivered themselves of paeans of praise today for the New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra and its conductor, Dimitri Mitropoulos.

CAIRO, Sept. 13 -- The military and economic aspects of the Arab-Israel conflict will be discussed here tomorrow. Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns is arriving in the morning to talk about the Gaza strip. Eric Johnston will come in the afternoon to discuss the Jordan water project.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The United States has begun repaying aluminum it borrowed from the British Government in 1952 and 1953.

Summer vacations for an increased number of sightless persons will be made possible as a result of the benefit performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet the afternoon of Oct. 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A tentative date for a "nonviolent'' march by Pakistanis across the Kashmir cease-fire line has been set and it is Thursday of this week. Volunteers for the march have been signed up in various religious and civic organizations and their number is now said to be about 10,000.

A C for "cleanliness" was sounded at yesterday's weekly band concert in Battery Park. The Department of Sanitation Band played the first half of the concert. The second half was played by the Downtown Manhattan Festival Band.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- State Department officials said today they approved the West German-Soviet agreement to establish diplomatic relations on the basis of an understanding that German prisoners in Russia would be freed.
Two pedestrians were killed and another was seriously injured when two trucks collided at a Bronx intersection at 3 P. M. yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union appears to have embarked on a program for normal literary relations with the non-Communist world.
The Allied Stores Corporation increased its department store chain to 78 units with the purchase of two Canton, Ohio, stores from Halle Brothers Company of Cleveland.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The Government's agreement on the next steps in Morocco could be, and some here hope it will be, the beginning of a new French policy toward the overseas territories. The tendency would be toward decentralization of authority and possibly toward some federal relationship that would replace both the protectorates and the so far ill-defined French Union.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 13 -- An Air Force medium bomber crashed into a cemetery today, killing all six men aboard. The pilot had aimed his crippled craft away from a row of small homes.

VERONA, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Two women were burned to death and a highway worker was killed late today in a flaming car-truck crash described by state police as the worst wreck on New York State's Thruway since it was opened fifteen months ago.
Eleven secondary Communist leaders, convicted of conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, gave up yesterday their fight for a new trial.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 13 -The old nickname of "Willie the Wedge" is appropriate again for Willie Turnesa.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -Late-inning two-run homers by Jimmy Piersall and Faye Throneberry lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 7-6 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in the second game of a double-header today. Vic Power's twelfthinning single gave the Athletics a 6-5 triumph in the opener.
Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital, which for seventy-four years treated diseases of the chest -with the emphasis on tuberculosis -- will close its doors Friday.

Eight four-story buildings at 147-51 East Forty-fourth Street through to 140-46 East Fortyfifth Street have been sold by Central Court Apartments, Inc., to a syndicate headed by Louis Denberg. The property fronts 100 feet on Forty-fifth Street and seventy-five feet on Fortyfourth Street and will be improved with a seventeen-story apartment building.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Former Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York and Frank Erickson, the gambler, have run into more Federal tax troubles.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Twelve new members have been added to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the executive director. Walter Byers, announced today.

Results in the seventeenth round of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg brought about no important changes in the standing of the leaders, according to a report received yesterday through Swedish sources.

New issues of corporate securities aggregating more than $93,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. Among the offerings are mortgage bonds and common stock of gas transmission and electric power companies and common shares of an industrial enterprise.

It is evident that Governors Meyner of New Jersey and Harriman of New York need and deserve the forthright support of the citizens of these two states in the present strike dispute between the I. L. A. and the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- New developments that may help man explore and live in frozen wastes of the Far North or the Antarctic subcontinent were disclosed by the Army Corps of Engineers today. They include:
The International Longshoremen's Association, hunting a face-saving way out of its ruinous strike, was up against a bipartisan agreement to bar any by-passing of the Waterfront Commission.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- A new Syrian Government has been formed under the Premiership of Said Ghazzi, it was officially announced here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- At the rate the nation's railroads are "highballing," net operating income will jump to $1,042,000,000 this year.
BERLIN, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The West Berlin Boxing Commission meets tomorrow to reconsider the disqualification verdict rendered Friday against Artie Towne, 28, New York middleweight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The Communist party today asked the Supreme Court to declare unconstitutional the 1950 Internal Security Act. The subversive activities control board was set up under the law.

MIAMI, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Hurricane Hilda churned over the eastern tip of Cuba today, losing some of its ninety-mile-an-hour punch against a mountain range, and brushed by the big United States naval base on Guantanamo Bay.
The Transit Authority raised its wage offer to the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., by 3 cents yesterday, making it 14 cents over a three-year period.

The Meredith Publishing Company, engaged in magazine and book publishing, radio and television broadcasting, increased its revenue to a new high for the thirteenth consecutive year, but earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30 were slightly lower than the year before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Cleveland Indians increased their American League lead to two games over the Yankees tonight by beating the Washington Senators in a twilight-night program at Griffith Stadium.
A folding ladder became a new proof yesterday of the resourcefulness of a determined woman.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The worst smog on record shrouded the city today.

WHITE SANDS PROVING GROUND, N. M., Sept. 10 -- This vast desert valley where the atomic bomb was born now is waiting for a specialized bolt of lightning to strike. That will be some definitive word that it will be the springboard for man's first forays into outer space.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A sharp warning that the Government would invoke quotas on petroleum imports if voluntary curbs failed was served on eighteen oil companies today.

Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball, issued the formal regulations for the 1955 world series yesterday, certified a list of eligible players on all contending teams and established the exact price of tickets for each city.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- West Germany and the Soviet Union agreed tonight to establish diplomatic relations.

Future prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil and rubber were active, but other commodities registered light volume. Cocoa, rubber, hides, burlap, sugar and zinc rose; cottonseed oil, wool, soybean oil, silk, potatoes and copper eased, and coffee closed mixed.
Scenes of San Francisco, which has been called the New Yorker's New York, have been reproduced on fabric and wallpaper.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Wheat prices opened lower this morning because of the estimate that wheat put under Government loans up to Aug. 15 totaled only 47,000,000 bushels, compared with 127,000,000 bushels a year ago.

Not children in trouble but troubled children is the way Greer, a community for children from broken homes, likes to describe its charges. Greer, a member of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, will shortly celebrate its Fiftieth Anniversary.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Today's report on the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture foUows:
A Marine Corps captain, reinforced by his father, a retired Navy captain, braved a quizmaster's fire last night and captured a prize of $64,000 as millions of television viewers watched.
PANAMA, Sept. 13 -- Venezuela today is a country without real freedom of speech or political action, but where nobody seems to care much about that situation.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 13 -Johnny Antonelli, who formerly drew his paychecks here, was at his best tonight at County Stadium. The southpaw ace of the Giants spun a six-hit, 9 -- 1 victory over the Braves. Until the home side broke through in the ninth, Antonelli had a three-hit shutout in the making.

Eight hundred passengers aboard a Long Island Rail Road express were stranded in a tunnel under the East River for eighty minutes during the evening rush hour yesterday. The delay was caused by a smoky short circuit.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 13 -- The chances for industrial peace in Northern Rhodesia's copper belt are considered to have been improved by a new agreement to expand job opportunities for Negroes.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of a joint communique on the SovietWest German negotiations and a statement by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, at the final session today, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 13 -- Morocco began a death watch today on the reign of its old, powerless and unloved Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.
