WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 13 -- First selectman W. Clarke Crossman said today an "amiable settlement" had been reached in the case of the local health inspector who was pushed into a pond by a housewife. She had become irritated because he had no credentials to show and refused to leave her property, where he had gone on official business.
Animal and plant life dominate designs in new bathroom towel and rug collections for fall.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 (UP) -The Chicago White Sox barely kept their pennant hopes alive tonight with a six-run rally in the ninth inning to beat Baltimore, 9 -- 6, in the second game of a double-header. The Orioles won the twilight opener, 2 -- 0.

The two vessels that constituted the now-suspended Hudson River trailership service between here and Albany may be moved as far away as Tasmania. The craft are to be auctioned to satisfy obligations of their owners.
Ventures, Ltd., Canadian holding company with mining interests in nearly every part of the world outside the Iron Curtain, has chosen a new president.

An annual conference of the British Trades Union Congress is important whether it does anything or not. This year's meeting at Southport accomplished little, but it may have put a brake on the pressure for wage increases and, if so, that will mean a good deal to embattled Britain today.

MISSIONARIES rarely are rewarded with enduring fame. For every St. Paul, St. Patrick and St. Francis Xavier there must have been thousands of humble men who fared forth into foreign lands to win converts for their faith and were never heard of again except by their friends, relations and immediate superiors.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (UP) -Picket line disturbances were reported in two cities today during the strike of 44,000 electrical workers against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The French Government today outlawed the Algerian Communist party for supporting the bloody nationalist uprising in which 1,500 persons were killed.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 13 (AP) -General Manager Frank Lane of the White Sox, in the midst of a feud with Vice President Chuck Comiskey, today denied reports the St. Louis Cardinals sought his services.
MURIEL KING professes to design clothes for mature women, small women and chic women just the right size. In her fall collection for Stein Blaine, the mature woman of sophistication makes out best.

HONOLULU, Sept. 13 -- The Very Rev. Arnold M. Lewis, Dean of St. John's Cathedral of Jacksonville, Fla., since 1951, today was elected Bishop of the missionary district of Salina, Kan., by the fifty-eighth triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Army announced today that its review board has upheld a two and a half year prison sentence for Cpl. Harold M. Dunn. He had pleaded guilty to a charge of collaborating with the Communists while a prisoner of War in Korea.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- A simplified wage agreement designed to give shipowners "their exact labor cost per voyage" was announced today by Harry Lundeberg, secretary-treasurer of the Sailors Union of the Pacific.
Four mobile units of the Red Cross regional blood program will collect blood today from employes and staffs of six companies.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 8 -This year, the twenty-fifth of Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo's power in the Dominican Republic, could decide the final stamp he will leave.

By mutual arrangement, Glenda Farrell is withdrawing from "The Desk Set," starring Shirley Booth. Miss Farrell, who is a featured performer, decided to relinquish the stint because the author had written a new conception for her part, it was reported.
The 1955 bull market, as measured by The New York Times fifty-stock average, has broken new high ground on six different occasions since it crashed the 1929 "sound barrier" back on June 23.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13 -One Republican upset marked primaries in Westchester County today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 13 -- Chemical studies of city air reveal that it sometimes is a weak soup cooked with solar heat from an unknown recipe. The soup is peppered with vile and probably poisonous chemicals that are formed in the air itself.
In proposing a nation-wide system of free junior colleges, President Eisenhower has, unwittingly perhaps, touched on a highly controversial educational issue.
PHILADELPIA, Sept. 13 -A new technique for correcting "funnel chest" was described to the International College of Surgeons today.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept 13 -- American motor vehicle production will total between 7,400,000 and 7,500,000 this year, Robert S. McNamara, vice president and general manager of the Ford Division of the Ford Motor Company, estimated today.

The Coast Guard has cleared for a commission as ensign a graduate of its Officers Candidate School whose Reserve commission had previously been withheld because of his mother's former association with "subversive" groups. The young man in question is Norman Pierre Gaston.
HARTFORD, Sept. 13 (UP) -Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff ordered all state agency heads today to "fire on the spot" any state employe found using illegal methods to help organized labor.

Although early last evening the longshore union agreed to present to its members a new formula ending their strike, it is high time that the officials and all the members of the I. L. A., not to mention the public, recognize the relation between the latest waterfront walkout and the laws of the land.

The sorely pressed shipbuilding industry gained a reprieve last month as contracts were placed for three new vessels -- two supertankers and one passenger-auto ferryboat for New England offshore operation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Three of the top Japanese war criminals will be released under parole tomorrow. They are Gen. Kingoro Hashimoto, who led troops in China and Manchuria; Okinori Kaya, wartime Finance Minister, and Lieut. Gen. Teiichi Suzuki, a wartime state minister.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Malcom P. McLean testified at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today that he had rid himself of his trucking interests before acquiring steamship lines in January.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner said today Republicans might lose their chance of regaining control of Congress next year if farm prices kept falling.
Three new films will open today at first-run and neighborhood theatres.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- A former Massachusetts Attorney General asked the New York State Athletic Commission today to eliminate the secrecy on the round-by-round decisions of officials at the Rocky Marciano-Archie Moore heavyweight championship fight in the Yankee Stadium next Tuesday night. His request was rejected immediately.

One event more than any other was responsible for the adoption of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements by the United States in 1934 and the more or less logical emergence in 1948 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, more popularly known as GATT.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Representative Dean P. Taylor preserved his Rensselaer County Republican leadership and his status as a potential nominee for United States Senator today by beating down a primary challenge by Mayor Edward A. Fitzgerald of Troy.

WARNER BROTHERS last night led off this season's parade of major Hollywood studios taking the television plunge. Its initial show was presented from 7:30 to 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company's network.

The National Merit Scholarship Corporation may have other benefits than those conceived by the founders and donors. With some thought and foresight these scholarships might well help to solve a serious problem facing American public education.
"Would you go back to your wife today?" asked the judge.
ALL the stores are thinking about Paris these days and Bonwit Teller is no exception.
The Southern Nitrogen Company, Inc., set up to establish a modern petrochemical plant at Savannah, Ga., has completed arrangements for financing the new facilities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today net farm income had declined slightly more than 4 per cent during the first half of this year. A further decline during the year's third quarter was forecast.

One of the staple sources of humor in the world is provided by the British penchant for preciseness and order -and it is especially a good source for those who love the British, for it allows of a humor that has an edge but is not cutting.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 13 -Israel was invaded today by marauders from the usually tranquil Lebanese border.

Investors have purchased the five-story building at 1946-48 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, from Enkells-Rakoff, operators. The buyers were represented by Samuel Morgenroth, lawyer. The property, which contains thirtyeight apartments and eight stores, is assessed at $188,000.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 -- Policemen held off 3,000 protesting villagers and sympathetic unionists today while a Government team surveyed land in Sunakawa village for expansion of the near-by Tachikawa United States Air Base.
As a result of complaints of nurses in city hospitals, the City Department of Personnel is reviewing the table of equivalencies for the nursing occupational group under the Career and Salary Plan.

Adventure books by two women authors will appear Sept. 26. One is "Leopard in My Lap," by Michaela Denis, which will be published by Julian Messner. It describes the experiences the author and her husband, Armand Denis, had in remote parts of the world. The other is "The Jungle Is a Woman," by Jane Dolinger, which Henry Regnery will publish. It describes the author's experiences in searching for a pre-Stone Age man in Peruvian jungles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations has begun a study of Communist influence in schools attended by Korea war veterans under the G. I. bill.
Hubert T. Delany, whose term as justice of the Domestic Relations Court expired last Aug. 31, was denied reappointment yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Aetna Life Insurance Company, whose president once said he had "no confidence in the present management" of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, and the Phoenix Life Insurance Company declined today to participate in a $10,000,000 loan to the railroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Government today signed a contract with the Harvey Machine Company of Torrance, Calif., calling for prompt construction of a $65,000,000 aluminum plant at The Dalles, Ore.
Not only did stocks advance yesterday to new historic highs, but the close for The New York Times combined average was above the previous high, recorded on July 6.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 13 -George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, advised underdeveloped areas today not to turn to Moscow for a type of industrial development that "Russia herself has already outgrown.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Nino Valdes of Cuba stopped Don Cockell, Britain's heavyweight champion, after three rounds of a scheduled ten-round bout at White City Stadium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Pakistan signed today multimillion-dollar oil concession agreements with Nelson Bunker Hunt, son of H. L. Hunt, wealthy oil man of Dallas., Tex.
A young woman plunged twenty-four stories yesterday into the midst of 125 persons finishing a late luncheon in the Palm Court of the Biltmore Hotel. She died a few minutes later.
The city's school system is going to take a long look at itself.
An intensive advertising campaign aimed at dramatizing the threat of public apathy toward the country's $250,000,000,000 housing investment was announced yesterday.
CASEY STENGEL was sitting on the bench in the dugout yesterday. An envelope containing his passport pictures for the Yankees' forthcoming tour of Japan was handed to him.

A $21,000,000 - a - year retail women's fashion business, unknown by name to all but a handful of its customers, will make a public bow today when Goldring, Inc., the country's largest operator of leased fashion departments, opens a store under its own name in New Orleans.
Unionized bartenders joined yesterday in the fight on juvenile delinquency.
A television series for children based on the "Landmark Books" historical volumes will be presented on the Columbia Broadcasting System network in the fall of next year.

ROME, Sept. 13 -- Without counting the Communist bloc, the world has slightly more food available today per capita than before World War II. In the Soviet Union, China and Eastern Europe, though, the average man is eating less than he did before the war.
As spirited a battle between railroads and the truckers as has been seen in a generation will open next Monday.
Petroleum may be a depleting resource. But its indefinite survival as an industry was predicted here yesterday.
The city of Buffalo, N. Y., borrowed $12,847,000 in the public market yesterday to finance school construction, street paving and other public improvements.
RARE chamber music by Italian composers of the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries was the attraction at last night's Interval Concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The Yankees, in the words of their eminent skipper, Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, "ain't concedin' nothin' yet."

MELBOURNE, Sept. 13 -- Dr. Herbert C. Coombs, governor of the Commonwealth Bank, has asked trading banks to exercise restraint in making new loans and to apphove no new or increased borrowing for capital expenditure or to increase financing for additional imports.

Directors of the Towmotor Corporation yesterday increased the common dividend to 50 cents a share, payable Oct. 1, and announced plans for a 100 per cent stock dividend. The company paid dividends of 35 cents a common share in previous quarters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Henry Fonda, who is in Rome co-starring in "War and Peace," has a date at Warner Brothers in January to head the cast of "The Wrong Man." Alfred Hitchcock will direct and produce the suspense drama from a screen play by Maxwell Anderson.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The New York-Buffalo Thruway bridge across the Tappan Zee of the Hudson River here is 90 per cent completed. Engineers had a tentative completion date for mid-November but today they attached no certainty to it. They declared instead that an opening before the Yule holidays was "definite."
American exporters and importers hailed last night the prospect of an early settlement in the seven-day strike of longshoremen here.

MONTREAL, Sept. 13 (UP) -- Two games on Oct. 6 will start the 1955-56 National Hockey League season. The Montreal Canadiens will play hosts to the Toronto Maple Leafs, while the Detroit Red Wings, last season's Stanley Cup winners, entertain the Chicago Black Hawks on that night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- The United States wants the United Nations General Assembly to endorse the Eisenhower plan for an exchange of military blueprints between the United States and the Soviet Union.

In its comment on the report concerning the announced reductions in the armed forces of Poland and Albania The New York Times states that "the precise meaning of the announced intention of Soviet bloc nations to reduce their armed forces was not clear to military experts."

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Conservative supporters of the Moroccan Sultan, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, made strong efforts today, both in Paris and Morocco, to block a Government move to remove him from the throne as the first step for settling the Moroccan crisis.

CULINARY cosmopolites know how wine enhances the flavor of less tender cuts of beef. Not so familiar is the use of beer with beef, most famously done by the Belgians in their carbonnades a la flamande.
The statements contained in your editorial "A Truce at Gaza" of Sept. 9, regarding Israel's attitude to her present frontiers and "aggressiveness" are not borne out by the facts.
AUDIENCES at night clubs along the glittering Las Vegas highway known as The Strip seldom realize how much of their enjoyment they owe to a little whirlwind of a woman 2,150 air-miles away.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 13 -- West Germany made a new move today to nudge Britain's pound out of the position as the leading currency of Europe and replace it with the Deutsche mark.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 -- This afternoon Karl Spooner was rated by Manager Smokey Alston as one of his world series starting pitchers. Tonight that rating may have dropped a few points.
Strike leaders of the Port of New York have accepted a settlement formula originating with a New Jersey State Senator.

An industrial plot of 77,632 square feet between Fourteenth and Eighteenth Avenues and 127th and 128th Streets in College Point, Queens, has been sold by the Hanover Management Corporation to the Hoffman Construction Corporation.

Pillsbury Mills, Inc., plans to take a leaf from the success story of the clothing trades in order to succeed in the years ahead. This aim was brought out at the Minneapolis company's annual meeting yesterday by R. J. Keith, vice president and administartor of all food divisions.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 13 -- The solid front of members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea against retroactive sales taxes was broken yesterday.
BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 13 -- Senator Styles Bridges asserted today that the United States must curtail aid to other countries.
READING, Pa., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Meadow Ace, with a burst of speed in the homestretch, today won the third and deciding heat of the $12,108 3-year-old Pacing Futurity at the Reading Fair.

The common people of Russia have an evident friendliness for Americans, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas reported yesterday. He arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from Helsinki, Finland.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The Farmers Home Administration made and insured farm loans totaling a record $293,190,000 in the recent fiscal year, the Agriculture Department has reported.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Senior British diplomatic officials reserved comment on the outcome of Soviet-West German talks in Moscow until the actual results of the talks were evident.

A prediction that the country in the next ten years will see growth and development far surpassing any observed in recent years was made yesterday by Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The United States has started a program to teach underdeveloped countries to whom it gives technical assistance the lates techniques in publicity and promotion.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 13 -- There were indications tonight that the agreement to establish official relations between Moscow and Bonn might be received coolly by at least one Government party here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UP) -- The American Veterans Committee declared today the American Legion would be speaking only for itself when it testified before the Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The work now done by weather forecasters may be altered through use of high speed computers (electronic brains).
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 13 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced today plans to give the people greater power through decentralization of the Government.
Mandingo still has "plenty of run." The 7-year-old gelding owned by Meyer J. Kaplan demonstrated as much yesterday at Aqueduct, where he won the feature race.

VIOLETTA ELVIN was the Princess Aurora last night in the Sadler's Wells Ballet's second performance of "The Sleeping Beauty" at the Metropolitan Opera House. There seems to be an inexorable law in the theatre that second nights, especially after unusually brilliant first nights, shall be second-nightish, and this occasion was no exception.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 13 -- Congressional fact finders studying uranium stock marketing practices today heard witnesses characterize some mining ventures as "sheer speculation" and a "rolling gravy train."

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 13 -- Eugene Landy, of Bradley Beach, N. J., who was denied a commission in the Naval Reserve because of his mother's former membership in the Communist party, registered today for a regular three-year course at the Yale University Law School.

State Senator Frank D. O'Connor won a narrow victory last night over T. Vincent Quinn, the incumbent, in a primary contest for the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of Queens. On the basis of complete unofficial returns from all 940 election districts in the county, Senator O'Connor received 34,178 votes to 32,055 for Mr. Quinn.
Opponents of the use of premiums as a selling tool were singled out for attack yesterday by Gordon C. Bowen, president of the Premium Advertising Association of America, Inc.
As a devoted South Carolinian I cannot watch silently while my native section plunges headlong into needless racial strife.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of letters from Premier Bulganin to Chancellor Adenauer. Dr. Adenauer's letter to Premier Bulganin was identical except that he spoke on behalf of the West German Government instead of the Soviet Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Officials here are "interested but skeptical" about Soviet offers to revive large-scale trade with the United States.
Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road got preliminary assurance yesterday of immunity from future hardship of the kind that brought thousands to work late on Monday morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The United States is parachuting 1,000 tons of rice to starving mountain villagers in Northern Laos.

The Fund for the Republic began a move yesterday to explain its policies and programs directly to all the local posts of the American Legion. The action was in answer to attacks made last Sunday by Seaborn P. Collins, the Legion's national commander.

The return of Hugon Nanke to Poland last week, after he had been designated Premier of the Polish Government in Exile, is "insignificant and does not represent a trend in redefection," a leader of the Polish Council of National Unity in Exile declared yesterday.

A six-hour strike by 100 garbage disposal scowmen was called off at 6 o'clock last night after an appeal by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain. He asked the union president to withhold strike action pending a meeting today with Abraham D. Beame, budget Director.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of San Angelo, Tex., today upset Tony Trabert of Cincinnati to win the long-delayed Tristate-Western tennis final.
THERE are still plenty of local hunters who think of a "railbird" as an individual in a checkered suit perched on a fence at the track with a stop watch in one hand.
The Health Department announced last night that it would start second 1955 Salk vaccine inoculations against poliomyelitis for 167,000 school children on Sept. 27.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The establishment of diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and West Germany is regarded by qualified sources here as a gain for the Russians in the long-term struggle for Germany.

HONOLULU, Sept. 14 -- Membership in the Protestant Episcopal Church has reached a record high of 2,757,744. This was disclosed today as the church's twelve-day fifty-eighth general convention approached adjournment tomorrow.

Newark Airport, once the poor relation of Idlewild and La Guardia, will solidify its Mainline status today with the opening of the West Side Airlines Terminal. The new $5,000, 000 station for airport buses is at Forty-second Street and Tenth Avenue, virtually in the mouth of the Lincoln Tunnel.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, large manufacturer of electronic and telecommunications equipment, yesterday increased its quarterly dividend for the second time this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The United States refused today to discuss the possibility of a foreign ministers' meeting with Communist China until Peiping had fulfilled its promise to release forty-one Americans.

THE Yankees were more relaxed at the Stadium yesterday than they've been in weeks. It was almost as if they had finally realized that it was silly to keep looking fearfully upward to see if the sword of Damocles had started to fall. If it fell, it fell. There was nothing much they could about it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Punishment by foreign courts of United States military personnel for off-duty offenses was defended today by the deputy Republican leader of the House of Representatives.
Proposals to permit insurance companies to issue variable annuities were criticized yesterday as not making adequate provision for protection of the public.
A two-year wage accord covering seventy Department of Sanitation scow captains was reached yesterday between the city and Local 333, United Marine Division, A. F. L.
THIS morning will find surfcasters from at least a half-dozen states scattered along the popular Martha's Vineyard beaches for the opening of the thirty-day striped bass and bluefish derby.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) The Air Force said today there was nothing unusual or irregular about the attendance of two Russian embassy air attaches at the recent National Air Show at Philadelphia.
I refer to Arthur Krock's column in the Sept. 8 issue of The New York Times.

Movements in prices of futures on the New York commodity exchanges were irregular yesterday. The settlement of the dock strike tended to weaken imported items. Coffee, cocoa, wool, potatoes, zinc and lead eased; cottonseed oil, rubber, hides, onions and soybean oil rose, and changes in sugar and copper were mixed.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 8 -- A determined attack on national illiteracy has been opened by the Dominican Republic.

The naming of Justine Wise Polier to her third ten-year term on the Court of Domestic Relations is in accordance with Mayor Wagner's generally good record of appointments. In dealing with the delicate family problems which this, one of the most personal of all our courts, has as its daily grist, Judge Polier has built up an excellent reputation for humanity and understanding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Government today made 11,000 tons of copper, originally destined for its stockpile of strategic materials, available for the use of private industry in the closing quarter of this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- The Interior Department today formally established the Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. It is the seventh and largest historical park in the United States.
Sales by the nation's chain and mail order companies continued to climb last month to register the largest gain over a year earlier since March of this year.
A bit of Swiss navy arrived here yesterday with the docking of the thirty-four-foot yacht Bahoa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- It is a long time till the election, but the Republican National Committee headquarters is already as busy as a State Fair on Saturday night.
MILAN. Italy, Sept. 14 -- How far the foreign policy of a democracy should be controlled by public opinion was discussed today at the conference on "the future of freedom."
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 -- The Government of India announced today it would introduce legislation to bring important aspects of the newspaper business under state regulation.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 14 (UP) -- A fifty-ship military transport fleet fought to break through ice packs in the Arctic today to deliver cargo to outposts of the early-warning radar line.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- The Soviet Union declared today that the United States was attempting to discuss "in a vacuum" the Eisenhower plan for an exchange of military blueprints.

Professor of Sociology Egon E. Bergel, in trying to inform "some uninformed readers" about South Africa's apartheid, goes off the rails himself. He advances the theory that anthropologists and social scientists have the sole right "to speak with authority about questions of race and race relations."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- It is, of course, too wild a fancy to have expected National Chairman Hall or any of the Republican state leaders who went to Denver last week to talk back to President Eisenhower. But a protest, well grounded in our political history, could have been made by any of these in reply to his reproachful remarks to this group about the doctrine of "indispensability."
TINY star-shaped bits of carrot and thin julienne strips of chicken are just two of the many garnishes that chefs use to add interest and appetite appeal to consomms.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania represented the Democratic party tonight as indifferent as to whether President Eisenhower ran for a second term.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday directed the eleven district banks to tighten the lid on credit advances to the more than 4,200 savings and loan institutions that are members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Clement R. Attlee is ready to retire as leader of the British Labor party and hand over its direction to a younger man.
IS the Channeled Welk to be carried for evening? Is the world made of ivory? Does the horse's bit come attached to the feedbag?

THE Sadler's Wells Ballet gave its first program of short ballets last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and two of them were new to this country. One was Frederick Ashton's "Scenes de Ballet'' and the other was John Cranko's "The Lady and the Fool."
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 14 -- As often as not, when the gazettes quote Jim Tatum on the world - beating Maryland football team he is molding, they get him wrong.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, denied today there was any conflict between his study of United States civilian employes abroad and a 1954 State Department study of the Foreign Service.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Vicki, the runaway elephant, came charging out of her wooded hideaway today, bowled over her handler and disappeared again.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Sir Linton Andrews, chairman of the British Press Council, sharply criticized today the manner in which some British newspapers had speculated about Princess Margaret's marital intentions. The press council is a management-employe group set up in 1953 primarily to safeguard the freedom of the press.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The State Department hailed the Bonn-Moscow accord today as a triumph for Western diplomacy and a confession that Soviet policy on Germany was bankrupt.

The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended on last Friday increased 1,045,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 154,337,000 barrels, compared with 152,292,000 a week earlier and 153,279,000 a year ago.
For the first time, a textile mill has adopted quality standards set up by the American Standards Association.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $26,214,000 of notes due in about six months to finance temporarily the development of two state-subsidized low-rent projects -- the Frederick Douglas Houses in Manhattan, and the Marlboro Houses in Coney Island.
Labor peace through 1957 on the city's subway and bus lines was assured yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14 -- The first full description of the staggering air-pollution problem that confronts New York City was given here today at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the legality of a proposed reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company by affirming a lower court ruling on two appeals and dismissing a third appeal.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 - A Japanese surgeon reported to the International College of Surgeons today that radioactive isotopes had simplified diagnosis of cancer in the stomach and intestinal tract.
Jack Frye, former president of Trans-World Airlines, offered yesterday a new design in the high-stake aeronautical search for a DC-3 replacement.
United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company declared a dividend of 75 cents on its common shares yesterday, payable on Oct. 15. The company paid 25 cents in April and June.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14 -More than 1,000 towns and cities had to curtail water consumption last year because of shortages.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 14 -Representatives of the United States and three Latin American nations met here today in the opening session of a conference in an effort to settle the controversial matter of fisheries in the southeast Pacific.
The land under the fifty-eight-story office building at 500 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Forty-second Street, has been sold by Gerry Brothers Co. to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Six acres on the north side of Union Avenue, east of West Street in Harrison, N. Y., have been purchased by the Pambob Development Corporation, a group of home builders headed by Arthur Stang. Clients of Herbert Goodman sold the property through the Severin Company, broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The president of the Minneapolis-Moline Company and the leader of a group of Eastern investors who threatened a fight for control of the company announced today they had resolved their differences.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Stockholders of Prosperity Company today approved a three-for-one split of the Class A and Class B common stock.

Publicly financed parking facilities may be the solution to one of our most vexing traffic problems, a British expert suggested yesterday. Alexander Samuels, chairman of the London and Home Counties Traffic Advisory Committee, made the suggestion as he prepared to return home after a two-week inspection of traffic problems in this country.

ONCE upon a time a great function of painting was to give a true view and searching criticism of an age. The ubiquitous camera seems to have cowed many modern artists into forgetting all about that. Certainly, when you look at the works of the reigning shower-curtain school, it is hard to remember.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -Independent oil producers today endorsed threats by the Government to curb foreign petroleum imports.
Everett L. Kayhart of Lincoln Park, N. J., was chosen yesterday to receive the Admiral McNulty Scholarship of the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University.
WILMINGTON, N. C., Sept. 14 (AP) -- The crew of the Isthmian Line freighter Steel Surveyor heaved a sigh of relief today after ridding the ship of the "curse of the white python."

An assertion that advertising and public relations workers should take more of a share in framing company policy was put yesterday before the convention of the Life Insurance Advertisers Association at the Essex House.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Tony DeMarco belted his way back into the welterweight picture tonight in the first round as he plastered Chico Vejar with sudden, sickening blows for a technical knockout at Boston Garden in a nationally televised bout.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 -The Buenos Aires International Airport at Ezeiza was under guard again today. About 300 troops moved to the airport area last night and were billeted near the Control Building.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 14 (UP) -- Rocky Marciano was pronounced in "perfect" physical condition today but described as "definitely on edge" by Dr. Vincent Nardiello of the New York State Athletic Commission.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 14 -- A crowd of 500 Europeans, led by chiefs of the Presence Francaise, an organization that opposes compromise with the nationalists, marched to the residency tonight to protest the Government's projected policy.

Part of the garment center traded its usual street sounds yesterday noon for the harmonies of a miniature U. S. O. Camp Shows performance. The session, augmented by Eddie Cantor and Capt. Richard Sherrill McCutchen of the Marines, hero of "The $64,000 Question," attracted a large crowd.

Sales and earnings of Dresser Industries, Inc., for the nine months ended on July 31 were slightly less than for the corresponding period a year ago. H. N. Mallon, president, however, said yesterday that the 1955 fiscal year should set new records in both sales and income and that there was every reason to anticipate near-capacity operations well into 1956.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 14 -- Bob McCall, a former Colgate University football player, downed the last of the former titleholders in the United States amateur golf championship today. The 205-pound Youngstown (Ohio) sports salesman eliminated Willie Turnesa, the 1938 and 1948 champion, by 4 and 3 in the fourth round at the Country Club of Virginia.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Willie Hartack kept his backers happy today by riding five winners, including both ends of a $28.80 daily double.
A bench warrant was issued yesterday for Paul H. Hughes, 35-year-old Army veteran, after his indictment on six counts of perjury by a Federal grand jury.

The honest light of day is a salutary medicine for dictators. Men like Generalissimo Trujillo of the Dominican Republic and Brig. Gen. Perez Jimenez of Venezuela work happily in the dark. They do not like visits from objective correspondents such as The Times has just sent to their countries.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer faced today the task of convincing the Germans that the agreement to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union would contribute to German reunification.

I have a plan which would raise millions of dollars for the City of New York and at the same time be a boon to automobile owners and business men of New York City. My plan will relieve the streets of New York of the unnecessary cars that are now cluttering them; cars that are not moved but stand permanently or are moved daily on alternate streets.

PITTSBURGH, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., ended last night a three-day walkout at Westinghouse Electric Corporation plants. But the big local that triggered the walkout in a dispute over a company efficiency move said it would stay on strike.
The eight-day dock strike against the Waterfront Commission was called off yesterday.

A bit less than one-fifth of the money borrowed on securities is being used to finance out-and-out speculation, according to a study just completed by the New York Stock Exchange. Of the $4,495,000,000 of securities loans outstanding in the nation on June 30, Keith Funston, Exchange president, reported yesterday, $850,000,000 could be attributed to speculation.
ARNOLD CONSTABLE presented its 130th anniversary collection of fashions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The styles belie the age of the store.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The National Education Association advised school boards today to put their policies into writing and make them public.
A Broadway theatre information center that ultimately would help people to obtain ticket reservations to legitimate stage attractions either by telephone or in person is being set up.
Gordon Duff has been named producer of "Justice," the National Broadcasting Company's weekly half-hour television series that begins on Sunday, Oct. 2.
Plans for an intensive advertising campaign to clean up New York were unfolded at a luncheon yesterday to representatives of the city's seven daily newspapers and of outdoor advertising media.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Secretary General of France's Socialist party tipped his hat today to United States free enterprise. "I will admit it at least deserves its name," he said.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 7 to 17 points yesterday, the far months showing the most strength.

THIS has been a dark week for small fry. But some of the gloom occasioned by the beginning of a new school year must have been dispelled between 7:30 and 8:30 o'clock last night. That's when "Dumbo" came to television.
DENVER, Sept. 14 -- Harold E. Stassen will report to President Eisenhower Friday on the progress of the disarmament talks at the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Malcolm P. McLean said today he had begun working on a plan to buy the Waterman Steamship Company as early as June, 1954.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 15 -- Three of Japan's most notorious war criminals will be released this week by agreement of the United States and seven other Allied powers that sentenced them to life imprisonment ten years ago.
Greater progress has been made toward equal opportunity for all Americans in the last three years than in any similar period since 1865, according to Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

At last the leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association have found -- or manufactured -- a face-saving gimmick in their proposal to end their tie-up of the docks: a "citizens' committee." The enthusiasm with which the union members have approved is a measure of how sick and tired they have been of the sorry mess into which their officers have led them.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the report issued today by the Australian Royal Commission on Espionage on the Petrov case and the text of the commission's conclusions:
LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Gordon Pirie defeated Emil Zatopek in a stirring finish in the 5,000- meter race of the two-day Britain-Czechoslovakia track meet in Prague today.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 14 -- Archie Moore is a sharp talker, a master of the quick rejoinder. He dances away from a direct question, but if you lead with a metaphor he is a ready mixer.

THE country store, its jumble sale atmosphere intact, but with the addition of dry goods by Vera Maxwell and a few tins of pate de foie gras shelved above the cracker barrel, is making a successful comeback in rural New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -Aerial reconnaissance has disclosed no sign of the Peruvian troop concentrations that Ecuador charged last Thursday were threatening her security and the peace of the Western Hemisphere.
The Jewish people here and over the world will usher in at sundown tomorrow Rosh ha-Shanah, which marks the Jewish New Year 5716.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western aRilroad, once a blue chip as "the road of anthracite," learned to tighten its belt during the terrible Thirties and the decline of hard coal. The lesson has been applied to the $7,000,000 flood disaster that struck its lines last month.
ALBANY, Sept. 14 -- The Democratic State Commissioner of Investigation and the Republican State Chairman traded verbal blows today over the subject of questionnaires.

READING, Pa., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Childs Hanover won the $12,457 Reading Fair Futurity for 3- year-old trotters today in a Grand Circuit race that took five heats to decide. The bay colt is owned by K. D. Owen of Houston.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14 -- Australia unfolded today a 100,000-word story of far-reaching Soviet espionage here, imperiling the security of "the whole Western world."

The historic and at times stormy conference between the Soviet rulers and Chancellor Adenauer has ended in a last-minute compromise which, on the decisive issue, represents at least a defensive victory for the West. But in respect to the German problem the compromise is so full of loopholes, and open to so many interpretations, that its real significance can only be determined by the test of action.

Approval of a two-for-one split of the common stock of Owens-Illinois Glass Company was given by stockholders yesterday at a special meeting held in Toledo, Ohio. Shareholders also voted to increase the authorized shares to 12,000,000 from 4,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Congressional investigators said today the mystery man in recent "whitewash" charges against top Internal Revenue Service officials was Harrell T, Vance, Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue for administration.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Trading was extremely dull at times on the Board of Trade today. Wheat, which had been showing some life recently, was lower. Corn, oats and rye were strong.

A new method of making transformer coils and other electromagnetic equipment coils by using aluminum strip instead of the conventional copper wire was announced yesterday by the Reynolds Metals Company.

If you go to Yankee Stadium -- as a lot of baseball fans will be doing in these exciting final stages of the American League pennant race -- a personal or business emergency may arise that makes it necessary for your family or associates to reach you.
YONKERS, Sept. 14 (AP) -Adios Harry, the world's fastest harness horse, will attempt a comeback after three bad races in the $25,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Ezra Taft Benson entered a new political farm fight today with a promise to give Congress something "very specific" to ease sagging farm incomes.

Today's new film is "It's Always Fair Weather," an M-G-M musical in CinemaScope and color directed by Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen, at the Radio City Music Hall. Arthur Freed produced the film from a story and screen play by Betty Comden and Adolph Green.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 10 -- There will be one flag and one people when South Africa becomes a republic, Johannes G. Strijdom, the Prime Minister, said today.
A shift toward increased emphasis on teamwork in management has occurred during the last year, it was asserted yesterday by Lawrence A. Appley, president of the American Management Association.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, and Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, reviewed the Amy's budget for the 1956 fiscal year today. They are seeking to achieve economies that would not affect the service's combat readiness.

Unrealistic television "family comedies" in the long run might do more to confuse some youngsters' attitudes toward life than crime and adventure stories, specialists at the Family Service Association of America feel.
WARSAW, Sept. 14 -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today he had found friendship for the United States on his visit to Poland.
PARIS, Sept. 14 -- Further snags tonight threatened the Government's program for ending the Moroccan crisis.
Continuing their determined pursuit of the Indians in what has suddenly shaken down into a two-team American League pennant race, the Yankees downed the Tigers, 6 -- 4, at the Stadium yesterday.
Lazard Freres Co. and Lehman Brothers are planning to become active in the Italian investment banking market.

Martin Yamin, a former Baltimore police magistrate, was committed to Kings County Hospital for observation yesterday by Kings County Judge George J. Joyce. He was to have gone on trial on a first-degree murder charge on Sept. 27.
CAIRO, Sept. 14 -- Egyptian authorities are considering a United Nations proposal of a neutral zone and barrier along the Gaza demarcation line.
PALMYRA, N. J., Sept. 14 -- Passenger-car tolls on the Tacony-Palmyra and Burlington-Bristol Bridges were reduced today from 25 to 5 cents by the Burlington County Bridge Commission.

Public offering is being made today of an issue of $100,000,000 of 3 5/8 per cent debentures of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation by an investment banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Lehman Brothers. The debentures will come due on Sept. 1, 1970, and are priced at 98.575 to yield 3.75 per cent to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 7:

TRENTON, Sept. 14 -- The disclosure that a citizens committee had been formed to mediate the dispute between the bi-state Waterfront Commission and the International Longshoremen's Association detonated like a bomb today in the Jersey political arena.
Mayor Wagner was denounced yesterday for refusing to hear five organizations favoring reappointment of former Domestic Relations Justice Hubert T. Delany.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 14 -- Communist China has notified the special committee of the International Geophysical Year, 1957-58, of its intention to participate in the world-wide program of basic scientific research.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Although Herb Score set a major league strikeout record for a rookie, the Cleveland Indians' American League lead was cut to one game tonight as they bowed to the Washington Senators, 3 -- 2, at Griffith Stadium.

The ten-story apartment house at 55 Glenwood Avenue, East Orange, N. J., has passed to new ownership. A New York syndicate represented by Roy Berlin, attorney, has acquired the property through the purchase of the common stock of the Glenwood Realty Company, owner of the development.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 -- The political upset in the Republican primaries at New Castle yesterday was so decisive that control of the Republican town doubtless will be handed to the new wing of the party in November.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Sept. 14 -- A light bomber failed in a take-off at Mitchel Air Force Base today, crashed through a heavy wire fence and came to a halt on Hempstead Turnpike here. The mishap tied up traffic for three hours on the heavily-traveled east-west highway.

The board of directors of American Broadcasting - Paramount Theatres, Inc., has approved the redemption of 150,000 shares of its 5 per cent preferred stock ($20 par value), it was announced yesterday by Leonard H. Goldenson, president.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 14 -- Obviously, the Giants, who dropped a 9-2 decision to the Braves tonight and fell six lengths behind the runners-up, are going nowhere. However, Willie Mays, the New Yorkers' precocious Say Hey Kid, solidified his chances for the homerun championship by slamming two round-trippers before 22,312 fans at County Stadium.
A spectacular blaze that broke out yesterday on a Jersey City pier set a cargo ship on fire and spread a thick blanket of stinging smoke over the downtown area there.
STRANGE lands always seem to infect hat designers with a creative fever. So it is with Martin Belasco.

For the second successive day a double handful of stocks, most of them "standard" issues of the market averages, gave lively performances in an otherwise unexcited session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. As a result, The New York Times combined average pushed ahead to a historic high.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Henry Suydam, State Department press officer, on the Soviet-West German agreement:
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 14 -- A divided Opposition Labor party must determine its stand on the politically hot report of the Royal Commission on Soviet espionage made public in Canberra today.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 14 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, said today that the Department of Justice did not regard the protection of the country's internal security as the exclusive prerogative of the Federal Government.
David Bronstein of Russia, the leader in the interzone chess tournament in Gothenburg, gained a half-point in the eighteenth round yesterday.
Famine amid plenty.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- A delegation from the East German Communist Government will arrive in Moscow Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- After-hours use of present high-school buildings for junior college classes was suggested today by Herold C. Hunt, new Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- Before Chancellor Konrad Adenauer left today for Bonn he said German war prisoners "will in the very near future leave the Soviet Union."

A fine new convenience for the air traveler is put into service today with the opening of the West Side Airlines Terminal on Forty-second Street at Tenth Avenue. This is a $5,000,000 building, of four floors, with the basement level providing space for parking nearly two hundred automobiles.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- Manager Smokey Alston's lecture to the Dodgers after last night's defeat had no visible result tonight. The Cardinals, behind the three-hit pitching of Tom Poholsky, won, 3 -- 0, at Busch Stadium again.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 14 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler of Britain said today that the world's financial leaders could cease worrying about the pound sterling.

Work has been started on a parking garage in the Herald Square district. Scheduled to be completed next April, the four-story structure at 323-29 West Thirty- fourth Street will accommodate about 500 automobiles.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (UP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, to Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, made public today, stipulating reservations made by the West German delegation during the negotiations here that ended yesterday:

A fine new convenience for the air traveler is put into service today with the opening of the West Side Airlines Terminal on Forty-second Street at Tenth Avenue. This is a $5,000,000 building, of four floors, with the basement level providing space for parking nearly two hundred automobiles.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14 -- Manager Smokey Alston's lecture to the Dodgers after last night's defeat had no visible result tonight. The Cardinals, behind the three-hit pitching of Tom Poholsky, won, 3 -- 0, at Busch Stadium again.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 14 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler of Britain said today that the world's financial leaders could cease worrying about the pound sterling.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14 -A top oil refinery executive warned service station operators today that the legislation they were seeking to end gasoline price wars might be a boomerang.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Greek Ambassador George V. Melas said today it would be "most dangerous if nothing were forthcoming" from the United States in the way of support for Greece's demand that the right of self-determination be given the British colony of Cyprus.

Land acquisition for a modified version of the once-defeated Fordham Road improvement project in the Bronx was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The Board of Estimate probably will pass on the action next week.

Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Precious Lady won the six-furlong sprint that featured the program at Aqueduct yesterday. Under a smooth ride by Henry Moreno, the daughter of Requested improved gradually to take the race by a length.
MIAMI, Sept. 14 (UP) -- A new tropical storm swept toward the Virgin Islands today. Meanwhile, Hurricane Hilda moved out to the Caribbean after hammering a path of death and destruction across Cuba.

Freda Kirchwey has resigned as editor and publisher of The Nation, the 90-year-old crusading weekly, but will remain as an editorial contributor. She is succeeded as editor by Carey McWilliams and as publisher by George C. Kirstein.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration predicted today that in ten years the air lines would carry more passengers than railroads and buses combined.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 14 -- Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali, who has been in office one month, disclosed tonight that an electoral reforms commission would be appointed this month. The move will be preliminary to the holding of Pakistan's first national elections in her eight-year history, he added.
Dr. George S. Counts is scheduled for election tonight as state chairman of the Liberal party. He will replace Adolf A. Berle Jr., who resigned last spring.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon, widely regarded as an accomplished television artist, took the position yesterday that good off-the-cuff broadcasts take far more time to prepare than do formal speeches. He came out against written texts or the use of prompters in airwave campaigning.
District Attorney T. Vincent Quinn of Queens delayed a decision yesterday on whether to ask for a recount of Tuesday's Democratic primary ballots.

Carmine G. DeSapio accepted yesterday an invitation to make a Columbus Day speech in San Francisco. It will be the Tammany leader's first public speaking appearance outside New York State since last fall's election.
There are 200 models in the 1956 truck line announced yesterday by the Ford Motor Company. They range from pick-up delivery units to heavy duty vehicles with a carrying capacity of 42,000 pounds.

A patent covering a new type nylon stretch yarn has been granted to Alamance Industries, Inc., Burlington, N. C., an affiliate of Chester H. Roth Company, Inc., hosiery producer. The method is said to be more economical and to produce a smoother and sheerer yarn.

Any thought that New York City can relax in its school building efforts must be discarded as the age of present educational plant is examined. We suppose a good many New Yorkers would be shocked at the extent of this over-age problem. The city's public school system is actually using, for instructional purposes, four buildings over one hundred years old, one of them built in 1847.
FOR those thousands who by their unswerving loyalty and devotion have kept ice shows in business for almost a generation the news this morning is as they undoubtedly had hoped it would be.
Back in the halcyon -- if unsteady -- days of the gold standard, a man possessing any currency in the world could buy any other with it.
WOWEN oriented in the field of home cookery will find much to inspire them in the array of canned fish on grocery shelves. It seems to widen almost daily, offering a constantly tempting variety.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Rocky Marciano has no set plan for his fight with Archie Moore at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.
RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 15 (UP) -- The University of North Carolina announced today it would admit Negro students to its undergraduate school this fall for the first time in its 166-year history.
Another step forward in the rehabilitation of Morningside Heights as a "residential and cultural community" will be taken today.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 15 -While West Germany was assessing the results of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Moscow, the East Germans moved more prominently into the picture today.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 15 -- The political vacuum in which this capital waited today for signals from Paris was symbolic of the economic stagnation caused in French Morocco by two years of doubts and intermittent violence.
Bearing in mind the saying that money talks, foreign TV interests are seeing if they can educate "The $64,000 Question" to speak in British and French accents.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Burley growers hope to have a representative promoting the use of the tobacco in Russia in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Navy said today it would not abandon any of the ships battling their way through heavy ice to carry supplies and equipment to the new Arctic radar station line and other outposts.
ATHENS, Sept. 15 -- King Paul has temporarily canceled his plans for a holiday in Austria and Germany to return to the capital.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -The International College of Surgeons was told tonight that the United Nations effort to improve the physical standards of underprivileged countries was helping to found lasting peace.
Third Copy, the third choice, was the $14.90-for-$2 winner of the $7,970 Bushwick Hurdle Handicap at the Aqueduct track yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 15 -- The fifth annual convention of the Congress of European-American Associations opened here today.
HONG KONG, Friday, Sept. 16 -- Communist China today released two American civilians. Two or three others were expected to cross the border into Hong Kong momentarily.
MOST of the artists in the gallery group are represented in an exhibition entitled "Figurative Painting" at the Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue.
Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the year 5716 on the Hebrew calendar, begins at sundown tonight with services in synagogues and temples.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 15 (AP) -- The state's top American Federation of Labor official "publicly apologized" to the state Congress of Industrial Organizations today for remarks made by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 15 -Harvie Ward, the pre-tournament favorite, was among those to gain the semi-final round of the United States amateur golf championship today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15 -- Britain today submitted an outline of methods by which Western and Soviet commanders could check on each other's armed forces and non-atomic armaments.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., announced today the union had taken over publication of The Colorado Springs Free Press.
DENVER, Sept. 15 -- Earl Mountbatten will be a guest at the White House late next month.
Refreshed by a thirty-hour breathing spell and encouraged by Cleveland's Wednesday night defeat in Washington, the Yankees will renew their determined pursuit of the American League pennant tonight.

Former King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia left his throne to become an active politician. It was a dramatic gesture, just as was his previous self-exile in Thailand to force action on Cambodian independence. This time he sought vindication of the policies he had adopted and he sought it from the electorate. He won a smashing victory.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary moved into a three-way tie for fourth place by winning an adjourned game yesterday in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, according to a report received through Swedish sources.
Next year should be "excellent" for both business and consumers, Arthur O. Dietz, president of C. I. T. Financial Corporation said today.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- The Government of Cyprus officially banned today an underground organization that has waged a terrorist campaign to back up demands for the merger of Cyprus with Greece.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service has signed a contract with the American President Line or the transport of military personnel and their families on trans-Pacific-voyages, starting next month.
Officials of Cook County, Ill., have decided to make another try soon on raising $40,000,000 for the initial financing of a $245,000,000 system of free expressways to serve Chicago.
A hitch developed yesterday in efforts to end the complex labor dispute on the Long Island Rail Road.
ALICE ESTY, soprano, with David Stimer at the piano, offered a program of contemporary songs at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
The New Haven Railroad will build a new station at New Canaan, Conn., with ample land for long-range parking requirements, the railroad announced yesterday.
Trading volume is worrying the New York Stock Exchange's employes. Personnel of the Exchange, numbering about 1,100, receive a bonus each quarter on the turnover of shares.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Behind after two quarters, 21 -- 7, the Chicago Bears fought back tonight to defeat the Cleveland Browns, 24 -- 21, before a crowd of 43,067 in Soldier Field. It was the tenth annual Armed Forces benefit football game.

A conference began in Santiago, Chile, on Wednesday that may prove of considerable importance to one of the most cherished of all international rights -- the freedom of the seas. The meeting is only between four nations -- the United States, Chile, Peru and Ecuador -- but it so happens that the three Latin-American states on the Pacific Ocean are the ones above all in recent years who are challenging this great principle.

WASHINGTON, Sept 15 -- The presence in this country of Richard G. Casey, and one of the principal reasons for this visit by the distinguished Australian Minister for External Affairs, provide occasion to correct a misstatement about Anglo-American relations that has been made so often, and by Britons of such prominence, that it has become widely accepted as a fact in the United Kingdom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -President Eisenhower today proclaimed Nov. 6-12 as American Education Week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A one-time "fellow traveler" challenged today the right of a committee of Congress to compel testimony about "past and reformed associates" already known to it.

A combination shopping center and drive-in theatre is planned in Nanuet, N. Y. The fifty-acre site fronts on Route 59, also known as Nyack Turnpike. Work is expected to be started next month and the development is scheduled to be completed by next June.
High above the Atlantic City race course there is a little padded room. Every racing day a man stands alone in this cubicle and mumbles aloud to himself.

PARIS, Sept. 15 -- An international meeting of experts on race relations will open here Monday probably without three noted United States authorities who have been unable to get clearance in time from the State Department.

During the last year, several books have been published that discussed Herman Melville and his use of symbolism in his writing. A new discussion of his work will be published next Friday by the Harvard University Press. It is entitled "Melville and the Comic Spirit."
DENVER, Sept. 15 -- The White House replied angrily today to what it said was a Democratic accusation that the Republican party was the friend of gangsterism.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- A State Department official said today that West European countries had made a "marked shift" toward the free enterprise system since World War II.
The successful team of George S. Kaufman and Howard Teichmann, authors of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," is teetering. For one thing, they dropped "In the Money."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The head of the Passport Division said today that her office was being swamped with work now that "the war scare is over."

A garden-type apartment building is planned on an irregular vacant plot at 18 Dahill Road, southwest corner of Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn. The property was acquired from Mary and William Westley by John Tricarico, Carl Pechter and Milton Mandel, who have formed the Dahill Construction Corporation.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Registration is in progress here on the beautifully landscaped campus of C. W. Post College. An independent unit of Long Island University, the liberal arts college will open next Thursday.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Two American war veterans said tonight they had worked as Soviet spies in Western Europe for six months in a self-conceived plot "to serve our country by infiltrating Russian intelligence."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A group of Soviet housing officials today accepted an invitation by private builders to tour United States housing projects from New York to California.
VIENNA, Sept. 15--With its first oficial exhibit in the Vienna Fair the United States has apparently overshadowed the Soviet Union which had been represented three years.
An imposing array of helicopter experts have backed the Port of New York Authority in its quarrel with the city over a Manhattan heliport.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Diplomatic sources said today that prospects for a successful Big Four foreign ministers conference in Geneva next month had worsened following the agreement to Soviet-West German diplomatic relations.
The plan for a passenger beltconveyor to replace the old Times Square-Grand Central shuttle appeared doomed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- In the first machine tool show since 1947, $20,000,000 worth of new machine tools are being exhibited at the International Amphitheatre here by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

The "hard-sell" approach to advertising was abandoned yesterday by the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation. The appliance industry long has been using hard-driving, shouting advertising to sell its wares, television receivers among them.

The Harriman Administration will seek to double the duration of state benefits for sick workers. Announcement of the plan was made yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Isador Lubin at a union-sponsored luncheon in the New Yorker Hotel.

CARACAS, Sept. 15 -- Venezuelan business men here have become alarmed over a recent statement by Arthur Flemming, Director of the American Office of Defense Mobilization, warning eighteen American oil companies that they are importing too much oil.

Mayor Wagner advised the City Planning Commission yesterday to give top priority in its 1956 capital budget to projects in four "vital areas." He said the four areas were education, pollution control, transit and waterfront development.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 -- The front-running Indians were at home resting today, following an airplane ride from Washington this morning. Their idleness will not be for long, though, because a three-game set against the dangerous Detroit Tigers starts at Municipal Stadium tomorrow night.

Spurred by the rails, chemicals and coppers, The New York Times combined average yesterday broke through to a historic high for the third successive day and the tenth time in 1955. The stock market, which had shown little drive on the whole, then wobbled and closed lower.
A NUMBER of states have now initiated the hunter safety program for training youthful shooters. A marked decrease in hunting accidents has resulted from these programs during the past few years.
A small but significant increase in tankers withdrawn from idle status over the world has taken place in recent months.
If James Cash Penney, who is 80 years old today, had not been born, Horatio Alger might have had to invent him.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 15 -- Archie Moore didn't have anything to do but rest today after a leisurely jaunt in the early dawn through the woods on Mount Greylock.
AMONG Ohrbach's customers are French women here for visits. This coal-to-Newcastle situation seems reasonable when one can buy a good imitation of a Balenciaga suit for $79.95.
TWO group shows and two one-man appearances add their forces to the growing strength of the new season.
Mrs. Walter A. Rickett received word of the release of her husband from Communist China in a telephone call from this newspaper to her parents' home in Yonkers early today.
A fleeing 16-year-old rape suspect was shot and killed yesterday evening by the police.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 15 -The business of splitting the T -- not to be confused with crossing the t or dotting the i -- was the brain-child of Don Faurot of Missouri.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Aluminum producers attacked Government stockpiling and scrap export policies today at the annual meeting of the American Die Casting Institute here.

A tea and rehearsal for the Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League to be held at the Plaza on Nov. 23 took place at the hotel on Wednesday. Attending were the 1955 provisional members of the league, all debutantes of the season, who will be honored at the dance, the mothers and the young men who will escort the debutantes to the fete.
DENVER, Sept. 15 -- President Eisenhower, in a New Year's greeting to American Jews today, hailed their religious teachers as a force for justice and goodwill among persons of all faiths.
Samuel S. Leibowitz, Judge of Kings County Court, was reported yesterday as a likely choice for appointment to the State Supreme Court.
TOKYO, Sept. 15 (UP) -Rebellious villagers surrendered their homes and rice paddies for expansion of the Tachikawa United Air Force base today, ending two days of violent opposition.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy intensified yesterday the department's drive against narcotics, gambling and pressure groups.

PRICES are higher on many foods this week-end. Some of the increases are large. Fresh water fish, much in demand for the Jewish New Year holiday, is, in several instances, as much as 50 cents a pound more than it was a week ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- The executive board of the United Nations Children's Fund allocated $3,375,000 today to aid seven countries in the eradication of malaria. The appropriation was the largest ever voted in the history of the agency for a single program.
The Civil Liberties Union will ask the United States Supreme Court today to review the case of a man convicted of murder.

JERUSALEM, Friday, Sept. 16 -- President Izhak Ben-Zvi warned the Arabs against continued hostility in his Jewish New Year's message and chided the Western powers for failing to "act effectively" to bring peace to the Middle East.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (UP) -- Henry W. Grunewald, the "Silent Dutchman" of 1951-52 Congressional tax scandal investigations, was arrested in a fourth Federal case today on charges of cheating on his own income taxes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -There has been a growing tendency in Washington since the war for the Government to put out not what it knows to be true but what it wants people to believe is true.

Warner Swasey Company of Cleveland would buy the assets and business of the Duplex Truck Company, Lansing, Mich., under an agreement reached by directors of both concerns. The proposal must be approved by the stockholders of Duplex.
" SOME of them other managers are able to predict that they'll win the pennant," Casey Stengel was saying the other day, "but I ain't that smart. I just don't know."
HONOLULU, Sept. 15 -- The Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church gravely warned here today that the fate of the world rested in large measure with Asia's hungry and depressed masses.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Sept. 13 -- The police here have been combing the city for an 18-year-old student who called President Juan D. Peron a tyrant and dictator.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 15 -- Prime Minister Robert Menzies joined issue today with Herbert V. Evatt, leader of the Opposition, on the report of the Royal Commission on Espionage.
Dr. George S. Counts was elected state chairman of the Liberal party last night and immediately began a drive to enlarge its influence.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 15 -- A Foreign Office official blamed the United States today for bad relations with Hungary.

There have been several articles in your paper regarding the United States Information Agency, reporting that there is an urgent need to revise the policies and practices of said agency, without showing clearly enough why this should be so.
BERLIN, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, has received permission to visit the Soviet Union's Vorkuta slave labor camp, his wife reported today.

The Australian Royal Commission's report on the Petrov case now joins the equally distinguished and even more sensational Canadian report of 1946 on the Gouzenko case. Both show with ample documentation the extent to which the Soviet Union goes in its efforts to spy and suborn individuals in foreign countries.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 15 -- President Manuel A. Odria carried out today a reorganization of the Peruvian Cabinet. The move was considered a preliminary step to next spring's general election.

No one is likely to object to the wage settlement made with the transit workers by the New York City Transit Authority as overly generous if the fare can be kept from going above the present 15 cents. The amount of the hourly wage rise is a maximum of 17 cents, to be reached July 1, 1957.
PARIS, Sept. 15 -- The Government delayed again today the execution of its program to end the political crisis in Morocco.

Today's new film is "Pearl of the South Pacific," an R. K. O. adventure in color, with Virginia Mayo, Denis Morgan, David Farrar and Murvyn Vye, at the Palace. Allan Dwan directed and Benedict Bogeaus produced, from a screen play by Jesse Lasky Jr. and a story by Anna Hunger.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The Government reported today that industrial production rose moderately in August to a new high.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (UP) -President Walter O. (Spike) Briggs of the Detroit Tigers failed today in an attempt to purchase the American League club for a syndicate he headed because his sisters said "there are too many complex questions to be resolved."

One indication that summer has gone can be found these days in the stores. Under wall signs briskly announcing "School Supplies," there can be found cords of unsharpened pencils, reams of paper, notebooks of every size.
Governor Harriman has authorized the State Power Authority to build its own transmission lines to carry St. Lawrence hydroelectric power to its principal customers.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 -Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania described President Eisenhower's election tonight as the result of an abnormality.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 15 (UP) -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits of New York recommended today that the state set up a youth authority with wide powers to "meet the emergency of upsurging juvenile delinquency."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 15 -- A method for attaining the large quantities of heavy nitrogen that may be essential to operate breeder reactors that produce more atomic fuel than they consume was suggested today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -A first night favorite, Verdi's "Aida," was produced for a capacity audience in the War Memorial Opera House tonight as the San Francisco Opera Company opened its thirty-third season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- India reminded the United Nations today that she was an unhappy host to eighty-two prisoners of the Korean war. India added that the United Nations Command had not paid its share of the prisoners' maintenance bills.

Cottonseed oil continued to climb yesterday to new seasonal highs on the Produce Exchange. The volume of 247 tank cars was the third highest of the year. Prices rose 9 to 17 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Most interests were on both sides of the board.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 15 (AP) -Hurricane Ione, caught in a mass of cold air, slowed her forward movement tonight as she moved west-northwest in the Atlantic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- The drive for establishment of a five-day week in motion picture studios has become the key factor in contract negotiations now going on between local units of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

The flurry of trading along Third Avenue that is accompanying the demolition of the old elevated structure resulted in another transaction yesterday. The northwest corner of the avenue and Seventy-third Street was sold for improvement with an apartment house. Pease Elliman was the broker.
THE sands of time bring business from all over the country to a dusky little shop on Lexington Avenue, just below Fifty-sixth Street.

The Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities will be the beneficiary of a country auction on Sept. 24. The event will be held in the carriage house on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Grant White in St. James, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--The Navy, a volunteer force since World War II, turned reluctantly to the draft today to meet its authorized strength.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Dr. J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty at Princeton University, resigned tonight as director of the university's industrial relations section. He had been in the post for twenty-nine years.
An 18-year-old Queens youth was convicted yesterday of assaulting a physician, a policeman and a press photographer.
HONOLULU, Sept. 15 -- Following is the text of a pastoral letter issued today by the Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church at the church's fiftyeighth general convention:
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today "we are ahead" in the technological race with the Soviet Government.
