Baltimore County, Md., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $15,900,000 in the public market. The money will be raised by the sale of serial bonds on Sept. 28. The obligations will be dated Oct. 1, 1955, and will come due on Oct. 1 from 1958 to 1985.

One of the nation's most successful merchants and useful citizens is 80 years old today, James Cash Penney, whose stores are known to every state in the Union. He was born in a small town in the Midwest, the son of a Baptist minister and farmer.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 15 (UP) -- David Eisenhower, 7-year-old grandson of the President, was present at the opening of school today. He "made out just fine," his teachers said.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday the appointment of Howard Taubman as music crit He succeeds Olin Downes, who died on Aug. 22.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 -- The Dodgers battled into the twelfth inning at Busch Stadium today but when they flew home tonight they had their longest losing streak of the year, five games.

The nation's railroads set their best safety record last year and are heading for an even better safety record this year, industry officials were told last night at the thirty-sixth annual presentation of the E. H. Harriman memorial awards.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading were today:
Camilla Williams, soprano, will sing the title role in Gian-Carlo Menotti's "The Saint of Bleecker Street" with the Vienna State opera tonight in Vienna.

HONG KONG, Friday, Sept. 16 -- Two American Red Cross representatives, British police officials and press correspondents reporting on a "pool" arrangement were at the Hong Kong-Kowloon border for the arrival of the American civilians freed by Communist China today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. and nine others, including business men and members of Congress, were sworn in today as members of the United State delegation to the United Nations General Assembly meeting. The session opens in New York Tuesday.

DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK, author of the seven million-copy best-seller, "Baby and Child Care," yesterday attributed the success of his book more to mother-grandmother rivalry than to the book's inherent worth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Diphtheria is on the rise in this country as polio goes down.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 16 -The Soviet Government challenged last night Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's claim to speak for all Germany and his right to seek a revision of that country's present borders.

The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company and the Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., reported yesterday that the net earnings of the companies in the group for the first six months of this year were 70,728,561 ($198,039,970). This compares with 69,193,290 ($193,741,212) in the six months ended on June 30, 1954.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 -- A Radical deputy today caused the Argentine Congress to order an investigation of charges that a retired Army general was slowly being poisoned in a guardhouse. The general was Leon Bengoa, former commander of the Third Division who was placed on the active reserve list Aug. 20.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 13 to 35 points (65 cents to $1.75 a bale) on active months, yesterday. Weakness was most pronounced in near months.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- A moderate impetus to buying was afforded grain and soybean futures today by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson's statement that he would recommend a specific plan, outside the support program, to bolster sagging grain prices.

Stockholders of the PennTexas Corporation at a special meeting yesterday in Cresson, Pa., approved its merger with the 95-year-old Niles-BementPond Company. Penn-Texas will be the surviving corporation. The plan had been approved by Niles stockholders on Aug. 26.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- An opera written thirty years ago by Sergei Prokofieff, discovered in a box of old papers in a Paris basement after World War II, took the stage for the first time here last night.

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP) -- American leadership in science and engineering is the most powerful deterrent to international aggression, Don G. Mitchell, chairman and president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Republican National Chairman promised today that his party would "work night and day to get our farm economy out of the depressed state" he accused Democrats of bringing about.
New challenges have been made against the legality of the Army program for giving "other than honorable" discharges to draftees in security risk cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 706,575 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This total (for the week including Labor Day) was 87,617 cars or 11 per cent fewer than for the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Treasury said today the United States sold $45,250,000 worth of gold to other countries in the second quarter of this year and bought $3,500,000 worth.

Directors of the Copperweld Steel Company yesterday elected James M. Darbaker as president to succeed Frank R. S. Kaplan, who becomes chairman of the board. Henry G. Riter 3d, president of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., and president of the National Association of Manufacturers, was elected honorary chairman of the board of directors and chairman of the finance committee.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 15 -- At their tenth anniversary meeting the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund have made an impressive demonstration of strength.

Representative Francis Walter has again sprung to the defense of his much-criticized Immigration and Nationality Act by obtaining from the Immigration and Naturalization Service statistics (not yet officially released or available to others) which he presents as proof that immigrants wanting to come to the United States have "never had it so good" as under the McCarranWalter Act.
The Secretary General of the United Nations asserted last night that the world organization could greatly increase its contributions to peace if the "cold war" was ended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Three hundred and sixty citizens, many of them widely known, asked the United States Supreme Court today to declare the Internal Security Act of 1950 unconstitutional. The petitioners called the act the worst threat yet to American liberty. The law penalizes members of Communist, Communistfront and Communistinfiltrated organizations.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 15 -- Joe Green of Lititz, Pa., was severely injured in the first event, the green jumper stake, as the annual Piping Rock horse show opened today.
A veteran shipping official, Eugene F. Moran, was elected vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority yesterday. He succeeds Bayard F. Pope, who retired July 6.

The directors of the Fund for the Republic declared yesterday that Seaborn P. Collins, National Commander of the American Legion, was misinformed and had misinformed others regarding the purposes and program of the fund.
New York City commercial banks continued to experience a scarcity of lendable funds during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 15 -- The first part of a definitive edition of the Tosefta, part of the basic law of the Jews, was presented to Israel today by the United States on behalf of the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A librarian from a community of 600 persons challenged today the right of Senate investigators to question her about communism.
MACY's buyers have completed the European fashion tour and have returned with bulging suitcases. And, it should be added, hat boxes.

The release simultaneously of the annual reports of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the Bretton Woods twins) comes as a fresh reminder that parochialism in international affairs is a thing of the past.

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of the Soviet Union is ill. For that reason he was unable to be present at the Central Airdrome today when President Juho K. Paasikivi of Finland arrived here on an official visit.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 15 (UP) -- The president of the World Bank said today that the proposed International Finance Corporation probably would begin operations early next year.

PANAMA, Sept. 12 -- In the view of Colombians interviewed recently in their country, President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla has changed in two years from "the great peacemaker" into an old-fashioned, hard-listed military dictator.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 -The case of three turncoat prisoners of war, Otho Bell, Lewie Griggs and William Cowart, was appealed directly to President Eisenhower today.

As the author of a research study discussed by your reporter Edwin L. Dale Jr. on Sept. 2 in an article on traffic safety, may I comment on his intepretation of my findings? The study was a comparison of the accident experience "on two roads in Maryland -- one old and one new, both covering the same route across a set of mountain ridges between Frederick and Hagerstown."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 15 (AP) -- C. I. O. electrical workers ended a three-day sympathy strike today at twenty-five Westinghouse Electric Corporation plants and union negotiators immediately opened 1955 pay talks with a demand for a substantial wage increase.
LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek beat Gordon Pirie in the 10,000-meter race today but the British track team defeated Czechoslovakia in the two-day meet at Prague by a score of 117 -- 95.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Representative Frances Bolton, Republican of Ohio, has purchased a 485-acre tract along the Potomac River opposite Mount Vernon. The purchase was described as "a holding operation to forestall adverse development of commercial or domestic interests."

What promises to be a big part of Mrs. Theodore Evans' future arrived at 8:05 last night in Grand Central Terminal in the form of four Chinese boys, 12, 13, 14 and 15 years old. Mrs. Evans, at 47, plans to put them through college.

YONKERS, Sept. 15 -- Adios Harry, back in competition after a nine-day rest cure, captured the $27,900 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 20-year-old brown colt held off bids by Torrid and Diamond Hal in the stretch to win by a neck.
The regional Red Cross will collect blood today at 346 Broadway from personnel of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Army Corps of Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The State Department was reported today to have refused jobs to several Foreign Service applicants because it said their relatives were security risks.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Sir Anthony Eden is ill of influenza, the Prime Minister's office said today. Sir Anthony has been forced to cancel his immediate appointments.
BERLIN, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- Dimitri Mitropoulos played a dual artistic role tonight at the first concert presented here by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in twenty-five years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -Department store sales in the United States last week rose 11 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A public utilities specialist said today that New York Telephone Company charges to consumers in 1954 were increased by $13,000,000 because the company financed through the sale of high-interest stock rather than low-interest bonds.
Longshoremen returned to work by the thousands yesterday and their best friends warned that they had better stay on the job.
OTTAWA, Sept. 15 -- The natural gas of the Gulf Coast area was brought a step nearer to the homes and industries of Ontario and Quebec today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Officials said today that the United States, in demurring to Communist China's proposal for highlevel negotiations, did not mean to impugn the Communists' good faith in promising to release imprisoned Americans.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 6 points up yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, announced today that the Air Force had "honorably and sensibly" cleared up a case of what he called "guilt by descent."
The police staged a narcotics raid in the Bronx yesterday and took eleven persons into custody, including a woman superintendent of a building and her two sons.
PANAMA, Sept. 12 -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla of Colombia is waging a devastating war against freedom of speech.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- A Federal district court today set Feb. 1 for the start of the perjury trial of former Lieut. Aldo Icardi who has been accused of murdering his superior officer during a cloak-and-dagger mission in World War II.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16 -- Two events this week brought into sharp focus the complex problem of Chile's claims of sovereignty over a remote Antarctic area and over a thousand square miles of the Pacific Ocean along her coast.

The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service again will be the beneficiary of the annual post-debutante Tiara Ball. Committees have been appointed and have begun to work for the fete, a dinner dance to be held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 29.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- The fiftieth annual horse show ball of the Piping Rock Horse Show Association took place tonight at the Piping Rock Club. It was the social highlight of the three-day traditional sports and society event on the North Shore.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Another underground terrorist organization aimed at ending British rule of Cyprus came into the open today in the intensified struggle by Greek Cypriotes to unite their island with Greece.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.3 per cent to 111.4 of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products and for processed foods, especially meats, led the rise. The index for all commodities other than farm products and foods also advanced.
The Gillette Company, producer of safety razors and hair preparations, is going into the pen business.

By 1947 agreement with New York City the Port of New York Authority is charged with responsibility for developing and operating airports. The city of Newark made the same arrangement for its fine airport. The pact with New York provides that the city may not establish or promote any new public aircraft facility without the consent of the Port Authority.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16 (AP) -The question of whether Texas schools could obey the United States Supreme Court desegregation opinion and still qualify for state aid was argued before the Texas Supreme Court today.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., realized a 58.1 per cent increase in its half-year earnings on a sales gain of 9.9 per cent over the period a year ago, according to the report of Bruce A. Gimbel, president, to be released today.

It won't be numbers of athletes but the talents within each that will establish whether the United States or the Soviet Union finishes ahead in the point department at the Olympic games in Australia next year.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 16 -- "I'm ready," said Archie Moore today. He had just had two rounds of sparring with Jesse (Gorilla) Brown, a tough young man who simu lated the style of Rocky Marciano.

Airlines, tobaccos, steels, motors and metals led a firm market session yesterday. Volume eased to 2,540,000 shares from 2,890,000 on Thursday but strength became more general. There was hardly a depressed section in the list.

When the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development opened its doors for business in 1946 it represented the joint undertaking of fifty-four nations with capital stock equivalent to approximately $9 billions in American dollars. The articles of agreement stipulated, however, that only 20 per cent of the subscribed capital was actually to be paid in by the various countries.
Robert Moses accused the Federal Housing Administration yesterday of causing delays up to two and one-half years in a "dozen" private slum clearance projects in New York.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Leo Biagetti, a 28-year-old pro from Willoughby, Ohio, took a three-stroke lead today in the $20,000 Daily News open golf tournament with a 66 for 133.
DROP in almost any afternoon at the musty little pewter shop of Harry Hirsch (one flight up at 213 East Fifty-fifth Street) and you will find the proprietor immersed in a book -on pewter.
GENEVA, Sept, 16 -- The Turkish riots last week were much Worse than could be reported from Istanbul. So is the situation they reflect.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Navy said today that two cargo ships, crippled in a struggle with Arctic ice, were undertow of Navy tugs off the coast of Alaska.

Coelacanth is a "living fossil," that is, a fish that paleontologists were long convinced had been extinguished fifty million years ago. A fisherman was inconsiderate enough to catch one a few years ago off the coast of Africa and upset the conviction.

How strange that 180 years after Americans had far from dispassionately rejected European colonial rule a section of American opinion, ably represented by Philip Marshall Brown in his letter published Sept. 9 should seek to rally to the defense of European colonialism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 -- There was a blank space today on an art show wall where yesterday had hung a color lithograph satirizing Vice President Richard M. Nixon. Removal of the caricature was attacked as censorship and defended as the only proper course at a tax-supported exhibition.

MADRID, Sept. 16 -- Leaders of the Istiqlal party here instructed their representatives in Paris today to reject several modifications that Premier Faure has made to his plan for settlement of the Moroccan question.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches announced today a nation-wide program on religious freedom and civil liberties. It named a special commission to conduct the program, with Prof. Albert Rassmussen of Colgate - Rochester Seminary, Rochester, N. Y., as chairman.

LAST night the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House gave the first New York performance of Frederick Ashton's "Tiresias." Who says this company can do nothing but Petipa revivals? Here is a modern, profoundly creative and altogether extraordinary ballet danced superably and produced to perfection.
CAIRO, Sept. 16 -- Agreement between the Arab nations and Eric A. Johnston on technical details of the Jordan Valley water plan is close to realization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today there was an increasing threat of inflation that might reach "dangerous" proportions soon unless checked.
The pennant-winning Brooklyn Dodgers got an enthusiastic reception from their fans yesterday.

The four-story factory and adjoining two-story building at 346 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Fulton Manufacturing Company to the S. O. S. Products Company. The property, containing a total of 20,000 square feet of space, will be used by the buyer for the manufacture of chemical products and refractories. Lieberman Sprung was the broker in the transaction.

John F. Gehan, executive vice president, and William H. McConnell, vice president for passenger traffic of the American Export Lines, will sail for Europe Thursday on the liner Constitution. They will attend the semi-annual meeting of the Transatlantic Passanger Conference in Rome.

"THE sea," Joseph Conrad said, "never changes and its works, for all the talk of men, are wrapped in mystery." That may be ultimately true. But it is not enough for Hanson Baldwin, a seagoing man-of-all-wars who paces his quarterdeck a few fathoms north-northeast of this lit'ry beachhead. On the contrary, Mr. Baldwin's existence is dedicated to exploring the great waters' heart of darkness.
Playing on their newly resodded home field must have given the Dodgers a lift. Last night, before 16,951 eyewitnesses, they snapped their five-game losing streak by beating the Giants, 4 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A railroad-proposed "train-load" coal rate was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Senate narcotics investigation will start public hearings in New York Monday on a controversial proposal by the New York Academy of Medicine that addicts be given free narcotics at state clinics.
Jews here and over the world ushered in Rosh ha-Shanah at sundown yesterday, marking the year 5716 on the Hebrew calendar.

In the main event at the Aqueduct track yesterday Sweet Music led all the way and was three lengths in advance of the runner-up at the end of the mile and a sixteenth. She was a $9.40-for-$2 item. Her breeder-owner-trainer is Eugene Jacobs.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 16 -- Saddled with a schedule contracted by a previous administration with grandiose dreams of gridiron glory, Pennsylvania in 1954 endured its grimmest football season in history. It must have been a nightmare for its new young head coach; Steve Sebo.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Dispatches reaching the State Department today from Argentina suggested that the latest uprising against President Juan D. Peron was the most serious in the recent series.

BERLIN, Sept. 15 (Reuters) -- Soviet and East German leaders have recently emphasized their contention that the people of East Germany would not want the achievements of the Communist regime sacrificed in the process of reunification.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay wishes now that he had never mentioned these 50-cent maps showing major uranium deposits. They've created a mailroom problem his department doesn't quite know how to handle.
WABASH, Ind., Sept. 16 -- Former Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard accused President Eisenhower today of failing to keep a pledge made in 1952 to the nation's farmers.
LONDON, Sept., 16 -- The Indian Government was said today to welcome mediation by the United States of its claim to Goa.
Two thugs enlisted the unwilling assistance of an elevator operator in staging an armed robbery yesterday at the Sun Chamois Window Cleaning Service, 140 Broadway. They escaped with a $1,100 payroll.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The two Anaconda Company subsidiaries here will invest $38,207,000 to increase copper production and improve social conditions of their workers. Vice President Rodolfo Michels of Chile Exploration Company and Andes Copper Mining Company, the subsidiaries, disclosed this today.
GRETNA GREEN, Scotland, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Gretna Green's smithy, the most famous runaway-marriage place in the world, is up for sale.

Tomorrow will be "Phil Rizzuto Day" at the Yankee Stadium. It comes at an unusually opportune time, since the perennially young shortstop has just been, staging one of the greatest comebacks of his career. He has belied all the gloomy sages who said he was washed up and the legs wouldn't take it any longer.

THE surfcaster is again coming into his own from Hatteras to Cape Cod. The big channel bass are moving in to the surf along the North Carolina outer banks and the stripers are moving in from Long Island to Provincetown.
DENVER, Colo., Sept. 42 -- On the second floor of one of Denver's sparkling new skyscrapers is a troy sanctuary set aside as an unusual memorial to President Eisenhower.

An off-duty patrolman saw a familiar face on the Bowery last evening. He promptly arrested William Miltimore, whose photograph had been circulated as No. 12 on the Police Department's list of thirteen "most wanted" criminals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Senator James O. Eastland contended today that relaxation of refugee immigration requirements would flood the United States with "criminals and Communist agents."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Representatives of copper-using industries today were asked to wait until early next week for an answer to their plea that the Government release 100,000 tons of its stockpiled copper.

Governor Ribicoff of Connecticut now finds himself at odds with both the C. I. O. and the A. F. L. over a point of ethics. A few days ago, speaking at an A. F. L. convention, he criticized the phrasing of a C. I. O. organizing pamphlet which said: "The C. I. O. won't give up on the major issues.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 -- Steve Gromek, a 34-year-old side-arming right-hander who has not hurled a complete game since June 30, did a big favor for the Yankees tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Communists today stopped coal shipments to a tiny Western enclave in East Germany.

TELEVISION drama is getting around gradually to the conclusion that not all teen-agers are depraved. Further evidence or this heartening development was seen last night in "Cop Without a Badge," a drama offered on the "Star Stage" series over Channel 2 from 9:30 to 10 P. M.

The usually staid and dignified Yankees whooped and shouted last night after their spectacular comeback triumph over the Red Sox. It has been many a moon since there has been such a spontaneous outburst in the Bombers' dressing room.
WARSAW, Sept. 15 -- Polish Communist journalists said today anti-American propaganda in Poland in the last decade was a bad thing.

Rubber prices fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Volume was the fourth heaviest of the year. Trading was influenced by weakness in London and rumors that an international report expected to be released over the week-end will show a rise in world rubber production.
DENVER, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Two Republican leaders predicted today that President Eisenhower would be drafted for renomination and would be re-elected.

Miss Lucy Lucile Hanan, former manager of the home service division of the sales department of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., was killed in a motor accident near Madison, Wis., on Thursday.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- In Japan's traditional wrestling "judo" means "soft art." It has proved anything but that for twenty-two barnstorming Americans.
CORNING, Iowa, Sept. 16 -- Five hundred southwest Iowa farmers met here last night to discuss organization of a statewide citizens committee to protest the current decline in farm prices.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16 -- Cancer, in animals, acts as a very large and active pool of iron in the body. This was reported here today at the closing session of the 128th national meeting of the American Chemical Society at the University of Minnesota.
MILAN, Italy, Sept. 16 -- Nigeria's delegate to the Conference on the Future of Freedom asked today for a copy of the "House Rules" for the "Western democratic club."
James Cash Penney, founder and board chairman of the retail stores bearing his name, was honored in two separate events as he celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Robin Roberts pitched his twenty-third victory of the season tonight, 8 -- 1, with a five-hitter against the Pittsburgh Pirates. He was backed by the Philadelphia Phillies' eleven-hit attack.

Great engines out in California these days are preparing to spare any laughing California peasant girls, if such there be, the trouble of personally trampling out the grapes which, by due process of nature and under the supervision of the technicians, will produce this year's vintage of that state's wines.

Melvyn Douglas, usually the suave, charming gentleman of drawing-room comedies, undertakes a dramatic leading role tonight in "Inherit the Wind" at the National Theatre. He succeeds Paul Muni, who was compelled to withdraw from the cast several weeks ago because of a serious eye ailment.

It is customary to refer to the United States as a "young" country, and to our continent as the "new" world. But often overlooked is the fact that our Government, as governments go, is a very old one; and our Constitution, as a written instrument establishing the framework of our Government, is actually the oldest now in force.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in August averaged 35,861 bales a working day.

David Bronstein of Russia, leading the field of twenty-one in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, drew his nineteenth-round game in fifteen moves with Carlos E. Guimard of Argentina, according to a report received through Swedish sources.

Nobody was very much surprised by the terms of this week's wage settlement between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. But the method by which they reached agreement -- and the reasons for it -- are less well understood.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP) -- A special week-end hurricane alert was ordered by the Weather Bureau today for four southeastern states as the ninth tropical storm of the season, Hurricane Ione, swung into a potentially dangerous position.

The Greater New York Association, Inc., made application to the State Racing Commission yesterday for approval of its plan to purchase the Belmont Park, Jamaica, Aqueduct and Saratoga tracks for an over-all price of $32,616,750.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 (UP) -- Willie Hartack, who leads the nation's jockeys in victories this season, rode five winners today -- including four in a row -- to lift his total of 1955 triumphs to 302.

BARTER ISLAND, Alaska, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Unloading operations for the Navy ships that dot the northern rim of the continent in this area continued at full speed today, thanks to a lesson learned from the Eskimos.
The new Citizens Waterfront Committee went into action yesterday in the initial phase of its plan to seek order in the turbulent waterfront situation.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Elizabeth Bosley of Unionville, Pa., rode The Clown to the green jumper championship in the fiftieth Piping Rock Horse Show today. The Clown won with 13 points.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Allocation of 3,819,621 cubic centimeters of Salk vaccine was announced today by the Public Health Service.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- The first Japanese film to be made in its entirety in a Hollywood studio and on California locations finished shooting today at the Samuel Goldwyn studio. The company of eleven Japanese actors and technicians, which had worked side-by-side with Hollywood crews and performers for the last twenty days, will leave by plane Monday for Tokyo.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 16 -- Three South Korean Cabinet Ministers resigned today under pressure from anti-Administration members of the National Assembly.
FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 16 (UP) -- Four witnesses testified today that Maj. Roland E. Alley had advised other American prisoners of war in Korea to give certain information to their Communist captors.
The police broke up tonight what they described as a scheduled gang fight in which one group of youths planned to throw flaming gasoline bombs on other teen-agers.

ATHENS, Sept. 16 -- The Greco- Turkish quarrel is far more serious than the United States apparently realizes. A little cold war -- with hot edges -- is being fought right inside NATO. The steady growth of friendship between Greeks and Turks has been terribly set back.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 16 -- The three Socialist parties announced today agreement on a program for Premier-designate David Ben-Gurion's next government. They also agreed to continue their efforts to broaden the coalition through the inclusion of non-Socialist and religious parties.

Shareholders of the Detroit Steel Corporation at a special meeting yesterday in Detroit approved a plan for refinancing the company's first mortgage note to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Under the plan Detroit Steel will sell $30,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and issue $6,000,000 of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Today's report Of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission cleared the way today for resumption of hearings involving importation of Canadian natural gas. It dismissed portions of four El Paso National Gas Company proposals which other companies said they would not accept.

Three books about post-war Germany are scheduled for publication in the next four weeks. The first to appear will be "Mainsprings of the German Revival," by Henry C. Wallich, Professor of Economics at Yale University. It will be issued by the Yale University Press on Wednesday.

Production of newsprint last month reached a new monthly high while consumption by newspapers set a record for August. This was announced yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau and the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

ATHENS, Sept. 10 -- General Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, has ordered Admiral William M. Fechteler, Commander in Chief of the Allied forces in Southern Europe, to proceed to Turkey. He is scheduled to be in Izmir (Smyrna) on Monday, probably stopping here on his way.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- A day of complete idleness and rest made up the program for Rocky Marciano today. The heavyweight champion didn't even go near the gymnasium. He contented himself instead with sitting, sleeping and eating in his little cottage that is located three miles away from the bustle of "town."
GEORGETOWN, Colo., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Foul air stalled the efforts today of searchers trying to rescue two Kansas men who vanished into an old, jinxed mine high in the Rockies while hunting uranium.
ROME, Sept. 16 -- On the eve of a journey to Moscow and Peiping, Pietro Nenni, Italy's leading fellow traveler, conferred today with President Giovanni Gronchi and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The largest French producer of motor cars, the nationalized Renault company, has countered the strike wave by an agreement described here as applying United States methods in industrial relations.

The stock of the Pittsburgh Metallurgical Company, Inc., was admitted to trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The company is a large producer of alloying materials for stainless, electrical and other steels.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 16 -- Harold E. Stassen said today that the odds favored eventual Soviet acceptance of President Eisenhower's plan for an exchange of military blueprints by the United States and the Soviet Union.

The eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 1061-65 Lexington Avenue, between East Seventy-fifth and Seventy-sixth Streets, has been sold by Henry Goelet, realty investor and builder. The deal was negotiated by E. G. Fanslow and Paul Hayman, brokers.

Bernard L. Hegeman has been nominated to serve for a second year as president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board. The board will hold its annual golf tournament and dinner on Thursday, Sept. 29, at the Rockville Country Club in Rockville Centre, L. I.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16 -- Rebel Army and Navy forces plunged Argentina into civil warfare today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Pentagon, making ready for the arrival of new reservists, reported today that more money was needed for building additional training facilities.
PIERMONT, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Dr. Price Adams Kirkpatrick, New York City psychiatrist, was found guilty early today of petit larceny in a burglary committed here last Memorial Day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Commerce Department made today a preliminary estimate of $157,000,000 as the amount of industrial damage in last months's floods.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Ann Harding, former motion-picture star, will emerge from semi-retirement to play a leading role in "Tryout," an original story by Robert Wallsten, on the General Electric Theatre show Oct. 2.

In the near future, a would-be investor won't have to look far to find the names of a New York Stock Exchange member firm in his community. In fact, he'll only have to look in the classified pages of the local telephone directory under "N. Y. Stock Exchange, Members of."
The nation's new six-month training program, authorized by the recently approved Reserve Forces Act, will start about Oct. 1.
The American Society of Newspaper Editors, The New York Herald Tribune and The Daily News joined yesterday in demanding access to official records of criminal trials.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- Injection of a small amount of tuberculin in an infected person with reveal tuberculosis with "uncanny accuracy" even before signs are evident through chest X-rays.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 16 -- Paul Prebisch, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, expressed satisfaction over the results of the commission's sixth session, which concluded here today. Three weeks of discussion were devoted to the principal economic problems of the region.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- An appeal was sounded here today for support by all information media of the efforts of the American Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 16 -- In Budapest, where this correspondent was a visitor earlier this week, people speak of life on two levels.

CAIRO, Sept. 16 -- Jewish worshipers gathered tonight in Cairo's twenty-three synagogues for Rosh ha-Shanah celebrations. They began the services with the old Sephardic refrain, "May the year end with its maledictions and the new year begin with its benedictions."

The Investment Bankers Association is asking its 806 members what they think of the proposal to expand the underwriting power of commercial banks into the field of local government bonds not secured by the taxing power.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16 -- The revolutionary command apparently was in firm control tonight of strategic Cordoba Province.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Production gains at Ford and Chrysler, both in 1956 model production, boosted this week's car assemblies to an indicated 122,646 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Truck assemblies also moved up slightly to 18,598.

The market of new issues of corporate and local government securities is continuing at a brisk pace. The corporate backlog was diminished slightly this week by the successful marketing of $150,000,000 of debt securities of the C. I. T.

Two Russian-made documentaries will open today at the Stanley Theatre. "Indian Artists,'' running forty minutes, describes a Soviet cultural exchange tour by a delegation of dancers, singers and entertainers from India. The eighty-minute "Russian Holiday," in color, covers last year's mammoth athletic display in Moscow by delegates from the sixteen Soviet republics.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The grain market developed reactionary trends today, reflecting yesterday's profit taking by longs. A late rally raised wheat prices above yesterday's close, but failed to wipe out losses in corn and soybeans. Some commission absorption Was indicated on the setbacks, but buyers were not inclined to follow upturns.

Mayor Wagner's recent refusal to reappoint Hubert T. Delany to the Domestic Relations Court drew rebukes from two sources yesterday. It was charged that Mr. Wagner had bowed to "political considerations" and had ignored the principles of fair play and justice.

Your education editor, Benjamin Fine, stated on Sept. 11 that, though the National Merit Scholarship Corporation is a great step forward in making a college education available to the intellectually gifts youth of our nation, more help still needed.

The obvious question that one asks one's self on hearing of still another rebellion in Argentina is, How long can any country stand such a period of unrest? Exactly three months had passed yesterday morning from the day of the sanguinary naval uprising of June 16 and in between the story was one of constant ferment.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- Premier Otto Grotewohl and a planeload of other top East German officials landed at the Central Airdrome today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) --The Defense Department has warned defense industries to "exercise considerable caution" in making public economic and technical information even though it bears no secrecy label.
New nonprofit cooperative housing developments for 2,750 middle-income families are being undertaken by members of the United Housing Foundation at a cost of $30,000,000.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 16 -- Two Argentine destroyers were attacked by pro-Peron planes this morning. The ships arrived here tonight with five men dead and thirty-two wounded.

Wasatch Corporation, a subsidiary of Atlas Corporation, reported yesterday that since June 30 it has disposed of almost all its remaining holdings of Italian securities. Wasatch, formerly the Italian Superpower Corporation, said that almost all lira proceeds from the liquidation also have been sold.

The one-story building at 46-07 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Union News Company, a subsidiary of the American News Company. The premises will be used for the servicing and distribution of vending machines. Queens Industrials was the broker in the lease of the property, which is owned by Thomas F. Mulligan Sons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Air Force has ordered a review of its publicized "torture" school in Nevada to see if changes are needed to make it conform with the new prisoner-of-war code for Americans, it was announced today.
Business will show a moderate decline late this year or early next, according to Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration.
I entirely agree with your recent editorial about having all traffic stop at the same time to protect pedestrians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A word-writing typewriter with a vocabulary of forty-two words and phrases was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, New York.

The Federal Government was charged yesterday with breaking its Constitutional contract and "shamefully" violating personal rights by "socializing" the lives and property of the people instead of protecting them.
TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- Numerous campaigns against the expansion of United States military bases in Japan were coordinated on a national basis today.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 16 -- Harvie Ward, the 1952 British amateur golf champion, today gained the final of the United States amateur championship for the first time.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer indicated today that the reality of the Soviet Union as a world power was in part responsible for his decision to establish diplomatic relations with it.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Frankie Ryff, boxing's "rookie of the year" in 1954, cleverly protected a gash over his left eye and gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Joey Lopes of Sacramento, Calif., tonight in a nationally televised bout from Olympia Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Col. John K. Arnold Jr., one of the eleven United States airmen freed last month by Communist China, called on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today with a message of thanks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Government reported today that the world consumption of natural and synthetic rubber from January through July was nearly 250,000 tons, more than in the first seven months of 1954.
Christian Education Week, which begins Sunday, Sept. 25, will be observed in most Protestant churches throughout the country.
ROME, Sept. 16 -- Premier Antonio Segni told the Cabinet this morning that a Government-controlled company has struck oil in the Abruzzi region east. of Rome.

SMALL sausages being broiled outdoors over charcoal spice the air these nights along Mulberry Street. For the Feast of San Gennaro is now being celebrated in Little Italy -- and a feast it is. Pushcarts and stands, packed close to each other along the curbs, offer all sorts of exotic things to eat.
Channel 7 and other outlets of the American Broadcasting Company network will present the first in a new series of outstanding British movies tomorrow night from 7:30 to 9 P. M.
The Yankees had first place within their grasp at the Stadium last night. They let it slip away for a few agonizing moments, then they made one more grab for it. This time they made it.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Sept. 13 -- Friction is mounting between New Mexico's Roman Catholics and Protestants over the use of public funds to transport pupils to parochial and other private schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The stricter grain sanitation program, which was held up May 1, 1953, for further study, will be resumed in full next year, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Ezra Taft Benson denounced the "prophets of gloom and doom" today for their efforts to make political capital out of the decline in farm income.

Representative Henry J. Latham was reported yesterday to be a probable Republican choice for State Supreme Court Justice in the Tenth Judicial District. His nomination could add a Congressional battle to this year's off-year election in Queens.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 -Stockholders of Atlantic City Electric Company approved a 3-for-2 split of common stock today at a special meeting of stockholders. The shareholders also authorized an increase to 4,000,000 in the umber of common shares.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 16 -- Senator Edward P. Larkin of West Hempstead resigned from the Legislature today. He is slated to be nominated Monday as the Republican candidate for Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead.

LONDON, Sept. 16--Prices declined in nearly every section of the stock market here today. Demandfor British Government securities, fairly strong all. week, fell away and losses of around five shillings (70 cents)were common.
CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The recent East coast dock strike was denounced today as arrogant, anarchistic and a strike against Government.
A man who is not getting enough to eat tends to grow lazy and disagreeable. In these conditions a diet of candy bars is no worse than any other, Dr. Francisco Grande said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Brig. Gen. Dalmiro Felix Videla Balaguer, described in reports from Buenos Aires as leader of the uprising in Argentina, is known in Washington as a stanch Army career officer with strong Nationalist convictions.

YOUNG members of the family may be called upon soon to share notepads and pencils with parents headed for classrooms. Or, on the other hand, they may be encouraged to accompany their mothers or fathers to classrooms at which special parent-child activities will be conducted.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- The French Government called the Resident General in Morocco, Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour, to Paris today. It sought to break a deadlock that has threatened the entire plan to end the Moroccan crisis.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Sept. 17 -- Lawrence Robert Buol of Stockton, Calif., a Nationalist China Civil Airlines pilot imprisoned by the Communists since Jan. 15, 1950, crossed the Red China border into Hong Kong territory this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that a bantamweight atomic bomber capable of flying at more than 630 miles an hour had made its first landing on an aircraft carrier.
HARTFORD, Sept. 17 -- A new law giving Connecticut legislators free privileges on toll highways and bridges may be repealed before it becomes effective.
Production of television receivers this year may shatter all previous records, according to one forecast.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -- A study course for persons interested in community planning will be opened Thursday by the Westchester Planning Department and municipal officials of the county.

ONE of the great scenic sites of the Midsouth, unknown to most tourists because of its relative inaccessibility, is an area on the Virginia-Kentucky border where the Sandy River cuts through a rugged gorge of the Cumberland Mountains 2,000 feet deep.
Taxpayers subject to withholding tax should take care that their exemption records are current, the Internal Revenue Service cautioned yesterday.

Biochemists believe that nucleic acids are the rock bottom of life. Without the acid (a combination of oxygen, hydrogen, carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus) self-reproduction, as in bacteria and other cells, is impossible. Living things are composed of proteins, and all proteins are derived from other proteins -- their fathers and mothers. In addition to fathers and mothers, protein molecules need a midwife to be born. The midwife is nucleic acid.

PARENT educators today stress time and again that parents tend to bring up their children as they themselves were reared. Often a young mother detecting what she feels to be a flaw in her own methods will trace its sources back to her childhood and complain, sometimes even with bitterness, "If only my mother had done differently. * * *"

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -- The last of California's major forest fires in the most disastrous season the state has experienced since 1924 was controlled today. State and Federal officials and corporate timber owners began figuring the losses, which will run to many millions of dollars.
The immediate causes of Friday's uprising in Argentina remain obscure. President Peron's Government has been plagued increasingly during the last year, however, by economic and political troubles.
MANKATO, Minn., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen said today the United States must stay strong as it sought a disarmament system guaranteed by inspection.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 17 -- The question of whether to raise or lower toll rates for Panama Canal transit -- or leave them alone -- is expected to be contested actively after Congress reconvenes next January.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- The operation of the Gideon Putnam Hotel on the Saratoga Springs reservation is official again, but the problems of the swank summer resort are still a long way from solution.

Amid the reports from riot-stricken and politically troubled Morocco these last few weeks is one story that stands out in sharp contrast. Issued by the World Health Organization, it, too, is the story of a fight -- a fight in South Morocco by seventeen medical commando teams against blindness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- One of the hottest issues to be considered by the American Legion when it meets in annual convention in Miami Oct. 10-13 is expected to be the so-called "Murphy Report" on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 17 -- Representatives of 1,200 libraries from non-Communist and Communist countries unanimously adopted a recommendation here today. It was "that endeavors by all means -- governmental and nongovernmental -- be made toward a strengthened basis for the wider exchange of professional experience and personnel and publications" among librarians' organizations throughout the world.

Kent Cooper, former executive director of The Associated Press, has released for publication early next year a book on censorship called "The Right to Know." Written five years ago, it has been completely revised and brought up to date. The publishers are Farrar, Straus Cudahy.
Three hundred sixty citizens who sought last week to have the Internal Security Act declared unconstitutional were charged yesterday with a "whitewash" of the Communist party.

BRITISH animal collector Gerald M. Durrell and his partner went to British Guiana recently to collect specimens for zoological gardens. Faced with the problem of where to start, they quite sensibly got a large map, found a local man who knew the country, and adjourned to a quiet bar to work out the crucial decision.

MANY students of government believe that the weakest feature in the whole American political system is its failure to provide any assured position of respectability and responsibility for the leader of the opposition party. It is not so in parliamentary democracies elsewhere in the free world, where the acknowledged leader of the opposition usually continues to serve in the Legislature even after he has failed to become or remain Prime Minister.
COLUMBIA, MO., Sept. 17 -- Maryland struck for two early touchdowns by Halfbacks Ed Vereb and Bill Walker then held off a determined Missouri second-half rally for a 13-12 football triumph today.

Recently while rereading William Lyon Phelps' autobiography I came across an interesting sidelight on the Shakespeare-Marlowe discussion. In Chapter 41 under the heading of "1903," Mr. Phelps writes of hearing Edward H. Sothern give a performance of Hamlet and of lunching with the actor the next day in his New York home.

THE story of Alfred E. Smith appears to be headed toward the movies. Last week, it was learned that Demby Productions, Inc., local producers of live and filmed television programs, had acquired film rights to a biography of the former Governor of New York and 1928 Democratic Presidential candidate.
The Yankees will have to carry on their fight for the American League pennant without further help from Mickey Mantle, their distance-clouting center fielder.

The brightest color in the woods these next few weeks will not be on the leaf of a tree or a shrub, but on a vine. On that cousin of the fox grape which the botanists know as Psedera qinquefolia and which is sometimes known as woodbine and sometimes as Virginia creeper.
SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass, Sept. 17 -- Flood scars along the banks of streams and rivers in this south central region of Massachusetts await the healing that time will bring.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Harvard University plans to enroll 10,500 students next week, 1,125 of them as freshmen.

PIERRE DANINOS is a writer of casual pieces for the Paris newspaper Le Figaro. French lovers of light literature cherish him; he has invented several lively characters who sparkle in his columns. The most famous of them, Maj. W. Marmaduke Thompson -- already beloved on both sides of the Channel -- is now destined for trans-Atlantic popularity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Miss Pepsi, a three-time winner of the event, took the deal in the President's Cup speed-boat regatta today. The Dossin Brothers' entry from Detroit scored 800 points by winning the two heats in which she competed.
Morris Ketay is one of those men who is always being carried away.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept 17 (AP) -- Louisiana State University, playing under a new coach, outscored mighty Kentucky, 19--7, tonight in the season's football opener for both teams.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A fellowship program for staff psychiatrists in public mental hospitals and schools for the retarded was announced today. Its goal was to arm psychiatrists with new knowledge of therapies and techniques for application where most needed in this country.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Representatives from the United States and Western Europe should meet to discuss the serious problem of flag discrimination existing in the world, a prominent Norwegian shipping representative said in concluding a sharp attack on American flag discrimination.
FRANK SINATRA, who has upset the skeptics by excellent performances in dramatic roles in motion pictures, will be facing a new challenge tomorrow night.
" Citizenship Quiz" by Alma Denny (Sept. 11) asks on Page 40: "The President can be impeached. How many have been?" and answers on Page 42. "None."

THE value of shade trees on home properties has been well established. But when a home owner chooses a tree indiscriminately he is gambling with more than his financial investment. For if the tree is unsuited to its location, the gardener usually does not become fully aware of his dissatisfaction until the tree has reached sizable dimensions.

RILEY, as readers of "Back-Seat Driver" will remember, was a pretty accomplished dog in the way of small and big talk (which his master alone understood) and in rumpus-raising, even before he bullied the doctor into taking a vacation.

EACH new novel by Robert Mirvish about life and love in the merchant marine shows some improvement, in grasp of character and in command of language. And his productivity must be admired. But he does continue to have weaknesses stemming from too great a preoccupation with actuality.

The next few days ought to reveal whether the "spirit of Geneva," which recently has taken quite a battering, can be transferred to the United Nations. The General Assembly is starting its 1955 session on Tuesday, and the speeches by Mr. Molotov and his supporters may reveal at last whether there is anything behind the Russian smiles.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 -- Construction of a two-mile expressway link, a subject of controversy for twenty years, may start soon. It would end one of the worst traffic bottlenecks in St. Louis County.
ROME, Sept. 17 -- Giuseppe Sotgiu, a lawyer and leading Communist, has beeen acquitted of charges of immoral practices. An investigating magistrate dismissed the charges "for lack of proof."
WERNER EGK's new opera, "The Irish Legend," this summer's principal novelty of the Salzburg Festival, was handicapped at the outset by its patently primary pupose of conveying moral enlightenment.
ROME, Sept. 17 -- The Vatican believes that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty is still detained.
DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 17 -- Dallas County property owners face a new tax of 48 cents on each $100 valuation this fall to support a new city county hospital district.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- The International Harvester Company and the United Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., reached an agreement today to settle a twenty-six-day strike of 40,000 workers that closed eighteen company plants.

UNOFFICIALLY the broad-leaved evergreens comprise that group of plants belonging to the heath family. It includes rhododendron, azalea, mountain laurel, pieris, blueberry, enkianthus, oxydendron and a number of others, not all of them evergreen everywhere.

A SERIES of violent rainstorms in the closing days helped to dampen the political fireworks that characterized the sixteenth Venice Film Festival. These fireworks resulted in the forced withdrawal from competition of such films as Czechosolvakia's "Jan Hus" (anti-Catholic), Spain's "El Canto del Gallo" (anti-totalitarian) and the United States' "Blackboard Jungle" (anti-American).
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Princess Margrethe, 15-year-old heir apparent to the Danish throne, left with her parents for Britain today. She will spend a year in a boarding school.

TO my mind the most enchanting of all Stendhal's non-fiction is THE LIFE OF HENRI BRULARD, now available in the Vintage series for 95 cents. Stendhal is, of course, the most famous of the hundred or more pseudonyms that Henri Beyle put on and took off like a shoe; I believe Brulard is the second most famous of his shoes.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 -- An extraordinary drama has begun. The German people once again seem to be ready to accept a fantastic political and diplomatic defeat as a virtue born out of necessity.

A month has passed since floods spawned by Hurricane Diane crippled the Northeast. But in river-wrecked communities of Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts, the people are still digging out.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has been using his "quiet diplomacy" technique to try to resolve the difficulties of Iran's Bahai community.

DAHLIAS will be in the limelight in New York on Tuesday and Wednesday when the American Dahlia Society stages its annual exhibition in cooperation with the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc. The show will be held at Essex House, 160 Central Park South, and doors will be open from 4 to 10 P. M. on Tuesday and from 10 A. M. to 9 P. M. on Wednesday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 11 -- Recent indications of continued oil imports by the United States have given a new lift to Venezuela's booming economy and apparently contributed much to internal political peace.

MOST of Miss Erdman's novels feature heroines who start as inexperienced softies but soon display unusual courage and endurance. To this author, the real pioneer of the Texas Plains was the woman -- the hardy, patient mother whose life was more trying and lonely than that of her man.
Plans have been completed for the annual card party and fashion show for the benefit of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, the Bronx. The event will take place on Sept. 27 at the Pierre.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL was at his desk in the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday, shuffling line-up cards with the dexterity of a Las Vegas gambler trying to deal himself a winning hand. The injuries to Mickey Mantle and Bill Skowron had left the cagy old bloke without a couple of aces.
The code name was "Mayfair." It was chosen by the Philip Morris producers, who owned the word as a brand name, in testing for a mystery cigarette.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz has given up his quest for a place on the State Supreme Court.

The renewed growth of lawns in September is a sure indication that grass is a cool weather plant and does its best under autumn conditions. At the same time, the revival of lawns from a practically brown state to a lush green is another proof of the vitality of permanent grasses.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 (UP) -- The U. A. W. today warned rebellious striking skilled workers who are dissatisfied with two new contracts with Chrysler Corporation to return to work.
WASHINGTON Sept. 17 -- The cold war seems to have halted, but something of the effect remains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Senate action early next year on farm prices, now developing as the sharpest political issue of 1956, was forecast today by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas. Mr. Johnson, the chamber's Democratic leader, listed revision of the Administration's price support law among the major items of unfinished business to be tackled at the start of the session opening Jan. 3.

AN attachment snaps on and off any thumb-operated spray container in a moment, and turns the container into a spray gun. The device keeps hands away from the spray nozzle, and the lever action combined with a pistol grip makes longer spraying jobs less tiresome.
LAVALLETTE, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Three persons drowned in the ocean near here and two narrowly escaped this afternoon. All five had gone to the rescue of an 8-year-old girl and her mother.

IN summing up Erich Fromm's argument in his book "The Sane Society," your reviewer Joseph Wood Krutch writes, "Contemporary capitalistic society denies its citizens an opportunity to love while leaving them political liberty and showering them with material benefits, because it denies them both a genuine sense of belonging and a genuine sense of individuality.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- broken brake lever caused a cable car accident in which twenty persons were hurt, none seriously, yesterday-afternoon.

A new $2,200,000 library on the campus of Seton Hall University, South Orange, N. J., was ready this past week when classes resumed for the fall semester. Designed by the Rev. Charles Murphy, librarian, and J. Gerald Phelan, Bridgeport architect, it is one of the most modern in the country.
The appointment of Irving S. Schneider as national director of the combined campaign for American Reform Judaism was announced yesterday.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz proposed new legislation yesterday to clarify the right of the press to access to official records of judicial proceedings.

In a recent Rialto Gossip column, something was printed that a great many of us here in Yellow Springs feel should not go by without some comment. The note said that Maurice Evans "is reported to have a hankering to do Iago provided he could locate a satisfactory Othello."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, will make a nationwide radio speech Tuesday night in time provided by the American Broadcasting Company to compensate for a Labor Day broadcast made by former President Harry S. Truman. He will speak at 7:30 P. M.
ROME, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII has upheld motorscooters as a means of making life easier, even if some persons think they are noisy.

EGYPT, one gathers in Israel, is a land of shocking contrasts between the rich few and the multitudinous poor, and the assumption is made that such a condition makes any Cairo regime intrinsically unstable. The present military leaders are appraised as honest, patriotic and idealistic, but often misguided. Their efforts to better the fellahin's lot are reported in Israel to be producing small results. Consequently, it is thought the poor are dissatisfied.

THE new home owner is often bewildered by the number of different shrubs he can choose for his landscape. Too often he starts and stops with the common ones like forsythia and lilac, which are, incidentally, lovely, but there are many other interesting kinds that can add character and charm to the property.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Unbeaten Blackpool downed the Wolverhampton Wanderers by 2 -- 1 today to stay in first place in English soccer.

FOR many years before coming to this country, I had been conditioned to the manners of tipping here as demonstrated in American movies -- the ubiquitous page boy, the expectant look, the extended palm.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 -- Leading industrialists here plan to ask Tokyo and Washington to agree on an expanded arms production program aimed at making Japan the arsenal of free nations in the Western Pacific.
Rocky Marciano, the heavyweight champion of the world, will risk his title against Archie Moore at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.
WARSAW, Sept. 17 -- Fewer than 100 Jews assembled today in Warsaw's only synagogue to pray on Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.

A former local administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency warmly seconded yesterday charges by Robert Moses that the Federal Government was guilty Of "outrageous" delays in handling New York slum-clearance projects.
