IT was with great pleasure that I read your article of Sept. 4, in which you describe the efforts of a violinist friend to finance a foundation whose purpose would be the commissioning of symphonic works for instruments other than strings.

AT this juncture it appears that "Marjorie Morning-star," a new novel by Herman Wouk (rimes with artichoke, which is defined as a thistle-like plant with an edible flower-head), is the thing. "Have you read it?" -- one hears the question in corridors, drawing rooms and up and down chimneys.

THE scholarly and brilliant "Cities in Revolt" by Carl Bridenbaugh should go far to right a persistent over-emphasis in the dominant attitude toward the American past. The myth rolls on that our society has been so exclusively characterized by a frontier, or at least a rural, lack of sophistication that, when sophistication existed, it was not the result of any indigenous development, but in each generation an import from abroad.
HONG KONG, Sept. 17 -- The American whom the Chinese Communists had held prisoner longer than any other walked to freedom today with a smile that would not rub off.

CORNING, Iowa, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Former Gov. Dan Turner called today for the resignation of Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture. Mr. Turner, 78 years old and a life-long Republican, was Governor from 1931 to 1933.

The chairmen of the various committees for the Kips Bay Boys Club theatre benefit will be guests at a tea to be given on Tuesday by Mrs. Colley E. Williams in her home at 885 Park Avenue. Mrs. Williams is chairman of the women's board of the club.

BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 17 -- A peculiar but potentially powerful threat to the free movement of the world's commerce and warships was officially removed this week from where it stood poised above a Panama Canal channel.

Three years ago engineers told Ohio state officials that a concrete expressway could be laid across the state for $318,176,000 -- including a liberal fund for contingencies -- and that the job could be finished in less than forty months.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 -- Blue Choir, Irish-bred 4-year-old colt owned by Mrs. H. L. Nathenson, won the $50,000 Foreign-Bred Stakes today.

THIS umpteenth anthology of Groff Conklin's is emphatically one of his best bargains. For a mere thirty-five cents Mr. Conklin's customer will receive over 125,000 words of science fantasy that is, largely, very readable stuff indeed.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 10 -- Freedom of education has been written into the new Constitution, but for the first time in eighty years the teaching of religion has been allowed in public schools.
THE big production push at Hollywood television film studios now is under way and will continue at its present brisk pace to midspring at least.
A large subscription has been reported for the world premiere of the motion picture "Oklahoma!" to be held on Oct. 12 at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the Vocational Advisory Service.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 17 -- Defense counsel disclosed today that they would press for the trial of both the murder and kidnapping indictments returned against two white men in the death of a 14-year-old Chicago Negro.

MIAMI BEACH -- The clank of pick and shovel is replacing the happy cries of sunburned tourists all along the shoreline here as the summer season wanes into the long period of preparation for the winter season.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- Great Lakes freighters hauled 95,728,642 net tons of ore, coal and grain up to the first of this month, representing an increase of 17,891,361 tons over the year-ago total, according to statistics compiled by the Lake Carriers' Association.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Investments in new plants, additions and purchases of land or buildings in the Chicago area during the first eight months this year totaled $246, 598,000, a gain of 51 per cent over the $163,352,000 reported in the same period last year, the Association of Commerce and Industry announced.
Rabbis in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons yesterday morning looked at the world situation and found it hopeful.
The development of an extra-long staple cotton in Arizona may make the United States independent of foreign sources for that type of fiber.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Government representatives throughout Southeast Asia are keeping a sharp and hopeful eye on the activities of Harry Miller Jr., an American technician for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
Barnard College will welcome the largest freshman class in its history at the annual freshman orientation program, which begins tomorrow.

BY worldly standards Victor Rossiter was a successful physician, with a practice among rich neurotics in the Washington area, a beautiful wife and a stepson that he loved -- in short, everything his father had not been.

MANILA, Sunday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Manila Chronicle reported today general of the Army Douglas MacArthur had sold out his holdings in Consolidated Mines, Inc., yesterday in the heaviest trading ever recorded by the Manila Stock Exchange.

ATLANTA, Sept. 17 -- Retail stores in the Atlanta metropolitan area experienced a near-record advance in sales in the first seven months of 1955 compared with last year, according to the Atlanta field office of the United States Department of Commerce.

Getting the world's greatest port back into business after a waterfront strike takes skillful management and hard work. New York's maritime industry demonstrated last week that it had not lost these qualities. It turned to chip away at the mountain of freight piled up during the eight-day tie-up that ended Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Doug Ford of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., and Bud Holscher, 24-year-old star from Apple Valley, Calif., took the lead in the $20,000 Daily News golf tournament at Cobbs Creek today.

ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 17 (UP) -- A top Defense Department official said tonight the United States military strength had grown "immensely" under the Eisenhower Administration while military manpower and spending had been slashed.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Britain, which is combating a separatist movement in Cyprus, will examine sympathetically next week the demands of Malta, another Mediterranean colony. Malta wants closer, not looser, links with the British Crown.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- The Massachusetts General Court ended its long session this week with a new record for spending and with an eye to the 1956 election.

A SCALE-MODEL ground display is reported to have caused a bigger ripple than supersonic planes at this year's Farnborough Show outside London. The British Government's jet-engine research establishment showed an intriguing design for a new lift system that is a radical approach to the problem of getting huge, fast airplanes on and off the ground without requiring thousands of feet of expensive runway.
The flight surgeon who doubles as a human bullet said last week that the automobile industry is deriving safety aids from Air Force research in high speed land travel.

ACCORDING to Menke's "Encyclopedia of Sports" the story of baseball's beginning "has been -- perhaps always will be -- shrouded in impenetrable mists." The game was most likely the result of an evolutionary process with important contributions by men like Alexander Cartwright, Henry Chadwick -- and possibly Abner Doubleday.

THERE are few experiences more disheartening to a gardener than waking up on an early autumn morning to find frost shimmering on tender flowers and vegetables. Anyone who has known that experience has wished that the chill blight could be stayed another week or two, particularly since the return of warm nights may be expected before cold weather really arrives.

THE wagon train which snaked into Pennsylvania's Conococheague Valley in 1765 loaded with weapons for the Indians brought a hot, angry response from the frontier farmers. Disguised as Indians and under the leadership of James Smith, they burned the wagons.

HARTFORD, Sept. 17 -- A special State Flood Disaster Recovery Committee has tentatively agreed on recommendations to be submitted to the General Assembly. An emergency Assembly session is expected to be called early in October.

The Christmas line of David D. Doniger Company, producer of McGregor sportswear, will stress a change from dark to light colors. The line, shown after a two-day sales meeting at the company's plant in Dover, N. J., last week also features styles inspired by the Far East.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Fullback Bob Grief and a third-string halfback, Dick Bowen, and a blazing sun took the steam out of California today as Pitt stormed from behind for a 27-7 victory over the Bears. The Panthers scored three touchdowns in the final period.

EVERY year at this time comes the expected announcement -- the dates for the opening of the annual Audio Fair. And every year the announcement proudly states that the Fair will be bigger and better. The announcement up to now has always turned out to be true.

IS there not something ironic in Lincoln Kirstein's view of the American Shakespeare Festival's future task, as reported in a recent Times? He takes, says The Times report, the "long view," holding that it will be at least five years before the "dream" will be realized, and compares it to the creation of England's Stratford.
STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 17 -- Goldenrod blooms along the winding roads of the Poconos and fall has touched the leaves.

THERE is an essential logic to this book, despite a mass of detail and a sort of geographical leap-frogging that may puzzle a reader not familiar with Mexico. It may be put this way: Erna Fergusson studs her text with references to various -ismos that are part of Mexican life.

Has anybody ever looked into the case of the Thundering Commercial? Why is it that the picture and the sound suddenly achieve a technical perfection years ahead of the rest of the show when the commercial begins?

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 17 -- A British Institute building in the center of Cyprus was set afire tonight as new anti-British riots broke out in support of demands for union of this strategic island with Greece.

WITH the increased popularity of house plants and particularly of large-foliaged and unusual specimens, most indoor gardeners acquire more pot plants than look well scattered about the house. And some plants have to stand in uncomfortable and culturally unsound quarters because of the lack of window space.

Alice Marble in her "A Love Letter to Baseball" (Aug. 28) speaks of' AJlie Reynolds dramatically "standing on ' the thresbo]d of pitch/ng his first no-hitter" in a game .between the New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox.

PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Pan American plane carrying Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and other members of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations General Assembly was forced to return to Orly Field late yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -- Gen. Carlos Ibanez del Campo, Chile's 79-year-old President, appears to be really in control of the political situation in the country for the first time since his election in 1953.

PARIS, Sunday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Top level Government talks broke up early this morning with French officials and Moroccan nationalists still unable to settle the one issue holding up settlement of the Moroccan crisis -- the composition of a regency council.

IN September, 1890, after more than two years' wandering in the South Seas, Fanny and Robert Louis Stevenson moved into temporary quarters on their newly bought Samoan plantation. Fanny signalized their settlement on their own land by starting a new journal, which she continued intermittently for the next three years. That journal, never seen by Stevenson's biographers, is now printed for the first time.

AGAINST the drab background of a small Canadian mining town Andre Langevin explores the lives of young Dr. Alain Dubois and his beautiful red-haired bride, Madeleine. Dr. Dubois, starting out to practice, tells the story in the first person.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- Economic chaos threatens the world unless Governments that have been getting more and more into foreign trade in farm products are willing to cooperate to greater extent than in the past.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Sept. 17 -- The 60,000-ton aircraft carrier Forrestal has been repaired, dock-tested, and is set to resume her interrupted sea trials on Monday, the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- The quality of Princeton's football material has deteriorated of recent years. Perhaps it would be more correct to say that the quality material has been running thinner.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Catcher Bill Shantz of the Kansas City Athletics caught a ball dropped from the twenty-third floor (340 feet high) of a downtown building today by Mayor H. Roe Bartle.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- The Moore Institute of Art, Science and Industry has completed plans for the erection of a seven-story modernistic school on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway opposite Logan Circle.
PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The Delaware River still runs a muddy course past this resort town in the foothills of the Catskills. Flood damage is estimated at about $1,000,000.

INDUSTRIAL output set a new high in August, a month in which activity generally declines. The Federal Reserve Board index for the month was 140, compared with 123 in August of 1954. This represented a gain of about 14 per cent.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 -- One major Louisiana sugar refinery settled a five-month strike this week but another important and larger refinery was deadlocked in a strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Along Publishers' Row these last few days were reviving memories of "Gone With the Wind" and its late author, Margaret Mitchell. The occasion was the implementation yesterday of the universal copyright convention in fifteen countries, including the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today conceded that it had blocked efforts of an internationally recognized American scientist to present his views at the world's first conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy.

MUSICIANS have been traveling from one place to another almost as long as there has been music. Because their art is not confined by the boundaries of language, they have had ready acceptance in lands other than their own.

THERE is nothing like a good dry spell after a good wet spell for getting at those small frailties that develop in houses. During the wet spell, doors, windows and drawers swell up and become an aggravation.

All pupils entering public high school this year will receive tuberculosis patch tests from school physicians. Similar tests will be given to new pupils in twenty - three Catholic high schools where the department's Bureau of School Health furnishes service.

PREPARING rusted or corroded metal surfaces for painting, especially those exposed to weather, is a long, tedious task, but it can be speeded by taking off scale and rust clumps with a wire brush attached to a quarter-inch electric drill.

CORDOBA, Argentina, Sept. 17 (UP) -- A battle is being fought foe this city in a river gorge about eighteen miles southwest of it. Intense cannon and machine-gun fire were heard all through the early morning. Later it died out.
One hundred and twenty-five men and women were invested in the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem by Cardinal Spellman yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MANILA, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Staff officers of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty organization ended a conference on Communist subversion in Asia today. They warned that united action was needed against the threat but apparently were divided on how to go about fighting it.

The recent and comprehensive report of The American Foundations Information Service on "American Foundations and Their Fields" documents many of the commonly accepted impressions about these organizations: the huge size of the biggest ones -- there are seven with assets over $100 millions; and their overwhelming interest in education and social welfare -- about two-thirds of those reporting show an interest in the one and one-third of them in the other.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- Two more dramatic moves on the international chessboard were made today by the Soviet Government.
WHEN the training program of the American Theatre Wing begins tomorrow on a campus scattered over the four corners of Manhattan it will mark the beginning of the tenth year of the project.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The next-to-last regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of the Long Island Sound season, conducted by the Huguenot Yacht Club, was distinguished on two counts today. Neither was good.

ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Eagle Day, supposedly shunted to the bench on pre-season performance, passed, punted and ran the Mississippi Rebels to a 26-13 victory over Georgia tonight in a Southeastern Conference football opener.

AMONG the many hundreds of garden clubs throughout the country, few approach their full potential as active forces for good in the community. No club should feel that it is some appendage to the community or that the era of progress has no place for those who know the value of plants and flowers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) Harry J. Anslinger, Federal Narcotics Commissioner, said today the four-year-old law providing stiff penalties for narcotic peddling had helped to cut such traffic "way, way down" in some areas. But he called for an even stiffer law. He wants a Federal law that is even stiffer.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- British film critics have found the American film "Blackboard Jungle" appalling.

Before this week is over, an all-time record number of nearly 40,000,000 young Americans will be attending the nation's schools and colleges. This is the eleventh consecutive year of increased total enrollment.

PERHAPS the best way to praise the second volume of Ernest Jones' biography of Freud is to say that it is as good as the first volume -- "Years of Maturity" is as dramatic and instructive a book as its predecessor, "The Formative Years and the Great Discoveries."
DENVER, Sept. 17 -- The White House issued today a summary of Federal financial assistance given to the flood-stricken areas of the Northeast.
PARIS, Sept. 17 -- Officials labored today without success to break up a five-day logjam that was threatening disaster for their effort to establish peace in Morocco.
The American Heart Association will hold its thirty-first annual meeting and twenty-eighth scientific session in New Orleans from Oct. 22 to 28.
United Nations disarmament talks were more or less becalmed last week, and the indications were that the discussions would mark time until some action was taken by the General Assembly.

MODERN America has been, among other things, the land of the stampeding neuroses. A large part of the nation became hysterical over "socialists" in the Eighteen Nineties, oven more joined in the anti-Bolshevik mania after World War I, and now we have lived through McCarthyism.

The Salk vaccine should prove considerably more effective against polio this year than it was in last year's mass field trial, said Basil O'Connor in a statement that accompanied the annual report of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, of which he is president.

RESPONSE to a recent column on Longfellow has been so warm that, abetted by a return visit to the city of his birth, I am emboldened to make a few additional remarks. People from as far distant as Holland have expressed satisfaction in the fact that room was found here for a few words in his behalf both as a poet and a scholar.

Some of the fundamental problems which higher education must face in the years ahead are presented by Dr. John A. Perkins, president of the University of Delaware, in the current issue of the "Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Miss E. R. Sears' bay gelding Diamant from Pride's Crossing, Mass., won the jumper championship and the Robert Winthrop Trophy as the fiftieth Piping Rock Horse Show concluded today. Diamant, who was ridden by Gabor Fultany, scored 15 points.

A large committee of prominent persons has been chosen to work for the success of the Belmont Futurity Ball to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 6. The event, a dinner dance, will benefit the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Avenue.

NEXT to spring, autumn is the gardener's most crowded season. In addition to essential chores like lawn renovation and the planting of spring bulbs, there are countless tasks around the house that cannot be neglected -- odd paint jobs, storm windows that must be mended and eaves or places in the roof that need patching.

BUFFALO, Sept. 17 -- John Francis Noto of Buffalo will be the first person to be tried in New York State under the membership clause of the Smith Act. Mr. Noto, described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a leading New York State Communist, is expected to go on trial in United States District Court in Rochester next month.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 17 -- While hand-laborers and modern mechanized equipment move across the snow-white fields of Mississippi under the hot September sun, a sordid murder case has focused the glare of national attention on the intricate system of race relations which the dominant white group enforces in the name of stability.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Refreshed by a two-week holiday on Duck Island in Lake Ontario, Secretary of State Dulles embarked today on a schedule that promised no rest until Christmas.
The familiar prospect of world series cash seems to do something to those Yankees and there was no faltering in the ranks yesterday.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 17 -- George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, warned today that any attempt to find freedom through avoiding social obligations resulted invariably in some new enslavement.
PARIS, Sept. 10 -- France seemed this week to be stumbling toward a new policy for the protectorate of Morocco which would resemble that adopted for the protectorate of Tunisia.
LAST week's presentation of Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" provided a good illustration of a growing artistic problem in television: the abuse of the close-up.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Two Socialist members of Parliament predicted today that unless the Government acted soon to curb inflation the trade unions would press new claims for wage increases.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Two throwing errors enabled the Chicago Cubs to score a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today, moving the Cubs to within one game of fifth place.

Throughout the cold war United States policy in Europe has pivoted on Germany. The ultimate objective of that policy was to force the Soviet Union to abandon its East German satellite, retreat behind its own borders, and agree to the restoration of a unified Germany free to align itself with the West.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The problem of landing on the moon is going to be harder than most space enthusiasts thought. The lunar atmosphere has been found to be a thousand times thinner than the values obtained previously by optical measurements, and it is probably getting thinner.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Sept. 17 (UP) -- The deadline for registering to vote in the November elections passed today without the registration of President and Mrs. Eisenhower.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, will deliver an address at a bicentennial dinner in memory of John Marshall, first Chief Justice, at Harvard on Saturday.

City College will officially open its new eighteen-and-one-half-acre South Campus with a brief tape-cutting ceremony at 11 A. M. tomorrow. The college's president, Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, will officiate at the ceremony at the South Campus Main Gate, Convent Avenue and 133d Street.

TRENTON -- The sovereign state of New Jersey has decided not to recognize the arrival and departure of Labor Day. By official directive of Gov. Robert B. Meyner the state's fifty-odd shore resorts have united with the state and the New Jersey Highway Authority which operates Garden State Parkway to keep summer and the summer-resort season going until the snow flies, or at least through October.

Television has been used at medical conventions in recent years to bring new techniques to the attention of scores of physicians and surgeons who would have seen nothing had they crowded around an operating table. To Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith, consultant radio engineer, this is only a promising beginning.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- A bipartisan attempt to borrow money for the state to build new and improved highways has touched off one of the hottest controversies in the many years that New York has been changing its much-amended Constitution.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 15 -- A new law to deal with political uprisings has been enacted in Southern Rhodesia.
Governor Harriman called last night on the United States for more help to peoples struggling against Communist slavery.

A royal Savonnerie carpet, made during the seventeenth century at the order of King Louis XIV of France, has been placed on exhibit in the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue nad Eighty-second Street.

MOAB, Utah -- Airplanes are giving a totally new dimension to sight-seeing in the vast, virtually trackless regions, so full of spectacular natural wonders and national monuments, in this desert-and-mountain state and south into Arizona, as well as east into Colorado and New Mexico.
MADRID, Sept. 8 -- After 250 years, Britain may finally get her hands on part of a treasure she tried to wrest from Spain in days when admirals were both watchdogs of empires and glorified pirates.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -- Those who have seen the Grand Canyon only from the ground have a treat in store for them. Viewed from a small plane, a thousand or so feet above the Rim, it is more magnificent than ever.
The first branch of the Brooklyn Public Library to be situated in a housing project will open its doors at noon tomorrow. The branch was set up in the Cypress Hills Houses, 465 Fountain Avenue.

News on the latest civil war in Argentina has been confusing. Some aspects of it are contradictory. There are signs of censorship and distortion. It may be some days before the whole story emerges. But already two facts are clear. Regardless of its outcome, this will have been the most sanguinary of all the revolts against Peron.

At the first turn the fun went out of the running of the $69,400 Beldame Handicap at the Aqueduct track yesterday. There were three spills, in rapid succession, three-sixteenths of a mile after the start of the race, and they resulted in injuries to two riders and one horse.

Four Democratic Senators sailed yesterday aboard the Navy troopship Upshur for a five-week four of United States military bases in Europe and North Africa. Also aboard the Upshur were 2,082 members of the Tenth Infantry Division from Fort Niley, Kan.
JOHORE BHARU, Malaya, Sept. 17 -- The Sultan of Johore warned today that the Communists would probably take over if the British left Malaya.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Dr. Sherwood Johnston of Greenwich, Conn., won the eighth annual Grand Prix sports car race today, whizzing over the twisting course in Jaguar D at an average speed of 81.92 miles and hour.

IF leading thinkers of the nineteenth century were dominated by the idea of a biological struggle for existence, those of the mid-twentieth century show an equal fascination for the "struggle for Existenz," which means, for man's authentic, personal being in this world.

THOUGH commonly referred to as wormwood or ghost plant, artemisia is a highlight in my garden. Not only is it a star in the border, it has a multitude of uses. It serves as a filler in floral arrangements or is ideal as a dried flower.

NO matter what the temperature reading may be today, autumn is in the air. This is as true on the West Coast, where leaves are starting to fall from the sycamore trees, as it is on the East Coast, where so far only a few scarlet leaves can be seen on an occasional red maple tree.
Last Tuesday in St. Louis the National League champion Dodgers played some Class D baseball and were spanked afterward by their manager.

SINCE the Sadler's Wells Ballet has a spate of novelties in the repertoire this year it is too early to begin making any inclusive estimates. On the strength of its opening performance of the full-length "Sleeping Beauty," however, it would be unthinkable to withhold a round of cheers.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 18 -- An amnesty was proclaimed here today for virtually all Soviet citizens who collaborated with the German forces during World War II.
PERFORMANCES this afternoon and evening will conclude the "Othello" at the City Center. On Wednesday evening the same company will present the first part of "Henry IV."
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 17 -- Hurricane Ione, the biggest and strongest tropical storm of the year, continued its relentless advance toward the Georgia and Carolinas coasts tonight.
The Wall Street area echoed yesterday not to the clatter of the market place but to the singing of juvenile voices.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17 -- With the rolling Virginia hills as a background, Harvie Ward today became the first Southern-born golfer to win the United States amateur championship since Bob Jones in 1930.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- Although an expected gain in manufacturing failed to materialize during the summer, employment in the Philadelphia area has continued upward. More than 1,628,000 persons, including agricultural and self-employed, were employed in this area in August, according to data compiled by the Pennsylvania State Employment Service.
The first two-way bulk carrier of major size is now being prepared in Japan for service around the world.
ONE of the stirring tales of our era is that of the building of the first land route to Alaska.

THE strides that have been made in the bulb industry are almost fantastic. A decade ago the assortment of spring-flowering bulbs was centered around traditional colors in the usual varieties. Whereas today's selection has mushroomed into vast colorful catalogues with all sorts of colors, varieties and types.
HONG KONG, Sunday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Three American Roman Catholic priests crossed Freedom Bridge today from prisons of Red China.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 17 -- Negro teachers are finding integration no barrier to employment in Phoenix public schools.

May I relate a sad theatrical story with a happy ending. Last month I bought tickets for "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," "Bus Stop" and "Damn Yankees" and promptly proceeded to lose them. However, a record had been kept of the seat numbers and the theatres were notified.

The oriental influence is making a heavy impact on the ready-to-wear market, with many Chinese, Japanese and Indian adaptations being shown, resident buying offices report. The sheath and sheath-type continue to sell strongly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- "An illegal payment" of more than $2,000,000 by the Government to a group of concerns dealing in cheese has been referred to the Justice Department. This was announced today by the House Government Operations subcommittee, which investigated the transaction.

NOTHING in art may ever be entirely old or new. Still, the necromantic painting of Giorgio de Chirico, springing to sudden maturity in about 1910 and following a strange and marvelous course for nearly a decade before losing itself in the quicksands of tasteless academicism, is the most unexpected phenomenon of twentieth-century art.
ATHENS, Sept. 17 -- Premier Alexander Papagos said tonight "material restitution and moral satisfaction are prerequisites for continuation of friendly relations with Turkey."

LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Senator George W. Malone was quoted by the Moscow radio today as having expressed surprise that the Soviet Union was free of debt while the United States was $281,000,000,000 in debt.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- While the Soviet Union has been concentrating on complicated diplomatic maneuvers this week, another factor has been at work in the background of the various Moscow negotiations.

STORIES about the possible sale of Carnegie Hall were current in the spring. It was no secret that Robert E. Simon Jr., president of the owning company, was anxious to put it on the market. He would have been happy to have the Philharmonic - Symphony purchase the hall.

THE American people increasingly show approval of the United Nations. Recently they have seen its influence work dramatically in the freeing of our fliers, imprisoned in China. In all probability no single government could have done this by itself.
IF they can do it, why can't we?"
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -- Five hundred friends, relatives and business associates congratulated James Cash Penney at a birthday party on the lawn of his home here this afternoon.
IDAHO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 4 -- A campaign to return an estimated 15,000 acres of National Forest lands to the management of the Forest Service has been set in motion from a headquarters here.

IF there were as many world series seats as there are hotel rooms in New York, the coming games would be the most heavily attended of any since the autumn baseball classic was first held fifty years ago.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- It was so quiet here at Municipal Stadium today one could almost hear a flag drop. The more distressed the Cleveland Indians became, the more de pressed a Ladies' Day crowd of 24,973 became.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Sept. 17 -- The 119th annual session of the New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church will be here Thursday through Sunday. Three hundred eighty churches south of the Raritan River will be represented by 600 ministerial and lay delegates.

DENVER, Sept. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower delegated yesterday to the Secretary of the Treasury certain "relatively minor duties" that the President has performed heretofore with respect to operation of the Coast Guard.

PERENNIALS, like shrubs, give a feeling of permanence to the garden. The brand-new home owner can plant a few perennials this fall, knowing that they will come up and bloom not only next summer but also year after year.

THINGS had a way of going wrong, those last summer days while Sebastian Maritimo waited for his father to decide whether he could make his first tuna-fishing trip on the Ponderosa. There was, for instance, the night at the cliffs, when only a fire department rescue saved him and Red Martin from the crashing tide.
Anent Robert K. Carr's "Should We Have a Hyde Park, Too?" (Aug. 28), in which he vividly portrays the soapbox carnival that goes on in London's Hyde Park:

BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 -- The correspondent of Handelsblatt, West Germany's leading economic newspaper, reported today from Moscow that the Soviet Government was prepared to negotiate a five-year trade agreement with Bonn.
Potato prices have remained low despite recent news that would appear to strengthen the market.

THE striking two-tone wood finishes that are so popular today can be easily achieved in a number of ways. The means and methods used will depend of course upon the wood to be finished, and the desired effect.

Can't something be done to help correct the dreadful habit of mispronunciation of foreign names by radio and TV announcers? Not a day goes by without such maddening things as a recent case in which "Snegouroutchka' was said "snyeego roochka," with accent on the "snyee" and on the "rooch."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 4 -- This country's import and export trade almost broke even in 1954, according to the Bureau of Statistics. Total imports were $80,653,614 and exports were $80,960,669 -- giving a favorable trade balance of only $307,055, compared with a favorable balance of $6,481,169 the preceding year.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A rebel radio broadcast tonight an ultimatum that President Peron resign by 6 A. M. Sunday (5 A. M. Eastern daylight time).

TWO things strike the traveler wherever he goes in Israel. The first is the material achievement of the new westernized Jewish nation -- new factories, raw and energetic new settlements, young forests planted on bare hills and plains and the ever-extending network of water pipes.
WABASH, Ind., Sept. 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today derided Democratic criticism of the Administration's farm program as demagoguery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Congressional files revealed today that almost 1,000 individuals, firms, associations and corporations engaged in lobbying during April to June.
FALL weather is bringing with it as varied a cluster of rail trips as the most ardent, lover of railroading could desire. Taking them chronologically, they shape up at this writing as follows:
Washington money managers have been applying brakes to the business boom since April, despite the fact that business activity then was below the postwar trend.
NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Eight members of the United States Conference of Mayors arrived here today on their way to attend the eleventh world congress of local authorities in Rome.

THE distinctive ways of living which human beings in every society learn from their elders and pass on with some variations to the younger generation evolve in time and space. But cultural evolution looks more like the banyan tree of the tropics than the biological evolutionary tree with a single trunk and spreading branches.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Rhode Island's Jack Leach, a fullback, swept left end for 7 yards in the third period today to enable the Rams to tie Northeastern, 13 -- 13, in their traditional football opener.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 -- Great Lakes vessels will carry a minimum of 78,000,000 tons of ore this season. Optimistic operators of lake fleets made the prediction today.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Sept. 17 -- The University of Notre Dame will begin its 114th academic year Thursday with an enrollment of 5,400, the university announced today. The freshman class of 1,350 students arrived yesterday for an orientation program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The 168th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, was marked today, Constitution Day, by a ceremonial hearing of charges by citizens of violations of constitutional rights and privileges.
The Federal Civil Defense Administration at Battle Creek, Mich., announced yesterday designs for five home and industrial shelters against nuclear attack.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Willard Schmidt of the St. Louis Cardinals continued his mastery over the Milwaukee Braves today limiting them to four hits for a 4-1 victory.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 17 -- The effervescence and good humor of Hungarians are astonishing to a visitor to their country, who is also surprised by some things they say.

Hotter than the American League pennant race between the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Indians is the close contest between income and outgo being waged in the counting houses of almost every ball club as a result of a long-term slump in attendance.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 -- The University of Southern California, led by Halfback John Arnett, routed Washington State College today, 50 -- 12, before 35,051 football fans in Memorial Coliseum.

VIENNA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Gian-Carlo Menotti got a mixed reception today from Vienna's critics for his opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street." But the New York singing star, Camilla Williams, was much praised.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- once more Latin-American countries find themselves caught in a trade trap devised by foreign totalitarian states.

New York City's public schools opened last Monday with an enrollment of 923,505 pupils -- 16,000 more than last fall. In a "progress report," Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, pointed to the various advances that have been made during the past twelve months to solve major problems.

IN her first book for children, Muriel Rukeyser, the poet, describes with understanding and great tact the problem of children who inadvertently mislay their grownups. It isn't, she makes clear, the child who is lost but the attendant elder.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- More than 800 civic, church and labor leaders paid tribute to Matthew Woll, 75-year-old first vice president of the American Federation of Labor, at a testimonial dinner here tonight.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 17 (UP) -- About 200 persons who attended a postmen's picnic at North Lake Park here tonight were taken to hospitals and physicians' offices for what was believed to be food poisoning.

HONG KONG, Sept. 17 -- Having completed the first phase of its talks on an ambassadorial level with the United States at Geneva, Communist China has put on record two immediate tactical "objectives" in its continuing "peaceful coexistence" drive.
THE National Broadcasting Company's widely heralded project for luring outside talent into the toils of television is bearing its first fruits.

IN the early Nineteen Thirties a story called "First Blood," by F. Scott Fitzgerald, appeared in The Saturday Evening Post. It was about a 16-year-old girl, Josephine Perry, who lived in Chicago with her family.
To lend money to home buyers, savings and loan associations recently have been leaning heavily on Federal Home Loan Bank credit. Last week the Federal Home Loan Bank Board yanked the crutch away.

WHATEVER else may be said of the art world it is quite evident that anyone in New York who wishes to know what is going on in other parts of the country -- or the world -- may readily find out. Traveling exhibitions are comprehensive, numerous and explicit.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 17 -- Plans for a drainage survey to determine how the needs of Suffolk County can be served best were announced this week by the County Board of Supervisors.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- That new smile on the face of the Russian bear doesn't mean the Soviet Union is going to abandon communism. In an extraordinary speech tonight at the Kremlin, Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, gave warning of that to the Western world.

THIS aviary is a selection from "Mr. Gould's Tropical Birds," a folio of two dozen plates in color (Crown, $7.50), taken from the works of a singularly copious birdman. All told, John Gould, a Victorian Englishman (1804-1881), put upon the market nearly 3,000 colored pictures that filled forty-one volumes.

THE caulking gun and paint brush are among the chief tools of the home owner in keeping his house in good condition. Many prefer springtime for outside painting to clean up the ravages of winter and to brighten the house for the summer and autumn months.

I read Harrison E. Salisbury's article, " 'Kollektivnost' -- Key to Russia's New Look" (Aug. 21), with great interest. Mr. alisbury calls the new form of government "committee" or "junta" rule and says that it "is not a very stable
In June, 1945, The New York Times correspondent in Argentina cabled his New York office:
The New York State Nurses Association reported progress yesterday in revising employment classifications of the city's nurses.
The first summer camp established for children with muscular dystrophy closed last week, ending a successful two-week experiment.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 17 -- President Juan D. Peron's "forces of repression" announced tonight that they had "liberated" Cordoba, provisional capital and key base of the rebel government.

SANTA FE, N. M., Sept. 17 -- Return of land no longer needed by the United States Government is being sought by the Mescalero Apache Indians. A Federal hearing, however, has brought a ruling adverse to their demand.

ALONG tonal scale, high resolving power, absence of grain, and wide exposure latitude are the characteristics claimed by the makers for the new high-speed Polaroid Land film, which goes on sale tomorrow.

THE merger of the Manhattan and the Miniature camera clubs, two of the oldest in the city, was announced last week. The name of the new organization, which will hold its first meeting tomorrow night at the Empire Hotel, Broadway at Sixty-third Street, will be the Miniature and Manhattan Camera Club of New York. Joseph A. Bernstein is president, Martin Bercu and Alan H Rosenberg, vice presidents.
DENVER, Sept. 17 -- The Summer White House named today 139 leaders in education, government and athletics to attend the President's Conference on the Fitness of American Youth late this month.
ATLANTA, Sept. 17 -- Georgia Tech's Yellow Jackets, combining a healthy helping of luck with typical speed and smartness, whipped a powerful Miami football team, 14 -- 6, today.

IT is a virtually phenomenal coincidence that there have been showing in New York simultaneously two productions of Shakespeare's "Othello," one on the stage and one on the screen. For "Othello" is even less frequent on the screen than on the stage.

Capt. John Norlander and the fourteen crew members of the Swedish American liner Kungsholm who rescued twenty-nine seamen in the Atlantic last month will be honored tomorrow at a ceremony aboard the liner.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 17 -- Scattered incidents of violence accompanied a seeming hardening today of opposing political positions in the Moroccan crisis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The new military reserve program will not endanger the business careers of youths but probably will create some problems, a survey of big industrial firms showed today.
A company headed by two men in their thirties is beginning to cut sizable portions out of several segments of the restaurant business.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 17 -- Harvie Ward was a jubilant champion as he was surrounded by his wife, his mother and dad and a special golfing friend today.

CHARMING, intelligent and sympathetic, Marsha Whitney strives hard to measure up to the record of her older sister and never quite succeeds -- or so she thinks. Half-hypnotized by Di's beauty and brilliance, and genuinely fond of her, Julie is almost resigned to staying in the shadowy background.

THIS is the time of year when tourists go out into the country to look at the brilliantly changing color of the foliage. Most of this looking is done at an upward angle, with the tourist peering out from an automobile or bus window up at a tree, or out and upward at hills and mountains.

ALONG the roadsides and in the fields and woods, natures's harvest has set and fall planting is under way. Seeds and fruits and berries, now ripening everywhere on plant and vine, shrub and tree, wait only to be gathered and sown by their own special agents.

ON Nov. 29. 1887, an 11-year-old pianist named Josef Hofmann made his American debut at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was no stranger to recital audiences; he had played to audiences in London and on the Continent.
ALEXANDRA DANILOVA, with Michael Maule as her partner and with Moscelyne Larkin and Roman Jasinsky also in the company, has left for a two-month tour of the Orient opening in Manila.

OF the many new arrivals on the American garden scene during the past few years, one of the most useful and decorative is the garden "baffle" or windscreen. The present version seems to have originated in the gardens of sunny California.

In his letter in The Times of Sept. 11 Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith of Harvard University asks for "different directions" in our Federal monetary and fiscal policies. This is in criticism of the Eisenhower Administration's present anti-inflation program.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 17 -- A sudden return of hot weather cut into retail distribution last week and the gains generally were limited to around 5 per cent, compared with a year ago. Merchants report the figures from now on will be competing with a rising curve in the 1954 trend and that it might be difficult to maintain the 9 per cent gain for the year to date in the Kansas City area.

HOW do birds, animals, and even fishes, find their way about? This intriguing problem has interested many naturalists. I have never heard of any adequate explanation, and herewith offer my own, which is pure theory * * *.

Department store sales in New York and Brooklyn last week were lower than in the comparable week of last year. Store executives estimated that the decrease would be about 8 per cent for the nine major stores, against sales of the ten big stores in operation last year.
NEWARK, Sept. 17 -- Candidates seeking seats Nov. 8 in the New Jersey Legislature have been asked to answer a pre-election questionnaire on "social, moral and ethical" problems.
OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- In Canada the supposedly vanishing Indian is not vanishing at all.

WHAT New York is to America Moscow is to the Soviet Union -- the biggest tourist attraction in the country. Every day about 400,000 persons enter the Soviet capital, the greatest city of Eastern Europe. Most of these travelers are commuters to whom the sights of Moscow are as familiar as their own backyards.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 17 -- A statewide survey to determine what is being done for public school children of exceptional intellectual ability is under way in Connecticut.

FLOWERS that bloom from bulbs are needed in gardens large or small. But it is, perhaps, in the small intimate garden that they most endear themselves to the gardener. There they can be viewed close at hand all during the spring, summer and autumn.

THIS is a cosmopolitan capital of over three million, with some of the world's best food, art and music but, until a little more than six months ago, the world of the theatre was a parched desert, with only cheap variety shows and a very occasional play produced under difficult circumstances. Fortunately for Mexico's many would-be theatregoers, this situation is now changing rapidly.
The Good Samaritan Dispensary, which has given free and low-cost medical care to countless thousands of lower East Side residents for sixty-four years, will close on Sept. 30.

About the biggest and heaviest piece of machinery ever devised for medical research is now in operation at the Royal Air Force Institute of Aviation Medicine at Farnsborough, England. It is a human centrifuge, a machine that whirls a man around and thus simulates the conditions that he must face when he suddenly departs from straight-line flight in a high-speed fighter plane as he maneuvers in combat.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 17 -- Dr. You Chan Yang, Ambassador to the United States, said today North Korea had begun a new program of subversion in South Korea designed to disrupt the 1956 elections.

Two facts stood out last week about relations between the United States and Communist China. One was that at no time since the Communists came to power in 1949 have relations been better. The other was that none of the fundamental issues which brought the two countries close to war less than six months ago have been solved.

Greatest of all worries of the companies that will be producing atomic power in the next ten or fifteen years is the disposal of radioactive wastes. Most of these decay so rapidly that they present no problem. It is the wastes that send forth dangerous rays for years that are already giving trouble.

The Hospitalized Veterans Service will benefit from "A Night in Monte Carlo," a ball to be held Jan. 6 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event will be under the patronage of His Serene Highness Prince Rainier 3d of Monaco.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- The State Thruway Authority reported today that $1,752,547 in tolls had been collected in August on the superhighway between Suffern and Buffalo. Collections in July were $1,688,793.

ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Paul H. Hughes, a witness in the Federal New York grand jury investigation of Harvey Matusow, turn-about witness, surrendered to Federal authorities in Roanoke today. The grand jury indicted him on a perjury charge Wednesday.

AS befitted a king-sized elephant, Chaga loved to charge through the jungle scattering the small animals in a panic -- until he suddenly, miraculously shrank to the size of a rabbit. By the time Chaga regained his original majesty he had fled from a leopard, battled a jackal and learned the hard way what life is like for small creatures -- a lesson never to be forgotten.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Preliminary inquiry into more than 100 complaints of alleged Government suppression of news indicates that "many of them" are valid. House of Representatives investigators made this statement today.

A CHERISHED item of American folklore is the picture of the aviation test pilot as a swashbuckling, bescarfed, Clark Gableish figure whose life is an extravaganza of devil-may-care aerial acrobatics and general hey-nonny-nonny. The contrast between this picture and the truth is one of the more staggering illustrations of the era of vastness and complexity through which our civilization is dog-paddling.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -- Argentine army insurgents said tonight that they remained in control of Cordoba. A radio broadcast asserted that Buenos Aires would be attacked by air "within hours."

THIS novel begins in the lovely April of Cathy Donnar's senior year in college. It ends two days later, when Cathy comes home to tell her family that she will have a child in June, and that she will not marry the child's father.

THIS first collection of H. L. Gold's short stories presents a remarkably clear delineation of both his virtues and faults as a storyteller of science-fantasy. So equally balanced are these that I, for one, cannot determine which outweighs the other.
Disarmament, that most appealing of all words in the dictionary of diplomacy, has a mongrel history. The failures in trying to achieve it have been colossal; the successes just enough to revive hope.
LOS ALAMOS, N, M., Sept. 15 -- The deep-thinking scientists who have plumbed the mysteries of the atom admit they are stumped by a far less abstruse problem.

FREDERICK RAMSEY JR., who was largely responsible for Folkways' excellent eleven-disk survey of recorded jazz, has recently spent a year in Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana with a tape recorder and a Guggenheim Fellowship, attempting to trace and record authentic reproductions of Afro-American music as it was played between 1860 and 1900.

Many gardeners still consider growing fruit a much too complicated and demanding operation -- too big for the average home property. That they are missing a great deal of beauty and pleasure in exchange for comparatively little effort is here attested by three "average" amateur growers.

WHEN school opened this semester, many classrooms in hundreds of communities throughout the country were jammed to the sills with children -- three shifts a day in some of them. In others, the pressure was relieved -- temporarily at least -- by new schools.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17 -- An effort to increase the protection afforded buyers of uranium stocks is in prospect during the next session of Congress. This would be a direct result of hearings concluded here this week by members of a House Subcommittee on Commerce and Finance.
The Administration's power policy is slated to get a going over at the hands of Senate Democrats starting tomorrow.

IN a brief foreword, Ruth Patton Totten, daughter of the Third Army's late great battle leader in World War II, says she thinks of this book as a "memorial of inestimable worth to his family as well as to his profession and to history."
POSTMASTER General Arthur E. Summerfield made available last week the design, a portrait of Theodore Roosevelt, of the twelfth stamp in the new regular series inaugurated last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Housing starts rebounded in August to the highest level for that month in any year except the 1950 peak.
Physicists in rolled-up shirt sleeves and husky riggers combined brain and brawn for ten hours last week at Columbia University. They installed a $425,000 Van der Graaf generator.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Everywhere there are weeds, and in some places so tall that they must be pulled by hand before soil is cultivated. Wherever other plants won't be harmed, spray the weeds with 2,4-D.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 17 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today India would judge the policies of other countries on the basis of their attitude toward Portuguese Goa.
I read with great interest the recent letter by Robert G. Mead Jr. concerning the need for intensive training in foreign languages for Americans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- United States economic relations with Britain are fast approaching a stage of crisis. There have been recriminations, although diplomatically couched. These have dealt with Britain's worsening inflation and with "backpedaling" by the United States on its pledge to liberalize imports.

FORECASTS these days point to increased prices for 1956 automobiles. Reasons for such surmises are familiar enough. Foremost among them are two: higher payrolls for automotive employes, and higher costs of materials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Little is known here so far about the possible connection between the rebelling military forces and the political opponents of Peronism, such as the Radical party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- "Everything is booming but the guns," says the Republican National Committee. The country is prosperous, Captain McCutchen has finally won the $64,000. The Yankees and the Indians are in a lovely brawl, and everything would be fine if the Communists would just go away.

On Tuesday of this week the General Assembly of the United Nations will resume its sessions. This tenth regular session can be the most momentous in the history of the organization. It is confronted with problems of the greatest significance.

THE German music critic, Kurt Blaukopf, confidently sets out to examine twenty-two conductors. This he does, with a set of standards and a prose style so uniquely echt-Deutsch, plus a translation so inept and full of Teutonic locutions, as to paralyze the average reader.

OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's economy expanded sharply in the second quarter of this year. The gross national product -- value of all goods and services produced -- rose to a record annual rate of $26,248,000,000.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Jackie Simpson returned an intercepted pass 100 yards and went 46 yards on another scoring run as Florida defeated Misissippi State, 20 -- 14, in a Southeastern Conference opener today.

BY the third quarter of the twentieth century man has almost lost his world. Mice, rats, cats, dogs and horses, given near-human intelligence by a scientist named Paget, are decimating his fields and flocks, destroying his transport and communications and driving him from his communities.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The Bey of Tunis today approved the first all-Tunisian Cabinet to take office in 64 years.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A styling revolution is gaining momentum in the auto industry.

This week's outstanding art event is the memorial exhibition of paintings, drawings, prints and illustrations by Reginald Marsh, who died in 1954. It is to be held at the Whitney Museum. It will open there on Wednesday and continue until Nov. 6.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Ed Lopat and George Zuverink pitched Baltimore to a 3-1 victory over Washington today, moving the Orioles to within one game of the seventh-place Nationals.

OSWALD JACOBY once defined winning bridge as "the art of defeating the opponents' superior cards." He was only half right; the other half of the art lies in making the most of one's own superior cards, when one is fortunate enough to hold them.
TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- The 1955 New Jersey political campaign will move into high gear next week. It is expected to attract record interest for an off-year election.

THOMAS MANN had the insatiable appetite of genius for something which is often confused with mere bulk or volume -- thoroughness. His major works -- "Buddenbrooks," "The Magic Mountain," "Joseph and His Brothers" -- were first planned as short novels or novellas. All of these tales grew into epics, each one more complex; more complete than its predecessor.

Like most psychiatrists, Dr. John M. MacDonald, who acts as a consultant to the District Courts of Colorado, sees no virtue in what is popularly known as a "truth serum." He objects to the name, because the so-called "truth serum" is not a serum" at all but a barbiturate, the principal component of most sleeping tablets.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Princeton University will initiate a graduate program leading to the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in Religion with the opening of its 210th academic year on Monday.

On Sept. 18, 1948, Harry S. Truman stood up before 90,000 farm people at the National Plowing Contest on Mrs. Agg's farm in Dexter, Iowa. He said: "The Republican gluttons of privilege are cold men. * * * How many times do you have to be hit over the head Before you. find out what's hitting you?"

I cannot accept your critic's judgment on the television production of "The Skin of Our Teeth." His criticisms are clear and sound and intelligent, but incompatible with his opening judgment that it was a fine presentation.

Phil Rizzuto has received many honors during his long and distinguished baseball career. NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17 -- A city charter commission, in a report this week, proposed four-year instead of the present two-year terms for elective officials, the consolidation of several major departments and the appointment, instead of election, of some office-holders.

TOO many rose gardens, even though horticultural triumphs, are just collections of bushes in rectangles. There is no design interest, no edging plants to conceal the leggy bareness of the bushes when they are not in bloom and no background planting whatsoever.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17 -- Yale University will award its Howland Prize, Monday, to Sir Owen Dixon, Chief Justice of Australia and United Nations mediator between India and Pakistan in 1950.

FROM Greek mythology Albert Camus has selected as the image of the human condition the hero Sisyphus who was condemned by the gods to roll a rock up a hill from which it perpetually slipped back. Everyman is his own Sisyphus rising each day to roll the rock of his life forward up a slope only to have it endlessly return to the bottom again.

IN some ways it is a pity that the eagle, a vulture, became the heraldic emblem of American might and power. Far better would have been the great and formidable grizzly bear, Ursus horribilis, the real king of all the animal world.
HARTFORD, Sept. 17 -- Connecticut is slowly recovering from the great August flood.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Decreases in mortality rates throughout the world in the years between 1938 and 1953 amounted to 36 per cent, the United Nations monthly bulletin of statistics reported today.

When I was last in New York I went to two matinees, and for the first time in many years I was shockingly aware of what was to me a very disturbing audience change: the presence in the theatre of many coatless, tieless men; the sport shirt crowd seems to have infiltrated the legitimate theatre!
BERLIN, Sept. 13 -- The East German Communists are using an anti-religious slogan to promote the harvesting of crops throughout the Soviet zone this year.

BELGRADE, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- Vladimir Kuts of Russia today established a world record of 13 minutes 46.8 seconds for the 5,000 meters at an international track meet here.
The National Broadcasting Company is making an intensive effort to capture one of the Columbia Broadcasting System's most highly valued television programs -- "The $64,000 Question."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Twentieth Century-Fox is negotiating to obtain motion-picture rights to the play "The Desk Set" in advance of its scheduled Broadway opening next month. A company representative confirmed the studio's interest but would not say whether or not an arrangement had been made.
Nineteen persons suffered minor injuries yesterday when a wooden bandstand collapsed during a religious festival in Manhattan's "Little Italy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The best boat on the Potomac did not win the President's Cup today but 100,000 amazed spectators were sure the best pilot did. For months to come, perhaps years, this 1955 victory of Guy Lombardo's Tempo VII, driven by the canny ex-Californian, Danny Foster, will be a topic of speculation when speed boat-regatta fans gather.

Senate hearings into possible incursions against the Bill of Rights were commended in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. William Howard Melish. He preached at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Montague and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A Yale scientist said tonight that the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine had three drawbacks, but that intensive laboratory work was being carried on to end them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Eisenhower Administration is looking meticulously under the rug for $1,700,000,000 to balance its budget in the current fiscal year. And while the talk generally has been that most of it might come from the Defense Department's allowance, the civilian agencies, too, are being pressed to help the cause.
The International Longshoremen's Association has invited Louis Waldman, veteran New York labor lawyer, to present its complaint case before the Citizens Waterfront Committee.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 18 -- The Secretary of the Army struck back today at Democratic critics of the nation's defense preparedness. Wilber M. Brucker said if war were to come the country's defenses would be ready.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 18 -- The Government of President Juan D. Peron in effect appealed to the rebels tonight to refrain from bombing Buenos Aires.

Last week there arrived at the desk of this writer a copy of a memorandum recently prepared by Roy L. Reierson, vice president and economist of the Bankers Trust Company, titled: "The Recent Tightening of Credit." The original purpose of the paper was to bring this subject up to date and in clear focus for the officers and staff of the bank.
More than half the prison and exile population of the Soviet Union could benefit from the amnesty announced yesterday for those who collaborated with the enemy in World War II.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, said today that the institution's educational policies were "based firmly on the rock of our confidence in the uncommon man."

Seymour M. Tannenbaum has resold the six-story, thirty-family apartment house at 1314 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, to Burton A. Goldberg. Assessed at $50,000, the property was sold subject to a first mortgage of $39,397.

ZURICH, Sept. 18 -- On the Zurich Stock Exchange the feature this week was the heavy turnover in American certificates, prices stiffening in accord with the trend in New York. On favorable prospects for 1956 General Motors advanced 32 francs to 589, American Telephone and Telegraph, 13 to 775; du Pont, 14 to 998, and Kennecott Copper, 8 to 548.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The number of privately owned, ocean-going vessels under the American flag declined by two ships and 17,000 deadweight tons during the month of August, the American Merchant Marine Institute said today.
A campaign to have every New Yorker -- man, woman and child -- wear an identification tag was announced yesterday by Robert E. Condon, city Director of Civil Defense.

TOKYO, Sept. 18 -- Japanese industrialists view India's dispute with Portugal over the colony of Goa as something more than a mere nationalistic territorial claim. Here in Tokyo, the political quarrel over the small Portuguese possession on India's west coast assumes an important commereial complexion of international concern.

American Airlines, the first carrier to order American-built turboprop aircraft, has selected the power plants that will drive its new fleet. They will be 3,750-horsepower turbine engines built by the Allison Division of General Motors.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- The French Government avoided a complete breakdown of its program for Morocco tonight by asking Premier Edgar Faure to find a solution to the current deadlock by tomorrow afternoon.
Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, former publisher of the newspaper La Prensa of Buenos Aires, said last night that the Peron regime appeared to be in "mounting difficulties."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Following are items proposed for inclusion on the regular and supplementary agenda of the tenth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene here Tuesday. Explanatory material within parentheses was compiled by the United Nations Department of Public information.

Sir Winston Churchill, who is to receive the annual Freedom Award of Freedom House this year, will record his acceptance speech, the organization announced yesterday. The recording will be broadcast at the group's anniversary dinner on Oct. 9 in the Sheraton-Aster Hotel.

Phil Rizzuto, somewhat shaky in the knees as a result, of his beaning on Saturday, but otherwise none the worse for wear, had his "day," before yesterday's game with the Red Sox. It was a big one, as befits the stature of the little shortstop as a great Yankee.

Business was "very good" last week in the steamship charter market, with a sharp upturn in demand that generally pulled rates with it. Most of the strength was attributed to activity by British and Continental coal charterers.
SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 18 -- The trial of two Mississippi white men accused of the murder of a 14-year-old Chicago Negro will start tomorrow in this Tallahatchie County courthouse town.

Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third largest automobile producer, disclosed over the week-end that it is planning a gigantic ten-year expansion program. The exact cost was not reported but it is understood to involve several hundred millions of dollars.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States increased contra-seasonally by $5,219,000 during August to a total of $654,855,000 at the end of the month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end. This total is $92,015,000 greater than a year ago.

HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 19 -- After two years of separate isolation in the servants' quarters of their mission house, three American Roman Catholic missionaries emerged yesterday from Communist China with their respective personalities and sense of humor intact despite more tightly notched belts. munists since Jan. 13, 1951, crossed the border into Hong Kong. The Rev. Mr. Lovegren was the seventh imprisoned American to be released by the Peiping regime since Friday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- The new Farm Policy Strategy Committee of the Democratic party will meet here tomorrow to plan an attack on the Eisenhower Administration's farm program.
Autumn, as usual, is the open season for vice presidents. Announcement of their election or appointment popped up yesterday from all corners of the advertising field.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Main Attraction, the 9-year-old chestnut mare owned by Miriam Duffy, won two championships and five blues at the Bedford horse show on the Shannon Stables grounds today.

"The First Five Million Miles," by Byron Moore, a personal account of the growth of the American airlines industry, will be published Wednesday by Harper. Mr. Moore, who has been a barnstormer, mail pilot, test pilot and wartime pilot of the Air Transport Command, is now senior pilot for American Airlines.

Many people have the wrong impression of the longshoreman. The boys do not want to strike, as we are the ones who suffer by it. We really see no sense in it, but if we don't strike at the order of the bigwigs, or if we even utter one word against a strike, the officials send their goons around to beat us up and fit us for hospitals.

A strike of eighty clerks and managers employed in newsstands of the Garfield News Company has been called for this morning. A spokesman for District 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., said last night that the workers would start the walkout by meeting at 8 A. M. at the union offices, 13 Astor Place.

Some years ago Herman E. Krooss and E. A. J. Johnson wrote a book on "The Origins and Development of the American Economy." It was an excellent work for the beginner or the foreign student. Now Dr. Krooss has made a solo effort, far more ambitious and far more exciting. It is called "American Economic Development"* and it is obviously intended for both college student and business man.
The city was accused yesterday of imposing an "unfair burden" on its voluntary hospitals through inadequate compensation for the care of indigent patients.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Rocky Marciano "wrapped it up" today. The world heavyweight champion concluded his sparring and general training preparations for his title fight with Archie Moore at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night and he's fit and eager.

We will admit that the conveyor-belt plan for replacing the Times Square-Grand Central subway shuttle had an element of adventurous innovation in it, although the belt, the moving sidewalk, the escalator have long since passed the test of transport experience. But the conservative view has been getting the upper hand, within official circles, land rejection seems likely.

On Sept. 12 Benjamin Fine in "Costs at College Reach New Peak" mentions apprehension in educational circles that rising costs of a college education will deprive the future of talented students and that economics rather than talent will determine who attends college.

THERE was a profound sigh of relief when Phil Rizzuto strode into the Yankee dressing room yesterday morning, as spry and as chipper as ever. His solicitous team-mates crowded around him because the little Scooter had been cracked on the back of the head by an errant pitch the day before and had been carried off the field on a stretcher.
Another "first" has been claimed for the 32,000-ton tanker World Concord.

The new Family Court, which last week began hearing matrimonial cases as a part of Supreme Court, will improve the mental health of this and future generations, Dr. Paul V. Lemkau predicted yesterday.
The expansion of the church is the personal repsonsibility of every Roman Catholic, the Rev. Charles J. McManus declared yesterday.
OTTAWA, Sept. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Cash income of Canadian farmers for the first half of this year was $30,000,000 below the level of the first six months of 1954.
