We hail with enthusiasm the opening of the new Family Part in the New York County Supreme Court, Justice Samuel M. Gold, presiding. This is a welcome stride forward in the movement, now getting well under way, to bring the antiquated administration of our courts into step with the needs and the knowledge of today.
Willie Mays hit his forty-eighth home run and Don Mueller made his 1,000th hit at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Giants couldn't win the ball game.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Philadelphia Phillies split a doubleheader today. The Bucs took the first, 5 -- 2, on a three-run homer by Frank Thomas, and the Phils won the nightcap, 2 -- 1, behind Saul Rogovin's six-hit pitching.
Shipments of refined copper to domestic fabricators increased to 90,078 tons in August from 60,143 tons the previous month, the Copper Institute has reported.
Michael J. Quill's prescription for preventing higher fares on the city's mass-transit facilities is a ban on all automobile traffic in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The discovery of a blue-green area, almost the size of Texas, on the red face of Mars was announced today by the National Geographic Society. The area is believed to be living vegetation.
Sidney Kingsley, the playwright, and a group of his associates -- both in and out of the theatre -- are planning to set up a syndicate to help combat the growing shortage of Broadway playhouses.
HATTERAS, N. C., Sept. 18 -- Hurricane Ione -- third and most vicious to hit the East Coast within six weeks -- smashed into the North Carolina beaches tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept., 18 -- A controversy has arisen in the State Department regarding proposed changes in passport regulations, fingerprint requirements for foreign visitors and travel restrictions.

Langdon W. Post has been appointed associate executive director of the Liberal party. Dr. George S. Counts, party chairman, announced yesterday that Mr. Post's appointment to assist Ben Davidson, executive director, was part of an intensified political and organizational effort outlined at the party's state committee meeting last week.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Determined that high waters will not wash away his summer cottage again, Ernest Levermann is rebuilding it on stilts at Gerard Park, overlooking Gardiners Bay.

The four municipal colleges -- Brooklyn, City, Hunter and Queens -- open today with a combined freshman class of 5,800 or 500 more than last year. Preliminary registration indicates a total student body of 73,000. Applications for admission increased 20 per cent over those of last year.

TATIANA DU PLESSIX, who deserted the fine arts to make a label for herself in the fashion arts, displays all her talent for painting and sculpture in her current collection of custom millinery at Saks Fifth Avenue.

PARIS, Sept. 18 -- Demonstrative French music lovers at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees tonight enthusiastically acclaimed the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's first concert here in twenty-five years.
A new contract providing a two-step increase of $7 a week for 5,500 workers in the city's commercial printing shops will become effective today.
Prices of cotton futures continued to decline last week on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The 13,505 banks whose deposits are insured by the Government increased their assets and deposits about 5 per cent during the fiscal year ended on June 30, it was reported today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- Certain statements about recent Soviet-West German negotiations that were made in Moscow yesterday were erroneously attributed by the correspondent of The New York Times to Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 18 -- The football picture seems to have brightened on the banks of the Raritan. Beaten in six of its nine games in 1954, Rutgers' gridiron forces are envisioning better things.

The annual award of the E. H. Harriman Memorial Gold Medals and Certificates of Commendation shows that the nation's railroads set a splendid record for safety in 1954. As a whole, they reported 15 per cent fewer fatalities of all kinds than in the previous low years of 1952 and 1953.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- A more cheerful tone was noted in stock markets in the past week. The gain derived its impetus from these factors:
Dr. Douglas S. Smith has been appointed director of research and development for the J. B. Williams Company, Glastonbury, Conn., manufacturer of shaving products and related items.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Organized hotel workers were cautioned by their union today to avoid Miami and Miami Beach in the coming winter season. Normally, many hotel workers go south to work in the winter.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has put into a brochure the story of how a small manufacturer fought the giants in his field until his advertising budget is now as big as his total sales volume in 1948.

IN a Greenwich Village apartment the other evening, a crimson-turbaned Sikh, Dharam Jit Singh, cooked an Indian meal for some food-minded New Yorkers in which there hardly was a hint of curry. Though his guests found a delicately flavored Indian dinner an anomaly, Mr. Singh disclaimed it was a tour de force.

DENVER, Sept. 18 -- The White House explained today why President Eisenhower had not registered for a November election in Gettysburg, Pa. It was not due to neglect of his civic responsibility, the White House said.

Now that the longshoremen are back at work would it not be well to admit that in their inarticulate fashion they failed to give a bill of particulars as to the grievances which they hold against the Waterfront Commission?
MOSCOW, Sept. 18 -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Defense Minister, said tonight the Soviet Government had decided to liquidate its military bases on foreign soil.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Mrs. William B. Mosle, chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball committee, has announced that invitations have been sent out for the ball to be held in the Tuxedo Club on Oct. 22.

Tony DeSpirito, one of the nation's leading jockeys, was listed yesterday at Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights, Queens, as in serious condition as the result of injuries suffered in a fall at the Aqueduct last on Saturday.
Adlai E. Stevenson will be the featured speaker at the first meeting of the National Citizens Committee for the Woodrow Wilson Centennial.

The specialist is doing the thinking and the leading for too many Christians, the Rev. Walter Donald Kring lamented yesterday. He preached his first sermon as minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

Standard Oil Company of California has issued a reply to a recent letter directed to the major oil importing companies by Arthur Flemming. Director of Defense Mobilization. Mr. Flemming said oil imports were exceeding the levels recommended by the President's Fuels Policy Committee and asked for recommendations leading to a solution of the situation.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions overcame a sluggish first half and struck for two touchdowns in six minutes of the third quarter to defeat the New York Giants, 27 -- 17, in a National Football League exhibition today before 34,487 in Briggs Stadium.
An interfaith congregation was called upon by its minister yesterday to join spiritually in observance of the Jewish High Holidays.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- A program to expand production and raise efficiency in industry and to reduce Government spending is under consideration by the British Cabinet, according to authoritative sources.

Net income of the New Idria Mining and Chemical Company and wholly owned subsidiaries operating in the United States rose to $173,386 for the year ended June 30 from $140,000 for the previous fiscal year, the company reported over the week-end. Gross income rose to $2,808,440 from $2,396,118.

With the Soviet "new look" diplomacy busy on all fronts, top-ranking diplomats of the United States, Britain, France and Germany meet in Washington beginning today to prepare, for later decision by their foreign ministers, the Western strategy at the next Geneva conference to meet the latest Soviet moves.

THESE are the days when world peace seems, somehow, to be contingent on the imminent world series, and a baseball manager speaks with the arresting voice of an Old Testament prophet. And Casey Stengel, on his personal mountain, the Yankee dugout steps, orates with authority that sometimes can pinchhit for wisdom.

Gradually, a few at a time, the civilian prisoners of the Chinese Communists are being released. This "trickle technique" is an obvious face-saving device, apparently to suggest that each case has been judged on its merits. In line with this, also, is the formality of reading charges and ordering deportation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- A split developed in the American Legion today over the Fund for the Republic and its activities in support of freedom of thought.

The building at the southwest corner of East Fifteenth Street and Second Avenue, formerly occupied by the Little Sisters of the Assumption, has been purchased by St. Mary's Greek Catholic Church. The buyer, which recognizes the Pope as the head of the church, was assisted in the purchase by the New York Archdiocese.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Republican National Committee will sponsor some 100 "Salute to Eisenhower" dinners Jan. 20 to kick off its 1956 fund - raising campaign. They would also enable Republicans to urge General Eisenhower to run for re-election.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 18 -- The West German Government has become alarmed at critical reaction in Washington and London to the agreement Chancellor Konrad Adenauer made in Moscow.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Strange Lady, a 6-year-old chestnut mare, captured the jumper championship at the eleventh annual Watchung hunter show today. The mare won three blue ribbons as she collected 18 points for the title in the competition at the Watchung Stable.

We are seeing one of the great dramas of Latin-American history in Argentina these days. There are all the elements of high tragedy -- the protagonist around whom the action swirls, the suspense, the ebb and flow of events, the profound emotions, the great themes of which the principle is the age-old demand of the civilized human being for liberty, and the course toward death.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- Dr. Frederick L. Schuman, educator and author, said tonight that a series of diplomatic bargains or stand-offs on all major issues between the free world and communism "is now inevitable."
A Scottish clergyman suggested yesterday that various types of "spiritual lameness" could be cured by turning to Christ.

A group of twenty young men and thirty-nine young women cadets who will become officers in the Salvation Army staged a pre-college parade yesterday from Union Square to Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street.
The Yankees wound up their 1955 home season at the Stadium yesterday in the grand manner.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- Steel companies were still having trouble last week expanding production.

I would like to commend The New York Times for its objective and realistic treatment of the events connected with Cyprus. If we are to reach a solution -- and the security of the free world requires this -- it will be by a realistic, unemotional and nonparochial approach to the problem.

High city officials will be among the lecturers in a course on "Administrative Problems of the City of New York" to be given at the New York University Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service.
"Jazz at the Philharmonic" the annual Norman Granz presentation at Carnegie Hall, held sway there for two Saturday evening concerts, the first at 8:30, the second at midnight.

With the celebration of the bicentennial of Ticonderoga, historians are recalling battles skirmishes, defeats and victories of old in which the provinces that became part of Canada and those that became part of the United States bore major roles over more than a century and a half.
TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, should he decide to run again next year for the Presidency, may count on the undivided support of New Jersey Democrats.

A prominent business man in the export-import field has been denied re-admission to the United States by the Immigration and Naturalization Service because of doubts about his background and place of birth.

The annual World Championship Rodeo will be held in Madison Square Garden Sept. 28 through Oct. 16, with six 1954 winners defending their titles. Entries close tonight. Frank Moore, the Garden's rodeo manager, already has 150 acceptances.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- History's odds book -- as read through Democratic eyes -- established Adlai E. Stevenson today as a three-to-one favorite over President Eisenhower if both run again in 1956.

The General Instrument Corporation announced over the week-end that enough proxies had been received to indicate approval of an increase in the authorized common stock from 1,500,000 to 3,000,000 shares. A special stockholder meeting is scheduled for Wednesday at Elizabeth, N. J.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Kansas City crushed the stumbling Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 1, today on two four-run innings, one of them featured by Gus Zernial's bases-loaded home run.

TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Nearly 4,000 persons attended the bicentennial celebration of Fort Ticonderoga today. Construction of the fort, originally known as Carillon, was started by the French 200 years ago today.
Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen is continuing his fight against the trunk-line sewer planned by the Middlesex County Sewerage Authority of New Jersey.

The sixth annual Musical Talent in Our Schools series, sponsored jointly by radio station WQXR and The New York Times, will begin auditions in October to determine the participants on the broadcasts scheduled for next spring.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, in a sermon here yesterday, emphasized the revivification of Christianity and linked it with the moral and spiritual preparedness of the free world against communism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- A Democratic Congressman today came to the defense of a Republican colleague who was reported to be under political attack as too concerned about music and other cultural affairs.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept 18 -- The General Confederation of Labor called upon its members today to join the struggle against the rebel forces and to live up to the unions' often-shouted slogan, "Our lives for Peron."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles appealed to Greece and Turkey today not to let the "unhappy events of the past two weeks" destroy their partnership as supports of the free world.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 17 -- The manner in which the Soviet-led coalition in Eastern Europe coordinates its industrial and commercial efforts for the "common prosperity" is stressed in Hungary. This correspondent visited Budapest, the Hungarian capital, recently.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Grain and soybean futures displayed a strong tone most of last week.

ATHENS, Sept. 18 -- Since Greece joined NATO in 1952 she has been one of the toughest and most determined members of the alliance. Having had experience of Communist insurrection, conspiracy and civil war, this country became particularly skeptical of Soviet intentions. But that mood is now changing.

THOUGH the week-end programs of the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House devoted themselves to familiar work, there was the most interesting sort of novelty in the Saturday afternoon presentation of "The Sleeping Beauty," for the company's newest ballerina, Svetlana Beriosova, made her first local appearance in the title role.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 -- On the field, in the stands, almost everywhere they turned, the Cleveland Indians found themselves surrounded by enemies today at Municipal Stadium. There wasn't a friendly face among the Detroit Tigers, who completed the sweep of the three-game set with a 10-3 rout of the fading American League champions.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 18 -- The third annual Pacific Coast Music Festival closed this afternoon with a concert conducted by Leopold Stokowski and Stravinsky's Mass sung by a chorus as a memorial to the late Olin Downes, music critic of The New York Times.
A fleet of eighty-eight sloops sailed in streaky air yesterday as the Morris Yacht and Beach Club of City Island conducted the final program of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Donald MacLean and Guy Burgess, British diplomats who disappeared in 1951, spied for the Soviet Union over a long period, the Foreign Office reported today.
The bankruptcy notices that this newspaper prints day after day under the one-line heading, "Business Records," are not necessarily the end of a dream.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The tenth annual session of the United Nations General Assembly will convene Tuesday.
WARSAW, Sept. 18 -- Hugo Hanke's defection is being used by the press here as a weapon to discredit the Polish emigre movement among the Polish people.
THERE is quite a story behind the stainless steel curtain that Marie Nichols, a weaver, has designed.
Three hundred worshipers at the Grace Congregational Church called on Mayor Wagner yesterday for an end to "character assassination and calumny" against former Judge Hubert T. Delany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Post Office Department told stamp collectors today that special stamp packets were available through the department's Philatelic Agency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) -- The Air Force has adopted a policy designed to tighten the reins on profits of airplane manufacturers and curb production of faulty military planes, Aviation Week Magazine said today.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- William Houston, a 15-year-old high school sophomore, starred today in the first annual fall regatta of the New York Rowing Association held on the Orchard Beach lagoon and finishing at Travers Island.

Paul Keres and Ewfim Geller of Russia scored victories yesterday in the twentieth and semi-final round of the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, according to a report received through Swedish news sources.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 18 -- Dutch monetary officials have not yet contemplated tightening credit, although bank loans and installment financing have increased considerably this year. This word has been passed on to Dutch banks by Dr. Marius Holtrop, president of the Netherlands Bank.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Ezra Taft Benson accepted the issue of declining farm prices and crop surpluses today as a key factor in the 1956 Presidential election.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A two-out single to center by George Crowe gave Milwaukee a 2-1, eleven-inning victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today and clinched second place for the Braves.
Governor Harriman is getting a state-wide television and radio program of his own.

The Yankees announced last night that they would accept world series ticket orders. Public sale of box and reserved seats will be by mail only, with customers being required to buy and being limited to two four-game strips.
Six new films, including imports from England and France, are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The State Department said tonight that all its communications with Buenos Aires had been interrupted since about noon.
The State Insurance Department was asked yesterday to rule on the right of labor-management welfare funds to self-insure benefits totaling hundreds of millions of dollars each year.

Gale-force winds and heavy rains were forecast for New York City today as hurricane Ione roared up the coast. The East braced for a possible repetition of the devastating floods it had suffered last month.
PERRY COMO who made his debut as a National Broadcasting Company star over Channel 4 on Saturday night, has a challenging assignment before him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet Union's avowed decision to liquidate its foreign military bases and the suggestion that Washington follow suit was regarded here as a propaganda stunt.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 18 -- The "Frontier Gandhi," leader of a half million tribesmen in the North-West Frontier Province, was arrested yesterday without explanation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- William H. Jackson, New York investment banker, has been given a key role in developing United States plans for increased contact between the Communist and non-Communist worlds.

Whatever his faults, Michael J. Quill does add a certain piquancy to life in Gotham. The ebullient president of the Transport Workers Union is rarely, if ever, at a loss for words; and his words are usually calculated to anger, annoy, amuse or alarm, as the case may be.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Acting Attorney General said today that the "appalling" backlog of cases in Federal courts bordered on a national disgrace.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 -- Until elimination becomes a mathematical certainty, the Cleveland Indians are not going to give up. Al Lopez, the quiet pilot of the Tribe, admitted today that the pace-setting Yankees, two lengths ahead of the Indians, hold a tremendous advantage, but he refused to toss in the towel.
A record goal of $18,100,000 has been set by the Federation of Jewish Philantropies of New York in its thirty-eighth annual appeal. The appeal, for the benefit of 116 member
Yanni Evangelides is a Greek who says he has "fall in loff with the beautiful ladies of America." Quite naturally, he designs gowns to make them look more beautiful and ladylike.

A superseding indictment, including fourteen counts from an indictment voted last May, was returned yesterday against John G. (Steve) Broady. Broady, a lawyer and private investigator, has been described as the "prime mover" of a wiretap conspiracy here.

Directors of the Bunker Hill and Sullivan Mining and Concentrating Company have approved plans to acquire the 50 per cent stock interest in the Sullivan Mining Company held by the Hecla Mining Company.
Plans are afoot for extensive use of New York's public school buildings as neighborhood centers. Mayor Wagner discussed the plans last night on a television program.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Following are translated texts of the Argentine Government's offer to confer with the rebels, as broadcast by the Argentine state radio today, and of President Juan D. Peron's statement, as read by Gen. Franklin Lucero:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Differences among the Western powers were apparent today as Western diplomats met here to work out their position at the Big Four foreign ministers conference next month.

Support for the promotion campaign planned by the National Restaurant Association next year was urged on the tea industry yesterday by Marion W. Isbell, president of the association. The campaign will be built around "Family Dine-Out Month" in February, a "Drive and Dine" promotion in June and "Holiday Times is Eat-Out Time" in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Pilot fatigue was cited today as a probable contributing factor in the crash of an Italian Airlines plane at New York International Airport last Dec. 18. The accident killed twenty-six persons, including the ten-man crew.
For the first time, City College students had a real campus yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Negotiations aimed at settlement of an eight-month dispute between United Air Lines and the Flight Engineers International Assocication, A. F. L., have been broken off.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley charged today that the Defense Department was "playing politics" with the new military reserve program by locating combat training camps in the South.
A Brooklyn trumpet player heard his playing described yesterday as "an unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise" that was detrimental to health.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 19 -Hearings on the application of the Connecticut Light and Power Company to construct a $20,000,000 generating plant on Manresa Island were resumed here today.
Abe Stark, President of the City Council, proposed yesterday that New York City apply for Federal funds to build modern industrial plants on sites now occupied by shabby factories.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation is seriously considering doing its own devalued variation on "The $64,000 Question" by way of meeting the competition of commercial television.

The nearest approach to a "Parliament of Man" meets again today when delegates from sixty nations, including twenty foreign ministers, convene at United Nations headquarters in New York to open the tenth regular session of the General Assembly.
No city service means more to the people than the care of the patients in our municipal hospitals. Much has been said about the need for more nurses.
The New York State Conference on Education, which was expected to run into a few controversies, came up with one sooner than any of its 800 participants expected.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -Robert B. Blyth, assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, today called for a "proper balance" between saving and spending for a vigorous, sustained growth in our economy.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- Cadillac will drive into the 1956 sales race equipped with a new Whirl-away transmission and engines ranging from 285-to-305-horsepower.

GENEVA, Sept. 19 -- Ambassador Wang Ping-nan of Communist China issued a statement here today denouncing the United States for refusing to talk about other matters until all Americans in Communist China get out.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- There is no disposition among British officials to put the blame for Britain's current economic difficulties on the United States or any other nation.
WARSAW, Sept. 19 -- Poland has reaped substantially better crops this year than last year, Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz declared in a speech printed here today.

Dr. Kathryn L. Hopwood became the dean of students at the downtown division of Hunter College yesterday. She succeeds Dr. Ann Anthony, who retired Sept. 1. The downtown division is at Park Avenue and Sixty eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A ten-year decline in civil rights was charged by Harry P. Cain today before the tenth National Conference on Citizenship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov's first move as head of the Soviet delegation to the tenth General Assembly was to pay a courtesy call this morning on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
Mlle. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube reported for duty yesterday as a rehabilitation trainee and took over her first case at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.
Ten new singers have been signed by the New York City Opera Company, which opens its fall season on Oct. 5. Of the ten seven are from the United States.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Ziv Television Programs has decided there is room on the networks for another Half-hour series of adult westerns. And so it will produce "Stockade" later this year.
From Britain come poignant accounts of the commemoration of the fifteenth anniversary of the Battle of Britain, in which British fliers ruined forever the peak striking power of the Nazi air force.

THE first volume of one of the most ambitious projects undertaken by a contemporary historian is published today. It is "The King's Peace 1637-1641" by C. V. Wedgwood. How many more volumes will be necessary before the complete work, which will be called "The Great Rebellion," is completed probably even Miss Wedgwood does not know.
Mayor Wagner tumbled headlong into a promotional pitfall yesterday afternoon. He may have recurrent headaches as a result, but more serious consequences are unlikely.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 19 -- Broadcasts from Argentina indicated today that the rebel forces were operating with at least three separate commands and that no over-all chief of the movement had yet emerged.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- India called today for the immediate establishment of an international organization to collect data on the hazards and long-time consequences of nuclear radiation.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches equaled women's par with a fine 38, 36 -- 74 today to win the qualifying medal in the thirtieth Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship over the long Plainfield Country Club course.

A block of preferred shares of Lamson Sessions Company is being offered today to the public. It consists of 60,000 shares of $50 par value, 4.75 per cent cumulative convertible stock and the price is $52 a share plus accrued dividends.
Most weather specialists do not believe that the hurricane experience of the last two years contains any suggestion of a change in the expected path that the storms follow in the Atlantic.

Record keeping by American business has not kept pace with progress in other areas, according to Alfred Pelham, budget director of Wayne County, Michigan. He made the assertion in a talk at the second annual Conference on Records Management at New York University yesterday.
The stormy, thirty-five-year career of Peter Loftus in the Fire Department was closed yesterday.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 19 -- Top United States economic officials have been telling European Governments that they should stop crying havoc every time the United States raises one or two tariff duties that it had previously lowered.
Steamship and plane schedules here were altered yesterday because of Hurricane Ione.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Top officials of the Eisenhower Administration denied today that a proposed new transportation policy favored railroads over trucks or other modes of transport.

It is to be hoped that the tenth session of the United Nations General Assembly will remedy the incongruity of not having any African membership on the Trusteeship Council although most of the Trust Territories are in Africa.
Oldsmobiles will comprise 10 per cent of the automobiles sold in 1956, by American manufacturers, company executives predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- His Yankees riding a five-game winning streak, which suddenly has ripped the American League pennant race wide open, Manager Casey Stengel marshaled his forces today, eager to move in for the kill.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Willie Hartack, the nation's leading rider, won four races and finished in the money with three other mounts today.

ONE advantage of being a homemaker in New York is the easy access to new ideas in interior decoration. Stores, educational institutions and museums offer a wealth of new merchandise, decorating tips and information on the home arts.
The new Social Court for Men, handling cases of alcoholism and vagrancy, was opened yesterday by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.
The New York City Housing Authority will open bids for $28,910,000 in short-term loan notes at 12 noon, Oct. 4, Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the authority, announced yesterday.

The former publisher of the Buenos Aires newspaper La Prensa, which was confiscated by the Peron Government four years ago, said last night that he hoped soon to return to Argentina and put his 86-year-old publication back into public service.
THORNTON WILDER'S bittersweet masterpiece, "Our Town," transferred to the television screen last night, provided ninety minutes of magnificent entertainment.

Governor Harriman was urged yesterday to reconsider his preliminary approval of the State Power Authority's project to build its own transmission lines. The appeal came from the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, which speaks for business groups.

J.E. JOHNSTONE, who remembers when grass was growing in the space now occupied by the Biltmore Hotel, satdown in a drugstore the other morning and, over several thick mugs of indifferent coffee, talked about fine food. His companion was Ronald Kytan, manager of Charles Co.'s Bon Voyage, 340 Madison Avenue.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- During the week-end the New York State Conservation Department launched a new phase in its program of teaching young hunters how to pursue an avocation with safety and sportsmanship.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., Sept. 19 -- The National Park Service opened a six-day conference today in this gateway town to the Great Smoky Mountain National Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The dulcet female names which the United States Weather Bureau gives to hurricanes must long since have passed the toleration point for the communities that for two successive years have been smashed by these forces of desolation.

A mare that had won only once since last April captured the $5,000 Mount Kisco Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Responsible for the triumph was Miss Weesie, Thomas F. White's 5-year-old daughter of Jeep, who left the post as the 3-to-1 third choice.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals, by a 2-1 vote, today overturned a New Jersey Federal District Court ruling that would have revoked the citizenship of Albert Anastasia.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 19 -- The political leadership of President Syngman Rhee was seriously challenged today with the formation of a new Opposition party.

Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that steadily increasing use of electric power throughout southeastern Michigan produced sizable increases in August sales, net earnings and steam power plant generation.

During World War II children in New York's public schools wore plastic identification tags which dangled from thin, plastic cords around their necks. Even after the bombing threat was past, tags were worn. With the surrender of the Axis powers, the plastic disks found their way into trash baskets and bureau drawers filled with discarded relics.
Another color television "first," commercial harnessing of the sun's vast power, and vistas of the future that verge on science fiction were in the news yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- An out-of-court settlement of a suit filed by Armour Co. charging Swift Co. with infringement of Armour patents covering modified lard was announced today.

BEING as ingenious as he's droll, Archie Moore spent close to $50,000 in bombarding sportswriters the country over in a telegraphic campaign to force Rocky Marciano into the ring with him. Of the 1,134 typewriter pounders who responded to his unique poll, 992 of them agreed that this ancient gypsy was deserving of a bout for the heavyweight championship of the world.

Serious doubts have recently been expressed concerning the future political and propaganda value of Radio Free Europe, Radio Liberation and perhaps even of the Voice of America. It is maintained that since the Kremlin itself now quotes extensively from important speeches by United States and Western statesmen through its own information media, the United States may not need the services of these agencies broadcasting behind the Iron and Bamboo Curtains.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, Sept. 20 -- The Rev. Levi A. Lovegren of Cherry Grove, Ore., the seventh imprisoned American to be released by the Chinese Communists since Friday, reached freedom here today just in time to cut a cake.
A strong possibility developed yesterday that a Negro would be elected a vice president of the merged labor federation this December.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

TRENTON, Sept. 19. -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the Legislature moved tonight to speed the transformation of the now closed Bordentown Manual Training School into a center for 600 mentally retarded children.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Representative Emanuel Celler denied today that relaxation of immigration requirements would have a deleterious effect on United States security.
The heavy electrical equipment industry is beginning to feel the effect of recent strikes and wage settlements, plus continuing heavy demand for raw materials.
A French mime making his first United States appearance and the revival of a musical constitute tonight's off-Broadway theatrical fare.
Mayor Wagner announced plans yesterday for a $500,000 tuberculosis detection program in the city.

A reward of $25,000 was offered yesterday for information leading to the conviction of the murderer or murderers of Serge Rubinstein, who was found strangled in a bedroom of his home, 814 Fifth Avenue, on the morning of Jan. 27.
The Wentworth Manufacturing Company will acquire Royal Miss, Inc., another leading maker of house dresses, under an agreement reached yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP) -- New car assemblies have moved upward again, reflecting the quick changeover to 1956 models by Ford.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- The number of new cases of poliomyelitis reported in the upstate area last week totaled 178, a record for the year. This compared with 159 in the previous week and 102 during the comparable week last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union called on the West today for proof of good faith that would match Moscow's promise to surrender Finland's Porkkala naval base and to cut the Soviet army by 640,000.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Col. Earl Blaik shook down his Army football team for the last time today prior to Saturday's opening game in Michie Stadium. Following last Saturday's scrimmage, three changes were made and the line-up is now set for Furman.
Narcotics clinics, at which out-patient addicts could obtain now-forbidden drugs at low cost or free, were urged yesterday by five witnesses before a Senate subcommittee.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Britain is expected to recommend shortly to the United States that the two countries begin studying the possibility of combining their bomber forces in war under one command.
PARIS, Sept. 19 -- A French plan to bring peace to Morocco was delayed today by one man's hesitation to cooperate in its execution.
TORONTO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Seventeen thousand workers in five General Motors plants in Ontario struck today. Their union rejected a company package offering a layoff pay plan.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Fred Hawkins of St. Andrews, Ill., and Rudolph Montgelas of the Weeburn Country Club, Darien, Conn., had the winning best-ball card in the second annual Apawamis Country Club pro-amateur benefit golf tournament today. With Montgelas helping at six holes for a total of nine strokes, the team posted 29, 30 -- 59 for a three-stroke victory.

David Bronstein of Russia clinched first place yesterday in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg. He defeated A. Fuderer of Yugoslavia after forty-eight moves in a game adjourned from the twentieth round, according to a report received through Swedish news sources.
Television station WABD is trying to obtain the Brattle Shakespeare Players for a full-length performance of "Othello" over Channel 5.
Sales and earnings of the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, Inc., for the fiscal year ended June 30 declined from the previous year, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
Stocks climbed slowly most of the session yesterday, hitting new records for the averages, and then slid down to their starting point in the final thirty minutes.
Domestic steel production last week exceeded expectations by a small margin, and this week is expected to remain unchanged, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

One of the first'private dwellIngs to be erected on the East Side in many years is planned for a vacant plot at 10 East Eighty-seventh Street, which has been purchased by 1Virs. Joseph Buttinger of Brookdale Farms, Pennington, N. J. The property was acquired from the .Valter P. Bliss estate in an allcash transaction negotiated by Douglas L. ElBman Co., Inc., as broker.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Light to fairly heavy rains in Kansas, Missouri and Nebraska caused free selling of wheat futures early today. But, although other grains were easy at the start, they moved up sharply. Corn was especially strong, registering gains of 1 cent or more from the preceding close.

Mountaineering in the Himalayas is the subject of two books scheduled for publication a week apart. One is "Everest, From the First Attempt to the Final Victory," by Micheline Morin, which John Day will issue Sept. 29.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Senator Stuart Symington charged today that the Administration was pursuing a "business-as-usual" approach toward air power at the risk of losing air superiority to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Congressional committees open the fall investigating season in earnest next month. Inquiries will range from Reds in government to the politically potent issue of skidding farm prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department swore in a new chairman of the Reserve Forces Policy Board today. He is Maj. Gen. Milton G. Baker, founder and superintendent of Valley Forge, Pa., Military Academy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19--The Republican and Democratic national chairmen held meetings in the same hotel today but were miles apart on the political situation.

IT is an irony in the fashion world that the work of Mainbocher, one of the greatest American couture designers, should be difficult to write about. Mainbocher's clothes are never revolutionary and seldom even "newsy." They frustrate fashion reporters seeking a startling lead paragraph. He has gone on for a quarter century making quiet little suits and well-behaved evening gowns for the world's best-dressed women.
TROY, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- There must be easier coaching jobs in the country. But Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's new football coach, Richard Lyon, isn't interested.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, not one to be caught asleep at the switch, puts into service today a new mechanized freight classification yard at Conway, Pa., near Pittsburgh.
Russeks' new shop at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel opens today. It is exclusively a fur shop; in Russeks' words, "a Design Studio Fur Salon . . . devoted completely to the world's most precious furs."
Justice James W. Feely reserved decision yesterday in Brooklyn Municipal Court on a move by the New York City Housing Authority to evict sixteen tenants who have refused to sign loyalty oaths.
ALBANY, Sept. 19 -- Governor Harriman will seek the Presidential nomination next year if "convinced the convention wanted him," the Democratic State Chairman said today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- Measures to force West Germany to deal directly with the East German Communist Government were being planned today in Moscow.
PARIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Forty economics officers from United States embassies in Europe met in Paris today for a briefing with George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury.
The crew of an Air Force weather reconnaissance plane that tracked Hurricane Ione for more than twenty-four hours reported last night that it seemed to be the season's worst storm.

Recently a Congressman threw a new word into the wind over Capitol Hill. Representative J. Arthur Younger, a California Republican, offered "urbiculture" to our language. Initial reaction indicated that his offer would not be accepted.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- Finland and the Soviet Union renewed their mutual defense alliance today for a period of twenty years.

Rocky Marciano and Archie Moore are set to fight for the heavyweight championship of the world tonight -- if Ione does not interfere. The 31-year-old Marciano will risk his crown against his 38-year-old challenger in a scheduled fifteen-round fight at the Yankee Stadium, starting at 10:30.

The State Mediation Board intervened yesterday in a strike of eighty clerks and managers employed by the Garfield News Company. The board called representatives of the company and District 65, Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O., to a conference tomorrow morning at its offices, 270 Broadway.

Small signs point the way along the broad paths of history. Such significant signs are hopefully evident in Washington, D. C., these first weeks of school as the nation's capital moves deeper into its second year of desegregation without any apparent hitch.
admitted past membership in the Communist party, but balked at the request that they name other members in the party.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, Sept. 20 -- The Government of President Juan D. Peron fell last night.

The Near East College Association has chosen the Oct. 5 performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House for its twenty-eighth benefit. The program will include the first performance by the ballet of "Les Sylphides."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, back from her third round-the-world trip cautioned yesterday that Moscow's new friendlier look might lull the West into forgetting that the "battle for men's minds and hearts goes on."

Public interest in the campaign of the New York City Office of Civil Defense to have every New Yorker wear an identification tag was manifested yesterday in more than seventy-five telephone calls to that office by 4 P. M. Some of the callers were telephoning as individuals and some as representatives of companies or other organizations asking for from 100 to 800 application forms for the 25-cent tags.
The Soviet decision to return the Porkkala naval region to Finland has major propaganda and psychological importance, but is of no strategic significance.
VIENNA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of Washington said today he was told while in Hungary that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty had been released from prison.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati swept to an easy 6-1, 6-0 victory today over Chris Crawford of San Francisco in the first round of the twenty-ninth annual Pacific Southwest tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Administration officials said tonight that the United States would undoubtedly recognize any new Argentine Government that showed it was in control of the country.

Keith S. McHugh, chairman of the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean, announced yesterday the selection of an executive director. He is Christopher Gilson, vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers. Mr. McHugh announced also that about Oct. 1 the group's headquarters would be opened at 63 Vesey Street.
The taxpayer, though he probably doesn't know it, is sending about $1.5 billion to Washington this year that will simply be transferred from one part of the Treasury to another and not spent.

The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee will open extensive hearings on Oct. 11 into the problems of West Coast and Alaska fisheries and the shipping industry, it was announced yesterday.
A sweeping program of Federal aid to education, on both school and college levels, was advocated yesterday by Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Democratic effort to goad the Administration into unveiling its farm plans before Congress reconvenes in January was under way today.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Coffee, onions, potatoes, rubber and hides rose; cocoa, lead, copper and zinc eased, and changes in cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar and wool were mixed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Ernie Banks of the Cubs set a record tonight with his fifth grand slam homer of the season, but the St. Louis Cardinals scored a 6-5 victory on Rip Repulski's home run with two out in the twelfth inning.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 19 -- Gov. Gen. Ghulam Mohammed resigned today. An official announcement was issued after the ailing head of state had moved out of the palace he had occupied since October, 1951.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 19 -- President Eisenhower took a vacation from Denver golf today and settled in his Rocky Mountain hideaway for a week at the trout stream.
Following is a chronological list of previous hurricanes in 1955 and those of other years that affected this or other east coast areas:
BONN, Germany, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The hard-working West Germans expect to raise their gross national product by 10 per cent this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -Excerpts from the address by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, before the American College of Hospital Administrators at its convention here today follow:
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Trading contracted in all important sections today and prices drifted lower.
The city's chief traffic officer gave a cool reception yesterday to Michael J. Quill's idea for solving both the traffic and transit problems by "locking" automobiles out of Manhattan.

The merger of Gotham Hosiery Company of New York into Chadbourn Hosiery Mills, Inc., Charlotte, N. C., was approved by stockholders of the two companies yesterday at special meetings here and in Charlotte. It will take place on Sept. 30.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines tonight ordered unlimited Government aid for storm-lashed Tampico as Hurricane Hilda sent a flood of "catastrophic proportions" over three-quarters of the port city.

An appeal to Manhattan and Bronx women to volunteer for assignments in the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was made yesterday. Registrants now can be immediately assigned to a four-session training course that will start on Oct. 17.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The twenty-second women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties, a 54-hole medal-play contest for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy, will open Wednesday at the Century Country Club here. A field of 106 will compete.

In the nine years since Juan D. Peron strode into Argentina's ornate Casa Rosada (Government House) as his country's twenty-ninth President, a three-word slogan has thrilled -- or chilled -- the Argentine people.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- New alternatives, submitted by the El Paso Natural Gas Company appeared today to have removed the obstacles from previous proposals to import natural gas from Canada.
Fedway Stores, Inc., a division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., will take over direct operation of Halliburton's, Federated's specialty-store subsidiary in Oklahoma City.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Frank Lane, general manager of the Chicago White Sox, plans to leave the club as the result of a breach with Charles (Chuck) Comiskey "that cannot be healed."
Residents of the metropolitan area battened down for Hurricane Ione yesterday while Government and welfare agencies made elaborate plans to mitigate the fury of wind, rain and high tides.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay announced today that a new schedule of service charges for processing public land transactions, mineral leases and permits will become effective Sept. 28.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- The essence of Americanism is discussion, but those devoted to that concept incur the peril of being labeled controversial, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins told delegates to the American College of Hospital Administrators today.

The American Standards Association has elected as its president J. L. Cranwell, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, it was announced yesterday by George F. Hussey, managing director and secretary of the association.

Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister for External Affairs, said here yesterday that there was "a little too much prosperity" in his country. He added that the Government was calling in business and banking leaders to find means of cutting down imports without having to impose official restrictions.

The announcement by Senator Kilgore that he intends to open full-dress hearings on proposed changes in the basic immigration law puts the Administration somewhat on the spot, as it was undoubtedly designed to do.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The Foreign Office and British security services were attacked today when the long-simmering anxiety over the Government's handling of the Case of the Missing Diplomats boiled over.

The City of New York and the port's shipping industry paid tribute yesterday to the Swedish American liner Kungsholm for a "job well done" in the rescue of twenty-nine seamen of the British freighter Argobeam last month.

Events today: Downtown Manhattan Festival Band, Battery Park, 12 noon; Interval Concert, with Phyllis Kraeuter, 'cellist; Karl Kraeuter, violinist, and Joseph Wolman, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P. M.
SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 19 -This deep South town witnessed today a courtroom session in which the touchy race relations subject received extraordinary treatment.

" The Desperate Hours," Paramount's film version starring Humphrey Bogart and Fredrie March, will have an invitational world premiere on the night of Oct. 5 at the Criterion. Joseph Hayes, author of the book and play of the same title, wrote the screen play, which was produced and directed by William Wyler.

The Argentine drama reached its inevitable climax yesterday with the fall of President Juan D. Peron. It had to be that way; there was no other possible denouement. He, alone, held the Government forces together and the whole struggle was against him and all that he stood for.
Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein was reported yesterday as definitely slated to be one of five ew candidates for Supreme Court Justice in the First District, consisting of Manhattan and the Bronx.
Hurricane Ione tore wide destruction in coastal North Carolina when it roared in from the Atlantic Ocean yesterday morning.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 19 (UP) -- Former King Norodom Sihanouk announced today that Cambodia soon would break all her remaining ties with France.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- James Sinclair, Canadian Fisheries Minister, was carried across the border from Communist China on a stretcher today with a broken leg and other injuries suffered during a visit to Soviet fisheries.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 19 -- The West German Cabinet unanimously approved tonight the agreement to establish diplomatic relations with Moscow. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was congratulated for having obtained a Soviet promise to release 9,626 prisoners of war.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept, 17 -- A new collectivization drive has been started in Hungary. The aim of the drive is to speed up the objective of socializing more than 50 per cent of the land by 1960. Hungarian agriculture is one-third socialized now.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The nation's farmers face a grim future unless action is taken immediately to relieve them of economic stress, a Democratic agricultural advisory committee said today.
Max Morris Weiss, 45-year-old Moscow-trained Communist underground leader, was arrested here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after a four-year search.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 19 -- The American film industry was urged today by Ichiro Kono, Japan's minister of Agriculture and Forestry, to "do all it can to further understanding and friendship between our peoples." Mr. Kono, described by American film sources as the "best informed" member of his governrnent on motion pictures, was guest at a luncheon here of the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- A noncontroversial start is assured for the 1955 session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene tomorrow afternoon. The only important business scheduled for tomorrow is the election of Jose Maza, a veteran Chilean diplomat, as President of the Assembly.

Improved safety and styling and increased horsepower are among new features of the 1956 cars announced yesterday by the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company. A $100 increase in the New York City delivered prices also was announced. The cars will go on display here Friday.
Walter Alston will manage the Brooklyn Dodgers again in 1956. Walter O'Malley, the club president, yesterday confirmed a statement to that effect he made Sunday night at a Dodger victory party.

BANGOR, Me., Sept. 20 (UP) -- Twelve crewmen escaped fiery death today when a four-engine refueling plane crashed and burst into flames on a runway at Dow Air Force Base. Five of the men were injured, three seriously.

The sale of Copper Canyon Mining Company's properties and assets to the Battle Mountain Copper Company for $1,000,000, was announced yesterday by Leonard I. Schreiber, president of Copper Canyon. Stockholders of Copper Canyon will meet on Oct. 18 to authorize the sale.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The "hurricane belt" has shifted northward in the last two years because of mysterious changes in upper air currents, according to Dr. Jerome Namias, chief of the Weather Bureau's Extended Forecast Sector.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- The following is a translation of the text of the pact signed today between the Soviet Union and East Germany:

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 -Governor Harriman informed the Democratic county convention in Westchester today that he had appointed George A. Brenner, Democrat, to serve as county judge until the end of this year. Immediately afterward the convention named Mr. Brenner to run for the full term of six years in the election next November.

The pennant-winning Dodgers closed their home season on a pleasant note last night. They won both games of a twilight-night double-header from the Phils, 6 -- 3 and 6 -- 1, beating the redoubtable Robin Roberts in the second affair at Ebbets Field.
Two major changes in golf rules affecting play on the greens will go into effect Jan. 1, 1956.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- A thin, spry gray-haired little lady with a trace of the United States south coast in her voice marched out of Red China today and said something unusual for an ex-prisoner of the Chinese on the mainland.
Northern textile manufacturers think they should get some tax consideration for making their mills snug and safe against floods. They have made this known to President Eisenhower.

MENDOZA, Argentina, Sept. 20 -- A high Argentine revolutionary leader said tonight that the rebel junta would seek to hold immediate elections for the re-establishment of constitutional government in the country. He said there should be no more "military governments or dictatorships."
BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Sept. 21 -- Fighting broke out early today between army troops and about 400 fanatical supporters of the ousted President, Juan D. Peron.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 -- Martial law authorities in Ankara and Istanbul tonight ordered closed five major newspapers, including the organ of the opposition party. The papers were accused of having violated censorship regulations imposed since the destructive riots of Sept.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- New individual income tax forms and instructions lacking the telltale colored stripes that adorned last year's edition came off the press today.

Change in commodity prices on the New York exchanges were irregular yesterday. Cocoa, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose; onions, sugar, wool, zinc and copper eased, and moves in coffee and potatoes were mixed.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer tonight called upon President Eisenhower to run for re-election next year as a "duty" in this time of international unrest.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 20 -- The nation's stock of atomic weapons is so big that it now amounts to "several tons of T. N. T. for every inhabitant of our plant."

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society is planning a summer music school and festival at a site not far from New York. The school and festival will be organized along lines similar to those at Tanglewood and at Aspen, Colo.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- It wasn't easy, but the Cleveland Indians snapped a four - game losing streak by beating the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 2, before 23,454 fans at Comiskey Park tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The general manager of theI :National Rural Electric Co-op-I !erative Association said today it was through a "clerical er-I
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, suggested today that the question of pay television be made a campaign issue next year.

Two arbitrage situations accounted for virtually all the 230,795-share increase in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange between Aug. 15 and Sept. 15, according to figures made public by the Exchange yesterday.
THE glib Archie Moore was at his spell-binding best one recent afternoon at his training camp in North Adams, near the western terminus for the Mohawk Trail, when a listener spoke up.
CAIRO, Sept. 20 -- Egyptian troops are withdrawing 500 meters (about 1,600 feet) from the Gaza strip border and are erecting a barbed-wire fence along stretches of their new line.
A traffic authority declared yesterday that "we are losing ground in cutting down" the accident toll, despite publicity and education.
Hurricane Ione scared off the heavyweight and the light-heavyweight champions of the world yesterday -- and then, like a temptestuous prima donna, failed to appear here.

The tenth annual exposition of the Society of Industrial Packaging and Materials Handling Engineers opened yesterday at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. Approximately 4,700 persons visited the eighty-six exhibits set up by leading companies.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration "will never put our desire to balance the budget ahead of our determination to maintain adequate military strength," Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared tonight.

Kidder Peabody Co., one of the nation's largest investment-banking concerns, has leased space for its senior officers in the twenty-seven-story building going up at 20 Broad Street, next to the New York Stock Exchange.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Lew Hoad of Australia led the way into the third round of men's singles in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today. He defeated Earl Baumgardner, Oakland, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

A nephew of the late Edward J. Flynn was assured yesterday of a Democratic nomination for the Supreme Court. He is slated to replace the former Bronx Democratic leader's brother-in-law, who is retiring.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 20 -The trial of two Mississippi white men accused of murdering a 14-year-old Chicago Negro was recessed abruptly today to allow prosecuting attorneys to examine new witnesses of "major importance."

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Medical science has new evidence tending to prove that duodenal ulcers result from failure of the body's telegraph system to signal the brain for a shutdown of gastric juices delivered to the stomach.
The Garrett Corporation, which engineers and makes products allied with the aviation, machine tool and hardware trades, attained a new high in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30.

The Callahan Zinc-Lead Company increased its board from six to nine members with the election of Joseph H. Hirshhorn, Gordon Dean and Philip D. Wilson, it was announced yesterday by Joseph T. Hall, president.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- All grain futures and soybeans were strong in early trading today. But, as usual, buyers turned cautious in the rallies and there were substantial recessions later.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Canada lodged an official protest today at the State Department in behalf of the whooping crane.

At a "modest estimate," there are 100,000 automobiles parked illegally in mid-Manhattan daily, Theodore W. Kheel asserted yesterday. The impartial chairman of the private bus industry said spot checks in the last ten days in the critical area between First and Tenth Avenues from Fourteenth to Sixtieth Street has uncovered the "shocking picture" of every street and avenue rife with cars illegally at the curb or double-parked.
In Arthur Krock's column of Sept. 9 there appears in the penultimate paragraph a grouping of queries and affirmations as follows:
TRENTON, Sept. 20 -- New Jersey will spend $34,140,751 during the present fiscal year to improve and make safer its state and Federal highways.

Secretary of Agriculture Benson, just back from Europe, where he has been working on the problem of expanding foreign markets for surplus American farm products, has been interviewed by Washington newsmen and addressed a television audience.

State forestry camps to rehabilitate juvenile offenders may be among the recommendations of the Temporary State Commission on Youth and Delinquency, State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday. A member of the commission, he spoke at a mental health institute conducted by the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

A 16-year-old youth was found guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of juvenile delinquency, sending out false distress signals that cost the Coast Guard more than $50,000 in a search for a nonexistent vessel.
The political director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations charged yesterday that President Eisenhower was being protected by a "newspaper curtain."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Secretary of Labor, James P. bIitchell, said tonight the nation was enjoying more prosperity under President Eisen-i bower than in 1952 under theI Democrats.

ATHENS, Sept. 20 -- A curious feature of this decade is the friendly association between Communists and kings. His Imperial Majesty, Haile Selassie, Conquering Lion of Judah, visited Belgrade as Marshal Tito's guest. The Yugoslav revolutionist will soon put up at Addis Ababa's royal palace.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that its profits so far this year are already three times greater than those for the same eight-month period last year.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 20 -- The Israeli radio replied today that there were no Egyptian positions within 500 meters of the truce line. The Egyptian move was termed propaganda to cover rejection of the barrier proposed by General Burns.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles won their sixth straight game and took seventh place by beating the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 2 and 7 -- 4, in a rain-plagued double-header today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 -- Panic alternated with joy yesterday in the seaside cities of Mar del Plata and Eva Peron.
The City Housing Authority has raised by $300 a year the maximum income limit for admission to its new federally aided projects.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 -- Political campaigning is nearing a climax as the Indonesian Republic's first national election approaches.
Monday's total of collections for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was 345 pints of blood. Included were 202 pints given at Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday. The close was unchanged to 8 points (40 cents a bale) higher than on Monday. Business was moderate.
Christian J. Mohn has been named president of the Norwegian America Line Agency, Inc., of 24 State Street. He succeeds the late Georg Unger Vetlesen.

City police will team up with the State Tax Commission soon to place truck road blocks here. The move is to enforce the state's mileage tax on big trucks, as well as to check on observance of city traffic ordinances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The President's Committee on Government Contracts took a preliminary step today to end discrimination in employment in the transportation industry. The committee is headed by Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

Low volume, morning losses and somewhat smaller afternoon gains characterized the stock market yesterday. Save for advances in aircrafts, a few rails, a few steels and a handful of "special situations," most changes were limited to fractions.

MANY New Yorkers with neither the time nor skill for home baking maintain their interest in chocolate cake. For them, because they rely on commercial sources for a favorite dessert, a blindfold tasting was held yesterday in The New York Times' test kitchen.

Every dictator can say, as Louis XV was supposed to have said: "After me, the deluge." They make it so. Ex-President Peron of Argentina created a vacuum around himself. No man or group of men in any element of Argentine society was allowed to become strong or popular.

THE tendency of many parents to "retire early" from the world of children's books was scored recently by a firm advocate of parent-child book sharing. Mrs. Jean Fritz, children's librarian in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., said a recent survey of the reading habits of elementary school students revealed that the majority of their parents had stopped, reading to them as soon as they had learned to read for themselves.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, said today the Administration would continue to strengthen its farm aid programs but would not be "stampeded into ill - considered actions."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Jose Maza, the Chilean lawyer-legislator elected today as president of the General Assembly has a reputation in United Nations circles as a good mediator.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Guido Cantelli, gave the first concert in Switzerland of its current European tour in Victoria Hall here tonight.

THE Sadler's Wells Ballet, which is feeding us a rich diet of new ballets and revivals these nights at the Metropolitan Opera House, last night offered us one more work in each of these categories. The new one was Frederick Ashton's "Rinaldo and Armida" and the revival was the Fokine-Stravinsky "Firebird."
A COMPREHENSIVE exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by the late Reginald Marsh opens to the public today at the Whitney Museum.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Hurricane Ione robbed the General Assembly's opening day of some of its customary color. Because weather forecasts at sunrise were unfavorable, United Nations officials decided not to raise the sixty flags that traditionally line First Avenue on meeting days.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 -- Harvard University received gifts totaling $3,471,275.70 in the second quarter of 1955. This included $1,752,434.63 for capital use and $1,718,841.07 for current use.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- An appeal was made today to Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov in behalf of Jewish writers, artists and cultural leaders who are reported to have "disappeared from public view" in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The United States declared a strict "hands off" attitude today toward the internal struggle in Argentina.

The two-story industrial building at 38-15 Thirtieth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Lanova Corporation to the Guardian Chemical Corporation. After alterations are completed, the building will be occupied by the buyer for its main office and laboratories.

The acute need for an increasing number of science students and better science teaching in high schools is finally receiving much serious thought and attention. The programs proposed by the various scientific, educational and government agencies should go a long way toward the eventual solution of the problem.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The threat of a $70,000,000 damage suit has prompted the Government to reverse itself and agree to guarantee financing for a $75,000,000 aluminum plant in Oregon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Vice-President Richard M. Nixon told San Francisco art show officials today the public should have a "full opportunity" to see a drawing depicting him as "Dick McSmear."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Following are the texts of the opening speech by the temporary president, Dr. Joseph M. A. H. Luns of the Netherlands, and the acceptance speech of the new president, Jose Maza of Chile, at the start of the General Assembly session today:

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Sept. 20 -- The men who direct and operate the national park system began today a detailed study of an ambitious program designed to give the country a parks system "worthy of the United States."

Heavy promotional efforts are being made to increase the sale of automatic electric dishwashers, which have not proven as popular as other kitchen appliances designed to take the drudgery out of housework.
The stewards had to do a lot of back-and-forth running of the film-patrol pictures before deciding who would get the money in the $29,675 Cowdin Stakes at the Aqueduct track yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The growing character -- and influence -- of the television medium is abundantly evident in British commercial television, scheduled to start Thursday evening.

PARIS, Wednesday, Sept. 21 -- French officials were reported early this morning to have reached an agreement that would permit execution of their program for Morocco to begin later today. The program would grant a measure of self-government to the North African protectorate.
Former President Juan D. Peron has a good chance to escape criminal prosecution by Argentina if Paraguay adheres to a liberal interpretation of the traditional Latin American right of asylum.
First nighters are reminded that "Henry IV, Part 1" will start promptly at 7:45 o'clock tonight at the City Center.

More than seven hundred years ago the barons of England extracted from their king at Runnymede a Great Charter, which included in its fortieth paragraph the solemn promise: "To no one will we deny justice; to no one will we delay it." Thus in this fundamental guarantee of human liberty the delay of justice was put on the same level of proscription as its denial.
Hurricane Ione spared the storm-battered Northeast yesterday. It swirled eastward into the Atlantic just before dawn after pirouetting mockingly off Norfolk, Va., for hours.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday that he would start Saturday on a four-week trip by air around the world.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company successfully completed yesterday its offering of $280,000,000 of first consolidated mortgage bonds, thus enabling it to consolidate its complex mortgage debt.
FRASER, Colo., Sept. 20 -- Nature over the Rockies last night transformed President Eisenhower's summer vacation retreat into a wintry Alpine scene.

An international conference to promote better understanding of this country's Cargo Preference Act, which reserves half of all Government aid shipments to American vessels, was advocated here yesterday by Representative Frank W. Boykin.
The free world must develop "new common denominators in terms of positive peacetime values" to meet the shift in Soviet foreign policy, Walter P. Reuther declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Asked if the new arrangement for which he said there "is no written contract," portended a Union Pacific-Milwaukee merger, Mr. Kiley said, "I don't believe so."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The United Nations recognized today the delegation of Argentina to the General Assembly despite the overthrow of the Government of Juan D. Peron.
A patrolman who has been on the police force thirteen years is facing a departmental inquiry as the result of testimony he gave in Vehicle Accident Court.

An appeal for articles to r-e-I plenish the shelves of the Op-[ portunity Shop at 46 West For-I ty-seventh Street was begun I early this week 0y a volunteerI committee headed by Mrs Ellsworth M. Statler.

Central registration for this year's general election came to an end yesterday in New York City. Indications were that fewer persons than usual took advantage of that means of qualifying as voters this year.

SEVEN theatre marquees will blaze to life next week to herald the revival of that annual war of nerves known as ticket-buying. Theatre lobbies will flare with more temperament than the stages, and it will become difficult to tell whether the bars in front of box-office windows are for the protection of customers or ticket sellers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Treasury Department said tonight it had reopened the security case of an official cited by former Senator Harry P. Cain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The Controller General has ruled that the Air Force may not go ahead with a long-term privately owned air defense communications network without specific authorization from Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Ecuadorean Ambassador Jose R. Chiriboga said today that Ecuador considers "null" and "arbitrary" a Peruvian oil concession to the Canadian-based Peruvian Oil and Minerals Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -Despite cutbacks in the United States, Free World cotton production in 1955-56 likely will be close to last season's 29,100,000 bale crop, the International Cotton Advisory Committee predicted today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- This dispatch is being written by electric light generated partly by atomic energy.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- Pham Van Dong, former Communist North Vietnam Vice Premier and Foreign Minister, has been appointed Premier in a Cabinet shuffle, according to reports by the North Vietnam radio received here today.

The city soon will lose a lesser voice in its summer symphony. That is the cheerful, insistent tinkle of the ice-cream men's bells. Since early June the shining white trucks have cruised slowly through suburban streets.

Modern kitchens and terraces with transparent glass sliding walls are some of the improvements planned in apartments in the old brownstone house at 135 East Thirty-fifth Street, which has been purchased by Brownstone Properties, Inc., a company specializing as buyers and renovators of buildings of this type.
The Overseas Press Club called upon the Argentine nation yesterday to re-establish a free press as an essential step in the "restoration of democracy" after twelve years of Peronism.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot equaled the competitive course record today as he led the field in the opening round of the fortieth Metropolitan open golf championship. Despite shifting winds, Harmon played the Fenway Golf Club course in 67 strokes, four under par.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, today named seventeen utility and securities company executives scheduled to testify in an investigation of utility company mergers this week.
Ohio Power Company sold $17,000,000 of 3 3/8 per cent first mortgage bonds and 60,000 shares of 4.20 per cent cumulative preferred stock.
An old friend of the International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to help the union out in its case against the Waterfront Commission.
Willie Mays smashed his forty-ninth and fiftieth home runs of the season yesterday as the Giants routed the Pittsburgh Pirates in a double-header at the Polo Grounds.
Almost 2,000 policemen have been put back on patrol duties since April, 1954, Mayor Wagner reported yesterday.
A PROGRAM of chamber music by the Kraeuter Trio, Karl Kraeuter, violin; Phyllis Kraeuter, 'cello, and Joseph Wolman, piano, was offered at last night's Interval Concert in Carnegie Recital Hall.
CANNED laughter may kill a new comedy show that potentially is one of the brightest ever offered on television.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 20 -- The Social Democratic caucus reluctantly agreed tonight to vote for the agreement establishing West German-Soviet diplomatic relations. The Bundestag discussion of the agreement is to begin Thursday.

The nation's stock fire insurance companies will handle half of the $503,000,000 coverage of the New York City Housing Authority. This, spokesmen for the authority announced yesterday, marks the first time the stock companies will have come in for their share of the policy.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The United States tennis champion, Tony Trabert, admitted today he had received an attractive offer -- reportedly an $80,000 guarantee -- to turn professional for Jack Kramer.
Detroit, Mich., sold $9,131,000 of various purpose bonds yesterday to a group headed jointly by Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and Drexel Co.
