CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The office machine business is entering the most dynamic five-year period in its history Fred. M. Farwell of New York, president of the Underwood Corporation, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Soviet Embassy is not angry at Representative W R. Poage, Democrat of Texas, and will give him a visa if he still wants to visit Russia, a spokesman said today.

Independent druggists are relying on improved service and new sales-stimulating items to better their competitive position, it was indicated yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual Drug, Cosmetic and Sundry Show at the Statler Hotel.
Edgar Sands de Wolfe, 85-year-old brother of the late Lady Elsie de Wolfe Mendl, international society figure, was killed in a Queens traffic accident Monday night.

THE most popular book published in France in the last few years was neither "Forever Amber," "Annapurna" nor "Bonjour Tristesse." It wasn't a novel about l'amour nor a story of danger on the heights nor peril on the seas. It was a little book about that most enduringly fascinating of all subjects to Frenchmen, the French national character, which contains many sidelights on that most enduringly fascinating subject to Englishmen, the English national character.

Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, a member of the City College faculty since 1907 and the central figure in a student strike there in 1949 has retired. His retirement became compulsory this month when he reached the age of 70.

The Board of Estimate was urged yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame to reject the proposal for construction of a $12,273,000 combined plant for the Police Academy and the City College Baruch School of Business and Public Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The tax "bite" of cities in the United States reached $64 per capita in 1954, the Government revealed today.
Representatives of all branches of the American Zionist movement pledged last night increased efforts to help Israel absorb an expected influx of Jews from North Africa.
The immediate future of the trailer ships that operated on a Hudson River run, between Albany and this city, remains clouded, despite their sale at auction yesterday.
By an overwhelming vote, delegates to the New York State Conference on Education adopted a resolution yesterday urging the Federal Government to support the nation's schools.

Today's new film is "The Left Hand of God," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama in CinemaScope and color, with Humphrey Bogart and Gene Tierney, at the Roxy. Buddy Adler produced and Edward Dmytryk directed, from a screen play that Alfred Hayes based on a novel by William E. Barrett.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The General Assembly opened its 1955 session today and voted to postpone until next year a decision on whether Communist China should hold China's place in the United Nations. The vote was 42 to 12, with six abstentions.
LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Prices moved lower on the stock market here today, reflecting the end of the bookkeeping account and the setback on Wall Street.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 20 -- President Jose Figueres expressed concern that the Communist-engineered strike on the United Fruit banana estate here was being "misrepresented" to the United States public.

Election of Laurance S. Rockefeller as a director of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation was announced yesterday by John M. Olin, board chairman, and Thomas S. Nichols, president. Mr. Rockefeller is president of Rockefeller Brothers, Inc., an investment and research organization founded in 1946 to survey the needs of venture capital in aviation, electronics and housing.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad and the Union Pacific Railroad have reached an agreement for joint operation of five passenger trains between Chicago and the West Coast.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 20 -- Israel's first United States- sponsored school of higher learning, Bar-Ilan University, opened its doors today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Is the constitutional guarantee of free speech and a free press being abridged?
The New York Academy of Medicine's proposal for free or low-cost narcotics for addicts outside institutions was widely criticized yesterday before a Senate subcommittee.
THE CURTAIN went up yesterday on an opulent collection staged by Elizabeth Arden.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20 -- America's highly developed medical and hospital services should expand to include maintenance of good health and prevention of disease, delegates to the fifty-seventh annual convention of the American Hospital Association were told today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The junta named leading army men today to replace Peron appointees at the head of the nation's police forces.

Mrs. Myrtle Power, who has been a baseball fan for sixty years, continued her perfect batting average last night on "The $64,000 Question." When Hal March, master of ceremonies on the television quiz program, threw her the $32,000 question, Mrs. Power correctly identified six major league players who had collected 3,000 or more hits during their careers.

The Department of commerce is considering four new projects to encourage further investment abroad by American businessmen. This was disclosed yesterday by Joseph M. Marrone, acting director of the Department's Office for Foreign Investment.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- A series of agreements to enhance the power and authority of East Germany's Communist Government was promulgated here today.
WE might as well know what many other nations have learned already: Marcel Marceau is a brilliant pantomimist.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Tampico officials opened Government food stores today to care for 20,000 persons homeless and hungry as a result of the devastation of Hurricane Hilda.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Gaining momentum with every stride, the Yankees are now fairly thundering along the pennant trail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The Atomic Energy Commission made a special concession today to rural electric cooperatives and other public power groups in the second phase of the Commission's program to achieve production of commercial atomic power.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- A housing industry official said today his group would play down the "Hollywood," approach when Russian building experts visit the United States next month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- The Marine Corps announced today it would accept enlistments by pre-draft-age youths in the new six-month military Reserve training program.
A banker said yesterday that it was doubtful that Americans would continue to save 6 to 7 per cent of their disposable income, as they are doing now, even if the pace of economic growth is sustained.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today the Federal Government had $91,300,000,000 in spending power available as of last May 31.

ROME, Sept. 20 -- Princes and princesses of the House of Savoy opened a family council here today to divide among themselves the millions remaining of the fortune that once belonged to King Victor Emmanuel III.

American Gas and Electric Company's earnings for twelve months ended Aug. 31 topped the $36,000,000 mark for the second month in succession and set a new high of $36,922,877. This compared with $30,515,723 a year earlier.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 -Gen. Juan D. Peron attempted today to flee from Argentina on a Paraguayan gunboat. Meanwhile, an army junta began negotiations with the leaders of the rebels who had caused the downfall of the Peron Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The railroads told Congress today that the nation's present transport policy penalizes the carriers, the shippers and the public.

The overthrow of the Argentine dictator did not go unnoticed in Wall Street yesterday. Five thousand-odd miles from the scene of the uprising, American investors began combing the list of Argentine securities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The railroads told Congress today that the nation's present transport policy penalizes the carriers, the shippers and the public.

The overthrow of the Argentine dictator did not go unnoticed in Wall Street yesterday. Five thousand-odd miles from the scene of the uprising, American investors began combing the list of Argentine securities.

A one-story building containing ten stores at 797-813 Stanley Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Jacob W. Heller, Max Rothman, Charles Kfare and Max Holland through their Roman Trading Company. The buyer is 52 Clarke, Inc., of which Albert Greenberg is president.

Four outmoded tuberculosis hospitals in the city have been closed. A tuberculosis patient used to stay on the average six to eight months in a hospital; now only four to six months. In 1949 there were 199 tuberculosis deaths here, in 1954 only 73.
FRIEDLAND, Germany, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Four Germans arrived at this repatriation center today after their release from more than ten years of Soviet captivity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- New York was envisioned today as a ghost city if private automobiles were banned in Manhattan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- Allied Artists will wind up the year by starting six new pictures in addition to William Wyler's current production, "The Friendly Persuasion," according to Walter Mirisch, the company's executive producer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A reorganization plan for the bankrupt Sacramento Northern Railway was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The railroad, a freight carrier operating in California, is now controlled by the Western Pacific Railroad Company, which owns all of the capital stock.

CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Shareholders of the Scott Paper Company at a special meeting today voted to increase the authorized common shares from 10,000,000 to 40,000,000, and the indebtedness from $50,000,000 to $150,000,000.
ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- Luncheon with Clayton Seagears, education director for the New York State Conservation Department produced some observations on deer hunting that hereby are passed along.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- The struggle for a solution of the Moroccan question has been, and is likely to remain, noteworthy for what may be called the revolt of the diehards.
GENEVA, Sept. 20 -- The United States and Communist China compromised today on bringing political issues and the Western trade embargo into their Far East talks.
Neither summer floods nor threats of hurricanes hindered the opening yesterday of the forty-first annual show of the American Dahlia Society.
WARSAW, Sept. 20 -- The Soviet campaign to persuade refugees in the Western world to return home appears to have had relatively little success so far.

THE eminent correctness of the campaign for the return of "The Threepenny Opera" was proved last night at the Theatre de Lys. Forced to vacate the Greenwich Village premises in 1954 because of a prior booking arrangement, its departure was lamented with unremitting persistence by those who had seen it and by those who had failed to get there in time.
TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- Japan issued a strong plea today for resumption of negotiations with the Republic of Korea. These were broken off abruptly by the South Korean side two years ago.

A "get acquainted" luncheon was held yesterday by the New York Chapter of the Producers Council, Inc., in honor of the newly elected offices of the New York metropolitan area chapters of the American Institute of Architects.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Net profit of the Pittsburgh Metallurgical Company, Inc., rose more than 50 per cent, in the year ended June 30, to $1,362,670 from $903,738 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
Many tickets have been sold! for the performances on the; evening of Oct. 11 and the after-i noon of Oct. 15 of "Swan Lake" by the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -The Republican National Committee established a division today to enroll "new Republicans." The committee was carrying out President Eisenhower's advice to broaden the base of the party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin said today that the new Soviet policy of "honey words" for the West was designed to "disintegrate" the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The question whether the city has the right to divert the site of the closed Neponsit Beach Hospital from park use was debated yesterday in Supreme Court, Queens.
Herman Shumlin, stage producer, resigned yesterday from the League of New York Theatres as secretary and member amid reports of a membership wrangle over questions of policy.
MENDOZA, Argentina, Sept. 21 -- Insurgents in three provinces are moving swiftly to establish the machinery of civil government.

On Feb. 1, 1951, the General Assembly of the United Nations, by a vote of 44 to 7 -- only the Soviet bloc, India and Burma dissenting -- adopted a resolution declaring that the Communist Government of China
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Federal loyalty procedures were criticized today in the summary of the tenth National Conference on Citizenship.

COOKS with epicurean palates -- and plenty of time -- may insist that sauces and gravies be made from scratch. But the housewife who has to get dinner with dispatch may rely on canned meat gravies, Franco-American, for example.

Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that the Most Rev. James H. Griffiths, an auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has been appointed pastor of the Church of St. Monica, 413 East Seventy-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The State Department was involved today in a couple of minor mysteries involving its Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Charles E. Bohlen, and the West German Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer.
The Giants clinched third place in the National League by beating the Pittsburgh Pirates twice, 7 -- 2 and 7 -- 3, yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
Gordon W. Pollock's second production of the season will be "The Innkeepers," a contemporary drama of life in a Mexican resort town starring Geraldine Page.

THE possibility of it occurring is now rather remote but a Cleveland-Brooklyn world series would have had the historians thumbing the pages of the record books to check on the raffish events of the 1920 series between the teams. This festival offered indisputable proof of the accuracy of the ancient baseball axiom that everything happens to Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Willie Miranda's thirteenth-inning single was the decisive blow today as the Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8 to 7. Baltimore scored its seventh straight victory to sweep the three-game series.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Mickey Homa, the Westchester open champion, took the lead in the Metropolitan open golf championship today.
Thank you for your able reporting of the American Legion's Special Committee on Human Rights and the United Nations. Ray Murphy is to be commended for a job well done.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The state Department announced today that it had accepted a Soviet apology for the "improper conduct" of a Soviet officer in an incident involving Representative Joe Holt, Republican of California.

In 1933 Otto Dietrich became Hitler's press chief, convinced that Adolf Hitler "was a good man who was dedicated to promoting peace and welfare for the German people." At the close of the war, imprisoned and disillusioned, he wrote what he had seen and heard in twelve years of the closest association with Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Slowpoke motorists were described today as worse than speeders in causing highway accidents. Laws to control the dawdling driver were urged at the annual meeting of the American Automobile Association.

MC CUTCHEON'S set up a runway, brought in some extra chairs and presented a fashion show yesterday on their famous-for-fabrics third floor. The occasion was a showing of designs by Vogue Patterns made entirely in M W Thomas winter cottons.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 21 -- Lieut. Gen. Pierre Georges Boyer de Latour, the Resident General, arrived tonight by plane from Paris with full powers to resolve the Moroccan crisis.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued a formal complaint today charging the Yale and Towne Manufacturing Company with failure to bargain.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21 -- The Indian Government has decided to prevent all foreign news publications from printing editions in India.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- A British Government report said today communism had influenced trade unions in Cyprus and fostered enosis agitation in the crown colony. Enosis is the Greek term for union with Greece.
The United States Government started an action yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to regain full control of Farragut Gardens, Inc., a huge housing project.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Experts here think more and more North American birds on southerly migration in the fall are being picked up by strong Atlantic westerly winds and carried Britain.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 21 -- The defending champion, Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, the ranking favorites in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship, won their first-round tests today at the Plainfield Country Club.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Charles F. Spalding of Round Hill shot a 40, 41 -- 81 to take the lead after the first round of the women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties today. The tournament for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy is a fifty-four-hole, three-day event and is being held at the Century Country Club.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta urged today that Britain grant the Mediterranean colony an act of union incorporating it into the United Kingdom.

CHICAGO, SEPT. 21 -- The Regional Port District's plans for a Lake Calumet harbor development moved closer to reality today. An underwriting syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co., and Halsey, Stuart Co., of Chicago made an offer of $24,000,000 in revenue bonds.

Soviet Russia has concluded two more conferences in Moscow with two new pacts, each of which is presented as a step toward easing tension and normalizing international relations in the "spirit of Geneva." But both pacts are already being used as propagandistic and legalistic battering rams against the Western defense system.

The four - story apartment house accommodating twelve families at 44-46 Bay Thirty-eighth Street in the Bensonhurst secion of Brooklyn has been sold by Sylvia Kantrowitz and Lizzie Solovay to the 38 Bay Realty Corporation.
Seldom except on London's Savile Row does one see the work of a master tailor, but there is a small outpost on Fifty-sixth Street that keeps this dying craft alive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- House Appropriations Committee staff members began today an intensive investigation of a big Air Force contract with private telephone companies to provide communications lines for the continental air-defense warning system.
Nine players have qualified to compete in the challengers' chess tournament in Moscow next year according to a report received yesterday through Swedish news sources.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin has sent a personal message to President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A Senate Antimonopoly subcommittee opened an investigation today designed to show that "a small and powerful group of managers" was trying to recreate the electric power trust.
A number of churchmen "seem to feel obliged to prove their sympathy for the world by performing tricks for it," a clergyman charged last night.
BROOKLYN women need not venture over the bridge to find fashion. Martin's fall and winter collection is studded with the names of good American designers and manufacturers.
A 22-year-old disabled veteran, father of two, was seized on the West Side last night. Narcotics squad detectives found nineteen pounds of marijuana in his room.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 14:...

Moteling vacationers who drove away before Labor Day and are just returning now are finding themselves in a buyer's market. On the way out things were different. Whether it was north to Canada, south to Florida or west for the big push to the Coast, a traveler had to be careful.
As a Dominican citizen who has the honored trust of representing my country in the United States I am deeply distressed by your editorial of Sept. 15 referring to the Dominican Republic.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Brazil has offered to accept a group of war prisoners left in India's custody when the Korean war ended.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Yankees, sweeping on to their eighth straight triumph, tonight assured themselves of at least a tie for the 1955 American League pennant.
The Maritime Administration has awarded a $10,524,651 contract to the Avondale Marine Ways of Westwego, La., for the construction of three small cargo ships.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows . . .

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Possible tariff cuts on nearly $2,000,000,000 worth of imports will be discussed with twenty-five foreign countries when the United States bargains for reciprocal concessions early next year.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 21 -- Moses Wright, 64-year-old Negro sharecropper, pointed out from the witness stand today two Mississippi white men as the kidnappers of his slain nephew, 14-year-old Emmett Louis Till of Chicago.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 21 -- Consumers of Tennessee Valley Authority power saved an estimated $76,400,000 during the 1955 fiscal year, the T. V. A. said today.
With an eye to the world series next week, the Yankee management took elaborate pains to minimize damage to the Stadium turf at last night's heavyweight championship fight.

Intense public interest in the rapidly growing crisis of the schools was vividly reflected in the lively sessions of the New York State Conference on Education, which has just concluded its two-day meeting here. Some eight hundred representatives of a wide variety of citizens' groups joined in the parley, a preliminary at the state level to the national White House Conference on Education in Washington two months hence.
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Premier Edgar Faure appealed to French workers tonight to end a wave of strikes that threatens to upset France's delicately balanced current prosperity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Russians gave the United States $25,000 today for sufferers of the floods in the Northeast.
The tight copper market has claimed another victim.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Diplomatic dispatches cast new light on how and why Chancellor Konrad Adenauer agreed to establish full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- With 13,174 race track fans looking on, E. W. Reiber's Crystal Star today won the Home-Bred Handicap by four lengths. Second in the six-furlong affair was Jack Delaney's Lenny G., who was a neck ahead of Ancient Greek.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- A Greek proposal for debate on self-determination for Cyprus was rejected today by the Steering Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has canceled plans for the premiere of a television show produced by a subsidiary of the Twentieth Century - Fox Film Corporation.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21 -- Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, a rebel leader, announced today that he would begin ruling Argentina tomorrow as "provisional President" of a caretaker government.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 15 -- In Algeria France is at grips with the vital core of the problem of her North African empire.

NINETTE DE VALOIS' spruce and spanking new production of "Coppelia" for the Sadler's Wells Ballet proved to be a major delight at its debut last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Dame Ninette apparently has always had a fondness for this gay and ingratiating work and has provided a new production of it every so often.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The United Nations today completed the organization of its tenth General Assembly. Vice presidents and chairmen of its important committees were elected.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 21 -- The executive vice president of the United States Savings and Loan League predicted that the nation's savings and loan business will double in size within the next decade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The United States Fish and Wildlife Service joined Canada today in protesting an Air Force plan to operate a bombing range near the Texas wintering grounds of the almost-extinct whooping cranes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21 -- The American Hospital Association was advised today to stop thinking in terms of shiny modern hospitals and to begin to plan for the care of wounded and dying civilians under the primitive conditions likely in a hydrogen bomb attack.

An 18-year-old boy told Senate investigators yesterday how a Christmas party in a West Forty-sixth Street flat had turned into a heroin "skin-popping" spree for fifteen young persons. The experience led him into narcotics addiction and he became a burglar to maintain the costly habit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- That excellent jurist, Chief Judge John Biggs Jr. of the Third Circuit, the chairman of a judicial committee to find means to speed litigation in United States courts, can be relied on to attack his task with the vigor and industry its gravity deserves.
BASLE, Switzerland, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- The New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra under Dimitri Mitropoulos gave the second concert of its Swiss tour here tonight.

BERLIN, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The leaders of Communist East Germany said today on their return from Moscow that their country was now "truly sovereign" and would not unite with West Germany under present conditions.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Manfred Germar of West Germany upset America's Rod Richard in the invitation 100-yard dash today in the international track and field meet at White City Stadium.

The financial district took note of the overthrow of the Peron Government in Argentina this week, and its initial interpretation, at least, was bullish. Activity centered largely on the international "conversion" bonds of that republic. On Tuesday the American market raised its bid price on these 100-peso obligations (whose par value is about $7.22) to $2.50, as compared with $2.25 last week.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 21 -- Argentine exiles in Montevideo celebrated today the overthrow of President Juan D. Peron. They attended a thanksgiving mass at the cathedral for their deliverance from the Peron regime and prayed for their return to their own country without fears.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Tomorrow the calm of the London night will be broken by Britain's first television commercial -- an appeal to the English viewer to use the proper toothpaste lest he rattle around Mayfair without that cool, cool taste.
Port employers have widened contempt charges against leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association in connection with the eight-day strike earlier this month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The Government will offer up to 1,000,000 bales of its surplus cotton for export sale at cut-rate prices after Jan. 1, it was announced today.
The New York City Housing Authority is exploring the idea of selling nonsubsidized housing projects to private cooperatives.
IN "Henry IV, Part 1," which was put on at the City Center last evening, Jerome Kilty plays Sir John Falstaff. He has also staged the performance.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The United States is prepared to outline in further detail to the Soviet Union President Eisenhower's plan for an early warning system against surprise atomic attack, it was made known here today.
The market for new offerings of municipal bonds was busy yesterday as ten municipalities offered approximately $58,000,000 of bonds to the public.

Rocky Marciano had the hardest time in his entire career beating Archie Moore at the Yankee Stadium last night. The Brockton Blockbuster, the holder of the heavyweight championship of the world, knocked out the 38-year-old Moore in 1 minute 19 seconds of the ninth of a scheduled fifteen-round bout, but before he did he was in desperate danger himself.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (Canadian Press) -- A proposed exchange of major domestic and international air services between Canada's two big airlines has run into a problem with the Mexican Government, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- No matter what happens in the American League between now and Sunday, the Yankees are assured of at least a tie for the pennant. This not-at-all-surprising situation developed tonight after the Cleveland Indians dropped a 7-2 decision to the Chicago White Sox before 16,856 fans at Comiskey Park.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today.

NEWARK, Sept. 21 -- The advantages of an 11-cent weekly riding permit over the use of bus tokens, which would fit subway turnstiles in New York City and Philadelphia, were presented today at a hearing of the Public Utilities Commission.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- Greater independence is being given to local organizations of the Soviet Communist party and criticism from below is being encouraged in preparation for the Twentieth Party Congress to be held next February.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Federal Trade Commission published a set of "guides" today for its own use in appraising advertising claims of cigarette companies. The companies are expected to spend $80,000,000 in advertising next year.

The sale of the city-owned Washington Retail Market site and building to private interests was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor Wagner by Acting City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.

MOTHERS of pre-schoolers who sit glassy-eyed and chill of foot on park benches while their youngsters take their pleasure near at hand are likely to look forward to the time when the children will be enough to go out and play by themselves.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21 -- Harvard College this fall is widening the doors to advanced study for qualified students both here and in the secondary schools of the nation.
The designation "world's largest mnaufacturer of earth moving machines," passed from R. G. LeTourneau, Inc., two years ago. But the company is still doing things in a big way.
Relentless training, day in and day out since the latter part of May, enabled Rocky Marciano to keep his world heavyweight championship last night.
A proposed new maritime labor board to handle all disputes in the waterfront and shipping industries could make a "significant contribution" in the maritime field, according to Francis T. Greene.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A record $23,500,000,000 volume of business seems assured the chemical industry this year, the Government said today.

THE most engaging book on foreign relations I have read in a long time is Rose C. Feld's "My Aunt Lucienne."* This opens no new windows on the mysteries of Yalta. It doesn't explain why the Kremlin gremlins have suddenly become so ruthlessly jolly. It doesn't beat us over the head with a-new-policy-for-America statistics on what we must do to be saved.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 13 points yesterday, with the old October contract the strongest.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Sept. 21 -- The inhabitants of Cordoba celebrated tonight the establishment of Argentina's revolutionary provincial government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Humphrey Bogart has organized a new independent company, Mapleton Productions, and has acquired film rights to "Underworld, U. S. A." as the basis for the company's first picture. Negotiations for a co-financing and distribution arrangement with Allied Artists was said to be nearing completion.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Hard-hitting George Johnson caught Bobby Dykes with vicious knockdown punches in the sixth and tenth rounds tonight as he pounded out an easy decision over the world's sixth ranking middleweight fighter.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 21 -- Israeli armed forces occupied the El Auja demilitarized zone on the Sinai Peninsula frontier today. Two Egyptian soldiers were wounded, one seriously, in the action, which was denounced by Egypt and United Nations officials as a violation of the Egyptian-Israeli armistice.
IN the process of looking into more timely aspects of the outdoors picture, this reporter asked Clayton Seagears in Albany what he thought of the practice of making pets of wild animals.

When Belmont Park opened its spring meeting last April, the Brookmeade Stable's 3-year-old Sailor was the headliner. He won the Toboggan Handicap. There was the same headliner at yesterday's fall opening at dear old Belmont.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UP) -- The former University of Southern California star, Gil Shea, scored the biggest upset of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament when he defeated Ken Rosewall of Australia today, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.
A fireman flung himself from a twelfth-story window to a ledge one story below to thwart a suicide yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 21 -- In contrast win the Hungarians in Budapest the people here are quiet, almost glum. Here they mind their own business. The United States visitor with a camera attracts attention but no acquaintances.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Match play in the women's Trans-Mississippi Golf tournament started today with most of the favorites gaining the second round.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Sept. 21 -- The Democratic administrations of Pennsylvania and New Jersey called today for Federal leadership and financial aid in the development of the Delaware River.
A quiet but thorough loyalty inquiry has rooted out thirty-five subversive employes from city jobs in the last thirteen months, Mayor Wagner disclosed yesterday.
TRENTON, Sept. 21 -- The little engine that could, henceforth may not. That is, if its wish is to toot its noisy whistle within the Borough of Dumont between the hours of 1 and 7 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A record loss of $799,061,464 on Federal farm price support operations during the 1955 fiscal year was recorded today.

Negotiations have been completed for the purchase of an aluminum sheet and foil plant at Cap de la Madeleine in Quebec by the Reynolds Metals Company. The purchase involves between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000.
MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept. 21 -- A revolution in bank accounting was forecast with the unveiling here today of a plump automatic bookkeeper named ERMA. ERMA weighs twenty-five tons.
New York basked yesterday in a return of pleasant, low humidity weather.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- It probably never happened before anywhere in any year. The football coach at Syracuse has taken so optimistic an outlook that the man who beats the drum for the team has had to put on the breaks.

Chrysler stock, as if inspired by some unrevealed news development, made a sensational spurt in the final thirty minutes of yesterday's market session and gave The New York Times industrial average its best gain since July 7.
Fifty leading Democrats from New York and other states were the guests last night of Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall and Democratic national committeeman from New York.

A REFRESHINGLY old-fashioned flavor permeates the dinner parties given by Mr. and Mrs. Peter Greig in an apartment just off Washington Square. The general plan is interesting enough to be copied by other local hostesses, who may be weary of the casserole, the buffet and similar expedients of entertaining.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 "Our Town," the Thornton Wilder play presented earlier this week over the National Broadcasting Company television network, will be filmed for a weekly television program, according to Sol Lesser the movie producer.

Judge Francis L. Valente of General Sessions, a Bronx City Court Justice and a Bronx Representative in Congress were chosen yesterday to round out a Democratic slate for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District.
Irish and Belgian linen manufacturers are planning aggressive campaigns to promote the sale of pure linen products for the home, spokesmen said yesterday.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Campbell Soup Company in its fiscal year ended July 31, according to the annual statement issued yesterday.
Sales along Second Avenue featured realty activity reported in Manhattan yesterday. Operators were among the buyers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Navy said today that it had won a great victory in the Arctic this summer in unloading vast quantities of supplies to build and equip radar defenses.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 21 (AP) Princess Virginia Ira Fuerstenberg, 15 years old, was married today to Prince Alfonso Hohenlohe-Langenburg, 31, in this ancient canal city. They left for a wedding trip to Niagara Falls, N. Y.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Economic headaches inherited from the regime of Juan D. Peron will trouble Argentine Government administrators for a long time, an economist familiar with the situation predicted today.

Rocky Marciano wanted to be a baseball player, but he's much more satisfied with being the heavyweight champion of the world. He once reported as a catcher to the Chicago Cubs, who let him go because he didn't have a good right hand.

Committees are meeting this week to complete plans for the Blue Grass Ball to be held in the Persian Room of the Plaza next Thursday. The event, a dinner dance, sponsored by Elizabeth Arden, will benefit the Travelers Aid Society of New York. There will be a presentation of gowns from the Arden salon.

An industrial development is planned for a seven-acre tract at the northwest intersection of Southern Boulevard and the new Smithtown cutoff road at Nesconsett in Smithtown Township, L. I. The property has been purchased by the Restive Realty Corporation of Farmingdale from Raymond P. Hogan of Rye, N. Y., in a transaction negotiated by Country Life Real Estate of Fort Salonga as broker.

Morris L. Ernst's dislike of the principle of governmental regulation of the waterfront will strike a sympathetic chord in the minds of many thoughtful citizens. But in the face of incapacity or unwillingness of the waterfront to regulate itself, those of us who prefer self-regulation as a means of orderly conduct of private business must support governmental intervention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Consent decree settlements were entered into today by two of the smaller defendant companies in the Government's anti-trust suit. The suit charges a group of motion picture studios and distributors with conspiring to refuse to license 16 mm. prints of movies for television showings.

IT'S ONLY human to forget the trials of other generations of homemakers and remember only the "good" in the "good old days" -- when ceilings were twelve feet high and every family had at least one hired girl to help out in the kitchen and laundry.
Five persons were fatally burned and five injured early yesterday in a five-alarm fire on Mermaid Avenue in Coney Island. Official inquiries were started immediately into the cause of the tragedy.

TRENTON, Sept. 21 -- New Jersey is confronted with a serious shortage of housing for families in the low and middle-income groups. About 220,000 such families, priced out of the prevailing real estate market, are living in substandard dwellings or doubling up with relatives and friends.

Is the lid about to pop off the cost of living? That lid has sat pretty securely for three straight years, but mounting pressures are threatening to lift it loose. Underneath: the noisome brew of inflation.

Ancient Archie Moore not only can talk a good fight, but he can fight one, too. The old gentleman gave a rousing exhibition in his bold bid for Rocky Marciano's world heavyweight championship at the Yankee Stadium last night.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., sold $40,000,000 of 3 5/8 per cent debentures yesterday to a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co.

Forty-one advertising slogans passed the supreme test the other day -- they were remembered by advertising men. However, only seven slogans received more than one mention and only two were remembered by as many as four of the eight ad executives polled.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union has denied selling arms to Arab countries or even negotiating such sales, the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced tonight.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 (UP) -- Gus Bell drove in eight runs with a grand-slam homer, a double and a single today to help the Cincinnati Redlegs gain a 14-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended on last Friday decreased 2,172,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 152,165,000 barrels, compared with 154,337,000 a week earlier and 151,787,000 a year ago.
Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, new revolutionary President of Argentina, is a proud professional solder, a devout Roman Catholic and a man with no stomach for "petticoat rule."

As one dictatorship falls in Argentina another rises in Colombia. Gen. Juan Peron goes into what we may hope will be oblivion and Lieutenant General Rojas Pinilla steps onto the stage in a role as evil as that of the Argentine dictator and in a country that also is important in a material sense and has a long history of democracy now interrupted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Considerable activity developed in soybeans today as shorts covered freely. There also appeared to be some investment buying. Soybeans closed 3 1/4 cents off to 2 cents up. The market was extremely tight most of the session.
A design for a flying aircraft carrier able to launch a score or more jet fighters was put forward yesterday.
Japan has ousted Great Britain from her traditional position as the world's chief exporter of new merchant ships.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Freight Forwarders Institute asked Congress today to protect them from the unregulated competition of groups calling themselves "shippers' associations."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A House of Representatives subcommittee embarked today on a study aimed at pruning at least 10 per cent from the Federal payroll to make possible an early tax cut.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- A categorical denial of "conspiracy" was made today by counsel for five motion-picture companies charged by the Department of Justice with having contrived by "concerted" actions to withhold, unlawfully 16-mm. prints of movies from television.

An Air Force colonel who shot down ten enemy planes in Korea held a briefing yesterday for freshmen at Columbia University. Col. James K. Johnson was at the Morning-side Heights campus as part of an Air Force show designed to acquaint the freshmen at Columbia College with the university's Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Villanova University today commemorated the 400th anniversary of the death of St. Thomas of Villanova, a Spaniard who is patron saint of the 112-year-old school.

Today's new film is "Kiss of Fire," a Universal-International adventure in color with Jack Palance, Barbara Rush and Rex Reason, at the Palace. Samuel Marx produced and Joseph M. Newman directed from a screen play that Franklin Coen and Richard Collins based on a novel by Jonreed Lauritzen.

There must be at least sixty-four thousand folk tales about the orphaned boy, the unthroned prince, the seeming simpleton who accepts the king's impossible challenge in order to win the princess' hand. Slay me the dragon, bring me a ship that moves on land, return with the golden fleece, announces the king.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- A new spirit of independence and national self-assertiveness is the most vivid impression received by a foreigner visiting Poland these days.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The British public was said today to be "bewildered and puzzled" over the object and effectiveness of civilian defense measures.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N. J., scored a major upset in the twenty-ninth annual Pacific Southwest tennis championships today by defeating Lewis Hoad of Australia, 0 -- 6, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2. Richardson advanced to the semi-finals.
Four major roasters announced a 4-cent-a-pound increase in the wholesale price of coffee yesterday. A fifth, Chock Full O'Nuts, raised wholesale prices 3 cents a pound to 98 cents.

ANY week now, depending on the weather, four keepers of the Bronx Zoo will go forth in rowboats on Cope Lake in Bronx Park, to try to round up seven pelicans. These tropical birds apparently don't know when winter is coming, and they put up a struggle to avoid indoor quarters.

THE ADVANTAGES as well as the hazards, of changing fashions in home furnishings were analyzed yesterday by John Van Koert, a furniture designer. The occasion was a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League, at the Roosevelt Hotel.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Quick Chief, the first horse his owner ever bought, paced the fastest race of his career today to easily win the $66,683 Little Brown Jug.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- Casey Stengel was receiving congratulations today.

New body styling and more powerful engines are offered in the expanded 1956 Mercury car line. Thirteen models, two more than last year, comprise the line, presented yesterday by the Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union and the Ukraine dissented today against a committee recommendation that their assessments for the United Nations budget be increased slightly.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Country Club posted an 83 today for a 165 total and a one-stroke lead in the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy golf tournament at her home course.

LIKE many other New Yorkers, "The Goldbergs" have decided to move from their city apartment into a new home in the suburbs. This was the theme of the first in a new series for Gertrude Berg's domestic comedy, seen on film last night over Channel 5.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, warned today that the nation, despite its high level of prosperity, faced a critical shortage of skilled workers.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Sept. 22 -- An Israeli Army spokesman said Arab infiltrators had opened fire on a crowded bus with submachine guns and hand grenades today. Three persons were killed and nine wounded.

Secretary Dulles had some cheerful things to say yesterday in his address before the General Assembly of the United Nations. Undoubtedly it is true, as he remarked, that the international situation has improved in some important respects since the Assembly met a year ago.
Court hearings on charges of civil and criminal contempt against the International Longshoremen's Association and four of its top officers were postponed yesterday until Oct. 4.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (UP) -- An official of the Detroit Tigers said today their American League franchise probably would be sold despite a court decision that the Briggs family legally may retain control of the club.

BERN, Switzerland, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- The 104 members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra were guests at a reception here tonight given in their honor by the United States Embassy in Bern.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The best business year in history was forecast for 1955 by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today.
BARI, Italy, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Bari Trade Fair, biggest in the Mediterranean area, today celebrated the first official "American Day" in its thirty-nine-year history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A simple color test to detect an intestinal tumor often linked with diseased heart valves was announced today by the National Institutes of Health.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Public officials promulgated today a new system to try to mitigate "smog" sieges before they build up in Los Angeles.
While the Marciano - Moore fight qualified in every respect as a financial and artistic success, the International Boxing Club had more than a few post-bout headaches yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The Anglo-American film agreement that limits the annual remittance of United States film earnings to $17,000,000 has been extended without change for another year.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed today to an unhappy and restless Bundestag to approve the Moscow agreement establishing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

An interesting point was raised yesterday at Columbia's first weekly luncheon of the football season. It was whether teams opening the season against each other should exchange information as to the basic formations they planned to use.

Detroit Steel Corporation will put $30,000,000 of first mortgage sinking fund 4 7/8 per cent bonds due Oct. 1, 1970, on the market today. The price will be 98.69 per cent and accrued interest to yield 5 per cent to maturity.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Leaders of jurisprudence from many nations began today a conference on "Government Under Law." It is a tribute to John Marshall, who pointed the way to interpretation of the United States Constitution.

Futures prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cottonseed oil registered the sharpest advance of the year and wool was strong. Other commodities closing higher than Wednesday's final quotations were soybean oil, cocoa, rubber, burlap, potatoes and onions. Coffee, sugar, zinc and copper were mixed and hides eased.

Wall Street was following the news tickers as closely as the market tape yesterday. The list as a whole was generally ignored. Interest centered on several special situations and these reacted sharply on late news developments and rumors.
At its monthly meeting yesterday the board of directors of the New York Central Railroad Company announced a plan to purchase the capital stock of two other railroads.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Archbishop Richard J. M. Cushing said today that not one of the forty Massachusetts delegates chosen to attend the White House Conference of Education in November represented the Roman Catholic elementary and secondary schools in the state.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Selective Service has proposed relaxing draft regulations to exempt most young fathers and all men over 26 years old from compulsory military service.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Fred Haas Jr. of Claremont, Calif., and Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., carded five-under-par 67's today to share the opening-round lead in the $43,000 open golf tournament at the Charles River Country Club.

Rocky Marciano, with a puffed eye and a shy smile, held court at the Hampton House yesterday. The undefeated heavyweight champion of the world received compliments add congratulations steadily through his press conference for the beating he had given to Archie Moore in their fight at Yankee Stadium the night before.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Fifteen persons died in the flaming wreckage of a British airliner that crashed in a desert sandstorm near the Idriss Airport early today.

There could be no more fitting celebration of the 200th anniversary of Chief Justice Marshall's birth than the three-day conference that began yesterday at the Harvard Law School, made possible by the generosity of the Rockefeller Foundation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Frank Lane applied a formal "squeeze play" on the Comiskey family today in his quest to be released as general manager of the Chicago White Sox.

Daystrom, Inc., has signed an agreement to sell the assets, name and business of its printing equipment subsidiary, American Type Founders, Inc., to an investment group headed by David Berdon and Jay Levine of New York.

The 200th anniversary of Mozart's birth will be the central feature of the 1955-56 Music Subscription Series of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
The Australian Government presented a $50,000 check to the American National Red Cross yesterday to aid flood victims in six eastern states.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Vick Chemical Company in its fiscal year ended June 30, according to the annual report released today.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Janet, a small but dangerous hurricane, roared westward in the Caribbean tonight after causing heavy damage and leaving thousands homeless on Barbados Island.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- New polio cases for the week that ended Monday totaled 1,950. This continued the gradual decline from this year's peak of 2,289 for the week that ended Aug. 27.

NORTH WILDWOOD, N. J., Sept. 22 -- Plans for the establishment of an ocean ferry service to connect the Garden State Parkway at Cape May with Lewes, Del., were reviewed here tonight for the benefit of South Jersey municipal and industrial officials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A program to promote better labor - management relations throughout the world was offered today to the International Labor Organization.

Aggregate draft indebtedness of Latin-American countries to United States importers rose $2,900,000 in August, to $140,600,000. This is the highest amount since December, 1954, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported in its monthly survey of fourteen large commercial banks.

The one-story industrial building at 396-400 Bloomfield Avenue in Bloomfield, N. J., has been leased by the Crocker-Wheeler Company, a subsidiary of the Elliott Company. The lessee, which recently moved its manufacturing operations from East Orange to Jeannette, Pa., will use the premises as a regional sales office and for the warehousing and distribution of its products, which include electric motors and generators.

EL AUJA, Palestine, Sept. 22 -- The Israeli Army remained in control today of all but a few hundred square yards of the ninety-five-square-mile demilitarized zone here. Neither Egyp tian nor Israeli forces had made any move to comply with the United Nations truce chief's request for withdrawal.

Ours is a changing city, as passing events perpetually conspire to remind us. And the business of making New York over was never more active than it is today. It is an interesting process, and, at times, alarming to some of us, as it removes familiar landmarks and replaces them with what may be the image of the future.

ALBION, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Republican state chairman tonight described Governor Harriman's endorsement of Federal aid for schools as a bid "to win Southern support for his Presidential ambitions."

Three cheers for your editorial ("Patch Up the Shuttle ?", Sept. 19) in which you suggest the need for river-to-river transportation! But why stop at the rivers? A really efficient railroad would run from Queens to New Jersey via Forty- second Street.
SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 22 -- This state completed today its case against two white men on trial for the kidnap-murder of Emmett Louis Till, 14-year-old Chicago Negro.
A Parks Department plan to rebuild a run-down eight-block waterfront esplanade at Manhattan Beach into an extension of the Coney Island boardwalk was killed yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The National Agricultural Advisory Commission met today with Administration farm officials to discuss falling farm prices and income.

Developments in Argentina are being watched with a mixture of anxiety and hope -- mostly hope. The fall of General Peron is one of the most important events of contemporary Latin-American history. The echoes are resounding all over the world and doubtless they sound ominous to other dictators from Madrid to Bogota.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Prices of most grains climbed sharply today.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 17 -- French authorities here propose to give a greater degree of supervised self-government to Moslem natives in rural areas, where the current revolt was incubated.
MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Sept. 22 -- Governor Harriman of New York expressed today his "emphatic opposition" to conclusions in the Hoover Commission report on water resources and power.

A NEW trio of principals took over last night for the second performance of Ninette de Valois' restaging of "Coppelia" by the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. Maryon Lane was the Swanilda, Brian Shaw the Franz and Leslie Edwards the Dr. Coppelius.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Government closed its aluminum production expansion goal today and refused to reopen production goals for three other materials that it had closed earlier.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union has offered conditionally to accept President Eisenhower's plan for the exchange of military "blueprints" with the United States. Authoritative sources said tonight that a letter to President Eisenhower from Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, made the following proposals:

Requests that the Union of South Africa and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics remove import restrictions on American handbags have been made by the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry. Russia has never been a factor in the American export market but recent interest in American styles indicate a potential market according to Max Berkowitz, director of the association.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Shell Oil and Esso Petroleum, British companies, have ordered forty oil tankers. Of these eighteen will be built in foreign yards, which can offer earlier delivery than Britain's.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
UTICA, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Edward A. Hanna asked Governor Harriman today to replace the Central New York State Parks Commission "by a commission which will function effectively.''

If the Yankees bag this American League pennant, which now seems a "can't miss" proposition, they will owe a special debt of gratitude to a player they gave up on a few years back. That's Tommy Byrne, who refused to give up on himself.

The New York City Transit Authority is opposed to the construction of any new subway lines or extensions until it has completed the major part of its modernization and rehabilitation of existing facilities.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan declared today that Britain was served by the most loyal and most efficient foreign service at home and abroad that any country could have.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The United States called on members of the United Nations General Assembly today to make the "spirit of Geneva" permanent.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 22 -- A prominent Argentine exile warned today that the end of the dictatorship in Argentina could not mean the immediate return of full democracy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Art Doering of Inwood scored birdies on the last two holes today to gain a tie for the Metropolitan open golf championship with a fellow Long Island professional, Al Broach, of Cherry Valley. Each finished with 285 for seventy-two holes.

PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Jacques Soustelle, Governor General of Algeria, asked today for Government approval of military and administrative measures to meet a situation of "growing gravity" in areas where outlaw terrorism is rampant.
Six thoroughbred St. Bernard dogs will be "guests of honor" at the annual Pets on Parade, a dinner-dance for the benefit of the Mobile Clinic of the Speyer Hospital for Animals.

FRASER, Colo., Sept. 22 -- The White House announced tonight that it would release the text of Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's message to President Eisenhower within the next forty-eight hours. A speedy reply to the Soviet Premier's note appeared to be in prospect.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Latin-American countries, in their role as small states, expressed gratification today that tensions among the world's great powers appeared to be on the wane.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 22 -- Acts of violence that took three lives and left four other persons wounded in Morocco last night and today indicated a new deterioration in the political situation here.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- Five West German shipyards are designing new liners to build up the country's passenger fleet again, the Transport Minister, Hans Christoph Seebohm, said today.
Retail merchants expect to sell the American public more merchandise this coming Christmas season than ever before.
Bernard F. Gimbel chairman of the board of Gimbel Brothers, was honored at a dinner last night for his work in promoting the city's convention and recreation facilities.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 Producer-director Joseph Shaftel, the head of the newly formed LaSalle Productions, announced his production schedule today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 8 to 19 points yesterday, closing not far from the lows of the day.

ONLY a few price changes were noted yesterday by the City Department of Markets in its regular weekly check of the retail cost of perishable foods. Two pork cuts, ribs of beef and stewing chickens were reduced in price. All other meat and poultry remained at last week's levels.
Thomas Paine has risen from the ashes of Colonial history to stir a modern controversy.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 -- The role of Government in health was praised and criticized by speakers who addressed the fifty-seventh annual convention of the American Hospital Association today.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, predicted today the Soviet leaders eventually would give ground on the questions of German reunification and European security.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The official revelation that farm price supports cost the Treasury (the general American taxpayer) almost $800 millions in the twelve months that ended last June 30, almost twice the amount disbursed in the prior fiscal year, may check what some agricultural economists are referring to as the "panic" among Republican politicians over the current drop in farm income.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy urged President Eisenhower today to "fight back" at critics of the Administration's security program by taking "personal leadership" of a Republican counter-attack.

IN the eighteenth century Voltaire wrote a book about the virtues of the English form of government. Laurence Sterne wrote one about the pleasure of traveling in France: " 'They order,' said I, 'this matter better in France.'" Ever since then writers in both countries have been writing with wonder and affection about the essential differences between the two societies separated by only twenty-one miles of the English Channel.

In 1951, George W. Shepherd Jr. flew from London to Uganda to work for the Federation of Uganda African Farmers. He spent two years helping the Uganda people form cooperatives, cure coffee, gin cotton and market their products.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Israel apologized today for "inadvertently" capturing the headquarters of the United Nations Israel-Egypt Armistice Commission at El Auja Tuesday night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State Dulles before the General Assembly today:
May I comment on your editorial "Light on Dictatorships" and on your derogatory references to the Government of Marcos Perez Jimenez of Venezuela, in The Times of Sept. 15.
The 285,000 daily riders of the Long Island Rail Road got simultaneous relief yesterday from threats of a strike and -- for the present -- of a fare increase.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- The State Board of Law Examiners made public today the names of the 833 persons who passed the examination for admission to the bar that was given last June 29-30. A total of 1,644 applicants took the test.

Subject to ratification, a plan is being discussed under which the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre's complement, stationed at England's Stratford - on - Avon, would journey to the United States as guests of the American Shakespeare Festival.

PERUGIA, Italy, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Seymour N. Siegel, director of New York's municipal radio station, WYNC, was elected president of the General Assembly of the Prix Italia last night. The United States is a member of the organization through the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.
A REMINDER that Maine's upland game season would open on Oct. 1 came from Bob Elliot at Augusta with the promise that results were likely to be good.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks increased by $57,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Twenty members of the French Parliament had a rousing three-hour conversation with Nikita S. Khrushchev and Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin in the Kremlin today.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company declared the usual quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share yesterday, payable on Nov. 1. Directors also voted a year-end dividend of $1.15 a share, payable on Dec. 14, and a 5 per cent stock dividend payable on Dec. 21.

A Federal prisoner, taken in handcuffs before a Senate subcommittee, described yesterday the workings of a criminal combination that runs marijuana from Texas to New York and carries heroin back to the Southwest.
TOKYO, Sept. 22 -- Japan accused the Soviet Union today of using its new accord with West Germany to put pressure on Tokyo for peace treaty concessions.
The radio and television industries were asked yesterday to cooperate in the forthcoming campaign of the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean.

BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 22 -- The starvation diet that Bordentown Military Institute football squads have endured for the past two years seems to be over. The feeling on the Little Army campus is that the Cadets' twelve-game losing streak is sure to end this season.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 22 -- Perils created for motorists by the automotive industry engine power race were outlined today by the American Automobile Association.

The seven-story apartment house for twenty-nine families at ,407-8 Central Park West, near West 100th Street, has been purchased by Phillip P. Zipes, i operator. It is 51 by 100 feet 'and is assessed at $225,000.

THERE was a primitive beauty to the enthralling Rocky Marciano-Archie Moore bout at the Yankee Stadium the night before last. It was like a jungle fight between a bull elephant and a tiger. The tigerish Moore was swift, clever and elusive, dangerous with his slashing sorties until the end. The elephantine Marciano was the implacable destroyer, impervious to clawing as he plodded ever onward in a ceaseless effort to land the crusher.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Caterpillar Tractor Company today obtained a $10,000,000 credit from the Export-Import Bank.
When the Broad Hollow Steeplechase had its fortieth running at Belmont Park a year ago, Montpelier's Shipboard was the winner and Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji was the runner-up.
A stalled elevator gave its thirteen passengers a not-too-uncomfortable excuse for being two hours and forty minutes late to work yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Investment bankers who sought a merger of two Pacific Northwest power companies were asked today to furnish a complete list of their customers owning stocks in the companies.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (UP) -- Eleven unions representing 800,000 nonoperating railroad workers broke off negotiations with the railroads today and threatened a strike on some roads within a week.
Police and firemen converged yesterday on two Manhattan buildings in response to calls that a man had been observed near the edge of the roof of one and another man on a window ledge of the other.

Plans for the anniversary cocktail dance on Nov. 9 at the Pierre for the benefit of the Children's Health Service are being furthered by several teas held at the homes of persons working for the dance's success.
HARTFORD, Sept. 22 -- The Connecticut Commission on Civil Rights said in a report today that segregation existed in 40 per cent of the public housing projects in the state's larger communities.
The debut of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television program about the history of air power has been postponed; probably until early next year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Waterway operators told Congress today that if the railroads got the free hand recommended by a Cabinet-level committee the river and canal barges would have to go out of business as common carriers.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Beneficial Standard Life Insurance Company of Los Angeles has purchased with stock a major interest in Union Casualty and Life Insurance Company of New York, it was announced today by Leo Perlman, executive vice president of Union Casualty.

B. Altman Co. will open a suburban department store early next year on Morris and Essex Turnpike in Short Hills, N. J. The building will be of white glazed brick with panels of yellow brick. There will be two principal selling levels and a third-level penthouse with an exterior of glass and metal paneling.

Consumers Power Company reported yesterday a new high in gross operating revenues of $181,721,630 for the twelve months ended Aug. 31. This represented a gain of 9.55 per cent over the $165,887,384 reported a year earlier. Electric revenues represented $124,011,479 of the total, or a gain of 10.34 per cent over those for the 1954 year, while gas revenues increased by 8.11 per cent.
GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Secrecy surrounded a conference of American and European political, economic and military leaders that opened at this Alpine resort today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- American radiologists were told today by three New York' radiation therapists that regardless of the that the 1,000,000 volt X-ray method of treatment of lung cancer, the survival rates were low and described such treatment as "a disappointing business."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- John Ford, four-time winner of Academy Awards for motion picture direction, soon will turn his talents to television. As his first effort he will direct "The Bamboo Cross" for "Jane Wyman's Fireside Theatre."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The executive committee of American University's Board of Trustees has recommended that Prof. Herbert Fuchs, key witness in a Congressional investigation of communism in government, be dropped from the law faculty.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 -- The broad outlines of the development of the revolt that deposed Juan D. Peron are beginning to appear.

Leases have been signed byI ten maor national trade shows for space in the twelve-story New York Trade Show Building at 500 Eighth Avenue, between Thiy-fifth and Thirty-sixth Street. This brings to thirty the number of shows that have booked space, according to Duane W. Carlton, executive director of the bhilding,

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Ray M. Gidney, U. S. Controller of the Currency, told state bank supervisors today that Federal banking laws need overhauling to permit tighter supervision of bank mergers and other consolidations.
The permanent reactivation of an Army camp, closed as unneeded last year, is, in effect, the price the Army is being asked to pay to secure long-term maneuver rights in Louisiana.

The Republicans nominated a woman last night as their candidate for one of seven vacancies on the Supreme Court in The First Judicial District. The district comprises New York (Manhattan) and Bronx Counties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The powerful Steering Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected tonight a proposal for Assembly discussion of bloodshed and rioting in French Algeria.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Like Ben Schwartzwalder at Syracuse, Hal Lahar has developed a starting eleven at Colgate that he holds in high regard.

A 42-year-old tea leaf reader, who had been evicted from the Coney Island tenement in which five persons were burned fatally early Wednesday, was held in $500 bail yesterday. She was charged with vagrancy.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Representative Joe Holt, Republican of California, said today a Soviet note of apology for a Russian officer's pistol waving during the Congressman's recent visit to the Soviet Union had distorted the facts.

City Councilman Edward A. Cunningham, Bronx Democrat, said at City Hall last night he thought that bingo was legal -- under certain conditions. He is a strong proponent of legalized off-track betting and games of chance.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Advertising-financed television made its debut in Britain tonight, with the formal assurance that Hamlet's soliloquy would never be interrupted for a middle commercial.

Members of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy have taken over the performance of "A View From the Bridge," a new play by Arthur Miller, on the night of Oct. 4 at the Coronet Theatre.

A crack appeared yesterday in the wall of resistance built by Manhattan savings banks against the 3 per cent dividend rate prevalent in Brooklyn. The New York Savings Bank, at Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, announced it would pay the 3 per cent on savings on deposit for a full year.
The results of three adjourned games brought to a conclusion yesterday the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, according to a report received through Swedish sources.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The new revolutionary government that takes over power tomorrow has promised complete freedom of the press in Argentina.

Two new ideas for breaking mid-Manhattan traffic jams are being considered by Mayor Wagner. The proposals, advanced by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley at a meeting Monday with the Mayor and his Traffic Council, are aimed at relieving the steadily worsening traffic congestion by:

The stupid and illegal attempts of the leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association to fight the Waterfront Commission by direct action on the docks have made a dispassionate appraisal of the commission's functions and operations both difficult and dangerous.
The building contract for a $3,100,000 junior high school in fast-growing Springfield Gardens, Queens, was declared forfeited yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Education.
New York University began its 124th academic year yesterday. Thirty-nine thousand students started classes in the university's fourteen schools, colleges and divisions.
OTTAWA, Sept. 22 -- Canada's atomic reactor is operating again.

CORDOBA, Argentina, Sept. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi promised today to issue a call for national elections within twenty to twenty-five days so that the people of Argentina "can choose the government they want."

WHILE youthful newcomers to the academic world are furrowing their brows and learning to differentiate their p's and q's, adults are wrinkling their foreheads, too, trying to teach boys and girls to write in a hand that even a mailman could love.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 -- Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi declared Argentina's civil war ended today.

The decision of the United Nations Assembly's Steering Committee against putting the Cyprus issue on the agenda of this session may well prove to have been wise. The reasons advanced for the action are sound. Passions have become so inflamed in both Turkey and Greece at this time that public discussion might lead to more outbreaks of the sort that have recently taken place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Senator Walter F. George said today he believed "we are gradually approaching a situation where things are likely to move more rapidly" toward a high-level conference between the United States and Communist China.
The Transit Authority has a $10,200,000 problem.
Columbia opens its football season against Brown at Baker Field today with a team that Lou Little regards as superior to the Lions of a year ago.
The Eisenhower Administration was described yesterday as being "very active" in its enforcement of anti-trust laws.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania Boxing Commission today gave the co-managers of the lightweight champion, Wallace (Bud) Smith, until Oct. 3 to produce the financial records of his fight for the title With Jimmy Carter last June.
Jews in New York and elsewhere will attend services tomorrow on the eve of the Day of Atonement, Yom Kippur. It is the most sacred day in the Jewish calendar.

Few men have enjoyed a more varied career in baseball than Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel. He is 65 years old, though the record books insist on making him only 64. The Yankee manager admits he was born July 30, 1890, in Kansas City.
Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday it had arranged to purchase the plants, equipment and inventories of Universal Products Company.
Grievance committees of The New York Times and The New York Daily News units of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., have voted not to oppose the dismissals of two newspaper men.
Bingo's legal status in New York was a subject of confusion and debate last night.
The National Broadcasting Company refused yesterday to grant the Republican party in New York State equal television time to answer Governor Harriman's monthly "Report to the People."

For the benefit of drivers whose cars break down on the Henry Hudson Parkway the city's Park Department, which operates the parkway, has provided turn-outs and police telephones which stranded automobilists may use to summon help.

Another cooperative move between those two long-time enemies the railroads and the motor cars has got under way in Chicago, where an experimental lightweight passenger train is presented for the public in the General Motors Panorama.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The United States Consumer Price Index fell back 0.2 per cent from mid-July to mid-August after two successive rises.

Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, said on his arrival here yesterday that he hoped the Soviet Union soon would furnish tangible proof that the relaxation of international tensions was a reality.
Benjamin F. Fairless, former chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, reduced his investment in that company's shares by more than 46 per cent last month.

The Union Chemical and Materials Corporation, formerly the Follansbee Steel Corporation, had net earnings of $2,578,548 in the six months ended on Aug. 31, James H. Clark, president reported yesterday.
Following is the text of a British Government report, made available by the British Information Services yesterday, on the Maclean-Burgess case:

In addition to finishing first in the interzone chess tournament at Gothenburg, David Bronstein of Russia received the first brilliancy prize for the combination that enabled him to defeat Paul Keres of Russia, the runner-up, in the seventh round.
A survey of the condition of 975 multiple dwellings in the Coney Island area was made early in the summer, Deputy Housing Commissioner Bernice P. Rogers reported yesterday.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 18 -- At the root of France's political and economic troubles in Algeria is the growth of a native Moslem population at a much faster rate than the facilities for housing, feeding, educating and employing it.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 23 -- Four rare airmail stamps with a total value of $22,500 were stolen this morning from an exhibit at the Monticello Hotel, where the Philadelphia Philatelic Society is holding its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Representative Gordon L. Scherer, Republican of Ohio, said today it would be a "terrible mistake" for American University here to dismiss a professor who testified before the House Un-American Activities Committee.
