HONG KONG, Sept. 23 -- The Chinese Communist armed forces, whose officers formerly wore no insignia, acquired their first marshals today at the summit of a reorganized military rank system.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Department of Agriculture economists today predicted there would be little if any further decline in farm prices this year.

Evening of holdings prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Trading was generally dull. Hides, rubber, sugar, onions and zinc eased; cocoa and lead rose, and changes in coffee, cotton-seed oil, soybean oil, wool, burlap and copper were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 2,800,154 running bales of cotton from this year's crop had been ginned prior to Sept. 16.

Actions seeking to make The New York Daily News, The New York Herald Tribune and The American Society of Newspaper Editors parties to the appeal of The New York Post against Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz were filed yesterday with the Brooklyn Appellate Division.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Introduction of documents by the Government in its anti-trust suit against five film companies was started today in Federal Court in Los Angeles under the direction of Samuel Flatow, special assistant to the Office of the Attorney General in Washington.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair brought a long quest for the women's New Jersey Golf Association's match play championship to a successful conclusion today. She defeated Judy Frank of Aldecress on the thirty-seventh hole at the Plainfield Country Club.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Hurricane Janet left an estimated 100 dead and thousands homeless on Barbados in the Windward Islands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation received preliminary approval today for using ships as "sea tractors" to haul freight-laden highway trailers without additional authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission.

IF the many group exhibitions of paintings and sculpture taking place these days are something of a stop-gap, they nonetheless offer the advantage of introductions to little known artists who may one day make the grade.

TRENTON, Sept. 23 -- The Republican-controlled State Legislature today passed two bills designed to expand New Jersey's potable water facilities. Both measures are expected to be signed by Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat.

The appointment of John R. Wiley of 12 Lowell Road, Port Washington, L. I., as Director of Aviation of the Port of New York Authority was announced yesterday. Donald V. Lowe, chairman of the bi-state agency, said the appointment would be effective Oct. 15.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 23 -- Soviet Russia is ahead of the United States in research on the effects of atomic radiation, Dr. Cyril Comar of the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies said here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Vice Chief of Staff of the Air Force said today the 137-wing goal of the service might have to be expanded to match growing Soviet air power.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Bolivia and the United States are signing today an agreement to guarantee American investment in Bolivia. Foreign Minister Walter Guevara is signing for Bolivia and Ambassador Gerald Drew for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A broad review of the free world's strengths and weaknesses in the Far Pacific is scheduled here tomorrow. The occasion will be a meeting of the Anzus treaty Defense Council at the State Department.

Edna Best, noted stage and screen actress, will undertake her first directorial assignment on Broadway this season. She has agreed to stage Noel Coward's comedy, "Fallen Angels," which Charles Bowden and Richard Barr plan to open here late in November with Nancy Walker and Margaret Phillips starred.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The United Nations General Assembly declined today to debate the question of self-determination for Cyprus. Self-determination would give the island's population the right to decide its future political status.

Francis A. O'Neill Jr., chairman of the National Mediation Board, and his staff associate, T. F. Schoonover, deserve warm thanks from the hundreds of thousands who ride the Long Island Rail Road each day -- and from the company and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen as well -- for their superb mediation of the dispute that has been threatening since early August to end in a trainmen's strike.

A new type of emergency oil boom was put in operation yesterday in Boston Harbor for the protection of facilities and vessels from the threat of fire in the heavy oil concentrations along the Chelsea River.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Svengali," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in color with Hildegarde Neff and Donald Wolfit, is at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux. Goerge Minter produced and Noel Langley directed from Mr. Langley's adaptation of the story by George Du Maurier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston anonunced today that a full-dress Senate investigation of the controversial Wolf Ladejinsky security case will get under way Monday with all witnesses under subpoena.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Death sentences for narcotics smugglers and some peddlers were advocated today by the chairman of a Senate investigating subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Argentine provisional government has the temporary status in international law of an insurgent regime.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 23 -- President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla announced today the end of press censorship.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 23-- "If I hadn't broken my leg playing tennis I never would have taken up golf," Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer said today after winning the women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties for the sixth time.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 23 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman tonight accused Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization, of "neutrality ad absurdum."

Willie Mays was back in action yesterday, bruised hip and all. However, his "old Oriole" spirit did not help Willie in his quest for a Giant home-run record. Nor did it help the Giants, who are not looking for anything except the end of the season.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Union released today thirty-one prisoners, including twelve Frenchmen and fifteen Germans, the German Red Cross reported. Officials said the prisoner transport also included two Belgians, a Swiss and a woman believed to be Dutch.
DENVER, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Charles A. Haskell, facing prosecution on Federal income tax charges, resigned today as Colorado Republican chairman.

Employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company gave 177 pints of blood Thursday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Veterans Administration regional office at 35 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.
The Liberal party formally endorsed last night all the Democratic nominees for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District. This district consists of New York and Bronx Counties.

DENVER, Colo., Sept. 23 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's counter-proposals on disarmament have met a disappointed reception at the White House. The official view here is that the Soviet Premier's message to President Eisenhower, which was made public today, avoids acceptance of the President's proposal for an exchange of military blueprints and aerial reconnaissance.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Union's chief economic planner, Maxim Z. Saburov, said tonight that the Soviet Union was willing to sell to the Western world all the strategic materials it wanted.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of the Century Country Club won the women's open golf championship of Westchester and Fairfield Counties for the sixth time today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The directors of the Tradesmen's Bank and Trust Company and the Market Street National Bank agreed today to merge the two institutions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 -- The board of directors of Colt's Manufacturing Company, which was founded here 118 years ago, has agreed to sell its assets to the Penn-Texas Corporation, it was announced today.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Commercial television received today a cautiously cordial reception from the British press.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 23 -- The Bundestag unanimously approved today the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

What? The Yankees again? But -- just a few weeks ago they were -- and at the beginning of the season people said -- the Big Three gone, and still -- most of the sports writers picked them for -- tough schedule remaining and seven games left with -- four teams in the race and any one of them -- he's not the player he used to be -- the Yankees won, you say?

No horse-racing aficionado could ask for a better race than the one that Belmont Park has booked for the No. 6 spot today. It's the $100,000 added Sysonby Stakes, and in it the Belair Stud's 3-year-old Nashua, the year's leading money-winner, will run against older horses for the first time.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov pledged the Soviet Union today to the "utmost consideration" of plans of other nations for the limitation and control of armaments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Development of a more accurate X-ray examination for kidney trouble was disclosed today at the closing session of the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the American Roentgen Ray Society here.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Directors of Sears, Roebuck Co. recommended today a three-for-one stock split. The board called a special meeting of stockholders Nov. 14 to vote on the proposal. The announcement was coupled with a report of substantially increased earnings and plan for a 1 per cent stock dividend to follow the split.

I am surprised at the passionate, I might say ill-tempered, tone of Andre Michalopoulos' letter printed in The Times of Sept. 13, taking you to task for the alleged change of your position in the latest editorial of Sept. 8 regarding Cyprus.
Peerless Woolen Mills will build a new plant to manufacture women's wear fabrics in Cleveland, Tenn., John L. Hutcheson Jr., president, announced yesterday.

The New York Times editorial of Sept. 17 indicates that the Department of Marine and Aviation would like to build and operate a rooftop heliport rather than let the Port Authority construct and operate a heliport on the street at the foot of West Thirtieth Street.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today development of a combined helicopter and conventional airplane that has flown more than 180 miles an hour. Top speed for helicopters has been 156 miles an hour.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Ewald B. Nyquist of Feura Bush was named today as associate commissioner for higher education of the State Education Department. He has been assistant commissioner for higher education since 1951.
GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- A wire-haired, Ch. Venture of Co-Hill, was chosen best of breed at the 106th specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club today.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- The New York Yankees tonight clinched their twenty-first American League pennant. It was their sixth in the last seven years under the leadership of Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, who was sworn in today as Argentina's provisional President, was unknown to the vast majority of Argentines a week ago.
TOBERMORY, Scotland, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- A Scottish duke who has sunk a fortune in trying to raise a 400-year-old Spanish treasure ship from its ocean bed gave up the battle today.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 -- The virtually annual red-paint expeditions of Rutgers University students to Princeton prior to their football game were renewed today.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- To the very last Al Lopez, the manager of the dethroned Cleveland Indians, clung to the hope that lightning would strike twice at Boston. The first bolt had hit the Yankees when they lost this afternoon.
Summer is gone and fall is here -- officially.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- One of Washington's famous churches has been in danger of collapse for some time. Workmen doing a routine job at St. John's Episcopal Church, across Lafayette Square from the White House, made the discovery.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The medal winner, Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore, gained the semi-finals in the women's Trans-Mississippi amateur golf tournament today with a 4-and-3 victory over Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill.
John C. Dawson has been appointed in charge of the New York area sales office of United States Steel Homes, Inc., prefabricated housing subscidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Britain began today the largest air defense exercises of the year here. The nation's early warning radar system from Inverness in Scotland to Plymouth on the Channel was switched on at noon as "enemy" jet fighters and bombers began probing for gaps in the electronic screen.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Stan Slaby, the football coach at Admiral Farragut Academy, was listing the advantages of pre-school-year drills today. He said it had done great things for his inexperienced squad. He emphasized its value for reducing weight.

This association has continuously protested before the United Nations and hemisphere public opinion the violations of human rights which characterized Peron's ruthless dictatorship. These violations included not only suppression of the press, but political imprisonments and tortures, suppression of all free labor movements, and the subornation of all educational and intellectual movements.
Operators were active yesterday in deals involving East Side properties.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company announced tonight that it would resume normal operations Monday after a six-day shutdown because of a labor dispute.

The New York State Committee on Refugees asked yesterday for a year's extension of the Refugee Relief Act. The Federal act was passed in 1953 and is scheduled to expire on Dec. 31, 1956. It has as its goal the admittance of 209,000 refugees by the end of next year.

BUFFALO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Norman Granz canceled the concert of his "Jazz at the Philharmonic" troupe last night half an hour before curtain time. He declared that the neighborhood movie theatre rented for the performance was inadequate.
The Sunday school year opens in most Protestant churches in New York tomorrow or next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Mr. Chamblin, as vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, had charge of the organization's Government relations division.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A White Paper issued today by the Foreign Office left many questions unanswered on the case of the disappearance in May, 1951, of Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess, British diplomats.

ONCE in a blue moon there is a performance in the theatre of such perfection that you find yourself questioning the testimony of your own experience. Just such a one was last night's performance by Margot Fonteyn and the Sadler's Wells Ballet of "Le Lac des Cygnes" at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The on-again, off-again deal between Howard Hughes and Floyd B. Odlum for the R. K. O. Pictures Corporation is on again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- George G. Walker, president of the Electric Bond and Share Company, denied today that a subsidiary of the company, Ebasco Services, Inc., had initiated a proposed merger of Pacific Northwest utilities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23 -- United States Supreme Court decisions in the last fifteen years reflect continuing respect for the role and competence of the states, a Federal Circuit Court Judge told a conference today at Harvard Law School.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Harold P. Burke said today he could not accept John F. Noto, 38 years old, charged with Communist party membership in violation of the Smith Act, as a good risk for court appearance. He declined to reduce Mr. Noto's bail.
HULEIKAT, Israel, Sept. 23 -- Israel has struck oil here.
A NEW convenience for the home bar is the Fizzmaster, a unique device for charging water. Safe and easy to use, this soda maker is about $20 at Hammacher Schlemmer, 145 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The recently concluded conference in Brussels of African coffee-producing nations was a major step toward industry-wide international cooperation, according to Manuel Mejia, general manager of the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia
This is a timely tale of two cities and the possible financial confusion in each.

The American Civil Liberties Union rushed to the side of Thomas Paine yesterday against Providence, R. I. The A. C. L. U. criticized Mayor Walter H. Reynolds of Providence for spurning the offer of a statue of the Revolutionary pamphleteer, zealot of American independence and outspoken freethinker.

MEXICO CITY, Saturday, Sept. 24 -- Two dynamite-laden trucks and a train were shattered last night in a collision and explosion near Torreon. More than forty persons were reported killed and at least 150 injured.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Trading in futures on the Board of Trade today showed a confused pattern. There were alternate periods of strength and of weakness in some grains as longs took profits.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra gaves its fourth and final Swiss concert here tonight -- the end of its first Swiss tour in twenty-five years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Representative John B. Bennett, Republican of Michigan, today suggested new ways to curb what he called the "uranium stock swindle."
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Louis E. Wolfson said today "things are looking up" for Montgomery Ward Co. and he was "very pleased and very much encouraged."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23 -- President Sukarno is to be allowed to speak before a mass meeting at Bandung Sunday provided he refrains from politically partisan remarks affecting next week's parliamentary elections.
The well-known Schmidt's Farm restaurant and outing place in Greenburgh, N. Y., adjoining Yonkers and Scarsdale, has been sold and will be converted into a country club.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 23 -- Two Mississippi white men accused of the murder of Emmett Louis Till, 14-year-old Chicago Negro, were acquitted today. A jury of twelve white neighbors of the defendants reached the verdict after one hour and five minutes of deliberations.

The purchase of a site for a muscle research center here was approved yesterday by the board of directors of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America. The organization has earmarked $2,000,000 for the study of muscular dystrophy and related diseases.

New York retailers this week got the cooler weather they had hoped would stimulate sales of fall apparel, but only after many of their customers had been kept away for two days by a threatened hurricane.

Sheikh Yusuf Yasin, Saudi Arabian nominee on the international arbitration tribunal in the Buraimi oasis boundary dispute with Britain, expressed yesterday his regrets that the tribunal's proceedings had been suspended.
TWO filmed shows had premieres last night on Channel 11. "I Search for Adventure," seen from 8 to 8:30 P. M., told the story of the conquest of a peak by a Swiss woman mountain-climber.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (UP) -- A program of American-Soviet cultural exchange featuring top musicians, dancers and singers is rapidly moving toward completion.
Mayor Wagner welcomed the tenth United Nations General Assembly to New York last night at the city's annual reception for United Nations delegates and Secretariat members.
The 166th anniversary of the Bill of Rights was celebrated at noon yesterday in ceremonies on the steps of Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets.
Many New Yorkers will pay an additional 10 cents a month in their minimum rates for gas after Oct. 1, when the Consolidated Edison Company adopts a new gas-rate schedule.
SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- A Federal Communications Commissioner advised broadcasters tonight to develop station policy on political talks well in advance of the 1956 Presidential campaign.

An investor has purchased the fifty-three family apartment house at 963-657 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, from the Galfran Realty Corporation. The property, assessed at $170,000, was sold subject to mortgages of $121,000. The buyer was a client of Abbott Adams, Inc., attorneys, and the seller was represented by Max G. Koenig, attorney. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Following is an unofficial translation of an address in Russian by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, in the general debate of the United Nations General Assembly today: Mr. President and Fellow Delegates:
FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Six drivers -- who allegedly failed to do their best to win the seventh race at the Freehold Raceway Wednesday -- are under a five-day suspension.

"MEXICO REVISITED,"* by Erna Fergusson, is a friendly book of tall problems and small talk. The small talk of travel trivia somehow conveys the Mexico that Miss Fergusson has known for twenty or thirty years more vividly than the dutiful essays on education, irrigation, industrialization and procrastination.

The appointment of Rabbi Maurice J. Bloom as spiritual leader of Tremont Temple, 2046 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was announced yesterday. For many years Rabbi Bloom has served in the pulpit of Temple Beth Jacob in Newburgh, N. Y.

For years {t was believed that "The Complete Short Stories of Guy de Maupas. sant" contained all those the author had written. It has been revealed by Artine Artinian, vice president of the Socit des A_mis de Guy de Maupassant, that the author had: written a good many stories not included in the edition and that fifty-two stories that were included are known to be spmous.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- A group of French Deputies demonstrated today the principle of free speech on Soviet soil, upsetting the harmonious pattern that usually prevails at news conferences given by foreign visitors.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi became today the twenty-fourth President in modern Argentine history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Civil suits have grown so popular in recent years that litigants throughout the country must now wait fifteen months until they are finished.

Damage suits totaling $1,075,000 were filed yesterday against the Italian Airlines on behalf of six persons killed or injured in last December's crash at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Fred Haas mastered narrow fairways and tricky, rolling greens for the second straight day to take a two-stroke lead today at the halfway mark of the $43,000 open golf tournament at the Charles River Country Club.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Negotiations to bring about an amalgamation of Television Programs of America with Screen Gems, Inc., are progressing favorably, it was confirmed today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 23 -- Following is the text of a letter on disarmament sent to President Eisenhower by Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, as released today in Denver:
I have read with care the dispatch in The Times of Sept. 14 by Paul Kennedy on his visit to the Dominican Republic.

Forty-two discharged American Federation of Labor dockworkers were not the victims of unfair labor practices at Port Newark, N. J., and are not entitled to back wages, it was ruled yesterday. The longshoremen were dropped from their jobs a year ago.

BLUEFISH are providing the main attraction for those who leave Long Island ports these days. However, a number of the captains who operate Montauk Point charter boats are convinced that school tuna remain in their area and will try for them today. Those observations developed from a check made yesterday.
In bringing another American League championship to New York, the Yankees have run their record to twenty-one penants, a feat without parallel in the history of the major leagues.
AS the robin is the harbinger of spring, so the moving van means autumn and the end of a lease.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 23 -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee arrived here today for a two-day visit heralded by the United States Information Service in a 650-word press release.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The last remaining Australian was eliminated from the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today. A Davis Cup player, Rex Hartwig, dropped straight sets to Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the defending champion, in a quarter-final match. The score was 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 -- Eight years after the opening of its first store in the Republic of Mexico, Sears, Roebuck Co. opened its fourteenth and most luxurious store this week.
GENEVA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Ambassadors U. Alexis Johnson of the United States and Wang Ping-nan of Communist China, held their seventeenth meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Army has requested a 3,000 increase in monthly draft calls and a 16,000-man rise in over-all strength to help train youthful volunteers under the new six-months Reserve plan.
Prices scrambled to new peaks in yesterday's stock market, aided to a considerable extent by new developments, actual or expected.

Robert Hall Clothes is building a store at Central Avenue and Fort Hill Road in Yonkers, N. Y., on land bought from the Municipal Land and Development Corporation, headed by Morris M. Greenstein of Yonkers.
More than 100 years ago the school that is now known as Public School 35, Manhattan, must have been the pride of Greenwich Village. It was probably the latest word in school design.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission authorized today the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, Houston, Tex., to expand its natural gas pipeline system at an estimated cost of $56,001,000.

ATHENS, Sept: 23 -- Some ninety years ago France's Minister in Athens, the experienced and incisive Comte de Gobineau, concluded a dispatch to the Quai d'Orsay with the remark: "Political prophecy is always difficult, but in Greece it is hopeless."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- An Anaconda Company spokesman today disclosed long-range company plans to build a plant "in the Spokane, Wash., perimeter" to make alumina from domestic clays. Alumina, conventionally processed from bauxite, is the principal raw material of aluminum metal.
Department stores are increasing the efficiency of their credit operations, a survey by the National Retail Dry Goods Association showed yesterday.

A suit for a declaratory judgment was filed in Federal Court yesterday on behalf of eight Army privates challenging the right of boards of inquiry to investigate their fitness to remain in the service.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points off to 15 points up yesterday.

It is not surprising that there has been a temporary breakdown in the Japanese-Soviet negotiations in London. The test of these talks, from the beginning, was whether the Soviet Union was prepared to offer any reasonable concessions to Japan for the sake of re-establishing relatively normal trade and diplomatic relations.

There would seem to be a ready-made case for the wisdom of keeping better track of New York City's population between United States census reports than is now the case. The Committee on Statistical Program for the City of New York, established in early 1954 at Mayor Wagner's request, has published an excellent argument for doing so, in a sixty-eight-page pamphlet.

Manager Leo Durocher and the New York Giants will part company by "mutual consent" within the next few weeks and Bill Rigney of the Minneapolis Millers will be appointed his successor, the United Press reported yesterday.

PRINCE ALBERT, Sask., Sept. 23 (UP) -- Planes flew over the tundra of the Arctic region today looking for a trace of a six-man expedition from Dartmouth College. The group was a week overdue on a 900-mile canoe trip.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Average primary market prices held unchanged at 111.4 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended on last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The price level for all commodities other than farm and foods was unchanged from last week. Farm products and processed foods declined slightly.
There was much baseball talk in Felony Court yesterday. There was also a baseball bat, and there was a defense attorney's request that his client be paroled until after the world series.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey is scheduled to leave at 1 P. M. today from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a month-long trip around the world.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission ended today its hearing on the New York Telephone Company's petition for a "stop-gap" rate increase of $34,000,000 a year.
The ending of daylight time in many parts of the country tomorrow and its extension here and in other areas are expected to cause widespread confusion.

Ford C. Frick, Commissioner of Baseball, yesterday fined Paul Richards, general manager and field manager of the Baltimore Orioles $2,500 for violation of the bonus rule and conduct detrimental to baseball in connection with the signing of Tom Borland, left-handed pitcher.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- New England's Governors today asked President Eisenhower for approximately $50,000,000 in Federal funds to carry out flood control projects.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- British Government securities, particularly the short and medium dated issues, were in good demand today, with gains up to 10 shillings ($1.40). Other trading was on a subdued scale, and small losses outnumbered rises in most industrial groups.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Shareholders of the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest manufacturing concern, solidly approved today a three-for-one stock split.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Walter Chamblin Jr. of Washington, vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, was found dead at the bottom of a hotel elevator shaft here early today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Every month the Council of Economic Advisers prepares for the Joint Committee on the Economic Report a series of graphs called Economic Indicators.

UP to now a short story and article writer for the magazines, William B. Hartley, in "The Cruel Tower," is making his first venture into book-length fiction. It doesn't altogether come off, primarily because his story seems padded to fill out the length requirements of a book.

TOKYO, Sept 21 -- Since Jan. 1 this year 267 Japanese have gone to Communist China on goodwill tours. Although Tokyo and Peiping lack formal diplomatic ties, no bamboo curtain hangs between Asia's two major powers.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Belgrade radio reported tonight that Yugoslavia had broken off economic talks with Communist Hungary.
ACROSS-SECTION of contemporary talent at work rather than outstanding individual achievement is the principal impression made by many of this week's exhibitions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -On the official roster of the tenth General Assembly, session women have dropped back in numbers since the ninth meeting.

SINCE a word to the wise is said to be sufficient, let such a one be spoken here in the hope that those who can relish a ballet of subtlety and high distinction will hasten to see Frederick Ashton's "Tiresias."
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Early man probably roasted and ate elephants 11,000 years ago on Santa Rosa Island, off the California coast.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Some 8,500 bankers and their wives are pouring into this city for the four-day annual meeting of the American Bankers Association at the Conrad Hilton Hotel. It promises to be a lively session as a result of a contest for the vice presidency.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pussey, president of Harvard University, took issue tonight with those who he said had upset traditions of American fair play by their "misguided zeal" in professions of principles.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24 (UP) -- A senior quarterback, Jack Stephans, engineered the Holy Cross Crusaders to a 42-7 triumph over the Temple Owls today. The opener for both football teams was played in a driving rain before some 5,000 spectators at Fitton Field.
Leo Durocher resigned yesterday as manager of the New York Giants. He will enter private business.

Another equinox, and now fall is officially here. A man can be through with gardening and no eyebrows raised. Oh, there are squashes and pumpkins to be garnered, and late beets and late onions, maybe. But no hurry. And parsnips can be left where they are till they are mellowed by frost.

Daylight saving time did not end here at 2 A. M. today, as in previous years. Its continuance to the last Sunday in October is mandatory throughout New York State. This also holds true throughout New England, New Jersey, most of Pennsylvania and in Chicago.
THE time for courses has rolled around again. Gardens can now be left on their own for a while and so the gardeners can take time out to learn what's new and gain some pointers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission, long the source of such pronouncements as "quantity limit provisos" and "per se doctrines," turned to simple English today.
There was an Argentine accent in the Spanish prayers that ended a mass of thanksgiving at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

OWNERS of burie outdoor fuel-oil tanks may occasionally have difficulty in finding the sounding pipe in the center. Deep snow is the most common difficulty, but during spring thaws the pipe and its cap can be concealed so completely by swollen sod that the man delivering the oil can't find it.

THE famous explorer and zoologist, Roy Chapman Andrews, has woven memorable experiences into this fictionalized account of an expedition he conducted, years ago, into Tibet and the Yunan Province of China, where no other white man had ventured.

NEXT Thursday morning sirens will sound over the length and breadth of the 3,000-mile-long archipelago which is the Republic of Indonesia. They will call voters to the polls, in the first nation-wide elections ever held here, to choose 260 members of the young Republic's parliament.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A $10,000 goodwill gesture by Canadian onion growers to aid hurricane-stricken competitors in the United States has foundered on the shoals of United States tariff barriers.
WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 24 (AP) -A party of canoeists, objects of a wide search in Canada's barren Northwest Territories, turned up today, but one of the six had been lost by drowning.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers, outweighed and outmanned, gave Ohio State a scare today before succumbing, 28-20, to the Buckeyes before a capacity crowd of 80,171.

IT took Terry Moore a long time to get the answer he was seeking. But when the answer came, it was worth the wait. Many years after the St. Louis Cardinals had upset the New York Yankees in the 1942 world series, the fleet-footed Moore, captain and center fielder of the Redbirds from St. Loo, finally caught up with Bill Dickey, the slugging catcher of the Bronx Bombers, for a heart-to-heart talk.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Kansas sophomores, led by the throwing arm of Wally Strauch, upset Washington State, 13 -- 0, today to end at seventeen the longest losing string among major colleges.
Bill Rigney, an infielder with the Giants from 1946 through 1953, is "thrilled" to be back in the major leagues.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Percy Knight, vice chairman of the British Labor party, accused the Conservative Government in a political broadcast tonight of bungling Britain's economic affairs.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Jimmy Thompson, a halfback, and Toppy Vann, a substitute quarterback, starred today as Georgia Tech defeated Florida, 14 -- 7, for its second straight victory.
Professional baseball moves on the scene this week with its finest show -- the world series. The cast, bearing a familiar look, will be the Yankees and Dodgers for the sixth time.

THE 1954-55 trip of U. S. S. Atka to Antarctic waters was the forerunner of a large-scale invasion of the Far South that begins next year. Many nations are to cooperate in a carefully planned scientific program there, the results of which are likely to be epoch-making.

This has been a great week in the history of Argentina, for it has seen the downfall of one of the most pernicious dictatorships in Latin-American history. For that reason free men here and everywhere in the democratic world are rejoicing.
DENVER, Sept. 24 -- Fitzsimons Army Hospital, where President Eisenhower is a patient, is the Army's largest hospital. It is a completely modern medical teaching institution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Australia, New Zealand and the United States agreed today that it would be folly for the free nations to drop their guard in the Pacific so long as the promise of Geneva had not been fulfilled.
ELATH, Israel, Sept. 15 -- The ambition of this fishing village to become an important port city might seem far-fetched, since it possesses neither harbor facilities nor access to the high seas.

Waldo Frank's letter in your issue of Sept. 11 raises two points of issue. The general passport question has received sufficient comment in your columns already and I do not think anything useful can be gained by saying more.

We are pleased that the editor of The New York Times and Arthur Krock in thoughtful discussions in The Times of Sept. 21 and 22 have recognized the problems of congestion in the Federal courts in this area.

AN unusual and deeply effective novel, "So Help Me God" has a hero who sets a trap for the United States Government, its citizens and its headline writers, with himself as bait. In a kind of key sentence toward the end, a member of a Congressional committee investigating subversion says to an aide, "

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Princeton's football team opened another season with Rutgers in a gray setting at Palmer Stadium today. In 1869 their initial meeting marked the beginning of the intercollegiate sport.

VARIOUS American writers, of whom Robert Penn Warren is perhaps the most prominent, seem to be steering the historical novel back into the realm of serious fiction. Davis Grubb, whose first novel, the poetic thriller "
An "international day of repentance" was proposed yesterday by Dr. Israel Goldstein, rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.
FORT SCOTT, Kan., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Nine Fort Scott High School football players suffered burns about the legs and hips in a game won from Girard, 27 -- 6, yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24 -- Syracuse stood up to Pittsburgh's football powerhouse for most of three periods today and then tired. Then the favored Panthers went on to score a 22-12 victory in a drizzling rain at Archbold Stadium.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Powered by Ron Kramer's 23 points, Michigan crushed Missouri, 42 to 7, today for a non-conference, season-opening victory in Michigan Stadium.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 24 (AP) -Hurricane Janet's winds diminished for a few hours today. Later, the storm regained much of the 100-to-127-mile-an-hour winds with which it lashed the British Colonial islands in the Windward group.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the English-Speaking Union. The program will include "The Firebird," "Madame Chrysantheme" and the Coronation ballet, "Homage to the Queen."
A new undergraduate newspaper, one of the largest campus publications in the country, will appear next Tuesday at New York University.

MADRID, Sept. 24 -- The International Maritime Commission conference, at its final plenary session today, adopted three conventions. They dealt with the increasing shipowners' liability in general, increasing owners' liability toward passengers and the problem of stowaways.

THE floods which inundated some parts of the northeastern United States in August did not damage the scenery irreparably, and with highway travel back to normal in most areas, tourists should be able to enjoy the foliage spectacle with comparatively little inconvenience from detours.

LOOK to starboard and you will note that Herman Wouk's "Marjorie Morningstar" has two weeks after her opening pushed into the relative obscurity of the wings such folk as an unangelical French miss and the fellow in the gray flannel suit.
Agencies of the United Israel Appeal have expended $65,000,000 so far this year to carry out programs of resettlement and rehabilitation in Israel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -- Next Thursday the young island Republic of Indonesia, once aptly and memorably described as "a shimmering green girdle about the equator," will take a long stride forward on the road to democracy.

THE blossoming of art galleries in this city is only one indication of the constantly increasing interest in original art for the home. Picking a picture is purely a matter of personal choice. But in transferring it from gallery to home other points must always be considered.
The head of the National Heart Institute expects President Eisenhower to overcome his attack of coronary thrombosis and live a long, useful life.

IT may be rather late to be making the observation, but Leo Durocher never seemed to fit into his uniform as manager of the New York Giants. Sartorially replendent and custom-tailored though he was, the brassy Lip didn't look natural in his Polo Grounds garb. John McGraw had seemed born to that uniform. So had Bill Terry and Mel Ott. Durocher? Never.

THESE eighteen tales by the military editor of The New York Times make a capital evening's entertainment, for the reader who opens this book, however casually, will find it difficult to put down. Some, like the Titanic and Lusitania sinkings, are widely known; others, like the story of the wreck of the French frigate Medusa, give color and substance to names only vaguely familiar through art and letters.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 24 -- Mayor Walter H. Reynolds explained in a telegram today to the American Civil Liberties Union what he meant by the word "controversial" in his refusal to give city aid for a memorial to Thomas Paine.

THIRTY-TWO shooting preserves, several within reasonable distance of this city, now are operating in New York State. The hunting season on these pay-as-you-go game farms began on Sept. 1. It will last through Feb. 28.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 20 -- Prime Minister Sir John Kotelawala has directed that the scholarships offered to Ceylonese by foreign governments should not be accepted without the sanction of the Foreign Ministry.

SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 24 -- The State of Mississippi will try to obtain a kidnapping conviction against two white men acquitted by a jury yesterday of the charge that they murdered Emmett Louis Till, 14-year-old Chicago Negro.

Something approaching the millenium may have arrived when an American Secretary of State "gladly" notes the initiative of the Soviet Union, which has promised to donate nuclear materials to the proposed atoms-for-peace agency. And when a Soviet Foreign Minister notes "with satisfaction" that the atomic conference in Geneva last summer was originally proposed by the United States, it might be supposed that a thousand years of peace were already under way.

GROWING interest in religion has been making front-page headlines recently. Church membership has reached new heights and in Protestant churches the pace of Sunday School enrollment is three times greater than the birth rate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., protested to the Justice Department today against two proposed mergers in the textile industry.

IT has now been ten weeks since this department has considered anything but declarer's play, to the exclusion of the defenders' problems. In the meantime Hy Lavinthal of Trenton, N. J., has completed the manuscript of a bridge book that stresses defensive play, and two of his example hands form the basis of today's column.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The changes taking place in the Chicago area's industrial community and the growth it has made in the ten years since World War II were highlighted in an analysis of new manufacturing facilities made by the Commonwealth Edison Company.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 24 -- A general strike order for Monday circulated today in the medinas (moslem quarters) of major Moroccan cities.

Because of changes in the last thirty years, the United States has built for itself an economy "with no likness elsewhere." So declares Prof. Marcus Nadler of New York University in a brochure just published by the Hanover Bank, of which he is consulting economist.

NOW is the time to anticipate spring flowers, for in fall the bulbs that bloom from February until May must be purchased and planted. If a variety of bulbs is selected rather than just the familiar tulip and daffodil, bloom can start in February.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Blackpool's unbeaten run in English League soccer ended today as Manchester City defeated the Seasiders by 2 -- 0. An injury to its star winger, Stanley Matthews, crippled Blackpool's attack.

Retailing has its discount houses, at which the canny shopper can buy leather goods, tape recorders and television sets at 22 per cent or more below list price. They have become a recognizable and apparently ineradicable feature of city life.

With the publication this morning of the first installment of Harry S. Truman's memoirs The New York Times brings to its readers the personal story of a former President of the United States who, whatever his faults is a very human and a forthright man.

QUITE a laudatory to-do has recently been made about the late Justice Robert H. Jackson's little book on the Supreme Court, which put between covers three lectures he never lived to deliver at Harvard. At Jackson's death last fall, that old legal war-horse, John Lord O'Brian, was presumably rushed in as an oral pinch-hitter.

In Buenos Aires last Friday, church bells tolled, huge bonfires burned in the squares, thousands of persons coursed through the streets, singing, dancing, cheering. The ten-year rule of Juan Domingo Peron in Argentina had come to an end.
PARIS, Sept. 24 -- The mission to Morocco of Pierre Montel, head of the National Assembly's Defense Committee, has been withdrawn. M. Montel returned to Lyons today.

BEEZUS, in case somebody doesn't know, is Beatrice Quimby, neighbor and stanch friend of Henry Huggins. She is also caretaker and victim of 4-year-old Ramona, the most exasperating little sister we've encountered since Tarkington created Jane Baxter.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 -- This won't be news in Bridgeport, but political pundits elsewhere may be interested to learn that Jasper McLevy is seeking his twelfth term as Mayor.

THE hardy polemician John T. Flynn has set off in this book in a controlled conversational tone and has ended in what can only be called a strident and unconvincing shout. The consequences are genuinely unfortunate, for in the earlier part of his work Mr. Flynn has much to say that, as it seems to me, is both perceptive and tolerant of disagreement.

UNITED NATIONS,N.Y.,Sept. 24 -- Max Harrelson of The Associated Press was elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association today. He succeeds Dr. Max Beer of the Neue Zuercher Zeitung of Zurich, Switzerland.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 24 -- Navy's Sugar Bowl champions scored at first-period touchdown on a 26-yard pass play from George Welsh to Jim Barker today and then had to hang on desperately for a 7-0 victory over a scrappy William and Mary eleven.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union has intensified its courtship of newly independent lands in Africa and Asia and of national groups now seeking independence.

A SERIES of talks and demonstrations to be given on alternate Wednesday evenings will be inaugurated at 8 P. M. this Wednesday at The Camera Club, 101 West Fort-eighth Street. The initial program will be given by William Perrett of Ansco, who will discuss the new high-speed Anscochrome color film.
New York State's forty-one-year-old banking law is being carefully examined for signs of old age by an increasing number of committees.

IT is fashionable nowadays to believe that science and religion no longer have important disagreements. Scientists themselves have sometimes created this impression, chiefly by emphasizing permissible areas for religious faith left open by the new physics.
New York is trying to squeeze more cars every year into the five square miles of the teeming metropolitan center along ancient streets that stubbornly refuse to stretch.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Washington Huskies, bouncing back from a poor 1954 season, ripped to a 30-0 upset victory over Minnesota today before 58,817 fans in Memorial Stadium.

The pressure that has increased ever since the Geneva conference for increasing the flow of trade with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries has aroused considerable concern among United States military men.

BASED on information received from Havana, indications are that Americans will have a large share in Cuba's centenary stamp show, the Exposicion Filetelica Internacional Centenario (CUPEX), when it is held in Havana's Palace of Fine Arts on Nov. 12-19.
On the anniversary today of the adoption of the Bill of Rights in 1789, eighty-three prominent Americans demanded an end to all infringements upon it.
FORT BRANCH, Ind., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Townspeople and engineers battled swarms of mosquitoes today to check an outbreak of "sleeping sickness" that had taken seven lives and stricken twelve others.

AFTER all that's been shot and exhibited in the way of African wildlife films -- and especially after the excellent animal footage that has been shown in such fairly recent adventure pictures as "Ivory Hunter," "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "King Solomon's Mines" -- it took considerable confidence for Walt Disney to dispatch another crew of nature photographers to the Dark Continent for another picture of the familiar fauna there.

IN New York and other major cities of the country, city planners and social scientists, faced with tough overpopulation and delinquency problems, are deeply worried about communities that are running down. Good neighborhoods become overcrowded; buildings show their age and maintenance slips; new groups pour in, competing for space, education, understanding; old groups, decent and devoted to the community, develop fears and flee to "safer" neighborhoods.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Dick Donovan hurled his fifth shutout of the season today as the Chicago White Sox beat the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 0.
Two Japanese naval vessels will pay an official call on New York this week, the first since World War II.
The jury verdict acquitting two white men of the murder of a 14-year-old boy in Sumner, Miss., was denounced yesterday by Negro and Jewish organizations in New York.

THE lives of writers are generally laborious and uneventful. They offer, as a rule, little material for the straightforward biographer, and if they are recently dead he will be too early for the memoirs, the letters, the diaries on which biography feeds.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio -- Another huge link in the ever-lengthening chain of toll superhighways across the Northeast quadrant of the United States will be forged Saturday when the 241 -- mile Ohio Turnpike will go into operation across the full span of the Buckeye State.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -- The Philadelphia Eagles, trailing by 10 points at halftime, rolled back in the second half on the lightning dashes of Jerry Norton and the passing arm of Bobby Thomason tonight to defeat the New York Giants, 27 -- 17. It was the opening game of the National Football League season.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland Sept. 19 -- Smaller and less well known than most parts of Africa, Nyasaland has the full set of problems that beset the continent. The chief ones are political and racial.

Corporate developments or rumors thereof provided the dominant influence in last week's stock market. The New York Times combined and industrial stock averages each made four new historic highs and the rail average touched a new peak for the year.

HAVING worked out the 930 pages of "The Tontine" (see page 5), Thomas B. Costain might be pardoned if he wished to sit down for a year and glance off into space. This is not his way, however, for such glances have a tendency to make him nervous.

THIS week will be the last for "The Morning Show," a Columbia Broadcasting System television series, in its present form. Beginning Oct. 3, the show will undergo cast changes and be reduced from two hours to one hour.

The first day of fall, arriving yesterday in a dreary combination of rain and humidity, lured comparatively few persons to the highways. But some of those who did go out got into a good deal of trouble.
SUMNER, Miss., Sept. 24 -- This Tallahatchie County seat of about 500 persons afforded last week a view in microcosm of the social and racial problems that divide the rural Deep South.

MODERN Edinburgh, bustling with culture and gaiety (Scottish style), and that older Edinburgh, the legend-haunted alleys and courts hidden behind the Royal Mile, are blended into a fascinating backdrop in Elisabeth Kyle's new story.

MOST astronomy books are conservative to the point of timidity. Whether popular or technical, they tend to stick closely to theories that have been current for years and have worn well. Perhaps this conservatism derives from the finicky work that observational astronomers do.

By ROBERT E. BEDINGFIELD Cloud Wampler is a son of small-town school teachers. And he set out to follow in their footsteps until someone told him it was more fun to be a banker. He discovered this was true and made a profitable career that lasted from 1916 until 1941.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority has announced it will hold on Oct. 31 the first sale of the surplus Lehigh Valley Railroad properties it owns in downtown Buffalo.

DENVER, Sept. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's golfing companion at Cherry Hills Country Club said today the President had eaten -- and later had complained of effects from -- raw onions while playing twenty-seven holes of golf yesterday.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 23 -A game is being played in the French protectorate of Morocco that might well be called: Who loves the Sultan and who loves him not?

EVERYBODY talks about atomic power and several countries are doing something about it, but what India needs, according to official word from New Delhi, is windmills. Between 20,000 and 30,000 are to be put up in the next five years. Eventually, 100,000 may dot the arid areas from Saurashtra in the northwest to Madras in the southeast, so that the job of pumping irrigation water shall no longer be strictly for the bullocks.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, who had sat helpless in the rain yesterday while the New York Yankees captured the American League pennant, took revenge on the Detroit Tigers today with a pair of victories. The scores were 8 -- 2 and 7 -- 0. The first triumph clinched second place for the Indians.
Concerning Albert Morehead's "English at a Loss for Words," (Sept. 11), in which he calls attention to certain organic lacks in the language:

The parting of the ways between Leo Durocher and the New York Giants will end the longest present-day managerial tenure in the major leagues. Leo has been in command of the Giants since July 16, 1948.
BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- A patter of rain fell on Fenway Park today. No drought-ridden farmer could ever have welcomed this turn in the weather with such unbounded relief as the Yankees.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -Manufacturing employment in the Philadelphia metropolitan area has moved upward since the start of the late summer-fall production season. The recovery exceeded the midsummer loss. A survey conducted by the Pennsylvania State Employment Service indicated a total of 547,700 wage and salary workers were employed in non-government manufacturing here in mid-August.

THERE is a span of many centuries between Homer and Shakespeare, between Shakespeare and Tolstoy, but the movie world seems increasingly comfortable in any century, and among works as awesome as "War and Peace" and "Richard III." The classics hold fewer terrors for moviemakers than they once did.

IN "The Changelings," Jo Sinclair tells the story of a white street in the process of changing into a Negro neighborhood -- the fears, hates and loves this change lets loose, the fears between generations, the hates between neighbor and neighbor, the explosive terrors between race and race, that are so much a part of the world today.

THE story is virtually forgotten today, but less than forty years ago headlines in every paper screamed of the raid on Columbus, N. M., by the Mexican bandit Pancho Villa on March 9, 1916. Nine days later Black Jack Pershing led an expeditionary force across the border with announced orders to capture Villa and private instructions, men said, that already strained international relations forbade that capture.
TORREON, Mexico, Sept. 24 (AP) -It was announced today that about twenty persons were killed when a speeding, dynamite-laden truck smashed into a train last night. Fifty-two were injured.

The Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church has established fifty Presbyterian college scholarships. These will be awarded to qualified young people entering next fall in any of the forty-one colleges related to the church. The grants will range from $100 to $1,000, and will be based on the candidate's academic ability as measured by College Entrance Examination Board tests, Christian character as evidenced by service in the church and financial need.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Senator James H. Duff charged tonight that Pennsylvania's application for emergency flood relief had been delayed while Gov. George M. Leader "vilely and viciously" attacked President Eisenhower in "two ghost-written speeches in California."

In the picture layout, "Two Days Before the Mast" (Sept. 4), the skipper of sloop 84 has a right to shanghai The New York Times Magazine after reading that his wind is coming "from the right quarter." Actually, the wind is coming from the opposite direction -- from the port bow.

ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 24 (UP) -- A second-string quarterback picked as his target a halfback who barely made the roster, and brought Georgia steaming from behind to outscore Vanderbilt, 14 to 13, before 25,000 fans today.

OLEANDER has been flowering for months along the streets and highways of the sunny southern states. It blooms as luxuriantly and as long in Florida and Texas as it does in California. In colder states such as Utah and Connecticut, where single plants in tubs were moved outdoors in June, the stems are still covered with dainty blossoms, even though their owners must plan to move them indoors before frost.
The Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association, 30 Third Aenu,. will hold open house wee. k, beginning iomoriow. 'Registrations may be made for classes and all other activities during the week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Yale opened its football season against an unexpectedly strong University of Connecticut eleven in the Bowl today. While some 5,000 fans looked on, the Bulldogs subdued their Nutmeg State rivals, 14 to 0.
The hundredth anniversary of the birth of Eugene Debs will be marked Nov. 5. Memorial meetings in New York and other cities are being organized by admirers of the Indiana trade unionist.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 24 -- What's in a name?

Although he stated yesterday that he had not been "impressed with" the atom bomb, Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy said he did not remember using the words about it that former President Truman said he had used.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Army reportedly has just about decided to replace its four types of shoulder-fired weapons with a single new lightweight rifle.

Dr. John G. Hutton of the General Electric Company's engineering laboratory in Schenectady, N. Y., told the Cleveland section of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers last week that the man-made increase in the belt of carbon dioxide around the earth may be "having a greenhouse effect on our climate."

TWO items in the report made at the annual meeting of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York last week were in striking contrast. Item No. 1: The 1954-55 deficit was $245,463, compared with the 1953-54 deficit of $124,205. Item No. 2: The society would like to establish a festival and summer school near New York and would welcome the gift of a country estate suitable for such an enterprise.

A GNARLED old pine tree and a canny stag with a firm belief in the health-giving properties of parsley share the honors in Mr. Bemelmans' new picture book. A whimsical combination, certainly, and a whimsical story this is.

MIAMI'S $2,300,000 Miami Seaquarium, newest and largest salt-water aquarium in the nation, opened to sight-seers yesterday. It stands on a fifty-five-acre tract along Rickenbacker Causeway leading to Key Biscayne and Crandon Park.

Canadian children returning to school this month are expected to tax to the limit the facilities provided by education departments. A survey of school conditions in Canada, reported by The Canadian Press, shows that more schools have been built and more teachers trained than ever before -- but there are more students, too.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 -- Former President Juan D. Peron was authorized tonight by the revolutionary Government to leave Argentina for asylum in Paraguay.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- World travelers, beginning next week, will be served in a reorganized Passport Office at 1717 H Street N. W.
Art exhibitions of the week indicate that the new season has hit its stride with a score of group and one-man shows and with a number of new galleries entering the activities.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 -- If Manager Smokey Alston saw anything he liked tonight he can't be hard to please. His National League champion Dodgers dropped two games to the lowly Pirates, 4 -- 3 and 6 -- 1, at chilly Forbes Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder, the White House physician, is a 75-year-old Army officer who was recalled from retirement to become President Eisenhower's doctor.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad -- A $5,000,000 hotel with 200-250 rooms, the first major luxury hotel ever to be built in Trinidad, is to be open for tourists sometime in 1957 as a joint venture of the local government and of Hilton Hotels International, the foreign service of Conrad Hilton's American hotel empire.

IN the Northeast calla lily culture is considered the work of the florist and rarely does a backyard gardener venture to grow these stately spathes. First of all, being natives of South Africa, they revel in warm tropical weather and secondly they take up quite a lot of room and are not good companions with the more graceful border plants.
Jack H. Sheets has been appointed works manager and Leonard S. Wiener, chief rocket design engineer of the propeller division of Curtiss-Wright Corp., Caldwell, N. J.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Baylor made alertness pay off three times tonight to rout Villanova, 19 -- 2, before 63,409 fans at Municipal Stadium.

COURSES in photography for beginners and advanced amateurs, in black-and-white, color and movies, were announced last week. Two will be given by camera clubs, the Jamaica Camera Club, in conjunction with the Central Queens Y. M. C. A., and the Lincoln Terrace Camera Club, 12 East Ninety-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Army's well-drilled football team ran up the biggest opening-day score in its sixty-six years of intercollegiate football by walloping Furman University of Greenville, S. C., 81 -- 0, today.
The customer must be served, especially that most particular customer of all -- the woman shopping for her fall wardrobe.

ON Tuesday night, immediately after the D'Oyly Carte Company's chorus of "Iolanthe" has filled the Shubert Theatre with "Tantantara! Tzing! Boom!" the most fastidious of Broadway audiences will await a moment that, by its Savoyard standards, approaches the historic.

WILTON, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Individuals and organizations in all parts of the country rallied this week to the campaign started by Wilton research to rebuild and restock the library of Seymour, Conn. The library was destroyed in last month's floods.

CAIRO, Sept. 13 -- Egypt's future government is in the blueprint stage. No one outside the Revolutionary Command Council knows what the design looks like. But the regime's promise is that the plan will be converted to reality four months from now.
Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India was described yesterday as a very tolerant man and a "very good friend" of the Roman Catholic Church by the leader of a Catholic Eastern Rite.

HERE we have another "Life With Father," in a rural setting very different from that of Clarence Day's masterpiece -- but not unworthy of that company. It is the story of a Methodist Minister's family in a town beside the Shenandoah River in the Valley of Virginia.

A GLOSSARY comes with "The Shiralee" and this is just as well, for the background and characters are Australian, and the dinkum cobber dialogue is so colloquial that without explanation the reader would not be able to understand it.
A proud, seafaring veteran of sail and steam conned the passenger-cargo liner African Endeavor to sea last week and set a familiar course for Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The exact whereabouts of Vice President Richard M. Nixon remained a mystery tonight. His aides reported he was in town, but would not say where.

If any really significant headway is to be made in alleviating or minimizing disability among the 28,000,000 Americans who suffer from chronic disease, there must be an expansion of rehabilitation services in the nation's 6,970 hospitals.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Leo Burke, who won letters three seasons in a row as a fullback and a halfback, took a fling at quarterback today and scored three touchdowns as Virginia Tech upset Penn, 33 -- 0. It was the opening game of Penn's seventy-ninth season of intercollegiate football.

NEWARK, Sept. 24 (UP) -- An official of the State Federation of Labor, A. F. L., scored Gov. Robert B. Meyner today for being "largely responsible for the present crisis" on the New York-New Jersey waterfront.
The uncertain legal status of bingo in New York may be clarified tomorrow or Tuesday.

THIS tense, unhappy little cotton town is locked in a make-or-break fight over school integration that could have its counterpart almost anywhere else in the South. The school board has abolished the Negro school and put its students into white classes. Local citizens, outraged by this affront to "white supremacy," have forced the school to shut.

IN 415 pages, more than 2,500 pictures and a substantial amount of text, the editors of Year have produced a sound, if not particularly vivid, picture history of the United States. Any book of this sort invites a comparison with Roger Butterfield's "The American Past." "Pictorial History of America" is not at the same level of scholarship or general editorial ability.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 24 -- The Western powers are likely to take a closer look at the East German Democratic Republic as a result of the treaty signed in Moscow last Tuesday. This treaty conferred additional powers on the East German Communist regime with a view to giving it parity with the West German Government in the sharpening struggle for the control of Germany.

AIKEN, S. C., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said today that the fact no one could really win an atomic war "must incline Communist leaders to recoil from the deliberate decision to initiate such an international catastrophe as nuclear World War III."

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II early today cabled to President Eisenhower that she was "deeply concerned" to learn of his illness. She and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, sent their "warmest good wishes for your speedy recovery."
UNIVERSITY, Miss., Sept. 24 -- The archaelogist who uncovered the 2,300 year-old Greek city of Olynthus was honored this week on his seventy-fifth birthday.
Deep-sea skippers were either more cautious or luckier last year than in 1953.
The Army has rescinded an "undesirable" security risk discharge for a draftee who traces his troubles to a protest against threatened return to racial discrimination in a former Negro unit.

One oil well doesn't make an industry, but at a given time and place it can make some considerable differences. It is for that reason that the Israelis are hailing an oil strike north of Gaza as "the most important event since independence." It may, indeed, prove to have been one of the most significant developments of the year.
Volkswagenwerk G. M. B. H. of West Germany soon will become the first foreign automobile producer to assemble cars in the United States on a mass-production basis.

In the face of a ten-year trend toward specialists in procurement rather than general chandlers for the steamship industry, one old-line concern has expanded its business volume and is about to move to larger quarters.

THE legion of girls who have known Betsy Ray since she was 5, who have followed her from Deep Valley to Minneapolis and Europe, will be delighted that Betsy at last marries her Joe. The year is 1914, but not even World War I can overshadow their happiness and the gay times with their old and new friends.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24 -The people's right to know what is going on officially will gain a new bulwark in Ohio next Friday.

Travelers arriving at railroad terminals today frequently find the search for the familiar red cap of a porter a desperate one. They may have to count themselves lucky to have their bags trundled on a cart with those of several other passengers.
OPTIMISM continues to run high in all forecasts for business this year and the beginning of 1956. Almost all the signs are "plus" signs, and the predictions for good business are becoming bolder.
A plan that eventually would send labor union members into settlement houses to teach their trade skills to neighborhood youngsters was adopted yesterday by the New York City C. I. O. Council.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 -The Central Government today blocked President Sukarno from making a pre-election speech before a mass meeting that had been scheduled to be held in Bandung tomorrow.

William J. O'Shea, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, made public yesterday forty-three standing committees and seventeen special committees that will serve the organization in 1955-56.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Any way you look at it, the summer of 1955 in Moscow was a remarkable one. From May to September the Soviet Union's "peace offensive" was going like a house afire.
Behind by 12 -- 0 after the first eighteen minutes of play, Columbia went 47 and then 68 yards for touchdowns and a 14-12 victory over Brown on muddy, rain-soaked Baker Field yesterday.
An emotional reaction to crimes of violence committed by older teen-age youths has blinded the public to the problem of younger boys, according to the annual report of the Big Brother Movement.

GRAPEVINES have much to recommend them for landscaping about the property as well as much recommend them as a crop. East and West, September is probably the peak month for the grape harvest. And so this perhaps is a good time to look out to decide where to plant a grapevine.

Plans were advanced at a recent meeting in the Sapphire Room of the Pierre for the sixth annual entertainment, known as the Fall Frolic, to be held on Oct. 21 in the main ballroom of the hotel for the benefit of the Hemophilia Foundation.

Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., principal stockholder of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, and Lloyd H. Dalzell, chairman of the Dalzell Towing Company, Inc., announced yesterday the establishment of a Trust Fund for International Seafarers.
A tightening fall and holiday delivery situation is developing in several markets, resident buying offices report.
BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- This city holds its preliminary municipal election Tuesday, but the campaign has had scant public attention.

WHILE London viewers are digesting today their first Sunday of commercial television, there are some lessons for American TV to learn from the British. In some areas of video activity we are the stuffy and old-fashined ones and missing a great deal.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 24 -Refugees and stateless persons from the Communist countries were given assurances today that they need not fear extradition from West Germany as a result of the Soviet-West German agreements.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -The Mayoralty campaign swung into high gear this week with charges and counter-charges by both major parties.

GARDEN GROVE, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Maj. Sammy Lee, two-time Olympic diving champion, has bought a house in this Orange County community where he was rebuffed in previous home-buying efforts because of his Oriental ancestry.

WITH this epic of an Italian courtyard, 25 - year - old Goffredo Parise takes his place among the foremost young writers of Italy. Turning his back squarely on the hallucinated, kaleidoscopic dream world which he explored in "The Dead Boy and the Comets," Parise seems to have found his way in the vigorous, full-blooded neorealism of this compelling novel.
NOW that we of the free world have embarked on general negotiations with the Soviet leaders we ought to be clear on what we are negotiating for.

The Presidency of the United States has often been called the hardest job in the world. The American President is both the head of Government and the Chief of State. He is also the head of his political party. He must perform not only the demanding task of administering the Executive Branch, but the ceremonial functions that go with the office and the political chores that his party demands of him.

JEAN SIBELIUS, Finland's world - famous composer, celebrates his ninetieth birthday on Dec. 8. In honor of the event, an all-Sibelius concert will be presented in Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, Dec. 4, under the auspices of the Finlandia Foundation and UNISOMI (United Nations International Symphony Orchestra and Music Institute, Inc.).
The erroneous assertion that no President was impeached (Andrew Johnson was) has already been corrected in your letters column of Sept. 18.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Mississippi State's Maroons mounted drives of 75 and 54 yards in the rain today to beat Tennessee, 13 -- 7. The setback marred Bowden Wyatt's coaching debut here.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -Educators and administrators in India are decrying the fact that more and more university students are showing only a stumbling knowledge of English.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 24 (AP) -India announced this week it is inviting offers from manufacturers throughout the world to sell it railway equipment worth 300,000,000 rupees ($63,000,000) during the 1956-57 fiscal year. India said it needs almost 10,000 passenger and freight cars, 240 locomotives and other equipment from abroad to supplement the 320,000,000 rupees ($67,200,000) worth of equipment it intends to purchase from Indian manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A cloud as yet no bigger than Tammany Hall now shadows the anticipated candidacy of Adlai E. Stevenson for a second Presidential nomination by the Democratic party. The cloud may grow no larger; it may dissipate; or it may presage a political hurricane for Governor Averell Harriman in which the Stevenson candidacy will be swept away or narrowly survive.

THE Porter-Cable Routo-Jig is a portable jig saw, a high-speed router and a precision shaper all in one, quality tool. As a jig saw, the tool can be used for sawing wood, plastic or light metal. As a portable router it can be used for mortising, grooving, ing, dadoing or rabbeting.

TWO of the glories of the Sadler's Wells repertory are their full-length presentations of Swan Lake and Sleeping Beauty. Sadler's Wells is currently at the Metropolitan Opera, delighting American audiences with both ballets.

PERSISTENCE has paid off for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the case of "Tea and Sympathy." The Robert Anderson play was taken under option by the company at an unusually high price (reportedly $150,000) and in the knowledge that the movie industry self-censorship office, the Production Code

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Mr. Hall asserted that "two-thirds of the decline occurred during the Truman Administration." He added that President Eisenhower "has given his pledge that the farmers will share fully in the nation's prosperity."

TWO biographies of Lincoln written in the grand manner -- multi-volumed works -- have been attempted in this century, one by a great literary artist and the other by a distinguished academic scholar. First to appear was the poet Carl Sandburg's stupendous six-volume "Abraham Lincoln: The Prairie Years" in 1926 and "The War Years" in 1939.

THIS volume by a group of able participants and students of foreign economic policy is jointly sponsored by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation and the National Planning Association. Much of it is on a high level.
DENVER, Sunday, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower suffered a heart attack early yesterday morning and has entered Fitzsimons Army Hospital near Denver.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Lord De L'Isle and Dudley, British Air-Secretary, warned today that a ban on nuclear weapons such as that being urged by the Soviet Government would not make war impossible but "far more likely."
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Charlie Thomas, for two years an understudy to the all-American fullback, Alan Ameche, came into his own today when Wisconsin defeated Marquette, 28 -- 14.

WHEN Darwin propounded his theory of evolution, one of the cardinal principles he laid down was that nature produces mutations," or sudden and unexplainable variations from the normal appearance or characteristics of a plant or other form of life.

THE arrival of autumn frosts need not put an end to harvests from the vegetable garden. Many kinds of vegetables can be rescued and the gardener need not resign himself to a marked drop in the quality of these last fruits of a summer's labor.

OVER the years Southerners have pre-empted more of the public prints than the men who bite dogs. Whether the South has run the country, or been run by it -- assuming either is possible -- it has never been ignored.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- When Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, the bitterly anti-Communist head of the most vehemently anti-Communist government in the European alliance, travels to Moscow, mingles, negotiates and concedes, the steady revival of neutralism in west Europe should no longer provoke shocked surprise in the United States.

Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer of New York announced yesterday that precious stones, jewelry and articles of precious metal for personal adornment and money packets would be accepted as ordinary parcel post to Canada. Previously they had been prohibited from parcel post but were admitted in the registered letter mails.
