EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A third-quarter penalty against their coach infuriated the Miami Redskins today and they smashed to three touchdowns within seven minutes to upset Northwestern, 25 -- 14.

AFTER several years of hesitancy, they have finally made a movie out of "To Hell and Back," the Audie Murphy autobiography -- Murphy being the incredibly baby-faced veteran who took on half the Wehrmacht in Sicily and points north a decade or so ago.

EVERY home workshop should have safety equipment on hand at all times. The first, and perhaps the most important from a personal standpoint, is the first-aid kit. This can be a commercial kit or a coffee tin, painted with red crosses and containing iodine or merthiolate, bandages, a tourniquet strap and salve for burns.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 24 -- Dartmouth College has embarked, in the words of Dr. John Sloan Dickey, its president, on "fifteen years of sustained rededication and refounding, a unique period of intensive planning and development."

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 24 -- Maryland put across the one telling punch of a frustrating contest for both teams today to defeat the University of California at Los Angeles, 7 -- 0. Ed Vereb raced 17 yards around end to score the touchdown at 6.20 of the third quarter. This neatly executed flanking maneuver terminated an uninterrupted nine-play march of 79 yards by the Terrapins after they had received the second-half kickoff.

IN spite of a summer of unusual heat and limited rainfall in many sections of the country, hundreds of traditional autumn flower shows will be held. Prize-winning qualities vary among different plants, but each type must meet certain standards for exhibition that have been set by experts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Air Force said today that competition for 300 appointments to the Air Force Academy's second class was now open.

Belgium's Prince Albert inspected art treasures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday morning and expressed pleasure in work by the early Flemish, Far Eastern and Greek masters. The Prince is in this country for the first time.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 24 -The eighty-sixth Danbury Fair, one of New England's oldest agricultural exhibitions, will open next Saturday for a nine-day run.

WHEN Harry S. Truman was in the White House, he remarked that the Presidency was a job without a future. Yet the events of recent days question this. Ex-President Herbert Hoover, out of office for twenty-two years, has just fanned a fire with his new report on Government operations.
William E. French of Rensselaer, N. Y., was named yesterday a deputy administrator of the state's new Judicial Conference.

With rare unanimity but also with grave misgivings, the German Parliament has approved without a dissenting vote Chancellor Adenauer's agreement to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviets as ransom payment for the return of the remaining German war prisoners.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Sept. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Pacific Railway's costal steamship fleet will be tied up Sunday midnight by a strike of 450 seamen on eleven passenger and ferry vessels.

IN "the Naked and the Dead," Norman Mailer set something of a pattern for long World War II novels. Not content with telling a rousing story, he searched the back alleys of his characters' minds, cutting the corners easily from present to past to present.

I KNOW it's unfair for a reviewer to pounce upon typographical errors; but occasionally one may provide the most entertaining moment in a week's reading. A nice instance is to be found in Brett Halliday's STRANGER IN TOWN (Torqull-Dodd, Mead, $2.75), in which Mike Shayne, waiting in a doctor's office, reads a diploma "which conveyed the reassuring information that Jay Philbrick had duly passed the proscribed courses in the Southern Medical College."
New traffic restrictions, effective tomorrow, for both the Manhattan Bridge and the Ship Canal Bridge over the Harlem River were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- When the German Government was criticized this week for establishing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union the German Ambassador, Heinz L. Krekeler, did what many another Ambassador here has done in the past. He sought out Senator Walter F. George of Georgia to explain.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Oklahoma's slashing split-T power finally cracked a stubborn, alert North Carolina defense for two second half touchdowns and a 13-6 victory before 35,000 fans today.
A detachment of the Washington Greys Regiment is scheduled to fly today to England to participate in a celebration in the village of Washington.

Y., and its progenitor was a sturdy Irish immigrant who settled there in 1793, married three times, sired thirteen children and amassed a fortune of $3,000,000 in real estate and public utilities.
MANILA, Sept. 24 -- President Ramon Magsaysay announced today the appointment of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo as Phillipine Ambassador to the United States.

Scholarship grants of $5,500 each to sixteen undergraduate and graduate students were announced yesterday by Thomas Liebman, president of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, at Lexington Avenue.

Republican and Democratic leaders across the nation joined last night in expressing hopes for President Eisenhower's recovery.

A STRANGER in West Texas, it was once suggested by a newspaper man there, might safely "cuss the heat, the dust, even Tom Connally." But one word about C. H. (Toots) Mansfield that "ain't nice, and you'd better be fast on the draw."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- Blue Choir, the 4-year-old Irish-bred colt owned by Mrs. Harry L. Nathenson of Chicago, won the third running of the rich United Nations Handicap at the Atlantic City Race Track today.

IN presenting a large exhibition of the work of the late Reginald Marsh, the Whitney Museum has put forward something of an anomaly-Marsh the artist in the large sense of the word versus Marsh the illustrator.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 24 -- The United States is prodding Rumania to permit the departure of 371 American-born persons or their chcildren.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Sept. 24 -- Trackers today followed the trail of four marauders from the scene of Thursday night's bus ambush across the Lebanese border to near the Lebanese village of Meiron er Ras, a Foreign Ministry spokesman announced.
FONTANA VILLAGE, N. C., Sept. 24 -- Douglas McKay assured the National Park Service conference today that the service's pending development and management program would not be pigeonholed.

HARDLY a year goes by in which I do not have to get out the sackcloth and ashes and sit down to a supper of crow. This one, it now appears, is to be no exception. The tendency to generalize, which I mentioned only recently, has got me into hot water again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Army may soon start getting younger draftees instead of the doddering old men of 23 that the well-filled manpower pool has been supplying recently. And the Navy, which recently issued its first call for draftees since the days of World War II, may also benefit from the plan to draft younger men first that is now being proposed by the Selective Service System.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Joe Sabol scored two touchdowns and turned in a sparkling all-around performance today to help Penn State crush Boston University, 35 -- 0, before 20,000 fans. Sabol, a third-string fullback, was playing only because of injuries to the two top plungers.

The writer of the following letter is chairman of the Department of Conservation and General Ecology at the American Museum of Natural History. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:"Climbing Color" on the editorial page and "Nature at Work" on the garden page of Sept. 18 extol the beauty of our country roadsides in the fall. I wonder how many Times readers realize how extensively our roadsides were devastated this summer by chemical sprays.

But as readers of "Bright Days" and "Fripsey Summer" could have told the girls, no year among the eleven members of the Fripsey family -- with three dogs and four cats -- could be a quiet one.

IN the theatre world, perhaps more than anywhere else, seventy-five years is a devastatingly long time. Names fade, stars grow dim, dramas that were hailed as great in their season seem naive, even ludicrous.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 -- The nation's third-ranking metropolis took a deep, choking breath this week and told itself for the umpteenth time that it really would have to do something about the smog.

MORE than once Graham Greene has announced, after a bout of scriptwriting from one of his own books, that he will never again feed the maw of the income tax commissioners with revenue from this source, but will stick to his novels.

IN his recording of "Messiah" for Westminster early last year, Hermann Scherchen showed he had a fresh way with Handel. Too fresh, some traditionalists thought. Be that as it may, his approach means there is special interest in his recording for the same company of another of the great Handelian monuments -- the twelve Concerti Grossi, Op. 6.

THIS book was planned to give young people a better understanding of how the United States developed from a small, weak nation into a great world power; a deeper appreciation of the ideals which have guided its growth; and a stronger loyalty to its institutions.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Soviet economists are planning for an annual output of electricity and coal by 1970 that will exceed the United States' production of these major power sources, according to the journal Problems of Economics.
ROME, Sept. 24 -- Vatican sources said today Juan D. Peron, Argentina's ousted President, could have his excommunication revoked by manifesting sincere contrition for the sins that caused it.

FULL of years and honors the great Swedish sculptor Carl Milles died last week at his dramatic villa-museum near Stockholm, working to the end and to the end conceiving monumental figure groups such as those that adorn so many public places in Sweden and in this country.

There were five horses in the $106,700 Sysonby Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. Four jockeys apparently had orders to go all-out from the start. The fifth jockey was instructed to play a waiting game. Jockey No. 5 rode the winner of the tremendously exciting race.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y. -- When some 48,000,000 persons visit approximately 500 of an estimated 1,500 historic home museums or sites in the United States in one year, as they did in 1954, the automobile may well be credited with a cultural victory.

AS a form of life insurance, annuity, the tontine system unquestionably left something to be desired; but it did surely add its peculiar excitement to survival in the two centuries preceding our own. When shareholders in a tontine died their interests automatically reverted for equal division among surviving shareholders.
An undersea volcano 100 miles east of the New Jersey coast was reported last week by a Columbia University ocean research expedition.
LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 18 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community has drawn a statistical profile of industrial Western Europe's economic "way of life."

I HAVE often thought in reading the history of our country how much is lost to us because so few of our Presidents have told their own stories. It would have been helpful for us to know more of what was in their minds and what impelled them to do what they did.

ATLANTA, Sept. 24 -- Department store sales are being maintained at highly satisfactory levels in the Southeast. Despite unusually warm weather in the area, demands for fall and winter goods are exceptionally high and sales of appliances and home furnishings continue to exceed those of a year ago.

HAL SAMPLE, physicist, came out of college twenty-two years too soon. In 1955 he would have been pounced upon by recruiters from Los Alamos to Oak Ridge. In 1933, in a torrid July week during which this story unfolds, he is just another unemployed man in a dreary, worked-out, hopeless town.
MANILA, Sept. 24 -- Hadji Kamlon, Moro outlaw leader, surrendered to the Philippine armed forces today after eight years of continuous rebellion against the Government.

WINNIPEG, Sask., Sept. 24 -Canada is faced with what is probably the worst grain surplus in its history. Grain handling and marketing facilities from country elevators to lake and seaboard terminals are jammed with the carryover from the 1954 crop and the first deliveries of the 1955 crop.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Michigan State's eleven, masterminded by seasoned Quarterback Earl Morrall and Fullback Jerry Planutis, overwhelmed Indiana today, 20 to 13, to assume the lead in the Big Ten title chase before 23,000 fans and a regional television audience.

Meetings have been held recently at the Waldorf-Astoria to further the success of the benefit theatre fete of the Institute of World Affairs, Inc. The event will take place at the Nov. 3 performance of "The Desk Set," with Shirley Booth, at the Broadhurst Theatre.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The State Department of Audit and Control has accused the city of Troy of payroll padding and fiscal mismanagement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health has been organized to conduct a national survey of the problem of mental illness.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- In a dramatic finish that caught both Colgate supporters and rivals by surprise, the Red Raiders turned back Dartmouth's football team today, 21-20. It was a finish that was highlighted by a remarkable comeback by the Maroon eleven.

Selling of bathing suits has become almost a year-round business, according to A. Louis Oresman, president of Catalina, Inc., manufacturer of swim wear. Merchants formerly marked down stocks soon after July 4 and inventories were virtually cleared by Aug. 1, he said. Increased leisure time, the availability of private swimming pools and the vogue of winter cruises have spread the demand for swimsuits.
The wild animals of the "Thirtieth Annual World's Championship Rodeo" were herded into town yesterday.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Boilermakers of Purdue beat the College of the Pacific football team, 14 -- 7, on a fourth - period touchdown pass that went for 58 yards.
The 1955 world series will be played in one of the largest and one of the smallest major league ballparks.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 24 -- Quarterback Paul Hornung, a rugged junior from Louisville, led Notre Dame to a bruising 17-0 opening victory over Southern Methodist.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet Union set off another nuclear explosion in the last few days.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 24 -- Business activity in the Kansas City area inched higher in a seasonal expansion last week as production and employment rose, but the best news for the district was the generous rainfall throughout the Winter Wheat Belt.

ALLIED ARTISTS, a company whose picture projects and plans are burgeoning, is making another ambitious move. Last week, it was learned that A.A. officials are negotiating a pre-production deal for film rights to "The Lark."

IF Paul Muni had to leave the cast of "Inherit the Wind" it is consoling to have Melvyn Douglas take his part. By this time everybody probably knows that Mr. Muni had to abandon one of his best roles when an eye affliction required immediate treatment.
Despite the old saw about oil and water, the Creole Petroleum Corporation has found a mixture of the two that keeps the world tanker fleet and company coffers well filled.
Soft sell, sociology and movies.

RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 20 -Despite efforts by proponents of colonial reaction on the one hand and by Pan-Arabism on the other to paint Moroccan nationalism as a "holy war," there are no signs here of antagonism between Islam and Christianity as religions.

PAUL MUNI, his host of admirers will be gratified to learn, appears to be mending nicely. Mr. Muni, chatting with the departmental agent the other afternoon, conveyed a heartening mood of cheerfulness and optimism, not to mention elation over the handsome reception accorded Melvyn Douglas, his successor in "Inherit the Wind."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Eisenhower's illness was expected in Washington tonight to have a profound and perhaps decisive effect on the 1956 Presidential campaign.

DENVER, Sept. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Robert S. Folsom, a career Foreign Service officer, today to be alternate United States representative on the Council of the Organization of American States. John C. Dreier is the regular representative.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24 -- Maj. Gen. Euardo Lonardi started today to organize his Government. Simultaneously he began to dismantle one of the main props of the Peron regime -- the once powerful General Confederation of Labor.

DURING the exciting centuries when science was in hot pursuit of the mastery of nature, the underlying question of whether its quantitative concepts represented the truth about man and the universe could be disregarded.

HAPPY Americans returning from a summer vacation in Spain tell of eating paella; many want to know how to make it at home. The combination of rice with chicken, sausage and seafood-still-inits-shells seems to have something for everyone. There is drama in the great dish offering so many ingredients; there is deliciousness, too.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Northeastern states battened down this week for the hurricane that went to sea, an exercise that may have left many people a bit frustrated but illustrated how well Northerners have learned the lesson of preparedness.
American Indians and their friends celebrated the forty-first annual American Indian Day in ceremonies yesterday in Brooklyn and on Staten Island.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 -- Steel production in the ClevelandLorain district climbed to 101 per cent of capacity, highest since June. The previous week's revised rate was 98.5 per cent. After skidding to 1,369 in the holiday week, sales of new automobiles increased to 1,706 as dealers offered attractive bargains.
TOKYO, Sept. 24 -- Large quantities of the germ that causes colitis have been discovered in a variety of standard food items, in a spot check of 2,144 food stores in Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A publication of the Congress of Industrial Organizations confessed today to error on the conservative side.

WASHINGTON, D. C. -- Gettysburg will be more accessible from here for President Eisenhower after he returns from his Colorado vacation and wants to drive to his farm up there -- as well as for the many sight-seers who motor up to the great Civil War battlefield -- because of a nine-mile extension of the Washington National Pike between Rockville and Germantown, Md.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- British newspapers were virtually unanimous today in criticizing the Government's White Paper on the disappearance of Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess, former Foreign Office officials.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals honored two agreeable little dogs here yesterday. They were Micky, because he has been around for quite a while, and Brenda, because she saved the life of a friend -- a careless parakeet.
COMEDY writers and an energetic race horse are among the creatures that have caused Menasha Skulnik some unpleasant moments since he began working on television five years ago.

Soon after the Atomic Energy Commission was created we began to think of atomic energy in terms of power as well as of weapons. The possibility of substituting fissile uranium for coal in central stations and ships was readily accepted, but atomically driven airplanes were considered romantically improbable because the reactor or "furnace" in which heat is generated had to be shielded by a mass of concrete and steel that weighed tons.

THE genesis of "The Secret Raiders" is in the Germanically meticulous war diaries of the raiders' skippers and the no-less careful reviews of the same by the German Naval Staff (the SKL or Seekriegsleitung).

OVER the years we have evolved, a pattern, which now amounts to a convention, for the memoirs of a city man or dude who goes to the country. Within this pattern, the narrator arrives rather naive, survives trials and adventures among amusing and often conniving natives, and comes out triumphant.
New York churchgoers will join in prayer this morning for the speedy recovery of President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- An Illinois corn-hog farmer came to town this week to see the sights and perhaps pick up a word or two on the state of the union. He found few to talk with at the White House and on Capitol Hill.
NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Boston College, lacking several players because of a virus infection, blanked Brandeis, 27 -- 0, today in the football opener for both teams.
New York and Brooklyn department store sales failed to march year-ago levels again last week, owing chiefly to poor apparel volume and to the hurricane threat early in the week.

MOST of us, when profoundly stirred, express ourselves in cliches. Although "deeply moving" is a reviewer's overworked phrase, it is applied without apology to "Return to the Wood." Someone is quoted on the book's jacket as finding it "the most satisfying novel of World War I yet to appear," and many a reader, including this one, will agree.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24 -Spurred by a 23 per cent gain in August, volume of business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District stood 8 per cent above last year's figures for the first eight months of the year, the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank reported.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Divide and transplant big old clumps of perennials and set out new ones. Peony, Japanese iris, bleeding heart and Oriental poppy are first on the list. Perennials need time to make root growth in fall so that they will not be pushed out of the ground by frost in winter.

JUST twenty years after the publication of the first edition of "The Leica Manual" in 1935, the thirteenth will make its appearance next week. It will have a new title, "Leica Manual and Data Book" (New York: Morgan Lester. $6) and a changed character.

IN the average home workshop little attention seems to be given to the hacksaw and other metal-cutting tools. But the new popularity of brass, aluminum and wrought-iron furniture inspires many metalworking projects, creating a need for information on metal cutting.

THE premiere of the "Screen Directors Playhouse" on Oct. 5 with "Meet the Governor" will mark the entry into television of Leo McCarey, three-time Academy Award winner and maker of such movie hits as "Ruggles of Red Gap," "The Awful Truth," "Going My Way" and the memorable "Make Way for Tomorrow."

ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Governor Harriman's Public Works Superintendent today angrily protested an accusation that his department had attempted to break down "honest procedure" in connection with land acquisition for the St. Lawrence power project.
