WASHINGTON -- Witch-hunting methods of enforcing traffic laws and regulations were denounced at the fifty-third annual convention of the American Automobile Association here last week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Falling farm prices continued to supply ammunition today for Democratic and Republican verbal brickbats.

The rise and fall of Juan Domingo Peron, ex-dictator, ex-President of Argentina, was one of the great dramas of Latin-American history. To trace the ascending and descending curve of Peron's flaming career is like watching a play in which one man holds the center of the stage until tragedy overtakes him and the curtain falls.
ATLANTA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Prisoners at the honor farm of the Federal penitentiary here now can have members of their families as their guests for Sunday dinner.

IN "Protestant-Catholic-Jew" Will Herberg has written the most fascinating essay on the religious sociology of America that has appeared in decades. He has digested all the relevant historical, sociological and other analytical studies, but the product is no mere summary of previous findings.
ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Cornell came out of the fog that shrouded Schoellkopf Field today to win its football opener against Lehigh, 14 to 6.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- A set of bruising Illinois backs rolled up yardage easily today. But they showed a surprising lack of scoring punch and the Illini were pressed to the limit to defeat California, 20-13.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- "Another term for President Eisenhower is quite conceivable," Dr. Paul Dudley White, one of the world's foremost heart specialists, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that major crimes in the United States had declined in the first six months of the year, the first drop since 1948.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British Government was urged to investigate investments by United States concerns in the British chemical industry.

Many persons who are under the impression that they "love God and love their neighbor" should seek to discover "what impressions they are making on God and neighbor," Msgr. William T. Greene declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has authorized the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex., to expand its natural gas pipeline system at an estimated cost of $56,001,000.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- India this week will face the most important test of national unity since she achieved independence eight years ago.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 25 -- (AP) Doug Ford of Yonkers, N. Y., shot a four-under-par 68 today to gain a two-stroke lead in the $43,000 Sponsors golf tournament at the Charles River Country Club. Fifty-four holes have been played.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- Following is a chronology of events in President Eisenhower's illness. The times are in Mountain Standard Time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The prospects of tax reduction next year have produced a spate of newspaper speculation on the size and shape of probable relief and the strategy of Republican and Democratic policymakers. But the forecasts, authoritative as some may sound, can represent nothing better than informed guesswork at this stage.

Ten thousand persons at a Harlem rally were urged yesterday to go to the ballot boxes, to exhort their political precinct captains and, if need be, to march on Washington to bring an end to racism and lynching in the United States.
Andy Kuchinski, the football coach at Adelphi Academy of Brooklyn, was talking about his new halfback. He said the new boy was the team's best kicker as well as one of its best passers.
Granville S. Gilpatrick has been elected a director of the Crown Cork International Corporation. He is managing director of Woodstock Associates, Boston, Mass.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- A delegation of French Deputies and Senators returned here today from a tour of the Soviet Union.
Rate leaps were noted in the ship charter market last week. Coal reached new heights, followed closely by advancing grain rates.

The opening of a new passenger and automobile ferry service on Dec. 15 between Key West, Fla., and Havana, Cuba, was announced yesterday by Daniel E. Taylor, president of the West India Fruit and Steamship Company, Inc. For several years it has operated railroad car ferries between Havana and Florida.

Dr. Robert Hutchins, in his recent address, made the statement "in almost no case that I can think of, from the Hollywood Ten to the teachers suspended in New York a few days ago, has it been suggested that the alleged political views of the individual had any effect upon his work.
DENVER, Monday, Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower's condition last night was officially described as "satisfactory."
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- The National League champion Dodgers go into the world series with a "winning streak" of one game.

HEWITT, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Teen-agers were acclaimed the speed-boat stars here today. One, a 16-year-old, William Holmes Jr. of Piermont, N. Y., was the only double winner in the regatta of the Greenwood Lake Racing Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Democratic leaders of Congress will treat President Eisenhower's illness as a national crisis and will conduct the affairs of the legislative branch of the Government accordingly.

IN 1855 when young Tom was ten years old a little girl came to live at his Aunt Sarah's farm in the Ohio River bottomlands of West Virginia. Cathie, a solemn little thing, 8 years old, had nowhere else to go. When she told Tom that "my father shall be a king some day" he didn't know whether to believe her.
Those high in state Democratic party quarters had a positive view yesterday on one possible political effect of President Eisenhower's illness.

SANDS POINT, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. J. J. McDonald's Wings won the working hunter championship at the Sands Point horse show today. Wings scored in a hack-off after a tie at 11 points with Mrs. Sallie Sexton's Field Goal.
Steve Allen has signed a new three-year contract with the National Broadcasting Company, according to Jules L. Green, the entertainer's agent. The terms were not revealed.

With the opening this week of the 241-mile Ohio Turnpike the American motorist will be offered another opportunity to demonstrate that he can be a partner in highway safety. This newest in the steadily growing system of toll roads across the northeast quarter of the country contains every built-in safety feature that skilled engineering can provide, but it will be of no avail unless drivers practice courtesy and common sense on the highway.
A new state program to provide anti-polio vaccine for all persons 1 to 19 years old and for all expectant mothers was announced yesterday.
THE return of the Obernkirchen Children's Choir to Town Hall Saturday night was a happy one both for the children and for their audience, which seemed to include many old friends.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Field Marshal Sir John Harding, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, was appointed today as Governor of Cyprus. He will also be Commander in Chief of the British forces on the Mediterranean island.

Since the spotlight of public discussion has been focused on the issue wishfully referred to by critics of Administration policy in this area as "the plight of the farmer," everyone, as Mr. Durante would say, has been trying to get into the act. In some cases these guest artists have been able to make at least a minor contribution; some, it will probably be generally agreed, might better have remained in the wings.

BEING an adroit scene-stealer by nature, Casey Stengel wasn't going to let anyone muscle him out of the spotlight. That was for certain. Hence, it can surprise no one that the fellow who made this wise old codger the most accurate of prophets had to be Charles Dillon Stengel, the eminent monologist.

In the first change of ownership since 1919, the four-story private dwelling on a lot 20 by 102 feet at 338 West Eighty-fourth Street was sold by the estate of Maximilian Lewson to the M. C. Berg Realty Corporation, operator. The Morgenthau-Seixas Company was the broker. The property is assessed at $23,000.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System fired its first salvo Saturday night in a war of "spectaculars" with the National Broadcasting Company. The triumphant production that resulted indicates that audiences may be the big winners in the season's battles for ratings between the networks.

" A Day by the Sea," which enjoyed a long run in London, arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the ANTA Theatre. The drama was written by N. C. Hunter, a London playwright, who is making his New York debut.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Interest rates will increase little if at all during the remainder of this year, Homer J. Livingston, outgoing president of the American Bankers Association and president of the First National Bank of Chicago, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Opposition to President Eisenhower's moderate internationalist foreign policy was expected today to increase during the President's enforced convalescence.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- William T. Moor's 57-foot yawl, Argyll, won the final race of the series and the top prize today in the Philip J. Roosevelt trophy competition sponsored by the Seawanhaka - Corinthian Yacht Club.
Yom Kippur -- the Day of Atonement -- began at sundown yesterday for Jews over the world.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- The steel industry this week is headed into a period of activity that will break records for production and shipments. But this booming activity will not still the demand for steel or satisfy the shipment requirements of the industry's customers.
The decision of the Protestant Episcopal Church to retain the word "Protestant" in its name was applauded yesterday by the Very Rev. James A. Pike, Dean of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Following is a translated text of a radio broadcast tonight by Hugo de Pietro, secretary general of the General Confederation of Labor:
The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries reported over the week-end sizable gains in operating revenues and net income for the eight and twelve months ended Aug. 31.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 25 -- The Netherlands budget for, 1956 shows expenditure of 6,682,000,000 guilders and revenue of 6,102,000,000. This leaves an expected deficit of 580,000,000 guilders, against the original estimate of a 610,000,000-guilder deficit for the current year.

First prize in the national poetry contest conducted by the Catholic Daughters of America was awarded yesterday to Sister Assumpta, a student at Fordham University. She is a Dominican nun at St. Benedict's Convent, 2951 Otis Avenue, the Bronx.
SEOUL,. Korea, Sept. 25-- United States Ambassador William S. B. Lacy has asked Korean Government officials to present a true picture to the Korean public of tax claims against American business men.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Bolivia plans to propose tomorrow that a disarmament program for Latin-American nations be launched under United Nations auspices. The program would be separate from that under discussion by the great powers.

Perhaps the clearest signal light flashed across from Moscow in many a week was the cable in The Times reporting the unscheduled speech by Nikita Khrushchev at the banquet for the visiting East German delegation.

DENVER, Sept. 25 -- The White House revealed tonight that it had asked the Attorney General's office for an opinion on the constitutionality of delegating certain Presidential powers to another person in the event the President was unable to carry them out.
Two teller windows will be opened in the Grand Central subway station this morning by the Bowery Savings Bank. Thus subway riders will be able to do their banking without leaving the station.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 25 -- A state store was besieged last week by women seeking to examine new gas ranges. One attraction, said the manager, is that the metal containers for the "bottled" gas on which the ranges operate are more available.
WASHINGTON Sept. 25 (UP) -- Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, called today for a "crash program" to harness the hydrogen bomb for peaceful uses.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- Seth Ramakrishna Dalmia, one of India's most important business men, was arrested here today on a charge of embezzlement and criminal breach of trust.

LONDON, Sept 25 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight the text of a letter Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin sent to West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. The letter said the way was now clear for the two countries to establish diplomatic relations.

Thirty-seven years ago next week 651 American soldiers were trapped by the Germans in a drizzle-soaked ravine beside a stream called the Ruisseau de Charlevaux in the Argonne Forest of France. Only 194 survived.
ROME, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Mayor Elmer E. Robinson of San Francisco today urged "serious consideration" of new tax measures to aid revenue-starved city governments.
Constitutional experts agreed yesterday that President Eisenhower's heart ailment called attention to one of the most important and unsettled problems of the Presidency:
A continuation of the downward trend in the city's public assistance caseload was reported to Mayor Wagner yesterday by Acting Welfare Commissioner Crystal M. Potter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams threw a bristling defense against San Francisco today and used four breaks to whip the Forty-Niners, 23 -- 14, in their National Football League opener before 60,000 at Kezar Stadium.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- With uncertainty increasing as to the measures that R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, will take in his further endeavors to arrest the growth of inflation in the national economy, activity on the stock markets here remains at an unusually low level.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Many supporters of the new Government here were astonished tonight by the announcement that President Eduardo Lonardi had agreed that he would not modify the situation" of the newspaper La Prensa.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The possibility that President Eisenhower may not run for re-election next year will have no immediate effect on the political plans of Adlai E. Stevenson.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ray Boone knocked in two runs with a single and double to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 6-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today before a crowd of 17,888 in Briggs Stadium.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Billy Pierce blanked the Kansas City Athletics with three hits today to pitch the Chicago White Sox to a 5-0 victory.

ON Saturday morning, April 14, I arose at dawn. I have always been an early riser, but this was earlier than usual. The body of Franklin Roosevelt was to arrive that morning from Warm Springs, Ga., and I was going to the Union Station to meet the funeral train.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The United States is willing to sell weapons to Egypt on credit.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Wage increases already accorded or projected as a result of labor agitation have remained within the economic limits set by the Government. But more would put the national economy and finances in a critical state.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Art Doering, Inwood professional, became the Metropolitan open golf champion today.
The Ward International Corporation, a holding company, disclosed over the week-end that it had acquired a "substantial" block of the Martin-Parry Corporation and was the latter's largest stockholder.
The policy of the Police Department is to enforce all laws as written, including those against gambling in general and bingo in particular, Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday.

SALAMI, sausage of the hard or dry type, varies widely in taste, depending on the country of origin and even on the individual manufacturer. One of the finest, as gourmets abroad long have known, is Herz salami. First made in Hungary, it is now being shipped here from a factory just outside Amsterdam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The illness of President Eisenhower may affect the economy because of the changed 1956 election outlook, but it will not have any serious impact in the months just ahead, in the view of leading Government economists.
The 1955 grape harvest in the Champagne region of northeast France got under way yesterday. The recent warm sunny weather in the area has led growers to expect a banner year.

EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Clarence A. Davis, Under Secretary of the Interior, said today that he was "sick and tired" of listening to the "political hogwash" of Socialists who wanted to federalize the nation's electric power industry.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 25 -- Juan D. Peron's overthrow did not produce the electrifying effect on stock exchange business that was expected. This was because it was spread over so many stages, during which news from Argentina was conflicting and confusing.

JUSSI Bjoerling, tenor, returned after an absence of a year and a half to sing a recital in Carnegie Hall Saturday evening. Mr. Bjoerling had been absent from this country since March 13, 1954. Because of recurrent attacks of bronchitis, he canceled his engagements for the remainder of the season and returned to his native Sweden.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower now has his wife and only son virtually at his bedside day and night.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Alan (The Horse) Ameche galloped 79 yards for a touchdown the first time he carried the ball in regular season professional football today as the Baltimore Colts upset the Chicago Bears, 23 -- 17.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that President Eisenhower had "set up the Administration in such a way that policies, which are well defined, will be carried out in his absence."

Germany's economic recovery since World War II has been the result of "orthodox" policies, says Henry C. Wallich in "Mainsprings of German Revival,"* but the country has been "far from a laissez-faire paradise." The Government has planned and managed everything but has contrived to do it from the standpoint of the employer and capitalist.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- A Conservative Member of Parliament described the recent revelations on Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess today as "an astonishing story of sustained ineptitude."

THE Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House divided its week-end equally between "Le Lac des Cygnes" and "Coppelia." "Le Lac" took over both of Saturday's performances, and "Coppelia," both of yesterday's, with a different ballerina on each occasion.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- The Soviet Union is thirty to fifty years behind the United States industrially, but is making rapid progress, Senator George W. Malone said here today. He had just returned from an eight-day journey beyond the Ural Mountains.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Despite this year's soaring consumer, business and mortgage credit, the nation's total supply of money has so far been held under control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- When the national conventions of the two major political parties assemble next summer it will have been thirty-six years since both did so without clear prospects of who their Presidential nominees were to be. The last two "open" conventions, meaning those in which the outcome is in doubt up to the last minute, that were held in the same year were in 1920.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Personal income in the United States in 1954 totaled $285,368,000,000, an increase of about 1 per cent more than 1953, the Commerce Department reported today.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 25 (UP) -- An 18-yard touchdown pass from Tobin Rote to Gary Knafelc in the last twenty seconds gave the Green Bay Packers a 20 -- 17 triumph over the Detroit Lions today.

The Canadian Legion joined forces yesterday with the Queens County American Legion and other veterans' groups in a parade down Northern Boulevard to the Flushing Armory on Main Street. The event ended a three-day meeting of the Canadian Legion in New York.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- A political truce among anti-Peronist parties is expected while they work together to bar a comeback by Gen. Juan D. Peron and his supporters.
MONTREAL, Sept. 25 -- Public officials of big cities opened a spirited competition today for qualified planners.

ATHENS, Sept. 25 -- Because of our cumbersome security program the United States is gradually losing prestige and positions in international organizations. Our system of loyalty clearances and prior investigations often causes crippling delays before an American is eligible to accept a job on any of the numerous world bodies to which we belong.
Increased religious instruction to combat juvenile delinquency is recommended in the second interim report of a committee of the Catholic Lawyers Guild.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Congress will not make public the expense accounts of its members traveling abroad at taxpayers' expense, it was said today.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- The American League champion Yankees wound up their regular season today by splitting a doubleheader with the Red Sox. A surprisingly large crowd of 26,228 fans turned out for the meaningless twin bill and enjoyed every minute of it.

After a survey of the political, military and economic situation in the Far East, the Anzus Council has agreed that until the "spirit of Geneva" has been translated into a genuine peace the free world must keep up its guard against further Communist aggression.
A young Coast Guard member being rushed home from mid- Atlantic to the bedside of his critically ill wife arrived late last night at Rosebank, S. I.

From all over the world have come the messages of goodwill toward President Eisenhower on the occasion of his illness. We rejoice over the news that he is progressing satisfactorily and join in the chorus of good wishes for his speedy and complete recovery.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Doris Day will return to the Metro-Goldwin-Mayer studio to star in "The Amazing Nellie Bly." The actress will play Elizabeth Cochrane, the first of the great women reporters, who wrote in 1880 under the name of Nellie Bly. The climax of her career was a seventy-two-day tour of the world.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Communist Rumania has decreed a sweeping amnesty for many persons jailed on war-crimes charges, the Bucharest radio reported today.
State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams said yesterday that the growing volume of landlord-tenant cases threatened to swamp rent offices here.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 25 -- Terrorist acts cost four lives and left thirteen persons wounded in Morocco today.
Earnings of the Magnavox Company in the fiscal year ended June 30 were the highest in the company's history according to the report issued for publication today.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- British exporters were urged by the Treasury today to make greater efforts to sell to the expanding markets of North America and Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The United States, with record speed, recognized today the Argentine Revolutionary Government of Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi.

Backward - looking religionists "who have to be dragged screaming into the twentieth century" were assailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Carroll E. Simcox in his first sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.
Dollar deliveries to the Air Force will be stabilized through 1959 at between six and seven billion dollars a year. They have risen from $5,600,000,000 in 1953 to a probable $6,600,000,000 this year.
BOMBAY, India, Sept. 25 -- The Goan Liberation Committee announced a decision today to continue to send unarmed Indian volunteers into that Portuguese enclave.
The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad suffered a $1,157,511 net loss, before capital and sinking funds, last month. That reflected extraordinary expenses because of flood damage.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Ch. Blakeen van Aseltine won his seventeenth best in show award today in the annual event of the Northwestern Connecticut Dog Club. The white miniature poodle, owned by Mrs. Marguerite S. Tyson of Washington, was handled by Howard Tyler. Frank J. Parker of Avon, Conn., judged.

A great deal has been written in recent months to the effect that what at the end of 1954 had been merely a "recovery" of the economy from the post-Korean recession had increasingly taken on the aspects of a full-fledged boom since about the end of the first quarter of 1955.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- In the last thirty-six hours the summer White House has changed from a thing of golden, indolent tranquillity to a cold, gray, chaotic nightmare.
Leo Durocher's reign as manager of the Giants ended yesterday as the Polo Grounders finished their 1955 campaign by splitting a double-header with the Phillies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The 9-year-old Congressional retirement system now is paying out $372,120 a year to 107 former lawmakers. Members of Congress voted the pension plan in 1946.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 25 -- The orchestra of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society scored a triumphant success here tonight at the La Scala Opera House. The first concert of its Italian tour marked the opening of the symphonic season of one of Europe's leading opera centers.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Edward Lonardi's new Government made peace with organized labor tonight.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Scoring in each quarter, the Washington Redskins defeated the Cleveland Browns, 27 -- 17, today in the National Football League season opener here before 30,041 fans.
DAMODAR VALLEY, India, Sept. 13 -- The Damodar River, once India's River of Sorrows, has turned this valley into one of the most important industrial basins in Asia.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Prices advanced sharply on the Board of Trade last week, especially for soybeans.
The Navy transport General Langfitt is scheduled to arrive today with 1,118 refugees from Europe.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 25 -- As the Communist promoted banana workers' strike entered its third week, the Labor Ministry made a fresh effort to prevent its spread. Red leaders have threatened to carry it to the main United Fruit Company production area of Golfito.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steel Workers, C. I. O., announced today that the union would demand premium pay for Saturdays and Sundays in the basic steel industry. Contract negotiations will begin in 1956.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Wally Moon smashed a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning today to give the St. Lopis Cardinals an 8-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. It was the final game of the season for both clubs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Jess Oppenheimer, the radio and television producer, director and writer, has signed an exclusive contract with the National Broadcasting Company as a major program department executive.
Al Kaline, Detroit Tigers' 20-year-old outfielder, and Richie Ashburn, center-fielder of the Philadelphia Phillies, are the major leagues' new batting champions.
Multitudes the world over raised their voices in prayer yesterday for the health of President Eisenhower.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Indochinese Kingdom of Cambodia formally declared her independence from France today after nearly 100 years of association. Prince Norodom Sihanouk was named Premier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -The United States will publish the record of last July's Big Four conference at Geneva before the Big Four foreign ministers meet at Geneva on Oct. 27, administration officials said today.

Baseball attendance in the major leagues increased nearly 700,000 over 1954, largely because of the big jump at home by the Athletics, who transferred from Philadelphia to Kansas City, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
A mystery man long active in longshore circles on the New York waterfront has been identified by West Coast dockers under Harry Bridges as their official representative in the Port of New York.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- Friendship is just a word in the dictionary, Fred Haney concluded today.

The two-seated democrat is a meaningful part of American vehicular tradition. The democrat did not have the cozy intimacy of the top buggy nor the stylish flair of the fringe-top surrey. But many a man who drives a car with several score horsepower magically concealed in a small space beneath a metal hood remembers the sturdy, utilitarian, two-seated democrat.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs today routed the Chicago Cubs, 13 -- 0. Art Fowler hurled a four-hitter and Smoky Burgess got two homers for the Redlegs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today fell heir to one of the greatest responsibilities and political opportunities ever presented to so young a man in the history of the Republic.

In ordering a restudy of the economic plans for the Philippines, President Magsaysay has laid down six principles that should guide the efforts of the National Economic Council. They are realistic as well as imaginative. They reject doctrinaire Socialist concepts and place emphasis on individual initiative and effort.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- The possible political implications of President Eisenhower's illness, as far as the 1956 election is concerned, center on California. It has four of the leading potential alternate Republican entries for the Presidential contest.

It is almost incredible that the Department of State should hail the results of Chancellor Adenauer's visit to Moscow as a diplomatic triumph which demonstrated the "bankruptcy of Soviet policy with respect to Germany."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Army announced today it would soon test a plan for operating supply centers on a supermarket, self-service basis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Radio-Electronics-Television Manufacturers Association (Retma), announced today the appointment of a committee to study television channel problems and make recommendations to the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Labor's potency took on new significance today as political leaders measured the effects likely to flow from President Eisenhower's illness.
Expressions of hope for President Eisenhower's recovery continued to pour forth yesterday from leaders of governments in all parts of the world.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -The smog in which Los Angeles is shrouded periodically is composed of many esoteric chemicals. But the peskiest ingredient of the moment is politics.
Prices of cotton futures moved irregularly -- lower on the whole -- on the New York Cotton Exchange last week.
Two diverse efforts to give consumers a better understanding of the fundamentals of advertising were reported over the week-end.
A MEN'S accessory manufacturer believes men are beginning to show a bit of romance at least in their jewelry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Future Government tax concessions to defense industries will be governed by two new rules to be announced tomorrow.
The Citizens Budget Commission, in a bulletin sent yesterday to its membership, declared that the city "may be at the crossroads of its budget history."
The men's clothing industry operated at 87 per cent of capacity during August, compared to 79 per cent a year earlier, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association.
Eighty-six railroaders, railroad buffs and "just regular people" made a 300-mile "Around Long Island" excursion by train and bus yesterday.

HONOLULU, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Two of the five crewmen who ditched their crippled cargo plane Friday more than 1,000 miles west of here were picked up alive tonight by a freighter. The other three were dead, the Coast Guard said.
MADRID, Sept. 25 -- Two years ago tomorrow the United States and Spain signed agreements that marked the beginning of the economic and military collaboration between the two countries.
A crash on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad yesterday blocked the eastbound tube for fifteen hours and threatened to create a bad snarl in commuter service this morning.
At the Riverside Church yesterday the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken began his "tenth year in the service of Christ and this church" by stressing the high standards of a Christian creed.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Premier Edgar Faure said tonight that France must and would keep Algeria as an integral part of the mother country.

The Committee on Pastorate of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, has named the Rev. David H. C. Read of Edinburgh, Scotland, as successor to the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Juan D. Peron left Argentina for exile in Paraguay this afternoon.
MIAMI, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Hurricane Janet's death toll climbed tonight to 104. It was expected to go even higher as the hurricane gained power roaring across the mid-Caribbean.

HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A widespread search was underway tonight for three Langley Air Force Base jet pilots whose F-84F Thunderstreak planes were reported missing twelve hours after a wing mate was killed in a crash in a back bay marsh at Hampton.

How the California gold seekers amused themselves is the subject of a book, "Taming the Forty - Niner," by Elisabeth Margo. Before the arrival of the "Ladies," it was bear and bull fights, duels, fandangoes, hangings (a popular diversion), and "Bad Women."
Five new films, including imports from England and France, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
The debt owed by this country to a friend of Revolutionary days will be repaid on his 200th birthday anniversary.
OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- Four United States Cabinet members arrived here this evening for conferences with Canadian Government leaders on common economic problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said today some United States military leaders felt that all American troops should be brought home from Korea at "an early date."

Word that the five-cent cigar -- in face of the surrender in recent years of the nickel cup of coffee, phone call and subway ride -- not only is still with us but has been regaining lost popularity is a cheering thought.

In comparing the Yankees and Dodgers, baseball's outstanding academic minds already are finding themselves grappling with a most unusual development. Not in many years have the experts been confronted by an autumn classic so thoroughly baffling as the one starting Wednesday at the Yankee Stadium.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25 -- A mother who apparently had drowned her only child in a bath-tub leaped to her death from a fifth floor fire escape tonight after sending her husband on an errand.

The comments by Prof. Edwin E. Witte and Leo M. Drachsler on the employment of older people contain legalistic suggestions that may do little to solve the basic problem. It may be desirable to legislate matters of this kind. But in the long run legal compulsions, like those of the fair employment acts, may be met with reluctance by employers and resentment by the employes most affected by them.
YOU might pass the old brownstones on the north side of Fourteenth Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues a good many times without noticing a little sign, "Iglesa Catholica Guadalupe."
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- They wept in Moscow's Baptist Church tonight when they heard that President Eisenhower was ill.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Polly Riley of Fort Worth won her third women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today with an 11-and-9 triumph over Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- The position of the confiscated newspaper La Prensa gives the new provisional Argentine Government a knotty problem.

"Notes for a Journal," a personal memoir purportedly dictated by the late Maxim Litvinov, first Soviet Ambassador to the United States, will be published by Morrow on Oct. 25. E. H. Carr, internationally known auhority on Russia, examined the manuscript, which covers the period from 1926 to 1939, for authenticity.

HOME is potentially the most dangerous place a person can be in 1955. Five million Americans may be injured there this year and, by 1975, home accidents may affect 7,000,000 of them. These figures were presented yesterday at the first session of a two-day conference on safer living. The conference is being held at the Pierre Hotel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 26 -- Even opponents of the Communist party acknowledge that the Reds will probably gain the second or third highest total of votes in Indonesia's first nationwide election Thursday.
Agreement was announced yesterday on a director for the $800,000 study of rapid transit in the New Jersey-New York metropolitan area.

DENVER, Tuesday, Sept. 27 -- Barring complications, President Eisenhower should be well enough within the next two weeks to resume some personal control of the nation's affairs, a noted heart specialist said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Stephen Stephanopoulos, Greek Foreign Minister, expressed pessimism in a speech today over the refusal of the General Assembly last week to place on its agenda the question of the British colony of Cyprus.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- Louis J. Russo, assistant chief examiner and secretary of the State Civil Service Commission, was dismissed today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner Mr. Russo had been under suspension for fifteen months charged with illegally accepting $2,000 in overtime payments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- The reaction in grain and soybean futures to the President's illness was the reverse of that in the stock market. Buying on a big scale came into the pits after an indifferent opening.

DUBLIN, Sept. 26 -- One of the characters in the Abbey Theatre's latest play remarks that his only chance of making big money is to go to England and get a pick-and-shovel job. The laughter that greets this sally does not divert Irishmen from the most serious problem facing the republic -- the emigration of tens of thousands of young men and women to Britain.
Neal Rivers, 155 3/4, Niagara Falls, N. Y., won a unanimous decision over Bobby Dawson, 153 1/2, New York, in the ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 -- Canadian and United States Cabinet members agreed here today to have experts try to devise a way by which the United States can dispose of surplus farm products without hurting Canadian export markets.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Canada called on members of the United Nations General Assembly today to respond to the efforts of the great powers to relax international tension.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- The inevitable has happened. A United States motorist has driven right through Russia and into Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The official theme in Washington today was that "the team will carry on as before," but even on the most optimistic assumption about President Eisenhower's recovery, this seems highly unlikely.
DENVER, Sept. 26 -- The Constitutional issue of delegating an incapacitated President's powers to another person is not likely to be met head on within the next few days.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Governor Harriman has stayed for another month the execution of John Francis Roche, convicted rape-slayer of a New York City schoolgirl.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- A major American motion-picture company will lend to Japanese industry 2,700,000,000 yen (about $7,500,000) from frozen funds, if negotiations with the Motion Picture Association of America, now under way, are completed, according to Masaichi Nagata, president of the Daiei Motion Picture Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A project linking limited disarmament and inspection in Europe to the unification of Germany will be submitted to the Western foreign ministers when they meet in New York tomorrow.
The port's top tracker of waterfront racketeering has resigned to return to private law practice.
A project to send fifty women around the world to inspect United Nations contributions and to report their findings to the nation was announced yesterday.
MADRID, Sept. 26 -- The Spanish Government indicated today that it intended to participate in any decisions that would affect the future of Morocco.

J. Fischer Bro., music publisher, has purchased a site in Glen Rock, N. J., for a new office building. The parcel, comprising two and one-half acres on Harristown Road, was acquired from the B. R. V. Realty Company through the offices of George H. Beckmann, Inc., broker.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 26 -- The United Nations truce headquarters said here today neither Israeli nor Egyptian forces had budged from their positions in El Auja in the demilitarized zone.

The meeting of eight top Cabinet ministers of the United States and Canada in Ottawa yesterday was symbolic as well as practical. As Secretary Dulles said on his arrival in the Canadian capital, no two countries in the world have so great a flow of trade between them as the United States and Canada.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Dr. Mohamed Fadhil al-Jamali, Iraqi delegate, asked today that small states receive a voice at such meetings as next month's Big Four conference in Geneva.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- "A Christmas Carol," by Charles Dickens, will be offered to television viewers on "The M-G-M Parade" show over the American Broadcasting Company network during Christmas week.

Modernization is planned for two buildings at 244-46 Third Avenue that Edward Schwartz, real estate operator, has purchased from the 33 Gramercy Park South Realty Corporation. The two four-story structures, now vacant, occupy a plot 48 by 75 feet at the northwest corner of Twentieth Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- More than 5,000 persons tried to crowd into Moscow's Central Synagogue for a Yom Kippur service today. The capacity of the synagogue does not exceed 2,000. The street near the synagogue was filled with persons for more than 100 yards.

Silver-haired David B. Steinman, designer of the Henry Hudson Bridge, appeared among the blue beanies of freshmen registering for classes at Columbia University yesterday. He returned to the School of Engineering to set up a $10,000 "debt of honor" scholarship fund.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, recalled today that exactly two years ago Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Primate of Poland, was unlawfully deprived by the Polish Communist Government of his pastoral prerogatives.

The new Code of Conduct for Prisoners of War is merely a beginning in teaching troops to trade capture and interrogation, he of its authors said yesterday. Stephen S. Jackson, assistant general counsel of the Defense department, said prisoners who talked least fared best.

WHEN Christian finally reached Paradise and Robinson Crusoe escaped from his island they established a precedent most novelists have been glad to follow. By the last page of three out of four novels, problems are solved, true love is triumphant and hero and heroine seem destined to live happily ever after.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- France faced political resistance as well as armed rebellion in her Algerian departments today.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 -- Normal service was restored today fifteen hours after yesterday's two-train crash here on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad.
Peter Fusco, 78-year-old Bronx farmer who had until yesterday to rid his one-acre farm of four cows, won a dismissal of his case in court.

As a regular visitor to the United States I am well aware that the freedom of which its citizens boast is a real and happy fact. May I therefore, tell you about the unfortunate impression an Englishman gets when he applies for a United States visa in London?
Traffic tie-ups developed last evening on approaches to the Manhattan Bridge as the result of repairs that are being made.

Disgruntled over the possibility of a down-grading in pay scales, more than 700 registered nurses voted last night to form a permanent organization to protect the rights of more than 3,000 registered nurses in the twenty-eight municipal hospitals.
The publisher of a Bogota newspaper closed by the Colombian Government said yesterday that press censorship had been replaced in his country by "self-regulation" under arbitrary rules.
Although advertising linage is booming, newspapers are finding it difficult to keep income in line with costs.

The Western Printing and Lithographing Company, major producer of children's books, has leased the seventh floor in the twenty-four-story building under construction at 415 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-eighth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- This metropolis is experiencing a race between cold science and hot human tempers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Dr. Hernan Siles-Zuazo of Bolivia asked the General Assembly today for aid to underdeveloped countries through the transfer of savings from armament reductions. He also served notice that he would submit a definite proposal soon for a disarmament program specifically affecting the smaller nations.
DENVER, Sept. 26 -- Following is a chronology of the events yesterday and today in the President's illness. The times are in Mountain Standard time:
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Hurricane Janet roared toward Cape Gracias at the eastern tip of Nicaragua tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- An agreement on Britain's relations with the European Coal and Steel Community became operative last Friday when the final instrument of ratification was deposited, the Foreign Office said today.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Five of Long Island Sound's best International Class skippers took the first race of the "Amorita Cup series today. Competing against a quintet from Bermuda, the United States yachtsmen captured the first four places to win the opener by 34 1/4 points to 18.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Dr. White said tonight that "every day counts in his [the President's] favor, the first week being the most important."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A Senate Interior subcommittee recommended today a new department of mineral resources to be headed by a Cabinet officer.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on President Eisenhower's illness as gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press:

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- Erich Raeder, former grand admiral and Commander in Chief of the German Navy in World War II, was released today from Spandau Prison near Berlin. He was freed by order of the United States, British, French and Soviet Governments.
SDE BOKER, Israel, Sept. 25 -- Premier-designate David Ben-Gurion said here today the Gulf of Aqaba, now blocked by Egyptian guns, would be opened for Israeli shipping "in one year or less."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Yale sustained a damaging blow when Steve Ackerman was injured in the opening game with Connecticut Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The National Security Council, top policy-making group on foreign affairs and defense, assumes even greater importance during President Eisenhower's illness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- One of the gravest fears that the unhappy news from Denver immediately evoked in this country, and surely was reflected throughout the free world, was that a long time must elapse before the President could deal with any of the great affairs of state.
A forecast that factory workers would be paid on a year-round salaried basis "within our lifetime" was put before 1,300 industrial executives yesterday.
DENVER, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Army likes to say that it looks after its own. Since Saturday it had made a full effort to do just that for one of its most distinguished leaders -- President Eisenhower.

Today.'s new' film is ."Will Any l Gentleman ?", a British-made ro-I mantic comedy n color starring] George Cole, at the-Plaza. The screen play is: by. Vernon Sylvaine from his play of the same! title. Hamilton 'Inglis producedi and 1Viichael Anderson directedI the Stratford Pictures release.

HONG KONG, Sept. 26 -- Dilmus T. Kanady, an American business man who was imprisoned more than four years in Communist China, relaxed at the home of friends tonight. He arrived from Shanghai today in a somewhat nervous state.
CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- The Egyptian Government rejoiced tonight over a report that the United States was considering selling this nation arms on credit.

Stockholders of the Link-Belt Company at a meeting in Chicago yesterday approved the purchase of the Syntron Company of Homer City, Pa., for 134,433 shares of Link-Belt capital stock. The acquisition is subject to approval by Syntron shareholders and the Securities Exchange Commission.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Martin Issler of Short Hills, N. J., who never won a golf tournament until his fifty-fifth year, paced the qualifying round for the United States Golf Association national senior amateur tournament with a par-72.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation's passenger car divisions have built more than 3,000,000 units this year. The figures, for Jan. 1 through Sept. 24, come to 3,038,604, against 2,131,764 in the comparable 1954 period.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Macy's New York yesterday opened its redesigned housewares basement, built on the general plan of a shopping center with a perimeter area of ten separate shops surrounding a central mall.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Members of the Bennett Club of Southern Connecticut have arranged an unusual exhibition of needlework for the benefit of Bennett Junior College in Millbrook, N. Y. The display, comprised of specimens of needlework dating from the eighteenth century through the present day, will open on the afternoon of Oct. 10 in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Robinson in John Street, Greenwich.
Ebbets Field was ringed by 4,500 fans at 8 o'clock last night when the Brooklyn Dodgers started the public sale of some 34,000 world series tickets.
DENVER, Sept 26 -- Dr. Paul D. White, heart specialist, hedged today on his earlier statement that a second term for President Eisenhower was "quite conceivable."

THE announced intention of some Montauk Point charter boat skippers to see if school tuna remained in their bailiwick led to a check of results yesterday. That's all it led to. The captains didn't try for tuna after all.
HARD - PRESSED parents who have managed to survive the influence of Hopalong Cassidy, Davy Crockett and other heroes of the West on their youngsters may be confronted with new problems.
Six hundred delegates to the tenth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., which will get under way on Monday, face a crowded agenda.
The third annual course in safety and accident prevention for all phases of waterfront operation will begin today at the main building of New York University, Waverly Place and Washington Square.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Spain applied today for membership in the United Nations. The world organization has specifically barred her candidacy as long as Generalissimo Francisco Franco remains in power.
TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- The United States air base on Iwo Jima suffered heavy damage in a typhoon yesterday and today. There were no casualties.
Wall Street, the home of theories about everything under the sun, was too busy marking down prices yesterday to formulate a theory as to why it was doing so.

HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Trial of Der Spiegel (The Mirror), West Germany's leading news magazine, on charges of defaming Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Herbert Blankenhorn, Bonn's Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, opened today.
Leo Durocher, who resigned last week as manager of the New York Giants baseball team, has entered into negotiations with the National Broadcasting Company.

DENVER, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of the news conference today with Dr. Paul Dudley White, Boston heart specialist; James C. Hagerty, Presidential press secretary, and Maj. Gen. Howard McC. Snyder, the President's personal physician, on the President's condition:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The problem of financing Egyptian arms purchases is being studied, but the State Department is also "processing" certain Israeli requests for-military materials, Administration officials said today.

ROME Sept. 26 (UP) -- Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, in Rome for a brief courtesy visit to Italian Government leaders, sounded a call today to all who desire peace to pray for President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Government reported today that a sharp rise in spending by Americans, led by a 38 per cent increase in auto sales, is a "major force" in the nation's booming prosperity.

Two rival managers, the grizzled Casey Stengel of the Yankees and the more youthful Walt (Smokey) Alston of the Dodgers, yesterday were readying their forces for the world series opener at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow.
RICHMOND, Ind., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Fifty-two pickets were jailed on "rout and riot" charges in a shouting demonstration as Avco Manufacturing Corporation reopened its Crosley Refrigerator plant today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A leading Roman Catholic educator says the new prisoner of war code would give an enemy "an excuse for simply killing all captured Americans on the ground that they would be scheming to slay their captors."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower's Cabinet was summoned today to a Friday meeting at the White House. It appeared to be the first step toward setting up the mechanics for conducting Government business during the President's illness.
A Quaker-assigned lawyer is to help tomorrow to defend twenty-five pacifists challenging the state's Defense Emergency Act as an infringement of civil liberties.

Wall Street statisticians are second to none in their fondness for using slide rules in making comparisons. When the ticker finally came to a halt after yesterday's hectic trading, it showed the biggest day's volume in twenty-two years.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 26 -- Today in fifty crowded synagogues most of Bucharest's 100,000 Jews observed Yom Kippur.
MOLLIE PICON returned last night to the Yiddish theatre after five years of truancy, and proved to her large and adoring following that she still can triumph over an unimaginative musical comedy.

JUST before the opening of the 1927 world series between the Yankees and the Pirates, the members of Murderers' Row teed off in batting practice. Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Bob Meusel, Tony Lazzeri and the rest gave an awesome demonstration of their power. They sent liner after liner screaming into the distant stands or out of sight beyond the fences. The Pirates watched them with growing dismay.

Mrs. Joe Goodwin's Oil Painting carried 122 pounds quite easily in the $25,200 Step Lightly Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4 - year - old daughter of Papa Redbird, established the second choice in the six-furlong sprint, won convincingly under the guidance of Eddie Arcaro.

The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, last seen on Broadway during the winter of 1951, will open a nine-week season of repertory tonight at the Shubert Theatre with "Iolanthe." The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

QUICHE LORRAINE, the cheese pie that is deliciously served in France as an appetizer or main supper or lunch dish, is traditionally made with bacon. But Mrs. David Felix, a Philadelphia housewife with a flair for cooking, has created several interesting variations on this Gallic culinary classic.
The National Republican Club announced yesterday it would conduct a series of "Pulse of the Nation" forums. Republican governors from all parts of the country will participate.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday that it would attempt to raise $47,600,000 during its annual March of Dimes campaign in January.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 26 -- Ceylonese Transport Ministry officials and representatives of the KLM Dutch Airline agreed today to set up a new international air service.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The illness of President Eisenhower depressed European stock markets today, even before Wall Street opened.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- The transportation and decentralization problems that have been plaguing American cities will be nearer solution when officials grasp the idea that downtown is no place for conducting a drive - in business, a Cleveland transit manager said today.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The British Government is opposing United States plans to offer arms to Egypt. The American aim would presumably be to forestall Egyptian arms purchases from the Soviet Union.
Differences over the handling of the waterfront clean-up campaign have strained the relations between Governor Harriman and Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey.
MONTREAL, Sept. 26 -- Planners were advised today to concentrate on improving economic conditions of cities rather than to stress civic beautification and social reform.

The Southern Pacific Transportation System and separately operated, solely controlled affiliated companies increased the net income for the first eight months of this year to $44,330,292 from $30,582,017 for the corresponding period a year ago.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- Voters in Boston and five neighboring cities will participate in preliminary elections tomorrow. Regular municipal elections are scheduled Nov. 8.

Reacting to the weakness in the securities markets, futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were irregularly lower yesterday. Rubber, cocoa, zinc, copper, hides and silk eased; lead, potatoes, cottonseed oil and wool rose, while sugar and coffee were mixed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Bankers here for the annual convention of the American Bankers Association expressed confidence today that the economy would not be affected adversely by President Eisenhower's illness.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khruschev, head of the Soviet Communist party, who now are habitually running in tandem, will visit India together this year.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, wished President Eisnehower "a speedy recovery" today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Quarterback Jimmy Finks of the Pittsburgh Steelers hit Ray Mathews with a 27-yard touchdown pass with only 52 seconds remaining tonight. The score enabled the Steelers to trip the Chicago Cardinals, 14 -- 7, in a National Football League opener.

TORONTO, Sept. 26 (Cana dian Press) -- Trading volume remained low on the Toronto Stock Exchange today in the biggest price decline at least since 1934, the year the exchange began keeping indexes. The uncertain political picture in the United States sent prices plunging all around.

BELA BARTOK lives on Though he died ten years ago yesterday, he lives on in his music -- sensitive, intense, lonely, tender and fiercely proud. He was an original master, as the world has been acknowledging these last ten years.

Employes of Trans World Airlines, Inc., and Eastern Air Lines, Inc., will give blood today to the Red Cross at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Today also bloodmobiles will visit Dun Bradstreet, Inc., 99 Church Street, and the American Cyanamid Company, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- A tribute to President Eisenhower as the symbol of "all that is best in the ideals" of the United Nations was made on the floor of the General Assembly today in an expression of hope for his speedy recovery.

IF New Yorkers should notice a young man strolling along the street with downcast eyes that never seem to leave shoe level, it is Roger Vivier. This designer for Delman-Dior shoes works as he walks, watching shoes on feet in motion.

MADRID, Sept. 26 -- Mr. Brownell left here suddenly for Washington today by commercial plane. GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Eddie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds were married tonight in this Catskill Mountain resort where the singer began his career six years ago.

Major league players are still seeking a $7,200 minimum salary. This demand, along with others concerning bonus players, winter baseball and disposition of radio and television rights, was presented at a meeting yesterday in the office of their attorney, J. Norman Lewis.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The affection and respect in which Britons hold President Eisenhower was underlined in warm editorial tributes to him today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- The Volkskammer (Parliament) of East Germany ratified today its recent treaty with the Soviet Union. It immediately amended the Constitution to provide for national armed forces.
Maria Pflug, who has spent the last ten years in a camp for refugees in Austria, reached the United States yesterday. She was originally from Yugoslavia.

Laying of the world's first transoceanic telephone cable from Clarenville, Nfld., to Oban, Scotland, was completed yesterday.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- An Austrian Army marched again today through the streets of Vienna.

President Eisenhower's heart attack is a grim reminder that the office of President is a man-killer. In this century three Presidents have died in office, two have been crippled in office and two have died prematurely after retirement.

ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 26 -- This was an important day for Andover Academy's football squad.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 26 -- Many Argentine political and military refugees in Uruguay preparing to return to their country had more sober thoughts today about the revolutionary change in Buenos Aires.

The German Government has firmly rejected an implied Soviet demand for the "repatriation" of some 100,000 alleged Soviet "citizens" who, in Premier Bulganin's view, are being "detained" in West Germany. J., Sept. 26 -- One thousand two hundred employes of the Simmons Company plant here, manufacturers of beds and bedding, are scheduled to return to work tomorrow following an agreement on a new contract that ended a nineteen-day strike by members of Local 420, Upholsterers' International Union, A. DENVER, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower publicly expressed thanks today to people "throughout the world" who had "prayed and are praying for the recovery of the President."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Department of Commerce predicted today a "rough balance" between supply and consumption of copper in the last three months of this year.
Brooklyn's zero hour is only a matter of moments away.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Ezra Taft Benson conceded today that it was "gratuitous and unnecessary" for the Agriculture Department to designate Wolf Ladejinsky a security risk when it refused to retain him on its payroll last January.

EXETER, N. H., Sept. 27 -- Bill Clark, football coach of Phillips Exeter Academy, stood on a sideline this afternoon watching three of his backs punting. He started to go upfield several times but kept changing his mind.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The British Government was reported tonight to be seriously concerned over the Egyptian decision to sign an arms-purchasing agreement with the Soviet Union.
Education for all youth in proportion to their capacity to profit from it was proposed yesterday as the objective of higher education in America.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Ecuador withdrew today her appeal to the Organization of American States for action to prevent an attack by Peru.
MONTREAL, Sept. 27 -- Development of Great Lake ports is being hampered by "hostile, cynical or indifferent" planners, it was said here today.

Financing groups in United States grant about the same terms for loans on capital goods shipped abroad as foreign concerns, according to N. A. Bogdan, president of the American Overseas Finance Corporation.
Leo Durocher, who had never signed any contract except as a baseball player or manager, signed one yesterday in the capacity of television executive for the National Broadcasting Company.

When travel restrictions to the Soviet Union were relaxed recently applications for visas flowed into Washington. Tourists who had exhausted a good part of the world in normal guide book and camera expeditions took aim on Moscow, Leningrad and the places "hardly anyone else had ever seen."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The highest Government officials indicated today they saw nothing in the immediate future that necessitated a quick decision on a delegation of any powers by President Eisenhower.

Clarence G. Morse, Maritime Administrator, estimated yesterday that it would cost between 90,000,000 and $100,000,000 to build a counterpart of the superliner United States. The ship, which entered service three years ago, cost $74,000,000.

The Cooperative for American Remittances to Everywhere (CARE) opened yesterday a Christmas project to distribute surplus food from the United States to destitute persons in Europe and Asia. The cost of each twenty-two-pound package is $1.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Prices of British industrials became much steadier today, especially after the news of Wall Street's opening rally. Many leaders closed with small net gains and many more finished above the day's lowest levels.

Two new artists will join the Metropolitan Opera this season, and five former singers will return after lapses of one or more seasons. The 1955-56 roster was announced yesterday by Rudolf Bing, general manager.

The first wife of Mohammed Ali, the Pakistani Ambassador to the United States, arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. Her, arrival immediately presented diplomatic social circles with a singular problem.
YONKERS, Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Norman Rich of the Harrison Country Club won a year's possession of the Windle Challenge Trophy at Hudson River Country Club today.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Sylvester L. Weaver Jr., president of the National Broadcasting Company, predicted here today that commercial television would have more influence in elevating British taste than the British Broadcasting Corporation.

When the New York Yankees clinched the American League pennant Friday night it signaled the onset of a mild form of madness that grips the nation twice each year; once during the weeks before Christmas and again at world series time.
UTICA, Mich., Sept. 27 -- Improvements resulting from a year's $100,000,000 development program were shown today at a preview of the 1956 Studebaker, Packard and Clipper lines here.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, provisional President of Argentina, declared today that the country had nothing to fear from communism or Peronism.
LLANDUDNO, Wales, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Henry Williams, 22, heard today he had won 75,000 ($210,000) in a football sweepstake and said: "I'll give most of it to my mother."

It has not been a very long time since I studied the literature of the Greeks and the influence of Greek Drama on subsequent literature in Columbia College. However, I must now confess that the pace of modern progress and analysis has apparently made my studies obsolescent in two short years.
IF Brooklyn Bridge can be kept from jutting right through the plate glass and out into the avenue . . . if Grand Central Terminal does not look too big . . . or too small . . . if Central Park . . .
New York City announced yesterday a revision of its career and salary plan that is expected to counter part of recent criticism by nurses of the Department of Hospitals.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 27 -- Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies announced in the House of Representatives tonight a series of measures designed to check inflationary pressures. Further restrictions will be imposed on imports from Oct .1, designed to reduce their total value by about 80,000,000 ($180,000,000) a year.
THE Ziegfeld Theatre, once a movie house, more recently a legitimate showcase and now doomed to become a television studio, did service last evening as a kind of night club arena.

FREDERICK ASHTON'S newest ballet, "Madame Chrysantheme," was presented last night by the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House in its American premiere. Maryon Lane danced the title role for the first time anywhere, and Alexander Grant and the others appeared in the roles they created recently in London.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Foreign countries continued to build up their gold dollar holdings at a rapid pace in the first half of this year despite a substantial export surplus by the United States.
The second round of the 1955 Salk vaccine inoculations against polio began yesterday for 167,000 school children in the city.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- Argentina's provisional President, Maj. Gen. Eduardo Lonardi, dismissed Gen. Juan D. Peron today as a threat to the new regime and said that Paraguay could have him any time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A report on a drive against illegal traffic in amphetamines, called "thrill pills" by teen-age users, was made today.

Samuel M. Lane, whose retirement as counsel and executive director of the Waterfront Commission was announced yesterday, deserves the public's deep appreciation for his tireless, honest and courageous administration of its affairs during the turbulent period of his service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The Government's "housekeeping" agency announced today it was setting up a mail-order system to handle supplies ranging from typewriters to trucks. A spokesman said big savings were anticipated.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Operations on the Board of Trade quieted down today after the exciting fluctuations of yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- A revised version of Dmitri Shostakovich's much-criticized opera "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk" probably will be performed in Leningrad next year, the composer said today.

There is a more or less chronic debate concerning the role of the stock market that boils to the surface every so often. This controversy usually turns on some variation of the question, "Does the stock market really forecast the future of business?"

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The country's bankers were warned today to guard against the threat of inflation. At the annual four-day convention of the American Bankers Association, which ends tomorrow, speakers and committee reports reflected the opinion of convention delegates that business will continue to boom despite President Eisenhower's illness.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Mrs. S. H. Patterson of Pinehurst, N. C., and Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Rye won the United States Women's Golf Association foursomes tourney today.

A 70-year-old grandmother from Georgia decided to play it safe last night and to accept a prize of $32,000 on a nationally televised quiz show. Her alternative was to try for the title award in "The $64,000 Question," risking the loss of the amount she had already earned by answering questions about baseball.
The Coast Guard and the harbor police were searching early today for the captain of a tug-boat that sank last night in Arthur Kill between Staten Island and Carteret, N. J.

Your last two issues have carried indignant letters from highly placed officials of the Dominican and Venezuelan dictatorships, protesting against your recent excellent editorial condemning Latin-American dictatorial regimes. These letters are worthy of a short comment.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday that this year's goal was a formula for permanent peace on the waterfront.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Poland told the Western nations today to drop the issue of the Soviet satellite states in Eastern Europe.

Absent since 1948, Maurice Chevalier, who celebrated his sixty-seventh birthday on Sept. 12, will resume his Broadway affiliation at 8:15 o'clock this evening at the Lyceum. Under the auspices of Gilbert Miller, the engagement is of limited duration, ending Nov. 6.

DAVID RANDOLPH of the Randolph Singers, a group that specializes in singing madrigals, is eager to bring about a renascence of this once-popular music form and to that end has invited a number of composers to write madrigals for his group.
The United States gas industry and that of Western Europe needs "more exchanges of people and ideas," according to Ralph W. Hendee, outgoing president of the International Gas Union.

FEW people are as familiar with what is going on in American kitchens today as Mrs. Julia Kiene, who retires this week after eighteen years as director of Westinghouse's Home Economics Institute. And few have as clear and cheerful a picture of the kitchen of tomorrow.
DENVER, Wednesday, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower was reported alert, cheerful and comfortable yesterday as he continued slow but steady progress toward recovery.

The State Racing Commission yesterday authorized the Greater New York Association, Inc., to purchase the four running tracks for horse racing in the state. Thus the final stamp of approval was placed on the year-old plan to organize New York's flat tracks under one group and to remodel the physical layouts of one or more of the tracks.

Directors of the American Can Company placed the common stock on a $2 a year dividend rate with the declaration yesterday of an increased quarterly payment of 50 cents a share. It is payable Nov. 15 and compares with the previous dividend of 35 cents.

Our American Junior Chambers of Commerce have launched a nationwide campaign on behalf of Operation Brotherhood, whose cause they have espoused. They will undoubtedly receive a warm response, because the merits of the cause are apparent and the record of the "Operation" has been very good.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The city's Bureau of Port Operations intends to revamp its method of leasing fourteen municipally owned general cargo piers. The aim is to collect an additional $840,000 annually in rentals.
The Big Four foreign ministers agreed last night that their conference at Geneva, starting Oct. 27, would last about three weeks.

Two banana importers started action before the Federal Maritime Board yesterday against the Grace Line, accusing the company of excluding them from the use of refrigerated space on ships from Ecuador to New York.
RABAT, French Morocco, Sept. 27 -- A breach presaging a new conflict in Morocco opened tonight between the Resident General of France and a strong European colonial group here.

SINCE money is only a means to an end, the arguments some couples have over finances are really concerned with more important matters than dollars and cents. Before families can achieve "economic adjustment," husband and wife must come to some basic agreements on what they want out of life, and how they expect to handle their income so as to satisfy these long-range desires.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28 -- Faeroe Islanders have reopened their fight to reinstate Dr. Olaf Halvorsen. As a result, police reinforcements are speeding today to Klaksvig from Copenhagen on the Danish frigate Rolf Krake.
The head of one of the South's big industries condemned some Southern communities yesterday for trying to lure plants from the North with promises of cheap labor and tax concessions.
The United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation has acquired the Aerolab Development Company of Pasadena, Calif.

Supreme Court Justice Walter A. Lynch denounced yesterday as "arbitrary" and "illegal" the refusal of former Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams to appoint a man whose father once signed a Communist nominating petition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has drafted and is studying a proposed new rule to permit air lines to offer reduced-fare vacation travel to United States military personnel overseas.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 28 -- There was a buzz of excitement around the Brooks School's athletic office at noon today. The Green and Black's football squad was to hold its first outside scrimmage of the season and the players were anticipating it eagerly.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 28 -- A simplified form of registration under Nassau County's new Permanent Personal Registration was adopted today to expedite registration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following for the week ended Sept. 21: Decreases of $394,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $183,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, and $877,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points off to 8 points up yesterday. The near months showed the strongest tone.
The New York State organization of the Daughters of the American Revolution heard two speakers attack the United Nations yesterday as the organization opened its three-day annual conference.
Seven pacifists insisted on pleading guilty yesterday to refusing to take shelter during an air raid drill, even though Magistrate Hyman Bushel urged them to refrain.

The nation's gasoline stocks decreased 360,000 barrels in the week ended on last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week they amounted to 151,805,000 barrels, compared with 152,165,000 a week earlier and 151,145,000 a year earlier.

The first play to be registered under the provision adopted at the recent Universal Copyright Convention and the new amendment to the United States Copyright law, which went into effect on Sept. 16, is "Turnabout."
A complete revision of Democratic national strategy is in the making as a consequence of President Eisenhower's illness.
Percentage pursuers had a few chortles in Wall Street yesterday. It seems that the august figures of the Big Board have not told all.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The British Government today accused Archbishop Makarios, ethnarch of Cyprus, of "enlisting Communist support" in his campaign for self-determination for the Cypriotes.

Despite unparalleled prosperity, consumption of textile fibers is on the downgrade, according to Robert L. Huffines Jr., president of Amerotron Corporation. The concern is selling and management agents for the textile division of Textron American, Inc.
NEWARK, Sept. 28 -- The Public Utilities Commission revised today its bus-token decision and ordered the Public Service Coordinated Transport to issue weakly riding permits starting Oct. 17.

Mickey Mantle, sidelined with a torn hamstring muscle in his right thigh, was unable to play in the first game at the Stadium yesterday. However, even if the kid from Commerce (Okla.) does not hit, catch or throw a ball in this series -- and he might not -Mantle already has contributed more to the Yankees' cause than his mere presence.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil and wool were strong. Rubber, hides, cocoa and soybean oil also rose; potatoes and lead eased, and coffee, zinc and copper were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Bureau of Public Roads listed today the routes in and around 102 urban areas it had approved for the official "interstate" highway system.

International Business Machines Corporation has announced reorganization of its electric typewriter division as a completely autonomous operation with an administrative structure separate from the other divisions. The new plan becomes effective immediately.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 -Argentine universities reopened today as free schools after almost eight years of totalitarian Peronist regimentation.
Successful law enforcement depends upon the mutual respect of the public and members of the Police Department, Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday.

Starting Saturday, cars and trucks using the Ohio Turnpike will be weighed and classified while in motion.
