The timesaving job will be done by new electronic equipment, developed by the International Business Machines Corporation and installed at all toll booths on the 241-mile highway. visually the number of axles and depresses a corresponding key on the recorder.
WARSAW, Sept. 28 (AP) -Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski will be released "very soon" -perhaps in several weeks -Polish authorities said today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- If Frank Lane joins the St. Louis Cardinals as general manager, the contract probably will be signed in St. Louis early next week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, informed Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, today of the widespread displeasure and concern over the announced intention of Egypt to buy arms through the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial translation of the statement made before the General Assembly today by Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Nationalist Chinese Foreign Minister:

The Hospitalized Veterans Service will be the first organization in this country to benefit from a recital by the Soviet pianist Emil Gilels. His program on Oct. 11 at Carnegie Hall replaces a recital by Jascha Heifetz, originally announced as part of the service's Five Enchanted Musical Evenings series.

A trade association, a Union that allegedly embraced small business men, six corporations and three individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy to eliminate competition in the metropolitan smoked fish field.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 28 -- Four teams tied at 62 in the Celebrity Day phase of the $15,000 Long Island open Rotary golf tournament at the Huntington-Crescent Club today.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- The Government introduced today a bill seeking to regulate the working conditions of journalists.
Prices surged on a broad front yesterday and by the end of the session on the New York Stock Exchange 45.8 per cent of Monday's losses had been re-won.
Members of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., have voted to accept the terms of a wage agreement reached two weeks ago with the Transit Authority.
The National Association of Manufacturers yesterday called on management to provide additional job opportunities for the physically handicapped.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- A record score by Mrs. Harrison Flippin of Ardmore, Pa., marked the initial round of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship today.

Consider what happens when a fire breaks out and the first engine company to arrive finds a car parked in front of a hydrant -- especially if its doors are locked and its brakes are clamped tight. The firemen themselves have to turn to and move it away.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits urged Republicans tonight to support an expansion of state activities in a wide variety of fields.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad received good marks from the Public Service Commission yesterday in most of its operations. But the state agency was critical of the increasing number of late trains.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren, is embarrassed about the speculation that has linked his name to the Presidency since the illness of President Eisenhower.
It may yet come to pass that the Dodgers will win their first world series. But they took one long stride in the wrong direction yesterday.
Joe Collins, the two-homer hero of the Yankees' series-opening victory over the Dodgers, had to travel a rough road to get his big shot at baseball glory.
A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of Sam Accardi, 57-year-old narcotics suspect.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The United States challenged the Soviet Union today on its willingness to extend President Eisenhower's plan for aerial reconnaissance to the overseas military installations of the two powers.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept 28 -Mrs. Ella T. Landan, the wife of John. R. Landan, a New York advertising executive, was killed late last night when the car she was driving crashed through a wall near Schlaets Corner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- A witness, accused at a Senate subcommittee hearing today of selling narcotics illegally, walked out of the room into the arms of the police.

Trade sources here said they had expected Australia to impose restrictions on imports in view of adverse trends in her trade in recent months. However, the curbs announced in Melbourne were more severe than had been expected.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The Long Island Sound team, which had scored three straight victories over Royal Bermuda Y. C. representatives, gained another triumph in the Amorita Cup series at the American Yacht Club today. But the Americans, instead of clinching the cup, held a 3-1 lead at the end of the day.

Inter-American solidarity, so very important for the international peace and tranquility, began its development and evolution only after the United States of America had accepted, formally and solemnly, at the Conference of Montevideo in 1933, the principle of nonintervention.

The American merchant marine's problems and its role in defense and national economy will be examined by the Propeller Club of the United States and the American Merchant Marine Conference at their twenty-ninth annual convention in New Orleans.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Industrials continued to rally today under the lead of British Government securities, which have scarcely faltered this week. Business was small and rises generally limited to a few pence.

A COLLECTION of men's fashions tailored by the fine Italian hand of Gaetano Savini received a hearty American hand when it was shown here this week. Savini made New York his first stop on a trip that will take him all over the United States. He is one of Italy's leading men's clothing designers as well as president of Brioni Tailor, 79 Via Barberini, Rome.
Vast changes are in store for New York University.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the reappointment of Sean P. Keating as a member of the Board of Standards and Appeals. He announced also the appointment of James J. McFadden as Deputy Commissioner of Labor.

Those War Escape Books The prisoner-of-war escape book has been enjoying a new vogue in recent years. World War II supplied material a-plenty -- material with builtin suspense. It provided a new and avid group of readers too, for few who had anything to do with that "old war" can ignore a true P. O. W. escape tale. The pattern of war escapes is much the same.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- It is now abundantly clear that the President, accepting the possibility of a brief period of inactivity enforced by certain types of illness, coached his "team" in advance on what to do, and that, with Vice President Nixon as chief of staff, it is acting on the President's precepts.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Three extra-hole matches featured today's second round in the national senior golf tournament. The medalist, Martin Issler of Wrest Orange, N. J., had to go nineteen holes for a victory over Philip Ransom of Buffalo.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28 -- An order yesterday assigning a police official to twelve hours of duty from 8 P. M. to 8 A. M. was modified today by Director of Public Safety Lawrence A. Whipple.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28 -- The Yucatan peninsula was ripped through its center today by Hurricane Janet.
Frank Lane is in as general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals and Harry Walker is out as field manager of the Redbirds, the Associated Press reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 29 -- A formal decision has been taken to release 9,626 German war prisoners still held in the Soviet Union.
The New York Young Republican Club announced yesterday a drive to obtain the direct election of Republican district leaders in New York County (Manhattan).

"A View From the Bridge," the joint title of two one-act plays by Arthur Miller, opens tonight at the Coronet Theatre at 7:35 o'clock under the auspices of Kermit Bloomgarden, Robert Whitehead and Roger Stevens.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee is a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. It recommends, as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, the following motion pictures, to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified:...
ROME, Sept. 28 -- The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra achieved a success here tonight that inveterate concert-goers termed "sensational."

DENVER, Sept. 28 -- The goal of the National Recreation Association is to reverse the spectatorplayer ratio, George Hjelte, chairman of the group's national advisory council said today. He spoke at the association's congress here.

The will of John H. Bahrenburg, Brooklyn realty man, probated yesterday in Kings County Surrogate's Court, left the bulk of his estate of $1,529,698 to welfare and charitable organizations. Mr. Bahrenburg died on Dec. 3, 1951.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 -Police and Army investigators today were filming the interior of a luxurious hideout that Juan D. Peron in one of the city's best residential centers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- The Writer's Guild of America, West, is calling a meeting of its television writers on Oct. 7 to request authority to require members to withhold material and services from the major networks in connection with the production of films for television.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 -The provisional Government announced today a general amnesty.

The annual award of the National Defense Transportation Association for the "outstanding contribution to the transportation industry in its support of national security" will go this year to Charles H. Weaver. The selection of the vice president for atomic power activities of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was announced yesterday by Herbert B. Loper, Assistant to the Secretary of Defense (Atomic Energy).

Two new features will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Night of the Hunter," a United Artists suspense drama, is at the Mayfair. Paul Gregory produced and Charles Laughton directed, from a screen play which James Agee based on the novel by Davis Grubb. . . . "The McConnell Story," a Yarner; Brothers drama in CinemaSeope and V/arnerColor. is at the Astor Theatre.

IT seems likely that the old autumn tradition of preserving may be revived locally. The large number of families moving into the suburbs acquire backyards, often with grape vines and fruit trees. Surplus fruits inevitably suggest jams, jellies, pickles.
The Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., yesterday urged its member furriers to refuse to supply merchandise to be auctioned directly to the public.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -George V. Allen, an Assistant Secretary of State, flew to Cairo today for talks with Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser on Egypt's plans to buy arms from Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.
Three persons plunged to their deaths in Manhattan yesterday.

Consumers are spending a larger proportion of their money for services, according to an analysis by the National Industrial Conference Board. Purchases of services, the report shows, are now at a record rate of more than $90,000,000,000 a year, or about 36 cents of every consumer dollar spent for goods and services.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 28 -- New drugs tried recently in the treatment of mental patients have aided them greatly but have not served as a cure for the basic causes of their illness.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Nationalist China warned the United Nations today to look with distrust on Communist peace overtures. Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Foreign Minister of the Government on Formosa, told the General Assembly that "the Soviet peace drive is not, in fact, peaceful in intention; it is a form of war."
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- For the second year in a row, the women's New Jersey golf team won the Myra D. Paterson Trophy on the Sunningdale course today.

A men's committee has been formed to work for the success of the seventh annual dinner dance to be held on Oct. 13 at the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue.
CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 28 -- Operation Lifesaver, one of the biggest evacuation tests of the North Atlantic Alliance, started at 10:52 A. M. today.

David S. Meister, real estate operator and investor, has sold the one-story taxpayer building at 253 Fulton Avenue in Hempstead, L. I., to a client of Max N. Koven, attorney. The building is 150 feet deep on a plot 42 by 200 feet and contains two stores. Loebel Youth Center is one tenant and the other is Carol Green Dresses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28 -- Yale, Princeton and Cornell have been designated as the three top Ivy football powers, but everywhere the word is to beware of Harvard.

TRENTON, Sept. 28 -- The contribution of youth groups and playgrounds to the fight on juvenile delinquency was cited here today by a Superior Court judge as justification for his refusal to grant an injunction.

The appointment of the Rev. Timothy S. Healy as chairman of the Department of Communication Arts of Fordham University and director of the university-owned and operated radio station, WFUV-FM, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president.

Corporation Counsel Brown has handed to Mayor Wagner an opinion that bingo games may -- we would note particularly the "may" -- be legal if they are played under the terms of a 1952 decision of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal.
The regional Red Cross will collect blood today from the community of Glendale, Queens, at Glendale Memorial Hall, 72-02 Myrtle Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The Air Ministry announced today the replacement of Air Chief Marshal Sir Basil Embry. An outspoken officer, he had sharply criticized Royal Air Force policies while he was Allied air force commander in Central Europe.
Not until the running of the sixth race did the players of the favorites do any on-the-nose ticket-cashing at Belmont Park yesterday. Then Mandingo galloped to the rescue at 7-to-4 odds.
A 1,200-pound white-faced brown steer broke out of a meat packing building at Eleventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street yesterday morning at 8:40 and fled through traffic-lader streets to Central Park.

Though appraisals of the causes and effects of last Monday's break in the stock market may have differed in this or that particular respect, there seems to have been complete agreement on one point. That sharp decline represented a spontaneous and unmistakable demonstration of the enormous confidence that the nation places in Mr. Eisenhower's leadership.

From long familiarity with each other and intensive scouting, the Yankees and the Dodgers set their defenses in yesterday's series opener with a minimum of dugout wigwagging by Managers Casey Stengel and Walter Alston.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, has told President Tito that the United States is re-examining its relations with Yugoslavia. Mr. Murphy cited recent events and unclarified trends in Yugoslav policy.
They call it Operation Food for Thought.

After decades of concentrating their "sales pitch" on their product itself, cigarette manufacturers are beginning to pay attention to the consumer, according to the Institute for Motivational Research, Inc.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- New pressure built up here today for action to break the deadlock over the admission of new members to the United Nations.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The French Government sought today to hasten execution of its Moroccan program in a race to head off almost certain defeat in the National Assembly.

THE Yankees' disposal of the Dodgers yesterday afternoon was the first world series game to be televised in color. The tinted version was far from impressive, because outdoor pickups are not yet electronic color's strong feature. The mighty Joe Collins appeared to be skipping around an artist's palette.
The City Planning Commission vote yesterday to rezone the Columbus Circle area, including the new Coliseum, to provide a zoning pattern consistent with the anticipated development of the region.

On Sept. 21 The Times carried on its first page the report of the United Nations Assembly voting with the United States again to postpone the issue of China's representation, while seating the delegation from Argentina without protest. This disparity of treatment is conspicuous.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey will accept the Vice Presidential nomination on the Democratic ticket next year.

The eyes of the nation and of the world have been focused on the Presidency of the United States this week; and the hearts of men and women of goodwill everywhere are united in the hope that health will be speedily restored to the occupant of that great office.

The Delaware Power and Light Company expects to raise earnings by about 17 cents to $2.25 a share, Stuart Cooper, president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society, of Security Analysts. The utility reported in 1954 net income of $4,663,311, equal to $2.08 a share, on operating revenues of $30,577,435.
THE fairy story about the shrewd tailors who made robes of air to please their vain emperor has a 1955 version with a happier ending than it had in the original.

The Warner Brothers film "The McConnell Story" received an invitational premiere screening last night at the Astor Theatre. A large audience gathered to honor the Air Force Wives Association, attended the event.

HAS there ever been a more ingratiating, more infectious performer in show business than this Maurice Chevalier, this symbol and personification of all that is meant by the phrase "gay Paroe"? Has there, indeed, ever been anyone more indomitable?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, warned here tonight that Russia was ahead of us in training scientists and engineers.
A warning against weakening the North Atlantic Treaty alliance was given yesterday by Admiral Jerauld Wright, who is Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The American Bankers Association today elected Erle Cocke, vice chairman of the Fulton National Bank of Atlanta, as vice president -- traditionally the stepping stone to the A. B. A. presidency.
The call of the wild west far outdrew the world series television yesterday afternoon -- at least in the West Forty-ninth Street canyon.
The Heald Commission has tentatively fixed the cost of providing a basic public school education in New York state at $320 a year a pupil.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- United States commercial interests are negotiating here for the sale of up to 300,000 bushels of hybrid seed corn to the Soviet Union.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 28 -Adlai E. Stevenson asserted tonight that there were "serious flaws" in the country's booming prosperity.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Government today urged British exporters to increase their trade with the rich Middle East market.

Egypt's move to obtain arms from the Soviet bloc is provocative and irresponsible. One must say this because it was unnecessary and can only cause mischief. It is not Egypt's right to purchase arms wherever she can get them that is in dispute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Senators investigating the Ad-wound up three days of hearings in a partisan wrangle today. A Republican called the program "effective," and a Democrat promptly labeled it "slipshod."

The Pennsylvania Railroad plans to reorganize its management organization on Nov. 1. James M. Symes, president, disclosed yesterday that directors had approved the program, which will affect nearly every officer of the company.

Atlas Plywood Corporation is proceeding with its plan to consolidate six wholly-owned subsidiaries and to acquire the outstanding minority interest in Plywood, Inc., Robert A. Muller, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Boston.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- The sixth quadrennial convention of the Holy Name Society of the Roman Catholic Church was opened here tonight. Delegates from 3,600 parish units in this country and Canada are attending.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today invited India's film censors to take a sharper look at Hollywood's version of life in Africa. He made it perfectly plain he would not be unhappy if the censors decided to ban the films.
MONTREAL, Sept. 28 -- Cities hesitate to advance urban renewal projects because such programs are loaded with political dynamite, planners were told today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Israel complained today about Egyptian restrictions on shipping in the Gulf of Aqaba. She warned that she was prepared to protect her right to free passage "at whatever time and by whatever methods" she saw fit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -The chairman of the New York City Council of the National Jewish Welfare Board, Melvin L. Krulewitch, was sworn in today as a brigadier general in the Marine Corps Reserve.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Sept. 29 -- Indonesia holds the first national elections in her history today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Hollywood is giving the "cold shoulder" to the Audience Awards Poll to be conducted through the nation's movie theatres by the Council on Motion Picture Organizations.
For all the much-advertised ticket scarcity, all anyone who wanted to see yesterday's world series opener in person had to do was walk up to the Stadium gates and plunk down $2.10 or $4.20.

The Brand Names Foundation Company, Inc., plans to occupy the entire fifth floor at 437 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street. It has subleased the space from Simon Brothers through April 30 next and has leased the space thereafter through Riker Co., agents for the landlord. Collins Tuttle Co. were the brokers in the transaction.

A RICHLY colored voice and an adventuresome program made the debut recital of Beatrice Krebs last night in Town Hall thoroughly enjoyable. This is a voice of ample accomplishment and even greater promise.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UP) -- A twelve-day-old baby stolen from a hospital crib here nine days ago was restored unharmed to his frantic parents today by a woman who said she took the child because "I just wanted a baby."
THE last time the American League had defeated the Nationals in a world series game was in October of 1953. Naturally enough, the Yanks had done it.

The Richmond - Petersburg (Va.) Turnpike Authority sold a $69,000,000 bond issue yesterday to an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers, Smith Barney Co., Blythe Co., Inc., F. W. Craigie Co., Anderson Strudwick, Mason-Hagan, Inc., and Scott Stringfellow as joint managers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Increased hedge pressure was partly responsible for a weaker tone in soybeans and coarse grains today. Demand was slow as professional operators were inclined to sidestep anything that looked like country selling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -Administration officials got the complete support of the Senate's Republican leader today against any special legislative or other measures to carry on the Government during the illness of President Eisenhower.
The organization plans for New York's participation in the 1956 Olympic Fund Drive were, discussed yesterday at meeting, conducted at City Hall and the Hotel Ambassador. New York's goal is $375,000.
City Councilmen would be well advised to protect the use of city insignia on their private automobiles by law, Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown held yesterday.

Six years ago an agreement was signed by which the Hospital for Special Surgery became an affiliate of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Though the new building of the Hospital for Special Surgery at 533 East Seventieth Street has been occupied since last May, when the affiliation became effective, the ceremony of dedication, to be marked by a scientific conference on orthopedics, will occur today.

A 10-year-old youngster attending yesterday's world series opener with his grandparents unhesitatingly answered an impromptu question that stumped 62-year-old Patrick J. Keough of St. Louis, who has supplied $8,000 worth of correct baseball responses on television's "$64,000 Question" show.

The British Foreign Secretary predicted here last night that the test of the Soviet "new look" and the "Geneva spirit" would come at the Big Four foreign ministers conference. It is scheduled to open in Geneva Oct. 27.

Reflecting the sharp rise in sales, net earnings of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation for the quarter ended Aug. 31 climbed to $8,930,000 from $5,328,000 for the similar three months last year.

Three Swiss young men who set out two years ago to see the world with capital assets of $3, three bicycles and abundant good health and good humor, arrived here yesterday from the general direction of Mexico.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 28 (UP) -- Ramon Remine, one of the country's ten most wanted criminals, was captured last night on the tip of an optometrist who became suspicious when Remine tried to buy contact lenses that would change the color of his eyes.

Another landmark in New York City is about to come down. The Rhinelander Gardens on West Eleventh Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues) will be replaced by a public school building, according to recent announcements.

Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut told a group of industrial location experts here yesterday that "not one industry of any size whatever has moved out of the state" since the flood disaster on Aug. 19.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has ordered the armed forces to prepare for disruptions in command that might follow a surprise attack on this country.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 28 -- The Malayan Communist party has made a new offer to end the eight-year-old jungle war.

Following are the texts of a communique issued yesterday afternoon by the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France after their two-day conference and of a statement they issued yesterday morning on the German situation:

MOVING up the ladder of success in official biographies always seems an easy procession of one triumph after another. In the mature career woman showered with the honors of office, few remember or recognize the teen-ager first looking for a job.

MELBOURNE, Sept. 28 -- Imports from the dollar area will be subject to an overall reduction of 12 1/2 per cent starting Saturday, under a list of restrictions announced today by Minister of Trade and Customs Neil O'Sullivan.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will begin a long-needed public service -- a program to help children and parents understand one another's viewpoints.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28 -- The Mexican Government has signed a contract with the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation to export 100,000,000 to 200,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily over the next twenty years.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 -Israel has begun a diplomatic campaign to halt what is regarded here as an East-West race to supply arms to Egypt.
Two Brooklyn tugboat men lost their lives late Tuesday night in the sinking off Carteret, N. J., of the harbor tug F. A. Churchman.
Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that preliminary plans had been approved to build the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour at the southeast corner of Thirty-eighth Street and Park Ave.
Sixty-seven Bronx junior high school students yesterday visited the New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx. They were accompanied by parents, teachers and their school principal.

The five-story dwelling containing duplex and terrace apartments on lot 22 by 102 feet at 48 East Seventy-third Street was sold by Sadie Brown, head of the Collegiate Business Institute, to Eduardo de Valenzuela, who resold it after a brief ownership to Joseph W. Donner.

As a reporter who covered the health and welfare beat in New York for years I was deeply shocked when I read of Mayor Wagner's failure to reappoint Judge Hubert T. Delany to his place on the Domestic Relations Court bench where he had served with such distinction for thirteen years.
DENVER, Thursday, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower spent thirteen hours out of his oxygen tent yesterday and his doctors reported continuing satisfactory progress toward recovery.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Hoover Commission, whose keynote was economy in government, went out of existence today on a consistent note. It returned $83,000 in unspent funds to the Treasury.

Reo, a one-time household name in the automobile field, has completed a cycle from the "horseless carriage" to nucleonics. Stockholders of the Reo Holding Corporation approved yesterday a merger with Nuclear Consultants, Inc. The organization will then be known as the Nuclear Corporation of America.
The Western Big Three will make another attempt in Geneva to give guarantees that a united Germany will not be a threat to the Soviet bloc.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (UP) -Former President Harry S. Truman said today that "No President can delegate his powers to others."
Bill Terry, the former Giant manager and Hall of Fame first baseman, last night announced that he was ready to buy the Giants.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Leaders of the Moslem political opposition to French policy in Algeria asserted today that new elections were needed to provide an indication of popular opinion.

An American edition of "Atomic Policies 1945-54," by Elis Biorklund, has been scheduled for Oct. 20 publication by Van Nostrand. It is a political-historical analysis of the development and handling of international atomic problems during the last ten years.

A 16-year-old boy who had been found guilty of participating in a $50,000 radio hoax received a suspended sentence yesterday, but not before his father had made a personal plea that he be substituted if the son received a jail sentence.

DUBLIN, Sept. 28 -- Although Ireland and the world face far graver problems than that country's partition, no politician in Dublin is likely to admit it. Partition touches and often distorts every political policy or economic program in the Republic of Ireland.
Manager Smokey Alston was serious-faced, but not glum, after his Dodgers lost the opening series game to the Yankees yesterday.

Germany's military and political future, a key factor in the future of Europe, was under discussion again yesterday as preparations went forward for the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva.

THE slim line may be sweeping the fashion world, but Carrie Munn remains firm in her stand for belled skirts and tight tops. This cut appears 99 per cent of the time in her fall custom collection, sold also to special stores outside New York.

Wallace Magill, producer of the "Telephone Hour" broadcasts during the last fifteen years, will join the staff of the National Concerts and Artists Corporation and the Civic Concerts Corporation as general manager of the two concerns.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 28 (AP) -Three companies have filed petitions with the Peruvian Government for exploration rights in Peru's Oriental Region. The concessions requested involve 449,715 hectares (1,111,245 acres).

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 28. -- The Israeli Treasury announced today that it would raise the dollar exchange rate in favor of Hadassah, the United Jewish Appeal and other philanthropic organizations importing dollars into Israel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Export-Import Bank reported today that the number of new loans authorized in the first half of this year was the largest of any six-month period in the bank's twenty-one-year history.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 29 -- Northern Ireland feels "no enmity" toward the Republic of Ireland but is "not going to be pushed around" over the issue of Ireland's unity, Prime Minister Lord Brookeborough asserted today.

Royce Flippin, the 21-year-old senior tailback who injured his left knee in a practice scrimmage two weeks ago, will play very little if at all when Princeton meets Columbia in Palmer Stadium on Saturday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 29 -- The Masjumi, a Moslem political party, forged into an early lead in returns from the Jakarta area in Indonesia's first nation-wide elections, held today.

Many parties were given last night at the Blue Grass Ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New York. The event marked the formal opening of the Persian Room of the Plaza for this season.
If ever the Dodgers are to win a world series somebody will have to take them in hand and give them some fresh ideas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney announced today that the Senate Subcommittee on Patents would hold hearings Oct. 10, 11 and 12 on the functioning of the American patent system.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union today won a place on the agenda of the General Assembly for a discussion of measures for relaxing international tension and developing international cooperation.

JOHN GUNTHER'S "Inside Africa,"* which is published today, is a big book and big news in the world of books. For the better part of three days I have been happily immersed in its 952 pages and nearly 400,000 words. Now it is time to stop reading and to start writing and I don't suppose that I have actually read more than three-fourths of Mr. Gunther's book.

DENVER, Sept. 29 -- The White House announced publicly today that it did not approve of the coupling of a fund drive for the benefit of the American Heart Association with President Eisenhower's heart attack and forthcoming sixty-fifth birthday on Oct. 14.

The men and organizations responsible for the new Socony Mobil Building were honored yesterday by the Forty-second Street-Mid-Manhattan Association at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel, directly opposite the building site at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. Now nearing completion, the forty-three-story store and office skyscraper has a stainless steel exterior.

A four-story store and office building is planned to replace the two three-story structures at 426 and 428 West Thirty-fourth Street. The property occupies a plot about 41 by 98 feet on the south side of the street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

Directors of P. R. Mallory Co., Inc., have increased their eight-member board with the election of C. Harvey Bradley and James A. Roemer as new directors. P. R. Mallory, board chairman, in his announcement yesterday said the enlarged board reflects a program of continuing expansion and diversification of the company's electronic, electrochemical and metallurgical activities.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- United Nations members were warned today of the "pressing need" to resolve the problem of Korea.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Thousands of Greek Cypriotes left their jobs today in a twenty-four-hour general strike. Disorders flared in many parts of this British crown colony.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 29 -- The departure of Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa from the throne of Morocco appeared imminent tonight. There was reason to believe the tense watch that has been kept on the imperial palace since Sept. 12 might end within hours.

Only last month Robert R. Young, chairman of the Allegheny Corporation, made peace with a dissident stockholders' group by agreeing to pay $700,000 to the holding company. Yesterday he was faced with a new court challenge that may prove much more costly.

Commodity futures markets again are being used extensively for hedging, one of the basic functions of the exchanges, according to Roger R. Kauffman, Administrator of the Commodity Exchange Authority. During World War II and the Korean conflict, spot demand was good but little interest was shown in the weaker deferred months, making hedging generally uneconomical, he said.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today it would spend $3,500,000 to increase the capacity of its local chemigum and resin plant and $2,500,000 to raise the capacity of the Akron airfoam plant. These are new items in a $100,000,000 program of plant expansion. The two-year program now is partly completed, and includes millions of dollars worth of new equipment for making tubeless tires.

In an all-cash deal the Sterling Investing Corporation purchased the six-story apartment and store building at 432-34 East 149th Street, the Bronx, from Jack Resnick and Peter Feinberg, operators. The property is assessed at $65,000. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., were the brokers in the sale.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Department store sales in the United States last week rose 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Government today to restrict the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to telephone service on its proposed $35,000,000 cable system to Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today reopened 11 of the thirty-eight "expansion goals" for defense-related industries which had been suspended Aug. 11. All but one of the rest were closed permanently.

The New York State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution voted yesterday to oppose strongly the admission of Communist China to the United Nations. If Communist China is seated, the United States should immediately withdraw from the United Nations, the resolution said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, said today that 9,270 Federal employes had been dismissed or quit under the Administration's security program, rather than 9,310 as originally reported.
THE big bull striped bass that had been anticipated on their migration from New England waters have arrived off Long Island's tip.
Some of the details of "The Big Surprise" may turn out to be a surprise even for the show's producers.
Ebbets Field, scene of today's world series game, is best reached by subway. The automobile approaches to the home of the Dodgers are likely to be congested and parking accommodations are limited.
The fall season of the New York City Opera Company will open Wednesday evening with Otto Nicolai's "The Merry Wives of Windsor" and will continue for five weeks through Nov. 6.
Supreme Court Justice Peter M. Daly authorized yesterday a recanvass of Democratic primary ballots cast Sept. 13 in the Queens County contest for District Attorney.
The Transit Authority expressed confidence yesterday that it would end its fiscal year next June 30 in the black.

IF the Dodgers are beginning to show symptoms of claustrophobia, it's understandable. The walls are starting to close in on them. With inexorable and terrifying steadiness the shrinkage continues. By nightfall at the Yankee Stadium yesterday they barely had room enough to turn around. Pretty soon they won't have space to breathe.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Another Army back limped into the Cadets' infirmary today.

Each day that passes sees more progress made in the restoration of tranquillity and liberty to Argentina. The situation, after eleven years of Peron's dictatorship, is naturally one of confusion and enormous difficulties and dangers.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Sept. 24 -- The construction of the Central African Federation's biggest public works project, the Kariba Gorge dam and hydroelectric plant, is under way ninety miles southeast of here on the Zambezi River.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- France, which has been silent until now on the question of Soviet arms purchases by Egypt, aligned herself today with the position taken by the United States and Britain.

The merger of Theodore Gary Co. into General Telephone Corporation was approved by an overwhelming vote of General's stockholders at a special meeting here yesterday. Later, at Kansas City, Gary stockholders voted unanimously for the move.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept 29 (UP) -- The first seeded Tony Trabert, national and Wimbledon championship from Cincinnati, turned back Nadim Hajjar, former Lebanon champion, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, today to lead the favorites into the quarter-final round of the sixty-sixth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships.
Thomas J. Curran proposed last night that candidates for Governor and United States Senator in New York be nominated by direct primary.

Tommy Byrne fired 121 pitches yesterday in defeating the Dodgers. Seventy were strikes, fifty-one were balls. So far as could be determined from the stands, Tommy threw about twenty fast balls. The rest were "breaking pitches," curves or sliders.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Audie Murphy has purchased "Survival," an original story of the Air Force Survival School in Nevada, and will form his own independent company to produce the film. The young actor will star in the role of an airman going through the physical survival aspect of the school.

Newspapers are doing the best job of reaching the 15 through 18-year-old consumer, according to a report by the Youth Research Institute. Such media attract girls through their presentations of fashions and make-up while boys associate newspapers with "being grown-up," it was found.
Air freight will be flown across the country in eleven hours starting Monday.

Beryl Grey made her first appearance this season as the Princess Aurora in "The Sleeping Beauty" with the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. She is the fifth ballerina to dance the role during the present engagement, and like all her predecessors has something individual to bring to it.

An automobile went out of control in downtown Brooklyn during the rush hour last night and ran down five women. Two of the victims each had to have a leg amputated. The others were also seriously injured.
We deplore deeply the unfortunate and grave condition of our Chief Executive and hope sincerely for his fast and complete recovery.

Once again the time has come to examine the woodpile. Indeed, since the hour is later than anyone might think, the time has come not only to examine it but fill it. There have been evenings so brisk that great firmness has been needed to prevent the women about the place from turning on the furnace.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- High-class industrial shares managed to make further small gains today, despite a dwindling of business late in the session. Demand for British Government securities also fell, although earlier gains were generally held. They rose as much as 12 shillings 6 pence ($1.75). The slowing of the market in gilt-edge issues was ascribed partly to the weakening of the pound sterling against the dollar and some European currencies.
The Community Service Society opened a drive yesterday for the million dollars it needs to help New York families in trouble.

The question was raised in various quarters yesterday as to what would have happened in Wednesday's series opener if Yogi Berra had interfered with Frank Kellert, who was at the plate, on Jackie Robinson's successful steal of home.

A privately planned apartment project to be built in North Harlem received yesterday a Government-insured mortgage commitment. It was the first ever issued by the Federal Housing Administration for a private project in a slum area.
LONDON, Sept, 29 -- The British Government has notified Egypt it takes a "grave view" of the Egyptian-Soviet arms purchase arrangement.

Four straight? The Yankees, following their second conquest of the Dodgers, might have been thinking in terms of a clean sweep but they weren't talking that way. Despite the air of confidence that filled the dressing room after Tommy Byrne had disposed of the Dodgers yesterday, not a Yankee was willing to predict the quickest possible world series conquest.

Commodity futures were generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was light. Rubber, cottonseed oil, potatoes, onions, cocoa and copper eased; coffee, zinc, sugar and wool were mixed, and hides rose.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union is determined to push its vast program for developing the virgin lands of Western Siberia and Kazakhstan despite the threat of recurrent drought.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Sept. 29 -- If Lawrenceville School's lettermen continue to show improvement, "we should have a fairly good season," Larry Tiihonen, in his twenty-seventh year as head football coach, said today.
Plans by an American business group to help Spain expand production and trade were made known yesterday by Angier Biddle Duke, former United States Ambassador to El Salvador.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- An atomic power plant under construction in Scotland will create 170 pounds of plutonium for each 100 pounds of the atomic fuel it burns up.
Exiled leaders of nine Eastern European nations warned the people of non-Communist countries yesterday that too much reliance on "the Soviet smile" might cost them their freedom.

MAHWAH, N. J., Sept. 29 -Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, announced tonight a $500,000,000 expansion program for 1956. It was his answer to dismal outcries of "the Nervous Nellies" of industry, he said.

AT THE BENNER PASS, Italy, Sept. 29 -- The first contingent of United States Army combat troops to be transferred from Austria to Italy came through this wind-swept pass between the two countries today.
Cotton futures declined yesterday under liquidation that dropped March, May and July, 1955, deliveries into new seasonal low ground.
If their new general manager has his way, the St. Louis Cardinals' field manager for 1956 will be either Leo Durocher or Marty Marion.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 29 -- Lack of continuity in prison administrations is one of the greatest defects in this nation's correction systems, William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General of the United States, said today.
Former Mayor William O'Dwyer flew in from Mexico City yesterday prepared to discuss with the management of the Brooklyn Dodgers a proposal for moving the team to the Mexican capital.

THE elegant members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, catching their second wind, handsomely got on with the business of presenting "The Mikado" last night at the Sam S. Shubert Theatre. Earlier this week, the outwardly unruffled English verse singers auspiciously began their nine-week season of repertory here by spoofing the English aristocracy in "Iolanthe."

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The Boston heart specialist who served as a consultant on the heart attack that struck President Eisenhower five days ago clinically endorsed today the "family doctor's'' treatment of the case.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Following is an unofficial translation of an address by Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, before the United Nations General Assembly today:
The National League of Masonic Clubs opened its golden anniversary four-day convention yesterday in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel."

NORTHWEST TOWNSHIP, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- The 241-mile Ohio Turnpike will be opened for its entire length at 12:01 A. M. Saturday following a ceremony here at the Westgate terminal toll plaza near the Indiana line.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Further light on the problem of dealing with radioactive fall-out from an atomic bomb explosion was offered today by Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Record sales and earnings were achieved by W. R. Grace Co. in the first six months of this year. The company's semi-annual statement was issued yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, chairman, and J. Peter Grace, president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Treasury announced today it will sell on Monday $2,750,000,000 of tax anticipation certificates, bearing 2 1/4 per cent interest.
The Rockefeller Foundation has informed Congress that it would support legislation requiring full public reports on tax-exempt foundations.

A little more than two years ago, the Washington Senators jumped at the opportunity to accept $500 from a minor league club for the contract of Tommy Byrne, the pitching and batting hero of the Yankees second world series victory over the Dodgers yesterday.

The Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has leased space for a branch office in the twenty-five story office building being completed by Uris Brothers at 300 Park Avenue. The structure occupies the west blockfront between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- What is delaying the journey into exile of Juan D. Peron has become a first-class mystery here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The State Department is back in the market for new talent after several years of lagging recruitment.
A vacant plot of 106,000 square feet on Twenty-seventh Street, north of Forty-ninth Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the George A. Fuller Company to Arlen Associates, Inc.

The "good thing" finished just out of the pay-off spot in the feature at Belmont Park yesterday. The event was the Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap of about two miles, and the good thing was the entry of Hyvania and Landscaping.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 -- The Army has ordered everyone without a Lebanese passport to move at least six miles from the Israeli border. Nine thousand Palestinian Arabs are on the move seeking new places to live as a result of the order.
A second building, containing four stores, is being completed for occupancy next month in the Levittown Park Center on the southeast corner of Wantagh Avenue and Miller Place in Levittown, L. I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Department of Justice of this Administration, which Democrats charge with a loving alliance with Big Business, got another grand jury indictment under the Sherman Act yesterday and filed another anti-trust suit against the same branch of commerce -- the smoked-fish trade in New York City.

Hiram Walker, Inc., fourth in whisky production of the big four distillers, has come up with a new idha for its Christmas gift packages -- its regular bottles Christmas-wrapped by machine at the distillery. The resulting package, which was shown yesterday at a press conference at Hampshire House, is expected to enable the store clerk to attend a customer's wants with one sweep-off of a cellophane outer wrap.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 29 -- Late this afternoon an elderly sign painter lettered the words "Members New York Stock Exchange" on the front door of the brokerage firm of Muir, Dumke Light here.
STONEWALL, Tex., Sept. 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson and the two top Democrats in Congress pledged today that they would not seek to make political capital out of President Eisenhower's heart attack.

The Rockefeller Foundation has been so powerful a factor in promoting science, not only in this country but all over the world, that its annual reports may be regarded as good surveys of trends in research. These trends are often the outgrowth of controversy as well as of great research.

Today's new film is "The Naked Street," a United Artists melodrama with Farley Granger, Anthony Quinn and Anne Bancroft, at the Palace. Maxwell Shane directed the Edward Small production from a story by Leo Katcher.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The death rate on the country's highways is running more than 1,000 fatalities ahead of last year with the most dangerous months still to come, the National Safety Council said today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 29 -- Pakistan's new foreign minister talked today of the "spirit of friendship" with the Soviet Union and voiced support for Egypt's request for Soviet arms.
The gong sounding the close of the trading session today on the New York Cocoa Exchange will mark thirty years of dealings in cocoa futures.

An immediate study of traffic congestion on the city's waterfront, pier rentals and the city's proposed six-year $187,053,886 port improvement and development program was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

Wall Street revealed yesterday that it had recovered the aplomb -- if not all the money -- that was lost on Monday. As it has been doing rather regularly since 1903, the world series pushed the market off center stage on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.
A WAYFARER in a reminiscent mood made a pilgrimage down Second Avenue one recent day to see what changes time had wrought in that faded center of East Side intellectual and artistic life.
In his letter to The Times, published on Sept. 19, my Turkish colleague, Nuri Eren, made two statements with which one must agree.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The General Assembly's Steering Committee decided today on a full Assembly debate on the problem of Netherlands New Guinea.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $63,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Philadelphia Electric Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday sizable gains in operating revenues for the twelve months ended July 31. H. P. Liversidge, chairman, in a letter to stockholders noted that the gain reflected in part the abnormally hot weather of the past summer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Secretary of the Navy, Charles S. Thomas, today blamed buying practices under the Truman Administration for Navy troubles with a jet plane now under Congressional investigation.

Throughout the immense, sprawling Indonesian archipelago millions of citizens are now in the process of casting their first ballot in a nation-wide election. The final returns will not be in for perhaps as much as two months. It may be several days before even the early trends are firmly established.
Entertainment offered in connection with bingo games, except for charitable and religious purposes, must be licensed.
DENVER, Friday, Sept. 30--President Eisenhower's physician's have approved his resumption of Presidential authority for a moment this evening.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The board of publication of the United Lutheran Church in America announced today the purchase of a sixteen-acre tract in the Germantown section here. It will be used for the erection of a $1,500,000 national headquarters.
A jungle-like legal tangle and "paralyzing inertia" keep thousands of foster children from enjoying the benefits of adoption, the Welfare and Health Council of New York City charged yesterday.
Mayor Wagner presented the annual Gold Medal Award of the Hundred Year Association last night to David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America.

The Dodger fan stepped out of the ball park and looked around. Thousands of fans milled about and headed for subways, buses and taxis. The Dodger fan sighed. He started for the subway and stopped, turning around to look at the stadium where his team had just lost their second in a row.
Winifred Young presented a piano program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her selections ranged from the eighteenth-century Spanish master, Mateo Albeniz, to Mrs. H. H. A. Beach.

Directors of the Dover Corporation and the Peerless Manufacturing Corporation yesterday approved a plan whereby Dover would acquire all the assets and business of Peerless, subject to approval of stockholders of both concerns.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Representatives of public and private organizations concerned with book publishing met here today to plan for wider foreign distribution of American books.
Gasoline seeping from filling station tanks into a subway station halted service for nine hours yesterday on part of the I. R. T.'s Pelham Bay line.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson urged Controller General Joseph Campbell today to withdraw a "stop" order on plans to set up a privately-owned air defense communications network.
ARTHUR MILLER'S "A View From the Bridge," which opened at the Coronet last evening, consists of two short plays set on the opposite shores of the East River.
Private colleges and universities were urged yesterday to set the pace in expanding facilities for the 5,000,000 college students expected yearly in the next decade.

An 89-year-old patient in Queens General Hospital and his brother-in-law were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges of fraudulently cashing Social Security checks totaling $2,500.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The French franc took a new drop today to 388 to the dollar. It has been dropping more than a week.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 29 -- One of last Saturday's college football surprises was Dartmouth's 20-0 lead over Colgate going into the final quarter. Colgate put across three touchdowns and won by 21 -- 20. But it was a real achievement for the Hanoverians in their first game under their new coach, Bob Blackman, to make so close a fight against a team as good as the Maroon.
The United States Immigration Service will not repeat this year the mass induction of new citizens it held in 109 cities on Nov. 11, 1954.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System, off to a brisk and successful start this season with many of its new programs, cannot seem to get its lullaby hour working very smoothly.
The State Liquor Authority moved yesterday to make certain that there is a "clear and full view" of bars and restaurant from both outside and inside.

The first volume of "The War Memoirs" of Gen. Charles de Gaulle will be issued in two editions by Viking Press. "The Call to Honour" will be published in a one-volume, illustrated edition on Oct. 24. It tells of the pre-war French preparations up to the middle of 1942, when the North African landings were being prepared.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- France called on the Soviet Union today to agree to an authentic improvement in EastWest relations.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Oliver Poole, 44-year-old former Member of Parliament, was named today as chairman of the Conservative party organization.
The New York Telephone Company said yesterday it had received 184,500 calls for the score of Wednesday's world series game.

More than three months ago the writer was present in the office of Mayor Robert F. Wagner to see him formally execute the Sharkey bill creating a commission on InterGroup Relations. So far, however, no commissioners have been formally appointed and no commission functioning.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Pravda charged today that the Western Big Three foreign ministers had been holding secret talks in New York aimed at upsetting directives for their October meeting in Geneva with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov.
The Board of Education ruled last night that a principal, three teachers and a teacher-clerk who had admitted to being ex-Communists must stand trial.

Earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad amounted to $8,057,581 last month and lifted net income for the first eight months this year to a record $50,445,629. The previous eight-month high was $41,791,443, achieved in 1948.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 -- Hurricane Janet smashed into the Mexican mainland at near noon today at Pueblo Nautla, about eighty miles north of Vera Cruz, on the Gulf of Mexico.
The opening of "The Desk Set," starring Shirley Booth, has been deferred from Oct. 13 to the week of Oct. 24 at the Broadburst.

A strike threat hangs over twenty ship repair yards here, following the breakdown yesterday of wage negotiations between the companies and Local 1972 of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L.
MADRID, Sept. 29 -- The process of reconnecting Spain with the main currents of Western European economic life is slow and at times painful. But it is going forward.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- The provisional Government was conducting an intensive investigation today of the nation's economy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 29 -- Brazil is winding up her Presidential campaign with four candidates in the tightest race of recent Brazilian history.

RYE., N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The United States team captured the Amorita Cup from Bermuda skippers off the American Yacht Club today. Winning the fifth race in the scheduled four-out-of-seven series, 33 1/4 to 21, the host Long Island Sound quintet was victorious, four races to one.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Doug Ford, the national Professional Golfers' Association champion, set the pace today in a new tournament.
A dinner and supper dance was given last night in the Empire Room at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Southampton Hospital on Long Island.
GREENWOOD, Miss., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Two men acused of kidnapping a 14-year old Chicago Negro boy seek freedom on bonds tomorrow amid rumors that the boy, Emmett Louis Till, is alive.

VIENNA, Sept. 12 -- The two most joyful spots in Austria today should be the town of Doellersheim and the small city of Baden. Doellersheim was the center of a 55,000-acre maneuver ground taken over in 1945 by the Soviet Army as "German property." Baden was their headquarters.

The program of the Camp Fire Girls Council of Greater New York will be aided by the proceeds of the Wo-He-Lo Ball, a dinner and dance to be held on Oct. 24 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that about 2.3 per cent of housing that was for rent or sale stood vacant in the second quarter of 1955.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- No changes in foreign or domestic policies are "needed or contemplated in the near future," Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today. He made the statement after it was announced in Denver that Sherman Adams, the President's closest adviser, was flying there tomorrow to take charge of the summer White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on last Saturday, totaled 819,025 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 3,189 cars, or 0.4 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week, 108,810 cars, or 15.3 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, and 684 cars, or 0.1 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
A great need of home care for handicapped children was described yesterday by Dr. Helen M. Wallace, director of the Department of Health's Bureau Handicapped Children.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- The Chicago Regional Port District is in business.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Harrison Flippin of Ardmore, Pa., won the United States Senior Women's Golf Association's twenty-ninth championship today over the South Course of the Westchester Country Club.

Constructive efforts to help in meeting our nation's need for more and better engineers and scientists have been increasingly reflected in recent issues of The New York Times, particularly in the excellent analyses made by Benjamin Fine.

Ten public hearings will be held in nine cities next month on a proposal to consolidate the state's antiquated and complicated court system into five courts. Two of the hearings will take place in New York City.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The spanning of the Hudson River's broad Tappan Zee here by the new $60,000,000 bridge of the New York-Buffalo Thruway was completed this afternoon. This is the first structural crossing of the river in this area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission today denied an application for a new hearing on its decision authorizing the Idaho Power Company to build a power project in Hell's Canyon on the Snake River in Idaho and Oregon.

There is no indication that the Soviet Union now is prepared to agree to German reunification on any basis acceptable to the Western powers, Dr. Heinrich yon Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Federal Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Abraham Traub, a New York lawyer, for contempt of court. A jail sentence of one year imposed upon Mr. Traub was set aside.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Trading volume in soybean futures was sharply higher and early price fluctuations were about the most irregular and chaotic ever witnessed on the Board of Trade. However, after the first hour trading became more orderly, but prices remained sharply higher as a result of statistics showing a big disappearance, much lighter stocks of meal than had been expected, and higher prices for oil.
Rayonier, Inc., soon will begin construction of a $25,000,000 chemical cellulose plant at Jesup, Ga.
SINGAPORE, Sept. 29 -- The Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya has accepted the Communists' offer for truce negotiations with Chin Peng, secretary general of the Malayan Communist party.

MOSCOW, Sept. 29 -- Soviet writers were told today the time had come to redefine their literary canons. While continuing to promote Marxism-Leninism, it was said, Soviet authors should no longer eschew "positive" ideas of bourgeois classic literature.
ONE and a half million women go to work every day in New York, and they seem to be becoming more clothes-conscious all the time.
A Fifth Avenue window, an insurance company and Lord Beaverbrook were involved yesterday in a legal question of what to do about a painting by Fragonard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Sufficient reductions in military spending to assure a balanced budget this fiscal year were ruled out today by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Gerald Francis Burrill, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Chicago, was enthroned formally today in St. James Episcopal Cathedral.
The Hospital for Special Surgery has just received gifts totaling $5,700,000.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 -- A United Nations truce headquarters spokesman said here tonight that if Israel and Egypt did not withdraw their forces tomorrow from the El Auja demilitarized zone the matter would be referred to the United Nations Security Council.

Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said last night he would "do all I can to see that justice is done, for Morton Sobell." Sobell is serving a thirty-year sentence in Alcatraz, as an accomplice of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, executed atom spies.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York began last night its campaign for $18,100,000 with $2,500,000 pledged toward the record goal.
LANSING, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Gov. G. Mennox Williams of Michigan today canceled plans to deliver the main address at the Alabama Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner in Birmingham, Ala., Oct. 5.

Manager Smokey Alston didn't voice any confidence that his Dodgers would go on to win this world series after the Yankees had made it two straight yesterday. But neither did he express a lack of confidence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said today that enough Salk vaccine would be available next year to complete the inoculating of all children of the ages 1 through 9.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Government of President Carlos Ibanez repealed today a series of recent measures designed to curb speculation in stocks.
Commercial paper dealers raised the rate they offer buyers of their paper by 1/8 of one percentage point yesterday, the ninth increase this year.

CARMEN AMAYA brought her company of Spanish dancers back to New York last night for a series of four performances at Carnegie Hall after an absence of a dozen years. Certainly she has not been wasting her time in the interim, for whereas she left us a whirlwind gypsy without much form or discipline, she returns to us an artist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Sparked by a fast rate of automobile buying, the public went into debt another three- quarters of a billion dollars for consumer credit in August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Assistant Chief Edward Connors was named and sworn in yesterday as chief of the city's Fire Department.
SALZBURG, Austria, Sept. 22 -- Salzburg's second biggest employer, the United States Army is pulling out bag and baggage, leaving behind it 5,000 Austrian civilians without jobs.

What makes wrens what wrens are? The bird books do not explain wrens; they describe them. Those books are not unlike many volumes written by men about women; they too attempt to explain, but they really only describe. So with wrens:
The deliberately delayed delivery of an $11,000 payroll frustrated two kidnappers in a robbery attempt yesterday.

Seven five-story store and apartment buildings at 250 to 262 Eleventh Street in Hoboken, N. J., have been sold by the Sefel Holding Corporation to a New York syndicate headed by Chauncy S. Olman, attorney. Louis M. Tamarin was the broker in the sale of the property, which contains four stores and sixty-four apartments.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Immigration Service announced today that Lieut. Hsuan Wei, a Nationalist Chinese Marine, had been ordered deported to Formosa as a deserter.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 30 -- The United Nations truce chief, Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, assented early today to an Israeli request that the deadline for the withdrawal of Egyptian and Israeli forces from the El Auja demilitarized zone be postponed till Sunday.

Thursday's total of 592 pints of blood donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood program included two mass contributions. They were made at Time, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza, 155 pints, and at the Home Insurance Company, 59 Maiden Lane, 110 pints.

The aircraft carrier Forrestal, first of a class of warships designed to assure United States control of the seas throughout the Nineteen Sixties, will be commissioned this afternoon at the Norfolk Naval Shipyard at Portsmouth, Va.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation adopted a report today rejecting the proposal of the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, for Government purchase of pork to support prices. They suggested, instead, a program for development of larger markets for pork and lard.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 -- The Lebanese Government decided today to check agitators who had caused strikes and other protest actions among the 100,000 Palestine Arab refugees in the country.
RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Westchester Country Club horse show opened today with an entry of over 1,500. Eleven states and Canada are represented in the three-day event.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- By a single vote France lost her fight today to keep the Algerian issue out of the United Nations forum.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Joan Crawford will go to London in the spring to star in "The Story of Esther Costello," according to the Music Corporation of America, her agents.

Directors of Seeman Brothers, Inc., have elected J. Stanley Seeman as president to succeed Sylvan L. Stix, who becomes chairman of the board of the 70-year-old wholesale distributor of White Rose and other food products.

The Ex-Cell-O Corporation, producer of machine tools and dairy equipment, yesterday reported its net profit for the nine months ended Aug. 31 at $8,093,953, compared with $7,131,566 in the similar period a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The White House made clear today that the Administration had abandoned further consideration of a delegation of powers by the President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products increased 1 per cent between mid-August and mid-September.

Malaya's Communist terrorists have now made a "peace offer" to the Government of Malaya and the head of the Malayan Chinese Association. They want a "conference" to discuss a cease-fire and plans for a "peaceful and independent Malaya." The Government has tentatively

The three top officials of the International Longshoremen's Association declared yesterday that the union would never accept financial or other assistance from Harry Bridges and his West Coast dock workers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The board of directors of the Marquette Cement Manufacturing Company voted here today to submit to the shareowners a proposal for a 2 1/2-for-one split of the company's authorized common and preferred shares.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The appearance of Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, as a keynote speaker tomorrow night before the Federal Employes Veterans Association convention was canceled today by the organization, "in the best interests of all concerned."

Three volumes of natural history are scheduled for publication shortly. On Oct. 24, two books dealing with mammals will be issued by two publishers. One is "Living Mammals of the World," by Ivan T. Sanderson (Hanover House).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Labor Department reported today that strike idleness during the first eight months of 1955 was about one quarter of 1 per cent of all working time, nearly a post-war low record.

The recent upheaval in Argentina focused attention on private United States investments abroad. This country's business men have a stake of some $400,000,000 in the South American nation, holdings that have been largely frozen under the late Peron regime.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 26 to 53 points ($1.30 to $2.65 a bale) yesterday. The March and May deliveries showed greatest weakness.
" The big thing U. S. O. does," said President Eisenhower, "is to keep a soldier understanding that he is a part of America."

Career Boy of the C. V. Whitney entry won the Anticipation Purse at Belmont Park yesterday. Before the 14,950 spectators were able to find out who won, though, they had to await a scrutiny of the photograph by the stewards.

W. Randolph Burgess, Under Secretary of the Treasury, appeared before the annual convention of the American Bankers Association this week and had some good advice to offer the 8,500 delegates who had converged on Chicago for that meeting. Speaking not only for the
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- The Federal Government has decided not to appeal a Federal court decision clearing Harry Bridges of charges he belonged to the Communist party.

FASHION and the do-it-yourself fad have brought hard surfaced floor coverings out of the bathroom and kitchen. Rubber, vinyl asphalt and linoleum are now used in bedrooms, foyers and living rooms without apology.

Swelled by the retirement of a large issue of oil bonds, the total of $235,241,000 in bonds called for redemption in September before maturity was the largest for any September since 1947, when $322,801,000 was retired. It was the second largest monthly figure this year, being exceeded by $283,775,000 redeemed in January.

Charles K. Hellriegel of 194-33 115th Road, St. Albans, Queens, was elected president yesterday of the National League of Masonic Clubs. The election was at the business session of the league's fiftieth annual convention in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel.

United Nations members have again been reminded that the case of Korea is still very much before them. Questions are still unanswered and problems unsolved. The Commission for the Unification and Rehabilitation of Korea has submitted its report, which should, and probably will, lead to a full debate in the Assembly session.
It was a much different scene in the Dodger clubhouse yesterday after the boys had bounced back into what might be called World series "contention."
A PROGRAM of new chamber music was played last night at Carnegie Recital Hall as another of Norman J. Seaman's Interval Concerts.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 30 -- The Swedes said good-by tonight to forty-one years of partial prohibition. Tomorrow begins a new deal under which liquor can be bought in stores more or less freely and served in restaurants in any quantity customers show they can support.

RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 30 -- Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa of Morocco has signed his letters of resignation from the throne. His retirement is expected within five days. The Sultan, however, set a condition to his resignation that his powers be given to a member of his family.

Stocks moved downward in unhurried fashion yesterday and barely nosed into the minus column for September. The New York Times combined average closed off 1.69 points on the day and 0.23 on the month at 315.77. The rails slipped 0.50 to 99.89 and the industrials 2.88 to 531.66.

New bonds publicly offered here in September dropped to the smallest total for any month since May and for any September since 1952. Stock flotations, on the other hand, were the largest for any month since May and for any September since 1929.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The British Government is planning an intense drive to restore law and order in Cyprus as a first step to introducing self-government there.

CARLE PLACE, L. I., Saturday, Oct. 1 -- Three thousand employes of the Arma division plant of the American Bosch Arma Corporation at Roosevelt Field went on strike at 12:01 A. M. today. The division manufactures precision equipment for the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Export-Import Bank formally signed a $100,000,000 loan agreement today to help finance the Toquepala copper project in southern Peru.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The only change from Robert Moses' original plan for the Ramble seems to be that he is adding more cover for birds. But with gaming tables, parking lots and a big building it hardly seems possible that even extra cover will keep the birds coming into the Ramble.

It's not quite correct that the Dodgers have sold every seat for the world series games at Ebbets Field. Harold Parrott, the business manager of the Dodgers, divulged yesterday that one reserved seat strip remained unsold.

Two hundred exiles from East European nations asked the United States, Britain and France last night to demand free elections in the Soviet satellites as a prerequisite to any collective security system for Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the Secretary of the Navy, Charles S. Thomas, in connection with his decision to grant a Reserve commission to Midshipman Eugene W. Landy:
Music apparently had sufficient charms last night to legalize bingo.
ROME, Sept. 30 -- Any attempt to create a "European spirit" should be based on closer relations between European cities in different countries, Pope Pius XII said today.
A performance of the National Horse Show, traditionally one of the top events on New York's social calendar, will aid needy persons in the lower Yorkville section of Manhattan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Judy Garland's first experience last week with television is leading to a second.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 -- Brazilian financial circles were restless today over rumors of an imminent change in foreign exchange regulations.
ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The State University of New York reported today that it had been forced to turn away thousands of applicants for fall-semester enrollment.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SAN MATEO, Calif., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Pete Moreno was critically injured and two other jockeys also were hurt in a three-horse spill during the third race at Bay Meadows today.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 - Cornelius Shields, Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association champion of the International One-Design Class, won his second race in a row from Sir Bayard Dill of Bermuda off the American Yacht Club today.

The Ford Motor Company outlined yesterday some of the projects planned under an announced $500,000,000 expansion program in 1956. According to estimates, every dollar will be spent or earmarked before the end of that year.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Dr. Eddie Anderson headed for Dartmouth today with a Holy Cross football team that should be considerably stronger than the 1954 varsity.
