DENVER, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower formally resumed his Presidential authority last night.
New York's famed Riverside Church will observe its twenty-fifth birthday tomorrow.
After two days of aimless wandering, the Dodgers yesterday came upon the trail that may yet lead them to their first world series title.

" ONE HALF SO PRECIOUS,"* by Kate Farness, is a historical novel of the Nineteen Twenties. The scene is the Minnesota that such promising novelists as Sinclair Lewis and Scott Fitzgerald began writing about when they were natives of the midlands' northern reaches in what is now a faraway time.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Britain, France and the United States are preparing to protest jointly to Moscow against the recent transfer of control over Berlin's approaches to the East German Communist regime.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Inquiry into the organization of the Foreign Office by a small committee of privy councilors was suggested tonight by Herbert Morrison.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 30 -- Don Fairfield, a 25-year-old professional from Casey, Ill., took the lead in the Long Island Rotary open tournament today.

A demand for a long-range shipbuilding program capable of halting "the running tide of shipyard extinction and the annihilation of shipbuilding skills in America" has been made by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said today that "the welfare of the nation suffers" because Congress did not pass legislation this year for a giant roadbuilding program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Britain complained today that the Soviet Union was resorting to evasive tactics on key disarmament questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals unanimously affirmed today the conviction of Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson for collaborating with Chinese Communists while a prisoner in Korea.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Princeton will match its single-wing running power against Columbia's strong passing attack in an Ivy League football game at Palmer Stadium tomorrow. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P. M.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Sept. 30 -- Haverford School has one of the smallest, lightest and youngest football teams in Frederick R. (Doc) Wallace's twenty-seven years as head coach.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower's illness is obviously disturbing to Soviet authorities because it introduces a new and unexpected element of uncertainty into the international situation. This disquiet hasn't been communicated to the Soviet people.

THE growing stream of autumn art exhibitions includes both veterans and newcomers. Too many of the latter make premature appearances, but that is less their fault than that of galleries, ruthlessly exploiting potential talent at the years of art school levels.

Surrogate William T. Collins reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss objections to the probate of the will of Mrs. Agnes Baringere Momand filed by her 102-year-old mother, Mrs. Wilhelmina Van Etten of Detroit. Mrs. Van Etten seeks to share in her daughter's $3,000,000 estate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A safety wing for automobiles was patented this week by the proprietor of a Georgia motor court. His purpose is not to enable a car to take off but to hold it down on the road.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation has taken an option on 300 acres in suburban Brooklyn, Ohio, as a site for a $100,000,000 stamping plant, it was announced today by Mayor John M. Coyne of Brooklyn.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 30 -- A special "readjustment center" for problem prisoners instead of the traditional solitary confinement was suggested here today by a group of California correction officials.

The walk from the dugout to the dressing room at Ebbets Field is a long one. It's longer when your team loses. And as Casey Stengel led his beaten Yankees into the seclusion of their quarters after yesterday's game he whistled softly.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The British believe the removal of President Eisenhower from active service, even for a few months, would delay international progress toward the creation of a more peaceful world through settlement of outstanding East-West problems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Pro-French delegates to the United Nations expressed alarm tonight over the possible consequences of the General Assembly's decision to debate the Algerian question.
College football, with an attractive schedule of conference, sectional and intersectional contests, moves into the sports spotlight today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 30 -- The Archbishop and Ethnarch of Cyprus, Makarios III, is a twentieth century anomaly, a modern nationalist in medieval clerical garb. He studies scripture and the technique of political insurrection. He sits on a walnut throne adorned with the double eagle of Byzantium. But he learned sociology in Boston.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A heavy tone was the general rule in futures markets on the Board of Trade today. Pressure was especially heavy on corn and soybeans.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 -- The Argentine Central Bank placed forty-one large companies on an economic blacklist today.
Some of the young and beautiful people from the rueful pages of F. Scott Fitzgerald will be transposed to the stage of the Longacre Theatre at 8:30 o'clock this evening.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Two white men, acquitted of the "wolf-whistle" murder of Emmett Till but still facing charges of kidnapping the 14-year-old Chicago Negro, were released in $10,000 bond each today.

Commodity futures closed generally lower in dull trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, hides, rubber, cottonseed oil, lead, copper and potatoes eased, while zinc, burlap and wool were mixed.

CAIRO, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- A special United States envoy, George V. Allen, meets Premier Gamel Abdel Nasser today in an eleventh-hour bid to counter Egypt's announced intention of buying arms from the Communist bloc. His mission met with annoyance in high Egyptian circles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Imports in August soared to the highest level in over a year, except for a single month affected by a previous dock strike, the Commerce Department reported today.
A Jesuit brother who grew up on New York's East Side will skipper a fifty-foot schooner in the widely scattered Marshall Islands with only a month's training in seamanship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 111.3 of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Average prices for both farm products and foods were lower, while the index for all commodities other than farm and food was higher.

Despite Soviet efforts to dodge the issue, the campaign for the peaceful liberation of some 100,000,000 subjugated people in Eastern Europe continues to put the Kremlin and its satellite regimes on the defensive. In this campaign a particularly important task is being performed by the Assembly of Captive European Nations, now meeting in New York, close to the headquarters of the United Nations. Consisting

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The General Assembly vote today on the Steering Committee's motion to bar the Algerian question from the agenda was as follows:
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Price increases on most of its farm equipment products were announced today by the International Harvester Company.
Broken in spirit because delays in immigration procedure kept dashing his hope of American citizenship, Thadeusz Kassern, former Polish Consul in New York, attempted to take his life yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -- Hurricane Janet has apparently broken itself to pieces in the eastern Sierra Madre Mountains along the Mexican Gulf coast. But its ravages are mounting up to a catastrophe.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A demand that the Pentagon discontinue its "news blackout" was voiced here today by Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- Brooklyn Dodger fans will have a topic for endless debate if plans for a domed-over, indoor stadium in the borough are realized.
LIKE a lot of two-footed performers from Hollywood, Champion, the stallion, may be the victim of his own publicity staff.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Secretary of the Navy today granted a Naval Reserve ensign's commission to Eugene W. Landy. Mr. Landy had been denied a commission because of his mother's past Communist activities.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 30 -- United Kingdom and Continental shipowners have accepted an Australian shippers' compromise offer of a 7 1/2 per cent increase in freight rates between Australia and Europe instead of the 10 per cent requested. The new rates will go into effect tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Koppers Company, Inc., today bought the assets of Turner Haws Engineering Company, Inc., of West Roxbury, Mass., makers of a special line of filters for cleaning industrial air and gas.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept 30 -- American books are valuable weapons in the war of ideas, and their flow abroad should be facilitated by the Federal Government as a defense measure, it was agreed at a conference here today.
PASO ROBLES, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP) -- James Dean, 24-year-old motion picture actor, was killed tonight in an automobile accident near here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -The Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights announced postponement today of scheduled hearings Monday on the religious clause of the First Amendment to the Constitution.

The apartment building at 455 Empire Boulevard in Brooklyn has been sold by Jennie Moncher to Beno and Eva Rosenberg. Albert A. Altman was attorney for the seller and Isaac Anolic acted for the buyers. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month -- both in volume and prices -- brought back sobering memories of 1929. Volume soared and prices sank in reaction to President Eisenhower's illness.

WHEN the bedraggled and battered Brooks began to wend their weary way homeward on Thursday after experiencing disaster at Yankee Stadium in the first two games of the world series, they sat silently in the chartered bus. Then up spoke Dixie Howell, the third-string catcher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Justice got a consent judgment today against five large steel casting companies to end alleged monopolistic practices in the manufacture and sale of railway freight car parts.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- The appointment of Dr. Raphael Lemkin as Professor of Law at Rutgers Law School here was announced today. Dr. Lemkin, one of the authors of the Genocide Convention, continues active in a campaign to have the convention ratified. Fifty national parliaments have ratified the international proposal against destruction of national, ethnic, racial and religious groups.

Today's new film is "One Step to Eternity," a French-made drama of suspense starring Danielle Darrieux, Michel Auclair and Corinne Calvet, at the Paris. Henri Decoin directed the Ellis Films release, which has French dialogue and English subtitles.

The remarkable "Porgy and Bess" Company which has been winning friends for the American way of life will soon be singing the bright legend of Catfish Row behind the Iron Curtain. In a little less than a month the company will complete a tour of Latin America and fly to Moscow to begin a tour of the Soviet Union and the satellite countries.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 30 -- Following is the text of an address today by Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, before the General Assembly:...

I WAS 35 years old. Bess Wallace and I decided to go ahead with our plans for marriage and we set the day, June 28, 1919, less than eight weeks after I was discharged from the Army. We were married in the Trinity Episcopal Church in Independence. After a wedding trip to Chicago and Port Huron, Mich., we returned to live at 219 North Delaware Street in Independence.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 30 -- The National Assembly passed a bill today merging the 310,000 square miles of West Pakistan into a single province. The vote was 40 to 13. Twenty-seven members did not vote.

Sale of the two trailerships New York and Albany to the Delaware County National Bank of Chester, Pa., was confirmed yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman. The vessels were bid in for $350,000 ten days ago at a United States marshal's auction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Argentina's two top delegates to the current General Assembly session have been replaced as a result of the overthrow of the Peron government.

UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 30 -- The illness of President Eisenhower has made a deep impression on delegates at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, yet the prospect of its having any practical effect on international politics, as practiced here, is ragarded as zero.
VICENZA, Italy, Sept. 30 -- The first United States combat troops transferred from Austria woke up in their new home today and immediately started to rearrange everything.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Leroy Dixon, writing on New York's traffic ills, laid his finger on a number of weak spots in our system of regulations and enforcement. Among them he names "pre-emption of pedestrians' safety needs by automotive traffic," and he calls for strict enforcement to prevent vehicles from "hogging streets and ignoring proper stop spaces" and from "blocking pedestrians' right of way."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Manufacturers' sales and new orders rose more than seasonally in August to "about the highest rates on record," the Department of Commerce reported today. Sales were listed at $27,500,000,000, more than $4,000,000,000 higher than in the same month last year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many Americans now seem to be eager to welcome delegations from the Soviet Union. This is so because they believe that they are thereby helping the cause of peace and international friendship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Britain told the United Nations today that the Western powers could produce a plan offering "full protection" to the Soviet Union against the threat of a reunited Germany.

WHEN the Great Artist brushes the colors of autumn on his pallette and begins to paint the leaves, when smoke rises lazily from the chimney pots and there is a tang in the air, those who love the outdoors are stirred anew.
New studies with radioactive tracers have established that the bones of man and animals participate with amazing rapidity in a host of complex chemical reactions with the blood.
Judging by the New York Telephone Company's report, there is more interest in the Yankee-Dodger world series this year than there was in the 1954 classic between the Giants and the Indians.
Stockholders of Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., yesterday approved the purchase of the Spencer Wire Corporation, Union, N. J., maker of wire and cable.
" Monitor," the National Broadcasting Company's week-end round-the-clock radio show will participate in a simulcast on Oct. 16 between 4 and 5:30 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Democratic National Committee today announced a stepped - up program of meetings and fund-raising dinners to be held across the country during October.
" Chatter, chatter and ask questions; that's all you do all day," a harassed mother may complain to an underfoot child.
THREE first New York performances of twentieth-century American works were presented by Joan Holley at her piano recital last night in Town Hall. Yet the spirit of romanticism dominated the occasion.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Federal police revealed today what they described as the story of Juan D. Peron's "intimate relations" with a teen-age brunette. They said he was planning to send for her after reaching exile in Paraguay.

With increased benefits for New York's 2,000,000 children as its goal, the Citizens Committee for Children has taken over the Oct. 18 performance of "Tiger at the Gates" at the Plymouth Theatre. Christopher Fry's adaptation of the play by Jean Giraudoux will star Michael Redgrave, with Leueen MacGrath and Walter Fitzgerald.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30 -- Brazil tonight wound up a hard, noisy Presidential election campaign. The election will be held Monday.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Dr. Paul Dudley White said today he had "no objections whatsoever" to President Eisenhower running for a second term if he "has a good recovery as he seems to be on the way to establishing."
Emil Gilels, famous Soviet pianist, became yesterday the first cultural dividend of the Russo-American diplomatic rapprochement.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to purchase an "experimental quantity" of United States hybrid seed corn to bolster the Government's program for expanding corn production.

LE PREMIER Cuisinier de France (The First Chef of France), who won his envied title in an open competition six years ago, works, rather surprisingly, in the restaurant of a Paris railroad station, the Gare de L'Est.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although the nation should have been warned by President Wilson's stroke on Oct. 4, 1919, that our constitutional provisions governing the Presidential powers needed revision, nothing has been done, except to change the order of Presidential succession, in the thirty-six years between Wilson's stroke and Eisenhower's heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A petition asking that the National Negro Labor Council be required to register as a Communist-front organization was filed with the Subversive Activities Control Board today by Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General.
How old can a boy be? In the case of Daniel Spalding, he can be and is 58 years old.
TRENTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed into law today two bills that impose stiffer penalties for speeding and reckless driving.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Sept. 30 -- Strathglass Bethesda was selected as best in breed today in the annual outdoor specialty show of the Welsh Terrier Club of America. Bethesda scored in a strong final on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. S. Sloan Colt. Bob Craighead of Cross River, N. Y., judged.

Where will the $2,750,000,000 come from that the Treasury hopes to get from its sale Monday of tax anticipation notes? Non-bank buyers, expected to account for about $1,500,000,000 worth of the notes, will pay with funds on hand, for the most part by check in much the same way that the housewife pays the phone bill.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 30 (UP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati crushed Nick Carter today to win his quarter-final match, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, in the sixty-sixth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships.

The New York State conference of the Daughters of the American Revolution yesterday endorsed Mrs. Frederic A. Groves for president general of the national society. Mrs. Groves, former vice president general from Cape Girardeau, Mo., was a guest of the State Ex-Regents Club at luncheon after the conference closed.
DENVER, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The White House physician said today he had kept news of the President's heart attack a secret at first because of the possible danger to his patient.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A dull tendency pervaded virtually all markets today and industrials drifted slightly lower. Subdued sentiment was ascribed to the Wall Street setback, weakness of the pound sterling against the dollar, and the approaching end of the bookkeeping account.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has extended until Oct. 31 the deadline for filing complaints on its proposed new proxy rules.

MONTREAL, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Pulp and Paper Association today reported that pulp production had reached a record high in August and in the first eight months this year. Exports and domestic consumption showed substantial gains, compared with similar periods last year.
A large inscribed silver platter was presented yesterday to Robert T. Stevens for his "outstanding, patriotic and unselfish service" as Secretary of the Army from Feb. 4, 1953 to July 20, 1955.

The estate of Moritz Neuman sold the five-story store and apartment building on lot 36 by 100 feet at 1297 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Eighty-seventh Street, to Henry Payson, operator, in a deal negotiated by Harold M. Silverman, broker.
Denial of the privilege of the Fifth Amendment was described as subversive and un-American in a lecture at Fordham University yesterday.

Mayor Wagner has officially designated October as the United Hias Service Month in this city. It should be recognized that this is not to be just an idle honor, for during the month of October the important global migration agency is to intensify its drive for support in its urgent work of rescue. NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 30 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today asked the State Public Utility Commission for permission to raise $100,000,000 through stock and debenture issues to expand and improve service.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept 30 -- Army and Penn State will meet for the first time since 1950 at Michie Stadium tomorrow. A crowd of 25,000, including Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker, is expected.
" This was the best birthday present I ever had," said Johnny Podres yesterday after he had pitched the Dodgers to their first world series victory over the Yankees.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Saturday, Oct. 1 -- The United States and Yugoslavia have cleared up their differences and have arrived at a fresh and cordial understanding of each other's policies.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- The American Jewish Congress today telegraphed Mr. Thomas to praise his "decisive action" in granting a commission to Mr. Landy. The congress had provided a Newark attorney, Adrian M. Unger, to represent Mr. Landy at a recent hearing before a Navy board.

The two - story garden - type apartment development at 140th Avenue and 183d Street in Springfield Gardens, L. I., has been sold by Jacob Glass Sons to the Higbie Realty Corporation. The property, occupying an entire square block, contains fifty-six apartments and thirty garages.
Wall Street has found three ways of looking at the sharp stock market break of Monday and the subsequent partial recovery.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 1 -- Retail trade in the Kansas City area held at a steady level with recent weeks and maintained gains generally ranging from 5 to 10 per cent over the same period of 1954. Merchants reported that the showing is better than had been expected in light of the fact that sales were on the upgrade in the 1954 period.

GARRETT (PETE) ROSE, the old guide from Livingston Manor who conducted the first phase of our exploration in the northern reaches of Sullivan County, arrived bright and early for a tour of the fish and game country in the southern and southwestern parts of the county.

THE cool, restful quality of green is familiar to all gardeners, whether or not they have made special provision on their properties for evergreens, ivies, ferns and other hardy plants valued chiefly for their foliage. It is these plants rather than camellias, roses or any other flower that have been chosen for one garden in Kentfield, Calif., across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1 -- A compromise between the national political ambitions of Senator Estes Kefauver and Gov. Frank G. Clement is regarded here as likely to result from the increased attractiveness of the Democratic Presidential and Vice Presidential nominations next year.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Long aluminum tubes containing signaling apparatus are being dropped into the sea in an attempt to measure the velocity and direction of underwater currents.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Kentucky effectively used passes -- its own and Villanova's, too -- en route to a 28-0 football victory tonight.

AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 1 (UP) -Auburn, a powerful squad with a quarterback problem, found the answer on the bench today when Jimmy Cook went in to direct a 13 -- 0 victory over Florida. The triumph stretched the Plainsmen's winning streak to nine games.
Auto drivers who fail to be impressed by traffic courts and traffic court schools will be the subject of a study of the nature and motivation of the traffic scofflaw.
THE standard signals used by defenders, in the play of a bridge hand, are time-honored and (probably) ineradicably established. But that does not necessarily mean they are all good.
A challenge to the basic legality of applying the Federal security risk program to non-sensitive and non-policy-making posts is to be submitted to the United States Supreme Court tomorrow.

The infra-red spectrometer, a sort of private eye for industry, is saying business men millions of dollars a year in man-hours. It is used to identify components of materials and to uncover foreign intruders in them.

AS any reader of newspapers during the past generation knows, the world reaches at least a "crisis" or a "turning point," "new era" or "a remarkable new epoch" almost every Friday morning. Nations are always arriving at "crossroads"; and the free world, like Pearl White, is always barely saved from some dreadful fate.
Paul-Henri, Spaak, Foreign Minister of Belgium, announced here yesterday the election of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany as a European co-chairman of World Brotherhood.
The first day of Succoth, or the Feast of Tabernacles, was observed yesterday in the city's synagogues and temples.

A company that has been producing steel since George Washington"s time showed off a new mill addition last week -- an unusual plant designed to help Supply some of the most exacting steel needs of the atomic age.
GUATEMALA, Oct. 1 -- The police system of President Carlos Castillo Armas' Government has been charged with trying to implant a system of political conformity by silencing public criticism.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 1 -Earl Blaik turned loose a football pack that hit like demons in Michie Stadium today and a highly rated Penn State eleven was crushed, 35 -- 6.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Sea O Erin, even-money favorite with another Hasty House Farm entry, won the $54,700 Charles W. Bidwill Memorial Handicap at Hawthorne today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 (AP) -- A speedy, hard-hitting Harvard football team went on its biggest scoring rampage in years today, opening its eightysecond season with a 60-6 romp over a University of Massachusetts eleven at Harvard Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Five years ago the dispatch and delivery of mail in Iran was a ritual. It had picturesqueness and a leisurely pace that charmed tourists but infuriated business men. In the interval, it has been churned and changed from top to bottom, and everyone is delighted except the romanticists.

Advertising men at every level, from executive down to the mail room, are going to school. All sorts of programs dealing with various aspects of the profession are being offered by colleges and universities in this area, and attendance is reported to be very good, even though, in many cases, there is no degree but merely instruction.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Several top United States military commanders now favor early United States entry into the Baghdad pact. The aim would be to forestall Soviet efforts to penetrate the Middle East.

An early-morning contract settlement yesterday ended a fourhour strike of 16,000 textile workers. The agreement between the Textile Workers Union, C. I. O., and 300 finishing and dyeing plants provides for a 24cent hourly wage increase to be spread over the next three years.
Material about educational projects of the New York Public Library is on exhibition through Oct. 9 in the main lobby of the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

NO less a critic than E. M. Forster (in "Aspects of the Novel") has observed that the more a creative writer wishes to offer the authentic stuff of life, the farther he must fly from the tidy plot -- yet it is fatal to fly too far.
William J. Farson of Philadelphia has been elected executive vice president of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., it was announced tonight.

OPENING a new Humphrey Pakington novel is like noticing that the apples are ripening or a train is on time. There is a sense of living in an orderly, reliable world, not exciting or dangerous but pleasant and secure. It is a world few of us know from experience, but we are familiar with it every time the curtain in a theatre goes up on a chintzy English drawing room.

There will be a new one-design class of keel yachts sailing in next season's racing on Long Island Sound. Fifteen have been ordered from a Norwegian yard, Batservice, for Manhasset Bay owners. There has been interest in other yachting centers and the number may grow.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 1 -George Welsh and Ron Beagle riddled South Carolina's pass defenses today to set up a 26-0 victory for Navy on a field soaked enough for a shakedown cruise.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- The West Germans have adjusted themselves with remarkable speed to official relations with the Soviet Union.

EVERYWHERE at this time of year vegetables, fruits and flowers are maturing almost faster than gardeners can pick them. Out on the Pacific Coast there is under way a harvest that is most essential to gardeners all over the world. This consists of flower seed, which will be sold to gardeners for planting in 1956.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1 (UP) -- The sixteenth National Newspaper Week was opened here today with a declaration that the people's right to know "is not a special privilege of the press but a freedom of the people through the press."
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 -- If the wishes of home owners near the Westchester County Airport in Purchase carry much weight, the field will not become a Flying Boxcar training base.

DALLAS, Oct. 1 -- Department store sales in the Southwest last week continued to run well above the last-year volume. The Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank in its monthly summary of business conditions reported that sales for January through August were 10 per cent above sales in the same period of 1954.
New York is missing a great architectural opportunity in its new public housing, in the view of an experienced professional eye from across the Atlantic.

Henry L. Mencken deserves well of his country and merits the tribute Edgar Kemler pays him in "The Bright Twilight of H. L. Mencken" (Sept. 11). For many years, as Mr. Kemler recalls, Mencken was the most stimulating writer on the journalistic scene.

A FEW years ago in Argentina a doctor was commandeered by Peron's police to treat a university student who had been beaten by them to the point where they feared he might die. From that moment, the doctor was forced into an existence as nightmarish as a work by Kafka.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Plans for a history of the oldest churches of Long Island were announced here this week at the fall meeting of the Long Island Presbytery.

WHAT I found fascinating in studying the reaction of the English press to Giraudoux' "Tiger at the Gates" was the variety of interpretations put upon it. Almost all the reviewers admired it, but to some it was a pacifist play, to others it was a play emphasizing the inevitability of war, to still others it showed how idealistic efforts to prevent war only tend to provoke it.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 1 -Speed and deception triumphed over raw power today as Oklahoma beat Pittsburgh, 26 -- 14, in an intersectional thriller that extended college football's longest current winning streak to twenty-one games.

WAYNE D. OVERHOLSER won the 1953 and 1954 awards of the Western Writers of America for the best Western novels ("Law Man" and "The Violent Land") of those years. Now comes CAST A LONG SHADOW (Macmillan, $2.75), a worthy candidate for the 1955 W. W. A. Golden Spur. It's the story of Matt Keenan, whose father advised him always to line up with the big men, the "leaders."
The Brooklyn Dodgers defeated the New York Yankees at Ebbets Field yesterday, 8 -- 5. That tied the world series at two victories apiece.

The issue of colonialism has burned with ever-growing intensity since the end of World War II. The war itself shook centuries-old colonial structures to their foundations. A HUNDRED years ago bright young men at Oxford and Cambridge debated the still burning question of whether they would have been royalists or parliamentarians in the Great Civil War. Smaller boys played "cavalier" or "roundhead" and the character of Cromwell was a subject of heated debate.

Adams, Morris and Clinton were the team winners yesterday in group cross-country runs conducted by the Public Schools Athletic League at Van Cortlandt Park. The competition opened the local scholastic campaign.

IN "The Natural History of a Yard" Leonard Dubkin has created a prose reflection of Walt Disney's "Nature's Half Acre." If Mr. Dubkin fails to reproduce in print the vivid drama of the film he nevertheless has told an engaging and informative tale.

I SEE by the paper that the Ford Foundation and some other big outfits have contributed a mass of money "to locate the most able youths" and "to make it possible for them to get a college education regardless of their financial needs." More than $21 million has already been raised for this purpose.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Republicans looking toward the 1956 elections took heart today in an upward turn in farm prices. The Agriculture Department reported the trend yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Controller General Joseph Campbell has received a lengthy letter from Charles E. Wilson backing the Air Force's plan to contract for a communications network for an air defense project. The project, Semi-Automatic Ground Environment System, is known as SAGE.

Citations for outstanding performance of duty were awarded yesterday to 195 policemen in general orders signed by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

When trading on the New York Stock Exchange closed for last week-end, The New York Times index of fifty selected stock prices stood at the highest point in history -- 333.3. Before that, market prices had been climbing steadily despite repeated Government moves to tighten credit available for stock purchases.

COLEBROOK, N. H. -- Here, in what may still well be called the northern frontier country -- it is wilder today than fifty years ago and perhaps more beautiful -- is the region of the sporting camp which can be as rough-andready as it sounds, or as comfortable as a good motel.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Put on the right track by a 75-yard touchdown runback of a punt in the second quarter, Colgate's eleven swept to a 21-to-6 triumph over Cornell today.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 -- The death toll caused by Hurricane Janet and attendant floods has reached nearly 250 and is continuing to mount as reports trickle in from stricken areas.

MERION bluegrass is one of the best things that have come along for lawns in recent years. Known first in golfing circles more than twenty years ago, Merion bluegrass since then has been tested widely for home lawns.

Meetings have been held at Carlton House recently to further the sale of tickets for the pre-opening performance of "Janus," a new comedy with Margaret Sullavan, Robert Preston and Claude Dauphin. The event will be held on the night of Nov. 22 at the Plymouth Theatre.

When an employe of a New York City business contributes to the Greater New York Fund he fulfills a personal obligation to contribute to the city in which he earns his living. The fund is New York's most all-inclusive appeal. It provides the one opportunity for business and employe groups to give at one time to 425 local charities.
Trustees of the Ford Foundation met here Friday and yesterday, but they postponed decision on a proposal to sell some of its holdings of Ford Motor Company stock.

Behind the scenes at the United Nations last week the hard job of translating the Geneva spirit into action went forward in preparations for the coming Geneva meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers. During the week, the Big Three Foreign Ministers met, first among themselves, then with Mr. Molotov, later with West German Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano.

CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 1 (UP) -- Don King, with a fine exhibition of passing, led Clemson to a 26-7 triumph over Georgia today. It was the first victory for Clemson over the Bulldogs in 41 years and was marked by fighting among the players and among the crowd of 20,000.
LIKE the roc and unicorn, these beast from Mrs. Kepes' antic brush never lived on land or sea. She invented them for her children and she says:
BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- The five Northeastern states comprising Region 1, Federal Civil Defense Administration, suffered an estimated $387,467,344 damage in floods from Hurricane Diane.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Voters in twelve Fairfield County communities will go to the polls Monday to choose municipal officers for two-year terms.
WACO, Tex., Oct. 1 (AP) -- With Frank Tamburello firing the passes, Maryland scored a 20 -- 6 victory over Baylor tonight.

President Eisenhower's fame is based to some extent upon the crusade that liberated Western Europe ten years ago. But his illness has had an impact upon the world outside the United States that can certainly not be ascribed to his military victories, nor even to his position as head of the most powerful state the earth has known.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Prisoners staged a three-hour rebellion at Deer Island jail in Boston Harbor tonight. They were forced to surrender when soldiers, firemen and the police stormed their cell block using tear gas and high pressure hoses.

THE thirty-seventh camera to bear the Brownie name since George Eastman introduced the dollar camera in 1900 -- and the mot remarkable of the line -- will make its debut in San Francisco tomorrow at the opening of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association biennial Western States convention and trade show.

THE first live television program from Havana is being planned as a Christmas Day presentation by the Columbia Broadcasting System. One or two airplanes, circling between Miami, Fla., and the Cuban city, will be required to relay the signal.

THE second annual Photorama, which last year drew more than 25,000 visitors to Willoughby Camera Stores, 110 West Thirty-second Street, will be held Oct. 10-15. The stores will be converted for the occasion into an exhibition and lecture hall to accommodate exhibits by thirty-five leading manufacturers of photographic equipment and magazine publishers.

IN the recurrent cycles of the art world the mounting interest in and influence of oriental art has been repeatedly noted in the last twenty years. The war, the ensuing occupation of Japan, a new intimacy with phases of oriental culture have emphasized the fact.
President Eisenhower's illness and the publication of former President Truman's memoirs have stimulated interest once again in the constitutional position of the Vice President.

Since President Eisenhower suffered an attack of coronary thrombosis, millions of words in scores of languages have been published concerning his condition. Some statements have been virtual textbooks complete with glossaries on coronary thrombosis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Two salient questions are arising from the widely held assumption that his heart attack has definitely decided President Eisenhower to retire at the end of his first and current term:

When President Woodrow Wilson was stricken in office the medical bulletins intended to inform the world of his illness were noncommittal. It was generally supposed that he had suffered a stroke, but nothing explicit was ever officially given out to deny or confirm the supposition.
Delivery has become difficult in better-priced fall dresses, as resources begin showing resort and holiday lines, resident buying offices reported.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1 -- A bitter battle is being fought in this state between labor and business groups over a proposal to increase unemployment compensation benefits.

OTTO PREMINGER, the director-producer of "The Man With the Golden Arm," took time from production last week to comment on one aspect of his latest effort. His difficulties with the Production Code arose after he acquired from the estate of the late John Garfield, Nelson Algren's prize-winning novel of the addiction of a young Chicago gambler to narcotics.

The twenty-fifth anniversary dinner to mark the founding of Bennington College will be held this Tuesday at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the State University of New York, will address the affair, which will inaugurate Bennington's twenty-fifth anniversary fund.

HARTFORD -- A brand new code of traffic regulations went into effect throughout Connecticut yesterday. The new code, officially known as Public Law 278, was approved at the Legislature's last session and is designed to supplant antiquated traffic regulations and meet the requirements of present-day highway travel.

TO make a neat plastic hose splice using one of the new splice inserts, the hose must be cut evenly so the ends butt together. Try rolling a newspaper into a solid roll, slightly smaller than the inside diameter of the tube, insert and wet it thoroughly with water.
WARSAW, Sept. 18 -- Poland's capital has its first skyscraper, the Russian-built Stalin Palace of Culture and Science.
TRENTON, Oct. 1 -- The State Motor Vehicle Division is in the midst of reorganizing its licensing and registration procedures Most of the changes will become effective next April 1.
Sometimes a pitcher shouldn't think. Johnny Kucks did in the fifth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday and because he did the Yankees fell into a hole from which there was no escape.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Scranton University made a sharp first-half attack which netted two touchdowns and then went on to defeat Temple by 20 -- 6 before 5,000 Homecoming Day fans at Temple Stadium today.

The Institute of International Education at 1 East Sixty-seventh Street announced yesterday that Nov. 1 was the closing date for the competitions for Government educational exchange grants for graduate study abroad. Awards will be made under the Fulbright and Buenos Aires Convention programs for the 1956-57 academic year.
Stowaway trouble is on the increase aboard the Cunard liner Britannic. The ship left here on Sept. 8 with one unlisted passenger -- a cat -- and she returned yesterday with two kittens, as well.

IN addition to speeding German rearmament in Europe, the State Department is also busy in this country these days trying to restore 32,000 German soldiers to home soil. These troops have been mysteriously missing for ten years, but State was recently able to locate 423 of them in Texas.

NEMATODES are often the root of garden troubles, yet few gardeners realize it. When tomatoes wilt, 'mums drop their leaves, gardenias become yellow and roses spindly, there may be nematodes at work. Investigation is important.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -A social scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has undertaken to develop a new national portrait of the United States in a world setting.

Mayor Robert Wagner has created a Committee on Scholastic Achievement, designed to seek out talented youngsters who are unable, for financial reasons, to go to college and make it possible for them to do so with scholarships.
Other major food processors are watching with interest the entry of the H. J. Heinz Company into the field of geriatrics with a new ready-to-serve line called "Senior Foods."
Bird watchers have renewed their objections to Robert Moses' plan to turn the Central Park Ramble into a recreation center for old folks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. (UP) -- Russian housing experts are scheduled to visit Washington Monday on the start of a month-long coast-to-coast tour to see how Americans build homes and apartments.

THIS may well be remembered -by people in the business, anyhow -- as the year of the Great Disposition to Take on Directorial Roles. Already producer Stanley Kramer has put his unaccustomed hand to the direction of "Not As a Stranger" -- and done so quite capably; Dennis O'Keefe, the actor, has megaphoned "Angela" and Jose Ferrer, who has had experience as a stage director, has done his first film directing on "The Shrike."

THE President's illness has sharpened the realization among many business men that political climate might have a lot to do with the state of the national economy. Direct evidence of this was the reaction of the stock market, which fell sharply on the first trading day following the President's heart attack.

The nineteenth annual Pulaski Day parade will be held on Fifth Avenue today with possibly 150,000 men, women and children of Polish descent participating. The keynote will be the determination that Poland shall again be free.

Seventeen steamship and stevedoring companies charged last week that the New York State Insurance Department had allowed them to be overcharged for workmen's compensation insurance on longshoremen from July, 1948, to January, 1950.
Redwood tree farmers in California are practicing more forest conservation because they would soon be out of business if they did not.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -Average weekly wages reached a record $78.67 in the Philadelphia metropolitan area during August. A survey by the Pennsylvania State Employment Service also showed that average weekly hours worked by production employes in this area advanced from 39.8 in July to 40.3 in August.

IN the last mapping of the Sierra Nevada the Federal geodesists ruled out a brace of peaks at its north end: Shasta and Mt. Lassen, the one serviceable volcano on the continent. The geology sharps were pleased, but extreme was the anguish of those devoted to John Muir's "Range of Light."

CHILDREN have always loved flowers. They like to smell them, watch them, pick them, grow them -and -- they even like to paint them. This was certainly proved in a recent contest that was held at Gardener's Village in West Hempstead, L. I.
ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UP) -George Volkert and Toppy Vann led Georgia Tech to a 20 to 7 victory over Southern Methodist before 34,000 fans today.

EVERY now and then an awed sports columnist reminds us that Babe Ruth swung baseball's mightiest bat. Fashions in hero worship don't change much. Substitute a mighty word for the mighty bat, spin the clock back 900 years to the Middle Ages, and you have pretty much the Algeresque success story unfolded in Leslie Turner White's new historical novel about the First Crusade, "The Winged Sword."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Last in the backstretch, Mrs. J. R. H. Thouron's Happy New Year rallied to triumph at 41 to 1 in the $31,375 Absecon Island Stakes at the Atlantic City race course today. A crowd of 17,773 watched the race.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Leon F. Swears of Johnstown resigned, effective today, as a member of the State Athletic Commission, according to a report from Gov. Harriman's office.

HOLLYWOOD. IN the second act of "Hamlet," Hamlet says to Polonius, "Good, my lord, will you see the players well bestowed? Do you near, let them be well used, for they are the abstract and brief chronicles of the time: after your death you were better have a bad epitaph than their ill report while you live."
Right you are in your editorial assertion of Sept. 21 that "Peron's greatest crime, among his many crimes, was to destroy justice."
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- Without much publicity, India has managed to put aside some of her carefully counted supply of rupees to help a few of her neighbors.

THOSE who think of Manuel de Falla solely as a purveyor of Spanish nationalism of the castanetflamenco - heel - and - toe species know only one side of his work. It is true that scores -- and great scores they are -- like "El Amor Brujo" and "El Sombrero de Tres Picos" are almost direct translations of the Spanish folk idiom, glorified by an impressionistic technique and a rare ability to orchestrate.
An apparent outbreak of gang warfare in East Harlem last night brought death to one teenager and wounds to two others.

THIS is a tale of war, treachery and heroic sacrifices. It depicts England when the Wars of the Roses kept the nobles fighting constantly among themselves for the estates of owners who were losing favor at court.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk, who developed the polio vaccine that bears his name, said today he planned to test a number of polio vaccine preparations that appeared from laboratory tests to be somewhat more potent than those he worked with heretofore.
Tax information for employes covered by pension plans is being furnished by a growing number of companies -- and it is much needed.
The announcement of the "wasp-waist" fashion for planes, and what it does, apparently has provoked less comment than the latest Paris styles.

THE increasing, importance of national conservation policies as a political issue could hardly be more dramatically illustrated than by recent and conflicting statements on this subject by two prominent public officials: Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay and Senator Richard L. Neuberger of Oregon.
LAST night Audrey Meadows began her fourth year in the television role of Alice Kramden, the harried wife of Ralph Kramden, the bus driver, played by Jackie Gleason in "The Honeymooners."

CHORES FOR THE WEEK: Plant bulbs for spring bloom. Daffodils should be placed so that six to eight inches of soil covers their tips and also forms the distance between bulbs. Hyacinths go five inches deep and six inches apart. Six inches is sufficient between tulips, but the deeper they are planted the better the bloom -- ten inches is not too much.
Three members of the Dodger ensemble were cited for the garland wreaths after Brooklyn's second triumph yesterday.
A nine-day celebration of the forty-fourth anniversary of the Republic of China will begin in New York's Chinatown tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 -- The provisional Government abolished today the decree and law that had kept Argentina in a "state of internal war" for four years.
FOR the writer of comedy there is one fundamental maxim: What fools we mortals be! In "A Day by the Sea," sensitively acted at the ANTA Theatre, that is the topic that N. C. Hunter pursues.

MADRID, Oct. 1 -- The economic barometers in most countries of Western Europe are again set for "inflation." The efforts made late in 1954 and early in 1955, which stabilized the boom, were not effective enough.
A committee of the Child Education Foundation has selected the Dec. 1 performance of "No Time For Sergeants" as its annual theatre benefit. The comedy opens on Oct. 20 at the Alvin Theatre.

SOON the lawn, garden sidewalks and driveways will be cluttered with leaves. Although the temptation is to rake and burn them gardeners should pocket their matches. For of all the soil components that are needed, humus is first on the list, and no better inexpensive source can be found than well-made compost.

FAY CROMWELL, daughter of divorced parents, has spent most of her seventeen years drifting through Europe with her pretty, extravagant, much-loved mother. When the latter loses most of her money and her health, Fay goes reluctantly to Cape Cod to spend a summer with her grandparents.

A book bound in filigree gold and jewels, with a case of tortoiseshell and gold, will be among other "objects de virtu" to be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Marcel Marceau, a slim; intense man with an extraordinarily fluid body and features of astonishing mobility, is, in all likelihood, the greatest mime in the world today. He is the practitioner of an art requiring the highest discipline and the most rigorous physical control, outwardly; inwardly, his perception must be of the most exquisite.

Many readers of articles on football and those who follow games on radio and television may not understand, or sometimes may be confused by references to the various formations employed by attacking (the ball-carrying) teams.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept, 28 -- Means must be found to draw more closely together the people and territories of the Central African Federation if the two-year-old federation is to succeed.
The development of synthetic adrenal hormones to perform powerful therapeutic actions in the body without undesirable side effects was forecast here yesterday.

The National Defense Transportation Association will open its tenth annual convention in Boston's Sheraton Plaza Hotel on Oct. 11. The organization will again provide a forum for the problems of all forms of American transportation -- sea, air, rail, truck and inland waterway.
NEWARK, Oct. 1 -- Democratic Gov. Robert B. Meyner tonight accused the Republicancontrolled Legislature of seeking to "sabotage" major investigations involving official corruption.

CRESCO, Pa. -- Hard hit by the astounding flood of Aug. 18, the Pocono resort area has done a notable job of rehabilitation in order to be ready for the fall foliage display, which will be at its best between now and Oct. 14.

DESPITE the recent overwhelming emphasis on the baroque and ornamental in interior design and decoration there are still those who hold out for the simple, severe modern approach. Among these is Alvin Lustig, whose design accomplishments include books, magazines, posters and street signs, as well as a small helicopter and a large apartment house.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 1 -- The three-week-old strike of the United Fruit Company's banana workers ended this morning. Strike delegates signed a three-year wage contract with the United Fruit Company's general manager here, Walter Hamer, and Labor Minister Otto Fallas of Costa Rica.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, working most of the day on a normal day off, got his first briefing on the state of the world and the nation from a White House aide.

THEFTS at the scene of car accidents, particularly in cities, have grown into a thriving enterprise for sneak thieves. Offenders range from urchins who pilfer trinkets shaken out of wrecked vehicles to prowlers who pick up bill folds dropped from pockets of the accident dead. The loot is estimated at many thousands of dollars annually.
St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases last week announced plans for a $7,000,000 expansion project.

If seafaring colleagues were a bit surprised to learn last week that Capt. Harold Milde had retired as master of the liner America, there was not one arched eyebrow when they heard where the veteran skipper would take his ease.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 (UP) -- The sparkling play of Quarterback Gene Newton and Fullback Ronny Quillian gave Tulane an impressive 21-0 victory over Northwestern today before 20,000 rain-soaked fans.

I am astounded that so perceptive a political scientist as Stephen K. Bailey should suggest that the President be relieved of his status and duties as Chief of State and that these be transferred to a new office created by constitutional amendment.

QUEBEC, Sept. 30 -- At a federal - provincial conference opening in Ottawa Monday the Government of this FrenchCanadian province will press a long-standing claim against the Federal Government of Canada.
Outstanding students can do excellent college work at the age of 16 with only two years of high school preparation, a four-year experiment at Lafayette College has shown.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1. (UP) -- California ripped down Pennsylvania's defenses today with three scores in the last period for a 27 to 7 victory.

WILLIAMSTON, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Our higher educational system suffer from too few outstanding teachers and not from too many students. Dr. Nathan M Pusey, president of Harvard University, asserted here today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs today sold six players, including Pitcher Harry Perkowski and Outfielder Lloyd Merriman, to their Los Angeles farm in the Pacific Coast League.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins scored four touchdowns -- three in 2 minutes and 17 seconds in a fantastic third period -- to upset the Philadelphia Eagles tonight, 31 -- 30. The bitterly fought National Football League game at Connie Mack Stadium was seen by 31,891 fans.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The order withdrawing the French delegation from the United Nations General Assembly today was based on the contention that the organization had no right to discuss North African problems, which France alone must solve.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Soviet and Czech deals to supply arms to Egypt threaten to upset the balance of power in the Middle East and inject EastWest issues into the Arab-Israeli conflict.
With its founding school -- St. John's College -- and its Graduate College of Arts and Sciences moving from Brooklyn to Jamaica, Queens, St. John's University will begin today its eighty-sixth year.
There still was a strange lack of exuberance in the Dodger clubhouse yesterday after the series had been evened. The boys were happy, but not hilarious.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 -- Robert D. Murphy, United States Deputy Under Secretary of State, revealed today that Yugoslavia shortly would participate in the United States program for the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

JAKARTA, Oct. 1 -- The Indonesian Communist party faces this week its most critical period since a week in September seven years ago. At that time the party took a desperate gamble on the battlefield and did not win. Now the Communists hope to recoup at the polling booth what they lost on that battlefield.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- When the stock market took its heavy shudder on Monday, economists and plain citizens all began asking themselves the same question: Is the current prosperity just a mirage based mainly on psychology and "confidence" in the Eisenhower Administration?
HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 1 -Holy Cross beat Dartmouth at its own aerial game today, 29 -- 21, but had to keep fighting to the finish as the Indians scored three touchdowns in the final period.
PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The Sultan of Morocco, Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, left his throne today. But his flight has not ended the political crisis in the French protectorate.

PROBABLY only John Gunther could successfully assimilate in one book the whole Continent of Africa. The size of the job would frighten anyone with less intellectual vigor. Yet Mr. Gunther, with his astonishing energy, his ability to amass and then tidily sort out extraneous facts, has accomplished the gigantic task he set for himself -- and done so brilliantly. "Inside Africa" is informative, well written and a first-class piece of journalism.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Cornell University announced today it would seek funds above current gift levels to reinforce its teaching efforts.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- In spite of the economic changes that have resulted in the breaking up of large estates, the social functions of this colony have been maintained. There also is evidence that a renewed interest in sports activities here may receive national recognition.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Yale traveled uphill all through its game with Brown today. The task of overtaking the visitors looked too great for the Elis until the final period. Then, in that last quarter, the Elis struck for three touchdowns and pulled out the victory by the score of 27 to 20.
Says Bones LaBoyne, who books the mounts for Eddie Arcaro, "When the money's there, Eddie's there."

October is the year at rich maturity, a happy woman arrayed in festival dress and ready for a dance with a giant come down from the hills attired in a red, red shirt, buckskin pants and moccasins beaded with frost. October is a brisk wind in the treetops, a whisper among crisp leaves, a breath of apple cider, a gleam from a jack o' lantern, and the echo of laughter under a harvest moon.

IT appears that H. Allen Smith has written that long-awaited definitive treatise on the human tail. The word "definitive" in this case is no joke, for when Mr. Smith finally has done with his subject, the most captious student of socio-coccygeal phenomena would be hard put to detect a phase which Mr. Smith has left unexplored.

ON Sept. 2, while nationalism in the rest of North Africa was netting little but bitterness and bloodshed, the tiny protectorate of Tunisia quietly received the grant of internal autonomy from a very docile France.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 1 -Don Fairfield and Max Evans shared the lead today at the end of fifty-four holes of the Long Island Rotary open golf tournament.
Arthur M. Hayes has been named deputy head of the tax department of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 27 -- The United States flag is kept flying here over the legation building by eleven Americans, smallest State Department mission behind the Iron Curtain.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Oct. 1 -- Japanese newspapers publishers and editors, meeting here today, reaffirmed their determination to hold on to press freedoms gained since World War II.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -California's devastating series of forest fires lasted for eighteen "critical" days before light rains reduced the threat on Sept. 13.

THE genoise is a classic cake in French baking, delicate, tender and yellow with many eggs. Air beaten into the eggs leavens it. Beating by hand used to take forty minutes. Now an electric mixer does the beating, as indicated in the recipe appearing here.

Department store sales throughout the country in the week ended Sept. 24 were 3 per cent higher than in the corresponding week last year. It was the twenty-second consecutive weekly gain in sales volume reported by the Federal Reserve Board.

CRIMINAL law has always fascinated its practitioners as well as the public. Criminal lawyers don't earn the juicy fees of corporate barristers, but their work is more exciting. They also get the newspaper notices and are pointed out in night clubs.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1 -Figures showing that 134,000 Negro children are enrolled in desegregated schools in eight former segregation states and the District of Columbia were released today by the Southern Education Reporting Service.
TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- What has been described as the "worst" typhoon of the season was just another storm tonight.

LIFE will be simpler in the future for both guests and room clerks at the Belmont Plaza Hotel, Lexington Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, with the establishment of a new one-price policy.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 1 -The surprising Stanford Indians rolled to a touchdown the first time they got the ball today, then hung on to upset Ohio State, 6 -- 0, in a nationally televised intersectional football game.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 1 -- A drive to raise $10,000,000 to endow the Cordell Hull Foundation for International Education was started here this week.
DENVER, Oct. 1 -- For five days last week the Denver White House was located in the vest pocket of James C. Hagerty.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Red China reaffirmed today its intention to "liberate" Nationalist Formosa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -United States officials were confident today that France would not withdraw permanently from the United Nations.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested seven men on charges of procuring fraudulent home improvement loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 6 -- What is it like for a young American housewife from a big city to live in Indonesia on the other side of the world?

Theodore E. Schumann, chief examiner of the New York County Clerk's Office, Division of Jurors, closed his desk Friday afternoon after having examined 500,000 prospective jurors in 44 years of service.
COMPETITION is getting rough in the flying saucer business. Once a man could make an effect merely by seeing saucers. Then the saucers began to land. Now George Adamski has actually ridden in them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The race for the White House has started with irreverent haste, and the spectators are advised to hold on to their hats.
THE sculptor Jacques Lipchitz has for so many recent years been preoccupied with ultra-expressive form that a reminder of the cool and agile cubist painting of his past comes almost as a surprise.

C. G. Johnson, T. R. E. Southwood and H. Entwistle of the Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, England, have given up nets and adopted vacuum cleaners to catch insects. They tell about the change in Nature Magazine. An electric blower that scooped up insects in vacuum cleaner fashion from measured areas of grass took about 90% of the insects.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 1 -- Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa, Sultan of Morocco, quit his throne at 7 A. M. today after a reign of two years and forty-one days. The Sultan, who arrived later in Tangier, refused, however, to renounce his rights to the throne.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (UP) -Herb Score of the Cleveland Indians and Bill Virdon of the St. Louis Cardinals were chosen rookies of the year in the American and National Leagues, the Sporting News reported today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 24 -Henry Spencer Holt, an Oregon farmer who has dedicated his life to aiding Korean foundlings, will leave Korea Oct. 4. He will take with him eight children he has adopted and four others for new parents in rural areas of the United States.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1 -Several new automobile driving laws, extending the field of violations, became effective -- in Connecticut today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Supreme Court will reconvene Monday after a recess that began on June 6.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1 (AP) -Wisconsin routed Iowa, 37 -- 14, with surprising ease today and served notice that it is a power to be reckoned with in the Big Ten football race. Dave Howard speared three touchdown passes of 43, 16 and 33 yards to show the way.

Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, indicated last night that France might reconsider a planned Moscow visit by himself and the Premier, Edgar Faure, in reprisal for the Soviet vote in Friday's United Nations debate on Algeria.

The perennial emergence of the farm problem in an election year points up the conspicuous failure of both political parties to deal with an acute situation, loaded with potential danger to the whole economy.
The biggest individual creditor of the Russian Government is Carl Marks. Repeat, Carl Mark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A United States plan for developing East-West contacts is being shaped by William H. Jackson, special assistant to Secretary of State Dulles.

CHARLES ABRAMS, New York State Rent Administrator, ought to know something about housing, public and otherwise, for he has been up to his ears in it, officially and otherwise, for a long time. In this volume he traces the background of discrimination in housing and the reasons for it.
Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., which has helped emotionally disturbed youngsters for 100 years, will gain by two theatre benefits this fall.

I have just read in The Times a report of a recent foreign policy address in the United Nations by the Iraqi delegate before the General Assembly. Among the topics he touched upon was a proposal to set up an international university to educate young people for world leadership.

FRANCIS POULENC has just completed an opera, "Les dialogues des Carmelites," which will have its first performance at La Scala, Milan, in December, 1956, or January, 1957. The role of the heroine, Blanche de la Force, will be sung by the soprano Denise Duval.

" Didn't you hear them shout way back in New York?" said Maxine Karr, tap-dancer. "They said a U. S. O. - Camp Shows notice had been posted. But they didn't believe we'd make it until they saw us walking through the gate.

WITH all the reminders to plant bulbs now gardeners might forget that shrubs fit into this fall planting scheme too. Those planted now will have a good chance to become established before freezing weather.
More and more Americans are turning to French wines from the Italian import, according to a report over the week-end.

IN the passing of Carl Friedberg the musical world suffers a grievous loss. He was one of the last great names and personalities belonging to the romantic musical life of Europe before the two world wars. In his playing he combined a deep understanding of the classics with an innate sense of poetry and an unforgettable beauty of tone.
Barnard College has received a grant from the National Science Foundation and the National Academy of Arts and Sciences to support research on Panamanian marine fungi.

IN "Hogarth's Progress" Peter Quennell gives us not merely the history of a man but the portrait of a city and the character of a period. London of the mid-eighteenth century is the true protagonist of Mr. Quennell's informed and engrossing study: London seen through the eyes of an artist who was a born reporter, whose "vast picture of the age he lived in is both a record and a recreation * * *."

The late summer onion crop about balances expected consumption. But whether the average wholesale price of onions remains at $3 to $4 a hundred pounds depends on the accuracy of the Department of Agriculture's estimate of damage to the Orange County, N. Y., crop.

More than a million and a half tons of odorous, eye-smarting sulphur dioxide gas -- from which 2.2 million tons of corrosive sulphuric acid may be formed -- are poured into New York City's atmosphere each year, says Dr. Morris B. Jacobs, a chemist who is director of the laboratory of the New York Department of Air Pollution Control, and Dr. Leonard Greenberg, a physician who is New York's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.
Many prominent persons are patrons for Marian Anderson's concert appearance at Carnegie Hall the night of Nov. 4 for the benefit of the Morningside Community Center in Harlem.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1 (UP) -- A 158-pound halfback, Bunny Blaney, injected fire into a sluggish Duke offense today with an 80-yard touchdown burst and the Blue Devils rolled on to a 21 -- 0 victory over Tennessee.
The Port's handling of bulk cargo imports was threatened yesterday by a strike of professional weighers and scalemen affiliated with the International Longshoremen's Association.

WHEN, on a mild day recently, the millionth "People's Car," especially gold-plated for the occasion, rolled off the gigantic assembly line of the Volkswagen factory here, thus breaking all production records in the history of the European automobile industry, a hundred thousand people went out to fill the new Wolfsburg stadium.
Gerald Frankel has been named a vice president of Julius Kayser Co., manufacturer of women's accessories.

Fans who get to the ball park an hour or so before game time have the most fun. For in addition to the batting and fielding practice that brings out all the players on both squads, lots of entertainment is provided by the "characters" in the stands.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -The Army's new six-months military training program begins Monday and only 1,038 volunteers have signed up so far.

CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- George V. Allen, the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Middle Eastern affairs, discussed the Egyptian arms situation today with Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser. They talked for two hours after Colonel Nasser had kept Mr. Allen waiting an hour and a half.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Western Connecticut, which only a few weeks ago suffered heavy flood damages proudly hoisted its agricultural colors here today with the opening of the Danbury Fair.
CAIRO, Sept. 22 -- The United States Navy is arranging with Egypt for joint study of the treatment of bilharzia, a parasitic worm infection that afflicts 200,000,000 persons around the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The departure today of a three-man mission to eight LatinAmerican countries opens a new era of cooperation between the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration and the Organization of American States.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Michigan's Wolverines were outplayed in the first half, but defeated Michigan State, 14 -- 7, today in a Big Ten football game.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1 -A lock described as the highest single lift lock in the world is being designed for Wilson Dam in north Alabama, the Tennessee Valley Authority reports.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The greatest production capacity the auto industry ever has known may get a workout during the 1956 model year.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 1 (UP) -- West Virginia smothered Wake Forest, 46 -- 0, today to pin the worst defeat in a decade on the previously unbeaten Deacons.

Study in this country has become in recent years the educational goal of students all over the world. This year, a record 35,000 men and women from virtually every foreign land with the exception of the Iron Curtain countries, will attend American colleges and universities.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 1 -The Government granted amnesty today to seven former army officers and the former editor of The Pakistan Times. They were convicted in 1952 of "plotting to overthrow the Government by violent means in collaboration with a foreign power."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Government announced today that the poliomyelitis rate among children aged 5 to 9 inoculated with the Salk vaccine was 25 to 50 per cent lower than among those not vaccinated.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- France today abandoned, at least temporarily, participation in the major affairs of the United Nations.

Could it be that Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson is too sensitive about Democratic charges that the Republicans have not kept their promises to the farmers? Let Mr. Benson remember that the 1952 Republican party platform said: "We favor a farm program aimed at full parity" and pledged that "The Republican party will create conditions providing for farm prosperity and stability."

AMAN who ought to know -- Harry S. Truman -- said some years ago: "No one man can really fill the Presidency. [It] is an executive job that is almost fantastic. No absolute monarch has ever had such decisions to make or the responsibilities that the President of the United States has."
