A Naval Reserve pilot was killed yesterday afternoon when his jet fighter plane crashed into Jamaica Bay. He was on a training flight from Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station in Brooklyn.
DENVER, Sunday, Oct. 2 -President Eisenhower passed the halfway point yesterday in the critical two-week period that follows every attack of coronary thrombosis.

TWO tools provide the craftsman with a quick, sure method of retirieving small parts that may have dropped and lodged out of reach. The tools have long, slender handles with Alnico magnets at the end to pick up iron or steel parts.
With the coming of October, the local art season quickens its pace in both the number and variety of new attractions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -Democrats and Republicans met for a return match in the "numbers game" this week, and after it was over the Republicans, in the opinion of most observers, were trailing rather badly.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- Installment sales in Fourth District department stores have shown year-to-year gains of 25 per cent or more in every month so far this year. This is partly a result of the generally low level of sales which prevailed during much of 1954.

ONE of best known the names in the aviation industry, Jack Frye, is off on a difficult new venture. He is building an airliner to fill a role designers have I been trying, unsuccessfully, to fill for years -- the role of DC-3 replacement.

Albert Morehead's excursion into the lacks of the English language was amusing and apt -- "English at a Loss for Words" (Sept 11) -- but his excursion into German for a word meaning brother or sister or both falls short.

THIS is a light treatise on the political genealogy of the United States, mainly designed to establish Adlai E. Stevenson as the fourth intellectual leader (incidentally all four of them Democrats) whom the nation needed in time of crisis to furnish the constructive ideas on which the future depends.

ROCKPORT, Mass. -- What this country needs perhaps more than a good five-cent cigar is an eloquent advocate of the autumn vacation. The industrial revolution of recent years that has spread the blessing of holidays to more and more workers and white-collar employes may have become that advocate.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 1 -A new type of man-of-war, designed to control the seas in the atomic age, was commissioned here this afternoon.

DISCLOSURES made privately here last week, but yet to be announced to the philatelic world, indicate that no worldwide stamp show held anywhere in the past has surpassed in surprises, brilliance and color, and in display of classic postal rarities, the FIPEX show (Fifth International Philatelic Exhibition) to be held next April 28-May 6 in the New York Coliseum when that building opens at Columbus Circle.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1 -Informed Lebanese show uneasy awareness that the Soviet Union's willingness to arm the Arab states might deliver the Middle East into the hands of the Communists.

STARTING tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc. will be busy with their fifth annual fall conference at the Wildmere House, Lake Minnewaska, N. Y. District directors an the executive committee will meet Monday evening.

Buyers for the nation's department and specialty stores will begin this week to replenish the stock of their most important type of women's apparel -- sportswear -- in anticipation of record sales of casual clothes to an increasingly leisureminded public.

ALTHOUGH it may appear to outsiders as the sere, the yellow leaf, tottering middle age is having a dandy time at the theatre these days. Not only did it know Broadway when The Theatre was The Theatre -the Twenties, Thirties, back there -- but lately it has visited again, this time in tranquillity and in the pages of memoirs.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 1 -- Paraguay made it clear today that she would not recognize the new Argentine Government until the ousted President, Juan D. Peron, was allowed to go into exile.
Twenty years ago today the Hayden Planetarium opened its doors, and with them, the portals of its man-made sky.
BALAKIREFF: Isiamey; LISZT: Hungarian Rhapsody No. 12; Julius Katchen, pianist (London, 10-inch). Neat and accomplished playing that lacks the necessary bravura to milk the music for all it is worth.

DESPITE its title, Claire Reis' book is in effect an autobiographical account of her forceful role in modern music, as we have known it in the last four decades. The author relates briefly the musical and educational background which spurred her interest in the contemporary scene and fitted her to assume many administrative positions.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -The first twenty-two-inch, allclass, rectangular color television tube was produced here last week by the Westinghouse electronic tube division. It provides a viewing area of 265 square inches.
Another salvo in the city's continuing heliport dispute was fired yesterday by the Department of Marine and Aviation.

TO the average young couple the prospect of buying that first oil painting to go over that first mantelpiece is a bewildering business. How does one go about it? Which gallery? Which artist? Is one's taste sure enough to risk several hundred dollars? How much do paintings cost, anyway?

MILLBROOK, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The marriage of Miss Mary Ann Evangelista, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Evangelista, to Thomas J. Doyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Doyle of New York, took place here this morning.

The two-article feature, "Israel and Egypt: Myths and Realities" (Sept. 18), was an excellent idea. Both correspondents -- Harry Gilroy and Kennett Love, swapping assignments in Israel and Egypt, respectively -- vividly described the social as well as political currents in each of the two nations they were covering for the first time.
The Italian Line has scheduled 107 trans-Atlantic voyages for 1956.

PARENTS who enjoy dipping into books on child care and development will find much to think about and much to entertain them in this one. They'll also find some down-to-earth but, in spots, highly controversial advice on a variety of behavior problems.

MRS. FOWLER wrote "The Intruder" (published a few seasons ago with considerable success). Bernard Harris is a short-story writer. In collaboration they have produced "The Careless People," an original exploitation of the eternal triangle theme.

The deep shock that was felt throughout the world over President Eisenhower's sudden illness was a tribute to an individual whose personality, character and achievements have earned him the affection and admiration of countless millions.

COUNT BASIE has reached such a lofty position of eminence and influence in the jazz world that the release of almost every LP by his band is accompanied by at least one by some other group playing, quite avowedly and with attribution, in the Basle manner.

IN a cartoon in a recent issue of The Saturday Review, two youngish business men, briefcases in hand, are seen leaving an office-building elevator with a typical five o'clock crowd. "I must be getting old," one comments wistfully to the other.
BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S newest opera, The Turn of the screw, is now available on an English-made recording conducted by the composer (London, two disks).

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 1 -Best in show in the seventeenth annual all-breed fixture of the Suffolk County Kennel Club today went to a Scottish terrier, Ch. Rebel Invader. The competition was held on the grounds of the Huntington-Crescent Club.

For the clumsy "he or she" (and the attendant "his or her"), deplored by Mr. Morehead, I see no reason for not adopting the century-old word "thon," designed for precisely this purpose. (See full account in Funk and Wagnalls' "New Standard Dictionary.")

THE split in the film and processing charges of Kodachrome color film, which Eastman Kodak Company agreed to under the terms of the Federal court decree of December, 1954, went into effect last week, according to an announcement by the company.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 1 -- The Edward S. Harkness Memorial Hall, named for one of Yale University's greatest benefactors, will be formally opened at ceremonies here on Friday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- France's walkout from the United Nations is the second instance of a boycott by a major power of the world organization in protest against a majority decision. It marked the first time, however, that a nation had formally recalled its delegation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- In spite of all protestations about a "team operation," the question inevitably is going to rise during the next several weeks of President Eisenhower's illness of just who is running the Government of the United States.

The press conference in which newspaper men plied Dr. Paul Dudley White with questions on the President's condition and prospects revealed a yawning gap in medical knowledge. Though he answered his questioners frankly and simply, Dr. White had to reply only too often: "We don't know."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- High United States authorities believe that the Soviet Union now is prepared to accept President Eisenhower's proposals for control of armaments through aerial reconnaissance and an exchange of military blueprints.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct, 1 -- Columbia led Princeton for thirty-five minutes at Palmer Stadium today, then fell victim to the Tigers' crushing single-wing attack. With Sidney Pinch supplying the decisive touch down on a brilliant dash of 80 yards at 6:27 of the third quarter, the final score in this twenty-fifth meeting between these Ivy League rivals was 20 -- 7.

After all the recent hullaballoo about "runaway plants," "unfair regional competition" and "economic civil war," mostly aimed at the South, recent comments on the subject by a leading Southern industrialist deserve wide attention and applause.

Spain's role in the discovery of the New World will be discussed by the Most Rev. Fulton J. Sheen, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiacese of New York, at the Discovery Day dinner to be held on Columbus Day in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
More and more Europeans are cooking with gas these days, They are, that is, when they can get it.

HAVANA -- Speed-happy automobile drivers of Cuba, whose daring imprudence has long caused many an American visitor to wonder if he would ever again see his homeland, have been slowed down somewhat by the new Traffic Code. It would be highly inaccurate, however, to state that the traffic situation on this island has undergone a major change.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- An expenditure of $295,892,945 in the next twenty-five years to improve Chicago's water supply system has been proposed by an engineering concern after a detailed survey.

MEREDITH WILLSON is a brave and venturesome man indeed. He started out in life by deciding to play the piccolo. Now he has written a book titled "Eggs I Have Laid." By so doing he runs the risk of laying another one.
SOCORRO, N. M., Oct. 1 (UP) -- Sixteen members of the Lionel Hampton band and their driver were injured today when a chartered bus plunged into a ditch twenty-six miles south of here.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- From early morning until dusk today 10,000 persons milled along the sidewalks of this town's two central streets to see New Canaan's first outdoor art show.

AN $8,000,000 project, the Deutsche Staatsoper, has been rebuilt on its traditional location along Unter den Linden, in East Berlin. It has been reconstructed in accordance with the original plans of Knobelsdorff, who erected the house 200 years ago for Frederick the Great.
RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Bill Steinkraus, captain of the United States equestrian team, won the green jumper class with the Fairview Farm's Compass Rose at the Westchester Country Club horse show today.
The Department of Health will begin an intensive search tomorrow for 10,000 New Yorkers who are not aware that they have tuberculosis.

A FEW words first about the region in which I have spent the past two weeks -- the north woods of Maine. Although it ranks high among my favorite corners of the U. S. A., I first came to it in 1940, when I passed a few memorable days fishing Kennebago Lake and Kennebago Stream, a scant ten miles from where I write.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 28 -Britain has found a way of conserving many millions of its precious dollar holdings through an ingenious arrangement to pay for some of its imports of United States machinery, particularly electrical machinery, in Swedish crowns exchanged for pounds sterling.

WRITTEN with sympathetic insight, authority, and the touch of a man who has something to say on a abject he is sure he understands, David Mark's first novel pictures a horse player bound for all-out disaster.

The long advance in stock prices was interrupted last Monday by the worst break since 1929. But a sharp rally in the next two days erased a large part of the losses. However, they eased in the final sessions of the week.

The television commercial is a happy little thing of dancing elves, marching cigarettes, products that talk and sing and, speaking generally, sweetness and light.

The withdrawal of the French delegation from the current session of the United Nations General Assembly serves to dramatize the French protest against the ill-advised action of putting the Algerian problem on the agenda for debate. It cannot mean, of course, that France is leaving the United Nations.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- Signs of skullduggery appeared this week in connection with efforts to alleviate air pollution, the cause of smog here.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. l -Notre Dame, led by Paul Hornung and Don Schaefer, today beat Indiana, 19 -- 0. The victory was the tenth straight for the Irish under Coach Terry Brennan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the award of sixty-nine nonsecret physical research contracts totaling $3,875,344.

The second day of Succoth or the Feast of Tabernacles, was observed yesterday in synagogues.

A revised four-page outline for presentation of media information to advertisers and advertising agencies has been prepared by the National Industrial Advertisers Association. The revised Publisher's Sales Presentation Outline has been distributed to United States and Canadian business and trade publishers.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- France will continue to boycott the United Nations General Assembly but not the Security Council and probably not the Disarmament Subcommittee.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) -- John Gallucci, 70 years old, whose hobby is rummage sales disclosed today that an etching he had bought a year ago for 35 cents was a Rembrandt.
Crisp, sunny weather, cloudness skies and colorful autumn foliage failed to lure enough motorists onto the highways yesterday to cause traffic officials heavy headaches.
Officially, Sixth Avenue became the Avenue of the Americas ten years ago yesterday. Unofficially, the Avenue of the Americas is still Sixth Avenue.

Thadeusz Zygfryd Kassern, mer Polish Consul here, was home yesterday, having been discharged Saturday night from bellevue Hospital. He had taken overdose of sleeping pills last Thursday, a few days after receiving word from the Immigration and Naturalization Service at his long-pending citizenship appeal had been rejected.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 2 -- The Presidential election tomorrow promises to be a test of the voters' will to abide by Constitutional government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, envisaged today the reunification of Germany through creation of a "true security system."

AFTER an absence of seven years, the Spanish dancer Antonio opened with his company at the Broadway Theatre for a three-week run. He proved that lightning can strike twice in the same place. He is the second Spanish dancer within three days (Carmen Amaya was the first) to return after an extended period and reveal a completely revitalized approach to the art.
A great many proud people marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. The marchers -- Poles and men, women and children of Polish origin -- made it clear that they wanted Poland to be free again.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A tropical storm, believed to be an off-shoot of Hurricane Janet swept into the Gulf of Lower California today.
High up in the ranking of favorite American daydreams -- and possibly first among daydreams that do not concern the opposite sex -- is the little business of one's own.

The splendid and arrogant chancellor who became an archbishop, a martyr and a saint is the hero of still another book, "My Life for My Sheep,"* a historical novel by Alfred Duggan.

Whatever other aims the Soviets may pursue with their "new look" diplomacy of smiles, one aim is certain. That aim is to lull the free world into relaxing not only its vigilance and its defenses but also its unity, forged by the previous Stalin policy of force.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The Conservative party will gather at Bournemouth this week for what should be a victory conference with many of its members in a querulous and restive state.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Hal Wallis is seeking to convince Eva Marie Saint, last year's Academy Award winner as best supporting actress, that she should make her next three motion pictures for him. The producer has offered to the actress Tennessee Williams' "Summer and Smoke," "The Rainmaker," a familiar property to Miss Saint, who has been playing in it on tour this summer and "Night Man."

Five or six heaps of numismatic manna dropped to earth between 8 and 8:30 o'clock last night, on Forty-fifth Street just west of Broadway. A scrambling throng that quickly grew to 1,000 persons greeted the munificent shower with upraised arms.
Worshipers at a campus service at Columbia University were cautioned yesterday to avoid "the great lie" -- that there are no major convictions on which they should "stake their very lives."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A dead battery and three little kittens prevented Vice President Richard M. Nixon from using his new automobile today.

A new advertising agency that will handle eight products of the Toni Company will be formed on Dec. 1 by Don Paul Nathanson and Cyrus H. Nathan. Known as North Advertising, Inc., it will have headquarters at 430 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago, and offices at 6 East Forty-fifth Street, New York City, and 9533 Brighton Way, Beverly Hills, Calif.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The London Stock Exchange, having anticipated last Mondays collapse of Wall Street on the news of President Eisenhower's illness, stood up reasonably well when that slump actually developed.

Americans were Called upon yesterday to use their voting power to end racism and lynching in the United States. The appeal was made before 3,000 persons at a Harlem rally to protest the jury verdict that acquitted two white men of the murder of 14-year-old Emmett Louis Till, a Negro, in Sumner, Miss.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 2 -- The 1,219-entry thirty-third annual dog show of the Westbury Kennel Association ended in a victory for a black cocker spaniel, Ch. Taylor's Dark Knight today.

The National Lead Company has discovered new titanium ore deposits on its properties at Tahawus, N. Y., and in Norway, and has purchased large tracts of titanium-rich land in Florida, it announced over the weekend.
The Young Women's Christian Association of the U. S. A. announced yesterday that John D. Rockefeller Jr. had contributed $509,950 toward its centennial fund.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The illness of President Eisenhower started a wild rush to buy grain and soybean futures last Monday, just as it brought a rush to sell securities.

Great was the rejoicing in Brooklyn last night. Though the Dodgers haven't yet won their first world series, this long-sought goal could be just around the corner. Walter Alston's Brooks moved within reach of it at Ebbets Field during the afternoon when they brought down a stunned and bewildered band of Yankees, 5 to 3, in the pivotal fifth game.

An unusually large number of motormen on the IND division of the city's subway system reported "sick" last night in what was believed to be a minor labor dispute. Their action presented a problem in the maintenance of normal service, particularly in Queens.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 -- Steel demand was building up faster last week than-most producers or consumers had believed possible. The flow of new orders was still somewhat ahead of the industry's capacity to produce. As a result steel will be tighten than ever in the months ahead.
A prediction that a party split would not develop at the 1956 Republican Presidential convention was made yesterday by Daniel J. Riesner, president of the National Republican Club.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The Colonial Office announced today proposals designed to give the British protectorate of Zanzibar a greater measure of self-government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Weather Bureau is quietly seek-hug to find out how its hurricane forecasts are getting to the public by radio and television.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- Argentina's deposed President, Gen. Juan D. Peron, flew into exile today. His first destination was the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion.

WHEN Duke Snider emerged from the dugout yesterday morning he took a quick appraisal of the Ebbets Field landscape. The sun was beaming and the dew had the grass shimmering in a green glow. It looked mighty purty.

Transfer of the assets and business of Niles-Bement-Pond Company, recently merged into Penn-Texas Corporation, to a new corporation to be known as Pratt Whitney Company, Inc., was announced today by L. D. Silberstein, president and chairman of the board of Penn-Texas.
President Eisenhower in a filmed and recorded broadcast, urged citizens across the nation last night to support the united charity drives in their communities this fall.

OLD MYSTIC, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Methodist Church history was made today in this village.

I myself found the three articles by Gene Smith carefully impartial in their examination of the question of Federal regulation of natural-gas production.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Rebel terrorists struck today in Oran. The westernmost department of Algeria had previously been untouched by the violence afflicting other parts of French North Africa.
ABOUT half way through the evening "The Young and Beautiful," which opened at the Longacre on Saturday, settles down to work and becomes an interesting play.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A tax problem that has produced countless headaches over the years will be tackled Tuesday by a Congressional subcommittee. It consists of the many inconsistencies and inequities, come statutory and others administrative, in procedures for complying and collecting Federal excise taxes.

Traders on the New York Cocoa Exchange have their attention fixed these days on the barefoot natives in West Africa and South America who will bring in the 1955-56 cocoa crop. Present indications are that supplies and demand will be about balanced for the year.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2 -- A noted Argentine economist has undertaken the task of assessing the damage done to Argentina's economy by the rule of Gen. Juan D. Peron.

Although Margaret Tobias made her official debut last night in Town Hall, she is no stranger to the local scene. The young mezzo-soprano had been one of the soloists of the Bach Aria Group for several seasons, and she has given concerts in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- The Selective Service Director said today that men over 35 would be almost draft-proof in any war while men 26 to 36 would be used "only selectively."
Local 1190, International Longshoremen's Association -the sugar samplers' local with a membership of about forty men -- voted unanimously late Saturday night to strike today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The illegal use of narcotics by teen-agers is declining except in New York and Los Angeles, Senator Price Daniel said today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, playing in what may be his last amateur tournament, won his nineteenth final of the year today by defeating Vic Seixas, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, for the Pacific Coast Tennis championship.
ROME, Oct. 2 -- At the threshold of the nuclear era, "it appears that God is preparing something really unusual for all mankind," Pope Pius XII said today.

Directors of the Scovill Manufacturing Company have elected William M. Goss as president to succeed Leavenworth P. Sperry, who becomes chairman of the board. Mark L. Sperry 2d was elected executive vice president and will also assume the duties of general manager, it was announced over the week-end.

John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, yesterday named L. E. Pentecost general manager of the company's South Atlantic district. Mr. Pentecost formerly was manager of the Norfolk office. He will continue to serve in that capacity.

Ever since its organization forty- two years ago the Rockefeller Foundation has taken the public into its confidence as to all its operations. It has published reports annually since 1914, giving full details of its security holdings, its income and its disbursements -- especially its grants and the purposes for which they were made.

A six-story apartment building at 1024 Walton Avenue, near East 165th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Morris Silvers to Max and Anna Aronson for cash over mortgages amounting to about $134,000. The building is on a 97 by 78 foot plot.

THE lovely story of "Heidi" was crushed under theatrical ineptitude Saturday evening on Channel 4. The purity of spirit of the little Swiss girl was nowhere to be found in Max Liebman's yodeling assault on the classic.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 2 -- The expansion in the Dutch economy, although still going on, is slowing down. The ceiling on productive capacity has been reached and resistance to Dutch exports abroad is increasing.
A couple of new Dodger heroes stepped to front and center yesterday to join Duke Snider and Clem Labine, who came through with spotlight performances for the second day in a row.
SOCORRO, N. M., Oct. 2 (UP) -- The state police said today a tire blowout had caused a bus wreck that injured Lionel Hampton and fourteen members of his jazz band. The bus driver also was injured.

This morning the Supreme Court reconvenes after a recess since June 6. It faces an exceptionally crowded docket. There are some 700 cases to be passed on, although, of course, in a considerable number of them the first decision will be whether the Supreme Court should accept the appeal.
Casey Stengel, in what to him is an unfamiliar role of losing manager, saw what every one of the 36,796 fans saw yesterday at Ebbets Field.
The charter market was again led by coal cargoes last week, with rates reaching two-year high points.
Textron American, Inc., continuing its diversification efforts, announced yesterday the acquisition of a metal fastener concern and an agreement to buy a plywood mill.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 2 -- Max Evans, a 34-year-old professional from Utica, Mich., won the Long Island Rotary open golf tournament today with a 67 for 273 today.

DENVER, Monday, Oct. 3 -- President Eisenhower suffered a setback last night in his fight for recovery from the coronary thrombosis he suffered Sept. 24.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A laboratory test designed to show the presence of and the extent of damage to heart muscle in coronary attacks has been made successfully on 400 patients, a medical researcher reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon reported today that the Government had run smoothly without "internal disputes and jealousies'' during the first week of President Eisenhower's recuperation from a heart attack.
CATSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Somewhere a blond child called Nancy faces possible death unless she receives anti-rabies injections quickly.

It's almost like a double helping of dessert. Students at Cheshire (Conn.) Academy are going to be able to root for two football teams this season, instead of one. Sound like over-emphasis? Well, it isn't.

Mayor Wagner has directed the New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion, working with other top administrative aides, to undertake an immediate study of traffic congestion on the city's waterfront, pier rentals and the city's proposed $187,053,886 port improvement and development program.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2 -- Yugoslavia has adopted a far-reaching economic policy. It is designed to increase the standard of living by reducing investments in heavy industries and increasing investments in consumer goods and agricultural production.
First-nighters are urged to be in their seats at 7:45 o'clock tonight at the Plymouth, where Tiger at the Gates," starring Michael Redgrave, will have its premiere.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -- Rising rivers in eastern Mexico are causing new and serious inundations. Torrential rains have swelled the Pantepec River and parts of the city of Tuxpan were reported under twelve feet of water.
Baptist churchgoers were called upon yesterday to help build "bridges of understanding" between the United States and the Soviet Union.

CAIRO, Oct. 2 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser said today Egypt had intercepted British and French documents proving the West had sold arms to Israel despite a British report that Israel was probably more aggressive than Egypt.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 2 -- A flood of unofficial returns from populous Central Java today put the Nationalist party into the lead in Indonesia's first parliamentary election.

Joan Wolski of the Queen Mercurettes tallied 3,644 points to win the senior women's pentathlon championship in a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet at Victory Field, Glendale, Queens, yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A last-second field goal by Les Richter, the climax of one of the wildest professional football games in this city, gave the Los Angeles Rams a 27-26 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today.

ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Oct. 2 -- Tempo VII, the new Gold Cup and Unlimited Class speedboat owned by Guy Lombardo of Freeport, L. I., and driven by Danny Foster, won the International Cup regatta today with a perfect score of 1,200 points.
MANTUA, Italy, Oct. 2 -- The first "Orfeos," gold and silver statuettes of Orpheus, were presented tonight to outstanding opera singers and conductors.
The two teams that shared top honors in college football a year ago and that were expected to rank season the leaders again this season have both been beating with the campaign hardly began.
The Dole Hawaiian Pineapple Company has signed agreements to acquire two Pacific Coast canning companies, F. M. Ball Co., of Oakland, Calif., and Paulus Brothers Packing Company of Salem, Ore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Democratic national chairman said tonight that Wisconsin "right-wing" Republicans were about to try to "steal" the House seat of Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.

Production of high-grade precision lenses for cameras and other optical goods is winning Japan a new and profitable field of export trade. Three years ago the industry began a drive for a major share of world markets. It made rapid and sizable gains in exports of low and medium-priced cameras, binoculars and microscopes, particularly in the United States, the largest market.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 2 -- Owing to General Eisenhower's sudden illness, business on the Zurich Stock Exchange was more agitated last week than for many years past.
A dispute over whether Americans for Democratic Action should take sides in primary elections broke out yesterday at the annual convention of the New York chapter.
CAIRO, Oct. 2 -- Israel and Egypt withdrew their military forces today from El Auja demilitarized zone on the Sinai Peninsula frontier.
The New York Americans beat the Baltimore Rockets, 6 -- 0, in the second round of the American Soccer League championship series at Zerega Oval in the Bronx yesterday.
Almost seventy-five years of Long Island Rail Road operation in the Rockaway Peninsula ended at midnight last night.

At a special meeting in Greenville, Ohio, stockholders American Aggregrates Corporation approved a recapitalizatic plan. It provides for an increase in authorized common shares a 1,050,000 from 350,000 and change of common shares without par value to common share with a value of $5 each.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- A research expert warned today that millions of dollars in investments and thousands of jobs would be wiped out unless labor-management cooperation produced a more efficient distribution system.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Sixty thousand Holy Name Society men of the Roman Catholic Church marched here today in an eight-hour long parade that ended the society's sixth national convention.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- As the General Assembly opens tomorrow what is scheduled to be its final day of preliminary general debate, attention will be divided between the representatives of seven nations still scheduled to speak, and the empty chairs of the French delegation.

OSTEND, Belgium, Oct. 2 -The seafarers' section of the International Transport Workers Federation will open a three-day meeting here tomorrow. A report will be made of a successful action fought against Communist Poland's shipping companies in behalf of 500 to 600 Polish officers and men who served in the Allied merchant fleet in World War II.

Some of our career trust-busters have a term of thinly veiled opprobrium they like to invoke when they are talking about the automobile industry. The term is oligopoly. Oligopoly refers to a situation in which no single unit in the industry controls a sufficient proportion of total production to exercise monopolistic control over prices, but where the consumer market is divided among a comparatively small number of purchasing units.
Miss Florence Rose, executive secretary of the Meals for Millions Foundation, returned from a trip to the world's famine areas yesterday with the conviction that hunger can be defeated.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 2 -- Juan D. Peron, dictator of Argentina for more than ten years, arrived here today to begin a life in exile.
With festive lights and brassy music, Chinatown began last night a nine-day observance of the forty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic.

Two youths were held in $1,000 bail each in Felony Court yesterday on charges of felonious assault. The charges are the after-math of gang shootings on upper Madison Avenue Saturday night. During the exchange of gunfire one youth was killed and two others were wounded.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Kimberling, a 10-year-old bay gelding owned by the Kimberton (Pa.) Hills Farm, took the grand championship award as the Westchester Country Club's three-day horse show ended today.

Some tickets are still available in the block of seats taken by the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement for the ballet Thursday night. The Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House will present "Les Sylphides," "Daphnis and Chloe" and "Madame Chrysantheme."

SOMEWHERE IN CYPRUS, Oct. 1 -- The Right Wing of the enosis movement among Cyprus Greeks for union with Athens is represented by E. O. K. A., an underground organization of saboteurs, assassins and potential guerrillas. The initials stand for National Organization of Cypriote Fighters. E. O. K. A. espouses terrorism as an accepted nationalist tactic.
An evening of sensitive and intelligent music making was provided by the American pianist, Joseph Bloch, last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Some of the Dodgers were "romping" a little after yesterday's victory, but there was still restraint in their joy.
THE American woman's most coveted title, "Best Dressed Girl in the World," was won for her by American fashion designers as well as by her own good taste.
Riverside Church, a Morningside Heights landmark, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday.
CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- A serious new problem in the Gaza strip is that the children are being educated better than their parents and "then graduating into idleness."

Mayor Wagner is certainly on the right track with his new plans to solve the traffic congestion in Manhattan. The imposing of an anti- jaywalking law is long overdue in the city. It has shown very good results in various states, especially Michigan and California.
The American President Lines' third President Jackson is to be delivered Thursday for round-the-world cargo-passenger service.

MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Talk to the average Russian and he will tell you President Eisenhower's illness is unfortunate but not serious. By this he means neither the President's life nor the outlook for world peace is in imminent peril.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- If the Western powers cannot prevent Egypt from buying arms from the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, Ambassador Abba Eban of Israel declared today, they "should redress the balance by supplying arms to Israel."
RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 2 -- French outposts were fighting, off Moroccan tribesmen in the region of Fez tonight in a guerrilla war that broke out twenty-four hours ago.

There is a $955 reason for the Dodgers to play harder than the Yankees in what remains of this world series. Back-of-the-envelope computation yesterday produced the information that one full winning share of the series cut will amount to approximately $8,595 for the Dodgers and $7,640 for the Yankees.

Though the Department of Licenses was not set up under the City Charter as a revenue producer, this agency, through its collection of fees for licenses and permits, turned a welcome cascade of dollars into the city's coffers last year. Its total collections were $1,478,902, or $1,112,874 above the budget cost of running the department.
Roving squads of firemen, similar to those now operating in Harlem and the lower Bronx, will be established about Nov. 1 in the Brownsville and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn.
"I don't know what the letters really stand for," the young veteran said. "But in the
Raffi Petrossian, pianist, will give a recital in Town Hall tonight at 8:30.

The C. I. O. Maritime Committee joined Mississippi River tank barge operators yesterday in a protest against Federal aid for construction of pipelines to carry natural gas and petroleum and its products from Texas to Ohio and New Jersey.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, paced by Otto Graham's pin-point passing and the line cracking of Ed (Big Mo) Modzelewski and Fred Morrison, crushed the San Francisco 49ers, 38 to 3, today in a National Football League game.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Tobin Rote fired two touch-down passes and plunged for a third tally today as the Green Bay Packers registered their second upset of the National Football League season by humbling the Chicago Bears, 24 -- 3.

Charles Eastman won first prize of a $100 savings bond yesterday afternoon in the final chess tournament of the season in Washington Square Park. But he had to share the limelight with 12-year-old Bobby Fischer, who had weather the month-long contest and thirty-two eliminations before being beaten.
Humility has displaced rancor in the breast of former Mayor William O'Dwyer.
Pee Wee Reese, the Dodgers' captain and shortstop, who is the only one on the team to have played in the 1941 series against the Yankees, has been the most frustrated Dodger of them all.

ATHENS, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- The six-week Music and Drama Festival here ended tonight with the second and final concert by the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos.

By way of supplement to the excellent plan of the New York City Congress of Industrial Organizations Council to send labor union members to settlement houses to teach trade skills to neighborhood youth there may be a real opportunity to recruit trade teachers for vocational high schools.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Two long touchdown passes by Quarterback Lamar McHan and a 65-yard run by Halfback Dave Mann powered the Chicago Cardinals to a 28-17 victory over the New York Giants today.
DENVER, Oct. 2 -- The health insurance programs would be hard-pressed to offer their subscribers the type of medical care provided President Eisenhower at Fitzsimons Army Hospital.
ALBANY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Governor Harriman appointed an advisory committee today to study methods of expanding home-rule privileges for cities and villages.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 -- The most surprising bloc in Vice President Richard M. Nixon's fan club today is California's 3,266,000 registered Democrats.

MINSK, U. S. S. R., Oct. 1 -- The Germans murdered 100,000 Minsk Jews during the World War II occupation. Now 30,000 to 50,000 Jews are estimated to live here. They make up almost 10 per cent of the city's population.
ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- Vaccination against poliomyelitis is scheduled to be completed in the state soon for all children who were in the first four grades in the last school year.

"I Traveled a Lonely Land," by Nina Pulliam, wife of Eugene C. Pulliam, publisher of The Indianapolis Star, will be published next Monday by Bobbs-Merrill. Mrs. Pulliam tells of her trip by train and plane, car, jeep and truck, afoot and horseback, to almost every corner of Australia.

The Yankee Stadium is easily accessible from all parts of the city by subway and from the suburbs by automobile. Here are the most convenient means of reaching the site of today's sixth world series game:
Two striking groups of news distribution employes are scheduled to return to work this morning.
The man responsible for the new "wasp-waist" airplane design is a 34-year-old scientist who has been courting laboratory pallor since he was 12.

THERE is much that is new in Macy's eighth-floor delicacy department and most of it comes from the British Isles. Scotch soups, English cheeses and Irish fruit cakes are among the "finds" the store's taster, William Titon, and its grocery buyer, George Kinzler, brought back from a recent three-month trip abroad.
The National Broadcasting Company is thinking about dropping the Monday night performance of Steve Allen's "Tonight" and adding another television show for the star on Saturday evening.

The doctrines of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi are bearing fruit in the present period of relaxing international tension, V. K. Krishna Menon, India's representative at the United Nations, said yesterday.

When Gene Radano is off his beat, the 38-year-old patrolman, who has been a member of the New York police force since 1946, finds relaxation in playwriting. As a result of his perseverance, Mr. Radano, now a warrant officer on the staff of the Lower Manhattan Magistrates' Courts, has sold his first play.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Two goals by Earl (Dutch) Reibel and another by Gordie Howe carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-1 victory over the National Hockey League All-Stars tonight before 12,187 fans at the Olympia.

Louis Schleifer, who bought the twenty-five-story office building at the southeast comer of Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue two years ago, has resold it. The new owner is a syndicate headed by Frankel Silke, realty investors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Representative Albert Rains, chairman of the House subcommittee on Housing warned today that a recent Government tightening of housing credit might trigger a national economic slump.
ANDREW J. DUNN, bank clerk who is retiring from J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., remembers the Wall Street crashes of 1907, 1929 and, most vividly, that of Sept. 16, 1920, the biggest "crash" of all.
Diplomas were issued yesterday to seventy-six graduates of Long Island University in Brooklyn.

Fordham University and the Grey Advertising Agency are cooperating in setting up a "laboratory extension" school at the agency for the institution's courses in advertising and marketing. The first session is planned for Wednesday, Oct. 12.
Deep was the gloom in Flatbush last night.
The Presbytery of New York decided yesterday to conduct a $500,000 fund campaign to renovate and rehabilitate church buildings within its boundaries.

On a television program Sunday night Whitey Ford was asked who was going to pitch for the Yankees yesterday. "I am and it will be Tommy Byrne in the seventh game on Tuesday," responded Whitey without blinking an eye.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3 -- The Rumanian Grand National Assembly, which convened this morning for an hour, elected the new Premier unanimously. It also approved a reorganization of the government in which Gheorghe GheorgiuDej's position as the No. 1 man of the regime appeared strengthened.

FLOUNDER fishing is to the city man what bullhead fishing is to the man of the country. It has the same virtues of repose and relaxation and a few advantages over its country counterpart. The flounder is miles ahead as a pan fish and the sweep of Long Island Sound has a majesty no pond can match.

Despite a reigning Italian film star and a Swedish "Miss Universe," our G. I.'s rate American co-eds as the most beautiful girls in the world. Proof: a letter that a grateful mother relayed to the United Service Organizations.
Sales and earnings of the M. M. Wood Working Company for the quarter and six months ended Aug. 31 were higher than those of the similar periods last year.
SUFFERN, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Blond 5-year-old Nancy Bihler learned here today with surprise and some chagrin that she had been the object of a wide-spread police search.

Two six - story apartment houses occupy the blockfront on the east side of Fort Washington Avenue between 160th and 161st Streets have been purchased by Roosevelt Gabriel, real estate operator. The building at No. 36 was acquired from the Two-in-One Realty Corporation and that at No. 46-52 was bought from the Three Streets Realty Corporations.
A last-minute settlement yesterday afternoon averted a walkout by the forty-two members of the sugar samplers' local of the International Longshoremen's union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- The United States criticized the South Korean Government today for applying a retroactive sales tax on American business men in Korea.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele said today that prospects were bright for effective control of paralytic poliomyelitis next year.

The Army's oldest unit, "New York's own," which first fired at an enemy on July 12, 1776, was welcomed back home yesterday from thirteen years of overseas duty. The eightysix men of Battery D. Fifth Field Artillery Battalion, First Infantry Division, paraded up Broad Street to Federal Hall for noontime greetings.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- From the forum of the General Assembly, Israel urged the great powers today not to permit any disturbance of the delicate military balance in the Middle East.
Men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined a special squad of police yesterday in an attempt to find eight tiny figurines stolen on Saturday from the Brooklyn Museum.

Eddie Stanky returned to the New York Giants' organization yesterday. The fiery little second baseman of the Giants' 1951 National League champions, deposed in May as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, accepted Horace Stoneham's offer to pilot the Minneapolis Millers, the Giants' American Association farm club.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Emil Gilels, the first Soviet concert artist to appear here since 1921, made a triumphant American debut tonight with the Philadelphia Orchestra before a capacity audience in the Academy of Music.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- A largely rivetless single-engine metal plane was displayed in the first West German air show since World War II in Munich last week-end. The major parts of its fuselage were "pasted" together.
If there has to be a "goat" on the club that loses a world series game, it may be that Junior Gilliam must be measured for the horns.

OSTEND, Belgium, Oct. 3 -- The convention of the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization may come into force before the end of this year, it was reported to the Seafarers Section of the International Transport Workers Federation today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3 -- Brazilians went to the polls today to elect a President and Vice President.
Passage of the proposed state highway bond issue was urged yesterday by Robert Moses as City Construction Coordinator.

Plans have been completed for the sports and social entertainment programs to be featured at the third annual Secor Farms Horse Show, scheduled for Oct. 23 at the Secor Farms Riding Club, White Plains. It will be a benefit for the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- More than 600 persons from throughout the state met here today to seek answers for the problems of young people in trouble.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the National Democratic Committee, offered today to "bet" that the Republican 1956 national convention would be held here rather than in San Francisco.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 3 -- Israel will recast her five-year armament program in the light of recent developments in the arming of the Arab states.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- Maxwell Setton will start production on "Portrait in Smoke" before English cameras next month in London.

James A. Farley last night scored political machines that put politics above morality. The former Democratic national chairman said they encouraged corruption, bred delays, fostered incivility and made for insincerity in politics.
During a busy lifetime Julius Ochs Adler attained high position in two parallel careers, one in the military service and the second in newspaper management.

Steel production last week topped expectations and was at the highest level since early last May. The industry operated at 97.0 per cent of rated capacity and turned out 2,341,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The anti-colonial powers scored another victory in the United Nations today when the General Assembly placed the question of West New Guinea on its agenda. The vote was 31 to 18, and the United States was among the ten members that abstained.
Samuel H. Kress, merchant, left the residue of his great art collection to the foundation bearing his name. He established it in 1929 to promote the well-being and progress of the human race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Dr. Henrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, rejected today the thesis that relaxation of international tensions would lead to solution of EastWest political problems.

Mighty Maryland, which has played the toughest portion of its schedule in the first three weeks of the season, widened its lead yesterday in The United Press college football ratings. Oklahoma took over third place behind Michigan.
CAIRO, Oct. 3 -- The Czechoslovak weapons Egypt has contracted to buy will go far toward eliminating Israel's substantial lead in military equipment, a high-ranking United States diplomat said today.

The leasehold of the forty- three-story office building at 22 East Fortieth Street has been sold by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to an investment syndicate headed by Lawrence A. Wien. Helmsley- Spear, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is encouraging Arthur Godfrey to take vacations at regular intervals. It remains to be seen whether the network's biggest breadwinner will adhere to the suggestion.
GIMBELS, after watching the new Fords go by, has prepared a selection of sportswear and accessory items that repeat the two-tone colors of the cars.

National Fur Auctions, Inc., started a $750,000 damage suit in Supreme Court yesterday against the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc., its president, Samuel Schulman, and its executive manager, J. George Greenberg, charging them with "libelous and defamatory statements."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- There have been so many grim events and prospects since the Soviets gave everybody the big smile in Geneva that a merry moment in the State Department is worth reporting. After a high-level conference the other day, summoned to discuss what the United States should do about a new outbreak of trouble in the world, most of the conferees emerged laughing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon called today for builders to "step-up in the United States a dynamic program to eradicate slum and blighted areas."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The start of National Reserve training today reflected no flocking to the colors by volunteers.
A vision of having one student center for the use of all New York University students at the Washington Square branch became nearer a reality yesterday.

It seems only too possible now that Russia is embarking on a new policy of intervention in the Middle East. If this proves true, we are entering another period of tension and danger in one of the critical areas of the world.

TRENTON, Oct. 3 -- Delaware asked New Jersey today to agree to a diversion of toll revenues from the Delaware Bay Memorial Bridge. The money would be used to finance the construction of limited access feeder roads in Delaware.
Henry K. Norton, who outlined the Aerial Transit plan last night to the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission, has had long experience in transportation and communications.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Coach Frank Bell sent Hotchkiss School's football squad through a two-hour practice at Baker Field this afternoon and came off the gridiron still wondering about this season's prospects.
BONN, Oct. 3 -- The Bank Deutscher Laender reported today that West Germany's balance of payments in August showed a deficit for the first time in three years. The deficit was $7,000,000.
The Soviet Union has greatly stepped up its housing construction, I. K. Kozuilia, Minister of Urban and Rural Construction, said here yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Crime is a "national disgrace," J. Edgar Hoover declared here today. He called upon all law-abiding citizens to help "take the handcuffs off law enforcement."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The Soviet Union resisted Western efforts today to discover what control and inspection measures it would agree on for a future disarmament program.
Details of advanced communications systems on the Navy's new supercarrier Forrestal were described yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
Senator William F. Knowland called last night for an American policy based on freedom for nations now under Communist control.
Keep an eye on nature, especially in the autumn. At that season, more than at any other, she displays a deplorable tendency toward practical jokes. The victim is the obvious one.
"Island of Goats," a drama by the late Italian playwright Ugo Betti, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Fulton theatre. The play has for its setting a millhouse on a Mediterranean island.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The effort to harness the energy of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful purposes is being pressed in five laboratories but success appears to be far off.

PARTISANS of "The Yeoman of the Guard" had their turn last night. At the Shubert Theatre, where the properly celebrated D'Oyly Carte Company, is holding forth, they had a chance to revel in what they consider to be one of the finest of the creations by Sir Arthur Sullivan and Sir William S. Gilbert.
"Trial," Metro - Goldwyn-Mayer's screen version of the Don Mankiewicz novel, will have its local premiere on Oct. 13 at the Radio City Music Hall.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Tuesday, Oct. 4 -- The Russian national basketball team will meet Harvard University's varsity squad in the second game of a United States tour this winter according to an announcement in today's Harvard Crimson, the university's daily newspaper.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- The Government of Paraguay announced recognition today of the new Argentine Government.
A trio of major investment banking houses here and in London has formed an international company to buy shares in selected private enterprises in nations other than the United States and Canada.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 3 -A match of cards was necessary to break a three-way deadlock at net 67 and decide the winners in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at Quaker Ridge today.
Tributes to Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler and messages of condolences to his family were received yesterday from local, state and national leaders.

This business of classifying men over 40 and women over 30 as "unemployable because of age" is as grievous as it is heinous. But the suggestion of "A Times Reader" that all that is needed to eradicate this evil is to have a different mental climate is not practical.

The Community Service Society is seeking $1,000,000 in contributions to support its services to troubled New York families in the year ahead. The agency is no newcomer on the social welfare scene. For more than a century it has stood as a bulwark against perils that threaten family stability.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., yesterday asked the Government to take the lead in finding "a real solution" to the problems of the American merchant marine.

FEZ, French Morocco, Oct. 3 -- The two-day old guerrilla war in northern Morocco settled down to a deadly simmer tonight. The official death toll among French civilians and their defenders was fixed at twenty-three.

Business men, somewhat recovered now from the initial shock of the President's illness, stand firm in their oft-repeated convictions that the economy is sound, according to the First National City Bank.

The New York State Thruway Authority has decided to resume this fall the permanent financing of the expressway facility. The Authority announced yesterday that it would offer an issue of $50,000,000 of serial bonds on Oct. 11.

BREMEN, Germany, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Management charged today that a wildcat strike of 2,500 part-time dockers had a "definite political background camouflaged with wage demands." Management and union called on workers to return to their jobs tomorrow.

It's been a long time since a modest monthly rise in agricultural prices has created as much interest and discussion as did the advance of 1 per cent in the index of farm prices between mid-August and mid-September.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- A bequest of $1,000,000 for the improvement of athletic facilities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was made by David F. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., who was killed in an automobile accident last month.
NOTTINGHAM, England, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Young Martin of Spain won the European flyweight championship tonight. He knocked out Dai Dower of Wales in the twelfth round of a scheduled fifteen-round fight.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 3 -- Gen. Juan D. Peron, resting in comfortable exile here, indicated today he was hoping for a political return to Argentina.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Pickets instead of horses paraded today at the Suffolk Downs race track, but the settlement of a labor dispute made it a sure bet the horses would be on the track tomorrow to open the fall meeting.
HONG KONG, Oct. 3 -- Communist China's leadings newspaper accused the United States today of "obstructing" the talks in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Fourteen Wall Street brokers and business men have requested $1,700 in witness expenses from a Senate subcommittee that questioned them.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The French Government ordered its Resident General in Morocco today to carry out its plan for re-establishing political peace in the protectorate.
Army and Michigan are a magic pairing for the week in college football and Notre Dame and Miami (Florida) are another.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 (AP) -Lieut. Gen. S. D. Sturgis Jr., chief of the Army Engineers, asked for Federal legislation today to blueprint an "adequate water supply for the future."
