DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Last week United States automobile factories built 112,916 cars and 23,801 trucks, a total of 136,717. This compared with 123,009 cars and 24,067 trucks in the preceding week. So far this year total production is 6,003,603 cars and 935,435 trucks.
An intensive drive to track down 10,000 New Yorkers who are unaware they are suffering from tuberculosis was opened yesterday at ceremonies in the South Bronx.
Recently there came to my desk from your director of Canadian advertising a copy of the American section of the 1955 International Trade Supplement which I have read with interest.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Wall Street's reaction to the unfavorable bulletin on President Eisenhower, plus some local factors, had a depressing effect on the stock market here. However, the losses, while widespread, were small.
CASEY STENGEL'S taxicab drew up to the Stadium entrance yesterday morning as autograph-hunters, rubbernecks and neighborhood urchins swarmed around him.

We "Yanquis" will be watching with friendly interest the results of yesterday's Presidential election in Brazil. It will be some days before the count is finished. There are few countries in the Western Hemisphere -- or indeed in the world -- more entitled to be called a friend than Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The United States, Britain and France censured the Soviet Union today in notes reminding it of its responsibilities for the maintenance of free communication between Berlin and West Germany.
"Well, the season starts and ends tomorrow, observed Hank Bauer yesterday after the Yankees had squared the world series count with the Dodgers at three games all. That about sums up the situation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A Congressional subcommittee said it is time to stop "experimental dilly-dallying" and to begin building plans for upgrading manganese ores.

After two rounds of the chalengers' chess tournament among twenty women from eleven countries, Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York and Mrs. Sonja Graf-Stevenson of Palm Springs, Calif., were first in the standing, according to a report last night from Moscow.

The Guaranty Trust Company had net operating earnings of $17,928,503 for the first nine months of this year, an increase of $2,509,874, or of 16 per cent, over the record for the corresponding period of last year.

Increased engine power and mechanical improvements mark the 1956 automobiles of the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation. The new cars will go on display Friday in dealer showrooms in the New York metropolitan area.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The death in Piraeus, Greece, of Mike (the Greek) Potson, Chicago gambler who started out as a peddler of pistachio nuts and later amassed a fortune, was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The National Federation of Post Office Clerks, A. F. L., accused the Post Office Department today of imposing a "speed-up system" on postal workers. The speed-up threatens "a complete breakdown of the postal service," it said.

To the Fire Department, a car parked too close to a hydrant can be a matter of life or death. Until recently, there was not much it could do about it. Now, however, the department can hand out parking summonses, and yesterday it opened a program of doing just that and doing it thoroughly.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday had their widest swing in several years.

Election of Matthew A. McLaughlin as vice president and general counsel of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation was announced yesterday by Victor Emanuel, chairman and president. At the same made secretary of the company, which produces aircraft and industrial engines, precision machine parts and castings, farm equipment and home appliances.
A grand jury's charge that Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens and key aides "lack the proper concept of public office" was expunged yesterday.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 (Reuters) Japan's powerful pre-war industrial combines -- the so-called Zaibatsu -- appear to have reestablished their leading positions in Japanese industry, according to a report of the Japanese Government's Economic Planning Board released here today.

Andrew J. Higgins Jr., president of Higgins, Inc., New Orleans shipbuilders, announced yesterday that W. R. Grace Co. and a group of New Orleans business men had secured a long-term option to buy the family's holdings in the company.

The world series of 1955 has run out of tomorrows, so there will be no holding back by the Yankees today. Tommy Byrne, the 35-year-old southpaw, will be on the mound at the start of the rubber game this afternoon and every eligible New York pitcher will be in the bullpen. Even Whitey Ford, a standout winner yesterday, will not be spared.
ROME, Oct. 3 -- A resolution drawing attention to the "damaging waste" resulting from inadequate roads was agreed upon here today by members of the International Road Federation.

"The Fabulous Originals," by Irving Wallace, described as a "combination of literary detection and off-beat biography," will be published Oct. 17 by Knopf. The book presents the lives of some extraordinary people who inspired "memorable characters in fiction."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that President Eisenhower himself would decide whether a sense of duty should compel him to seek re-election.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -Jack Howard, labor reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle, was found in contempt of court and put in jail today. He had refused to answer a question involving the two-months old Sebastopol apple strike.
Friday's total of 623 pints of blood donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was the largest for any day in September. That month's total was 9,214 pints.

WALT DISNEY'S long-awaited afternoon show for children, "The Mickey Mouse Club," had its premiere yesterday on Channel 7. Hopeful parents, who had assumed that Mr. Disney would bring about a long-needed revolution in adolescent TV programming, can only keep their fingers crossed.
Senator Irving M. Ives has accused the Democratic majorities in the last session of Congress of having shelved important recommendations of President Eisenhower for partisan reasons.
A $1,500,000,000 plan, known as "aerial transit," was offered last night as a cure-all for the traffic and mass transportation ills of New York and its suburbs in three states.
Carmine G. DeSapio yesterday chided business men who failed to participate in politics.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- France's withdrawal from the United Nations General Assembly for its decision to debate her rule of Algeria appears to have bolstered the Government of Premier Edgar Faure at a time of need.

Paddy DeMarco, the former lightweight champion of the world, halted Kenny Lane's victory string at ten last night. The Brooklyn boxer gained a split decision in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 3 (UP) -- The Santiago stock exchange today defied an order by President Carlos Ibanez raising the margin, or cash down payment, on stock purchases from 30 to 40 per cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Paul S. Willis of New York, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, said today the nation's food industry could nearly double cash sales volume in the next decade.
AGAIN the voice of Giraudoux is heard in a theatre, conveying wit and thought with elegance. The voice has never said anything more pertinent.
Stock prices declined steadily yesterday following unfavorable news about President's Eisenhower's health. Prices closed near the lows of the day.

Rubber prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York in one of the sharpest breaks of the year. The market was influenced by lower prices in London and Singapore and the weakness in the stock market. Prices here fell to new lows for the move.
DENVER, Tuesday, Oct. 4 -- President Eisenhower rallied yesterday from a minor setback. He transacted some Government business from his hospital bed.

Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, yesterday urged representatives of the textile industry to attend forthcoming hearings on United States participation next year in tariff negotiations by members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The man who silenced the once-raucous automobile horns of Paris began trying today to end illegal parking.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- The work in the United States of Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, is being studied with interest in Bonn.
Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization in America and largest Zionist group in the world, opened its new five-story building yesterday at 65 East Fifty-second Street.

RANSOM, Pa., Oct. 3 -- A two-year, $15,000,000 program of paper manufacturing with hardwood pulp was announced here today by the National Paper Corporation of Pennsylvania, now a major producer of household tissue papers.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The British Government was urged today to take the lead in the fight against inflation by drastically reducing its own expenditures.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The Soviet Union has promised to consider a new "package" deal under which eighteen countries, including Japan and Spain, would be admitted to the United Nations. Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, gave this promise to Dr. Victor Belaunde of Peru before his return to Moscow last week.
A former city policeman and one who had been suspended pleaded guilty yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions to charges that they had participated in a police courtesy card racket.

EARLY in 1944 some of my friends began to suggest to me that I become a candidate for Vice President. I had never entertained such an idea, and whenever the suggestion was made, I brushed it aside. I was doing the job I wanted to do; it was one that I liked, and I had no desire to interrupt my career in the Senate.

A fairly wide variety of repertory, from Bach to Khachaturian, was played by Raffi Petrossian last night in Town Hall. It was his debut recital, and he lost no time in establishing the fact that the experience held no terrors for him. He played confidently and with verve, with no signs of inhibition.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 3 -- The Democrats won an unexpected victory in Republican Fairfield County today as the voters went to the polls in twelve towns to elect municipal officers for two-year terms.

Contracts for the construction of the first eight tankers to be built by private interests specifically for charter to the Navy are expected to be in the hands of shipyards by the end of this month, it was reported yesterday.

Oil Painting assumed greater value in the thoroughbred gallery yesterday by winning the Maskette Handicap for her second straight stakes victory at Belmont Park. The 4-year-old filly, owned by Mrs. Joe Goodwin, scored by a neck over Thomas F. White's Miss Weesie, to pick up $18,000 of the gross purse of $25,250.

A "sick" strike by 143 motormen cut rush-hour subway service 50 per cent for 90,000 Queens straphangers yesterday. Hundreds of thousands of other subway riders in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx were affected in minor degrees by the tie-up.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Nineteen persons were killed and sixteen injured in the crash of a Fawcett Airline DC-4 on an Andean mountain southeast of Lima yesterday.

The Sherwin Williams Company, paint manufacturer, has acquired space for executive and sales offices in the building at 260 Madison Avenue. The deal involves a sub-lease from the Jefferson Chemical Company, which has moved its principal executive offices to Texas.

The illness of President Eisenhower has thrown the office of Vice President of the United States into unaccustomed spotlight. In his memoirs this morning former President Truman calls it "the second highest honor that can be bestowed by the American people."
JAKARTA. Indonesia, Oct. 3 -The Nationalist party held a 1,000,000-vote lead Indonesia's parliamentary election as the unofficial count of ballots cast in the recent elections continued.

The letter from Judge Charles E. Clark, Chief Justice of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, published Sept. 25, dealt most interestingly with the problem of congestion in the Federal courts. He called attention to a condition that stymies our state courts as well -- namely, the overwhelming number of lawsuits arising from automobile accidents.
TAMPICO, Mexico, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Tampico's record - breaking floods grew graver today as the waters crept over the remaining dry areas of the city at the rate of two inches an hour.
The general funds of The Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind will be aided by the proceeds of a theatre party on Jan. 11.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Dr. John Ralph Rackley, Dean of the College of Education of the University of Oklahoma since 1949, was sworn in today as Deputy United States Commissioner of Education.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, construction engineering and marine salvage organization, now holds more than 96 per cent of the outstanding shares of six subsidiaries it acquired last year and early this year.
FALL, which brings a famine of fresh flowers, is a good season for developing a fresh point of view on arranging them. For it is now that one should learn to do more with less.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Harry A. deButts, president of the Southern Railway, today described four other railroads competing for business in the Southern territory as "poor losers."

A secondary distribution of a $15,600,000 block of common stock of the Aluminum Company of America was made yesterday by the First Boston Corporation and associates. The public offering involved 200,000 shares at $78 a share.

The United Hospital Fund opened its annual campaign last night at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel. It is seeking $3,500,000 to help meet the mounting costs of care in eighty-two voluntary hospitals in the city.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had risen to the highest point in more than two years.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- William G. Helis Jr., New Orleans sportsman, today announced the retirement to stud of Helioscope, holder of five track records and earnings of $418,275.
BUFFALO, Oct. 3 -- A shortage of male nurses prevents adequate care for many men suffering from mental illness, an industrial psychologist declared here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A movement to improve the staff facilities and living arrangements of the Vice President has been revived as a result of the illness of President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- New York State savings bankers were urged today to give greater consideration to split dividend rates on savings deposits.

TWO new practical aids -- an instructive folder and a teaching film -- have just been released, addressed to mothers and their youthful substitutes, babysitters. Both are designed to make Junior -- the object of any parent's affection on sitter's concern -- a safer and happier charge.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Sam Boulmetis and Willie Hartack shared riding honors at Atlantic City today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- An agreement "in principle" has been reached for the exchange of 200 masterpieces of art between the United States and the Soviet Union.
The Standard Oil Company (N.J.) and a group of its affiliates have organized the Esso Education Foundation to assist the nation's privately supported colleges and universities.

DEVOTEES of the table art strolling through an Italian or Greek district will note with pleasure that the first artichokes have arrived from the West Coast. As autumn advances, California will contribute larger numbers of this delightful vegetable.

Continued strength in home furnishings sales, and a slight gain in apparel volume, combined to give nine New York and Brooklyn department stores a total average sales increase of 3.5 per cent over last year for the month of September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The 1955-56 term of the Supreme Court began today.

It was Julie Adler's favorite quip about himself that he didn't know if he was primarily a newspaper man who was also a soldier or primarily a soldier who was also a newspaper man. The answer is that he was both -- more than both, for he crowded two lifetimes into one, a lifetime devoted to the newspaper profession and a lifetime to the military.
TAKAMATSU, Japan, Oct. 3 -- A vast intellectual gulf is growing between Japan and her nearest neighbor, Communist China, the Japan Newspaper Publishers and Editors Association was told yesterday.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Professional baseball in Toledo has scored a few runs, several hits and plenty of errors. Now it has struck out.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times, died of cancer of the pancreas in New York Hospital at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. He was 62 years old.

VIENNA, Oct. 3 -- Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, whose appointment as First Secretary of the Rumanian Communist party was announced yesterday, was relieved of his position as Premier today by the Rumanian National Assembly. He was succeeded by Chivu Stoica, one of his deputies.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev asserted tonight the problem of France's North African territories could be solved if the "legal rights and national interests" of the people of the area were taken into consideration.

Highly competitive bids for construction of two Grace Lines passenger liners were opened yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board in Washington. The 15,000-gross-ton ships will replace the Santa Paula and Santa Rosa in the company's Caribbean service.
Two mechanics were rescued at 8:30 P. M. yesterday after jumping from a burning yacht in Eastchester Bay, the Bronx. The yacht subsequently sank.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Following is the State Department transcript of the news conference held this morning by Secretary of State Dulles:

The Lewyt Corporation will turn out some time today its 2,000,000th vacuum cleaner. The high figure was achieved with consumer advertising in quantity, something of an innovation for cleaner manufacturers, Alex Lewyt, president, recalled yesterday.

Ship arrivals and departures here in the first nine months of 1955 exceeded the total for the 1954 period by 1,078 vessels, it was announced yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Thirteen local housing authorities will receive sealed bids on Oct. 26 on fifteen issues of new housing authority bonds aggregating $122,305,000.
Eighteen world series records were broken and eleven tied in the Dodgers' seven-game victory over the Yankees, The Associated Press reported last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 -- David Dubinsky of New York, president of the International Ladies Garment Union, A. F. L., announced here today that the union would establish a fleet of twelve mobile health centers for members living outside metropolitan areas.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 4 -- There is something pleasant happening to United States public relations in New Delhi these days. Jesse Owens is in town.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 4--The Western diplomatic community of Indonesia is disappointed by the results received so far in Indonesia's first national election.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The number of West Germans volunteering for their new Army has dropped by 80 per cent since the Big Four conference of heads of government at Geneva.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists took action yesterday that could lead to a jurisdictional battle between two talent unions.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation today announced a $90,000,000 expansion program is under way at five of its principal plants, with emphasis at Ravenswood, W. Va., where $75,000,000 is being spent.

The Marine captain had answered television's $64,000 question the night before. But now Eddie Cantor was asking the answer to a query worth $2,500,000 to American service men. The occasion was an outdoor U. S. O.-Camp Show and Rally staged for lunch-hour crowds in the Garment District three weeks ago today.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, announced today the program for the state-wide rally of party candidates here Friday.
The millennium and pandemonium arrived at approximately the same time in the Brooklyn Dodgers' clubhouse at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
The New York City Opera Company will open its fall season at the City Center of Music and Drama tonight at 8:15 o'clock with a performance of Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Tax returns of high revenue officials for the last three years are to receive special attention from auditors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Government opened a test case today seeking to prove that Harvey O'Connor, author, was guilty of contempt of Congress when he used the First Amendment to avoid answering questions on possible Communist affiliation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The W. A. Scheaffer Pen Company, one of the country's leading proponents of "fair trade," has informed its dealers that they may sell certain Scheaffer items up to $2 below list prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Public Housing Administration announced today that sixty-four local housing authorities have sold $115,781,000 worth of temporary loan notes at an average yield of 1.59 per cent.

The Continental Mark II, an automobile that is expected to sell for $9,500 or $10,000, was announced yesterday by the Continental division, Ford Motor Company. It will go on display Oct. 21 in dealer showrooms here.

Beckman Instruments, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30. The company designs, develops and makes precision analytical instruments for scientific, industrial, medical and laboratory uses.

Two months ago yesterday one of the finest newspapers of Latin America -- El Tiempo of Bogota -- was shut down in an arbitrary and inexcusable manner. This action seemed to all observers in the hemisphere to cap the climax of a steady move toward dictatorship by President Rojas Pinilla of Colombia.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today and tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The members of the National Security Training Commission expressed their sorrow today on the death yesterday of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times.

A certain number of countries are playing ducks and drakes with the United Nations and it is a dangerous game. The way the General Assembly voted on the Algerian and West New Guinea issues this week shows a recklessness that bodes ill for an international organization which is still in its infancy.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra concludes its European tour with a pair of concerts in London's Festival Hall, the first of which took place this evening with a large audience attending.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Premier Faure will urge Chancellor Adenauer tomorrow to join with him in preventing the rejection of the Saar statute.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday the formation of a housing committee. It will seek to solve the problem of the shortage of middle-income housing facilities in New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Army finally decided today to stand all President Eisenhower's medical expenses at Fitzsimons Army Hospital in Denver, and to bill him only for his daily food.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- Paraguay's dictatorial regime imposed censorship on all press dispatches from Asuncion Sunday in an apparent effort to cover up the fact that President Stroessner had flown to meet General Peron at the border.

Another large office structure is planned for the East Side, where a blockfront parcel on Third Avenue has been acquired by Uris Brothers, builders. The property, on the west side of the avenue between Forty-Sixth and Forty-Seventh Streets, was purchased from Bing Bing, Inc.
The qualifications of Ralph John DeMeo, recently appointed Director of Purchase of the Department of Purchase, are adequate, it was asserted yesterday at the office of Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Treasury cast new doubt today on prospects for reduction of excise (sales) taxes.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Parliament reconvened today in a fever of impatience to call Premier Edgar Faure's Government to account for the troubled state of France's North African empire.

WITHERBEE, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- This tiny Adirondack hamlet of iron miners went wild with joy when the home-town pride, Johnny Podres, pitched the Brooklyn Dodgers to their first world series championship today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 4 -- The action of the General Assembly of the United Nations in voting on Friday to place the Algerian question on the agenda of its current session has undoubtedly strengthened the hand of the Algerian rebels.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 4 (UP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, held the door "wide open" today for the return of Democrats who bolted in 1952. But he warned they would be accepted only as "singers in the choir loft -- not as leaders."
Midtown, Brooklyn and neighborhood theatre operators in the metropolitan area have agreed to an unusual arrangement to aid the benefit opening of Samuel Goldwyn's film "Guys and Dolls."

Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji contributed a pleasing performance in winning the Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The $17,300 event had its tenth running, and it attracted seven competitors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP)--A group of Russian housing experts picked up some pointers today on American bathing and television habits while getting their first look at homes built in this country.

GERMAN resistance had begun to crumble on all fronts by the middle of April [1945]. Until almost the end, however, there was talk of a last-ditch stand by the top Nazis and the German Command. It was believed that this stand would revolve about the so-called Redoubt, in the mountain areas of Bavaria, Austria and North Italy.
Dr. Eduardo Santos, publisher of the closed-down El Tiempo of Bogota and former President of Colombia, expressed confidence yesterday that his newspaper would be allowed to publish again before long.

Thomas J. Murphy, executive vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., said yesterday he would recommend arbitration of the dismissal of Melvin L. Barnet, former copy editor on The New York Times.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 -- Fragmentary results beginning to come in from yesterday's voting for President and Vice President serve only to emphasize the uncertainty of the outcome.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Representative Robert H. Mollohan, Democrat of West Virginia, called on the nation's railroads today to build more freight cars to overcome a shortage, which he said is hindering West Virginia's coal industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A special Government agency that deals with the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization today commended the American Legion for what it called "a significant contribution to American understanding of UNESCO."
DENVER, Wednesday, Oct. 5 -- President Eisenhower is continuing his steady progress toward recovery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Funds for mortgage lending will begin to become more plentiful in six months to a year throughout the country, a group of representative New York State bankers said today.
Syndicates and commercial banks granted yesterday two $100,000,000 credits.

The sixty-eight Founder's Day exercises at Pratt Institute yesterday included ceremonies of dedication for the newly completed residence halls. These buildings, housing a total of 206 students, are the first completed under the institution's new development program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- As the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee began work today, the possibility loomed that serious charges brought against French administration in the Cameroons might go undefended. French representatives were absent, their permanent delegation having been withdrawn last week.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- A spokesman for the pro-German parties in the Saar warned the Bonn and Paris Governments today to refrain from interfering in the territorial referendum Oct. 23.

LONDON, Oct. 4--A plan providing for parallel progress toward German reunification and European security will be offered to the Soviet Union by three Western powers at the foreign ministers' meeting in Geneva this month.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 4 -- The purpose of the United States economic and military aid to Pakistan was defined tonight by a Pakistani as an effort to help Pakistan build the same kind of "paradise" that Americans have built through the free-enterprise system.

We congratulate Edward Connors on his appointment as chief of the New York Fire Department to fill the position left vacant by Chief Loftus' retirement. While Chief Connors' continued service will depend on the results of a future civil service examination, his selection now is a well-earned reward for exceptional service.
The ashes of Dr. Henry W. Frauenthal, founder of the Hospital for Joint Dieases, were scattered yesterday from the roof of the hospital in Madison Avenue between 123d and 124th Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that he believed the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Geneva this month would make "positive progress" toward the unification of Germany.
MANY first steps, and perhaps some last as well, toward an exhibiting career are taken by artists at the New York City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street.

MONTREAL, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Royal Commission on Coasting Trade was told today that a situation could develop with completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway whereby the Canadian shipping industry would be ruined.
A Federal court jury took only twenty minutes yesterday to convict two trucking union officials of conspiracy to extort $64,000 from eleven milk haulers.

J. K. Paasikivi, President of the Republic of Finland, has agreed to be a patron of the all-Sibelius concert to be presented in Carnegie Hall on Dec. 4. The concert will honor the ninetieth birthday of the Finnish composer and the memory of Olin Downes, music critic of The New York Times.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 4 (AP) -- T. P. Fox, president of Associated Airways, Ltd., announced today that the line had relinquished responsibilities as prime contractor on the Distant Early Warning radar line airlift.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Ohio Valley Improvement Association adopted a resolution today opposing tolls and user charges on inland waterways.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Prince Albert of Belgium visited the United States Military Academy today, and as a result the Army football squad regained the services of Halfback Mike Zeigler of Fairborn, Ohio.
A special referee may be named in Supreme Court to take testimony on contempt charges arising out of the eight-day waterfront strike in September.
The body of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, lay in state yesterday at the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) Armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WEST NEWTON, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- A runaway lumber truck crashed into a moving freight train here today. Several derailed freight cars were catapulted into two buildings. The truck driver and four persons in the buildings were killed.

A new one-story building at 91 Industrial Avenue in the Little Ferry Industrial Terminal in Little Ferry, N. J., has been leased by the Laine Electronics, Inc. The lessee, which manufactures electronic tubes, mercury switches and allied devices, will occupy more than twice the space it now has on Sussex Avenue in Newark. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Two Republican Senators said today they hoped President Eisenhower would seek re-election next year if he recovered sufficiently from his heart attack.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 4 -- If the Arab states reject the Jordan River water plan, Israel "will regard herself free to resume work on her national water schemes, such as the hydroelectric project north of the Sea of Galilee."
BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- Prof. Theodor Oberlaender, Minister for Refugees, demanded yesterday that the Russian language be taught in secondary schools in West Germany.

The New York State Committee for the White House Conference on Education yesterday urged the National Committee for the White House Conference to include higher education and adult education on its agenda.
There is some evidence that the little man in Wall Street does not expect a stock market crash.

The television screen has proved once again that it has the attraction of a powerful magnet during an event of public interest. During the recent world series many a diligent jobholder had a tussle with his will power.

The Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night presented its fifth ballerina of the season in the dual role of Odette-Odile in "Le Lac des Cygnes." This was Nadia Nerina, certainly one of its top-ranking stars.
Eight members of Congress, who toured New York slums and housing projects yesterday, will start public hearings today in an effort to break bottlenecks in public and private residential development.
Racketeers already are moving in on bingo operation in New York, a City Council committee was told yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler reported tonight the loss last month of $112,000,000 from the gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area. He warned that new curbs on spending were in prospect.

Copper prices tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York in the sharpest decline of the year. Yesterday was the fourth consecutive trading day of lower prices. The close was off 135 to 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on thirty-four lots. The volume was the third heaviest of the year.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Free selling of corn was stimulated today by the October Galvin-Dupont crop report, which estimated the crop at 3,148,000,000 bushels.
The Hanover Bank announced yesterday the election as trustees of L. L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, and Robert G. Page, president of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, copper producer.
Greater centralization of authority and responsibility for planning, supervising and executing the city's housing program was recommended yesterday by Mayor Wagner's Committee for Better Housing.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The stock markets here staged a small rally late in the session today, but it generally failed to cancel early losses. Declines, although mostly small, far outnumbered gains at the close.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The start of the six months' voluntary training program initiates a period of major adjustment in military manpower.

Delegates to the tenth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., voted overwhelmingly yesterday in support of five constitutional amendments backed by their president, Joseph Curran.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 4 -- Canada and the United States should be the first nations in the world to set up a system of free trade, according to Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. He addressed Canadian business leaders attending the annual meeting of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce here today. "If free trade could exist anywhere on earth, it should succeed here," he said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India urged the United Nations today to accept nothing less than the total prohibition of nuclear weapons, regardless of the positions taken by the United States and the Soviet Union.

In its first change of ownership since 1919, the five-story brick dwelling on lot 20 by 102 feet at 12 East Eighty-first Street has been sold by the estate of Clinton W. Sweet to Irving Lent for occupancy. It was sold for cash in a deal negotiated by Talman Bigelow, Inc., broker. The property is assessed at $58,000.
New York City would spend $799,876,189 for its major public improvements next year under a capital budget brought out yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Coal interests in all parts of the country joined today in telling the Interstate Commerce Commission they cannot go on paying present freight rates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Two study groups recommended today a long list of improvements in two key areas of Government statistics.
A new automobile liability insurance coverage was announced yesterday. It will indemnify owners of insured cars for personal injuries caused by uninsured drivers.

TAZA, French Morocco, Oct. 4 -- Moroccan guerrillas threatened late today Aknoul, the French command post forty miles north of here, where Abd el Krim, rebel leader in the Riff war three decades ago, made his headquarters.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 -- Nurses served notice today that they would increase efforts to improve their working conditions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The Democratic party's National Advisory Committee on Political Organization ended a two-day meeting today. It submitted recommendations to the National Democratic Committee on procedures and techniques for the 1956 campaign.

CAIRO, Oct. 4 -- Armed rebels in Algeria and Morocco merged their guerrilla forces Sunday under a unified military command, according to an announcement made here today by exiled nationalist leaderes of both territories.

Franklin Butler Kirkbride, the announcement of whose death appeared in your issue of Sept. 29, was in many respects a most distinguished, lovable and effective personage. I knew him only in his later years, but during that period my contacts with him were close.

The Communists are well aware, just as the Nazis were, of the importance of sports in the field of propaganda. They are making full use of it. The significance of the Olympic Games is, fortunately, being increasingly recognized by the people of this country.

Members of the board of directors of the Young Women's Christian Association will give their annual luncheon in behalf of the organization on Oct. 20 in the ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. J. Ogden Bulkley is chairmain of the luncheon committee. Guests of honor at the event will be Sir Pierson Dixon, permanent British representative at the United Nations, and Peggy Wood.

At the Indian Science Congress held in Baroda Dr. Homi J. Bhabha, India's leading nuclear physicist, suggested that some day it would be possible to control a thermonuclear reaction, meaning that the fusion of hydrogen into helium, which is what happens in a hydrogen bomb, would be utilized for the production of power.
Dodger hysteria manifested itself in curious ways yesterday after the last out at Yankee Stadium saw the Brooklyns lifted to their first modern baseball championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Supporters of France decided today not to make any immediate effort to reverse the decision by the United Nations General Assembly to put the Algerian question on its agenda. Such an effort may be made in about two weeks.

AN EXCELLENT whole-wheat bread with a plain, wheaty flavor, the kind that is delicious with sweet butter, is baked at the Trappist monastery, Our Lady of the Holy Cross, at Berryville, Va., sixty miles west of Washington.

ONE man: three women. With the exception of an elderly Italian who makes two microscopic appearances, that is the entire population of Ugo Betti's "Island of Goats," which opened at the Fulton last evening.

Two 14-year-old Brooklyn boys suddenly got a "bright idea" while in the Brooklyn Museum Saturday afternoon and took eight silver figurines on exhibition. The police said the boys told them this last night and turned over two of the eight pieces of sculpture, Panther and Statuette of the Virgin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles has told Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov that delivery of arms from the Soviet bloc to Egypt would not help relax tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4. -- A new flood crisis for the city of Tampico was reported in the offing today. The overflowing Panuco River continued to spread block after block as the result of torrential rains that accompanied the recent Hurricane Janet.

The New Fork Clearing House Association at its 102d annual meeting yesterday elected S. Sloan Colt as president. Mr. Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company succeeds N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, former president of the Association.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The United Nations program to end the problem of European refugees was reported today to be in jeopardy. The situation was attributed to the slowness of governments to contribute.

The First National City Bank of New York and its affiliate, the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, had net current earnings of $30,812,331, or $3.08 a share, for the first nine months this year. This compares with earnings of $24,512,394 for the similar period last year, or $2.45 a share, calculated on the 10,000,000 shares now outstanding.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 4 (UP) -- Billy XIV, the Navy mascot, was tucked safely in his pen again today.

Five thousand invalid children, nurses and doctors spilled out on the Bellevue Hospital grounds yesterday morning for the twenty-sixth annual visit of the World's Championship Rodeo. Featured performers headed by Roy Rogers and his horse Trigger gave a show in the area facing the East River behind the hospital buildings at Twenty-eighth Street.
Two small waterfront strikes, involving 250 ship repair yard machinists and about 600 longshoremen handling bulk commodities, continued yesterday.
Prison sentences were handed out to four confessed nareotics dealers in Federal Court yesterday.
Brooklyn's long cherished dream finally has come true. The Dodgers have won their first world series championship.
SEOUL, Korean, Oct. 4 -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet said here today that for the next several years Communist China would be a greater menace than the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The State Department made public the text of the note delivered yesterday to the Soviet Foreign Ministry in Moscow challenging that government to maintain its responsibilities for free communications between Berlin and West Germany.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4--There is a saying in Paraguay that when there is storm in Buenos Aires rain comes to Asuncion three days later.

Reports from Paris this week reveal that the French franc in the black market has gone to a discount wider than any that has obtained over the previous two years. The official value of the franc has not been changed since shortly after the general devaluation of 1949, when it was set at a rate which was the equivalent of 349.50 to 350 francs to the dollar.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 4 -- Moscow's decision to peddle arms in the Middle East makes swift settlement of the Cyprus crisis more urgently needful than ever. Britain and Turkey maintain that British presence in the island is strategically necessary to defense of the eastern Mediterranean.

IF the sales clerk at your favorite shop tells you that tunics are good this year, that brown is one of the newest colors, or that tweeds are excellent fashion, listen to what she says. For she has educated herself -- or her store has educated her -- to help you.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 4 -- The Netherlands and Indonesian Governments, at odds since Indonesia won her independence in 1949, have agreed to explore the possibility of formal discussions to improve relations.

With reference to Leonard Buder's recent excellent article on P. S. 35, Manhattan, a reference should be made, I believe, to the time when this school housed the Boys' High School, opened in 1897 with a somewhat nondescript group of 400 boys who hailed from the Battery to the Harlem River and from the East to the North River.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Public Health Service today announced award of the first three fellowships under a new program making $625,000 available specifically for research grants and fellowships in nursing.
The battle over the coupon -- does it help or harm food merchandising? -- flared in a heated debate yesterday at the Sales Executives Club's luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon got a report today on the explosive farm price-cost squeeze. This was the first major Administration activity on this political subject since President Eisenhower's illness.

The Midas touch for evening has taken the form of glamorous small hats in hand-crocheted gold tinsel. To prove that all that glitters like gold is not expensive, some of these hats, by Madcaps, may be purchased at New York stores for $11 and less.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- British anthropologists are trying to reconstruct the physical appearance of the ancient Minoans of Crete by measuring and fitting together their skeletal remains.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- Prof. Seymour E. Harris of Harvard University issued a plea today for tax relief for New England textiles and other nondefense industries in their struggle to recover from the August floods.
Election of John M. Downs and Ford F. Robinson as vice presidents of the Curtis Publishing Company, was announced yesterday by Robert E. MacNeal, president.

Three Ohio authors will be honored Oct. 22 with Ohioana awards for their contributions to the book world in the fields of fiction, non-fiction and juvenile. Agatha Young will receive the citation award for "Clown of the Gods" (Random House).

It had been so long since the Yankees had lost a world series -- 1942, to be exact -- they seemed to forget how beaten finalists are supposed to act. Less than two minutes after the last out had been made at the Stadium yesterday, the Bombers were in their spacious dressing room, moving quietly and with dignity, as they prepared to shower and pack.
Major public utility companies raised $45,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of long-term debt securities at public bidding.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- J. L. Van Volkenburg, president of Columbia Broadcasting System-Television, testified in Federal Court today that his company had not tried to obtain feature films for use in television during the last five years.

"WHAT'S that you're reading?" asked my wife. "The jacket looks crazy." It does, too, being cartoons of two men and two women with the men's heads on the women's bodies and other surprising rearrangements. After a pause, while I searched for the mot just, I replied: "It's without doubt the damnedest novel I ever read.
EMIL GILELS, the Russian pianist, is here because of the "Geneva spirit," and he is welcome to stay and play for us as long as he pleases. He is a great pianist.

An optimistic corps of buyers for stores in all parts of the country began one of their periodic shopping sprees in the New York women's apparel market yesterday. They thronged Seventh Avenue salons to view the new collections of sportswear and casual clothes.

In reaction to three days of losses, stocks shot upward at yesterday's opening, held their gains through the noon hour and then went into a state of suspended animation while Brooklyn won the World Series.

Thubten Jigme Norbu, elder brother of the Dalai Lama, spiritual ruler of Tibet, has arrived here to seek American citizenship. He is a voluntary exile from his country, which is under Communist control.

"THE ANSWER," Philip Wylie's fantasy of thermonuclear bombs and angels, was made into a television dramatization last night on Channel 4. It is a story that perhaps can be told better in words than by the literal camera of TV.
ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- Establishment of a state-wide family court to handle all civil matters involving parents and children was recommended today to the State Commission on Youth and Delinquency.
A "get tough" policy by transit and union officials took out most of the drive yesterday of the "sick" strike by 143 motormen on Queens IND subway trains.

WICHITA. FALLS, Tex., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Swollen waters of the Wichita River and its tributaries chased hundreds from their North Texas homes today, smashed a main-line railroad bridge and spread across highways.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Two leading United States officials concerned with foreign aid policies arrived in Tokyo today.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 4 -- Gen. Juan D. Peron said today he still was the "constitutional President" of Argentina.

The performance of "A View From the Bridge" on the night of Nov. 21 at the Coronet Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for Greenwich House. Mrs. Herbert Scheftel is chairman of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the event and Mrs. Charles Allen is co-chairman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Paramount Pictures announced today that it had concluded negotiations to purchase "The Chalk Garden," a play by Enid Bagnold. The play is in the process of making its way to a Broadway opening.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 4 (UP) -- A group of Houston business men today offered to buy the town of Grants, N. M. Their price was $500,000, which is just about what the booming New Mexico uranium town needs to avert bankruptcy.

With "The Diary of Anne Frank," which relights the Cort at 8 o'clock tonight, Kermit Bloomgarden will have two attractions on the boards. Last week "A View from the Bridge" was jointly brought in by him, Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- Rear Admiral Alberto Teisaire, former Vice President, publicly called Gen. Juan D. Peron today the greatest blackguard in Argentine history -- and himself one of its greatest fools.

The brisk but pleasant autumn days in store for us are made to order for an excursion into the country. A twofold project for a family expedition of this kind was suggested recently by staff members of the American Museum of Natural History.
This was Johnny Podres' moment, and he was making the most of it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Samuel C. Waugh - who spent forty years learning the banking business in the Midwest -- was sworn today as president of the Export-Import Bank. The oath was administered by John R. Crown, the bank's assistant secretary, while some 200 employes of the bank and Mr. Waugh's friends looked on the board room.

OTTAWA, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The chairman of the International Joint Commission's United States Section said today that Canadian proposals for diversion of the Columbia River would result in "very great injury to the United States."

A grin is spread today across the face of a borough. The grin starts at Borough Hall and extends to Flatbush Avenue, along Eastern Parkway and up and down the banks of the Gowanus. Gone are the miseries of Brooklyn's inhabitants and far away are bitter memories of past failures.

IF the good burghers of Brooklyn are pinching themselves with unaccustomed violence this morning, they need do so no longer. It wasn't a dream, folks. Implausible though it may seem, the Dodgers won the world championship for the first time in their history yesterday. Honest, injun. It really did happen.
Your account of the French walkout from the General Assembly of the United Nations shows quite clearly the dangers facing the United Nations in dealing with issues of domestic jurisdiction.

Cotton futures came back fairly well on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, following losses extending to $7.70 a bale on Monday. The recovery was attributed in good part to technical factors. Final prices were up 10 cents to $3.95 a bale.

AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 4 -- The light of the sun was harnessed to power a rural telephone circuit near here this morning. At 10 A. M. a Bell Telephone Company engineer threw a switch to shift a rural circuit from usual battery power to operation on electricity made from solar energy.
Manager Walter Alston's adherence to baseball's right-left "percentage" code gave Sandy Amoros the chance to be one of the heroes of the Dodgers' series-clinching triumph over the Yankees yesterday.

EVERY homemaker is bound to pick up a few new decorating ideas from the seven model rooms that go on public view today at Bloomingdale's. Henriette Granville, who does the rooms for the store, has a sophisticated flair that enhances the modern furniture on which she relies with an unusual elegance and warmth.

THE verbal side of the outdoors will get some concentrated attention during the next few days. Starting tonight and continuing through Saturday, the New York State Conservation Council will be in session at Poughkeepsie.
The National Association of Manufacturers gave a preview here yesterday of its Americade, a traveling exhibition of the American economic future that will open in Syracuse on Oct. 11.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Mail order catalogues have made a hit with foreign nationals who visit the overseas libraries of the United States Information Service.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The old but still vigorous hand of Abd el Krim, which wrote one of the bloodiest chapters of Morocco's history during the Nineteen Twenties, is seen again in the current uprisings in the Riff and Middle Atlas Mountains.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday he was seeking to question a prominent business man concerning a swindle that "may run into hundreds of thousands of dollars."

There was high excitement among the fans and the official followers of the teams yesterday as the Dodgers and Yankees prepared to square away against each other in their contest for the world's baseball championship.

The Union Pacific Railroad has sold in the open market during the last several weeks its remaining securities investment in the Chicago and North Western Railway. The road disclosed yesterday it had sold its holding of 12,888 shares of preferred stock and $2,152,500 principal amount of second mortgage convertible 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the North Western.

ROME, Oct. 4 -- Soviet and satellite officials went to church this morning in Florence. They attended a solemn mass celebrated in the presence of Elia Cardinal Dalla Costa, Archbishop of Florence, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Jake McCandless, Kent School's new football coach, spent the early part of this afternoon in his English class. He delved into the intricacies of participal, gerundive, prepositional and infinitive phrases before an alert group of second-formers.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it was planning to receive bids on Nov. 16 on issues of serial bonds totaling $159,070,000.
A telephone installer yesterday gave the millionth pint of blood received by the New York Regional Red Cross since the start of its blood program on May 4, 1948.
UNION CITY, Okla., Oct. 4 (AP) -- George Skakel Sr. of Greenwich, Conn., chairman of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, was killed together with his wife in a plane crash last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today new, reduced trans-Pacific air mail rates that would save the Government $5,900,000 this year in payments to airlines. The new rates would apply to mail carried by Pan American World Airways, Inc., and Northwest Airlines, Inc., from the West Coast to points in Alaska, Hawaii, Japan and other areas.

The "Under new management" sign goes up at Belmont Park today when the Greater New York Association, Inc., takes over the operation of the thoroughbred racing in this state. The other tracks to come under the direction of the new organization are Aqueduct, Jamaica and Saratoga.
Beth David Hospital, which early next year will move from East Ninetieth Street to East Forty-second Street, took title to its new home yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles indicated today that, except in urgent matters, important foreign policy decisions would be postponed until President Eisenhower was well enough to give them his personal attention.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Oct. 4. -- Two weeks after its opening game with Benny Friedman's Brandeis eleven, Boston College returns to action Saturday against Villanova.

THE Allies had not forgotten what had happened after World War I. When the armistice was signed on Nov. 11, 1918, the German armies were still massed in formation on the Western Front, and this front lay in France and Belgium. Nowhere was there any foreign military on German soil.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, arrived here today for a one-week visit. He was welcomed at Moscow's flag-bedecked Vnukovo airport by Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, who was in exceptionally good spirits.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Anthony J. Celebrezze, the first foreign - born Mayor ever elected by Clevelanders, crushed both the Democratic and Republican organizations yesterday to win re-election in the primary.

Plans for a ten-story apartment house at 311-13 East Forty-third Street, near the northeast corner of Second Avenue, were announced yesterday as a plot 50 by 100 feet there was sold by Fred H. Hill to Harry Seeve.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The second and last of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's London concerts ended tonight with a performance of Shostakovich's Tenth Symphony. Few who heard it will readily forget it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union asked the United Nations today to assist in the drive to repatriate nationals of Communist countries. But it found a cool reception.

The attitude of the General Assembly of the United Nations in refusing to include the Cyprus item in the agenda of its present session would appear to have been influenced in no small measure by the statement of the British delegate that the way to further direct negotiation on the subject had been left open by the British Government at the London conference.
An involuntary petition in bankruptcy was filed yesterday against a real estate firm headed by Robert Morman, who is being sought for questioning by Distract Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Senate's Constitutional Rights subcommittee has called off scheduled hearings on freedom of religion that had threatened to provoke an angry controversy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Harvey O'Connor said today he refused to answer a question from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy on communism in July, 1953, because he felt the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee was engaged in "depredations on the liberties of citizens."

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday increases in operating earnings and lending activities for the third quarter, but decreases in total deposits and holdings of United States Government securities.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The French Government demanded today that Spain stop rebel guerrillas from entering the French zone of Morocco.
The change of Government in Argentina has yet to produce any actual or potential improvement in its trade with the United States, an export credit group heard yesterday.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 5 -- The greatest importance was being attached here today to the mobilization of the Moslem inhabitants of western Algeria against terrorist raiders reported to come from Spanish Morocco.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- The State Conference on Youth and Delinquency rejected today the night stick-curfew-jail approach to combating youthful crime.
LONDON, Oct.5 -- Three Irishmen were sentenced today to life imprisonment for an Irish Republican Army raid on a British army camp.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks led the field as the third annual women's New York State senior golf championship began today.
A 17-year-old boy was accused early today of the fatal shooting of a Parks Department attendant at an upper East Side playground yesterday afternoon. Three other youths also were arrested.
Ray Vir Den, publisher of The Daily American in Rome and president of the Dutch Treat Club, presented the Halmi portrait of his wife, the late Frances Alda, to the Metropolitan Opera yesterday.

Earnings of the General American Oil Company of Texas were in excess of $7,500,000, or about $5.50 a share, in the fiscal year ended last June 30, stockholders were told, at the annual meeting in Dallas yesterday. In the preceding fiscal year the net was $6,572,810, or $5.49 a share, of which $2,300,000 was a nonrecurring profit from sale of properties.
DISCUSSION here the other day about Long Island Sound flounder fishing led to the reflection that New York's seagoing back yard had other fish besides those trifling tuggers to offer the angler.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 5 -- Five thugs looted a home of $100,000 worth of jewelry and furs here last night and forced one victim to accompany them on their escape.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Political followers of Gen. Charles de Gaulle decided tonight to ask French Premier Edgar Faure to resign in favor of a government of national union.
CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser said today he had informed Washington in June that Egypt would buy arms from the Soviet Union if the United States would not supply them.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 -- The Peronist leadership of Argentina's powerful General Confederation of Labor collapsed tonight.

To the 18,358 racing fans at Belmont yesterday, there was little to indicate that a change in the operation of the sport had taken place. Although the Greater New York Association, Inc., was in charge of the promotion, having superseded all other thoroughbred organizations in the state, the program was presented in exactly the same manner as always.

The City Planning Commission has submitted a 1956 capital budget of $799,876,189 for public hearings to be held at City Hall next week. Of this total, $331,212,251 would come from funds that are exempt from the city's constitutional debt limit, with $468,663,938 left within the debt limit.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Diplomatic informants said today the United States, Britain and France were devoting all resources of their diplomacy to short-circuiting the Soviet block arms deal with Egypt.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Bill Walsingham Jr. quit as vice president of the St. Louis Cardinals today as the head of the club conferred with Frank Lane, expected to be named tomorrow as the new general manager.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has assured publishers that newspapers can print anything they like about proxy contests without running afoul of the commission's rules.

Talk to a friend over the telephone and the voice weakens so much with distance that it must be amplified if it is to reach its destination. Here the vacuum tube enters -- the Aladdin lamp of this electronic age. It can make the walking of a fly sound like a cavalcade, the ticking of a watch like a trip-hammer.
Times Square may be the gayest, brightest spot in the world. But it can be a lonely, bewildering place for a young serviceman on his first trip to Manhattan.
ROLLING nuts, chocolate, coconut or poppy seeds into pasty adds interest to the pies, which still hold top place among favorite American desserts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (AP) Negotiations are under way for the possible sale of Crown Zellerbach Corporation's 50 per cent interest in Fibreboard Products Corporation to Pabco Products Corporation, officials of Crown Zellerbach and Pabco announced today. Pabco already owns the other 50 per cent interest in Fibreboard.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Mrs. Irving Gushen's Star Rover hung on in the stretch today to win the $18,750, Longport Handicap on the final day of racing here.
ATHENS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Greece moved quickly tonight to form a new Government as the nation mourned the death of Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, the Premier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Premier Nasser's statement that he had warned Washington he would get Soviet arms if the United States delayed filling his request was received by Washington officials with incredulity.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends, as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
THEY have made a lovely, tender drama out of "The Diary of Anne Frank," which opened at the Cort last evening. They have treated it with admiration and respect.

THERE was an air of unreality to the recent world series. It was as if the script for it had been penned by Lewis Carroll after he'd acquired the feel for the job by writing Alice in Wonderland. This was a series, you see, where everything got curiouser and curiouser.

DEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Melvin B. Ellis of the Jewish faith was ordered arrested today after he had failed to appear in court to answer a charge of contempt for failure to turn over his adopted daughter, Hildy, 4 years old, to her natural mother, a Roman Catholic.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -Arthur Godfrey settled his difdifferences and difficulties with the Civil Aeronautics Administration for $500 today.

A large number of patrons are contributing their support to the Oct. 24 benefit performance of "No Time for Sergeants" at the Alvin Theatre. Miss Jessie Mann is chairman of the theatre party, which will aid the Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children at Farmingdale, N. J.

All-aluminum ships are feasible but will not be built until the disparity in cost between the light metal and steel is reduced, William C. White, president of the Alcoa Steamship Company, said yesterday.

The National Safety Council has made public some statistics that every motorist who values his life should consider. Their gist is that more mileage is being run up on the nation's roads this year than last year, and more people are being killed in traffic accidents.

As Brooklyn dug itself out yesterday from under a record-shattering night of riotous celebration, officials of the newly crowned world champion Dodgers were already busy looking ahead to 1956 and beyond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 28:
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The British Labor party took its first step toward political recovery today. It announced a detailed plan for the reorganization of its vote-getting machinery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that ninety-two of the ninety-four United States District Attorneys were appointed by President Eisenhower.
Governor Harriman's Administration is trying to persuade liability insurance companies to shoulder new responsibilities in the highway safety field.

Irmgard Keun, German author of nine books, will have an American edition of her novel, "The Bad Example," published Oct. 17 by Harcourt, Brace. When the concern sought biographical information on the author, it inquired of her former English publisher, who revealed that "to the best of my knowledge she died many years ago."

Specialists repeat continually that it takes "mature" parents and teachers to develop well-adjusted children. Just what they mean by "mature," however, is rarely spelled out. Karl S. Bernhardt presents a thumbnail description of the mature adult in a recent bulletin of Toronto University's Institute of Child Study.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that "For America," a group organized by Clarence Manion who was ousted from a Federal post last year, had been denied tax exemption for its financial contributors.
The City Council bill for regulating "legal" bingo would serve no useful purpose, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Canada supported President Eisenhower's "open sky" disarmament proposal today as a "bold step" that might break the long East-West deadlock.

NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 5 -- Strikers and nonstrikers fought a pitched gun battle here today at the Perfect Circle Corporation foundry. Eight persons were wounded. A near-by house that had sheltered city policemen was set on fire.
The Transit Authority completed hearings yesterday for 107 of the 143 Queens IND subway motormen who took part in a "sick" strike. Monday.
Stock prices rose yesterday morning, moved gently upward through most of the day and sold off near the close. There were moderate net gains, notably, among aircrafts, rails, oils, steels and papers.
United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc. achieved in its fiscal year ended on last June 30 an increase of 69.7 per cent in earnings over the previous year on a sales gain of 13.7 per cent.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies today released unconditionally Eddie Waitkus and Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey.
