Monroe County, Fla., Special Tax School District No. 1 sold yesterday $2,750,000 of building bonds due serially from 1957 to 1975 to B. J. Van Ingen Co. and associates at a bid of 100.1055 for obligations bearing interest of 3.5 per cent and 3.4 per cent, an interest cost of 3.425 per cent. Reoffering was at yields of 2 to 3.4 per cent.

A professor in the Department of History at Columbia University has been appointed dean of the Graduate Faculties. He is Dr. Jacques Barzun, a member of the department since 1927. He succeeds Dr. Edgar G. Miller, who died in June.

Two of the highest officers of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., were condemned yesterday by delegates to the union's tenth biennial convention for "setting themselves above the will of the membership."

THORSHAVN, Faeroe Islands, Oct. 5 (Reuters) -- Danish policemen have arrested five Klaksvik villagers on charge of having helped hold the Faroese Governor as a hostage last week in protest against the transfer of the island physician.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Rain in the Central West and Southwest stimulated buying of soybeans and corn, with prices for both moving up.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Press representatives in the Pentagon helped today to halt circulation of a document by the Defense Department that would have disclosed the complete world pattern of Air Force bases.

" The Treasurer's Report," by and with the late Robert Benchley, and "A Bill of Divorcement," the David O. Selznick production featuring John Barrymore, Katharine Hepburn and Billie Burke, will be shown at 8:45 tonight at the Museum of Modern Art.
The unfortunate illness of President Eisenhower has been the occasion of much comment in the press respecting the use of Executive power during the interim caused by the President's indisposition.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, decided unanimously today to start work Friday with a discussion of the atoms-for-peace program.
DETROIT, Oct. 5 -- The Ford Motor Company announced plans today for a $50,000,000 expansion of its research and engineering center in Dearborn Mich.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 5 -- South Korea's acting Foreign Minister, Cho Chung Hwan, accused the State Department today of not knowing the facts in regard to the tax dispute between his Government and United States business men here. He said the United States Embassy had failed to inform the State Department fully.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories demonstrated today a radio that works on only the energy of a human voice.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Treasury advised Congress today against taking it for granted that the Eisenhower Administration would recommend tax relief next year.

A record expenditure of $100,000,000 in the next five years for plant expansion and new construction will be made by the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation. This was disclosed yesterday by Alexander M. Beebee, president.

The five-story office and store building at 535 East Tremont Avenue and the adjoining apartment and store building at 4216 Third Avenue, in the Bronx, have been purchased by the Goodman-Herman Company, operators. The estate of Charles Klapow was the seller.
DENVER, Oct. 5 -- President Eisenhower's grandchildren want him to chomp on bubblegum while his heart mends.
Tributes to Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler and messages of condolence to his family continued yesterday. Among the messages were:

LOS ANGELES (Science Service) -- From the standpoint of mental health, the second year is the most important one of a child's life, according to Dr. Henry Work of the University of California (at Los Angeles) Medical Center.
A MASTERLY performance of Bela Bartok's Violin Concerto came as the climax of Anahid Ajemian's recital in Town Hall last night.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 5 -- While relations between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union are becoming more nearly normal than in the past, there has been no similar rapprochement between Belgrade and the other Communist Governments of Eastern Europe.

" BEHIND THE PICTURE WINDOW,"* by Bernard Rudofsky, is an enthusiastic assault on all sorts of ideas that domestic man cherishes and holds dear. It is all fair enough, though. For Mr. Rudofsky conducts his cheerful demolitions with familiar weapons of spoof and paradox that for centuries have been cherished and held dear by conscientious satirists.
The local Red Cross will collect blood today from the Army Ordnance District here, the Army Audit Agency and the Social Security Administration at 179 Varick Street.
BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- A delegation of Russian housing experts covered miles of unfinished streets and acres of freshly polished floors today in quest of trade secrets of American construction.
A Wall Street economist has measured the extent of last week's market break on 1,000 active common stocks listed on the Big Board.

In a dispatch appropriately datelined "Moscow" The Associated Press reports that American Legion conventions in two near-by communities have asked the University of Idaho to cancel a scheduled speech by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic.

Charles Abrams, State Rent Administrator, declared yesterday that New York City urgently needed a systematic survey of housing conditions in the five boroughs as the basis for a coordinated attack on its housing problems.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Democrats to the contrary, Republicans will open their 1956 national convention in San Francisco Aug. 20 as planned.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today a complaint accusing more than 100 wholesale druggists across the country of receiving illegal brokerage fees.
All eight silver figurines that two mischievous high school boys stole last Saturday afternoon from the Brooklyn Museum were restored yesterday afternoon.
The economy of the United States is on a very sound foundation, Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, said yesterday.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 5 -- There was an overabundance of incongruous-looking equipment on hand this afternoon as Choate School's football squad reported for its regular workout. In back of the north goal posts were two dozen medicine balls.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Six Russians who had decided to leave the West and return to their homeland changed their minds after less than two weeks under Soviet control and sought sanctuary here, it was announced today.
Tens of thousands of home- bound riders sweltered in a fifty-minute tie-up on the Lexington Avenue line of the I. R. T. subway at the height of last evening's rush hour.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Marge and Gower Champion, the husband-and-wife dancing team, have acquired "Chicago Blues" as the first property to be filmed by their independent company, Champion-Five, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The White House is expected to announce soon the names of twelve members of a bipartisan commission to review the Federal security program for government employes.

Much is being written about safety features in the 1956 cars. While safety is important to all of us, designing and building cars for more economical maintainance is equally important. Just about every car owner has had the aggravating experience of repeated expense in having a host of little things repaired, mainly because the car makers did not see fit to build a little more quality into their cars.
The Giants, who with the close of the regular season signed Biil Rigney to succeed Leo Durocher as their manager, made their first step yesterday toward rehabilitating their fortunes in 1956.
DENVER, Thursday, Oct. 6 -- President Eisenhower's doctors reported yesterday there was medical evidence that the healing process was under way in the damaged area of the President's heart.
FEZ, French Morocco, Oct. 5 -- Rebel resistance to French forces in the Riff Mountains north of here showed some signs of relaxing today.

The sudden death yesterday of Dr. Thomas T. Mackie has taken away from us one of our most eminent scientists at the peak of a long career devoted to human betterment. His field was tropical medicine and he became pre-eminent in it. He wrote with authority and spoke with assurance because he insisted upon having all his facts and upon getting them from personal observation.

Paul G. Hoffman urged non-Communist nations last night to rededicate themselves to policies of mutual cooperation and defensive strength. He said this should be done in the hope that the Soviet Union eventually would accept sincere coexistence with the free world.

Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, sailed for home yesterday. During a brief stay here, he conferred with Secretary of State Dulles, British Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan and French Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay.
Expect a reasonable number of cut lips, lumps on the head, blisters on the fingers and chipped teeth, parents of children from 1 to 5 are advised by Dr. Harry F. Dietrich in a new safety booklet.

CULVER CITY, Calif, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Howard Hughes, the movie-maker and industrialist, today threw open his long secret aviation plant to the press. He unveiled an electronic automatic marksman that guides rocket-armed interceptors toward attacking bombers with deadly accuracy.

Fresh produce, a late entrant in the field of branded merchandise, is doing so well in an advertising premium test barely a month old that two big West Coast packers behind the drive are considering a major promotional campaign.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said here today that many American farmers were not getting an "equitable return" for their efforts. He said that the Eisenhower Administration was "determined to do what is right and fair to alleviate that situation."
BUFFALO, Oct. 5 -- A state official underscored the need today for teachers in the nursing profession.
BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A Government economist today predicted spectacular gains in the national economy in the next ten years.

A decline of 539,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 151,266,000 barrels, compared with 151,805,000 a week earlier and 152,118,000 a year ago.

Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" program will present a historical study of the Vice Presidency of the United States in its seasonal debut on Wednesday, Oct. 26, from 9 to 10 P. M. The program will be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York underwent one of the sharpest breaks of the year yesterday. The volume, 4,610 tons, was the tenth heaviest of the year. Trading was influenced by weakness in London and easier prices and increased offerings from the Far East. Final quotations here were off 185 to 240 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- It is said that deficit financing by the Government is inflationary. This week came some direct evidence of how and why it is -- but with some additional evidence about why there is a bit more to the problem than meets the eye.
The library of the late Theodore Goodman, Professor of English at City College for thirty years, was presented to the college yesterday by his widow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Resumption of vaccination against poliomyelitis was approved today by the executive board of the American Academy of Pediatrics. The board is the governing group of some 4,000 children's doctors throughout the country.

Following are excerpts from Mayor Wagner's statement on New York City housing yesterday to the Rains subcommittee of the House of Representatives Committee on Banking and Currency at the Sheraton-Astor Hotel:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The Assembly's Trusteeship Committee set the stage today for an airing of grievances by dissidents among the populations of French-administered territories, unchallenged by the representatives of France.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Britain's new commercial television network is running into difficulties after only two weeks in business. It cannot sell advertising time on morning shows designed for housewives.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced a 100,000-ton increase in sugar import quotas for 1955.
A new play by Edmund Morris called "The Wooden Dish," starring Louis Calhern, makes its Broadway debut tonight at the Booth Theatre at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- New York State savings bankers were urged today to seek wider branch powers next year, rather than wait for recodification of the law, expected in 1957.

RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The honor system at ramp toll stations on the Garden State Parkway worked well during its six months of operation from March through August, the New Jersey Highway Authority reported today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Adhemar de Barros, businessman, and Juscelino Kubitschek, a Socialist with Communist backing, were running a close race today as returns mounted in Brazil's Presidential election.
Settlement of a phase of the strike involving 650 bulk commodity handlers was reached here yesterday. The agreement will result in resumption of work on the waterfront's four sugar piers today.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The Russians intend to survey large parts of the Pacific, Atlantic and Antarctic Oceans between 1957 and 1958 as part of their contribution to the International Geophysical Year.

Every now and then a man will sit down before his typewriter and write bravely, fearlessly, about something he feels strongly and deeply. He may or may not know, as he writes, that he will be assailed bitterly for his views.

The Clevite Corporation has acquired Intermetal G. m. b. H. of Dusseldorf, Germany, second largest European producer of transistors and diodes. The purchase price, which covered all of Intermetl's outstanding capital stock, was not disclosed.
A fireman and a truck driver died of injuries resulting from a collision between the two vehicles yesterday afternoon. Four other firemen were hurt.

GIMBELS' pint-sized customers are going to be spoiled this fall. The store's Young Boutique has just been flooded with imported clothes for children, and even babes-in-arms should look like something out of Junior Vogue in these styles.

The United Nations begins to present a strange spectacle these days. There was a time, in the days of violent Communist expansion under Stalin, when the free and independent nations stood shoulder to shoulder on major issues both in the Security Council and in the General Assembly.
Mayor Wagner disclosed yesterday a program for rehabilitating the West Side through Government and private enterprise.
LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 5 -- France and West Germany renewed tonight their support of a "European" status for the Saar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Corporations paid out more in dividends during the first eight months of this year than in any previous comparable period in United States history, the Department of Commerce reported today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Southern newspaper publishers were told today that a Government anti-trust suit against the American Newspaper Publishers Association threatened a newspaper's freedom to inform the public without fear of persecution

The offer of arms to Egypt by a Communist state was described yesterday as "particularly shocking to Americans" by the presidents of seventeen major Jewish organizations. In a joint statement, the signatories said they "shared Secretary of State Dulles' concern over Egypt's arms agreement" with Czechoslovakia.

The man who now wants to be known as just "plain Juan Peron" is not going to get his wish. Juan Peron has been a lot of things in his remarkable career, but one thing he has never been is plain or simple.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Despite earlier reports of a fall, the flooded Panueo River continued to rise here today. Additional heavy rains in the interior threatened new disasers for the devastated city.

THE final novelty of the Sadler's Wells Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House was its newly restaged version of "Les Sylphides," which was seen here for the first time last night. To think of Fekine's familiar masterpiece as a novelty is perhaps a bit of a stretch, but there is clearly an aspect of novelty in the present approach.
WOMEN prefer to be brunettes, according to a beautician who has been giving New Yorkers their choice of hair color for the last fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Martin P. Durkin, former Secretary of Labor, is in critical condition with a brain tumor. He is in Georgetown University Hospital.
A garden-type apartment house will be built for occupancy next summer on Wiltshire Road, near Heathcote Road, in the Scarsdale Downs section of New Rochelle, N. Y.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 6 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., Under Secretary of State, issued this morning a statement denying that he had given Japanese officials any reason for hope that the United States favored relaxation of controls over trade with Communist China.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Oct. 5 -- Ninety-seven feet under the Hudson River, a crew of sand-hogs constructing the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel crossed from New Jersey to New York this afternoon.

NAPLES, Italy, Oct. 5 -- Mount Vesuvius, quiescent and no longer adorned by a plume of smoke, looks down placidly upon some of the world's loveliest scenery. It looks with equal placidity on such poverty, want and misery as are exceeded in few other parts of Italy.
Mayor Achille Lauro of Naples was welcomed to New York yesterday by Mayor Wagner, who was his guest in Naples last June.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Price movements on the stock market were narrow arid showed no decided trend today. The only uniformly stronger section was British Government securities. These gained as much as 12s 6d ($1.75).

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, reprimanded the University of Chicago Law School today for concealing a microphone in a jury room at Wichita, Kan., as part of a jury study.
A funeral service will be held for Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, at 10 o'clock this morning in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took under advisement today a plea by the railroad industry to continue a temporary freight rate increase bringing it an estimated $1,000,000,000 a year.

Appointment of Hulbert S. Aldrich to the boards of directors in this city of member companies of the Royal-Liverpool Insurance Group was announced yesterday. These companies are the Royal Insurance Company, Ltd., Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, Ltd., British and Foreign Marine Insurance Company, Ltd., and Thames and Mersey Marine Insurance Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Lothair Teetor was reported today likely to resign soon as Assistant Secretary of Commerce. However, a spokesman for the department said "on the authority of Secretary [ Sinclair] Weeks" that the resignation has not been requested.

IN the centuries-old tradition of our colonial forefathers, heavily laden tables of delicious, authentic, dishes of yesteryear appeared as fare this week for a group of food editors at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street.

THESE are the statistics: The New York City Opera opened its twenty-fourth New York season last night at the City Center with Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor." It was the opera's fourth performance since its introduction last March.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- New York City wound up today its case before the Public Service Commission for an immediate $31,800,000-a-year cut in the New York Telephone Company's intra-state rates.

A 65-year-old city engineer is suing to upset his dismissal from the Public Works Department on charges that he failed to cooperate with a Department of Investigation inquiry into his activities. He ascribes his troubles to illness.

DECORATORS are doing things with doors. Such ornamentation is traditional in period decor; in many modern rooms, however, those doors that do exist (many have been eliminated by the open floor plan) are plain painted slabs.
SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 5 -- The Federal Government is about to put into effect a new approach to the age-old problem of assimilating the nation's Indians.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 -- Provisional President Eduardo Lonardi dismissed Argentina's Supreme Court and Attorney General today. In a brief decree noting that the re-establishment of judicial order is one of the country's most urgent needs, General Lonardi said his Government "assumed before history and the nation the responsibility" for ordering the dissolution of the nation's highest court.
The trailerships New York and Albany will soon resume their shuttle run between New York and Albany after an absence of three months, it was indicated yesterday.
Cotton futures closed 5 to 27 points (25 cents to $1.35 a bale) higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
ROME, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Fausto Gardini, the temperamental Italian tennis player, retained the national championship today.
Columbia's Claude Benham, the Ivy League football offense leader last year until he was hurt in mid-season, is off in front again, with most of his opposition coming from Princeton's Sidney Pinch.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Ambassadors of the United States and Communist China met for the nineteenth time today. After two hours and twenty minutes of secret discussion, they failed to report any progress toward easing tension in the Far East.

RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) -- A busiy Eddie Chavez earned a unanimous ten-round decision over Glen Flanagan tonight in their nationally televised bout. Chavez of San Jose, Calif., weighed 139 pounds and Flanagan of St. Paul, 139 1/2.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 5 -- Plans for a referendum to choose between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and the Chief of State, Bao Dai, are well under way.
Consolidated sales of the General Tire and Rubber Company reached a record $209,808,056 in the nine months ended Aug. 31. Earnings rose 55.3 per cent.
NO SPACE pioneer will need more dauntless spirit than does a sightless person. In a dark world of touch and sound a blind woman may find her own kitchen no less fearsome than a trip to the moon.
Earnings of the New York Central Railroad reached $38,601,296, equal to $5.93 a share, in the first nine months this year. In the same months of 1954 the company suffered a deficit of $5,121,146.

Canadair, Ltd., of Montreal, a subsidiary of General Dynamics Corporation, was awarded a contract yesterday to prepare a design and cost estimate for a "swing" type nuclear reactor, according to the parent company.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 5 (UP) -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight said today that if President Eisenhower did not run for reelection he would head a "favorite son" ticket in the California Presidential primary next June "regardless" of what Vice President Richard M. Nixon did.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 5 -- John Hay Whitney, New York investment banker and sportsman, has given Yale University $2,500,000 toward the purchase of three city high schools by the university.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- A top-level exchange visit between church leaders in this country and Russia was assured here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Eastern and Midwest railroads announced today they have agreed on a formula for dividing revenues from joint movement of freight traffic. Details were not immediately disclosed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The country's principal railroads and the Brotherhood of Railroad Train men reached a contract agreement early today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Vice President, with written authority from the President to supplement a prior verbal authorization, again this week will take the chair at meetings of the National Security Council and the Cabinet. There are four reasons why the President's choice of Richard M. Nixon was automatic.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The Army football team, preparing for one of its most formidable foes, Michigan, has been strengthened by the return of one of its swiftest backs. At the same time, another has been written off as lost probably for the season.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The capital's newsdealers today tossed out their Peronist boss, a central figure in the La Prensa seizure by the Peron Government.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 -- Jose Maria Whitaker resigned tonight as Finance Minister when President Joao Care Filho rejected his proposals for a more liberal foreign exchange policy.

A dream, not of dwelling, but of skating in marble halls, will come true for nine United states athletes late this month. They are the members of this country's roller skating team that will take part in the second international figure skating competition at the Palace of Sports in Barcelona.

TWENTIETH CENTURYFOX last night joined the list of major Hollywood studios doing their own television programs. This one was seen from 10 to 11 o'clock on Channel 2. It was more considerate of the viewer than some of its rivals, offering an abbreviated TV remake of Noel Coward's "Cavalcade" which at least reflected conscientious effort.

The United Corporation reported yesterday increases in net income for the first nine months of 1955 and in net asset value as of Sept. 30. Net income for the September quarter, however, fell slightly behind that of the like 1954 period.

Following is the text of the eulogy of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times, which was delivered by Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi, at General Adler's funeral service yesterday in Temple Emanu-El:

Fred H. Hill, as president of the Hansair Realty Corporation, has contracted to purchase the five-story dwelling at 7 East Eightieth Street, which has been occupied by the Satterthwaite family for more than fifty-five years. He plans to alter the structure into medical offices on the ground floor and two duplex apartments of seven and eight rooms on the upper four floors.
DENVER, Friday, Oct. 7 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will fly to Denver tomorrow at the President's request for a talk with General Eisenhower.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 6 -- Sharp reductions in Government spending ranging from the purchase of cattle food to the maintenance of battleships were forecast today by Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler.
TO the festive land of the Dodgers, where its citizens are still savoring the fruits of a first world series victory, Basil Rathbone and Helen Gahagan Douglas brought a bit of culture last night.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 -- The 1955 conference of the Federal Government and the ten Provincial Governments of Canada adjourned here late today. The sessions were inconclusive; but they found at least a new approach to the problem of fiscal relationships among the eleven governments.
Bill Rigney, recently appointed manager of the Giants to succeed Leo Durocher, was signed to a two-year contract yesterday.
FEZ, French Morocco, Oct. 6 -- The Resident General said today that the rebellion in the Riff Mountains "will become real war" if the Spanish authorities "do not police their zone of Morocco."

The Armco Steel Corporation, seventh largest steel producer in the nation, has decided to step up its expansion by $51,000,000 worth. This will be in addition to the $60,000,000 building program announced earlier this year.

IN addition to the exhibitions of Japanese prints at the New York Public Library and at the galleries of Warren E. Cox, a third exhibition is current at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue. This selection includes work by con temporaries illustrating the recent renaissance in print-making in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee announced today that it would open an investigation here Wednesday of a University of Chicago Law School project in which a microphone was concealed in a jury room.
IN response to the appeal for a good night's sleep, mattresses are growing in length and width.

VIENNA, Oct. 6 -- The Socialist and Peoples party, partners in Austria's coalition Government, are quarreling over the issue of nationalization of former German industries. Austria received these under the state treaty.
Congressional investigators were told yesterday that some of Long Island's relatively new communities already had developed signs of neighborhood decay and "suburban blight."
BUFFALO, Oct. 6 -- The State Nurses Association has accused the New York City Department of Hospitals of misrepresenting the nature of its job reclassification program for nurses.

PORTLAND, Maine, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A former shipmaster testified today that Maine's Maritime Academy offered practical education "far superior" to that given by the Federally operated King's Point (L. I.) Academy.

Henry K. Norton's proposal for integrated passenger transportation in the entire New York region is a far-seeing, bold plan to meet the challenge of metropolitan expansion. He has presented the citizens of our three-state area with a pattern for solution which deserves respect and searching study, rather than carping criticism of its details.
A former Staten Island bank teller received an eight-year penitentiary sentence yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on charges of embezzling more than $65,000 of the bank's funds.
Some of New York's largest savings banks are preparing to dip into a $250,000,000 pool for mortgage investment set up recently by Institutional Securities Corporation with the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Aluminium, Ltd., large Canadian aluminum producer, plans to nearly double its capacity for producing alumina -- or semi-processed bauxite -- in Jamaica, B. W. I., at a cost of $17,000,000.

Because the track was sloppy and slippery, as the result of the rain that started pelting the premises during the night, the Belair Stud's Nashua was scratched from the running of the $25,000 added Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Treasury agreed today to join Congressional staff experts in a thirty-day study of how to iron out inequities and inconsistencies in the excise tax structure.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York gained another victory in the women's challengers' chess tournament in Moscow. She is tied for first place in the standing with Mlle. M. Lazarevic of Yugoslavia, according to a report received last night.

" The-schools are quite different here." Prince Albert of Belgium observed yesterday on a visit to Columbia University. "There are more students and bigger buildings. But the main thing is that the professor takes more care."
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 -- The provisional Government indicated today that agriculture would be its immediate concern in the task of healing Argentina's economy.
The Transit Authority will complete hearings today for 143 Queens motormen who took part Monday in a "sick" strike on the IND line.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick, announcing the 1955 world series players' split yesterday, revealed that each member of the champion Dodgers would receive $9,768.21. The Dodgers voted thirty full shares. The individual amounts are the second highest winning shares in series history.

New Yorkers who sweltered through a fifty-minute tie-up Wednesday evening on the Lexington Avenue line of the I. R. T. had this consolation yesterday: The chairman of the Transit Authority was a fellow sufferer -- and he hated every minute of it.

HONG KONG, Oct. 6 -- Senator Estes Kefauver declared here today his observations in Malaya, Singapore and South Vietnam had caused him to alter an earlier impression that these places were lost from the standpoint of resisting world communism.
BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- Former President Harry S. Truman warned tonight to "beware of political budget cutters."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Any attempt to solve the internal problems of the motion picture business by relief through Federal regulation would result in "the most damaging situation we ever faced," Mitchell Wolfson warned in his opening address at the Theatre Owners of America Convention in Los Angeles today.
A 45 per cent Government construction subsidy to stimulate shipbuilding in American yards was recommended yesterday by Representative Francis E. Dorn, Republican of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Quaker welfare organization reported today a "startling" lowering of racial barriers in the nation's capital.

Custom smelters of copper, who refine the metal from purchased ores and scrap, trimmed the price of refined copper 1 1/2 cents a pound yesterday, to 47 cents. The large primary producers continued to quote 43 cents.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 6 -- Officials of the State Department said today that the admission of David Oistrakh, celebrated Russian violinist, for a concert tour of the United States had been approved in principle.
THE first strong autumnal rains yesterday beat down scarlet cannas and glowing marigold on city rooftop gardens and in the parks, grayed the city, snarled dripping traffic.

Matson, president of Impulsora de Empresas Electricas S. A., a subsidiary of American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan and Ray Heins cashed in on sparkling approach shots today to gain the first-round lead of the Eastern open golf tournament with five-under-par 67's.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Frank Lane was signed today as general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals in a move that August A. Busch, president of the club, hoped would start the seventh-place Redbirds back on the wing toward first division.
President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser said here yesterday that the United States could achieve a record-breaking $400,000,000,000 economy "in the near future."

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to spend $33,000 by March 31, 1956, for state-city planning. This is its half of the $66,000 cost of a professional survey and research staff for the ten-member New York State- New York City Fiscal Relations Committee.
Four firemen -- two of them officers and three of them honor men -- pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of neglect of duty.

GUNTHER JAECKEL'S fur picture is in glorious color this season. Colors undreamed of in furs even a year ago now run through the store's collection, particularly in less expensive pelts such as beaver and sheared racoon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Defense Department announced today that a preliminary contract had been awarded for production of a man-made satellite. The United States expects to launch it into outer space in 1957 or 1958.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Former Gov. Juscelino Kubitschek of the State of Minas Gerais regained the lead today in the counting of ballots from Monday's Presidential election.

Negotiations to merge the Catalin Corporation of America and Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., under the name of Reichhold Catalin Chemicals, Inc., was authorized yesterday by directors of the two plastic raw materials concerns.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Grain futures developed strength after initial setbacks today, wheat taking the lead as cash wheat was reported relatively strong at various distributing points. Soybeans opened lower on overnight hedge pressure.

France is going through a profound crisis which deserves all the sympathy and understanding that she can get from her friends in America. One is not speaking here of agreement or of refraining from criticism -- neither of which is a concomitant of friendship.

At a special conference arranged for the purpose Premier Faure and Chancellor Adenauer have joined forces to ward off the last remaining threat to French-German understanding. This threat arises because of the bitter campaign of the pro-German parties in the Saar to defeat the "European" statute for this tiny but rich territory worked out between the two Governments and subject to a referendum by the Saar people themselves on Oct. 23.

Central Maine Power Company is offering to holders of its common stock and of its 6 per cent dividend preferred stock the right to subscribe for 506,317 new shares of common stock at a price of $24.375 a share. The offer will end on Oct. 19.
The State Power Authority and the State Commerce Department agreed yesterday to cooperate in attracting new industry to the St. Lawrence Valley in northern New York.

WHEN the television comedy package called "The People's Choice" was conceived, its originators must have proclaimed that it was an "off beat" show. This, in the broadcasting business, has come to constitute an accolade.

This is the time of year to watch out for coryza, which is the correct medical term for a cold in the head. For autumn is here, winter will soon follow, and in prospect are chilly days, nippy nights, freezing spells, snow followed by slush, and a plethora of sneezes.

The Folding Box Company, Inc., has leased a one-story building at 35-49 Kent Avenue in Brooklyn from Jerome Zirinsky, and will use it for general offices and for the manufacture, storage and distribution of paper boxes. The company will consolidate its operations that have been conducted in Manhattan and in Jamaica, Queens.
MEATS, fish, poultry and eggs are all lower in price this week-end, according to the City Department of Markets.
Rumors about devaluation of the cruzeiro and further changes in the Brazilian Cabinet affected cocoa and coffee prices yesterday on the New York futures markets.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Carmen Basilio of Canastota, N. Y., the world welterweight champion, signed a three-way contract today with Tony DeMarco and Johnny Saxton, both ex-champions, spelling out the next two title defenses.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6 (UP) -- The nation's top 3-year-old trotter, Scott Frost, today brushed aside bad luck in the first heat to capture the $62,702 Kentucky Futurity over the famed red mile.
MONTREAL, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, in the league opener for both teams tonight.

Thaddeus Stevens, one of the dominant political figures of the Civil War, is the subject of a new book by Ralph Korngold that Harcourt, Brace will issue on Oct. 26. The biography, called "Thaddeus Stevens: A Being Darkly Wise and Rudely Great," traces the career of the Pennsylvania Republican who was the Majority Leader in the House during Lincoln's Administration and the Reconstruction period.
The upturn in the textile industry that began a year ago "gives every promise of continuing and strengthening," Spencer Love, chairman of Burlington Industries, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov told Lester B. Pearson today that the Soviet Union was optimistic about the outcome of the Geneva Conference of the Big Four foreign ministers this month. The Soviet Foreign Minister reiterated, however, the the German problem could be solved only within the framework of a general European security system.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Ezra Taft Benson insisted today that the solution of the nation's farm problem lay largely in research.
The New York State Mental Hygiene Department reported yesterday that new chemical agents might revolutionize the treatment both of mild and serious mental afflictions.

Rivalry looms between two productions of "Macbeth." The first will be off and running at 7:45 o'clock tonight in the 298-seat Rooftop Theatre, 111 East Houston Street. Staged by Ray Boyle, co-sponsor with Yolande Betbeze (the Miss America of 1951), the attraction will hold forth through Nov. 10.

The Jaymax Precision Products, Inc., manufacturer of Swiss precision products, has leased a one-story factory and office building under construction at 36-27 Prince Street in Flushing, Queens. The Berman Construction Company, Inc., is the owner-builder. Scheduled to be ready for occupancy about Nov. 1, the structure will contain about 7,000 square feet of space. Charles M. Richardson was the broker in the deal.

No progress was reported yesterday toward settlement of two small waterfront strikes. They involve bulk cargo handlers belonging to the International Longshoremen's Association, and 250 American Federation of Labor shipyard machinists.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Delegates of the Danish, Finnish, Norwegian and Swedish shipowners' associations lashed out today against United States-flag "discrimination." They urged their Governments to stop buying American surplus stocks if such purchases involved discriminatory freight clauses.

State and municipal long-term financing in September totaled $389,848,781, compared with $651,592,745 for the same month last year, The Daily Bond Buyer of New York reported yesterday. The revised total for August was $258,707,097.
MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- A small one-family apartment is now being held up as the approved objective for Soviet architects and construction engineers.
OAKDALE, L. I., Oct. 6 -- La Salle Military Academy's spirited football squad, back on the winning track, began preparations today for the visit of St. Dominic's High of Oyster Bay on Saturday.

MIAMI, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Miami throws three years of hard work and hunger for football fame against an injury-riddled but still powerful Notre Dame football team tomorrow night. A crowd of 75,500 will see the game in the newly enlarged Orange Bowl Stadium.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 2, tonight as the National Hockey League season got under way.
TAMPICO, Mexico, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Panuco River leveled off overnight, bringing hope to this flood-devastated oil port and the surrounding area where, by unofficial count, 326 persons have perished.
A revival of Tchaikovsky's "The Golden Slippers," which has not been heard in New York in thirty-three years, will be staged next Thursday by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.
The dynamic productivity of a group of tax - paying wage-earners who might have been relief recipients was described yesterday to the Rotary Club of New York.

Narrow price changes marked most of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, the dullest since Aug. 22 and the narrowest since Sept. 2. But wider declines for a few pivotal issues made the averages seem much weaker than the market.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 -- Union locals in the garment industry were instructed today to seek a general wage increase for 150,000 workers when the Federal minimum wage goes to $1 an hour March 1.
The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut agreed yesterday on the need for tri-state planning. However, they differed radically on the methods for accomplishing it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Leading educational officials are faced with a dilemma:

A benefit exhibition of thirty-three paintings, representing a cross-section of great art from the pre-Renaissance to the present, will open at the E. A. Silberman Galleries at 1014 Madison Avenue on Wednesday. On Tuesday evening there will be a preview showing for patrons and lenders.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Wholesale buyers, eager to anticipate higher prices for shoes, laid down a record volume of orders today at the New England Shoe and Leather Association Shoe Show, one of the first in the nation.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- The Cabinet decided today to establish a Civilian Defense Council at the summit of the armed forces that are to be raised.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Officials of the United States Military Academy declined to comment today on whether a shift in examination dates had cleared the way for the Army football team to compete in post-season games.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Premier Edgar Faure forced four Gaullist opponents from his Cabinet today. Then he went before the National Assembly and, against great odds, asked it to back his policy of conciliation in Morocco.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 820,312 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Gilbert Reese, 'cellist, made his first appearance in this city six years ago, and has studied since then with Pablo Casals. He returned to Town Hall last night in a program embracing works of Haydn, Brahms, Debussy and Nin. It was a thoroughly enjoyable evening.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks won the women's New York State senior golf title at the Knollwood Country Club today.

Fred Hutchinson, who piloted Detroit's Tigers two and a half years before leading the Seattle Rainiers to a Pacific Coast League pennant this season, will be named manager of the St. Louis Cardinals within a week or ten days, The Associated Press reported last night.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company will have its biggest profit year in 1955, but the amount of the profit will continue to be a carefully kept secret.
WHEN Louis Calhern was last in New York he played Old Man Lear in Shakespeare's tragedy. Now he is Old Man Dennison in Edmund Morris' "The Wooden Dish," which opened at the Booth last evening.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 6 -- Under Secretary of State Herbert Hoover Jr. and the director of the International Cooperation Administration, John B. Hollister, arrived here by air tonight from Tokyo on a fact-finding tour of the Far East.

Day-long rains held down the customer turnout at the opening of The Fair on Union Square yesterday. But enough bargain-hunters braved the weather to sustain traffic reminiscent of that which coursed through the building on a busy Thursday when it was occupied by Ohrbach's.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 6 (UP) -- The twenty-five-ton "vest pocket" submarine X-1, only fifty feet long and accommodating a crew of five, joins the Navy tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Army review board heard an appeal today from former Pvt. Herbert Wasserman of 2820 Bronx Park East, the Bronx, who was given an undesirable discharge after serving seven months.

THE thin shred of make-believe that holds together "Time Out for Ginger" snapped last night in a television version of the comedy presented on "Shower of Stars" over Channel 2. A little too much time was taken out for Jack Benny.
Stockholders of Stokely-Van Camp, Inc., at their annual meeting in Indianapolis yesterday authorized a major increase in capitalization.
CHICAGO, Oct 6 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Col. Jack H. Weske will assume his new duties as post commander of Camp Drum tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Following is the text of the draft statute for an international atoms-for-peace agency, as agreed upon by the United State and by seven other countries it has asked to become charter members.

Net assets of Lehman Corporation on Sept. 30, at the end of the first quarter of its fiscal year, declined from the record high set at the end of the preceding fiscal year, according to the quarterly report mailed yesterday.
The G. I.'s call them Ack Ack and Nike bases. The Anti-Aircraft Command settles for onomatopoeia. But the lads on the Nike bases name their guided missiles for the Greek Goddess of Victory.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $69,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 6 -- Governor General Iskander Mirza assured the West today that its ties with Pakistan were secure.
The Army Nurse Corps broke a fifty-four-year-old practice yesterday. It accepted into its ranks the first man ever to be commissioned as an Army nurse.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 6 -- A convention of African witch doctors has been under way the last few days in Pretoria, administrative capital of South Africa, thirty' six miles north of here.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 6 -- A crucial phase in testing Nassau County's recently adopted Permanent Personal Registration system starts tomorrow.

The city moved yesterday to buy, at an estimated cost of $1,400,000, the Montefiore Rest Home in Bedford Hills, Westchester County. The home would serve as an addition to the overcrowded children's center at 1 East 104th Street.

Paul A. Pfeffer, a 23-year-old former convict involved in an earlier killing case, went on trial yesterday in Queens County Court, charged with first-degree murder in the fatal beating of Mellon Byrd, a 59-year-old Rockaway handy man, on April 9.

A fourteen-room dwelling on one acre at 41 Forest Circle, New Rochelle, in Westchester County, was sold by Jacob O. Pedersen to Mitchell Boner, owner of the M. Boner Company, manufacturing jewelers in New York. The Thomas B. Sutton Corporation was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that most subscribers to its issue of 2 1/4 per cent tax anticipation certificates offered this week would get 32 per cent of the amount for which they bid.
The move to ban kerosene heaters in New York City -- started last winter after fires from such stoves had killed thirteen persons in eighty hours -- gained impetus yesterday.
The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday a plan for broadening television's coverage without increasing rates, thereby in effect lowering rates to advertisers.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 6 -- The Mayor of Providence turned down today a revised offer of not only a statue of Thomas Paine but a site for it as well.
The Santa Cecilia Choir of Rome made its first appearance in this city before a large audience at Carnegie Hall last night.
The driver of the panel truck that collided Wednesday with a fire engine, killing a fireman, died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 -- The crisis produced by the resignation last night of Brazil's Finance Minister, Jose Maria Whitaker, was temporarily eased today.
ALTON, Ill., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A runaway jet plane, abandoned by its pilot in Illinois, crashed today near Monticello, Iowa, about 250 air miles away.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 -- Despite the multiplicity of Protestant denominations in this country, there is increasing evidence of the emergence of what might be called an "American Church."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon presided today at a meeting of the National Security Council.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer re-emphasized today the necessity for French-German cooperation in explaining to his Cabinet the meaning of yesterday's talks with Edgar Faure, Premier of France.

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Selling prices of Canadian wheat have been reduced as much as 6 cents a bushel in a series of changes announced in the last week by the Canadian Wheat Board.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Bucky Harris signed a $40,000 contract today to manage the Detroit Tigers again in 1956, then surprised everybody by setting a lofty goal of ninety victories for next season.
Your Sept. 29 editorial regarding Egypt's move to obtain arms from the Soviet bloc calls for comment.

The city's campaign to beautify the streets will shift into high gear Monday when the Mayor's Interdepartmental Committee for a Clean City starts what it calls "the largest clean-up project in the city's history."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- W. H. Brown, vice president and treasurer of the American Viscose Corporation, said today his company's sales this year are expected to total $255,000,000, an increase of 18 per cent over last year's volume.

Directors of MacFadden Publications, Inc., yesterday declared a 50 per cent stock dividend, payable on Jan. 15, and a 25-cent dividend on common stock, payable on Jan. 3. Both are subject to stockholder approval.

WHAT makes a good dinner? Hostesses with a flair for feeding guests in a memorable fashion may not agree on specific menus but, whether they know it or not, they are guided by many of the same basic principles in mapping festive meals. Master these principles, apply them with culinary skill and, voila, an outstanding dinner party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The General Accounting Office charged today that tolls from a Wabash River bridge had been used to pay salaries, overly high printing costs and $85-a-day travel expenses for a former Republican Representative and his Illinois newspapers.
EVERY ship that arrives in New York harbor these days seems to carry cargo of contemporary Italian art for whose display a number of new galleries have arisen.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Three challenges were issued here today against British administration in as many dependent territories.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 6 -- An international seminar to evolve a program for the development of public libraries in Asia opened here today.
Among the tributes received since the death on Monday of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times, were the following:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 15 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

James P. Newell has been named vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad. In his new position Mr. Newell, formerly vice president in charge of operations, is second in command to James M. Symes, president.

Important manuscripts and books from nearly every country in the Far and Near East, that are both rare and beautiful, have been added to the collections of the New York Public Library. The acquisitions, on view today in the Spencer Collection in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty - second Street, have brought to the library exceptional pieces that round out its illustrated books collection.
Discriminatory tax rates limit economic development by restricting saving and investment, the National Association of Manufacturers said yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The bodies of two small boys were found today in an attic trunk where their playmate had locked them in a game of rocket ship.

SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 6 -- Initial efforts at "emancipating" the nation's 400,000 Indians from Federal trusteeship have been somewhat hasty and unsatisfactory, experts concerned with the problem reported today.
ATHENS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Constantin Karmanlis, King Paul's choice for Premier to succeed the late Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, was sworn in with his new Cabinet today.
BY this time it must be clear to everyone that the D'Oyly Carte Company can do no wrong this season.
Governor Harriman confirmed last night his acceptance of invitations to address Democratic meetings in Oregon, Washington and Idaho next month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- It rises on the slope of the Virginia hill that walls the Potomac -- this pantheon of the nation's military, the National Cemetery of Arlington. On its summit stands the pillared house where Robert Edward Lee was offered and declined the command of the armies of the Union.

When modern medical thinking knows and says that 85 per cent of those who survive an attack of coronary thrombosis are able to perform gainful work and that many even resume all their regular activities, why do some cute politicians insist at this stage that a second term for President Eisenhower is out of the question, that it would be a very bad thing, and so on?
Three unidentified Latin-American nations may be generating nuclear-fueled electric power within the next three years under a plan announced yesterday by the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A committee of children's doctors today issued a warning on competitive sports as a means of improving the physical fitness of American youth. President Eisenhower recently issued a call for more emphasis on competitive sports.

Three teen-agers were arraigned yesterday in Youth Term of Felony Court in the fatal shooting on Wednesday of a Park Department attendant. The shooting took place at Ninety-sixth Street and Second Avenue.
GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- A French delegation has withdrawn from East-West trade talks here in protest against the Soviet vote to place the Algerian question on the United Nations General Assembly's agenda.
Leo T. Crowley, former Foreign Economic Administrator, takes sharp issue with Harry S. Truman over the latter's version of the discontinuance of Lend-Lease after V-E Day.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -- On a sun-blistered fairground in New Delhi the atomic age is dependent on ancient ways, and is doing quite nicely.

The modern practice of shortening the time patients remain in hospitals has increased the need for visiting nurses at home. Last year nurses of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East Seventieth Street, New York 21, made 315,882 visits to 36,648 patients. Only one-third of this service was paid for in full.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Department of Justice has been successful in reducing the backlog of civil and criminal tax cases in the Federal courts, H. Brian Holland, Assistant Attorney General in charge of Tax Division, said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Selective Service announced today that its 1955-56 college qualification tests will be given Nov. 17 and April 19.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 2 to 30 points (10 cents to $1.50 a bale) yesterday, with a moderate volume of business.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 6 -- Political maneuvering to establish the new Indonesian Cabinet has begun.

The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that Willfred W. Lufkin Jr. would join the textile organization on Nov. 1 as a vice president and as president of its foreign trading subsidiaries, a new office.

The California Toll Bridge Commission is planning to borrow $46,000,000 in the public market before the end of the year. The commission announced yesterday that it has selected Dec. 13 as the tentative date for offering for sale an issue of revenue bonds.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States, with Britain and six other powers, has drafted a proposal countering the Soviet Union's formula for solving the problem of refugees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Census Bureau reported tonight that outlays of federal, state and local governments for all purposes were almost the same during the fiscal year 1954 as in the year before.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa. Oct. 6 -- Conservationists and water experts re-emphasized today the need for a new appraisal of the Delaware River's resources. They agreed that the residential, commercial and industrial boom in northern New Jersey and along the Delaware Valley required it.

The Federal Reserve System bought $140,000,000 of Treasury bills on a daily average in the week ended on Wednesday, thus adding funds to the commercial banking system, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Delegates to the tenth biennal convention of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., acted yesterday to make it tougher for newcomers to join the 40,000-member seamen's organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- Senator James Murray, Democrat of Montana, today strongly protested President Eisenhower's appointment of former Representative Wesley A. D'Ewart, Republican of Montana, as an Assistant Interior Secretary.

Dan Throop Smith, the Treasury's chief of tax policy, has told a Congressional committee that the Treasury Department would be "much concerned" over any change in the excise tax system that would involve a loss of revenues "under the present budgetary situation."

Well-known members of society and persons prominent in military and civic life and racing circles attended the annual Belmont Futurity Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds, as in previous seasons, will be donated to the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.

STEADY, men. This will have to be approached with feelings of trepidation. A timid gal will test the water by gingerly extending one toe before plunging in. Tenzing and Hilary will establish base camps before assaulting Everest. A guy just doesn't rush into these things willy-nilly.
NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 6 -- An uneasy truce was in effect today in this troop-patrolled city following yesterday's bloody rioting.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 -- Argentina's campaign to force Juan D. Peron off the American continent came into the open today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, was buried today in the Arlington National Cemetery at Arlington, Va. He was laid to rest not far from the tomb of the Unknown Soldier, his comrade in World War I, and near the graves of several general officers whose service paralleled his in World War II.

Betty Hutton, who made what the critics called an unspectacular television debut last year, will bounce back for her second show on Tuesday, Oct. 25, from 8 to 9 P. M. The variety revue will be presented over the National Broadcasting Company network.

IMOUZZER-DES - MARMOUCHA, French Morocco, Oct. 5 -- Four hundred turbaned tribesmen, many of them old men and boys, today surrendered thirteen rifles stolen Saturday night when the Marmoucha attacked this mountain outpost and killed eleven Europeans and five Moroccan soldiers.
J. A. Winston Co Inc, new investment securities brokerage concern, floor in 11 Broadway -- Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc, brokers.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- The first Comet airliner in eighteen months landed here today. This marked an important step in the British jet liner's return into commercial service. It also defied the "jinx" of Ciampino airport.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company sold yesterday at public bidding 1,173,696 rights to buy new shares presently being offered by Southern New England Telephone Company to its stockholders.

A GROUP of skin-conditioning products prepared with substances obtained from the "fountain of youth" springs of Moltig-les-Bains, in France, have been put on the market by Biotherm Natural Beauty Products.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Federal Judge Joseph C. McGarraghy today set Oct. 24 as the deadline for the filing of briefs in the trial of Harvey O'Connor for contempt of Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States and other charter members of the proposed atoms - for - peace agency have agreed on the countries that should have leading roles in directing its operations. The countries are: the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Canada.

A resolution honoring the memory of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, first vice president and general manager of The New York Times, was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Publishers Association of New York City. The text of the resolution follows:
WITHERBEE, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- Johnny Podres came home tonight to this small Adirondack Mountain community.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The government said today that it would remove export quotas on refined copper of foreign origin in the fourth quarter.
Columbia's hopes of defeating Yale at the Bowl tomorrow in the Ivy League's oldest football rivalry are wrapped up in one compact 170-pound bundle. That's Claude Benham.
A legal point raised by Connecticut is temporarily holding up a New York-New Jersey survey of air pollution in the metropolitan area.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 6 -- A proposal that privately owned waters be licensed for fishing on a commercial basis in much the same way as private lands are set apart as preserves for hunting received the approval of the New York State Conservation council resolutions committee today.
GOETTINGEN, Germany, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Twenty-four travel-worn generals of Hitler's World War II army returned to West Germany tonight after a decade in the Soviet Union as prisoners of war.
Brazil may be recapturing the share of the world coffee market she has lost to Colombia and other Latin American and African producers in the last two years.
LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 6 -- A United Air Lines plane carrying sixty-six persons smashed into a mountain peak today, killing all aboard. The DC-4 was broken into fragments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The propeller shafts of ten new Navy ships are being replaced at a cost of several millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A further drop in Federal subsidies to the nation's domestic airlines was reported today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The north lounge of the United Nations conference building is a large, well-appointed room with a bar, snack room and other comforts to help delegates relax. But it is also the center of another, little publicized phase of activities here -- lobbying.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Authority to haul "dangerous explosives" on Eastern highways was given to four truck lines today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The seventh in a series of booklets designed to assist Americans who are concerned with problems of investment and trade abroad has now been issued by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce. This one happens to concern the Philippines, so naturally it points to some highly favorable factors, including the close economic ties between the Philippines and the United States and the friendly Philippine attitude toward foreign investment and trade.

I represent the North Kanara and Belgaum districts of the Bombay State (the southernmost tips of that state) in the Indian Parliament. My constituency borders on Goa.
