A group of seventy immigrant refugees from Italy, North Africa, Trieste and Yugoslavia recently arrived at Idlewild, with their families, to begin life anew in New York. The men are skilled tailors who have been assured of jobs in the New York men's clothing industry, which has suffered a steady loss in manpower during recent years.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "Seven Cities of Gold," a Twentieth Century-Fox adventure in CinemaScope featuring Richard Egan, Anthony Quinn and Rita Moreno, arrives at the Roxy. Robert Webb and Barbara McLean produced and Mr. Webb directed from a script by Richard Breen and John Higgins.

Events tonight: "La Boheme," New York City Opera, New York City Center, 8:15; "An Evening at the Opera," Malin-Verdi Auditorium, 225 West Forty-sixth Street, 8:15; Frances Archer and Beverly Gile, folk singers, Town Hall, 8:30; Mildred Simonds, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; jazz concert, Stuyvesant Casino, 140 Second Avenue, 8:30.

DURING the ten days before the German surrender, I had continuous conversations with the Cabinet and the Chiefs of Staff on what forces and supplies we would send from Europe to the Far East. It was decided that those military divisions and units that had not seen much active service on the fighting front would be the first sent from Europe to the Pacific.
Civil and military leaders, newspaper associates and other friends attended a funeral service in Temple Emanu-El yesterday morning for Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Pre-packaged frozen meats represent "one of the most important developments in food distribution and merchandising."
SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 7 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association scotch foursome one-day tournament on Canoe Brook's north course ended in a tie for low gross honors today.

The twelve-story structure at 148-50 West Twenty - fourth Street has been purchased for occupancy by the Alvin Furniture Manufacturing Company, which is changing the name of the structure to the Alvin Building. The property is assessed at $225,000 and was sold through Williams Co., brokers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Juscelino Kubitschek appeared headed for victory tonight in Brazil's Presidential race, with more than two-thirds of the ballots tabulated from Monday's election.

" THE problem solved makes style," said Thomas Hastings. He happened to be speaking of architecture. But his remark is equally penetrating when it is applied to architectural writing, as we can see in Wayne Andrews' brilliantly organized new book, "Architecture, Ambition and Americans."

DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UP) -Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson scored a bloody six-round technical knockout over Rex Layne tonight when he opened a deep gash over Layne's left eye in a nationally televised bout at the Olympia.

Mayor Robert Wagner has established a Committee on Scholastic Achievement to seek out city high school students of ability who cannot afford to attend college, and to aid them with scholarships. The committee is particularly interested in local pupils with marked intellectual and scholastic attainments who have not planned to go on with their educations and who, in any case, could not do so without financial assistance.
The new aircraft carrier Saratoga, younger but more powerful sister-ship of the Forrestal, will be named and symbolically launched at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, today.

The four-story apartment house accommodating forty-two families at 1325 East Nineteenth Street, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, has been sold by Morris Zapin to the Relian Holding Corporation. Henry Futterweit was the broker in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $140,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A group of thirteen pickets from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and United Packinghouse Workers, District 1, C. I. O., demonstrated today against the conduct of the Till murder trial in Mississippi.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The National Association of Manufacturers renewed today its proposal for a uniform sales tax on all manufactured products except food.

SEATTLE, Oct. 7 (AP) -- An average speed of 550 miles an hour on a 3,038-mile non-stop test flight in the new Boeing 707 jet was announced today by the Boeing Airplane Company. It included a forty-three-minute whiz from Los Angeles to San Francisco.

NEW CASTLE, Ind., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Gov. George N. Craig sent word today that he was hurrying back to Indiana from Florida. A few hours earlier Perfect Circle Corporation won city officials' permission to reopen its struck foundry Monday.
A German Boy Scout, six and a half feet tall, came back to New York yesterday after a 13,000-mile, fourteen-week, coast-to-coast sightseeing tour that had cost him only $60.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7. -- A convention of the Theatre Owners of America was told today that the Exhibitors Film Financial Group, Inc., formed nine months ago to lend funds for film production, may face dissolution in six months.

The man who, more than any other individual, perhaps, is in a position to watch the nation's economic machine as a whole in action and to pass on its performance seems to believe that, generally speaking, the gears are meshing smoothly and that there is little evidence of undue waste of power between the engine and the wheels and that the safety valve and "governor" seem to be performing their appointed functions.

ONE of the tragic aftermaths of a world war is the harvest of little Caesars and their acts of aggression. When the great powers are in conflict, pent-up fanatical nationalisms begin to stir everywhere. This poses a constant threat to peace, for these little acts of belligerency or aggression -- these "little wars" -- are frequently fought in the name of liberation.

Rumors from Brazil continued to influence coffee and cocoa futures. Trading in the other commodities on the New York exchanges was generally limited to evening of holdings for the weekend. Prices were irregular with cocoa, coffee, copper, zinc and lead lower; rubber, hides, silk, cottonseed oil and soybean oil higher, and sugar, potatoes, onions and wool mixed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Fifty-two anti-trust cases have been filed by the Department of Justice in the last twelve months.
DENVER, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower had a luncheon surprise today -- soup made from his own recipe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -The Federal Power Commission today authorized the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company to increase by 15 per cent its natural gas deliveries to Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Missouri and Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The index of average primary market prices registered a decrease of 0.3 point to 111.1 (1947-49 equals 100) over the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 7 (UP) -- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., the former national amateur champion, took the first-round lead in the $5,000 Richmond women's open golf tournament today. She fired a 74, two over men's par, on the Richmond Golf Club course.

Your issue of Sept. 25 carries a story under the headline "New Fight Begun for Bill of Rights." Beneath the headline is an imposing list of dignitaries said to have signed an "open letter to the American people" released by "Americans for Traditional Liberties" asking a Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights to "probe every area of constitutional violations boldly."
District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn said yesterday that "persons of a professional element" appeared to have become a factor in Brooklyn bingo.

" Japan's Modern Century," by Hugh Borton, Professor of Japanese and Director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia University, will be issued Oct. 24 by Ronald Press. It is an interpretive account of Japan's transformation from a secluded, agrarian, semi - feudal country into a modern, industrialized world power.

Two honeymoon couples are among the more than sixty persons who will leave New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, this morning for the first stage of the New York Yankees' baseball tour of the Orient.

Further legal steps were taken yesterday to restrict the business activities of Robert Morman, prominent realty man sought for questioning by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. Mr. Hogan has linked him with a suspected swindle involving hundreds of thousands of dollars.
The British expect to deliver atomic electric power on a commercial basis by the end of next year, "possibly in October or November."
PHILADELPHIA. Oct. 7 -Princeton University's football team is favored to defeat the University of Pennsylvania when the elevens resume their rivalry tomorrow on Franklin Field.
The National Casket Company, Inc., declared yesterday a semi-annual dividend of $1.50 a share payable Nov. 15. The company previously had paid a semi-annual dividend of 65 cents in May.

John Flaherty, a 31-year-old Brooklyn building superintendent, was shot and killed yesterday when he sought to escape from two guards while leaving the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions. He had just been found guilty of petit larceny.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Ron Murphy turned in the three-goal hat trick tonight to spark the New York Rangers to a 7-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 5,980 fans.
The "cold war" may be drawing to a close, or anyway "growing appreciably less grave," Jose Maza, president of the United Nations General Assembly said last night.
The flag of the United Service Organizations carries seven stars. They symbolize the seven great national agencies that joined together in 1941 to serve men of the armed Services.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 7 -- The Nationalist party leadership has decided not to offer any ministerial posts to Communist party members in any Cabinet it forms.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, asserted today that the Army was equipped to cope with the increasing danger of local "brush fire" types of war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- About forty years ago, Earl Warren and Walter A. Gordon, students at the University of California, met occasionally in the afternoons and boxed a few rounds.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Political enemies of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam today attacked his plan to ask the Vietnamese people to choose between himself and the absentee former emperor, Bao Dai, as Chief of State.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- Soviet officials were told today that the Soviet Union's farmland was threatened by erosion and soil exhaustion unless conservation practices were begun at once.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- The Pontiac show, "Playwrights '56," will be presented from Hollywood on Oct. 18 at 8:30 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Donald A. Quarles said today that he had "tentatively approved the location and architectural style" of five buildings for the new Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, Colo.

HARTFORD, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Connecticut's Insurance Commission said today that Connecticut motorists could not get the new insurance protection being offered in New York because Connecticut had more uninsured cars than New York.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 7 -- President Joao Cafe Filho is undergoing the severest criticism of his political career for delaying the simplification of Brazil's foreign exchange system.
WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 7--Coach Ralph Erickson had good reason for stressing pass defense in the Loomis School football team's workout today.
DALLAS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Charley Jackson caught a 39-yard pass for one touchdown and romped 40 yards for another tonight to give Southern Methodist a 13-6 victory over Missouri.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 7 -- Harold Macmillan, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today that Britain, the United States and France were prepared to offer the Soviet Union a detailed security pact covering military dispositions in central Europe.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- The Columbia football team will meet Yale tomorrow in an Ivy League game starting at 2 P. M. in the Bowl.
Out from under the shadow of baseball at last, college football comes into its own today.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The de Havilland Comet jet airliner took a major step forward today on the come-back trail to commercial operation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -The threat by Gov. J. Bracken Lee of Utah not to pay part of his Federal income taxes brought official comment today that the Government had "adequate machinery for collecting."

Lament on Canning Up in the attic the two-quart jars lie gathering dust, and beside them are smaller brothers, once used for jelly. These latter came into the house filled with peanut butter, and as emptied were set aside for the preservation of fruit in season.

Mayor Wagner will be seen and heard on "Mayor's Conference" over Channel 11 between 3:30 and 4 P. M. on Oct. 16. The Mayor will be interviewed by a panel of newspaper reporters. Walter Engels, director of the station's news and special events, also will participate.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Grace V. Ackerman, 35 years old, formerly of this city, and her 16-month-old son, Thomas B. Ackerman, lost their lives in the crash yesterday while flying to see her husband, Maj. Clifford Ackerman, 36, in San Francisco.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 7 -- The Brown and Dartmouth elevens will meet at Brown Field tomorrow. The game probably will be an aerial battle.
One topflight, dependable shortstop. One solid pitcher. One capable outfielder.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 7 -Israel said today she had information that guerrilla incursions from all four neighboring Arab countries were controlled and directed from Cairo.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 -- Mass evacuation of the critically crowded populace in flooded Tampico is under consideration by the Mexican Government.

The regional Red Cross will collect blood today at the Masonic Temple, 137-70 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. On Thursday the Red Cross here collected 559 pints of blood. Included were 146 from the Army Audit Agency, Army Ordnance District and Social Security Administration of 180 Varick Street, and 100 at Broadway Temple, 211 West Fifty-sixth Street.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 7 -- Gen. Walther von Seydlitz, deputy commander of the German Army that surrendered at Stalingrad in 1944, was snubbed by his fellow prisoners today after their return from Soviet captivity.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 25 points ($1.25 a bale) higher on the old October contract yesterday. But all other months closed 10 to 27 points (50 cents to $1.35 a bale) lower.

No one who needs help is ever turned away by Travelers Aid of New York, which this year is observing its Golden Jubilee -- a marker of fifty years of devoted service to wayfarers everywhere, without regard to race, creed or color. In this first half-century of service the society has assisted 16,000,000 travelers.
The shipping industry's contempt of court case against longshoremen involved in last month's strike will be heard by former Federal Court Judge Simon H. Rifkind.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Work at three United Fruit Company banana plantations virtually ceased today because of agitation promoted by Communist union leaders, Gov-I ernment sources said.

POUGKEEPSIE, Oct. 7 -- Discontent over Conservation Commissioner Louis A. Wehle's failure to appoint an advisory committee on conservation affairs developed among organized sportsmen assembled at the convention here today.
Nuclear energy is to be used on the American Stock Exchange at 11 A. M. Monday to activate 959 stock tickers in 163 United States and Canadian cities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The mounting costs of going to college prevent from 100,000 to 150,000 superior high school graduates from continuing with their education.
DENVER, Saturday, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower is perpared to reassert his guidance of United States foreign policy.

A NEW filmed television series called "Crossroads" began last night on Channel 7 between 8:30 and 9 P. M. The programs, to be seen each Friday, are dramatizations of true episodes in the lives on clergymen.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Wheat, led by the December contract, was strong for most of today's session on the Board of Trade. But, as usual, demand lagged as prices rose, with offerings increasing. No bullish news was reported, but cash wheat is showing a firm tone and there are hints that free wheat may be harder to obtain from now on.
NAPLES, Italy, Oct. 7 -- Military men believe that in case of war the Mediterranean could be held against any combination of forces likely to be hurled against it from the East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Three judges of the Federal Court of Appeals took under advisement today, after hearing arguments, the question of whether Mrs. Marie Natvig must serve a prison sentence for perjury.
ATHENS, Oct. 7 -- Greece seems to have avoided a serious political storm over the succession to Premier Alexander Papagos, who was buried today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Confidential Magazine won a round in its battle with the Post Office Department today when a Federal Judge tossed out an order that could have kept it from the mails.
The Giants yesterday asked waivers on Sid Gordon, 37-year-old infielder-outfielder, for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

Efforts to settle two minor strikes in the shipping industry will be renewed on Monday. The walkouts -- one involving machinists in small ship repair plants and the other affecting scalemen who handle bulk commodity imports -- began a week ago.
" LA BOHEME" as performed at the City Center last evening was marred by poor work in the pit during two of the most familiar moments of the score, Rodolfo's narrative and "Mi Chiamano Mimi."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A full-dress session this week of all the highest authorities in the Federal Reserve System has produced the conclusion that nothing has happened yet as result of President Eisenhower's illness to warrant a change in the present restrictive money and credit policy.

Mayor Achille Lauro of Naples, which was badly damaged in World War II, called on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur yesterday and received the general's cheering opinion that war between countries on this earth was probably obsolete.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 7 -- Marion B. Folsom, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said here today that the Eisenhower Administration "will continue to press for a sound and workable program to encourage school construction."

The stock market's reaction to President Eisenhower's heart attack bears only a slight resemblance to activity immediately following former President Calvin Collidge's "I do not choose to run" statement of 1927.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Violent demonstrations, involving civilians, against the recall of French reservists for service in North Africa broke out in Paris and Rouen today.

Today's new film is "Dr. Knock," a French-made satire starring Louis Jouvet, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Guy LeFranc directed the import, and Jacques Roitfeld produced, from a scenario that Jules Romains and M. LeFranc adapted from M. Romains' stage play.
Three young robbers walked into the Sapolin Paint Company, a five-story building at 183 Lorraine Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and walked out with a $7,973 payroll.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Premier Edgar Faure made new efforts today to get his stalled Moroccan program moving quickly to prevent his defeat in the National Assembly. As the debate on Morocco went into its second day, the Premier dispatched his new Defense Minister, Brig. Gen. Pierre Billotte, to the protectorate with a political as well as a military mission. The general was accompanied by the Deputy Resident General, Francois de Panafieu.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Hog prices tumbled today to the lowest level in more than nine years. Losses ranged from 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Four foreign language newspaper men invoked the First and Fifth Amendments to the Constitution today to keep from testifying at a Senate Internal Security subcommittee hearing.
The Consolidated Edison Company's 10-cent-a-month increase in minimum rates for gas -- which went into effect temporarily on Oct. 1 -- came under fire from the city yesterday.
Two records in the scofflaw field were set by a man who was sent to jail yesterday for 122 days.
HARTFORD, Oct. 7 -- A nine-member commission was appointed today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to plan, construct and operate five new bridges across the Connecticut River in the Greater Hartford area.
The forty-fifth anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral will be celebrated tomorrow.

A prediction by a prominent newsprint manufacturer that prices would be increased "in the foreseeable future" brought vigorous protest yesterday from the head of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
PARIS, Oct. 7 -- France's military problems in North Africa will be placed before the defense ministers of the fifteen North Atlantic Treaty nations here Monday.
A project that would centralize the $15,000,000 - a - year school lunch program and take the high school principals out of the restaurant business is being developed.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 7 -- Israel is the most extraordinary of the newly independent states of Asia. It is founded on a dream -re-creation of a Jewish homeland after almost two millenia. Its population comes from six continents. To most of its citizens the national language, Hebrew, was until recently a dead and unfamiliar tongue.
BERLIN, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Two Germans were convicted and sentenced to prison today for kidnapping a refugee former officer of the Communist secret police and selling him to the Reds.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The United States announced today that it had called on eight leading military, scientific and industrial figures to make a broad reappraisal of disarmament policy.
A 22-year-old narcotics addict was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court at his own request to a four-year prison term instead of the two years he ordinarily would have received.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon refused again today to be drawn into the political dispute kicked up by his opponents in his home state of California.
NEENAH, Wis., Oct. 7 (AP) -Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced today the formation of Kimberly-Clark of Mexico and the acquisition of the two Mexican mills of Fabrica de Papel la Auroa.

The gainful result of a three-year promotional effort by the Theatre Guild-American Theatre Society and the Council of the Living Theatre to stimulate theatre interest on the road were made public yesterday.
A scholarship at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism was established yesterday in honor of the late Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (Reuters) -- Saudi Arabia tonight described as "fantastic" British charges that she had offered bribes totaling nearly $100,000,000 to gain control of the oil-rich Buraimi oasis, on the Persian Gulf, whose future is under international arbitration.

Two Federal housing officials yesterday blamed New York City officials and certain builders for long delays in slum clearance and apartment building. Appearing before a Congressional subcommittee, they replied to charges by City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses that their agencies had been responsible for tardy action.

FRANCES ARCHER, soprano, and Beverly Gile, contralto, made their first appearance last night at Town Hall in a program of folk songs and ballads. They are comely, beautifully gowned and groomed young ladies who have a way with a song.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 -- Harry S. Truman, a self-styled "farmer boy from western Missouri," gave a lesson in practical politics today to 2,000 local Democratic candidates.

MIAMI, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Notre Dame took to the air for the first time this season and rode Paul Hornung's passing arm to a 14-0 victory tonight over a fumbling Miami team that couldn't cash in on its scoring opportunities.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- Methods of standardizing passenger tickets on ships in the Atlantic run were discussed here yesterday at the statutory autumn meetings of the principals of the Trans-Atlantic Passenger Conference.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7 -- Argentina's new Supreme Court was sworn in today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- The San Francisco Opera's "Don Giovanni" has enough distinctive elements to differentiate it from productions in the East and abroad. The most important are the musical conception of Erich Leinsdorf, the conductor, and the use of projections of slides to take the place of drops and solid structures as background sets.

Saigon now reports that there will be a general election within a relatively short time to determine the will of the people in respect to the Chief of State. The Vietnamese will be asked to designate, in a popular ballot, if they wish Bao Dai to continue in his titular position or if they prefer that Premier Diem assume the functions of President of a Vietnamese republic.

IN "Bengazi," a standard little melodrama, a less than compelling assortment of good and bad people mingle in a North African bistro and finally end up out on the desert in the usual search for gold. Richard Carlson, Richard Conte and Mala Powers head the cast of this listlessly told offering, produced by Panamint in Superscope. It accompanied the Palace's new stage bill yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -The Government reported today that exports of merchandise declined in August to a total of 1,227,400,000, the second lowest month of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Several top scientists said today this country's earth satellite program was part of an international effort to increase man's knowledge. It is not, they said, an attempt to beat Russia into outer space.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 - Two Cincinnati scientists got a patent this week for metallic substances that help the human skin "breathe." The skin takes up oxygen from the air and from the bloodstream. The inventors, Elton S. Cook and Cornelius W. Kreke, have discovered that certain salts of magnesium, calcium, potassium, iron and other metals are powerful stimulants to this skin breathing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that price support rates for most types of tobacco would be the same as those announced on a preliminary basis on April 1.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -A Federal income tax lien for $167,958 was filed today against Clyde L. Powell, former assistant administrator of the Federal Housing Administration.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 7 -- Rumania has a bumper crop this year, according to agricultural experts of the Academy of the Rumanian People's Republic.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said yesterday that the next major concession the seamen would seek from shipowners would be a two-month paid vacation after each year of sea time.

The Woodbrook Development Corporation, headed by Arthur and Paul Stang of New York, has taken title to fifteen acres on Haviland Lane in White Plains, N. Y., purchased from the Young Men's Christian Association. The site was used for a day camp.
Americans will spend more than $700,000,000 this year for almost half a billion feet of linoleum and other resilient floor coverings.
The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning after a five-week European tour during which it gave twenty-seven concerts.

OFF-BROADWAY'S battle of "Macbeths" began last night with the Rooftop Theatre company wielding the first dagger. On Oct. 19 the Shakespearewrights, a little longer in the service of the Bard in our town, joins the fray and what will be will be. Meanwhile, to the business at hand.
Acquisition by a group of Texans of the controlling interest in the Chickasha Cotton Oil Company of Oklahoma was announced yesterday by J. M. Ferguson, a member of the group.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Mike Homa, an assistant pro at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., took the lead at the halfway mark of the Eastern open golf tournament at the Mount Pleasant course today with a 68, 70 -- 138.

LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Rescue teams brought down the first bodies today from the mountain-peak scene of United States' worst commercial airlines disaster. Investigators still sought the cause of the crash, which took sixty-six lives.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 7 -- Registration of voters in Nassau County got off to a slow start today. It will continue tomorrow and next week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- By offering amendments late today, Saudi Aradia staved off United Nations action on Soviet and Western proposals dealing with refugees.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- Two of Japan's three leading newspapers carried critical comment today on the disavowal by Herbert Hoover Jr., Under Secretary of State, that the United States favored a relaxation of restrictions on trade between Japan and Communist China.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 -- Senator William F. Knowland told a California Chamber of Commerce meeting here today that "the state of the nation is good," but warned of several danger signals that make eternal vigilance necessary.

FEZ, French Morocco, Oct. 7 -- The Istiqlal (Independence) party was represented today as prepared to negotiate with the Riff guerrilla leaders to restore peace if the French Government "gives us a political basis to work from."
A NEW enterprise, the Delacorte Gallery, opened its doors yesterday in an ingeniously redecorated brownstone at 822 Madison Avenue.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 7 -- A grant for $41,550 for a new cardio-respiratory center in Grasslands Hospital, Eastview, was announced today by the Westchester Heart Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP)--Representative Emanuel Celler. Democrat of New York, urged today an investigation of what he called an attempt by the Republican-controlled Wisconsin Legislature to pass an "insidious gerrymandering" bill aimed at unseating a Democrat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A patent on a device used in isotope separation was received this week by the Atomic Energy Commission as assignee of the inventor, Dr. Frank Oppenheimer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson was urged today to "explore the possibilities" of having the Government buy limited amounts of pork for the school lunch program to bolster skidding hog prices.
Angel Lopez, the former manager of Kid Gavilan, and John Silvestro, a manager from Cleveland, testified yesterday before Julius Helfand, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.
OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Some United States investors are cashing in their Canadian holdings and switching to American stocks and bonds, Canadian Government financial officials said today.
SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 7 -A partnership between the Federal Government and the states was viewed today as the the next step in solving the "Indian problem."

In this second school year since the Supreme Court wrote its historic opinion of May 17, 1954, ruling against segregation in public schools, the city of Baltimore (population nearly 1,000,000, about one-fourth Negro) has itself been writing a historic chapter in education. After the opinion, the school board had voted unanimously and promptly to "conform to a nonsegregated basis."

Describing the tremendous upsurge of the Herut party of Israel during that country's recent parliamentary elections, the "News of the Week in Review" section of The Times on July 31 characterized that party as "near Fascist." Of course, the term "'near' Fascist" is meaningless and more suitable to the uses of innuendo than to serious political reporting.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The Soviet Union has replied to the United States proposal for the establishment of an international agency on the peaceful use of atomic energy.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- British Government securities were the only stocks in demand today. Elsewhere, apart from some selected issues, losses were general.

Oliver D. Appleton, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Cyrus J. Lawrence Sons, has been chosen chairman of the Boston and Maine Railroad. The appointment is subject to approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Legislation providing for "heavy penalties" against railroad freight car users might be asked if voluntary efforts by public shippers did not alleviate the present car shortage, the Interstate Commerce Commission said today.

For the third time in as many days custom smelters of copper reduced their price of refined copper 1 1/3 cents a pound yesterday. The new price of 45 1/2 cents a pound compared with 50 cents the smelters had quoted between Sept. 12 and last Wednesday.
Studies suggest that mental ills may possibly be caused by a derangement of the body chemistry to produce substances that poison the mind, a group of medical men was informed here yesterday.
Individuals or groups concerned with learning about "The United Nations and How It Works" may find useful a new model-making teaching aid by this title.
One hundred and forty new fur garments were put on the auction block yesterday in a public sale that has provoked a controversy in the industry.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 -- The Democratic State Committee provided more than 1,000 local party candidates today with a political survival kit.
Ten Soviet construction experts went to the upper East Bronx yesterday. Their visit was part of a cross-country tour of housing properties begun Monday when they arrived in the United States.
Noble Try, competing in the colors of Isaac D. Prickett, took the feature purse at Belmont Park yesterday. Fighting off a closing bid by Howell E. Jackson's Caesar Did, Noble Try triumphed by a head.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York and Mlle. M. Lazarevic of Yugoslavia, leaders in the challengers' tournament in the series for the women's chess championship, met in the fifth round and drew in forty-six moves, according to a report received last night from Moscow.
I refer to your interesting editorial of Sept. 27 "Indonesia and New Guinea."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Government and Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., signed a contract today for the largest merchant ship construction and replacement project in the nation's history -- a $313,000,000 program stretching over the next fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins said tonight that persons "who fear an impartial investigation" of the Government's loyalty-security program "do so because they are afraid of the truth."

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- A British security officer was offered a large sum of money by an intelligence agent in Moscow in April, 1952, to permit the substitution of a dummy bag for a bag containing British diplomatic papers.

About six months ago the New York City Department of Traffic lifted the ban on overnight parking and substituted a regulation permitting parking for twenty-four hours. The department and the public have now had ample time to appraise the results of this order.
The Harriman Administration's approval of new automobile insurance coverage has raised several questions that are troubling political leaders, lawyers and insurance company executives.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 7 -Army and Michigan, both unbeaten and ranked among the top football powers, will meet here tomorrow in one of the most attractive games of the season.

After drifting steadily lower for four unexciting hours, prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suddenly dipped to within a shade of their Sept. 26 lows. Then with even less warning, they staged a brisk rally.
Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd., announced yesterday that its net income for the year ended June 30 rose to 3,452,502 ($9,667,006) from 2,417,729 ($6,769,641) in the preceding year.

Activity in the new capital market promises to be moderate for awhile except in the field of local government financing. In the latter, urgent need for roads, schools and sanitary facilities continues to compel requisitions on the market, without regard for timing.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- A team of five fresh-water skippers from the Royal Canadian Yacht Club won the first race of their new series with American Yacht Club Two-Ten class sailors by 10 1/4 points on Long Island Sound today.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 7 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate, tonight lashed hard at the Eisenhower Administration's "failures" on the farm front.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- Canada and the Soviet Union established today what was described as the "basis" for expanding their trade relations.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 7 -- Senator George Smathers, Democrat of Florida, proposed today that Congress be asked to "take a second look" at this country's air power program in the light of reports of Russian air power expansion.

INCREASINGLY social historians turn to the natural and applied sciences and to technological developments for a better understanding of the American past. Edmund Fuller has joined their ranks with a conversational, easy - to - read story of the Yankee inventors -- Yankee standing in some instances for American, more frequently for the primacy in these matters of the New Englander and most often for the ingenious men of Connecticut.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Mississippi, ably directed by Quarterbacks Eagle Day and John Blalack, scored touchdowns in each of the first two quarters, then checked Vanderbilt's aerial attack and gained a 13-0 triumph tonight.
An increasing number of New York State savings banks may begin to reward long-term deposits with higher dividends.

MEMBERS of the television audience should feel properly contrite this morning. After a number of last week's presentations it is clear that viewers are becoming a dreadful nuisance to many program producers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Harold E. Stassen predicted today that the world's great powers eventually would agree on a program of disarmament. He said the program would include important features of the proposals now advanced by the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8 -- Brazil has received new assurance that the Army will not interfere if Juscelino Kubitschek and Joao (Jango) Goulart are confirmed as President and Vice President.

We can all be grateful to CARE for keeping its weather -- and holiday -- eye open for the world's needy. Once again this nonprofit, quasi-governmental agency has opened its Christmas Food Crusade, and invites the participation of everyone who has the goodness and, indeed, the wisdom to send help to the less fortunate in other lands.
ARMONK, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Ten touring Russian construction officials required no help from their three official interpreters today to understand that mud is mud in any language.

HAINES, Alaska, Oct. 8 -- The $40,000,000 Haines-to-Fairbanks military pipeline, regarded as the most spectacular project of the defense construction program in Alaska, will be turned over to the United States Army's Alaskan Command at a formal ceremony here Wednesday, Columbus .

RARE indeed is the household that has not at least a pot of ivy or philodendron, wax begonia or geranium. At the other extreme is the house plant enthusiast who fills every window, bookshelf and mantelpiece with plants and collects new ones all the time.
European and American art, including work by old masters and by moderns, makes up a highly diverse week of new attractions in the New York galleries.

TORONTO, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored twice in the first period tonight and toppled the Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings to their second successive defeat. 4 -- 2, before 13,489 fans.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 8 -- Michigan State cut loose with a brilliant and daring pass attack to overpower Stanford, 38 -- 14, in an intersectional football game today.

I WOULD like to disagree with Father Harold C. Gardiner and his strictures on condensed books as reported by J. Donald Adams in "Speaking of Books." It is quite true that lengthy scenic descriptions, "essence of atmosphere, leisurely character development, philosophical asides" are omitted from book condensations, but it is also true a lot of books do not have these characteristics.

A LIGHTWEIGHT aluminum vise holds circular saw blades for filing and honing. The blade is easily turned on a center stud, with proper filing angle maintained at all times, according to the manufacturer.

ONE HUNDRED YEARS ago tomorrow a Yankee inventor received his patent to protect a new musical instrument. This was the age of steam, so J. C. Stoddard of Worcester, Mass., employed it to power the loudest organ ever built.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8 -- India's capital became a place of refuge today for thousands of villagers fleeing heavy out-of-season floods.
AN agreement was reached at The Hague recently to double the limit on damages that may be collected from an airline for death or injury of a passenger on an international flight.

A FEW days ago the 296 cadets at the new United States Air Force Academy selected the falcon as their counterpart to the Army's mule and the Navy's goat. Their choice would indicate that these fledgling cadets already have a pride to be reckoned with.
A group or scientists called yesterday for a wider exchange of nuclear energy data among nations, particularly with Russia.

As a teacher thankfully not returning to another year of rude American children, I was gratified to read Robert Waithman's article. During a six-month vacation in Britain I, with several other Americans, was delighted with the abundance of well-mannered and happy children there.

JARVIS MECKLY was 12 when the tennis court was built on Six Mile Island. After that, whenever he wasn't helping his father with the island's potato crop, he was whonking balls over the net or practicing his service in the barn.

THE offices of the Palisades Interstate Park Commismission, both here in the city and at Bear Mountain, have been deluged with unseasonable requests from ski jump followers who want to plan for week-ends next winter; so the commission has decided to announce its coming schedule of Saturday and Sunday ski jumps without a sign of snow in the air.

FOR more than twenty years Ilya Ehrenburg has played a prominent role in the Soviet world of letters. If at times Ehrenburg has seemed to abandon any pretense of morality he might perhaps say in his own defense that, after all, he managed to survive.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 8 -- Sir Anthony Eden announced today that the British Government had decided to reduce its fighting services by about one-eighth over the next thirty months.
TETUAN, Spanish Morocco, Oct. 8 -- Border patrols have been strengthened in Spanish Morocco to prevent the natives in this zone from joining the rebels fighting in French Morocco.
LONDON, Oct 8 -- The British Government accused Premier Nasser today of having used "inaccurate" and "grossly exaggerated" figures in a recent speech about alleged British arms sales to Israel.

IT will be farewell to the steam locomotive on the Long Island next Sunday. To mark this historic event there will be a 160-mile, nine-hour tour on a special train hauled by a G-5 type engine. Babylon, Hicksville, and Port Jefferson are among the stops on the schedule.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 6 -- Two major plants of considerable importance to India's economy were opened in South India this week by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 8 -- Paraguay announced today she would expel Juan D. Peron, Argentina's fallen dictator, if he violated the conditions of his political asylum.

IN reviewing Harry Hodgkinson's "Language of Communism,'' Harry Schwartz states that George Orwell "presumably had in mind the Soviet Union" when he wrote "1984." Orwell's book is laid in England, which in turn is part of Oceania, whose capital is New York.

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) -- L'Osservatore Romano said today the Bishop of Shanghai, at least twenty other priests and 200 to 300 Roman Catholic laymen were arrested last month in a new anti-church campaign in Communist Shanghai.

The 1955-56 school session began in the Southern and border states with white and Negro children attending mixed classes in 362 school districts and counties. The pattern of desegregation in the Southern and border states has followed the outlines of those school districts where there is the smallest ratio of colored children to white in the public schools and where the impact of change upon public school administration could be more readily accommodated.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Rutgers displayed a strong offensive attack in beating Muhlenberg, 21 -- 0, before a Parents Day crowd of 3,500 today.
WROUGHT iron or mild steel (which is normally used) may be worked at home without a blacksmith's forge. An ordinary gasoline-fired blowtorch will heat the metal for bending and shaping.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- The chances are against reaching sufficient agreement at this General Assembly session for the calling of a conference to review the United Nations Charter.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Cornell entered the picture for Ivy League football honors today by defeating a favored Harvard team, 20 -- 7.

THERE is so much informal charm in "Papa's Wife" that it seems churlish to complain of it in any way. Nevertheless it did occur to one reader that, after thirty-five years of woman's sufrage, it might be nice if somebody wrote a book in which mama never knew what was good for her, and papa got his own intelligent way.

AT a time when so many young novelists -- and older ones too -- are writing with one eye cocked at the silver screen, and on the other side of the fence, story editors for the film companies scan not only the current output of fiction, but ransack the library shelves as well, it may not be amiss to consider the relationship and the differences between the two mediums.
Two rabbis, deploring Egypt's intention to buy arms from Russia, called on the United States Government yesterday to preserve peace in the Middle East.

The freighter Fernmoor, third unit of the Fern-Ville Line's second post-war shipbuilding program, will begin her maiden voyage from here to the Far East on Oct. 20, Nils O. Seim, vice president of Fearnley Eger, Inc., said yesterday.

By an opportune stroke of finance, the Allegheny County Sanitary Authority has solved the problem of financing in advance the construction of a $100,000,000 sewage disposal system in the face of an unreceptive bond market.

HIGHLIGHTING the early season, two shows of work by truly great modern artists have just opened. Paintings by Braque from the period 1924 to the present may be seen at the galleries of Paul Rosenberg and twenty-five of the bronzes by Edgar Degas who died in 1917 are on view at Galerie Chalette.

IN his long and arduous struggle for laughs, man has prospected the wellsprings of humor with a tenacity that is probably best exemplified by such disparates as Sigmund Freud and Milton Berle. Freud devoted a considerable portion of a book to explaining a joke that Berle is authoritatively reported to have stolen fifty years later.

In April, 1954, the Bell Telephone Laboratories demonstrated for the benefit of the press a solar battery which directly converted into electricity useful amounts of solar energy. An efficiency of 6 per cent was obtained -- not much, yet enough to amplify voice and speech on a rural telephone line.

BALTMORE, Oct. 8 -- Speed and precision were Navy's chief assets en route to a 21-0 victory over the University of Pittsburgh football team today at Memorial Stadium. The Panthers had neither and after the opening minutes, when they recovered a fumble but went nowhere, did not offer a solid threat.

DALLAS, Oct. 8 -- A bank call reflected increases in deposits and resources in most Southwestern banks. In Dallas, deposits in twenty-two reporting banks were $91,000,000 higher than a year ago. Deposits and resources both were highest ever recorded on an autumn bank call, and were just below the record highs reached last Dec. 31.

IN a society in which the avowed aim of millions of adults is to get, and to keep, as much as they can of the world's goods -- in a nice way, of course -- it is interesting to observe the determination of many parents to "teach" their young children to "share" at the earliest possible moment.

A series of awards was announced yesterday by the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation in the hope of encouraging the more wholesome material for children from radio, television and film producers and the authors of comics and other books.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 -- Yale's Dennis McGill brightened a murky afternoon in the Bowl today by racing through and around Columbia's defenses for four touchdowns as the undefeated Bulldogs routed the Lions, 46 -- 14, before 15,000 drenched onlookers.

May I congratulate you for Miss Samuels' splendid article on the Morningside Heights projects. It is extremely well done and should stimulate many citizens to inquire further on how such an outstanding program can be developed.

IN the fall of 1954, James Cameron of The London News Chronicle made a two-month tour of Communist China. This book is the result. As an analysis of contemporary China it is no world shaker, but it does contain some choice reporting.

Mrs. James H. M. Ewart and Mrs. Duncan Van Norden are co-chairman of the Mayfair Assembly, which will be held on Dec. 16 in the main ballroom of the Ambassador under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller. The Mayfair Assembly is a subscription ball for debutantes, post-debutantes and their escorts.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 8 -- Algeria has been living in a state of nerves since Aug. 20.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP) -- The Air Force appeared today to have fired the first public shot in what could become a battle with the Navy for control of sea-based atomic-powered planes.

The American Press Institute begins its tenth year of operation tomorrow with a two-week seminar fo rmanaging editors and news editors. The meetings will be held in the institute's conference room in the Journalism Building at Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Government and the Communist party are squaring off for another round of a fight that each side proclaims will be to the finish.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Two Long Island Rail Road steam engines chugged into the Hicksville station today -- late for their own retirement. But their tardiness did not dim the enthusiasm of a group of official well-wishers who lined both platforms.
ZOMBA, Nyasaland, Sept. 20 -- Ten years of labor by five priests with no technical training have produced a hydro-power plant and maize mill at a Roman Catholic mission here.
Now that the gardening is finished and the lawn left to its own devices, and before the leaves demand raking, there is a long moment of leisure for questions that demand no answers.
Blind students and other blind adults will be aided by the Nov. 29 performance of "Janus," a comedy starring Margaret Sullavan, Robert Preston and Claude Dauphin at the Plymouth Theatre.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 -- More than half a million United States citizens living abroad are to all intents, disfranchised. Now a move is on foot to do something about it.

THE partnership factor in bidding is understood, in principle, by nearly every bridge player, including the veriest beginner. The correct bid depends not on one's own thirteen cards so much as on the twenty-six cards of the two partners.

The Monmouth County Hunt Racing Association will conduct its annual steeplechase events on Saturday, Oct. 22, in Middletown on the Woodland Farm estate of Amory L. Haskell, president of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club.

TURIN, Italy -- This city takes the tourist by surprise. It may be known as the source of Lenci dolls, Fiat cars and Piedmontese wines, but it is not ordinarily included on an itinerary of Italy's major points of interest.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 8 (AP) -- A sophomore, 194-pound Dick Borstad, paced Minnesota to an 18-7 Big Ten victory over Northwestern today.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 8 -- Missouri voters have approved a new public school foundation plan and a state cigarette tax to help finance it.

BROOKLYN'S Dodgers arrived in the promised land last week. But the New York theatre is destined to continue its wandering. Only the other day there were jubilant reports that the financially powerful Producers Theatre, consisting of Roger L. Stevens, Robert Whitehead and Robert W. Dowling, had opened negotiations for the Globe Theatre, at present a movie emporium and once a mighty fine citadel of the legitimate stage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- As inevitably as the seasons roll around, the wheat farmers in Kansas were busy this week planting the seed for next year's crop of hard red winter wheat.
The Cooper Union Forum, a lecture and concert series that was originated before the Civil War, will begin its ninety-sixth season tomorrow night at the Great Hall, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

RETICENCE is not a quality we normally expect to find in contemporary art and least of all in work by an Italian living in Bologna. Yet reticence is the chief attribute, and indeed the great lure, of Giorgio Morandi's still-lifes, an agreeable little selection of which is now on view at the Delius Gallery.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney said today that a three-day "roundtable" hearing on patents might produce major changes in the nation's patent laws in the next session of Congress.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is scheduled to return to Boston Tuesday as a witness, instead of as an interrogator, in the case of Leon J. Kamin, a research assistant at McGill University.
SWIMMING pool owners north of the Mason-Dixon line should start thinking about measures to protect the pool against winter damage. Generally speaking, there are two schools of thought on winterizing.

THE Crown Colony of Singapore -- a green, prosperous and pleasant little island just north of the Equator and just south of the Malayan Peninsula -- is one of the most strategic and important pieces of real estate between Karachi and Tokyo. It is Southeast Asia's greatest commercial and shipping center.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 8 -- A plan to heal the rift between the American Legion and its fun-making organization, the Forty and Eight Society, was adopted by the society's governing body today.
STARKVILLE, Miss., Oct. 8 (UP) -- Mississippi State set up a touchdown by snaring one loose ball and covered two others today to beat Tulane, 14 -- 0.

Since the end of 1952 farm price support-loans have risen by $6,900,000,000, or at the rate of about $2,600,000,000 a year. Economists are beginning to wonder whether American farm problems may stem from an attempt to give both the mule and the tractor the right-of-way.

The Standard Oil Company (N. J.) was one of the first big American corporations to recognize that it had an obligation to be a good citizen as well as to make money for its stockholders. It has also found that, far from being contradictory, the two policies complement each other.
HARTFORD, Oct. 8 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff is meeting with legislative leaders of both major parties Monday to set a date for a special session of the General Assembly.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed to French Premier Edgar Faure at their Luxembourg meeting last Wednesday to postpone the Oct. 23 referendum in the Saar.
Effective protection of the creations of fashion designers against style pirates has moved a step closer to reality.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 8 -The executive branch took an initial step today toward insuring that the first national elections under the proposed new Constitution would be free and fair. An electoral reforms commission was appointed by Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali.

A SMALL Connecticut town was still burying its dead several days after the flood of last Aug. 19. The first selectman hadn't slept in forty-eight hours. He had roads to reopen and the carcasses of twelve drowned cows to dispose of. People were standing in line to receive typhoid shots.

Fire Prevention Week, which begins today, comes this year at a particularly appropriate moment. For only two weeks ago a conference at a local hotel brought forth the melancholy news that the home had become the greatest potential source of disabling accidents.

THE would-be whistler (and who isn't at the age of 5?) will find in Tootles O'Toole a typical fellow-sufferer who hopefully puckers up for a shrill whee only to produce a disappointing whuh. Tootles wanted to whistle so he could call a dog -- if he had one.

OXFORD, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Dick Stearns of the Wilmette Harbor Fleet, Chicago, sailed his Magic to a 2-point lead over forty-one other Star sailboats after two races of the Eastern shore wind-up regatta today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, an Old Bolshevik, admitted today he had erred on a point of Communist theory.

SEATTLE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Washington furnished one 80-yard stroke of football lightning in the last quarter of a raindrenched game today to upset Southern California, 7 -- 0, and take the lead in the Pacific Coast Conference race.
BUFFALO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Hobart College and Buffalo fought to a scoreless tie today, with Hobart losing a bid for its fifteenth straight football victory since the 1953 season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- Factory employment in Pennsylvania rose 1 per cent during August to a total of 1,064,900 -- highest point since early last year -- the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported. Weekly wage payments also were up 1 per cent and weekly working time was 2 per cent higher.

TRENTON, Oct. 8 -- New Jersey's 567 municipalities spent a record $621,419,000 last year, and their total net indebtedness hit a peak of $371,172,452. Indications are that, in each instance, the trend will continue this year.

HONOLULU -- Eleven sleek outrigger canoes will race across thirty-six miles of choppy open sea to Waikiki Beach next Sunday, and thus Oahu's annual Aloha Week celebration will be launched. During the days that follow, the islanders will revive the splendor of ancient Hawaii in a series of pageants and parades.

BEYOND question, Daniel Boone, by far the country's greatest frontiersman, is currently the most shortchanged hero of American history, which is not exactly the case with one D. Crockett, by far the country's best-selling myth.

Willard C. Gulick of Akron, Ohio, is a man who gets around -- around the world, that is. So far this year he has flown some 96,000 miles and almost a fourth of the year is still ahead of him. Racking up mileage in such figures in his job isn't hard, even though he actually tries to spend half to two-thirds of his working year in Akron.

The teacher shortage is still serious, even though 86,696 qualified candidates received their teaching certificates last June. This is disclosed in the recent 1955 Teacher Supply and Demand Report, prepared by the National Education Association.

A CRUEL rule usually condemns great literary figures whom death has just claimed to wander for two or three decades in a purgatory of oblivion. Some, like Anatole France, never emerge from it. Others, hardly more fortunate, pay a harsh penalty for having cultivated ambiguity, symbolic meaning and metaphysics: over-subtle critics "lie heavy on them" who had laid many a heavy load on the commentators' brains.
The deep freeze that hit the ice industry with the advent of home refrigeration has defrosted. Today's iceman is busier than ever. He supplies ice to industrial, commercial and dom
Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the Casita Maria Fiesta for the benefit of the Casita Maria Settlement House to be held on Nov. 30 at the Ambassador.

Your critic's review of "A View From The Bridge" comes to me as such a shock that I feel I must write this letter. I was at the performance opening night, too, and I find it hard to believe we were in the same theatre, seeing the same plays.

A large subscription has been reported for the benefit performance of "A View From the Bridge" by Arthur Miller at the Coronet Theatre the evening of Oct. 17, Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt has charge of arrangements for the event which will benefit the Park Association of New York City.
The eighty branches of the New York Public Library in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island will be closed Wednesday, Columbus Day.

RELATIVELY short as the history of sound reproduction may be, it runs true to larger tradition in its obsessive tendency to repeat itself. Such recent "novelties" as speed wars, long-playing records and sensationally realistic "demonstrations" are old stories to veteran audiophiles, disillusioning as it must be for the younger generation to learn.
PARIS, Sunday, Oct. 9 -- Premier Edgar Faure obtained the wide approval of the National Assembly early this morning for his program of conciliation and reform in Morocco.

The author of "The Tamarack Tree" has written a delightful new novel called "Shad-Run." Set in the Hudson River Valley, and centering in Poughkeepsie in the year 1788, it is a vigorous, smoothly told story.
NEWARK, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- A multicounty library system is being considered by officials in Wayne, Monroe and Livingston Counties.

There isn't a single commercial atomic-power plant in this country, but there will be half a dozen plants in less than ten years, and at least one in another year. The Atomic ergy Commission saw a real need for a text on the subject, and so it authorized Dr. Samuel Glasstone, one of its consultants, to prepare an 861-page book on "Nuclear Reactor Engineering," which has been published by D. Van Nostrand Co.

BETHLEHEM, Pa. Oct. 8 -- Lehigh University scored its second straight victory today, defeating Bucknell University, 27 -- 20, before 6,500 Parents Day fans in Taylor Stadium. It was the Engineers' sixth triumph over the Bisons in nineteen games.

The issue of colonialism has moved into the forefront of international affairs in the last few weeks. The passions that have been aroused are doing harm on all sides. Those who believe in the peaceful evolution of human affairs must step back and take a calm look.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Whether Mrs. Patrick O'Leary's cow kicked over a lantern or not, Chicago and its historians will never forget the fire that started eighty-four years ago tonight in the O'eary cow barLn at the rear of 137 (now 558) DeKoven Street.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 8 -- The national Woodrow Wilson fellowship program announced today the results of its first decade of recruiting outstanding young men and women for college and university teaching.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Bernie Blaney, speedy halfback, scored twice as Duke turned three fumbles into touchdowns and routed William and Mary, 47 -- 7, today.

MITCHELL WOLFSON, a Southern theatre operator, opened the annual convention of the Theatre Owners of America last Thursday with an address that warned against trying to solve industry problems by legislative methods.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The National Security Training Commission made many recommendations today for the health, welfare and morals of young volunteers in the new Reserve program.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8 -- The requirements for the Dean's Honor List at Yale College have been raised because students are obtaining higher grades than those of earlier generations, it was announced today.

Narcotics addiction will be the subject of a series of monthly conferences to be held this month through next May. The sponsors are Riverside Hospital and the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.

According to Dr. Hans Simons, president of the New School for Social Research, West Germany's workers will soon demand shorter working hours. This, he said, is likely to affect Germany's prosperity, which to a great extent is based on the export of economically produced goods.

CAMP FRIEDLAND, West Germany, Oct. 8 -- Adolf Hitler's personal pilot said tonight that he saw the Nazi dictator and his wife, Eva Braun, commit suicide in April, 1945, as Russian troops neared their Berlin bomb shelter.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Cotton and wool manufacturers are worried over foreign competition, which may be worse next year as a result of tariff talks scheduled to begin in January. There is no doubt, in the opinion of most textile executives in this area, that synthetics are making progressively greater inroads into the use of natural fibres and this trend is likely to continue.

The United Seamen's Service, 39 Broadway, announced last week it would seek funds this fall from the port's maritime industry. The agency, serving United States seamen in fifteen foreign ports, is seeking $250,000 in a nation-wide appeal.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Six Union County municipalities will have local referendums Nov. 8 in addition to the water supply bond question, which will be a state-wide issue.

TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- An agreement by which United States film companies eventually will be enabled to send home money earned here by American films was said today by a local trade publication to have been worked out with the Japanese Government.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7 -- Yale University dedicated its new eleven story student residential center, the Edward S. Harkness Memorial Hall yesterday in a brief ceremony attended by more than 300 faculty members and students.

As our school year gains momentum there is an increasingly sharp appraisal of our educational problems. We are trying to provide more classrooms, more teachers and more funds. We are trying to make it easier for the gifted student to get the schooling of which he can take best advantage.

LIKE so many recent good books on Black Africa, this one is unblushingly in the first person. Yet this is not merely the story of a young American from the London School of Economics who went out to Uganda to try to help some Uganda Negroes make a success of an agricultural cooperative.

FOR creditable reasons Arthur Miller has deliberately under-written the two one-act plays that are now on the stage of the Coronet. Believing in the dramatic values of the material, he has tried to let the plays tell their own stories.

Engineering education has reached an age of functional maturity and henceforth must ally itself more closely to science to deal successfully with the technological future, the president of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn said yesterday.

BOURED, French Morocco, Oct. 8 -- The new French Defense Minister called at this scarred and burned outpost of the French protectorate today to promise that he would send all the forces necessary to restore peace in the Riff of Morocco.

OTIS BARTON'S development of a deep-diving sphere -- and its use by William Beebe under the auspices of the New York Zoological Society to reach an undersea depth of over 3,000 feet -- marked the beginning of man's conquest of the last unknown part of his world.

ALREADY well known in a previous English translation, "Poet in New York" has been carefully interpreted anew by Ben Belitt. Federico Garcia Lorca suffered a grave mishap on arriving in New York in 1929. He found himself in a friendly, plain, cordial, expressive, and at the same time inaccessible city.
" The United Nations cannot achieve its purpose unless the peoples of the world are fully informed of its aims and activities." -- General Assembly resolution, 1946.
Wide efforts are under way to re-examine the ideas of the late President Woodrow Wilson as a living force.
Institutions of higher education soon will need more than $3,000,000,000 for new student housing facilities, in the opinion of an official of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 8 -Britain's Prime Minister warned the Soviet Union today it was increasing the dangers of war in the Middle East by permitting Czechoslovakia to supply arms to Egypt.

ALTHOUGH he is not ignoring the tumult and shouting for "Oklahoma!" which reaches a final crescendo this week, Fred Zinnemann, its noted director, appears ready to embark on a new and important film venture.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- United States policy toward the Middle East was virtually at a standstill today with a drastic reappraisal in prospect.

EVER since viewing William Wyler's new thriller, "The Desperate Hours," which is based on the popular novel and stage play of Joseph Hayes, this reviewer's thoughts have been buzzing with a genuine anxiety.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Injury-ridden Iowa struck for three first-half touchdowns and then held on to defeat Indiana, 20 -- 6. A Dad's Day crowd of 51.976 saw the game in sunny Iowa Stadium today.

TO an average Englishman the name "Courtauld" is perhaps connected with the manufacture of rayon or artificial silk. Or, if you ask him if he has ever heard of the Samuel Courtauld collection, he will shake his head vaguely or guess that, like a good many rich manufacturers, Mr. Courtauld must have amused himself by buying works of art to furnish his London house during his lifetime and bequeathe to the nation after his death.
" * * * one nation under God, indivisible * * *." Great words through which every Ameri can has pledged allegiance.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 5 -- The Ford Foundation and universities of southern India began an adventure in publishing today. For the first time this book-hungry country will have an industry for the large-scale manufacture of inexpensive books.
The problem was to sell thick, hot corned beef sandwich on fresh rye bread, with mustard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The beginning of the end of United States foreign aid activities in Europe is expected to result from a survey now being made by John B. Hollister, director of the International Cooperation Administration. A retrenchment is planned for Asia, too.

A DEBUT disk is Charles De Forest's Daydreams and Nightdreams (Version). Mr. De Forest is a young singer whose debt to Frank Sinatra is evident, especially in numbers with a strong rhythmic beat -- What Is This Thing Called Love and By Myself reveal it on this disk.

LAKE PLEASANT, N. Y. -- We have never disagreed with the hearty deep-in-halers who argue that autumn around here is the best time of the year. Likely it is. We have even been quick to concede that a nip in the air makes one want to get out and go.

The retail dollar volume of board games is expected to reach $100,000,000 this year, a record amount and about a 15 per cent increase over last year's figure, according to industry spokesmen. The outlook for the Christmas season is excellent and sales probably will be the best in the history of the industry, according to Robert B. M. Barton, president of Parker Brothers, Salem, Mass.

New York City has a multi-million-dollar stake in approval by the state's voters next month of a proposed amendment permitting cities to finance pollution control projects outside their constitutional debt limits.
